title: An 11-Hour Cleanup Of Asbestos in Brooklyn

title: Suffolk Legislature Orders Lilco Takeover on Ballot
description: In a slap at Gov. George E. Pataki, the Suffolk County Legislature voted today to authorize a November referendum on his plan for the state to take over the Long Island Lighting Company's electricity service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABZUG, BELLA
description: ABZUG-Bella. The National Women's Political Caucus of New York State mourns the death of Bella Abzug, our leader in the fight for women's rights. As we celebrate the 150th anniversary of the Women's Rights Movement, Bella will be remembered as our history and our strength.

title: The Genesis Of an Idea?
description: Last week JAMES CAMERON proclaimed himself ''king of the world'' as he collected three Oscars for ''Titanic.'' But he also tried to strike a more somber note by instructing the audience that night to observe a moment of silence for the people who died when the supposedly unsinkable ship sank in 1912.

title: TRESCOM REJECTS HIGHER BID FROM IDT FOR PRIMUS'S OFFER
description: The IDT Corporation said yesterday that it had bid $10.50 a share in cash for Trescom International Inc., but Trescom said it would proceed instead with a lower offer from Primus Telecommunications Group IDT provides long-distance phone services. Primus provides long-distance services in North America, Europe and the Asia-Pacific region. Trescom, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., provides long-distance services in the Caribbean and Central and South America. Trescom was not specific about why it turned down IDT's $125 million offer. It agreed on Feb. 4 to Primus's offer of $10 a share in stock, or $118.9 million. Trescom's shares rose $1.125, to $10.1875. Shares of IDT fell 50 cents, to $37.50, while Primus fell $1, to $29.

title: Despite Clash, Giuliani Reappoints Campaign Finance Chief
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that he was reappointing the chairman of the city's Campaign Finance Board, saying that while he objected to the way the board had treated his re-election campaign last year, he was generally pleased with its performance.

title: Clinton Seeking Wide Privileges In Starr Inquiry
description: Taking an expansive view of executive privilege in the Monica Lewinsky investigation, White House lawyers have argued in secret court proceedings that it can be invoked by officials other than President Clinton and that it protects conversations between aides and Hillary Rodham Clinton, lawyers involved in the inquiry said today.

description: Despite the politically charged atmosphere that has surrounded the Crown Heights case from the beginning, those who know Judge David G. Trager well say that the severe sentence he handed down yesterday reflected his independent assessment of the crime.

title: By the Book; Southeast Asia in Color and Taste
description: PLENTY of cookbooks make up for what they lack in photogenic splash with page after page of alluring, reliable, delicious recipes that are meant to be enjoyed on the plate, not vicariously in a picture. ''Mark Peel and Nancy Silverton at Home'' (Warner Books, 1994) and ''A French Chef Cooks at Home'' (Simon & Schuster, 1975), by Jacques Pepin, may not be much to look at, but there is a good reason why they sit near my stove, dog-eared and stained.

title: RUBBERMAID TO SELL BRANDS TO DECORA FOR $62.5 MILLION
description: Rubbermaid Inc. agreed yesterday to sell its Con-Tact adhesive paper and other shelf-liner brands to Decora Industries, for $62.5 million in cash as it focuses on its main plastic products business. Decora, based in Fort Edward, N.Y., developed the top-selling Con-Tact paper in 1952 and makes it under an agreement with Rubbermaid. The sale includes the Grip-Liner and Shelf Liner brands, rights to shelf space in stores and certain production equipment, Decora said. Decora plans to pay $57.5 million at the closing and $5 million in the next nine months. Decora posted $41 million in sales in the 1997 fiscal year, while the Rubbermaid unit had $70 million in revenue.

A holiday that Jews have treasured for millenniums, celebrating it at home with the highly ritualized dinner, the seder, is becoming for many one more special occasion in a restaurant, another reason to dine out.

title: Hospitals Aren't Candid On Poor Care, A Study Says
description: New York City hospitals are vastly underreporting cases of poor care, which can mean anything from a wrongful death to an infection caused by a doctor with dirty hands, according to a study to be released today by Public Advocate Mark Green.

title: Political Memo; Bold and Brassy, She Defined The Combative New Yorker
description: It was impossible to miss Bella S. Abzug at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago in 1996. Even in the tumult that was the New York delegation -- and even from the diminished perch of her wheelchair -- Bella Abzug was at the center of it all, bellowing at delegates and reporters, signing autographs, and waving at the strangers who traveled across a floor of celebrities just to get a glimpse of the woman from New York.

title: Plan to Toughen Drunken Driving Laws Suffers Blow in House
description: A proposal to toughen drunken driving laws around the country was dealt a serious blow tonight after a House panel voted to squelch the measure by keeping it from a vote on the floor.

title: For Middle Class, New York Shrinks as Home Prices Soar
description: Todd Neuhaus, an advertising executive, and his wife, Christina, didn't want much. They wanted to rent a Manhattan apartment for less than $3,000 with a bedroom for themselves and one for their two boys. They wanted it to be near good public schools, because private school was beyond their means.

title: Mayor Defies Bar Association And Reappoints Queens Judge
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday reappointed a Family Court judge from Queens to a 10-year term, defying a recommendation by the city's bar association that the judge's temperament made her unfit for the bench.

description: In an unusual case pitting a claim of defamation against defense of academic freedom, a labor relations professor at Cornell University is being sued for slander by the nation's largest nursing home company.

title: Bella Abzug
description: People who knew Bella Abzug tended to describe her in terms of decibels. Her approach, heard from afar, somehow sounded like the rumble of a tank battalion on the move. Up close, it posed a definite threat to all the glass objects in proximity. Ms. Abzug, a leader of the feminist and anti-war movements in the 1970's, was a pioneer, and pioneers often have to shout so that those who follow can enjoy the right to modulated tones. But her pitch was also a measure of her intensity. Bella Abzug yelled, one friend said, because she took every conversation seriously.

title: Hong Kong Cuts Back Land Sale Program
description: Hong Kong's government cut the amount of land it will release for development in the next five years by 8 percent in the wake of a slump in property prices. The Planning, Environment and Lands Secretary, Bowen Leung, said 400 hectares (almost 1,000 acres) would be sold to developers in the next five years, down from 433 hectares the government had earlier said it would release.

title: German Plane Found at Fault In Collision With Air Force Jet
description: The German troop transport that collided head on with an Air Force cargo jet off the coast of Africa last September, killing 33, was cruising at the wrong altitude, the Pentagon said today.

description: By arrogantly preventing a vote on campaign finance reform this week, Newt Gingrich so angered fair-minded lawmakers that they are now rallying to the cause of cleaner elections. Supporters of an overhaul of fund-raising laws were gathering more signatures yesterday for a drive to bring remedial legislation to the House floor in defiance of the Republican leadership. They have 190 names, 28 short of the number needed. Many more House members favor revising the law in principle. Now is the time for them to sign up.

description: Ralph Kiner, an original Mets broadcaster, announced on the air yesterday that he has been suffering from Bell's palsy for the last three months and was recovering. But the condition, which causes temporary facial paralysis, impaired his voice during the six innings he worked during the Mets' opening day telecast on Fox Sports New York.

title: A Dated War, a Modern Peace
description: Now that virtually all wars are internal conflicts, most of them ethnic or religious, the hostilities between Peru and Ecuador are a throwback. Their clash, which last erupted in 1995, was the last time the armies of any two governments fought each other. Since 1942 Peru and Ecuador have gone to war three times over border areas that both claim. Now, however, this traditional war may be coming to a very modern end, since the two countries have agreed on the outlines of a peace treaty that would set up trade, commerce and joint access to the disputed land that started the war.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about drugs to treat impotence misstated the major side effects of one drug in advanced trials. The drug, an alprostadil gel being developed by the Macrochem Corporation, may cause minor local warmth but has no reported systemic side effects. It has not been reported to cause nausea, flushing, loss of appetite or yawning and stretching.

description: Malaysia's central bank said yesterday that all 39 of the nation's finance companies had agreed to merge or to be acquired by their parent companies, meeting the deadline to arrange combinations. The central bank set the target date for consolidation three months ago in an effort to shore up finance companies against increasing bad debts and a slowing economy.

description: Channel One, the 12-minute news program that is broadcast daily to eight million students, costs $1.8 billion a year in classroom time, including $300 million for its two minutes of commercials, a study by the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee has found.

In ''Ghost on Fire,'' a poignant play suffused with humor, Mr. Weller writes their requiem.

title: SLH TO PAY $535 MILLION FOR ALL OF SYNTROLEUM
description: The SLH Corporation agreed yesterday to pay $535 million in stock to acquire the shares it does not already own of the Syntroleum Corporation, a provider of a potentially valuable technology that transforms natural gas into oil products. The shares of SLH jumped $4, to $32. The SLH Corporation, based in Shawnee Mission, Kan., is a venture-capital concern whose interests include real estate and energy. It already owned 31 percent of Syntroleum. Syntroleum's technology transforms natural gas into easily transportable oil products like home heating oil. Upon closing, SLH's shareholders will own 34 percent of the combined company, which will be renamed Syntroleum.

It's very efficient, too: the egg yolks that are separated and set aside while making the baked meringue disks are used in the sabayon, and so is the poaching liquid for the pears. There's no waste.

title: Scavenging For Humanity Amid Cruelty

The place is an ugly, sprawling heap of bombed-out rubble crisscrossed with trenches and littered with discarded vehicles. The desolation is so pervasive that you wonder how people can survive in such a place. And yet they do. Just barely.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCNALLY, FRANK
description: McNALLY-Frank. Retired vice president and treasurer of Ethyl Corporation, naval aviator, attorney, native of Bal Harbor, New York, died Monday, March 30 at his home in Southern Shores, North Carolina. Mr. McNally was eighty one. He is survived by his wife of fifty-five years, Eleanor Holland McNally; ten children; 26 grandchildren, & four nieces and 2 nephews. Mr. McNally graduated from Xavier High School, Manhattan College, Columbia Law School, and the Advanced Management Program at Harvard. He served as a naval aviator during World War II. Following his service in World War II, he worked briefly at the SEC before joining Ethyl Corporation in 1946. He retired in 1982 following a thirty-eight year career in finance and tax at Ethyl Corporation. Mr. McNally was a member of Friendly Sons of St. Patrick of New York and also a member of the 3rd Order of St. Francis, the Amackassin Tennis Club of Yonkers, New York where he was the singles champion for three years, and a former president of the Colts Boys Club of Yonkers, where he coached basketball and football. He was a resident of 50 Greystone Park in North Yonkers for 19 years prior to moving to Richmond, Virginia when Ethyl Corporation relocated there. Mr. McNally was the son of Frank McNally and Lillian Perry McNally, and the brother of Dorothea Petrie, who predeceased him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARE, MONTGOMERY
description: HARE-Montgomery. Born August 21, 1911 in New York City. He died at age 87 on March 28, 1998, at his home in Cornwall, Connecticut, where he and his family have lived since 1940. Mr. Hare grew up in Saint James, Long Island, New York, and in Lenox, Massachusetts; and New York City. He graduated from Groton School, class of 1929 and Yale University, class of 1933.In 1938 he married Mary Potter Sturges. She died in 1990. In February of 1996 he married Alida White Lessard. Mr. Hare was also instrumental in many planning and zoning issues in Cornwall. He was an environmentalist long before the environment became an issue. For example, he collected DDT residue samples from the brooks in Cornwall in the 1950's as part of a study that led to restrictions on its use. His long life is best summarized by his love of the land. It kept him continuously involved in conservation groups. He was a founder of the Housatonic Valley Association, and served it as a director and president for many years. In his work with the Association, he was a leader in the preservation of many tracts of land along the Housatonic, including, for example, several miles of the river's undeveloped west bank and the adjoining ridge from Cornwall to Kent. During his lifetime, Mr. Hare was a reporter, playwright, producer, poet, and painter. He wrote and directed plays for the famous Barter Theatre in Virginia during its heyday in the late 40's. He was a conscientious objector at a time when very few men were. He was deeply involved in the community of Cornwall, serving for many as a very well remembered Sunday School teacher, Deacon, and director of the Christmas Pageant in the First Churchof Christ Congregational in Cornwall. Mr. Hare is survived by his wife, Alida Hare; his 4 children, Meredith Burke of Ipswich, Massachussetts, Patrick Hare of Cornwall, Connecticut, Robert Hare of Kingston, New York, and Constance Hare of Montpelier, Vermont. He also is survived by six stepdaughters, eight grandchildren, and two great grandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, CECIL
description: JOHNSON-Cecil. A resident of Las Cruces, N.M. since 1995, died March 31 at the Good Samaritan Nursing Home, at the age of 96. Mr. Johnson, a Fellow of the Royal College of Engineering, was born in London, England, August 5th, 1901. Following his graduation from Dulwich College, he went to India as a nineteen year-old engineer in the employ of Babcock & Wilcox, Ltd. Fourteen years later, he was responsible for all the company's interests in Asia and was based in Shanghai, China where he numbered among his friends such personalities as Herbert Hoover, Wallace Simpson, and Two-Gun Cohen, a general in the Chinese Nationalist Army. Mr. Johnson was an accomplished pianist, raconteur, and polo-player, and an enthusiastic race-horse owner. He was also a man of conviction and daring who, before his internment in a Japanese prisoner-of-war camp in Shanghai in 1942, managed to sabotage Babcock & Wilcox power plants to prevent their being used in the Japanese war effort. During his 3- 1/2 years in the Japanese camp he served as the elected representative of his fellow prisoners in all dealings with their captors. Following the Communist takeover in 1949, Mr. Johnson successfully negotiated the release of all B&W employees who were held hostage by the Communists. In 1958, Mr. Johnson and his wife, Marjorie, returned to England, where they lived until Mrs. Johnson's death in 1966. In 1983, Mr. Johnson joined his only child, Cecilia, in New York where he led a full and active life until 1993, when he suffered a stroke. Even then he continued to display the virtues of an Aristotelian gentleman -courtesy, magnanimity, and courage. He and his daughter moved to New Mexico in 1995. Mr. Johnson's death is deeply mourned by his daughter, Cecilia, and her husband, Alexis Bespaloff. His good will and joie de vivre will be missed by the friends he continued to make throughout his life. By his wishes, his remains were cremated. The date has not yet been set for a memorial service to be held in New York.

title: TORONTO-DOMINION IN $100 MILLION DEAL FOR JACK WHITE
description: Moving to expand its discount brokerage operations in the United States, the Toronto-Dominion Bank said yesterday that its Waterhouse Investor Services Inc. unit had agreed to acquire the closely held Jack White & Company for about $100 million. Toronto-Dominion Bank, based in Toronto, is a Canadian chartered bank. In 1996 it bought Waterhouse Investor, based in New York, in a move to expand its United States discount brokerage operations. Waterhouse has 128 branches. The purchase of Jack White & Company, a discount brokerage firm based in San Diego, will increase Waterhouse's active account base by about 15 percent and add an additional $12 billion in client assets, Toronto-Dominion said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMBERTSEN, ELEANOR C., ED.D., R.N.
description: LAMBERTSEN-Eleanor C., Ed.D., R.N. The New York and Presbyterian Hospital & the Divisions of Nursing are deeply saddened by the passing of our beloved friend and dear colleague Eleanor Lambertsen. She served as Dean of the Cornell University New York Hospital School of Nursing from 1970 to 1979 and as Senior Associate Director of Nursing Service at The New York Hospital from 1974 to 1982. A national and international leader in the field of nursing, Dr. Lambertsen's pioneering work in patient care delivery has been used as a model throughout the world. Many of her publications were translated for use abroad. Dr. Lambertsen held innumerable appointed positions in nursing organizations and served on a number of boards and advisory committees. She was a member of the Surgeon General's Consultant Group which spearheaded the first Nurse Training Act, a source of significant federal funding for nursing education, and a member of the 1971 federal advisory group which called for significant increased authority for nursing practitioners. We mourn the loss of this dynamic educator and spokesperson for nursing, who leaves a legacy of scholarship and dedication. She was much loved and will be greatly missed. Our sincere condolences are extended to her family. David B. Skinner, M.D. Vice Chairman and CEO William T. Speck, M.D. President and COO Doris M. Glick, R.N. Vice President, Nursing Darlene L. Cox, R.N. Vice Pres., Patient Care Services The New York and Presbyterian Hospital

The implication must be that we have all learned our lessons; it will never happen again.

The release is part of an agreement by the United States last month to drop sponsorship of a resolution condemning China's human rights policies.

description: A United Nations special investigator today rejected charges by the Scientology movement that the German Government is using Nazi tactics of persecution and ill treatment against it.

title: There Is No Buying the Time
description: Would you believe that in return for a contribution from a brewery, the official time in Britain would be known as Guinness Mean Time, rather than Greenwich Mean Time? The Financial Times, Britain's leading financial newspaper, reported on Tuesday that Guinness P.L.C. would sponsor the Old Royal Observatory in Greenwich, and as a result of that sponsorship, the name Guinness Mean Time would be used throughout 1999, in the run-up to millennium celebrations.

title: With a Tune About Garlic, Having Fun With Salsa
description: Fatal Mambo, a raucous salsa band from France, is a joke group, a Sha Na Na for salsa. The band performed at S.O.B.'s on Monday night, supporting a new album, ''Fatal Mambo'' (Tinder), and it poured irony over the music. While its work as a joke band is mildly interesting, that it exists at all suggests how far Latin culture is making itself felt internationally.

title: Ah, the Hiss of Yesteryear: Audio Buffs Look Back
description: IN ARTY neighborhoods like the Lower East Side in Manhattan and Silverlake in Los Angeles, the future becomes the past with unimaginable speed. Fashions change overnight, and what is new one day is old the next and back in as retro on the third. These shifts in taste and attention have always applied to clothes, hair and philosophies of art. Now technology is in the mix.

The European Union's 20-member executive body unanimously voted to step up pressure on the French Government, signaling its increasing frustration at the rising cost of Europe's most expensive bailout.

title: Trout Season Heats Up in a Hurry
description: Call it a warped sense of tradition, but to me New York State's opening day of trout season, held yesterday in June-like conditions, just didn't feel right without the usual mass suffering. With most rivers running 20 degrees above their normal early-spring temperatures, anglers lounged in shirt sleeves as birds sang and clouds of hatching insects filled the air.

She died of a heart attack at the Spring National Championships in Reno, Nev., last week after a happy day playing with one of her favorite partners. She was 51.

title: UNITED AIRLINES EXPECTS REVENUE LOSSES LINKED TO ASIA
description: United Airlines, a unit of the UAL Corporation, said yesterday that its revenue for the first quarter and all of 1998 might fall below expectations as a result of reduced business in Asia. The Chicago-based airline asked employees in a phone message to cut costs to save money and said it must find more ways to make up the lost revenue. Asia's economic problems have led to reduced demand for air travel. United's Asia passenger traffic fell 11.5 percent in January and February. Route changes and low fuel costs have allowed United to save some money. To add to revenue, it recently asked its sales force to make up an additional $200 million in countries outside Asia. UAL shares fell $2.6875, to $90.25.

The object of this game is to breed, raise and train virtual monsters and then pit them against rival monsters in the ring. It's a cross between a Tamagotchi, an Ultimate Fighting contest and the Westminster dog show.

title: PUTTING DREAMS TO THE TEST: A special report; Elite High School Is a Grueling Exam Away

The most recent test one icy winter day -- with scores released just last month -- was, as usual, full of held-back tears, stomachaches and dreams.

Mr. Feinstein has at his fingertips literally hundreds of Gershwin songs, complete with alternative verses, historical footnotes and anecdotal lore. And at Rainbow and Stars, where he is performing a rare cabaret engagement through April 25, the singer and pianist is offering a centennial tribute (to George Gershwin) that strikes a delightful balance between the familiar and the esoteric.

title: INTEGRATED HEALTH SELLS 5 NURSING HOMES TO OMEGA
description: Integrated Health Services Inc. said yesterday that it had sold five nursing homes to the real estate investment trust Omega Healthcare Investors Inc. of Ann Arbor, Mich., for $50 million to pay down debt. The nursing homes are being leased for 13 years to the closely held joint venture Lyric Healthcare L.L.C., which hired Integrated Health of Owings Mills, Md., to operate them. Integrated Health will receive management and franchise fees of 4 percent of revenue and an incentive fee based on excess operating cash flow. Integrated Health expects to sell more facilities and secure contracts managing them. In a similar transaction by the three companies in February, Integrated Health sold five nursing homes to Omega for $45.5 million.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Tuesday about a group of parents, teachers and administrators protesting charter schools in New Jersey described the financing for the privately run schools incompletely. For each student enrolled, a charter school receives 90 percent of what the public school district would have spent on that student. These funds include state aid as well as money raised through local taxes. The charter schools are not financed solely by state aid.

Still, much of the meeting will be devoted to a discussion of issues that are challenging the industry even during one of its most upbeat eras.

title: Public Eye; Vintage Knoll Preserved
description: THE Harry Bertoia diamond chair in my living room was conceived about the time I was, in 1952. I've seen the Bertoia chair in many places: in corporate offices, at Paley Park, in antiques stores, in a new Rockport shoe advertisement. But it also inhabits museums, among them the Knoll Museum, which quietly opened last fall in East Greenville, Pa.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MASON, GEORGE PERLEY
description: MASON-George Perley 67. Died in Cancun, Mexico, March 1, 1998. A memorial service will be held for family, friends, and employees Friday, April 3, at 5:30 P.M. in The Church of Saint Peter, 16 Barclay St., Manhattan. A native of Brooklyn and veteran of the Korean War, Mr. Mason was a graduate of Seton Hall University and a Certified Public Accountant. For the past seventeen years, he served as Chairman and CEO of Panache Resources & Systems Corporation in Jersey City. Mr. Mason divided his time among family and friends in New York, Rhode Island, and Virginia, where he maintained separate residences. He is survived by two sons, three daughters, and three grandchildren. Donations to honor his longstanding commitment to education may be made to: Seton Hall University, College Scholarship Fund, 400 South Orange Avenue, South Orange, New Jersey 07079.

title: Yakking It Up While Peering at the Grave
description: What's so funny? Why are people at the Golden Theater laughing with such childlike happiness? The images up there onstage are of an unconditional bleakness: a gray, bombed-out-looking room inhabited by a gray, bombed-out-looking man and woman, clearly in their twilight years in an expiring universe. The conversation, which rambles into gibberish, smacks of senility and delusion, and the overall effect is of a world stripped of God, meaning and even memory. And that's entertainment?

description: NOT all dinosaurs were stupid, and not all of them are dead. Sony's Betamax, for instance, lives on. The video cassette recording and playback technology that Sony put in permanent ''pause'' mode in 1988 still has a devoted following and, thanks to the Internet, a number of lively forums where die-hards can swap technical tips, spare parts and commiseration.

Women's Wear Daily, the chronicler of the style scene, did not find even one dress wonderful enough or bizarre enough to splash across its cover as it had done in the past. It was a phenomenon reflected this week in the collections of two designers to the stars, Richard Tyler, the long-time show business dresser, and Randolph Duke, the new Hollywood upstart designing for Halston.

description: In a historic judgment on the role that French administrators in German-occupied territory played in the Holocaust in World War II, a court today found Maurice Papon, a career French civil servant, guilty in the arrest and deportation of Jews in World War II. He was sentenced to 10 years in prison.

description: Expanding its banking business in the Midwest, the Union Planters Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Ambanc Corporation for $30 a share, a total of $211 million. Ambanc, based in Vincennes, Ind., is the parent of Ambank Indiana N.A. and Ambank Illinois N.A. With this deal and other pending acquisitions, Union Planters will have assets of $29 billion, ranking it among the top 30 United States banks. It is based in Memphis and has other offices in seven other states. Union Planters will exchange 0.4841 share for each share of Ambanc. Shares of Ambanc fell 75 cents, to $29. Shares of Union Planters fell 56.25 cents, to $61.625.

description: ON a bright, chilly morning last month, I joined a small group of my neighbors who had gathered just south of Kent, Conn., chain saws and loppers in hand, to face down a threat to one of the prettiest landscapes in New England. Known locally as the ''southern gateway'' to the Berkshires, this particular stretch of Route 7 winds lazily along the Housatonic River between Bulls Bridge and Kent, threading a well-ironed quilt of cornfields and hedgerows that meets the wooded Litchfield hills in a gratifyingly sharp crease. This flat, rich bottomland has been under cultivation since pre-Colonial times, having been first cleared and planted by the Schaghticoke Indians.

description: New York City has reached a tentative settlement with Hasidic residents of Crown Heights in a lawsuit involving the 1991 racial violence there, community leaders and lawyers familiar with the case said yesterday. Mr. Escovedo was also backed by cello, violin, second guitar and accordion, instruments so portable that halfway through his set, he and his band left the stage to perform unamplified in the middle of the club. title: Editorial Observer; Anonymous No More: As Addicts Go Public

I didn't want to miss the cocktail hour the night before. I told no one but my wife and daughter where I was going. I just disappeared. I paid Delta with a credit card, and my medical insurance paid for the drug treatment and rehabilitation center. I wasn't about to tell anyone that I was going there.

The Pentagon, for instance, cannot find a $1 million missile launcher, or a $460,000 floating crane that, like the missile launcher, should be hard to miss. Some departments have not allotted nearly enough for pension obligations, while others have greatly underestimated the costs of environmental cleanups.

Lycos makes its money by providing advertising space on its Web site and licensing its search technology to other companies.

description: The stock of the computer retailer CompUSA Inc. plunged 19 percent yesterday after the company reported only a slight sales gain and said it saw no increase in the coming quarter. CompUSA fell $5.125, to $21. The Dallas-based retailer said its comparable-store sales -- sales in 122 stores that have been open at least a year -- were up 1.2 percent in its third quarter, which ended on March 28. Over all, its sales rose 14 percent. But it said it was disappointed with the performance and cautioned that it saw no gain in the fourth quarter. CompUSA operates 150 computer superstores in 68 markets around the country.

Actually, this decline dates back to the Fourth Republic (1944-58), or perhaps the Third (1871-1940). As for visions, France has always had a logjam of them. It is not lack of vision that hamstrings the country, but a surfeit of aborted aspirations.

Mr. Hyde was beloved at FIT and in the menswear industry nationwide. FIT will hold a memorial in late April. Call 212-217-7705 for details.

description: The Mets won the argument. Then they nearly won the game.

title: Sadly Loping Along, With Brief Snatches of Euphoria
description: Neil Greenberg has claimed a spot for himself in American modern dance of the 1990's by imaginatively addressing the vast subject of time. His odd vocabulary of movement -- loping, galumphing, looping and sequences of steps called triplets -- has become a personal style. But there was a distracting lack of clarity to the trilogy, the first of two programs, that Mr. Greenberg presented on Tuesday night at Playhouse 91.

title: Ex-Teammate Calls Messier Source of Canucks' Troubles
description: Gino Odjick, who was traded from Vancouver to the Islanders two weeks ago, yesterday blamed Mark Messier for the Canucks' dismal season.

description: There is no physical attribute more appealing to Ahn, the bullheaded, 10-year-old heroine of ''Golden Child,'' than big feet. As a daughter in a wealthy family in the China of 1918, she has been forced to undergo the brutal ritual of foot-binding, a ''beautifying'' process so excruciating that she walks as if perpetually stepping on hot coals.

title: Seven Shops Join Qualcomm Review
description: Qualcomm Inc. has named seven agencies to participate in a review for the account of its consumer products division, which markets wireless digital telephones. Billings were not disclosed, but trade publications estimated them at $20 million.

title: TV's Toddlers Take the Stage
description: Adults who sigh over the likes of George Clooney and Calista Flockhart may be surprised to learn that one of the biggest stars on television isn't the least bit sexy (although he is scantily clad) and doesn't get millions of dollars an episode.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REISCH, ELSIE
description: REISCH-Elsie. Our loving and devoted aunt and sister-in-law will be missed by Fran, Linda, Lois and Uncle Manny. Our love and deep condolences to all of Elsie's family, especially Norman, Joan, Barbara and Aunt Sally. The Rosenblatt Family

title: On My Mind; Land for Something
description: In the years of negotiations between Israelis and Palestinians, two labels became popular around the world -- ''Peace Now'' and ''Land for Peace.'' As concepts, both failed.

title: Topics of the Times; Right Man for a Tough Job
description: Washington may be having trouble reforming the country's campaign finance laws, but in New York City, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani made sure the basically sound system would stay that way by reappointing the Rev. Joseph O'Hare as head of the Campaign Finance Board.

title: Disinterest Bothers Calipari
description: With the season winding down and every game, perhaps every possession, vital, John Calipari was looking for a sign, even in defeat, that his team was up to the challenge. But instead, what Calipari saw was disappointing and distressing.

title: Both Houses Approve Campaign Funds Limit
description: A measure that would make Connecticut the second state in the country to stop national political parties from funneling millions of dollars of unregulated campaign funds into state races was unanimously approved by the State Senate yesterday, a week after passing the House. Gov. John G. Rowland has said he will sign it.

title: 4 Salvadorans Say They Killed U.S. Nuns on Orders of Military
description: After 17 years of silence, all four of the former national guardsmen convicted of killing three American nuns and a lay worker in 1980 have said for the first time that they acted only after receiving ''orders from above.''

title: Ruling Upholds Legality of Fordham Radio Tower
description: New York State's highest court today upheld a New York City zoning decision that would allow Fordham University to build a 480-foot radio tower in the Bronx over the objections of its neighbor, the New York Botanical Garden.

title: Miranda Rule Benefits Police, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: Finding No Fault In an Old Kitchen
description: In the grill room at the Four Seasons, there was the nonstop glitz that was a book party for LIZ TILBERIS, the editor of Harper's Bazaar, while around the corner in the pool room, a quieter celebration was in progress: GEORGE LANG, the restaurateur, was having a book party for his memoir, ''Nobody Knows the Truffles I've Seen.'' It has been some years since Mr. Lang was associated with the Four Seasons. (Cafe Des Artistes, Mr. Lang's present restaurant, is undergoing renovation.) ''I have a many-layered past, as my book indicates, and this is just one of my layers,'' Mr. Lang said.

title: Topics of the Times; A Verdict on Vichy
description: Maurice Papon, the third-ranking official of the Gironde region in Nazi-occupied France, was sentenced by a Bordeaux court yesterday to 10 years for complicity in crimes against humanity -- the illegal arrest and deportation of Jews, almost all of whom were later killed. At the age of 87, Mr. Papon is the first high-ranking Vichy official to be tried since just after World War II, and is likely to be the last. The symbolism of his conviction is important.

title: The Mayor vs. the BID's
description: One of the engines of New York City's renaissance has been the business improvement districts. The BID's have been responsible for much of the cleanliness, improved security and revitalized spirit of commercial areas in all five boroughs. But now Mayor Rudolph Giuliani appears determined to emasculate the BID's by limiting their ability to plan and advocate on behalf of their members. This is a puzzling development that seems to go counter to Mr. Giuliani's own vision of government.

title: Suspects Seen But No Pattern In 14 Killings Of Women
description: A new Essex County task force began delving today into the slayings of 14 black women over the last five years in the Newark area, as law enforcement officials acknowledged that they needed to work harder to solve the cases of murdered women.

title: Judge Orders Prosecutors' Secret Memo Released in Mob Case
description: Defense lawyers in a highly publicized Mafia case in Manhattan will be allowed to have copies of the prosecution's confidential strategy memorandum that the Federal Government accidentally placed into the public record, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Friday about a meeting of a Roman Catholic-Jewish committee after the publication of the Vatican document on the Holocaust referred imprecisely to Pope Pius XII. He was not yet Pope in 1937 when, as Vatican Secretary of State, he helped write a condemnation of Nazism; the condemnation was issued by his predecessor, Pope Pius XI.

title: Oxford to Withhold Remainder of Ex-Chairman's Severance
description: Under pressure from Gov. George E. Pataki and the New York State Insurance Department, Oxford Health Plans agreed yesterday to withhold the rest of a $9 million severance package it had planned to pay its former chairman, Stephen F. Wiggins. The company has already paid Mr. Wiggins $3.6 million in cash from that package.

title: Girl Convicted In Park Killing Is Sent to Prison
description: Daphne Abdela, the 15-year-old who pleaded guilty last month to manslaughter for the part she played in a man's murder in Central Park, was sentenced yesterday to 39 months to 10 years in prison.

title: Sushi
description: It would be hard to overestimate the passion of New Yorkers for raw fish. Sushi is everywhere, from the small midtown sushi bars that opened 25 years ago to cater to Japanese businessmen, to the Chinese restaurants now offering sushi to add to their takeout business, to a completely American approach: all-you-can-eat sushi (if that's the kind of sushi you want). Here are 12 settings for sushi. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: Indonesia to Sign 3d I.M.F. Rescue Pact
description: Indonesia is within days of signing its third accord in five months with the International Monetary Fund to try to rescue its collapsing economy, and the fund's leadership is already fending off criticism that it is giving in too much to the demands of President Suharto, the country's authoritarian leader.

title: Now Playing: Babes in Cyberspace; Digital Diaper Set Is Next Gleam in Software Industry's Eye
description: ''No, no, no,'' Joseph Dillon scolds the personal computer in frustration. But with a few deft moves of the mouse, he solves the problem. The image he wants pops up on the screen.

title: The Case Russia Forgot
description: There is growing bipartisan support in Congress to compel Russia to halt missile exports to Iran. In an effort to defuse the issue, the Russian Government has denied involvement in the transactions and has introduced new controls on the military exports.

title: Gun Links Man Who Shot at Officers to '97 Killing of Token Clerk, Police Say
description: A Bronx man who shot at two police officers who were chasing him Wednesday night has been linked to the killing of a token booth clerk in Long Island City last year, the police said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRUMEYER, JOSEPH (JERRY)
description: STRUMEYER - Joseph (Jerry). Beloved husband of Arline, devoted father of Jeffrey and Gayle, Sheri and Robert Bayles, Donna and Mitchel Ratner, loving grandfather of Allison, Michelle, Daniel, Greg, Aaron and Zachary, dear brother of Gertrude Ruden and the late Ruth Whitman. Services Sunday 10 A.M., at ''Gutterman's, Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Rd, Rockville Centre, Long Island.

title: In Memphis, Conflicting Paths on Dr. King's Legacy
description: Thirty years after the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was killed on the balcony of a Memphis motel by a sniper's shot to his jaw, thousands of pilgrims plan to gather here this weekend to try to draw meaning from his remarkable life and death.

title: Yankees Take Show on Road And Fall Short
description: Back-to-back losses in June or August translate into nothing more than a minor slump, an isolated blip. But when the Yankees, a team expected to compete for a World Series title, lose back-to-back games to start the season, well, that's a mini-crisis.

title: Op-Art
description: Richie Chevat is a writer from Montclair, N.J. Paul Sahre is a graphic designer.

title: Residential Real Estate; High-Rise Recycling Turns to Automation
description: A small but growing number of developers and owners of high-rise apartment buildings in New York City have begun to install automated recycling systems that separate recyclable material from the rest of a tenant's trash at the push of a button.

title: Judge Rules for M.T.A. on Tunnel Contract Linked to Pataki Donor
description: A judge has declared that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority did not violate its regulations in awarding a $97 million contract to repair the Queens-Midtown Tunnel to a company owned by a major financial supporter of Gov. George E. Pataki and the State Republican Committee.

title: Sun Sets on British Car Makers
description: WITH the announcement this week that BMW of Germany would buy Rolls-Royce Motor Cars for $571 million, the British auto industry has hawked its last valuable piece of family silver. What remains are some old kitchen utensils and sports equipment.

title: MAYOR APOLOGIZES FOR CITY RESPONSE TO CROWN HEIGHTS
description: Ending another bitter chapter stemming from the 1991 racial violence in Crown Heights, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani formally apologized yesterday for what he called the city's ''clearly inadequate response'' to the disturbances and announced that the city would pay $1.1 million to settle a lawsuit filed by the neighborhood's Hasidim.

title: COR THERAPEUTICS STOCK UP 79% ON F.D.A. NEWS
description: Shares of Cor Therapeutics Inc. jumped 79 percent yesterday after the company said it had received a letter from the Food and Drug Administration saying its heart drug Integrilin could be approved. The agency said Integrilin could be approved for the treatment of unstable angina, the acute chest pains that can precede heart attacks, and for patients receiving balloon angioplasty to open clogged arteries, if Cor resolved some details regarding labeling. In January, an advisory panel to the F.D.A. recommended that an additional clinical trial be performed to gain approval, or that the drug might be approvable only for angioplasty. Cor shares gained $9.84375, to $22.3125. Cor, a biotechnology company based in South San Francisco, will share manufacturing and marketing of the drug with the Schering Plough Corporation.

description: To the Editor:

title: The New Rules
description: Thanks to Judge Susan Webber Wright's ruling Wednesday in Paula Corbin Jones's lawsuit against the President, we know what doesn't constitute sexual harassment. Now office Lotharios can enjoy a safe harbor from complaints if they follow a few simple rules.

title: Many Voices Tell a Most Intricate Tale
description: AN INSTANCE OF THE FINGERPOST

title: Schnabel, as a Composer, Taps the Past and Future
description: Most listeners know Artur Schnabel, through his recordings, as one of the most eloquent Beethoven and Schubert pianists of the first half of the 20th century. But he was also the composer of several harmonically rigorous chamber works, a handful of which have been recorded but are rarely played in concert. The Magellan String Quartet, the graduate quartet in residence at the Juilliard School, made a strong case for the first of Schnabel's five string quartets in its program at Alice Tully Hall on Tuesday evening.

title: A License to Harass?
description: The dismissal of the Paula Jones case has raised fears that sexual harassers will now feel free to accost co-workers without fear of legal punishment. But that would be an erroneous reading of sexual harassment law, and an overly pessimistic conclusion about the ability of American workplaces to continue fighting harassment.

title: Students Arrested as Jeffries Cancels Talk
description: An appearance at the College of Staten Island by Leonard Jeffries Jr., the City College black studies professor known for his anti-Semitic statements, dissolved into chaos last night after he abruptly canceled his speech, then showed up two hours later, prompting security to block his entry and leading to the arrest of student protesters who wanted him allowed onto campus.

title: Christian Coalition Criticism Irks G.O.P. Leader
description: The chairman of the Republican National Committee was apparently miffed about recent remarks by the Christian Coalition that the Republican Party has been too accommodating to those who support abortion rights.

title: State Senate Passes Plan To Reduce Auto Rates
description: With bipartisan support, the New Jersey Senate voted overwhelmingly today to approve changes in the state's auto insurance system that lawmakers said would guarantee a 15 percent reduction in premiums for most drivers.

description: SAMSONITE CORP., Denver, said it had laid off 149 more employees at its Denver factory because of mounting inventory in a year of slackening suitcase sales.

title: Sports of The Times; Long Chase Is Over; Problem Isn't
description: THE compromised ''student athletes'' usually get caught, don't they? Sooner or later, evidence of their objectionable romance with a drug, an agent, or a gambler washes up on shore. The law catches up to them, be it institutional or criminal. Coach may teach them how to fight through a screen, but they are typically closed out of the classes on self-defense.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HOGS FALL 3.3 PERCENT. Hogs and pork bellies dropped because of a record domestic herd, growing bacon stockpiles and weakening consumer demand. April hog contracts fell 1.725 cents a pound, to 50.625 cents.

description: The Olympic champions may be missing, but the Russian dominance in figure skating has continued unabated at the world championships.

title: Jets and Giants Marking Their Calendars for Prime Time
description: The last time the Jets were on ''Monday Night Football,'' in 1992, Bruce Coslet was the coach, Browning Nagle was the quarterback and Blair Thomas was the running back.

title: With Licks From the Past And a Partiality for Kitsch
description: Raul Malo, the singer and guitarist for the Mavericks, is a big man who radiates calm; his band's music, inspired by classic pop from Phil Spector to the string-laden Nashville sound to the Beatles to mariachi music, rolls along with the self-assurance of a Cadillac. And when the Mavericks played at Tramps on Wednesday night, every song made a gorgeous entrance, saying what it needed to say -- with a wicked hook from an organ or a guitar, or with Mr. Malo's trembling, Roy Orbison-like tenor -- in the first 30 seconds.

title: Write Your Books And Go to Parties
description: PAMELA THOMAS-GRAHAM said she had never done any creative writing, except for a a stint with a campus arts paper in college. A 1985 graduate of Harvard, she majored in economics. ''Statistics are the most creative things there are,'' she said yesterday from her office at McKinsey & Company, the consulting firm, where she was the first black woman to become a partner.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesdayabout a farmer in Chesterfield, N.J., pruning peach trees misstated the length of the heat record that was broken on Tuesday when the temperature reached 86. As the caption reported correctly, the previous record was set in 1986, which was 12 years ago, not 8.

title: Everest, and Sherpas, Are in Vogue; New York's Cool New Guys, Thanks to Books and Films
description: The Sherpas are bemused.

title: Volkswagen's U.S. Sales Soared in March
description: Volkswagen said today that its United States sales rose 44 percent in March as demand for the New Beetle was strong.

title: Reviews/Fashion; Rulers of the Night: Blass, de la Renta and Beads
description: There are designers whose reputations are based on their day clothes, who show a few evening pieces just to round out the collection. And there are others who show both day and evening but whose evening wear is what people remember and what draws their loyal customers.

title: A Vice Chairman of Salomon Leaves to Manage His Money
description: Robert H. Lessin left his position as a vice chairman of Salomon Smith Barney Wednesday to devote his time to venture capital investing and managing his own money.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Hedge Fund Rose Fast, Fell Faster
description: Last year was disappointing for investors in hedge funds. Most managers of these freewheeling funds designed for the wealthy did not keep up with the stock market.

title: On the Morning After, Springtime Inside the Beltway
description: Across the Potomac from the Lincoln Memorial, Jennifer Falls stepped up to a display wall of dozens of morning newspapers from across the nation, all screaming a chorus of headlines about Paula Corbin Jones and her failed lawsuit against the President of the United States.

title: News Summary
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: From Mamet. A Con Game. Secrets. Very Complicated.
description: An airport-security X-ray scans packages at the start of ''The Spanish Prisoner,'' revealing the inner workings behind tame-looking exteriors. If only such a device could read the conniving minds at work in this, David Mamet's craftiest and most satisfying cinematic puzzle. But no: this film's characters remain wonderfully inscrutable, speaking in the clipped vernacular of Mametese even when merrily taunting the audience. ''Who in this world,'' ask several of the film's carefully artificial characters, ''is what they seem?''

title: Collectors Buy American
description: While the recent fortunes made on Wall Street have helped fuel many segments of the auction market, American art has particularly benefited from the new wealth. And though the market for multimillion-dollar paintings by American Impressionists has soared with the strong stock market, so has the demand for paintings of the American West.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Nissan Shares Fall On Report of Stock Loss
description: The shares of the Nissan Motor Company plunged 6.9 percent yesterday, the second consecutive decline, after the auto maker said it would probably post a 50 billion yen ($376 million) stock loss for the year that ended on Tuesday. Shares in Japan's second-largest auto maker fell 34 yen, to 457. About 5.1 million shares were traded.

title: Check In and Check Out: Love on the Astral Plane
description: What Candido Tirado's new play, ''Checking Out'' (''Morir Sonando'') demonstrates is that in the end, no matter how hard the actors work or how attractive they are, suicide is not amusing and characters pursuing it tend to alienate an audience or simply exhaust it.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: West 13th Street between Avenue of the Americas and Seventh Avenue is rich in restaurants. That's the only possible reason I can think of for Antonio Restaurant's being empty (except for us) on Sunday night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TARIN, MARIA
description: TARIN-Maria. Wit, raconteur, friend of all children and animals, housekeeper. Daughter of Senaida and Roberto. Passed away of natural causes on March 29, 1998. A memorial service will be held at St. Francis Xavier, 30 West 16 Street, New York, NY on Saturday, April 4, 1998 at 9:30AM. Interment in Alpine, Texas.

title: Companies Oppose Disclosure of Detail On Gifts to Charity
description: Big publicly held companies are bridling at proposed Federal legislation that would require them to disclose how much money they give individual charities, warning that such a law would have a chilling effect on corporate philanthropy.

title: Japan, Asia's Giant Economy, Struggles to Rescue Itself First
description: As Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto arrived in London today to discuss how to solve Asian financial troubles, bad economic news in Japan helped send many of the region's markets lower.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Circuits section yesterday about maps on CD-ROM misidentified the company that makes Toposcout software. As the listing at the beginning of the article reported correctly, it is Maptech, not Mapquest.

title: Fascist Outrages Awaken A Death-Obsessed Editor
description: Toward the end of his long and illustrious career, Marcello Mastroianni created a gallery of remarkable old men, portraits of the aging rendered in splendid detail and devoid of vanity, intended to preserve his youthful reputation as a Latin lover, which he disdained.

title: SECURITY CAPITAL PLANS TO COMBINE 2 APARTMENT REIT'S
description: Security Capital Group Inc. said yesterday that it planned to merge two of its apartment real estate investment trusts in a transaction valued at about $1.6 billion, creating one of the largest owners and developers in the United States. The two trusts, Security Capital Pacific Trust and Security Capital Atlantic Inc., will be combined to form Archstone Communities, a company with 304 properties and 90,166 apartments in 19 states throughout the South and the West Coast. The terms of the agreement call for Pacific to swap one share for each Atlantic share. Pacific, which is based in Denver, will also assume about $527 million of debt. Atlantic, which is based in Atlanta, rose $1.5625 a share yesterday, to $22.5625. Pacific fell 93.75 cents, to $23.1875.

title: Plane Carried Perilous Cargo Despite a Ban
description: Two months after old aircraft parts shipped as cargo caused a Valujet plane to crash, killing all 110 people aboard, another small airline based at the same airport shipped the same kind of cargo on the same route on another passenger plane, the Federal Aviation Administration said today.

title: ART IN REVIEW

Professor of Mathematics & Computer Science at the Graduate Center, CUNY and Queens College, Visiting Professor, Mathematical Logic, University of Siena, Italy, April 1, 1998. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:30 A.M., St. Luke's RC Church, Whitestone, Queens.

title: From 'Passion' to 'Alleluia,' the Music of a Sacred Season
description: This is a sampling of the musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and concert halls in New York City. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.) This selection, compiled by Paul Griffiths, represents what caught this critic's eye and excited his expectations. Unless noted, church choirs are featured in church concerts.

description: Catherine Opie

description: * Gateway 2000 Inc., North Sioux City, S.D., has named, as expected, McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., to handle its worldwide account, which had been handled by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications, New York, a unit of MacManus Group. Billings were estimated at $50 million to $70 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, BORENSTEIN, LILLIAN
description: BROWN - BORENSTEIN - Lillian. Beloved wife of Samuel Borenstein and the late A. Milton Brown. Devoted mother of B. Warren and Benjamin Brown. Loving grandmother of Debra Silver, David Bennett Brown, Donna Beth Brown, Steven Michael Brown, Alan Theodore Brown and Daniel Lewis Brown. Great grandmother of Michelle and Matthew Silver, Jason, Alexa, Erika and Max Brown. Funeral Friday, 10am at Congregation Kehilath Jeshurun, 125 E. 85th St., New York City.

title: Hilton Reports Chairman Plans To Sell About 10% of Its Shares
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said today that its chairman, Barron Hilton, was planning to sell the nearly 10 percent of the company held by a charitable trust he controls.

title: Random House Editor Ready to Talk Books
description: ANN GODOFF of Random House once made her living selling Oldsmobiles -- new, not used -- on 11th Avenue, training she says has served her well in negotiations over book advances to authors. Perhaps it will be equally useful this morning when she meets for the first time with Peter Olson, the Bertelsmann executive who is the latest most important person in the publishing industry, and very soon her new boss.

title: Boyish Eyes On the Moon
description: Jules Verne got there first. In his 1865 novel, ''From the Earth to the Moon,'' he invented a group of Americans who gather in Florida and launch a huge projectile rocket. As the Apollo flights would a century later, Verne's rocket holds three men who are propelled on a journey to the moon.

title: Recalling Bella Abzug's Politics and Passion
description: In a farewell burst of talking, singing, humming and cheering, Bella S. Abzug was memorialized yesterday by entertainers, politicians and feminists in a ceremony that suggested the wide swath Ms. Abzug had cut in New York public life.

title: Death Penalty Ruled Out In Killing of Newborn Boy
description: In a retreat from their original position, prosecutors will not pursue the death penalty against Amy S. Grossberg, the New Jersey teen-ager accused of killing her newborn son, according to court documents released yesterday.

title: Classicism With Clarity And an Air of Inevitability
description: Alfred Brendel's way of dazzling an audience has less to do with speed, technique and finger power than with his ability to toy with his listeners' perceptions, usually by presenting contradictions and seeming to reconcile them at the same instant. For a time, he did this mostly by shuttling between the worlds of Beethoven and Liszt. In Beethoven, he illuminated the music's courtly roots while at the same time making a point of its increasingly revolutionary architecture; he played Liszt with impeccable virtuosity while arguing that beneath Liszt's glittery veneer lay music of uncommon depth.

title: Reno Will Investigate Report That One Witness Was Paid
description: Attorney General Janet Reno said today that she intended to pursue accusations that an important witness in the Whitewater investigation might have received financial help from conservative groups while providing investigators with testimony that was damaging to President Clinton.

title: Richard Bellamy, Art Dealer, Is Dead at 70
description: Richard Bellamy, a New York art dealer whose Green Gallery was one of the most important showcases of avant-garde art during the American art explosion of the early 1960's, died on Sunday at his home in Long Island City, Queens. He was 70.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in the New York metropolitan region this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Burnishing The Lamp Of Americana
description: Israel Sack Inc., the venerable 93-year-old antiques firm, has been among the most respected sellers of American antiques for several decades. But the world is changing.

description: HENRY - Mary Pegnam. On March 30, 1998. Beloved wife of Robert Vincent Henry. Loving mother of Father Robert Henry, Mary McCann, Marian, Jane Reynolds, Frances Riley, Michael, and the late Thomas. Devoted sister of Frances and Louise McCarthy, and Martin Pegnam. Mass of Christian Burial, St. Augustine's Church, Larchmont, Saturday, at 10 A.M. Interment in St. Patrick's Cemetery, Rockland, MA.

title: Torre Is Bringing Out The Best in Williams
description: Two years ago, Joe Torre became the first Yankee manager to treat Bernie Williams like a man. Now Williams is being asked to reward the manager and be ''the man.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YEGEN, GLADYS (DR. GLADYS TER)
description: YEGEN-Gladys (Dr. Gladys ter). Loving wife of the late ChrisWintian. Died April 2, 1998 at the age of 93. Formerly of Teaneck and Tenafly, New Jersey. Beloved mother of Laura Kahl (Jim), Christian Yegen (Lonna), Carol Lerer (Nat). Devoted grandmother of Katy, Kristy, and Laurie, Hillary and Christopher, Keith, Scott and David and nine great grandchildren. She leaves the legacy of love, kindness and caring for her family and friends. She was truly a women of uncommon virtue. Donations may be made to a charity of choice. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date.

title: Affirming Her Identity In Quietly Heroic Forms
description: Something of the determination, stamina and resourcefulness it must have taken for Elizabeth Catlett to sustain her long and distinguished career is embodied in her sculpture, a selection of which is on view in a 50-year retrospective at the Neuberger Museum of Art in Purchase, N.Y. Her archetypal figures, abstracted in wood, stone, clay or bronze into postures of defiance, endurance and, in the case of many mother-and-child images, fiercely protective tenderness, exude a spirit of indomitable hope and will.

title: David Bourdon, 63, Art Critic With Expertise in Modern Genres
description: David Bourdon, a critic who was closely involved in the innovative Manhattan art world of the early 1960's and who was one of the early writers on the Minimalist movement, died on March 27 at Simi Valley Hospital in Simi Valley, Calif. He was 63.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN HALTS ITS SLIDE. The Japanese currency broke a four-day decline, rallying slightly on traders' fears of central bank intervention to defend the currency's value. In New York the dollar cost 133.50 yen, down from 133.68.

description: Patrons wandering into the dim, seedy Kit-Kat Klub to see Natasha Richardson in the critically praised revival of ''Cabaret'' know they are going to see a musical. But they are also wandering into a fully realized, three-dimensional version of a nightclub in Weimar Germany, an environmental experience as well as a theatrical one.

title: Israelis Accused in Killing
description: After a raucous funeral today for a suspected Hamas bomb-maker who was killed near here on Sunday, Hamas and some Palestinian officials accused Israel of assassination.

title: NORTHERN CALIFORNIA MALL IS SOLD FOR $130 MILLION
description: Colony Capital Inc. and the developer Michael Swerdlow said yesterday that they had bought the Great Mall of the Bay Area, the largest shopping mall in Northern California, for $130 million. The two teamed up to buy the 1.5-million-square-foot mall in Milpitas, Calif., from the real estate unit of the Ford Motor Company. The property operates as a factory outlet center, selling clothes and other goods directly from 185 manufacturers and retailers at discounted prices. Preliminary plans call for Mr. Swerdlow, who is based in Miami, and Colony, a Los Angeles-based real estate investor, to spend more than $25 million adding entertainment-type tenants to the mall.

title: Industrial Bank of Japan Reports Deep Loss
description: The Industrial Bank of Japan Ltd. became the latest in a wave of Japanese lenders to say it would report a deeper loss in the year that ended on Tuesday to write off more bad loans than it had previously expected. The bank -- the largest of three Japanese lenders that specialize in long-term lending to companies -- widened its current loss forecast to 370 billion yen ($2.7 billion) from 250 billion yen.

Interment George Washington Memorial Park. Family will receive friends Friday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: Ex-Vichy Aide Is Convicted And Reaction Ranges Wide
description: A French court's historic finding today that Maurice Papon is guilty of complicity in Nazi crimes against humanity because he turned Jews over to the Germans in World War II has both comforted and disconcerted the country he served as a high-ranking civil servant for 50 years.

title: Whitney Whittles Intimate Corners
description: History under pressure. That's a good description of the inaugural display of 50 years of American art packed into the new permanent collection galleries at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Carved out of former offices on the fifth floor of the museum's 1966 Marcel Breuer landmark, these 11 svelte spaces are the first galleries in the museum's 69-year history to be dedicated exclusively to its own extensive collection.

description: LEVINE-Lillian Bennett. Lifelong fighter for progressive causes, teacher. description: Students presented works by guest choreographers as well as pieces of their own when the Second Avenue Dance Company performed on Monday night at the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University.

title: Factory Orders Drop Sharply As Boeing Falls
description: Orders to American factories fell sharply in February, though the decline was caused by a big drop in the volatile aircraft industry, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Judge Rejects 3d Push to Keep School District Of Kiryas Joel
description: A State Supreme Court justice in Albany yesterday struck down a third attempt by the Governor and the State Legislature to preserve a special public school district for the Hasidic enclave of Kiryas Joel, calling the latest effort to tailor a valid law an act of ''legislative favoritism'' that endorsed a single religious group.

description: Whitewater independent counsel Kenneth W. Starr insisted today that a Federal judge's decision to dismiss Paula Corbin Jones' sexual harrassment lawsuit would not hamper or derail his criminal investigation of President Clinton.

title: Jones News Gave Networks Little Lift, if Any
description: Wednesday's breaking news of the decision to dismiss Paula Corbin Jones's lawsuit against President Clinton did not lead to a surge in viewing for television news programs.

title: Love, Yes; Oysters, No
description: In his white wig and tri-cornered hat, Henry Fielding stands on the road to Squire Allworthy's estate and alerts the audience to his presence. ''I think it proper to acquaint you that I tend to digress through this whole history,'' he says, and as this three-part mini-series of ''Tom Jones'' goes on, his wry guidance does much to justify the opening credit: ''Written and narrated by Henry Fielding.'' His occasional presence as on-camera guide is the first clue that this ''Tom Jones'' has staked out its ground apart from Tony Richardson's delicious, beloved 1963 film version with Albert Finney.

title: SENATE APPROVES BUDGET BLUEPRINT CURBING TAX CUTS
description: After calming recalcitrant conservatives, the Senate tonight approved a Republican budget blueprint for the new fiscal year that would hold tax cuts to $30 billion over five years and reject nearly all of President Clinton's proposals for new spending.

title: Forever the Football Fan, Mother Benches Her Son
description: In Vincent Gallo's ''Buffalo '66,'' Billy Brown (Mr. Gallo) steals a blond kewpie doll named Layla (Christina Ricci) out of her tap dancing class and browbeats her into masquerading as his wife at a dinner with his parents. Billy hectors, cajoles and tries to bribe Layla. (''You can eat all the food you want. Just make me look good.'') He threatens both that he will kill her and that he won't be her best friend. He bullies her outrageously but with such crazy brio and jittery persistence that Layla falls for him. Mr. Gallo's film, a deadpan original mixing pathos with bravado, works on its audience in much the same way.

title: After the Fad: A Salon Favorite Now Forgotten
description: Although today his name wouldn't raise an auction paddle, Alexandre Cabanel (1823-1889) was one of the most popular painters in late-19th-century France. A salon artist par excellence, he never got past the Old Masters he so sedulously studied in his youth. As the radical notions of realism swirled around him, he produced florid, old-style history, biblical and allegorical extravaganzas, most titillatingly ''The Birth of Venus'' in 1863. Now reposing at the Musee d'Orsay in Paris, it depicts a luscious reclining nude attended by flying cherubs, so chastely rendered that it was bought by Napoleon III at that year's Salon.

title: Liberty, Equality, Sorority
description: ''American Ingenuity,'' the new show at the Costume Institute of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, has a sturdy, homespun appeal. Gingham. Striped cotton. Horse blanket capes. Bustle bows. A survey of women's sportswear in the postwar decades, the show is not glitzy. It does not offer the most glamorous interpretation that could be made of its extraordinary complex subject. But it has the summery glow of a vine-ripened tomato or a fresh ear of country corn.

title: Ever a Free Spirit, Prankster Turns Hooligan
description: Set in a picturesque Irish town and featuring a freckle-faced young hero in knee pants, ''The Butcher Boy'' may look familiar at first. But as the real, disturbing nature of Neil Jordan's audacious film emerges, this story moves far outside the realm of the ordinary. Mr. Jordan's films at their best (''Mona Lisa,'' ''The Crying Game,'' ''Interview With the Vampire'' and now this) are perversely comfortable on such difficult terrain, contemplating the hidden extremes of human nature. The filmmaker's gift for genuinely shocking his audience is, for him, an essential way of telling the truth.

title: Extra Gear and Glitter For Space Family Values
description: When actors get the unaccountable yen to see themselves as plastic action figures, maybe a toy-crazy extragavanza like ''Lost in Space'' looks like a smart career move. Otherwise, this lavish venture into the realm of television reruns has more limited appeal. Ambitious enough to include 750 special effects, Stephen Hopkins's version of the quaint, tinny black-and-white television show is often frenetic enough to suggest that all 750 are happening simultaneously. And special-effects technology is not yet capable of creating lovebird chemistry between William Hurt and Mimi Rogers, who play married scientists shepherding their brood on an intergalactic adventure.

title: Conviction Is Upheld For Railroad Gunman
description: An appellate division of the State Supreme Court yesterday unanimously upheld the 1995 murder convictions of Colin Ferguson, who is serving a 200-year sentence for opening fire on a Long Island Rail Road train in December 1993, killing 6 passengers and wounding 19 others.

title: China's Pirated Disks
description: To the Editor:

title: New Yorker Held Hostage in Colombia Flees Captors
description: With a fortitude that might do Indiana Jones proud, one of two Central Park bird-watchers who was kidnapped by rebels in Colombia escaped yesterday, marching through rugged terrain for six hours before being discovered by a television news crew near Bogota.

title: Auto Makers Seeking to Avoid Fines Over Mileage Rules
description: With full-sized sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks increasingly popular, auto makers are falling short of Federal fuel-economy standards and scrambling for ways to avoid the embarrassment of paying millions of dollars in fines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THOMPSON, JAMES D.
description: THOMPSON-James D. Formerly of Greenwich, CT., and New York City died Saturday, March 14, 1998 in Naples, FL. Mr. Thompson was born January 12, 1907 in Bala, PA., one of four children of Louise and Harry A. Thompson. Mr. Thompson spent his youth in Greenwich and attend Trinty-Pawling School and Wesleyan University, where he graduated Phi Beta Kappa in 1928. In 1935 he married the Broadway actress Peggy Conklin. Mr. Thompson served four years in the U.S. Navy during WWII achieving the rank of Lt. Commander on the Battleship New Mexico and seeing heavy action in the Philippine Islands. An accomplished and long-time sailor, Mr. Thompson had been a member of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club and, since 1931, The Cruising Club of America. He is survived by his wife Peggy Conklin Thompson of Naples, a daughter Antonia West of London, a son and daughter-in-law Michael and Peggy Thompson of San Jose, CA. and three grandchildren.

title: Weirdest Show On Earth
description: Step right up folks and welcome to the sideshow, an awesome assemblage of atypical anomalies, a Captivating Cavalcade of Curiosities and Spectacles. The spectacles are staggering, unprecedented and, yes, oh yes, breathtakingly shameless.

title: MITCHELL ENERGY AGREES TO BUY 3 PROPERTIES IN TEXAS
description: The Mitchell Energy and Development Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy three oil- and gas-producing properties in Texas in separate transactions totaling $50 million. Mitchell is buying a 67 percent interest in the Columbus field unit in southeastern Texas from the Occidental Petroleum Corporation. It is also buying a 100 percent working interest in six gas units and a 25 percent interest in five units in the Personville field in eastern Texas from 22 sellers.

title: MetroStars Acquire Galaxy's Hurtado
description: In a swap involving players from the Ecuadorian national team, the MetroStars added scoring punch to their forward line yesterday by acquiring Eduardo Hurtado from the Los Angeles Galaxy for Wellington Sanchez, a midfielder.

title: Willis Saves the Day (Hey, Someone Has To)
description: That smirk on Bruce Willis's face is sending a message. The amused little twinkle that glints through one action movie after another is the equivalent of a sheepishly guilty shrug. It acknowledges that the star knows that we know that what's happening on the screen is just a crock. But hey! There are worse ways to make a living than being a movie star, aren't there? Someone's got to do the dirty job of being an action hero, and it sure beats whatever.

title: Metro Business; N.Y.U. Leasing Site To Use as Dormitory
description: The 32-story building at 200 Water Street, facing the South Street Seaport, was built in 1971 as an office tower for the securities and insurance companies that once dominated the southern tip of Manhattan. Now it is about to become a dormitory.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MASON, GEORGE PERLEY
description: MASON-George Perley, 67. Died in Cancun, Mexico, March 1, 1998. A memorial service will be held for family, friends, and employees Friday, April 3, at 5:30 P.M. in The Church of Saint Peter, 16 Barclay St., Manhattan. A native of Brooklyn and veteran of the Korean War, Mr. Mason was a graduate of Seton Hall University and a Certified Public Accountant. For the past seventeen years, he served as Chairman and CEO of Panache Resources & Systems Corporation in Jersey City. Mr. Mason divided his time among family and friends in New York, Rhode Island, and Virginia, where he maintained separate residences. He is survived by two sons, three daughters, and three grandchildren. Donations to honor his longstanding commitment to education may be made to: Seton Hall University, College Scholarship Fund, 400 South Orange Avenue, South Orange, New Jersey 07079.

title: What's Purple And Can Dunk? Shaq (50 Points)
description: Dressed in purple, he towered over everyone. He wore a perpetual smile and enraptured 20,000 people who came to see him frolic.

title: High Chicago Officer Gets Top Washington Police Post
description: Vowing to get tough on criminals and unethical officers, the Deputy Superintendent of Police in Chicago, Charles H. Ramsey, was named today as the Chief of Police in the District of Columbia, where high crime rates and Police Department scandals have plagued the city for years.

title: Apartment Owners Agree To Settle Bias Lawsuits
description: The owners of two apartment complexes agreed yesterday to pay $300,000 to settle housing discrimination lawsuits brought against them by the Federal Government, officials of the United States Department of Justice said.

title: Settlements Reached With Explosion Victims
description: The owners of a natural gas pipeline that exploded in 1994, injuring 100 people and destroying eight apartment buildings, agreed on Wednesday to pay 19 victims a settlement totaling $500,000, the lead lawyer for the claimants said yesterday. Individual amounts range from $2,000 to $200,000.

title: Victorian Portraiture, Rich in Feeling and Faith
description: Such a provincial country, this America of ours. Poor Alfred Stieglitz had to struggle for nearly a decade to convince an American museum that images made with cameras were worthy of hanging on their walls and entering their collections. Finally, in 1910, he persuaded the Albright Knox Gallery in Buffalo to mount an exhibition, even to buy a few photographs that were offered at such bargain-basement prices that the photographers were offended.

title: City Houses Foster Children With Runaways in Brooklyn
description: As the number of foster children sleeping on fold-up cots in city offices has surged to record highs in recent months, New York City has begun to house abused and neglected teen-agers overnight in a runaway shelter in Brooklyn, city officials said yesterday.

title: The Clintons as Teammates, Dovetailing in Africa
description: Over the last 12 days, Bill and Hillary Clinton have treated Africans -- and Americans watching from home -- to a full dose of the buy-one-get-one-free Clinton partnership, sprinkling images of a fun-and-policy-loving First Couple across the continent.

title: Budget Near in Albany
description: Moving with remarkable swiftness, leaders of the Legislature reached tentative agreement on almost every part of the state budget.

title: Michigan and Boston College Reach Championship Game
description: Boston College and Michigan skated rings around their opponents at the Fleet Center tonight in semifinal matches of the National Collegiate Athletic Association hockey tournament, although their goals did not come easily.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PYLE, JAMES TOLMAN
description: PYLE-James Tolman. Of Oyster Bay, Long Island and Seal Harbor, ME. Died April 1, 1998.
