title: HOMESIDE LENDING TO BUY LOANS FROM BANC ONE MORTGAGE
description: Homeside Lending Inc., a closely held mortgage company, agreed to acquire the residential mortgage loans of Banc One Mortgage from the Banc One Corporation for $201 million. Homeside, based in Jacksonville, Fla., would also acquire the mortgage servicing assets of Banc One Mortgage. The deals, announced late on Wednesday, would transform Homeside, a unit of National Australia Bank, into the fourth-largest mortgage producer and the sixth-largest mortgage servicing company in the United States. It would have a United States servicing portfolio of about $117 billion.

title: Rise in Smoking by Young Black Erodes a Success Story

Today, that optimism all but disappeared as a new study found that cigarette use among African-American high school students jumped 80 percent since 1991.

title: Republican Puts New Hurdle In Path of I.M.F. Financing
description: In a new threat to one of President Clinton's top foreign policy goals, the House majority leader today urged fellow Republicans to reject the Administration's request for $18 billion in new financing for the International Monetary Fund.

title: Corrections

McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville between the hours of 2-4 and 7-9PM Friday. Mass of Christian Burial Saint Joseph's Church, Bronxville, on Saturday, April 4th, 10 A.M. title: Out of Step at 'Eden' Prep As a New Age Is Dawning
description: One of the many small pleasures of ''Eden,'' a drama set at a New England preparatory school for boys in 1965, is that it gets the flavor of the era exactly right. Only one student at Mount Eden Academy, a proudly buttoned-down institution, has started growing his hair long and stumblingly incorporating into his vocabulary what will evolve into standard hippie argot.

title: Math as a Secret Decoder Of Markets and Mysticism
description: You don't have to be a math whiz to appreciate the heady notions Darren Aronofsky tosses around in his homemade debut film, ''Pi.'' The movie, made for just $20,000, offers a brash horror-comic variation on a familiar type, the paranoid wild-eyed genius who is so obsessed with proving a theory that he goes mad. Before he's finished experimenting on his home computer (named Euclid, of course), Maximillian Cohen (Sean Gullette), the film's central character, has shaved his head in order to plug his computer into a specific area of his brain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUROSS II, CHARLES E.
description: DUROSS II-Charles E. Born in New York on November 27, 1940 to the late Neil and Emily Duross, and graduate of Fordham University and Law School (1963, 1967). From 1967-74, he was an associate and later partner at Zock, Petrie, Sheneman & Reid in New York. In 1974, he became counsel to The Upjohn Co. in Kalamazoo, MI., where he retired as Assoc. General Counsel and Managing Director in 1988. He returned to New York to be President and CEO of Chas. E. Duross & Sons, Inc. Recently, he served on the Board of Governors of the New York Athletic Club, where he had been a member since 1961. He is survived by his loving wife Judith; his sons, Sean and Charles; and his sisters, Denise Beckerle and Suzanne Kelly. A funeral mass will be held at St. Bernard's, 330 W. 14th St., April 4th at 10:30 am. Please contact Redden's funeral home (212-242-1456) for more information. Charlie will be missed by all who knew him as he was always ready to greet people with a broad smile, a tall pint of Guinness and a witty joke.

title: NBTY AGREES TO ACQUIRE 3 COMPANIES FOR $180 MILLION

The mail-order companies to be acquired are Nutrition Headquarters Inc., based in Carbondale, Ill., and Lee Nutrition Inc. of Cambridge, Mass. The vitamin maker is Nutro Laboratories Inc. of South Plainfield, N.J. The acquired companies had combined sales of $77.4 million last year. The stock of NBTY, based in Bohemia, N.Y., rose $2.5625 yesterday, to $62.8125. The stock traded for $15 last April.

title: METALS USA SAYS IT HAS ACQUIRED FOUR COMPANIES
description: Metals USA Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired four companies with combined annual revenues of about $151 million. Financial terms were not disclosed, but the company said it paid in cash, stock and debt assumption. Metals USA, a Houston-based metal processing company, said it expected the companies -- Fullerton Industries, Sierra Pacific Steels Inc., Industrial Metals Inc. and the Concord Metals Corporation -- to add to earnings immediately. Metals said the acquisition of Fullerton would give it an entry into the Chicago steel market. Sierra Pacific has operations in California's heavy carbon steel industry. Industrial Metals has operations in the Chicago specialty metals market. Concord is a flat rolled steel processor in Walker, Mich.

title: A System of Conducting, or, Rather, 'Conduction'

Usually Mr. Morris works with musicians who are used to improvising, in fringe-art performance spaces before audiences who know what to expect. But classical musicians can play by his rules, too, and the Florence experience illustrates how well it can work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEYL, WALTER
description: WEYL-Walter. A resident of Kendal at Hanover, N.H. Died on April 1, 1998, at the age of 93. Born in Hamburg, Germany, December 11, 1904, the first child of Michael and Margarete Fahning Weyl. He arrived on Ellis Island in 1923, the day after his 19th birthday and continued his journey to St. Louis, Missouri. In 1926 he married his longtime friend from Hamburg, Kaethe Schwettscher who died shortly after they celebrated their 60th wedding anniversary. He left the midwest in 1930 and took up permanent residence in NYC where he learned the printing trade, ultimately joining the New York Times (the only newspaper he deemed worth reading) retiring as a linotype operator in 1969. He was a lifelong member of the International Typographical Union. He and his wife toured the U.S. extensively both before and after retirement, their particular love being the national parks. Their trips were amply photographed and relived with friends. An introvert by nature he loved to read, listen to his expensive record collection, peruse his photo albums and tackle New York Times crossword puzzles. His skill in word games such as Scrabble and anagrams was unsurpassed. He moved to Hanover, N.H. in 1993 where his only child, Dr. Hilda Weyl Sokol resides. He is survived by two sisters, his daughter, three grandchildren and four great grandchildren. The family will have a private memorial service.

title: Proposition 209 Shuts the Door
description: California's Proposition 209, which prohibits public universities from considering race and ethnicity in their admissions decisions, is closing doors to black and Hispanic students at an alarming rate. The University of California at Berkeley released data this week showing that black, Hispanic and American Indian students accounted for only 10 percent of admissions for next fall's freshman class, compared with 23 percent last year. At the University of California at Los Angeles, admissions of those minority groups fell from nearly 20 percent last year to less than 13 percent this year.

title: From the Ground Up in East New York
description: Nearly 20 years ago, a visiting mayor walked through the slums of Brooklyn's Brownsville neighborhood. The abandoned blocks along one main street, Blake Avenue, were lined with fields of scrub grass and saplings. Concrete blocks and plywood planks boarded up the few tenements along the fringes to keep out vandals, squatters and thugs. ''I have seen,'' the mayor declared, ''the beginning of the end of our civilization.''

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE FALLS 2.6 PERCENT. Coffee fell to a 14-month low on weaker demand, forecasts of a bumper Brazilian crop and news of a wholesale price cut on the Folgers brand. May contracts fell 3.75 cents, to $1.4055 a pound.

title: Job Growth Stumbles
description: Some 36,000 jobs were lost from the nation's payrolls last month, the Labor Department said in a surprisingly weak employment report that showed the economy slowing after months of strong growth. The unemployment rate edged up to 4.7 percent from 4.6 percent in February.

title: Back Home, Clinton Chides Republicans
description: Buoyant in his first day back in the Oval Office after 12 days in Africa, President Clinton gathered his economic advisers in the Rose Garden and lambasted the budget proposal Senate Republicans pushed through on Thursday night. Clearly emboldened by the dismissal of Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct lawsuit against him, the President vowed not to be distracted by such matters.

title: Life's Dull Everyday Events, Like Murder
description: Movie murderers are a confident lot. Performance anxiety didn't seem to be a serious problem for John Travolta and Samuel L. Jackson in ''Pulp Fiction,'' for instance. They chatted casually about fast food and the metric system before drawing their guns and dropping in on some potential victims.

title: Turncoat Mobster Seen as Key Witness in Extortion Case Against Gotti's Son
description: Cast in the role of turncoat mobster and Government witness, William Raymond Marshall could be as important in the case against John A. Gotti, the son, as Salvatore Gravano was against John J. Gotti, the father, Mr. Marshall's lawyer said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUSSELL, KATHRYN V.
description: RUSSELL-Kathryn V. On April 4, 1977. Dearest friend, always kind and thoughtful. May you rest in peace with God throughout eternity. You will always be remembered. Howard

title: Laila Twigg-Smith, Art Collector, 53
description: Laila Twigg-Smith, an art collector and philanthropist, died on March 24 at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 53 and had recently moved to Manhattan from Honolulu.

title: Jews and Blacks Try to Avoid Reprise of '91 in Crown Hts.
description: Not quite a month ago, a black teen-ager walking home after dark in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, was startled when a Hasidic teen-ager ''shot'' him with the red light of a toy laser gun. The two teen-agers argued, wrestled over the toy gun, began fighting and eventually wound up at the 71st Precinct headquarters.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOYER, MAURICE L.
description: NOYER-Maurice L. On April 3, 1998. Beloved husband of Mary (nee McLoughlin). Loving father of Larry Noyer, Christine Seaver, Elizabeth Noyer, Dr. Charles Noyer, Mary Ann Noyer and Nadine Rote. Also survived by eleven grandchildren. Visiting Sunday, 7-9, and Monday, 3-5 and 7-9 PM, at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Rd., Larchmont, NY. Mass Tuesday, 10 AM, at St. Augustine Church in Larchmont, NY. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, New York.

title: Eberhard Rees, Rocketry Pioneer, Dies at 89
description: Eberhard F. M. Rees, a German-born rocket engineer who in 1970 succeeded Wernher von Braun as the chief of American rocketry efforts, died on Thursday at the West Volusia Memorial Hospital in Florida. He was 89 and lived at the Good Shepards Home in DeLand, Fla.

title: Corrections
description: The ''Making Books'' column in the Arts section on Thursday about sports books misspelled the surname of the president and publisher of Broadway Books in one reference. He is Bill Shinker, not Sinker.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The generals seem to want to stay in power forever. Some of us would gladly grant them that if they could point to one thing they have done for this country. All they have proven is that they know how to arrest people and to steal.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRUPNICK, AUDREE (WIGLER)
description: KRUPNICK-Audree (Wigler). Of Palm Beach Gardens, FL. passed away on April 2nd after a long bout with lung cancer. She leaves her adoring husband, Irwin, after 51 years of a most wonderful marriage; three children, Gary, James and Jane; daughters-in-law, Tammy and Debra; as well as the lights of her life, six grandchildren, Buffy, Katie, Kayla, Phineas, Amy and Ari. Audree will be sorely missed. Funeral from the Bernheim-Apter-Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, New Jersey, Sunday, April 5, at 11 A.M.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Weekend yesterday about winners of the George Foster Peabody Awards misstated the date the awards were announced. It was Thursday, not Wednesday.

title: Crew Member Missing at Sea
description: A crew member was tossed overboard in a fierce storm yesterday during an attempt by Giovanni Soldini, an Italian long-distance sailor, to break the trans-Atlantic record. The crew member, Andrea Romanelli, 33, of Italy, was reported missing at sea.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAIMONE, EMANUEL PAUL (MANNY)
description: MAIMONE-Emanuel Paul (Manny). Age 54. Friday, April 3, 1998, at his home in McLean, VA. Beloved husband of Carol; devoted father of Christian, Sara, Lauren and Greg. Son of Paul Maimone. He is also survived by 5 grandchildren. Friends may call at Money and King Funeral Home, 171 West Maple Avenue, Vienna, VA., on Sunday, April 5, 1998 from 2-4 and 6-8 PM with a Vigil Service at 7:30 PM. Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Luke's R.C. Church, 7001 Georgetown Pike, McLean, VA., on Monday, April 6 at 11 AM. Interment will be held in West Point, NY, Tuesday, April 7, 10 AM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Erica Fund, Virginia Engineering Foundation, A123 Thornton Hall UVA, Charlottesville, Virginia 22903.

title: Museum Of the Indian Drops Its Designer
description: From the beginning, the concept of the National Museum of the American Indian, planned for the Mall in Washington, was meant to be a design apart. American Indian elders were called in for ''vision sessions'' to guide the architects. The chief designer, Douglas Cardinal, is of Blackfoot ancestry.

title: A Sassy New Duet Danced to a Sprightly Old Solo
description: Eliot Feld has choreographically shouted ''Yo'' again. Last year he created ''Yo Shakespeare,'' a strenuous and sassy piece in which two men moved sometimes in competition and other times in cooperation to jaunty contemporary music by Michael Gordon. Now he's given us ''Yo Johann,'' an equally strenuous and sassy duet for the same men, Jason Jordan and Jassen Virolas. The music is just as jaunty. But this time the composer is Johann Sebastian Bach.

title: Showdown on the National Forests
description: Michael Dombeck made it clear from the start that he was going to be different from other Federal Forest Service chiefs. He wanted to trim the annual timber harvest, protect watersheds, restore wildlife habitat. He wanted to save the national forests, not cut them down.

title: Foreign Affairs; What the World Needs Now
description: You can learn a lot about President Clinton's predicament by studying the news conferences he recently held with two other world leaders, Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain and President Nelson Mandela of South Africa.

title: Jones Ruling Meets Letter of Harassment Law; Boorish Behavior
description: To the Editor:

title: Third Area Code Is Added In the Land of the Toll-Free
description: A third toll-free area code begins on Sunday, giving Americans eight million more numbers to call to reach operators standing by, to consult the Thanksgiving turkey hot line and, of course, to order now to get the Ginsu knife free.

title: Spain to Sell Its Stake In a Power Company
description: Spain said yesterday that it would sell its 41.2 percent stake in the powDer company Endesa S.A., valued at 1.7 trillion pesetas, or $11 billion.

title: INSIDE
description: Iraq Inspections Completed

title: WATERLINK TO ACQUIRE A GROUP OF COMPANIES
description: Waterlink Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire an undisclosed group of companies with combined annual revenue of more than $55 million. Waterlink, based in Canton, Ohio, provides water purification and waste water treatment services. It had sales of $64.7 million in the year that ended on Sept. 30. With the latest transaction, scheduled to close in June, Waterlink expects to have annual revenue of more than $185 million. Waterlink also said it had completed the acquisitions of Aquafine Engineering Services Ltd. and Purac Engineering Inc., which had combined revenues of about $16 million in the latest fiscal year.

title: Unemployment Rises (With an Asterisk)
description: After months in overdrive, the great American jobs engine seems suddenly to be idling.

title: Battery Reminder
description: Daylight time begins at 2 A.M. tomorrow; clocks should be set ahead an hour.

title: Moody's Issues a Warning On Japan's Credit Rating
description: The most creditworthy borrowers in Japan faced a new challenge today when Moody's Investors Service Inc. issued a pessimistic outlook about the nation's pristine credit rating.

title: Stuyvesant Needs Equal Admissions Policy; Getting Kids to Read
description: To the Editor:

title: INTERMEDIA COMMUNICATIONS BUYING NETWORK SPACE
description: Intermedia Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to buy space on the Williams Companies' telecommunications network for about $450 million. Intermedia said the 20-year agreement provided high-capacity transport for its integrated voice and data services. Under the deal, Intermedia receives the right to use about 14,000 route miles of Williams's network. The company said it expected the pact to reduce its transmission costs and added that it planned to connect about 50 cities in the next year. Williams, of Tulsa, Okla., provides natural gas and communications services, and had 1997 revenues of $4.40 billion. Intermedia, based in Tampa, Fla., had 1997 revenues of $247.8 million.

title: Harold E. Wilson, 76, Hero of the Korean War
description: Harold E. Wilson, a former Marine sergeant who won the Medal of Honor in the Korean War for ''heroic actions in the face of almost certain death'' in the Chinese Communists' massive human-wave offensive of April 1951, died on Sunday at Lexington Medical Center in West Columbia, S.C. He was 76 and lived in Lexington, S.C.

title: C.I.A. Charges Dismissed Spy Yielded Secrets
description: A veteran officer of the Central Intelligence Agency, enraged by his dismissal, tried to extort $500,000 from the C.I.A. in exchange for his loyalty and, when the agency would not buy his silence, told two foreign nations how the United States spied on them, officials said today.

title: Impotence Pill: Would It Also Help Women?
description: The buzz over the new impotence drug, Viagra, has prompted researchers to wonder whether it could improve the sex lives of women if they also took it. And, in the process, it is focusing attention on sex research in general and women's sexual problems in particular.

title: Divided Jury in L.I. Beating Case Is Asked to Deliberate Further
description: Jurors deliberating whether a 27-year-old white man from Queens attempted to murder a young black man during a racially charged brawl outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub two years ago said today that they were deadlocked, but the judge ordered them to try again to reach a verdict.

title: Jingles Ban Suspended Pending Court Hearing
description: The jangly strains of ''Turkey in the Straw'' and ''The Entertainer'' are free to ring out once more in the streets of Stafford Township, where officials have suspended a ban on ice cream truck jingles imposed last month.

title: Bangkok Journal; Was That a Lady I Saw You Boxing?
description: Muhammad Ali floated like a butterfly. Mike Tyson bites ears. Parinya Kiatbusaba, Thailand's kick-boxing sensation, pecks on the cheek.

title: Brooklyn Man Charged In Attempted Kidnapping
description: A Brooklyn man was charged with trying to abduct a child on a busy Park Slope street yesterday after the 8-year-old girl left school for lunch, the police said.

title: Washington Talk; Gingrich Sells New Book And Seeks Softer Image
description: Was it sheer coincidence that Newt Gingrich began the publicity tour for his latest book here in the Sheraton-Carlton's Presidential suite?

title: Stuyvesant Needs Equal Admissions Policy; Humanities Endure
description: To the Editor:

title: Memories of Lynching Divide a Town
description: Down by the Price River, the bare, twisted limbs of a dried-out cottonwood are enough to make a grown man shudder.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EPSTEIN, DIANA
description: EPSTEIN-Diana. On April 3, 1998. Co-owner of Tender Buttons. Beloved sister of Mel and Sheldon Green and Barbara Levin. Companion and partner of Millicent Safro. Also survived by many friends and the staff of Tender Buttons. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St Monday 11:30AM. Interment will be private.

title: Wargo Holds Lead With Birdie Binge
description: With the two hottest golfers on the Senior PGA Tour making it tight, Tom Wargo went on his own hot streak yesterday to increase his lead in The Tradition in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Saatchi & Saatchi Posts Earnings of $49 Million
description: Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. said yesterday that it earned $:29.7 million, or $49 million, on revenue of $:407 million in 1997. A year earlier, it earned $:23.3 million, or $38.9 million, on revenue of $:397.1 million. The results for Saatchi & Saatchi are the first since it was split off from Cordiant Communications Group P.L.C. in late 1997. They exclude the cost of the spinoff.

title: Tracking the '68 Parallels Of King and Kennedy
description: The public journeys of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert F. Kennedy come together tomorrow in ''Assassinated: The Last Days of King and Kennedy.'' As the unequaled black leader and the untested white politician moved toward their early deaths, they found themselves united in the causes of peace, racial equality and economic uplift.

title: GENERAL GROWTH PROPERTIES IN DENVER DEAL
description: General Growth Properties Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire a shopping mall in Denver from the developer Southwest Properties Venture for $64 million in cash and securities. General Growth, based in Chicago, is a real estate investment trust, which owns or manages 106 malls in 37 states. The mall to be acquired, Southwest Plaza, totals 1.3 million square feet and is 83 percent occupied. It is expected to produce about $10.5 million of net income in the next year. The purchase price consisted of $46 million in cash and $18 million in operating partnership units.

title: Reviews/Fashion; Iconoclasts Pursue Their Own Muses
description: American sportswear this season has emerged as decidedly no-nonsense, in contrast to the strong strain of romanticism evident in Europe, but the collections of Isaac Mizrahi and Patrick Robinson provided two important exceptions.

title: On Campus, the Cases For and Against Jeffries
description: If anything, Leonard Jeffries Jr. provokes passions.

title: Bang, Bang, Bang: Devils Lose
description: Suddenly, the best team in hockey is showing cracks. With the Stanley Cup playoffs approaching, alarms are sounding in the Devils' dressing room.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: About New York; For Workers, The Dream Marches On
description: MOE FONER sat in the glow of sunshine inside his office, where papers, posters and plaques were scattered about. He was on the phone or, more accurately, on hold, waiting for a car service dispatcher to get back to him. A heart condition and walking pneumonia make it hard for him to get around.

title: Companies Are Investigated For Aid to China on Rockets
description: A Federal grand jury is investigating whether two American companies illegally gave China space expertise that significantly advanced Beijing's ballistic missile program, according to Administration officials.

title: Times Names Chief For Labor Relations
description: The New York Times announced yesterday that Marc Z. Kramer had been named vice president for labor relations.

title: More Disappointment for 2 Rangers
description: Mike Richter and Brian Leetch said they were disappointed by the United States Olympic Committee's decision to exclude the American hockey team from a White House reception next month over an incident during which $3,000 in damage was done to a suite last February in Nagano, Japan.

title: For Jones, Appeal Court Is a Wild Card
description: If Paula Corbin Jones decides to appeal the ruling throwing out her lawsuit against President Clinton, her case will go before a generally conservative circuit court in St. Louis, with a record that could cut both ways for her case.

title: CARNIVAL IN $500 MILLION DEAL TO BUY CUNARD
description: The Carnival Corporation said yesterday that it and a group of investors would buy the Cunard cruise ship line from the Norwegian shipbuilder Kvaerner A.S.A. for $500 million, creating the world's largest luxury cruise line. Carnival, based in Miami, will merge Cunard with the Seabourn Cruise Line, which it owns in partnership with Atle Brynestad, a Norwegian businessman. Carnival will have a two-thirds interest in the combined company. Cunard's ships include the Queen Elizabeth 2 and the Sea Goddess I and II. Carnival's shares rose $2, to $74, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Campaign Ad By Kennelly Stresses Schools
description: With education emerging as the pivotal issue in the state elections this year, United States Representative Barbara B. Kennelly, a Democrat running for governor, has made ''Education comes first'' the slogan of her campaign's first television commercial, which began appearing today.

title: Sports of The Times; Nets Need Victories, Not Autographs
description: JACK HALEY walked into the visiting team's locker room Thursday night and asked for Shaquille O'Neal's autograph. He and his family then smiled and took pictures with Kobe Bryant.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TANG, GOODWIN, HOPE BABETTE, M.D.
description: TANG-GOODWIN-Hope Babette, M.D. on April 3, 1998. Assistant Professor of Pediatrics, Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons and Medical Director, The Women and Children Care Center at The Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. Beloved wife of James Goodwin and loving mother to Gordon TY Goodwin; sister to Hamilton Tang and Hamburg Tang, Jr.; devoted daughter of Hamburg and Miranda Tang. Funeral Mass Tuesday, April 7, 10:30 A.M., St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th St. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made to: The Hope Tang Goodwin Foundation, 39 East 79th St., NYC, NY 10021.

title: Outcast Grasps the Bird of Happiness
description: Life isn't any less difficult for a homeless man living in Turkey than it is for someone trying to survive on the streets of New York. Dervis Zaim's ''Somersault in a Coffin'' is a compassionate but hopelessly sketchy study of a drifter and petty criminal named Mahsun (Ahmet Ugurlu), who compulsively steals cars, sleeps in abandoned fishing boats and survives on day-old bread.

title: BERTUCCI'S, PIZZA CHAIN, IS SOUGHT BY NE RESTAURANT
description: Bertucci's Inc. said yesterday that the closely held NE Restaurant Corporation had offered to buy the pizza chain for $10.50 a share, or about $93.5 million, topping a previous bid of $8 a share from a Bertucci's management group. Bertucci's, based in Wakefield, Mass., operates 84 Bertucci's Brick Oven Pizzeria restaurants in the Northeast. NE Restaurant owns 31 Chili's Grill and Bar restaurants and two On the Border Mexican-style restaurants in the region. On Feb. 13, Bertucci's said it had agreed to be bought by Tenideas Inc., a management group led by Joseph Crugnale, Bertucci's chairman and chief executive, for about $72 million.

title: Bail for Man Accused In Burglary Spree
description: Bail was set at $500,000 yesterday for a man suspected of taking part in at least 60 burglaries in Bergen County during the last three months.

title: The Yankees Begin 0-2, And Now They'll Wait
description: Joe Torre's Yankee cap was tilted back high on his forehead after Thursday night's 10-2 loss to the Angels in Anaheim, a dumbfounded expression overwhelming his face. With a beer in his hand, he could have been a dead ringer for Walter Matthau as the manager of the Bad News Bears.

title: Beliefs; Courts are grappling with the constitutional issue of whether officials are promoting Christianity when they close public schools on Good Friday.
description: Do state laws closing public schools for Good Friday violate the Constitution's provision against the establishment of religion? Several years ago a 50-year-old Illinois law was struck down by a judge who said it did.

title: For Little Rock, the Buck Stops
description: The official position of Doe's Eat Place its steakhouse walls boasting notes signed ''Bill,'' thanking the owner for firm campaign support and tender porterhouse -- is immense joy and relief over the dismissal of the Paula Corbin Jones case in a courthouse right near here.

title: Oscar Awards to Get Their Own Theater
description: A permanent home for the Academy Awards show has been announced by Mayor Richard J. Riordan and the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

title: Clinton Warns Japan: Fire Up Economy to Stem a Decline
description: President Clinton warned in unusually explicit terms today that Japan must change course if it hopes to pull its economy out of a long-running decline that has worsened markedly in recent weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, EGON G.
description: FRANK-Egon G., 77. Of Monroe Twp., New Jersey, on April 2, 1998. Beloved wife of Hilda. Devoted father of Eva Young. Service 12 Noon, Sunday, at Mount Sinai Memorial Chapels, Cranbury Road and Evergreen Boulevard, East Brunswick, NJ. Burial Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN HITS 6 1/2-YEAR LOW. The yen fell after Moody's warned it might downgrade Japan's credit rating. The dollar hit 135.42 yen, the strongest since September 1991, before settling at 135.10 yen, up from 133.50.

title: Improvising a Troubled 13-Year-Old's Mind
description: David Williams's movie ''Thirteen'' belongs to a burgeoning genre that determinedly blurs the line between fiction and documentary filmmaking. Largely improvised, with no screenplay and featuring a cast that includes untrained actors as well as professionals, this portrait of a sullen, quirky 13-year-old black girl growing up in Richmond, feels utterly real during much (though not all) of its 87 minutes.

title: Rise by G.M. Trims Decline In Auto Sales
description: Auto sales fell 1.7 percent last month, but the decline would have been steeper without a rebate-fueled sales drive by the General Motors Corporation that helped obscure weak results at many other auto makers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, BERTHA
description: ADLER-Bertha. Of Deerfield Beach, FL., died of cancer on March 25, 1998. Survived by sons Richard, Stephen and Marty, grandchildren Eric, Jeff, Logan and Samantha, great-grandchildren Maxwell and Sydney.

title: Doctors Rebut the Accuser In Internet Torture Trial
description: Defense experts testified yesterday that there was virtually no medical evidence to support a woman's claim that she was tortured by Oliver Jovanovic, a Columbia University graduate student whom she met on the Internet.

description: NEW YORK  The Dow Jones industrial average topped 9,000 points for the first time Friday, reflecting seemingly insatiable demand for stocks from investors around the world.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Circuits section on Thursday about a computer game called Monster Rancher included an erroneous price provided by its maker, Tecmo Inc. The game costs $49.99, not $34.99.

description: Michael W. McCarthy, a former chairman of Merrill Lynch & Company who helped expand that brokerage firm into a global enterprise, died on Wednesday at his home in Indian Wells, Calif.

description: INTERNATIONAL A3-5

description: GANZ-Lou. The Seawane Club records with sorrow the loss of our beloved member Lou Ganz. We extend heartfelt sympathy to his family. Robert Roman, President

title: Hesitating Celebrity Couple Loses a Met Opera Contract
description: General managers of opera companies tend to be tough-skinned types who know how to calm fiery divas and placate high-strung tenors. But Joseph Volpe, the general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, has reached his limit with two of the Met's current celebrity singers, who are also the opera world's most famous married couple: the French-born Sicilian tenor Roberto Alagna and the glamorous Romanian soprano Angela Gheorghiu.

title: Day One Is Washout
description: Those tennis fans intrepid enough to brave severe thunderstorms in hopes of viewing Day 1 of the first-round Davis Cup encounter between the United States and Russia wound up pocketing their soggy American flags and unfurling umbrellas this afternoon at the International Tennis Center. An official washout was declared about 4:30 P.M. and both singles matches were postponed until Saturday because the team captains refused to start a match under the lights.

title: FAMILY GOLF TO PURCHASE EAGLE QUEST FOR $46.1 MILLION
description: Family Golf Centers Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Eagle Quest Golf Centers Inc. for about $46.1 million in stock, furthering its lead among golf center consolidators. Family Golf Centers, based in Melville, N.Y., operates golf-related operations like driving ranges, pro shops and snack bars. Its stock rose $4.0625 a share, to $44.0625, in Nasdaq trading. The acquisition allows Family Golf to expand into Texas, Seattle and Canada and establishes the company as the dominant player in the family golf center industry. Family Golf Centers also declared a 3-for-2 stock split, to be paid as a 50 percent stock dividend on May 4 to shareholders of record on April 20. As of March 26, Family Golf had nearly 13 million outstanding shares.

title: Covering Their Eyes With Parted Fingers
description: The New York Times asked a handful of scholars to comment on the apparent ambivalence of much of the country about the sexual accusations against President Clinton. News programs cover the issue constantly and receive higher ratings just when many Americans insist they are no longer interested and think the matter should be private. Here are excerpts from their answers, compiled by Janny Scott:

title: Swiss Central Bank to Fight Holocaust Claims
description: Switzerland's central bank served notice today with unusual bluntness that it would fight a planned class-action lawsuit in the United States that accuses the bank of accepting looted assets from Germany during the Nazi era.

title: CORSAIR COMMUNICATIONS ADDING SUBSCRIBER COMPUTING
description: Corsair Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Subscriber Computing Inc. for about $71.25 million in stock and cash to add software systems to the products that it sells to the wireless telecommunications industry. Corsair, which makes a computer system to combat cellular telephone fraud, will issue about $70 million in common shares to stockholders of Subscriber Computing, based in Irvine, Calif. Corsair will also pay the closely held Subscriber $1.25 million in cash for expenses related to the acquisition. Corsair said the purchase would add four ''major'' product lines, which include customer-billing and inventory-management systems.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, LILLIAN
description: HELLER-Lillian. The Board of Directors, Residents and Staff of the United Hebrew Geriatric Center mourn the passing of Mrs. Lillian Heller, beloved resident and mother-in-law of Allen Rich, esteemed member of our Board. We extend our sympathy and prayers to the Rich family. Malcolm Lazarus, President David Shatz, Chairman Rita C. Mabli, Executive Vice President

title: Lewinsky's Mother Questioned Again, but Not Before Jury
description: Investigators from the office of the Whitewater independent counsel, Kenneth W. Starr, questioned the mother of Monica S. Lewinsky again today but did so outside the foreboding confines of the grand jury room, said lawyers close to Mr. Starr's inquiry.

title: Daimler-Benz Profit Up 9% in 2d Half of '97
description: Daimler-Benz A.G., Germany's largest industrial company, said yesterday that its profit rose 9 percent in the second half of 1997, not counting a tax effect. Second-half profit rose to 2.208 billion marks, or $1.2 billion, from 2.018 billion marks, or $1.1 billion, a year earlier. The figure was calculated by subtracting the first-half earnings from the full-year figure. Including a 4.9-billion- mark tax bonus, in part because of losses in previous years, full-year net income almost tripled to 8 billion marks, or $4.3 billion, which was above expectations. Daimler benefited from a surging European truck industry.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONNER, JAMES C.
description: BONNER-James C. Age 50, of Fairfield, CT, died on April 2, 1998 in New York Hospital, New York City. Beloved husband of Susan Whidden Bonner and loving father of Christopher and Ellie Bonner. Brother to Peter Bonner of Swansea, MA, Nancy Ceccarelli of Marshfield, MA, Genny Pearce of Fairfield, CT., Susan Paden of Newark, DE, Sarah O'Neil of St. Simons, GA., and Margaret Bonner of Dallas, TX. Mr. Bonner was President and Senior Partner of Area Marketing Associates in New York City. A Memorial Service will be held on Monday, April 6, 1998 at 11 AM at Norfield Congregational Church, 64 Norfield Road, Weston, CT. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers the family requests that donations be made in his memory to: The Fund for Blood and Cancer Research, New York Hospital, 525 East 68th Street, New York, New York 10021.

title: Rejecting Racism in France
description: France's President, Jacques Chirac, is waging an admirable campaign to resist cooperation between his supporters and the racist and xenophobic National Front. He may not fully succeed. But his efforts set a good example for conservative parties elsewhere in Europe, where extremist parties of the far right are also gaining ground.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, JUDITH C.
description: SCHWARTZ-Judith C. Beloved mother of William Sinclair and Naomi Norman. Adoring grandmother to Alexandra, Michael, Rebecca and Anna Julie. Devoted aunt to Robert, Mitchell and Nancy. Loving friend to so many. She filled our lives with joy...touched our hearts with laughter. Her warmth, her inimitable wit and generosity of spirit lives on in all of us. Graveside services Sunday, 2 PM, at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, LI.

title: Dow Crosses 9,000 for the First Time, Then Backs Away
description: The Dow Jones industrial average passed 9,000 points yesterday before retreating and ending slightly lower as investors took profits.

title: Clinton Signals Showdown With G.O.P. Over Budget
description: Eager to shift the spotlight from Paula Corbin Jones back to the business of government, President Clinton today lambasted the Republican Senate budget proposal and warned tobacco companies to go along with a proposed settlement.

description: To the Editor:

title: Israelis Ask Arafat's Help to Stop a Hamas Attack
description: With the growing threat of a Hamas attack to avenge the death of a suspected bomb-maker, Israel sent its chief intelligence officer to Gaza on Thursday night to persuade Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, that Israel had nothing to do with the assassination and to enlist his help in blocking an attack.

title: Reviews/Fashion; Finding Ways Of Fitting In
description: Faced with the steamrolling might of companies like Ellen Tracy, small design houses had better have a taut idea to sell. Stores are interested in emerging lines that fit into overall themes already established by bigger names. The challenge to designers who lead small companies is to meld into this preset scheme while establishing their own identities.

title: Upset in High Jump At Texas Relays
description: Erin Aldrich upset Amy Acuff of U.C.L.A., who was ranked fifth in the world last year, in the high jump at the 71st Texas Relays yesterday in Austin. Both cleared 6 feet 2 inches and failed at 6-4i, with Aldrich, a University of Texas sophomore, winning on a first-jump clearance at 6-2.

title: Drury Named Best College Player
description: In his four seasons playing for Boston University, Chris Drury was a durable two-way performer who missed only two of 155 games, one because of injury and the other when Coach Jack Parker benched him as a freshman.

title: A Lilting History of Klezmer, With a Little Shtick Added
description: ''Hot Klezmer'' is the kind of show you'd like to love. After all, it's constructed around lively music and rooted in rich history. So the building blocks for success are in place.

title: The Game Behind the Gaming; Charges of Gtech Misconduct Fail to Shake Investors
description: It was a warm September day in 1993, and Richard Branson, the ubiquitous British billionaire, was having lunch in the sunny conservatory in his London town house. His guest was Guy B. Snowden, an American entrepreneur whose Gtech Holdings Corporation dominates the public lottery business worldwide.

title: Heldentenor, A Rare Bird No Longer?
description: Just as the opera world is rejoicing that a true heldentenor, Ben Heppner, has come into his own, another aspirant to this daunting repertory has arrived: Johan Botha, a 33-year-old tenor from South Africa. On Thursday, Mr. Botha stepped into the title role of Wagner's ''Lohengrin,'' which Mr. Heppner had been performing in the controversial new Robert Wilson production at the Metropolitan Opera, eloquently conducted by James Levine. And with this one performance, Mr. Botha established himself as a heldentenor of great accomplishment and even greater potential.

title: DEMOCRACY TO DESPOTISM: A special report.; Nigeria, in Free Fall, Seethes Under General
description: From the eerily calm streets of this newly created capital, a visitor might be excused for concluding that Nigeria's President, Gen. Sani Abacha, is a revered figure.

title: State Makes A Heavy Haul In House Bill For Transport
description: When the dust settled this week after the House passed its mammoth $217 billion, six-year highway bill, most New York lawmakers walked away ecstatic about the millions they managed to reap for their state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  REICH, ELSIE
description: REICH-Elsie. Our loving and devoted aunt and sister-in-law will be missed by Fran, Linda, Lois and Uncle Manny. Our love and deep condolences to all of Elsie's family, especially Norman, Joan, Barbara and Aunt Sally. The Rosenblatt Family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREEN, SHIRLEY
description: GREEN-Shirley, 70. Passed away Sunday, March 29, after a long battle with cancer. Memorial Services will be held on Saturday, April 4 at 7 P.M. at Kashi Ashram by the Pond. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to the River School in her name. For information please call 561-589-1403. ext 100.

title: A Debate on Activism in Black Studies; A Call to Protect Academic Integrity From Politics
description: IN the three decades since students demonstrated to create black studies programs on college campuses, more than 200 of them have been established. As the field matures, African-American scholars are re-examining the black intellectual tradition and debating whether black studies programs have gone off course. ''Who stole black studies?'' asks Manning Marable, the director of the Institute for Research in African-American Studies at Columbia University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, MINNIE
description: SHAPIRO-Minnie. Congregation Ahavath Torah of Englewood, NJ mourns the passing of our esteemed member. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Shmuel Goldin, Rabbi Gail Billig, President

title: After Reno, Partners Agree To Go Their Separate Ways
description: When two already married people run off together, there are two left on the sidelines, and it happens in bridge also. The victory of Paul Soloway of Mill Creek, Wash., and Bob Goldman of Highland Village, Tex., in the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams a week ago in Reno was the swan song of a great professional partnership. In the last two decades they have won a string of national and world titles, but this is apparently the end of the road for them at national level.

title: Driver Gets 240 Years in Prison for Bombing of Trade Center
description: Eyad Ismoil, the man who drove a rental van loaded with a homemade bomb into the World Trade Center garage in 1993 and caused the explosion that killed six people and injured hundreds of others, was sentenced yesterday to 240 years in prison.

title: Childs and Ward Struggling At the Worst Possible Time
description: It was easier for Chris Childs to be with the Nets two years ago. Less pressure, no hype. Having freedom from expectation meant wowing everyone as a play-making guard with a freewheeling style.

title: Cottages Can Stay, but Neighbor Will Loom; Skyscraper to Be Built on Top of a Manhattan Enclave
description: For more than a year, a handful of elderly and feisty tenants have been fighting to save their verdant Upper East Side enclave, known as the Cottages, from the wrecking ball.

title: Doctor Guilty In '96 Death Of Daughter
description: A Queens doctor who had fought a court battle to keep his 5-month-old daughter from being taken off a respirator was found guilty yesterday of causing her death by shaking her so violently two years ago that she was left brain dead.

title: Jones Ruling Meets Letter of Harassment Law; Protect the Presidency
description: To the Editor:

title: Jones Ruling Meets Letter of Harassment Law; Politically Motivated
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YEGEN, GLADYS (DR. GLADYS WINTER)
description: YEGEN-Gladys (Dr. Gladys Winter). Loving wife of the late Christian. Died April 2, 1998 at the age of 93. Formerly of Teaneck and Tenafly, New Jersey. Beloved mother of Laura Kahl (Jim), Christian Yegen (Lonna), Carol Lerer (Nat). Devoted grandmother of Katy, Kristy, and Laurie, Hillary and Christopher, Keith, Scott and David and nine great grandchildren. A graduate of Vassar College and Columbia College of Physicians and Surgeons. She practiced pediatrics in Teaneck, N.J. for 30 years. She leaves the legacy of love, kindness and caring for her family and friends. She was truly a women of uncommon virtue. Donations may be made to a charity of choice. A Memorial Service will be held at a later date.

title: Heroes, Victims, Gods and Humans
description: AS ''The Cure at Troy'' welcomely declaims its last words, the old, wounded, enraged and exiled Philoctetes, the possessor of the magic bow and arrows of Hercules, hobbles up the theater's aisle, as though into the great beyond. Here is the vision of an Olympics loser made to grasp at a last chance for glory. He is supported by the young, vibrant Neoptolemus, son of Achilles, who stirred him to reclaim his place among the living -- and to move on up from there.

title: Q&A/Elena deMurias; Banker to Museum Director With a Mission
description: WHEN the Discovery Museum in Bridgeport sought a new director in 1995, a startling 85 candidates applied. Only one did not have any prior museum experience. That was Elena deMurias, who landed the job.

title: Michelle Zweifler And Alan Helman
description: Dr. Michelle Zweifler, a chief surgical resident at Lenox Hill Hospital in New York, is to be married this evening to Alan Craig Helman, a senior account executive at Ampro Technologies, a computer-network consulting company in Kenilworth, N.J. Rabbi David D. Wirtschafer is to officiate at the Essex House in Manhattan.

title: Purposeful Purchases
description: THE best thing I ever bought while traveling was a brown felt buffalo, four inches long from horns to tail and fairly anatomically correct -- as I recall. I purchased it after saving my allowance for months and shopping with great deliberation in the gift store at the Y.M.C.A. Camp of the Rockies in Estes Park, Colo., where my family spent summer vacations during my childhood. The buffalo stayed on my bureau for years after that, reminding me of those halcyon Rocky Mountain days. But it's not there now, and I wonder what happened to it.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GANZ, LOUIS
description: GANZ-Louis. Father of Carol Ann Zinn and Robert Ganz, father-inlaw of Jo, grandfather of Adam, Omar, Nikki and Jackie. Gentle, strong, loving. Always his own man. We will all miss him. Services Sunday, 12 noon, Riverside Memorial Chapel, Mt. Vernon, NY.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: Taming the Wild Adolescent
description: When my kids were little, I would leave work each night thinking about the lyrical moment -- in Hollywood they'd shoot it in slow motion -- when I'd open the door and yell hello, and the kids' faces would light up, and they would run into my arms.

title: The Nation: Taking Offense; Perceptions and Facts In Sexual Harassment
description: PAULA CORBIN JONES cast herself as a woman not just discriminated against but damaged. She was ''bawling'' and ''squalling'' after her encounter with Bill Clinton, her sister said, and seven years after that infamous day in the Excelsior Hotel, in one therapist's opinion, Ms. Jones still suffered from ''sexual aversion.''

title: By The Book; Advise and Dissent
description: In mary mccarthy's novel ''the Group, two former Vassar classmates, babies in tow, meet in 1938 on a bench in Central Park, where they engage in a classic 20th-century maternal ritual. Eyeing each other's infant specimens, they start comparing expert-approved regimens.

title: Red Ink and the Rising Sun
description: THE MINISTRY

title: Fairness for Ken Starr
description: Throughout the long and winding course of the various investigations into a uniquely undisciplined and trouble-prone White House, we have argued for due process of law. We advocated that Paula Corbin Jones should have the full benefit of due process and that the President and First Lady should as well. Now it seems necessary to argue that the benefits of orderly legal process should be guaranteed for Kenneth Starr and the American people.

title: Student Dance Program
description: THE conjunction of Passover and Easter next weekend limits concert activity, so today's calendar is unusually crowded with events ranging from ancient voices of Italy to modern jazz from Brazil. In more or less chronological order, programs begin at 1 P.M., when works by Offenbach, Mendelssohn and Joplin are played at the yearly concert by students of the Westchester Theater of Dance at the Bendheim Performing Arts Center in New Rochelle. The dancer David Fernandez adds a professional touch to the program, which will be repeated at 4 P.M.

title: It's Deer Season, and It Should Be a Dandy
description: DEER, oh dear. Gardeners can brace themselves for a challenging year for several reasons. The main one is the bumper crop of acorns recorded for this past winter. And, of course, the season was relatively mild in the lower New England States. Deer herds survived well.

title: Classical Briefs
description: RAMEAU: OVERTURES

title: U.S. Auditing Five Hospitals In New York
description: Five teaching hospitals in New York City and Long Island are being investigated by the Federal Government to determine whether they submitted fraudulent Medicare bills for tens of millions of dollars.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LISKIN, ELLIOT
description: LISKIN-Elliot. April 5th. On this birthday and every day, always remembered . . . always loved and ''the memories linger on''. Grandchildren, Children and Joyce

title: VIEWPOINT; Clearing the Air Over Clearing Firms
description: IMAGINE that you have gone into debt to make a terrific feature film that has become the buzz of the Sundance Film Festival, and all that remains is to have your movie distributed, get some advertising and start making money. The problem is, you don't know any theater owners and you are neither an advertising executive nor an accountant.

title: As Wagner Intended
description: To the Editor:

title: The Changing Face Of America's Teachers
description: The lights went off inside the windowless, cinder-block room, and the television screen began to glow, filled with the grainy images of a Department of Defense video. As the 11 viewers took furious notes, the camera focused on a communications tower outside of Baghdad. Seconds later, the tower exploded, blown up by a bomb from the belly of an American plane.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGULIS, ESTHER (NEE EPSTEIN)
description: MARGULIS-Esther (nee Epstein). West Palm Beach, FL. Formerly of Mt. Vernon, NY. Beloved wife of the late Leon. Devoted mother of J. Reed Margulis, Nannette Baker and Anne Radin. Dear sister of Sonia Dortz. Loving grandmother of five grandchildren and two great - grandchildren. Services ''Wien & Wien,'' 129 Engle St., Englewood, NJ, on Sunday, April 5, 1998, at 12:30 PM.

title: Time Speeds Up as People Slow Down
description: NEW research shows that it's not just your imagination: time really does move faster as we get older. On March 24, which seems like only yesterday to me, The New York Times reported that, from middle age onward, we steadily fall behind the clock. For an elderly person, half an hour feels like 40 minutes, so actual clock time seems to be moving faster and faster.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Dreams of Quivira: Stories in Search of the Golden West. By Robert Franklin Gish. Clear Light Publishers, cloth, $24.95; paper, $14.95.

title: Attack of the Gadgets
description: Not long ago, I hit the tomato-red button on my white Braun coffee grinder. Silence. I panicked. Was my 22-year relationship with this countertop monument to 1970's modernism suddenly over? I don't usually get sentimental about machines, but I had watched this sleek cylinder flawlessly pulverize my beans for so long that, like many things from that era, it was starting to look new again.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: Aggressive Tactics Are Put to Good Use
description: WHILE building the American Century Companies into one of the nation's largest families of no-load mutual funds, James E. Stowers Jr. combined a growth-oriented investment philosophy with tight-fisted cost management -- personified by his habit of lunching on a peanut butter and jelly sandwich and an apple at his office here.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Mercy Road By Dalia Pagani. Delacorte, $21.95.

title: Gnomes and Nazis
description: The Swiss, the Gold,

title: Mutual Funds Report; How a Few Leapfrogged the Rest
description: WHAT a way to start the year. United States stock fund managers seized hold of the red-hot equity market and the best delivered returns as high as 24 percent, with only five diversified funds losing money in the first quarter.

title: When Art Became a Stage and Artists Actors
description: ALLAN KAPROW had the skinny. In 1958, when the young New York artist was beginning to mount the improvisational environment-events that he called Happenings, he wrote about the influence of Jackson Pollock's work in an article in Artnews magazine: ''Pollock, as I see him, left us at the point where we must become preoccupied with and even dazzled by the space and objects of our everyday life, either our bodies, clothes, rooms or, if need be, the vastness of 42d Street.''

title: Westwood Takes One-Stroke Lead
description: FREEPORT-MCDERMOTT CLASSIC

title: Coping With Catastrophe Abroad
description: Three days after an attack last January on 16 of its students and faculty touring Guatemala, St. Mary's College of Maryland issued a statement that the college would continue to lead students to study ''the diversity and beauty of human communities around the world.''

title: Essay on River Park Ignores Effort to Improve the Site
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Generations
description: To the Editor: I often read tales of grandparents taking grandchildren on trips (Practical Traveler, Feb. 22), but I would recommend one where grandchildren take grandparents. For my 90th birthday, two granddaughters took me on a trip to the Turks and Caicos for five days.

title: '97 Middle-Class Tax Relief Benefits Wealthy First
description: Last August, with Speaker Newt Gingrich at his side, President Clinton signed the Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997, praising it as a milestone that focused most of its benefits on the middle class through a $500 child tax credit, education tax breaks and the new Roth individual retirement accounts.

title: Arson Greets Religious Sect At a Colony In Montana
description: Jake Waldner turned off his table saw and, carrying a 2-by-4 in one hand, pointed to a gutted metal barn, where more than $70,000 worth of lumber for 15 Hutterite family homes was burned in March by an arsonist.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, OSCAR HAROLD
description: ISRAEL-Oscar Harold. Passed on April 2 at his home in Stamford, CT. He was a graduate of Ethical Culture Fieldston School excelling scholastically and athletically, where he held a 100 yard dash record for 26 years. Oscar graduated Dartmouth College, Class of '41 and received an MA in Business at Harvard. He served his country during World War II, eventually coordinating lend-lease operations in India and Burma. Upon his return he joined David's Specialty Shops eventually overseeing a chain of 54 stores, including L. Frank Co., Airport, and The Metro. He was a pioneer who first developed the ''Juniors'' concept in the apparel industry. He believed that mankind needed to work together to achieve global peace and was an early member of the United World Federalists and was a Vice President of the Center for War/ Peace Studies. He also sponsored many foster children around the world. Upon his retirement Oscar had been an active member of the Service Corps of Retired Executives in Norwalk, CT. He is survived by his brothers, Lawrence and Robert and his sons, Ronald, Tristan, Michael and James and four grandchildren. For service information call Gallagher's at 203-327-1313.

title: Liberties; Too Late for Libations
description: When the Africa trip began, White House photographers saw a sad, trapped look in the President's eyes.

title: The View From/Rosebrook Inn; Comfort Zone Made for the Internet
description: IT'S tea time at Rosebrook Inn, an English country-style retreat ''designed to make the most of your fleeting moments.'' In the drawing room, a fire crackles and a grandfather clock ticks companionably. The antique mahogany table has been set with a Battenberg lace tablecloth. Wine will accompany aged cheddar cheese served with homemade nut bread and pear slices. Soon there will be music, storytelling and lively conversation.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY; Round-the-World Ships Pause in Maryland
description: Baltimore and Annapolis are playing host to a celebration from April 23 to May 3 to welcome the nine ships sailing the Whitbread Round the World Race, one of the world's biggest sailing events.

title: Arctic Freeze to Tropic Breeze: 2 Saabs, 4 Days, 5,800 Miles
description: FOR a small Swedish car company, Saab is having a busy year, introducing not only the 9-5 luxury sedan, but also a largely reworked high-volume line, the 9-3 coupe, sedan and convertible.

title: PLUS: ROWING -- SAN DIEGO CLASSIC; Berkeley Has The Crews to Beat
description: California-Berkeley threw down the gauntlet yesterday, qualifying its varsity, junior varsity and novice men's heavyweight crews with first-place finishes in the opening heats of the San Diego Crew Classic. Berkeley's emergence as the crew to beat for today's Copley Cup heavyweight varsity title comes in the second year of Coach Steve Gladstone's second tenure as the school's head coach.

title: Mutual Funds Report; Gaining An Edge In Bonds
description: WITH the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index up 13.5 percent in the first quarter, investors with a case of vertigo may well be looking beyond stocks for something with a little less risk -- and perhaps with a dollop of yield. Bonds sound right.

title: What Hath Milbury Wrought? A Brawl.
description: No, said Mike Milbury, general manager and acting coach of the Islanders, he did not call a timeout in the third period of yesterday's game to embarrass the Rangers. He did not stop the action to let the Nassau Coliseum fans cheer his team and jeer the Rangers right after the Islanders went ahead by three goals with less than eight minutes remaining. He said he did not realize it would set off a long, wild, occasionally vicious gang fight between two terrible teams.

title: Now Accepting Applications for My Baby
description: In the three weeks since her baby was born, Gina Bruystens, 23, has feverishly, defiantly and exultantly done all the things she could not do when she was pregnant. She has pierced her ears, adding one more hole to the right side and two more holes to the left. She has also dyed her hair, using a bottle of 40 percent peroxide solution that she found at Hot Topic, a punk boutique near her home in Cucamonga, Calif. The goal was white streaks, but instead it all turned a rusty pumpkin orange, an accident she likes enough to keep.

title: Three Companies That Raised the Hurdles in the Stock-Options Chase
description: ONE common criticism of stock options is that they give executives immediate rewards for stock-price jumps caused more by broad market forces than by their individual efforts.

title: For Greens Of Germany, The Outlook Is Murky
description: Not too long ago, Germany's opposition Greens party seemed to be staking out a role as a political kingmaker. These days, to the chagrin of its friends and the glee of its foes, the ecologically minded party is being depicted more as the court jester.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LEIBNER, I. WALLACE, MD.
description: LEIBNER-I. Wallace, MD. April 7, 1988. Still very much part of our lives. The Family

title: At this flea market, just name your price
description: President Clinton once bought a small bronze frog. A German collector recently examined antique adding machines. Two soldiers eyed a case of silver coins.

title: Welcome Changes in Decor and Food
description: THE West End Cafe, in Carle Place, was part of a wave of casual Manhattan-style restaurants that swept the Island in the mid-1980's. Its lofty ceilings, sleek decor and high-tech exposed water pipes all said SoHo. The light-hearted, big-city food, however, had its ups and downs. That was then.

title: Back From Egypt
description: To the Editor: Since the terrorist attack near Luxor, many people have voiced the opinion that it is not safe to travel in Egypt. I recently returned from a trip to Cairo and Luxor, and want to describe my very positive experience. Wherever I went I was received with open arms. Many people greeted me with ''Welcome to Egypt'' as they were passing. Strangers shook my hand and asked me how I liked the country.

title: Backtalk; Compared With Tennis, Golf's a Drop in International Cup
description: There was an advertisement on television the other day promoting the Presidents Cup. That's just great. As if golf needed another cup. Last summer and fall I thought I was going to lose my mind with all these golf cups. First, there was the Walker Cup. Then the Ryder Cup. Then the Dunhill Cup. Golf world, please! Your cups runneth over.

title: For a Steel Work, You May Need a Steel Worker
description: AT first glance, the work installed in the garden of the Museum of Modern Art looks like a flat plane propped against the back wall. But that's just an optical illusion. Change your position, and it becomes a staircase cascading from thin air. Move again, and you'll see that the ''steps'' are irregular: each one a different shape, meeting its neighbor at a different angle. What's more, the stairs are punched with thousands of holes, making them sometimes appear opaque, other times almost gauzelike, depending on the light.

title: West Hinders Inquiry on Dumping as Rights Issue
description: Can dumping toxic waste violate human rights?

title: In Line for Local Camp, and a Bearable Summer
description: One by one, they arrived in the predawn chill, cloaked in fleece pullovers, warm-up jackets and windbreakers, forming a long, expectant line outside the Civic House in Memorial Park. Having left their spouses and children snoozing at home, they waited, determined to carry on a springtime ritual as predictable (and, some might say, essential) as setting the clocks ahead.

title: Almost Equal
description: After 13 years as a commercial litigator, Michael Scully was bored. Sure, he made good money and commanded his share of respect, but his life felt reduced to a predictable round of conference calls and court dates, to the single question of win or lose. More and more he fantasized about pursuing something he'd truly love, something unrelated to law. So in the spring of 1993 he told his wife, Doreen Lorenzo, that he wanted to quit. At the age of 38 he wanted to go back to school for a doctorate in American Studies -- a field that, among other things, offered no guarantee of future employment. And if she agreed, it would be up to her to support their family.

title: In Vietnam, A New Approach To English
description: Vietnam's English-language curriculum, hampered for decades by a lack of materials and trained teachers, is being revised for the first time in 17 years.

title: Dig Out the Ultrasuede! Halston's Coming Back.
description: LURKING amid the hype and hemlines of fashion week was the ghost of Halston, who put New York on the world map of high style. Now the man who vowed to ''dress America,'' and who wrecked his career by trying to do so at J. C. Penney, is the subject of a forthcoming movie, whose other major character is New York itself.

title: Battery Reminder
description: Daylight time began at 2 A.M. today; clocks should have been set ahead an hour.

title: In State's Churches, Celebrating Easter With Alleluias
description: ONE of the great sacred works frequently performed during Holy Week is Bach's ''St. John Passion.'' Excerpts from it will be heard in church services around the state, but the entire work will be presented twice at The Bushnell in Hartford, on Saturday at 8 P.M. and on Easter Sunday at 4 P.M.

title: In Mexico and the U.S., New Visas Produce Stress
description: Starting a sweeping new effort to control travel across the Mexican border, the American authorities have begun calling in border-crossing documents held for decades by millions of Mexicans to replace them with high-tech visas carrying a digital fingerprint.

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: TURNING STONES: My Days and Nights With Children at Risk

title: Profiting From Tax-Proof Companies
description: HERE'S a pleasantly rebellious thought for this tax season: After you pay the I.R.S., invest in some companies that don't have to.

title: The Outlet as Destination For Those Who Love a Sale; Desert Hills Premium Outlets
description: Driving down Interstate 10, from Los Angeles to Palm Springs, you can't miss Desert Hills Premium Outlets. After miles of stark desert landscape, intriguing billboards suddenly pop into view: Giorgio Armani General Store . . . Ann Taylor Loft . . . Kenneth Cole . . . Tommy Hilfiger . . . J. Crew. Ah, thinks the weary driver, civilization.

title: For Baby Boomers, A 90's Kind of Sit-In
description: From the moment she arrives at the santa Monica Alternative School House at 8 A.M., the principal, Viki Montera, is working the courtyard and classrooms. She spends about two and a half hours each morning listening to parents' ideas.

title: Computer Pornography on Campus
description: In a recent survey of 200 colleges, 66 percent reported that at least one complaint had been filed with school officials about being harassed by a sexually provocative E-mail or other computer transmission; 52 percent of the colleges had also received complaints about students displaying pornography on their computers.

title: Holly McGhee, Michael Steiner
description: Holly Marcia McGhee and Michael Alan Steiner were married yesterday at the Friends Meeting House in Manhattan. The Rev. Sean B. Murray, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIVETTA, GERALD P.
description: CIVETTA-Gerald P. On April 4, 1998. Beloved husband of Hyehwa. Devoted son of Alma and the late Guido Civetta. Loving brother of Denise and Cesare. Dear uncle of Tiffany, Samantha, Byungchun. Family will receive friends today from 2-4 and 7-9 pm at F. Ruggiero & Sons, Inc., 726 Morris Park Ave, Bronx, NY 10462. Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated at St. Lucy's Church on Monday, 9:45 am. Entombment will follow at Ferncliff Mausoleum. The family has suggested that donations be made to Gerald's favorite charities: The Fresh Air Fund or City Harvest.

title: Karma at Tramps: Deafening Rock, Quiet Krishnas
description: The scene at Tramps, a club on West 21st Street, last Sunday night resembled that of a hardcore rock concert, with slam-dancing fans and wildly hirsute musicians tearing at their instruments and the eardrums of the crowd.

title: Word for Word / Sponsoring a Child; Donations From the Heart, Greetings From the Grave
description: THERE are few images more powerful than the faces of forlorn and hungry children. A picture of a sad-eyed child can cut through politics, religion, even racial prejudice to touch whatever is maternal or paternal in the human heart.

title: A Movable Sushi Feast
description: When Howard Green, a pharmaceuticals salesman, entertains clients for lunch in midtown, he takes them to Genki Sushi. ''Out-of-towners love it, and the best thing is none of us get bored,'' he said. Why should they? The colorful lunch spot, at 9 East 46th Street and designed by Alison Spear in shades of orange and red, features a conveyor belt with plates of sushi, sashimi, vegetables and desserts. The belt moves along the rim of an amoeba-shaped bar, with chefs standing in the middle preparing the food and customers sitting along the outside making choices. The color of the dishes determines the cost of the meal; prices range from $2.50 (red) to $5.50 (yellow) to $7.50 (green).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, ROSE (NEE SLOOP)
description: SCHWARTZ-Rose (nee Sloop), 51. Of Tamarac, Fla., March 27, 1998. Beloved mother of Kenneth and Scott; dear sister of Stephen, Ronald (Anne), David (Holly); beloved aunt of Jessica (Richard), Emily, Samantha and Jordan; niece of Mildred, Paul, Ebby, and beloved cousin of Karen, Alice (Sol), Stephanie (Hy), Aileen, Ross (Bobby), Lee (Donna).

title: A Big Bash For a Gucci Light Box
description: IT made total sense that the quarterly publication Visionaire would introduce its 24th issue during the peak of Fashion Week. When else could you invite Giorgio Armani, Calvin Klein and Donatella Versace to a party and have them all show up?

title: The Macaroni Chronicles
description: My mother learned to cook, as girls of her generation did, in the natural course of events. She relearned after she married, trading in her old-fashioned methods and recipes for the timesaving back-of-the-box formulas that were all the rage in the early 50's.

description: FASCH: CONCERTOS AND ORCHESTRAL SUITES

title: Hold the Applause, Indeed
description: To the Editor:

title: Habitats/95 Vandam Street; After 3 Misfires, He Walks Into the Loft He Wants
description: GETTING outbid on loft space can have a happy ending. With the clock ticking on the two-year deadline for reinvesting the capital gain from his 1995 sale of a TriBeCa loft, Greg Di Benedetto lost out three times in his attempts to buy another space. title: Good Clean Fun
description: Modern design is about distillation -- the act of boiling elements down to their essence and eliminating the unnecessary, while keeping what delights the eye. That is why the best modern furnishings and accessories look at home in any setting. A Robsjohn-Gibbings floor lamp next to an 18th-century French chair? A 1940's Swedish vase on a 19th-century Chinese chest? Why not? After all, Robsjohn-Gibbings looked back to the creations of ancient Greece for inspiration. Mid-20th-century ceramicists studied the forms and glazes of antique Far Eastern porcelains. This century's designers have not set out to reinvent the wheel, but -- with modern materials and manufacturing methods -- they have succeeded in reinterpreting it. For example, a kitchen's surfaces juxtapose cutting-edge synthetic materials with more traditional natural ones. The objects and rooms shown in these pages are emphatically of their respective modern moments, and yet timeless in their purity. P.V.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEONG, ELLEN. DR. ELLEN FOOK, LEN LEONG
description: LEONG-Ellen. Dr. Ellen Fook-len Leong, 96, died peaceably at home in New York City on March 12, 1998. Born October 31, 1901 on Kauai, HI. She received her MD in 1926 from Rush Medical College to become one of the first woman doctors in Hawaii. In 1937 she was appointed to the head of the OBGYN Clinic at the Red Cross Hospital in Shanghai, China. In 1946 she and husband, Dr. Tzu-Pei Chou, established an office in New York City where she became affiliated with the New York Infirmary specializing in OB-GYN. At over 70 years of age, she began a new career in Acupuncture which she actively practiced until retirement in 1989. She was a founding member and once President of the New York Society of Acupuncture for Physicians and Dentists. She had many hobbies and was an accomplished musician. Ellen is survived by two sisters, Irene Wong and Elizabeth Lee; two sons, Frederick and Wayne; two grandsons, Philip and Michael; and two great-grandsons, Andrew and Brendan. A memorial service will be held at 3 PM on April 11, 1998 in the Chapel of St. George's Episcopal Church on Stuyvesant Square, located off of East 17th Street between Second and Third Avenues in New York, NY. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in remembrance of Dr. Ellen Leong Chou to: Cabrini Medical Center, Home Health Agency, 227 E. 19th Street, New York, N.Y. 10003, Attn: Faye-Ellen Lane. Please indicate your wishes for donations to either the Hospice or the Home Health Care Unit.

title: Living With Modernism
description: Anything modern, as the word implies, must change with the times. But the funda-mental ideas of early modernism -- those of openness, lightness and the lack of applied ornamentation -- are as valid today as they were 60 years ago, a fact demonstrated by the architecture and design presented in this issue. Ranging from classically modern to cutting-edge contemporary, everything here exudes a calm, uncluttered order that is bathed in light. It also refutes the argument that modern design is cold, slick and untouchable. In these rooms, glass and steel gleam with jewel-like precision, wood reveals its sensual texture, and even concrete can seem warm. And whether their prevailing esthetic is highly machined or hand-hewn, these interiors are full of details that please the eye as well as the hand. But most important, these are places with personality -- after seeing them, you know as much about their owners as you do about their designers. In today's modern house, there is plenty of living room. Pilar Viladas

Chan and Sons, one of the last of the city's great custom tailoring shops. As soon as I announced I wanted a suit made, it appeared that neither chicken flu nor crashing stock markets nor the return of the Chinese Government could keep these master craftsmen from working their measuring-tape magic. Suddenly, I was at the center of a storm of white chalk, straight pins and perspiration. Tang Yan Choi, a stout, tough-looking man, who -- like many of the best Chinese tailors -- claims Shanghai as his place of origin, tapped me in eight or nine places and grunted out something in Cantonese, while Raymond K. K. Kiang, the manager of the 41-year-old shop, took furious notes.

title: Keeping Cool, Comfy And Chic
description: It was a preview of the fall collections, but the unexpected July weather last week turned Fashion Week into a showing of summer style. The thousands of guests attending the shows in Bryant Park created a fashion meltdown: slip dresses, tank tops, hair swept up off the neck into French twists, some anchored with butterfly clips. The biggest story: open sandals.

title: Doggie Appeal

The partners ended the business a year ago, and now Mr. Edwards is back, by himself, at 473 Park Avenue (58th Street), with a new line of women's shoes and with plans to add men's next month. The shoes, in materials like napa leather, ostrich and alligator, start at $355.

title: Offering Women Fiscal Plan

Yet several years ago, Ms. O'Brien, divorced and the mother of two college-age children, felt uncertain and at a crossroads.

title: Car Talk

And what about a mother to take her? Well, that's the tough part. When she was 8 years old, Pamela's mom, Stephanie, died of complications from Crohn's disease, and ever since then Pamela has been living only with her father.

The disaster that sank the great ship also ended an era of unwavering faith in the infallibility of technology. But although the Titanic's maiden voyage lasted only five days, the lore and legend of the doomed vessel live on, through exploration of the wreck and through the current Broadway musical and Academy Award-winning film epic. Below, test your knowledge of the world's most famous nautical tragedy.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Archives of Innocence
description: For centuries until the Nazis, Poland was the heart of Jewish life in Europe. More than 75 percent of American Jews, it is estimated, can trace at least one grandparent to somewhere in Poland as it existed before the German onslaught of 1939. Poland's Jews bore the brunt of the Holocaust. But a significant part of their history has survived in municipal and Jewish archives. JEWISH ROOTS IN POLAND: Pages from the Past and Archival Inventories (Roots to Roots Foundation / YIVO Institute for Jewish Research, $50), by Miriam Weiner, a co-editor of ''The Encyclopedia of Jewish Genealogy,'' offers an authoritative guide to what records still exist and where they can be found. A town-by-town index to archives shows, for example, that in Lublin tax rolls go back to 1716 and Jewish community records to 1775. But there is far more than archival listings. There are hundreds of poignant photographs and old tinted postcards of scenes from the early years of the century, panoramas of aching nostalgia, given what we know about what was to come. A 1916 picture of a town square in Oswiecim, near what was to become the Auschwitz-Birkenau extermination camp, serves as a reminder that before such places became synonyms for horror, they were just places, with streets where people shopped and children played. Ralph Blumenthal

It was a passive smile, but his eyes conveyed an inner resolve as cool as the mountain wind that blows in Zacatecas, his hometown in Mexico.

description: THE three-bedroom semiattached two-story house that Don Lippencott selected at Harborview at Port Jefferson, under construction on a hill overlooking this village and its harbor, sells in other parts of the development for $269,000.
