Inside hot spots like the Wag Club and Hippodrome, she noticed that self-contained coffee lounges and souvenir shops were doing a hot business. Ms. Quinto, who owns Quinto & Company Public Relations in SoHo, thought the concept would work well for one of her clients, Illig, a maker of club wear like track pants and tongue-in-cheek hockey jerseys with a ''Waco'' logo.

title: Crime
description: Anna Pigeon, the intrepid National Park Service ranger in Nevada Barr's superb wilderness mysteries, has had some perilous experiences in the five novels that preceded BLIND DESCENT (Putnam, $22.95), but none compare with this thrilling subterranean adventure in the underground canyons of Lechuguilla, ''a monster man-eating cave'' in New Mexico's Carlsbad Caverns. When a fellow ranger is injured in a caving accident, Anna chokes back the willies of claustrophobia and joins the rescue team. Burrowing 800 feet below ground, she negotiates airless tunnels, gaping pits, vaulting caverns and silently flowing rivers, each hazard with a daunting nickname like Razor Blade Run or the Wormhole. At the end of the dangerous descent, she reaches her friend and hears her say, ''It wasn't an accident.''

title: Material Man
description: Things, like people, get a thrill out of being where they don't belong. And that thrill has often galva-nized, inspired and animated modern design. Ever since Marcel Breuer borrowed the steel tubing from a bicycle's handlebars to make elegant, chrome-plated chairs in 1925, creative thinkers have been reinventing industrial materials for use in the home.

title: Fixing and Modifying Threaded Water Pipe
description: HOMES built in the last 30 years have water pipes of copper, or possibly plastic. Copper is relatively easy to install because it is lightweight and the pieces can be joined by soldering. Plastic pipes are lightweight and inexpensive, and the parts are usually joined with solvent.

title: A New Generation, A New Mission
description: Daniel Fergus Tamulonis says he was inspired by the Peace Corps' invitation to talk to a Harlem high school about his experiences as a volunteer. So he decided to track down a former pupil, Elie Bamwesa Mbumina, whom he had taught English 20 years earlier in Zaire. He found his old student through the Internet. Mr. Mbumina had immigrated to the United States and become a French teacher at North Carolina A&T State University, in Greensboro. In what turned into a happy reunion, Mr. Mbumina joined Mr. Tamulonis (pictured at right) in front of the next generation of potential Peace Corps volunteers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNES, STEPHEN C.
description: JOHNES-Stephen C. Manager of the Merrill Lynch Growth Fund, died at his home in Princeton, New Jersey on Sunday, March 29, of Lou Gehrig's Disease (ALS). Son of the late Alfred and Elisabeth, Stephen graduated from the Loomis School and Cornell University and served in the U.S. Marine Corps. He was with White, Weld & Co. in New York, later managed the New Jersey State Pension Fund and was a managing director at Trust Company of the West. He joined Merrill Lynch in 1987 where he started The Growth Fund, which grew to $8.5 billion in assets. Stephen was a member of The California Club and The Bel Air Bay Club of Los Angeles, and The Brook Club of New York. He is survived by his brother Carl, his daughters Stephanie and Alexandra, their mother Carolyn MacKenzie, his god daughter Maude Duke, and his beloved friend, Anne de Selys of Brussels. His generous and adventurous spirit will always be remembered. A memorial service will be held at Miller Chapel, Princeton Theological Seminary, on Saturday, April 18th at 11 a.m. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be sent to the ALS Association, Greater Philadelphia Chapter, 980 Harvest Drive, Suite 105, Blue Bell, PA 19422.

title: Who's Got Time to Stay at Home?
description: One day recently, Elizabeth Munro was with her youngest child, Henry, 5 1/2, at a mall near their home in the Boston suburbs where the child was playing with his second-favorite toy, the escalator, gleefully riding up and down while his trim, athletic mother followed. His favorite toy, for the record, is any of his collection of action figures, and he would like to go to Power Ranger Camp sometime, where kids get to play with plastic figurines all day, drink action milk and learn karate -- a camp that doesn't exist except in his imagination. Henry's shoelace threatened to catch at the bottom of the moving steps, but before any mishap, his mother scooped the child to safety. As she crouched to offer a reprimand, the child said, ''Don't yell at me since I almost got hurt.'' To which his mother replied: ''This is why you must never, ever run ahead of me on the escalator. You have to be careful, Henry.''

title: Whose Hoop Dream Is It, Anyway?
description: My son's godparents live in England. ''Why is everyone so obsessed with lecturing you about the virtue of sports?'' they asked me during a recent visit to New York. It was one of those questions that make you instantly aware of cultural boundaries, for in fact I have never felt lectured, and I don't think my friends here are really obsessed. Yet upon further discussion, it became clear that what the godparents were responding to was an undeniable shift in some people's image of me ever since I adopted my son. Seemingly overnight, I was transformed from a spinsterish, over-40 law professor in an ''all-male world'' into the roiling Medusa archetype of Black Single Mother. What they were observing, in other words, was a low drumbeat of worried chiding from numerous male friends and acquaintances that I deliver my son up to the great gods of sports.

description: It began in 1978, Bob J. Frye recalled, as a way to break the ice at the beginning of the semester for his English composition class at Texas Christian University, in Fort Worth. He would write a letter introducing himself to the class, then ask each student to write a letter to him, once a week. No grades on the letters; just an exercise.

title: Tall Structures, Small Screen, Finnish Fascination
description: Maybe because there aren't any in Finland, a land of low-rise buildings, Erkki Dankwa, 27, a Finnish architect, became fascinated with skyscrapers.

title: Artists in Residence
description: The New York loft of Robert M. Greenberg and Corvova Choy Lee, recently renovated by Smith-Miller & Hawkinson Architects, is about as modern as modern gets. It has lots of steel and glass, furniture by an array of 20th-century masters, a media room controlled by a touch-screen panel and up-to-the-minute ISDN lines at every telephone jack. But this spacious, 7,500-square-foot interior also boasts dazzling amounts of sunlight; an artist's studio; paintings and sculpture in most of the rooms, and collections of small objects like painted antique fish decoys. There's high tech, but also plenty of handcraft. It's art that's state of the art.

description: CHURRASCARIA PLATAFORMA** [Rating: Two Stars]

title: Nets Refuse To Fold Against The Knicks
description: He thought about sprinting onto the court and hugging Kerry Kittles immediately. But in all the commotion, Keith Van Horn's exuberance was stalled by one agonizing thought:

title: Pack A Pixie Purse
description: With a flip of her wrist, Joan Sparks, 26, a designer for a new-media company in SoHo, reached into her miniature yellow and white purse and pulled out a Metrocard and a Chanel lipstick. ''I'm not a pocketbook lemming,'' she said, as she applied a coat of pink to her lips. ''I like to have something unique that not everyone on the street is carrying.'' Her bag, 6 1/2 by 7 inches, is by Pixie Yates, a 30-year-old designer based in SoHo, whose creations are selling fast at stores large and small, including Barneys New York; TG-170, 170 Ludlow Street (Stanton Street), and Hughie, a boutique in Aventura, Fla. The bags are made of nylon, cost $35 and come in bright colors and plaids, some with embroidery. They can fit inside a larger bag or be carried solo for evening. For those thinking ahead, they will be available in tweed for fall.

description: BACH FAMILY: MOTETS

title: The Outlet as Destination For Those Who Love a Sale; Discount Mania
description: Forget about the Statue of Liberty, Yellowstone or Universal Studios. Outlet shopping malls are rapidly becoming the major attraction for travelers and bargain-hunting shoppers from all over the world. CHARLES V. BAGLI

title: A market of letters for reading or framing
description: Behind Istanbul's sprawling Grand Bazaar is a narrow alley leading toward historic Beyazit Square and the grand portal of Istanbul University. It has been a book and paper market since the Byzantine period, and during the 19th and early 20th centuries it was a center for the distribution of books throughout the Ottoman Empire. Today, it is not only a bibliophile's paradise but also an ideal place to shop for magnificent examples of calligraphy.

title: TODAY'S SECTIONS
description: Special Today: Home Design/Magazine Part 2

title: Deals and Discounts
description: BRITRAIL BREAK -- Britrail has introduced a Party Pass for three or four people that affords a 50 percent discount on the third and fourth passes. In effect, a group of four can buy four passes for the price of three. The prices of a four-day Flexipass for each of a group of four people range from $131 a person for a youth (16 to 25) in standard class to $236 a person for an adult traveling in first class. The Flexipass allows four travel days in a month. The group discount can also be combined with the Britrail Family Pass, which provides a free rail pass to a child 5 to 15 accompanying a full-fare adult. (So two children can tra vel free with a group of three or four adults on the Party Pass.) Reservations: (888) 274-8724.

title: Martin Wanner, Robin Altman
description: Robin Alise Altman, the daughter of Marlene and Murray Altman of St. Louis, was married last evening to Martin Francis Wanner, a son of Virginia Wanner of Alpine, N.J., and the late Hans Wanner. Rabbi Charles D. Lippman officiated at the Hudson Theater in New York.

title: Turning Cartwheels Instead of Singing Arias
description: AS the name of a medieval performance genre as well as a performing troupe, Peking Opera seems more than a world away from opera as Western culture pictures it. So don't even think about ''Turandot.''

title: In the Region/Connecticut; At 91, Philip Johnson Ruminates in His Glass House
description: AS Philip Johnson, arguably America's most celebrated living architect, prepares his famous Glass House here to become the main attraction of a museum after his death, he gives little indication of leaving this world anytime soon.

title: Executive Forfeiture
description: Roger A. Enrico, Pepsico's chief executive officer, is forfeiting all but $1 of his $900,000 annual salary to provide scholarships for Pepsico employees' children. Calling employees who earn less than $60,000 a year the front line of the company, Mr. Enrico said, ''I decided to do something personal, as a way to say thanks to our often unsung heroes.''

title: When Time Is of the Essence, Try Chicken Breasts
description: WHEN I cook chicken I usually roast it whole or cut it up and grill the pieces. But recently, being in a bit of a hurry, I decided to buy only the breast meat, which cooks in minutes.

title: FILM; The Silents Prove Golden For a New Set of Filmgoers
description: THIRTY minutes before show time, a line of moviegoers on the Upper West Side of Manhattan stretched half a block into the freezing afternoon. It was a mostly under-40 crowd, wearing parkas, jeans and eager looks.

title: Barbie Moves to the Village
description: GROWING up the only girl in a big Midwest clan of boys, I was Mattel's best customer. I had 68 Barbies, one Ken, one G.I. Joe I stole from my brothers, 12 Little Kiddles and 28 Dawn dolls so tiny that instead of changing their clothes I switched their heads. To avoid my real family, I'd sit on my pink carpet and play with 110 members of my doll family, who resided happily in Barbie's Dream House, with my mother's sanitary napkins stacked as bunk beds.

title: Worried About Baby Sitters? Tape Them
description: WHEN a Rockville Centre nanny was caught on videotape last December, allegedly abusing a toddler sexually, working parents all over Long Island shuddered. But some did more than worry; they got in touch with one of several Long Island companies that install spying equipment in the home for the purpose of monitoring child caregivers.

title: Lipinski Criticized
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Relatives of Air Crash Victims Press Fight to Sue Government
description: Two years after an Air Force plane crashed in Croatia, killing Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown and the other 34 people aboard, families of some of the victims have made little progress in their effort to win from Congress the right to sue the Government.

title: Ideas & Trends; What Goes Up May Keep Going Up
description: THE Dow Jones industrial average passed another impassable barrier, rising above 9,000 for a while on Friday, the first time that had ever happened. Each time the Dow has racked up another thousand points, there has been no shortage of experts warning that stock prices cannot keep going up like this. But they do. And as the market goes through one barrier after another, even the Cassandras, having been burned too often, bone up on the rationale for a rising Dow.

title: Fake-License Suspects Are Arrested Again
description: State Police announced last week that they had charged seven men with operating a counterfeiting ring that sold thousands of near-perfect driver's licenses to college students along the East Coast. The day after the announcement, investigators discovered three suspects apparently trying to re-start the operation while on bail, officials said.

title: His Own Man
description: To the Editor:

title: A British Battle Royal, Smashingly Operatic
description: BRITAIN used to be called Das Land Ohne Musik, The Country Without Music, a designation that secretly made us Brits rather proud. The words themselves and the very idea of ''culture'' were, after all, foreign, and ever since Cromwell and his Major Generals, there has been a strong insular tradition of regarding art as indecent if not downright dangerous. This attitude, in fact, may have been one of our less welcome exports across the Atlantic.

title: O.K., So Where Do You See Yourself In Five Years?
description: To hear the folks in human resources tell it, interviews bring out the oddest behavior in some applicants. Job seekers, though, have their own stories about interviewers who aren't ready for prime time. Applicants, unite and reveal all! Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. title: Scanner Spoils Film In Checked Bags
description: The new equipment that looks for bombs in the checked baggage of airline passengers also lays stripes on photographic film packed inside, according to the Federal Aviation Administration and the manufacturer. When the picture is developed into a 4-by-6 print, the stripe is about as thick as three lines of type in this newspaper, and consists of graininess or color change.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on March 15 about Lift Gym, at 139 East 57th Street, misstated its policy on fees for personal trainers who use the gym. Although fees are waived for trainers who have at least five members of the gym as clients, trainers who have fewer than five must pay them.

title: John Alessio, 87, Businessman And California Political Force
description: John S. Alessio, a California entrepreneur who began his working life shining shoes in San Diego and went on to amass millions as a banker, businessman, restaurateur and race-track operator, died of cancer on March 24 at Scripps Green Hospital in La Jolla, Calif., his daughter Rose Marie Rosa said. He was 87 and lived in La Mesa, Calif.

title: Mutual Funds Report; Slice, Dice and Scrutinize: Risk Measurements Draw a Crowd
description: IT all started during the Renaissance, when a handful of gamblers tried to figure the odds of winning and losing money at cards and dice.

title: The Outlet as Destination For Those Who Love a Sale; Clinton Crossing Premium Outlets
description: Just off Interstate 95, about 100 asphalt-covered miles from Times Square, is Clinton Crossing, the 18-month-old discount outlet mall with the big signpost that trumpets Polo, Donna Karan, Liz Claiborne, the Gap Outlet and others. There is no warning: The signpost is on your left, the exit (Exit 63) is on your right.

title: The World; Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventures
description: The terms huge appetite and ambition apply to both men. One pioneered activist, progressive American government while the other kept it on life support. But Teddy Roosevelt and Bill Clinton part company when it comes to African safaris. Check the contrasts between this President's 90's-kinda nature outing in Botswana last week and T. R.'s blood-drenched, 11-month expedition across East Africa in 1909-10, as the rough-riding ex-President geared up for another charge at the White House. You could call this not-so-woolly vs. Bully!

title: Productivity as the Catalyst of Prosperity
description: LIKE scientists poring over a petri dish and quarreling about what the microscope shows, economists these days have been squinting at the ''new era'' economy to spot a sign -- any sign -- of the kind of growth that really matters. Yes, output is swelling and jobs are multiplying, the stock market is robust and inflation dormant. But what about productivity?

Beneath the Louvre, under its main courtyard and its manicured hedges, awaits an underground complex of shopping galleries full of wonderful things: Lalique crystal, foie gras, anthologies of poetry, reproductions from the museum galleries and stylish clothes for thin women and men.

A woman so easy to love, she still fills our spirit with her presence. Gathering For Remembrance: 8PM, 26 April, Hudson River Club, 4 World Financial Center. All who knew her will be there.

title: By the Numbers
description: To understand the transformation that has occurred in American attitudes toward the role of mothers, consider this question, which has been asked in national surveys over two decades: ''Do you agree or disagree that it is much better for everyone involved if the man is the achiever outside the home and the woman takes care of the home and the family?'' In 1977, 66 percent of adults agreed. By 1996, the figure had fallen to 38 percent.

title: Michael Malamut, Catherine Milch
description: Dr. Catherine Elizabeth Milch, an internist at New England Medical Center in Boston, and Michael Eric Malamut, an assistant general counsel for the Boston Housing Authority, are to be married this afternoon at Temple Israel in Boston. Rabbi Bernard Mehlman is to perform the ceremony.

title: Disney Wished Upon Times Sq. And Rescued a Stalled Dream
description: On a breezy summer day in 1993, a top Disney executive picked his way along 42d Street with a video camera, the viewfinder filling with images of the crumbling theaters and shuttered storefronts slung between Eighth Avenue and Broadway. It was not a vision he wanted to take back to California, where his bosses were weighing a radical idea: lending Disney's wholesome name to a street that had become a byword for urban decay and failed renewal plans.

title: Sidney Stewart Is Dead at 78; Bataan Death March Survivor
description: Sidney Stewart, a survivor of the Bataan death march and three years in Japanese captivity in World War II who wrote the highly praised memoir ''Give Us This Day,'' an account of how the prisoners endured their intense suffering, died on March 18 at a hospital in Paris. He was 78 and lived in Paris.

title: Spice World
description: THE term Namaskaar refers to the Indian pressed-palms greeting, and it suits the restaurant, a bit of grace in an otherwise drab mall. Beyond the concrete face of the mall, which is also appropriately named, the unlyrical Mall at IV, Namaskaar drapes its tables in linen, covers its walls with mirrors and brightens its mood with red carnations. The vast space and otherworldly demeanor of the servers also obscures the fact that you are in Paramus and not in, say, the Marabar Caves.

description: It's strange that there's a debate over whether our President should apologize for slavery. I thought our greatest President, Abraham Lincoln, already did, in his Second Inaugural Address.

title: Simple Gifts
description: Anita Calero's kitchen is simple and unadorned, yet quite elegant -- rather like Calero herself. Her domestic esthetic embraces materials both rugged and fine, forms both imperfect and perfect, and objects both humble and luxurious. All are arranged with Calero's seemingly effortless grace, which is why she was such a sought-after photo stylist before deciding, two and a half years ago, to get behind the camera herself. Now, her light-filled kitchen in Manhattan's Chelsea neighborhood does double duty: by day, it is used by her studio staff; by night, it is where guests gather around the dinner table. That table -- a postwar steel and wood design by the French modernist architect Jean Prouve -- is all you see of the kitchen at first, which is exactly the point.''I wanted people to be drawn to the space, and then to discover that it's a kitchen,'' Calero explains. She worked with the designer Lora Zarubin to arrive at the right balance of practical planning and sensual materials and details, for a result that Calero rightly describes as airy and clean. P.V.

title: A Humbled Shades Maker Strikes Back, and at Nike
description: JUST about everybody described the 1997 performance of Oakley Inc., the flashy sunglasses maker, with one word: humbling. The company's sizzling growth did not just slow; it reversed. The stock tumbled. The market for its high-end shades was hit hard.

description: For two years, President Clinton and the Republicans were locked in an uneasy embrace that allowed them to enact a number of major initiatives like the balanced budget agreement while containing their mutual hostility.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BROWN, BORENSTEIN, LILLIAN
description: BROWN - BORENSTEIN - Lillian. The Yeshiva University family mourns the passing of a dear friend who, with her beloved husband, Samuel, was a YU Guardian. With her first husband, the late A. Milton Brown, she was a Founder of YU's Albert Einstein College of Medicine and a Fellow of our affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary. We extend our heartfelt condolences to children, B. Warren and Benjamin Brown; grandchildren; greatgrandchildren; and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees

title: Where Madison Ave. feels a bit like Main St.
description: Mention Madison Avenue, and most think of the boutique-congested blocks from 59th Street to 72d Street, with shops that sound like a roll call from the pages of Vogue. But if you keep walking uptown, all the way to the low 90's if the mood carries you, the shops are smaller, no less silky and, in most cases, found only in New York.

title: Status Seating for F.O.S. (Friends of Sable)

title: Keeping Kosher Laws Is More Than Being Different
description: Although I was quoted correctly in the View column by Lynne Ames on March 1 (''As Kosher as Can Be, Deli Stresses Difference''), I believe the writer missed the point of Jewish dietary laws that my friends and I tried to convey. If keeping kosher was just a matter of keeping the Jewish people different, as the writer suggests, then the laws of kashrut would not necessarily have been based upon the ethics of human treatment of animals.

title: A Deft Stage Presence Moves Into the Movies
description: IN David Mamet's new thriller, ''The Spanish Prisoner,'' Rebecca Pidgeon plays a secretary named Susan Ricci. A worker ant in a big corporation, Susan is the sort of annoyingly perky person who chirps, ''I'm just the new girl.''

title: In a Cold War Hangover, Germany Confronts a Legacy of Steroids
description: For decades during the cold war, outsiders watched in frustration, rage, envy or astonishment as East German athletes accumulated gold medals, powering their way to record-breaking triumphs in sports from swimming to the shot-put. Many suspected drugs were fueling the success. But few of those suspicions could be definitively proved.

title: Murphy's Law of the Podium
description: If Robert Frost were alive today, chances are that he wouldn't be writing about walls. Maybe he'd write: ''Something there is that doesn't love a presentation.'' The mail brings tales of projectors running amok, balky disks, microphones bent on embarrassment, all manner of plans gone for naught. The Boy Scouts say, ''Be prepared.'' Easier said than done. Does anyone out there sell presentation insurance?

Thursday night's event was a fund-raiser for the Casanova boys, who will pile into a Ford van this week for a 16-city tour. Stops include a bowling alley in Minneapolis and a sushi bar in Charlottesville, Va.

But before the paint had dried, she was grabbing her camera, darting into the street and speeding uptown by taxi to Roseland to shoot behind the scenes at the most celebrity-spangled event of New York's fashion week, Donatella Versace's fall collection for Versus.

For baby boomers and people a little older, the mementos turn up as if they were items from a trunk. In a larger sense, they serve as reminders of who Americans were and how they thought. As trifles, they are fun and mildly revelatory. (That's Jack Nicholson playing the football coach in the 1958 pilot episode of ''Joan of Arkansas,'' a show -- or not such a good idea for a show -- about a dental assistant chosen by a computer to be the first person into space.)

title: A Triple Crown of Restaurants: Joe's Shanghai Comes to Elmhurst
description: Joe Si was once a co-owner of the restaurant Goody's just off Queens Boulevard in Rego Park. It specialized in Shanghai-style soup dumplings, delicate pastry filled with a mixture of pork and crabmeat in a hot broth. Joe went off on his own in 1994 to start Joe's Shanghai at 136-21 37th Avenue in Flushing and then, in 1996, expanded to 9 Pell Street in Chinatown. Now he's back in Queens with the third Joe's Shanghai, opened in February at 82-74 Broadway in Elmhurst.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDMAN, EUGENE
description: GOLDMAN-Eugene. Survived by wife Florence, sons Gary and Mark, sister Jeanette Ginsburg, grandsons Scott, D.J. and Jamie.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KIMLESS, KIKI
description: KIMLESS-Kiki. We think of you always. Sandy and Skip

title: Enjoying Breakfast One Minute, Homeless the Next
description: On the morning of March 4, Cathleen McGowan was sitting in her kitchen at 182 Avenue B, writing a little and enjoying her breakfast. Suddenly, a man was banging at the door, urging her and the other residents of the building to evacuate.

title: Peril of Politics in Japan
description: As the world's second-largest economy lurches to a standstill, possibly threatening to cause a global slowdown, paradoxically the fundamental reasons are not economic.

title: Chasing serendipity on Queen Street
description: For me, the perfect shopping experience is not Rodeo Drive or Bond Street -- emporiums of relentlessly enviable stuff that require simply a credit card and sangfroid. I prefer what I call adventure shopping of a very mild sort -- threading my way through a district where the chic and the dowdy, the consummately hip and the utilitarian cohabit. This is the sort of excursion that yields name brands but also allows you to crow, ''And then look what I found in this funny old shop!''

title: Children as Victims In Visitation Cases
description: It is not uncommon for people who are extremely stressed, or who have some arrested development, to treat their children with great insensitivity [''Custody Disputes Taking Heavy Toll on the Children,'' March 22]. We, as a society, cannot monitor the behavior of families at home, as unfortunate as this is for the children.

title: A Mother Is Heck On Wheels
description: Sitting astride her one-speed bicycle with a baby seat mounted on the back, Roberta Fineberg hardly fits the image of a lawbreaker. But Ms. Fineberg, 38, a freelance writer who lives in Carroll Gardens, is scheduled to go to trial April 23 for a crime usually associated with bike messengers and food deliverers who swerve between pedestrians on sidewalks at Tour de France speeds.

title: Another French Designer Sets Up Shop in SoHo
description: Barbara Bui, a French designer, joined the onslaught of fashion in SoHo with the opening of her boutique at 115 Wooster Street, between Prince and Spring Streets on Wednesday. The shop sprawls over two floors and 9,000 square feet. ''We think Big Apple, we think big,'' said William Halimi, the president of the designer's company, Barbara Bui.

title: Geometry Lesson
description: The owner of this Manhattan high-rise apartment asked Kathryn Dean and Charles Wolf, partners in the firm Dean/Wolf Architects, for two things. He wanted to enlarge his living room by appropriating a small second bedroom, and he wanted glass. ''We thought, what can we do with glass?'' recalls Dean. What indeed. Dean and Karel McAllister, an assistant, designed a pair of jewel-like doors that separate the living area from the former bedroom, now the media room, while keeping the entire space visually open. The interlocking L-shaped doors are partially sandblasted on the media-room side, to serve as a screen for the wall-mounted video projection camera. The doors also enclose a stainless steel perch for the client's two parrots. With their here-but-not-here transparency and reflections of surrounding skyscrapers, the doors create what Dean calls ''the idea of volumes contained in a very thin wall.'' Clearly, the idea works. P.V.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELKIN, DAVID B.
description: ELKIN-David B. On March 28, 1998. Beloved husband to Margot Turitz Elkin, loving father of Charlotte and Sam Elkin, cherished brother of Ethel Elkin and devoted son-in-law to Zitha Turitz. David was an economist, former Vice President of W.R. Grace and Co, adjunct professor, and economic consultant. He grew up in the Bronx, later lived in Manhattan, and settled in White Plains. His intelligence, vast knowledge, political conscience, wry humor and sensitivity will be deeply missed. Contributions to James Parkinson Fund for Research, Department of Neurology, University of Medicine and Dentistry of N.J., New Brunswick, New Jersey 08903.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219.

title: Flying High on The Option Express
description: CORPORATE America's numbers took off last year, with earnings climbing 11 percent and stocks surging 33 percent. But those results were merely booster rockets for executive pay.

title: March 29-April 4; A Crown Heights Ending
description: Six and a half years after racial violence rocked Crown Heights, Brooklyn, two developments helped move the city toward closure on the bitter episode.

title: County Settles
description: Legislator Louis A. Mosiello of Yonkers is sounding a note of caution about Westchester's response to lawsuits against the county. ''We should be careful not to send a message that we're an easy mark,'' he said, referring to three suits that the Board of Legislators voted to settle last month on the advice of the County Attorney, Alan D. Scheinkman.

title: Irish Dancing Stays Part of a Student's Life
description: KATHLEEN KEADY earned a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity two years ago at 19. She auditioned for and was selected to appear as a dancer in Michael Flatley's ''Lord of the Dance.'' The show was about to open in Ireland and go on a world tour, which included England, Australia and the United States. But Ms. Keady, an accounting major at Iona College here, hesitated before seizing the chance.

title: Oh, Those Death Valley Days
description: FORGE on, no matter the weather. This is something I learned last spring, while hiking in a downpour over the moors of southwest England -- a blissful, if sodden, enterprise. So in early February, when a series of brutal El Nino-powered storms battered the California coast, wrecking my plans to visit the Channel Islands by boat, I headed for Death Valley.

title: Wagon Limit Finds A Race He Can Win
description: Allen Jerkens worked his flair for racing history again yesterday when he won the Westchester Handicap at Aqueduct for the fifth time in 16 years, and he won it in grand form. His 4-year-old colt, Wagon Limit, ran the mile in 1 minute 34 seconds flat and snapped a seven-race, seven-month losing streak.

title: The Joys of Recognition: A First Name and a Bathrobe
description: They were looking forward to the handshake that would make them half-human again. For months the plebes had been counting down the time to their Recognition handshake on Recognition Day.

title: Courier Unravels, but Agassi Saves the Day
description: Washed out on Friday, wiped out today: that's the woebegone tale Jim Courier took away from his five-set Davis Cup confrontation with Russia's iron man, Yevgeny Kafelnikov, this afternoon at the International Tennis Center. A biting wind and a vagrant forehand conspired against Courier and got the United States off to an unhappy beginning in this weekend's first-round clash.

title: 'Is Ralph Here Yet?'
description: ''NINETY percent of life is showing up,'' as Woody Allen once said. But how many clock-watchers said it, or thought it, before him?

title: A Traditionalist Who Seeks To Update the Russian Soul
description: ROMANTICISM lives on in the highly charged work of the Russian choreographer Boris Eifman, a well-known figure in Europe whose Eifman Ballet of St. Petersburg only now makes its American debut, beginning Wednesday at City Center. On the bill are two evening-length works by Mr. Eifman that explore themes of forbidden love, alienation, sexual passion, insanity and death. Both works, ''Red Giselle'' and ''Tchaikovsky: The Mystery of Life and Death,'' were inspired by the lives of famous Russian artists, the first a dancer, the second the composer of some of the world's most glorious ballet music.

title: March 29-April 4; Cigarette Legislation Gets a Boost in Senate
description: ''This is only the first round, and there are many other rounds to fight,'' said Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, as his Commerce Committee gave a strong bipartisan vote of approval to comprehensive tobacco legislation.

title: Missing Man Leaves Gap in the Neighborhood Landscape
description: When a bank at the World Trade Center was robbed in January, a surveillance camera videotaped the three suspects, who were recognized by scores of their Windsor Terrace neighbors when their faces were broadcast on local newscasts. The police received some 60 calls, which helped lead to the men's arrest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DUROSS II, CHARLES E.
description: DUROSS II-Charles E. Born in New York on November 27, 1940 to the late Neil and Emily Duross, and graduate of Fordham University and Law School (1963, 1967). From 1967-74, he was an associate and later partner at Zock, Petrie, Sheneman & Reid in New York. In 1974, he became counsel to The Upjohn Co. in Kalamazoo, MI., where he retired as Assoc. General Counsel and Managing Director in 1988. He returned to New York to be President and CEO of Chas. E. Duross & Sons, Inc. Recently, he served on the Board of Governors of the New York Athletic Club, where he had been a member since 1961. He is survived by his loving wife Judith; his sons, Sean and Charles; and his sisters, Denise Beckerle and Suzanne Kelly. A funeral mass will be held at St. Bernard's, 330 W. 14th St., April 4th at 10:30 am. Please contact Redden's funeral home (212-242-1456) for more information. Charlie will be missed by all who knew him as he was always ready to greet people with a broad smile, a tall pint of Guinness and a witty joke.

title: Guess Who's Objecting To the New Insurance Bill
description: The insurance industry says it doesn't like the changes state lawmakers are making in New Jersey's auto insurance system. Members of the other powerful special-interest group in this game -- the trial lawyers -- say they don't like them, either.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about studios that provide marketing services for independent musicians misstated the size of the batches of compact disks issued by one company, Nova Music Productions. It typically issues CD's in batches of 1,000, not 10,000. The article also misquoted the owner, Michael Nova, about promotional flyers the company sends out with CD's. He said they are sent to record distribution companies, not record manufacturing companies.

title: Amid the Glitter, a Bauble With a Secret
description: AS crown jewels go, Eva Peron's flag brooch is hardly the Kohinoor. A patriotic piece of jet-set kitsch, the matchbox-size brooch, which Van Cleef & Arpels made in the late 40's for the First Lady of Argentina, copies in miniature the stylish blue-and-white striped Argentine standard in sapphires and diamonds. Yet for all its fame, the jewel, which will be sold tomorrow at Christie's in New York, remains a historical conundrum.

Beneath its nondescript skin, which is nonetheless highly functional and aerodynamic, is a quick, innovative and safe car that can mix it up with a pretty fast, sophisticated crowd.

description: THE Trenton Thunder's opening day is Wednesday, and the box office has a nice problem: not enough tickets. In Sussex County, the New Jersey Cardinals expect to sell more tickets for the season than there are seats. Standing-room-only has become routine.

description: When The Amherst Spectator published its first issue last May, people suspected it would make waves as the only conservative publication at Amherst College in Amherst, Mass. And it has attracted attention, but not because of scintillating articles.

title: The Storytelling Souvenir
description: SOME years ago, my mother and stepfather made their first trip to Europe. My husband, Tom, and I had bought platform tickets to meet them at the Gare de l'Est in Paris. As they passed through the barrier, the ticket-taker, not surprisingly, took their tickets. ''Oh,'' my mother exclaimed with dismay, ''I wanted to keep those.'' The ticket-taker bowed from the waist and presented them to her. ''Pour souvenir, Madame,'' he said.

description: AT&T broke ground last Tuesday on a 198,000-square-foot network operations center in Bedminster, N.J., that will coordinate the flow of communications moving across its network anywhere in the world.

description: When young Trina's adult teeth started coming in crowded, Dee Hanna did what so many other Americans have done -- she collared her little one and headed for a dentist who could straighten teeth.

description: To the Editor: I was thrilled to read the features on the Texas Hill Country -- particularly the piece on Austin by Shermakaye Bass (''Melting Pot, With Chili,'' Feb. 15).

description: The rising pay for chief executives means that they often need more help planning their finances and doing their taxes. But should they pay for those services themselves? Some companies think not -- and give executives additional compensation to cover such costs.

description: DALTON-Elaine. Beloved wife of Philip B. Dalton of Sarasota, FL. Mother of Linda Dalton of Sharon, MA and Barbra Reckhow of NYC; Grandmother to Laurie MacGregor and Alyssa, Grant, Taylor and Jensen Reckhow. Life member of Hadassah. Donations to SABRA Chapter of Hadassah, 3750 S. Osprey Ave., Sarasota, FL 34239.

title: In Defense of Building Affordable Housing
description: I read the article concerning affordable housing [''As Crisis Nears, Affordable Units of Housing Lag,'' Feb. 22.] I live in New Rochelle and am happy that my city has made provisions for this type of housing. I am very happy that I do not live in Scarsdale, which has taken to battling any such programs.

title: In Search of Festive Meals on Easter
description: EASTER Sunday frequently poses a dilemma: finding out which restaurants are open, and then determining whether it is already too late to make reservations. Following is a roundup of attractive places around the state that feature special menus for the holiday. More than half are inns, which seem to have a natural affinity for holiday dining, and reservations are mandatory at all places included. The fixed prices do not include tax, tip or drinks.

title: In Little City Safe From Violence, Rash of Suicides Leaves Scars
description: Sometime on the afternoon of Dec. 2, after he grabbed lunch with a school buddy, rode around town in a pickup truck and bought Christmas presents with his pocket money, 15-year-old Kenny White shredded the secrets of his short life when he gripped his father's pistol and shot himself in the head.

title: Senate Approves Tough Safety Bill on Amusement Park Rides
description: After a summer marred by several serious accidents on carnival rides, the New Jersey Senate passed a bill last week that would make the state's amusement park safety laws among the toughest in the nation, imposing stiff fines not only on negligent park operators but on reckless riders, too.

title: When a Bobcat's Man's Best Friend
description: RICHARD HOMAN, a disabled veteran from Somers, may be ''worn out and tired from the battle,'' as he said recently, but he is also a happy man now that he has his best friend back.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MULLINS, CONCHA (NEE MARTINEZ)
description: MULLINS-Concha (nee Martinez). On April 2, 1998. Beloved wife of the late John J.; cherished mother of Jeremiah and the late Rosemarie; grandmother of Rita, Catherine, John, Lorraine, Rosemarie, Mercedes, Carla and Andrew; great grandmother of six; sister of Mercedes Marra and the late Joseph Martinez. Reposing Redden Funeral Home, 325 W. 14 St., Saturday 7-9 PM and Sunday 25 and 7-9 PM. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 10AM St. Veronica's Church. Interment Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers donations to: Anne C. Mullins Foundation, c/o St. John the Baptist Church, 67 Valley St., Hillsdale, NJ 07642 would be appreciated.

description: SLOMOWITZ - Hyman (Harry). Passed away suddenly March 24, 1998. Much beloved son, brother, uncle, friend. Longtime member of Congregation Zichron Moshe in Manhattan, Trustee of Stuyvesant High School Alumni Association. The family requests that donations be made in his memory to your own charity or to Mesivta Ohr Torah, 6635 108th St, Forest Hills, NY 11375, attn: Rabbi Baruch Gottesman.

title: Fixer-Uppers
description: Ellen Laird and Barbara Brunhouse are New Jersey homeowners who got burned once too often when trying to find somebody reliable to tackle jobs around the house.

title: Breakfast Fan
description: To the Editor: If Robert Packard (''If It's Not Breakfast, Do Not Disturb,'' Feb. 22) is organizing a lobbying group to protest the disappearance of room service breakfasts, he may add my name as a charter member. After years of traveling with my husband, who is one of those first in line for the dining room buffet breakfast Packard writes about, I wised up and ordered breakfast alone in my room at my leisure.

description: HARD COVER

title: The Nation; Dear Driver: Sober And Buckle Up
description: TWO dangerous practices show up time and again as factors in fatal car crashes. One occurs in half the accidents and could be quickly remedied with equipment already in every car: unused seat belts. The other, present in 40 percent of fatal crashes, is far harder to recognize or remedy once the driver is behind the wheel: drinking.

description: EMPIRE BY DEFAULT The Spanish-American War and the Dawn of the American Century. By Ivan Musicant. Illustrated. 740 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $35.

title: An Overlooked Early Bird Bargain Dinner
description: THERE are two ways to order chicken Francese, one of the better dinner entrees at the new Portobello Restaurant in Port Washington. One is to select it from the a la carte menu and pay $11.95. The other is to order it, along with a bowl of soup or large salad, dessert and tea or coffee for $9.95. Not a difficult choice is it? Chicken Francese is one of four entrees (along with three appetizers and four desserts) on the three-course, $9.95, early-bird dinner available seven days a week before 6:30 P.M. The quantity, quality and price of this meal make it an incredible value.

title: Fulfilling the Promise of the Budding DVD
description: IT was a marriage made in some plugged-in part of heaven: opera and the digital video disk. And the first earthly unions, versions of Rossini's ''William Tell'' and Mozart's ''Don Giovanni,'' both staged at La Scala in Milan, fulfill much of the promise of a fledgling medium. Indeed, through an inspired decision, Image Entertainment, the producer of these disks, has solved the one really problematic aspect of DVD, its limited capacity to reproduce music accurately.

title: Fire Department Increases Effort To Educate the Public on Safety
description: The New York City Fire Department announced yesterday that it had sharply increased the size of its fire safety programs in response to an audit that showed the city spent proportionally less on fire safety than many other municipalities.

title: DESPITE AN EASING OF RULES, MILLIONS EVADE 'NANNY TAX'
description: Four years ago, after President Clinton withdrew Zoe Baird's nomination to become Attorney General because she had not paid taxes on her children's nanny, Congress simplified the requirements for reporting wages paid to nannies, maids and other servants and for paying the employer's share of Social Security, Medicare and Federal unemployment taxes.

title: Copyrights Can Inhibit Expression; Trademark Longevity
description: To the Editor:

title: Laura Forte, K. S. Kharbanda
description: Laura Jean Forte, the daughter of Margaret and Wesley Forte of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Kenneth Singh Kharbanda, the son of Parmeet and Udhe Kharbanda of White House Station, N.J. Bishop Roger Johnson of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints officiated at the St. Moritz in New York.

title: Mothers Should
description: When I was pregnant with the girl who made me a mother, the thing I hated most was how my size and shape demonstrated to anyone who laid eyes on me both what was going on in my body and what was going on in my mind. I had a secret, but everyone knew what it was -- I was going to have a baby, which was all I could think about. I wasn't wrong; I subsequently learned that motherhood is the most public of personal conditions.

title: Behind Every Step, Life's Twists and Turns
description: WHEN I first started going to the ballet, the thing that drew me back to it was not just the beauty of the performances but the fact that that beauty seemed personal to me. It is like people who collect stamps. In those little pictures they see details -- how many lines are laid down to make an ear or a mustache, and the inking, and the feel of the paper -- that they think only they can cherish. Only to them are these things so precise and so moving. So it was for me with ballet. I was sure that I was the only one who saw how the fairy, when she raised her wand, lowered it again in a special kind of arc, first fast, then slower. That was mine, and full of mystery.

title: Everybody Into the Shark Tank
description: MAYBE it's a myth about sharks and blood in the water, but I shaved extra carefully this morning. The dive master didn't help by mentioning that the five ragged-tooth sharks would eat later. ''They'll be hungry,'' he confirmed. ''They haven't been fed since Tuesday.''

title: Fixing and Modifying Threaded Pipe
description: HOMES that were built within the last 30 years have water pipes of copper or possibly plastic. Copper is relatively easy to install because it is lightweight and the pieces can be joined by soldering them together. Plastic pipes are lightweight, inexpensive and the parts are usually joined with solvent.

title: Program Helps Divorced Parents Ease the Effect on Children
description: ON a chilly Wednesday evening, close to 30 mothers and fathers assembled at the Nassau County Court House in Mineola. Some sat sprawled, others straight on courtroom benches and watched a video, titled ''In The Best Interests Of the Children,'' which featured the stories of children of divorce.

title: James Herman, 73; Led Dockworkers On the West Coast
description: James R. Herman, a former president of the International Longshore and Warehouse Union, which represents stevedores on the West Coast and a variety of other workers, died on March 20 at California Pacific Medical Center. He was 73 and lived in San Francisco.

title: Jocelyn Wolfe, Blake Schulman
description: Jocelyn Lizabeth Wolfe, the daughter of Helen Wolfe and Dr. Stanley Wolfe of Woodbridge, Conn., was married on Friday to Blake Schulman, a son of Stanley and Barbara Schulman of New York. Rabbi Ronald A. Sobel performed the ceremony at Temple Emanu-El in New York.

title: Ticktock Hitchcock
description: The master of suspense provides a terrific cluster of set pieces in FOREIGN CORRESPONDENT (1940), with Joel McCrea, Laraine Day and Herbert Marshall. Early on, his roving scribe (McCrea) witnesses a rainswept, political assignation in midtown Amsterdam amid bobbing umbrellas and clanging traffic. Moments later, a stealthy windmill episode ticks away like a hand grenade. And isn't that good old Macy's Santa, Edmund Gwenn, as a cockney killer? Indeed. Hitchcock's topper is his climax, a giant plane crash at sea. His principals are aboard, but the eyecatcher is an elderly woman clinging to a battered wing for dear life like an ancient, drenched bird. Leave it to Hitch -- MONDAY at 11:30 A.M. on AMC Howard Thompson

title: Sports of The Times; Five Champions, From Past and Present, Debate Boxing's Curse
description: MAYBE these five will be different. In their elderly years, maybe they will escape the apparent curse of boxing: the memory lapses that forced Floyd Patterson to resign as chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission last week, the Alzheimer's disease that afflicted the late Sugar Ray Robinson, or the Parkinson's syndrome that has Muhammad Ali speaking in slow motion.

title: Lights, Camera, Fashion!
description: Friends toast a label, a book, Barnard and special recordings; donors crowd the Met and City Center.

title: Ms. Longobardo And Mr. Wyckoff
description: Alicia Anahid Longobardo, the director of new products in the home entertainment division of Time Inc. in New York, was married yesterday to Robert Quentin Wyckoff Jr., a managing director of the Tweedy, Browne Company, a New York investment management firm. The Rev. John Vaughn performed the ceremony at Riverside Church in New York.

title: Beyond Fear
description: When I was told last year that my 2-year-old son had an illness that threatened his life, I tried to strike a bargain with fate -- I would do anything, I would trade my old life away, if only he would get better. We learned that our son would need months of treatment, maybe even a year, before we would know whether he would recover. My husband and I settled into a deadening routine; one night at the hospital, the next night at home to be with our daughter, then right back to the hospital. The days and nights were a blur of medical reports. Fear and despair engulfed me.

title: 'Henry IV' At Belmont
description: JUST like a tourist's guide to an uncharted land, the adjectival spin on a playwright's name represents a handy shortcut to style. Calling a play Brechtian, Beckettian or Pinteresque sums up a singular world. Or Pirandellian, which is instantly defined as a fusion of the real and the unreal -- guess which is more real -- the dropping in and out between a pretend, hallucinatory dreamscape and the so-called normal state. A play by Luigi Pirandello (1867-1936) is a metaphysical fantasy about appearances and a less veiled view of the truth.

title: At the Bushnell, A Violinist's Visit
description: MICHAEL LANKESTER will lead the Hartford Symphony Orchestra in concerts at the Bushnell on Tuesday and Wednesday at 8 (with preview discussions each evening at 7). The program opens with Rossini's ''Silken Ladder'' Overture and closes with Richard Strauss's symphonic poem ''Ein Heldenleben.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; The Russian T-Shirt Mob
description: Fans of Laurence Shames's five previous Key West thrillers will feel right at home with the menagerie of misfits and dreamers that populates MANGROVE SQUEEZE (Hyperion, $22.95). Among them are Suki Sperakis, a blue-eyed Greek-American who fled the shackles of a boring life in suburban New Jersey, and Aaron Katz, a refugee from Manhattan who ditched his wife and a promising career in mergers and acquisitions to renovate a run-down guest house with his elderly father. It's clear from the start that Suki and Aaron are meant for each other, but standing in their way are a bunch of Russian crooks who are laundering money through a chain of T-shirt shops. It seems that Suki, who works for the local newspaper, has decided to investigate the gang's activities. And this means tangling with the creepy ringleader, Ivan Cherkassky, a paranoid with ''a doleful scooped-out face, pockmarked and lumpy, like what was left when a wedge of melon had been spooned.'' When Suki is marked for death after asking too many questions, Aaron comes to her rescue, aided by his comical father. Joining them is a Shames favorite, the retired Mafioso Bert (the Shirt) d'Ambrosia, who turns up with his ancient chihuahua to give father and son some valuable lessons in mob etiquette. Shames plays it all for laughs, managing at the same time to make his story's locale seem both suitably exotic and peculiarly charming. ''Tenure is everything in Key West,'' we are told early on, ''and everybody came to realize that without needing to be told.'' Scott Veale

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CELLA, RICHARD
description: CELLA-Richard. Brigadier General Richard Cella was a command fighter pilot who flew more than 200 combat missions over the Pacific during World War II. He entered military service in May, 1939, as a Second Lieutenant in the Coast Artillery Corps reserve. He received his Masters Degree in Aeronautical Engineering from M.I.T. in 1947. In December 1962, he assumed the position of Deputy Chief of Staff/Systems, Ballistics and Space Systems, AFSC. During his services, Brigadier General Richard Cella was awarded, Legion of Merit, Distinguished Flying Cross with Oak Leaf Cluster; Air Medal with two Oak Leaf Clusters; Air Force Commendation Medal; Presidential Unit Citation with Oak Leaf Cluster; American Defense Service Medal; American Campaign Medal; Asiatic-Pacific Campaign Medal with 9 Campaign Stars; World War II Victory Medal; Army of Occupation Medal-Japan; Philippine Liberation Ribbon with One Star. In 1994 he was knighted by the President of the Italian Republic, Pertini. General Cella is survived and dearly missed by his beloved wife, Ivana, his dear sons, Christopher, Richard B. and Renzo. Also his loving granddaughters Lillian and Elizabeth. Mass of the Resurrection, St. Vincent Ferrer, Tuesday, 11 a.m. Interment at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. For information Louis DeLuca Mayflower Funeral Home, 718256-1212. Brigadier General Richard Cella also managed his family restaurant, ''Christ Cella,'' in NYC which was founded in 1926 by his father Christopher Cella.

Dr. Tang's formidable intellectual talents were recognized and molded during her undergraduate career at M.I.T. and medical training at Cornell University Medical School. We watched Babette mature as a pediatrician from her early days as an enthusiastic and hard working intern through her training and blossoming as an Infectious Diseases specialist. We will remember her for her long nights at the bedside caring for sick children, reassuring parents and patiently instructing house officers and students, all done with good cheer and in her own unmistakable style. We all admired her indomitable courage, perseverance and selfless devotion to those she loved. No task was too hard for Babette, no project too involved. Her brief years as a part of our community will be a cherished legacy. Though others may perform similar functions, she was a unique and irreplaceable individual and we shall miss her. John M. description: To the north stands the Summer Beach resort, a 450-acre complex that includes homes and a Ritz-Carlton Hotel, with seven condominium buildings under construction. To the south is the Amelia Island Plantation, a 1,330-acre resort and residential community that is opening a hotel and building two condominium buildings with plans for more single-family homes.

title: Washington Wins
description: The Washington oarsmen had to wait until the final race of the San Diego Crew Classic to win their first race of the regatta yesterday, but they then captured the featured Copley Cup with a vengeance.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about plans to tear down a historic building at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology referred imprecisely to its role in the development of radar. The single antenna radar, which became important to the Allies in World War II, was invented in Building 20; other forms were developed earlier by various countries.

title: Internet CD Copying Tests Music Industry
description: It is hard to imagine that a Goliath like the $12 billion American music industry could see a 19-year-old college sophomore as a threat to its long-term financial health.

title: Troupe From China Helps Demystify an Obscure Art Form
description: The Beijing opera, although China's most accessible art form, remains a mystery to Western audiences. Programs of excerpts are the norm: context is missing, and conventions of the genre are proclaimed but not explained. The more one understands, the more one needs to learn.

title: Calling a Truce in Stampede Journalism
description: Responding to a stampede of camera crews, journalists and photographers mobbing President Clinton's personal secretary outside a courthouse in Washington, one of the nation's leading news executives called on the news media to pool their resources and exercise self-restraint in covering events involving nonpublic figures.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ROSENFELD, ANNE
description: ROSENFELD-Anne. Always needed. Always loved. Always missed. Love, Your Daughter Debbie

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASEY, MARGARET
description: CASEY-Margaret. On April 4, 1998, of Pleasantville, NY. Wife of the late Patrick; mother of John and Roger; grandmother of five; sister of one. Mass was celebrated today at Holy Innocents Church. Maher Funeral Home (914) 769-2044.

title: Rebel Ranks Expand In Serbian Province
description: In Kosovo, once-elusive guerrilla bands fighting for independence from Serbia suddenly seem to be everywhere. Their numbers are being swelled by an infusion of troops and weapons smuggled in from Albania.

title: A Humble Man, Yet Sophisticated Too
description: The scholars are the stars of ''From Jesus to Christ: The First Christians.'' One says, to a magical picture of sunrise over Masada, that the historian's task in understanding Jesus and early Christianity is a lot like archeology: ''You peel back layer after layer of interpretation. And what you always find is a plurality of Jesuses.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Excite to Acquire Advertising Site
description: Excite, the Internet search service, has agreed to buy Classifieds2000, a World Wide Web site that posts classified advertising, for $48 million in Excite stock.

title: 'Titanic,' After 15 Weeks, Bows to 'Lost in Space'
description: After 15 weeks as the No. 1 film in the nation, ''Titanic'' was finally toppled at the box office over the weekend by ''Lost in Space,'' a science-fiction movie based on the 1960's television series.

title: Philip Davis, 90; Stood Up for the Right to Sit
description: Philip Davis, who practiced law so unobtrusively for more than two-thirds of a century that he made his biggest legal splash as a disgruntled railroad passenger, died on March 26 at a retirement home in Basking Ridge, N.J. He was 90 and twice went to court to establish the revolutionary notion that a railroad ticket entitles a passenger to an actual seat.

title: Afghan Women Demanding End To Their Repression by Militants
description: ''The Government can cover our faces,'' said the intense young woman, who had once been a teacher. ''But underneath, we still want our rights.''

title: Gen. Herbert B. Powell, 94, Ambassador and Army Leader
description: Gen. Herbert Butler Powell, a former chief of the Continental Army Command and former Ambassador to New Zealand, died on Saturday at a nursing home in Williamsburg, Va. He was 94.

title: It Don't Mean a Thing If It Ain't Got That Swing
description: The neo-swing movement, which may invade your consciousness soon enough, if it hasn't already, dates back to the late 1980's. It began in California, of course, where the soil for youth movements is well seeded. Back then, the retro-culture hounds in San Francisco were waiting with martinis at the ready to receive the Los Angeles band Royal Crown Revue, which was playing 40's jump-blues inspired by Louis Jordan. By the mid-90's this so-called swing (though it was really all jump blues) became a viable life-style package, a social music with less violence and drug abuse than punk and therefore more staying power.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFF, HON. JAMES J.
description: LEFF-Hon. James J. Retired NYS Supreme Court Justice, died April 5, 1998. Husband of Miriam. Father of John and Thomas. Grandfather of Michael and Philip. Judge Leff served on the NYS Supreme Court from 1969 to 1996. Funeral services private. A memorial is planned.

title: A Good Time to End Tobacco Quotas
description: Several anti-smoking groups, including the Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids, the American Cancer Society and the American Heart Association, have recently taken a position that is at odds with their goals. They want the comprehensive tobacco legislation, currently being debated in Congress, to preserve a Federal program that regulates the amount of tobacco that can be grown and the price at which it is sold.

title: Free Trade Victory Is Sea Turtles' Loss
description: The World Trade Organization ruled yesterday that the United States was wrong to prohibit shrimp imports from countries that fail to protect sea turtles from deadly entrapment in shrimp-boat trawl nets.

title: 7,100 Must Exchange Auto Inspection Stickers
description: About 7,100 drivers who have received the state's new two-year inspection stickers since December will have to exchange them for new ones because they resemble expired stickers, state officials said yesterday.

title: FIRSTMERIT IN $256 MILLION STOCK DEAL FOR SECURITY FIRST
description: The Firstmerit Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Security First Corporation for $256 million in stock. Firstmerit is a $5.3 billion bank holding company in Akron, Ohio. Security First, of Mayfield Heights, Ohio, is a $678 million bank holding company that operates 14 branch offices in six counties in Ohio. Security First shareholders will get 0.8855 share of Firstmerit stock for each Security First share held. Shares of Security First jumped $5.50 yesterday, to $27.875; Firstmerit slipped 18.75 cents, to $32.875.

title: Patterns
description: Celine for Bergdorf's

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Tuesday about changes in the design of The Reader's Digest misstated the number of its editions. Apart from the American edition, the international editions number 47, not 28.

title: Jurors Resume Deliberations in L.I. Beating
description: With a newly appointed juror on board, deliberations continued without further disruption today in the trial of a 27-year-old white man from Queens charged with attempting to murder a young black man during a brawl outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub two years ago.

title: Gambling Industry Spins From Red to Black
description: After posting a net loss of $257 million in 1996, the state's gambling industry was officially back in the black last year, with a net income of $6.4 million in 1997, the State Casino Control Commission announced yesterday.

title: Sports of The Times; The Coach Who Came To Stay
description: THE new coach was the most celebrated player the school ever had, and his mother-in-law lives right down the road. So while the position of head basketball coach at Iona College is far more vocation than it is community service, this is also a story about roots, about making it at home, about knowing where to go when there's no place to park.

title: Touch Therapy Wasn't Disproved; Ben Franklin's Example
description: To the Editor:

title: Clean, Adult and No Strobe Lights
description: ''We're home, we're home!'' Nile Rodgers whooped. He wore a banana-yellow suit with matching tie, and had a black guitar slung around his neck. He told the audience at Tramps on Friday night about how he was born down the street, at St. Vincent's Hospital, and how he remembered seeing Miles Davis at the Village Vanguard, a little farther down Seventh Avenue. He looked giddy, surveying the teeming crowd. It had been 20 years since Mr. Rodgers had performed the songs of his band, Chic, on his own turf, and the audience collectively exercised a sense memory of youthful exultation. Everyone was familiar with the coordinates.

title: Foreign Affairs; Sorry, Game Over
description: At this time each year world leaders prepare for the annual June G-7 summit meeting by asking themselves: What should we talk about this year? Every year they come up with some phony theme. Well, I've got an idea. Let's have them talk about something really important. Let's make this year's G-7 about Japan. Even though this year's summit will be in Birmingham, England, I say serve those G-7 leaders sushi and rice for every meal, make them attend origami classes and tea ceremonies, and list every item on the agenda as: ''Discussion about Japan.'' That's right, let's really spotlight Japan. Who knows, maybe that will help trigger the only thing that will really stimulate Japan's economy: a revolution.

title: 3d Straight Shutout for Isles
description: Wade Flaherty glanced up at the game clock tonight as it went from three seconds to two. With a shutout victory imminent, the Islanders' goalie thought the game was essentially over. Meanwhile, Tampa Bay's Sandy McCarthy, another defeat imminent, raced up the right side and cocked his stick for a desperation 40-foot shot.

title: Fox Sports Network Names New Agency
description: Cliff Freeman & Partners, New York, a part of Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C., said yesterday that it had been named agency of record for the Fox Sports Network in Los Angeles, a division of the Fox Broadcasting Company unit of the News Corporation. Billings have not been determined.

title: Repackaging the Dow 30 as the Dow 29
description: The decision by Travelers Group Inc. and Citicorp to merge will force a change in the composition of the Dow Jones industrial average, but experts said yesterday that the alteration was unlikely to be substantive.

title: Finding a Theme Is Mere Child's Play
description: Dressing up a simple theme as an exercise in deep intellectualism can be amusing, particularly when the excessive elaborations are the work of a master parodist. Leon Botstein clearly enjoys this game. Usually, the grand thematic programs that he assembles for his American Symphony Orchestra concerts have the trappings of serious business, but aspects of his Sunday afternoon concert at Avery Fisher Hall suggested that he might be toying with us after all.

title: Yank Slide Continues; Rivera Goes On the D.L.
description: Jamie Moyer, Seattle's soft-spoken, soft-throwing pitcher, often tips his cap to the home plate umpire when he is finished for the day. He was not so polite to the Yankees tonight.

title: APPLIED POWER ACQUIRING ZERO CORPORATION FOR STOCK
description: Applied Power Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Zero Corporation for $427.4 million in stock. Under the deal, shareholders of Zero would receive 0.85 share of Applied Power stock for each share of Zero held. The transaction, valued at $32.459 a share, was disclosed after Applied Power's stock closed at $38.1875 a share, down $1.375, and Zero closed unchanged at $28.875. The acquisition will give Applied Power annual revenues of about $1.4 billion. The company is based in Butler, Wis., and makes products for hydraulic and fluid power markets. Zero, based in Los Angeles, makes system packaging, thermal management and engineered cases for the telecommunications, instrumentation and data processing markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, ROY M.
description: KING-Roy M. On Sunday, April 5, 1998. Roy King, beloved husband of Miriam King, (nee Schiller), devoted father of Justin King and the late Melody Ann King. Devoted father-in-law of Cynthia King. Loving brother of Arthur Feigenbaum of New York. Adoring grandfather of Bradley and Aaron King. Please omit flowers. Contributions in his memory may be directed to the Melody Ann King Memorial Fund, College of Education, University of Denver, PO Bx 100864, Denver, CO 80250. For further information, please contact Sol Levinson & Bros., Inc. 1-800-338-1701.

title: Blatant Politicking For Baseball Hero
description: It was a politician's dream: stuffing a ballot box legally. And GUY V. MOLINARI, the Staten Island Borough President, got to do it -- not for a Republican but for a Giant: BOBBY THOMSON.

title: Building-Products Deal Seems Near in Britain
description: Heywood Williams Group P.L.C., a British maker of building products, said yesterday that it was in the late stages of talks to buy the Spectus-Kestrel Group for up to $:62 million ($102.8 million) in cash to bolster Heywood's window and door operations. The company also said that it was in the early stages of selling its auto windshield business and that after shareholder approval, it might buy back up to 10 percent of its share capital at a cost of about $:20 million. The company's shares rose 9.5 pence, or 4.2 percent, to 235 pence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINNEMA, JOHN
description: MINNEMA-John. The Board of Trustees of The Jaqua Foundation express our deepest sympathy to the family of our dear friend and devoted colleague, John T. Minnema. Our thoughts and prayers are with his wife, Gertrude and his children, Jill Worth and Joan Minnema. John's insight and wisdom will be truly missed. Eli Hoffman W. Fletcher Hock, Jr. Samuel Pollock

title: Robert Pilatus, 32, Performer In Disgraced Band Milli Vanilli
description: Robert Pilatus, a member of Milli Vanilli, the German pop duo forced to give up its 1990 Grammy Award when it was disclosed that the pair did not sing a word on its album, died on Saturday in a hotel room in Frankfurt. He was 32.

title: Dialogue in the Heartland: What of Social Security?
description: Before leaving for spring break, the students in Dick Katstra's seventh-grade social studies classes were told that when they returned on March 23 they should be prepared to look for solutions to an adult problem: the expected shortfall in Social Security financing in the coming decades.

title: Bell Atlantic Wins Backing To Add Service
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation took a big step toward being allowed to sell a full range of communications services yesterday as the Justice Department's antitrust chief and New York State's top utility regulator gave conditional support to the company's bid to sell long-distance telephone service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VIERENGEL, THOMAS J.
description: VIERENGEL-Thomas J. Of Melrose, NY at his residence on April 5, 1998. Husband of Diane Morell Vierengel. Devoted father of Frederick John Vierengel of Palm Coast, FL., and James Thomas Vierengel of Long Island, NY. Son of the late Edgar and Helene Corey Vierengel. Brother of Robert (Vierengel) Dorian of East Islip, LI & the late Edgar Vierengel & Therese Falke. Also survived by a grandson Samuel Aidan Vierengel. A brother-in-law Bill Morell. Also survived by several nieces and nephews. Mr. Vierengel had been a Managing Director of the Capital Markets Division of First Albany Corporation for the past 12 years. He began his career in the securities business in 1961 with Scudder, Stevens and Clark and had worked for several investment houses, including R.W. Pressprich, Smith Barney and Company, Fallon, Towse, Farrand & Vierengel; Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, Inc., and A.G. Becker, before joining First Albany Corporation. Funeral service will be held Wednesday morning at 8:45 AM from the Lasak & Gigliotti Funeral Home, 8 Dudley Heights, Albany, NY and at 10 AM from St. Mary's Church at the corner of 3rd Street and Washington, Troy where a mass of Christian Death and Burial will be celebrated. Relatives and friends are invited to attend and may call at the funeral home Tuesday from 4 to 8 PM. Contributions in Mr. Vierengel's memory may be made to St. Mary's Church, 196 3rd Street, Troy, NY 12180 or The Community Hospice of Rensselaer County, c/o 8 North Lake Avenue, Troy, N.Y. 12180.

title: In Court or on It, Lawyers Are Lawyers
description: Not every lawyer in the New York Lawyers Basketball League challenges every call the referees make, or don't make. For instance, last week, when the team from Graubard, Mollen & Miller clobbered Cooper & Cooper 77-60 in the league's Division A championship, there was plenty of physical play and plenty of penalizing whistles, but the bellowing was mainly at teammates, and nobody got thrown out of the game for contempt of ref.

title: Editorial Observer; Splendid, Stubborn, Adorable Moses Returns
description: After 40 years of wandering in entertainment wilderness, Hollywood has rediscovered the Book of Exodus. In 1956, with ''The Ten Commandments,'' the director Cecil B. De Mille set a new standard for biblical epics. Now Jeffrey Katzenberg, the former Walt Disney executive, is bringing the Bible movie back in animated form, but he has encountered problems undreamed of by De Mille.

title: Sports of The Times; Yankee 'Opponent' Hits Again
description: HERE is a case of pathology with its utilitarian side. In this year's Yankee media guide, the ''Opponents'' section begins with a photograph of a certain left-handed hitter with a graceful swing and deceptive smile.

title: Baby Sitter Is Charged With Abandoning Child
description: A 19-year-old woman who was baby-sitting a 4-year-old girl was arrested yesterday after leaving the child alone on a subway train in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Jonas Barish, 76, Scholar of Theater History
description: Jonas A. Barish, a historian of the theater and an authority on the English dramatist and poet Ben Jonson and his contemporary Shakespeare, died on Wednesday at Kaiser Permanente Medical Center in Oakland, Calif. He was 76 and lived in Berkeley, Calif.

title: Wildwood District Told To Scale Back Budget
description: A state judge yesterday ordered the Wildwood Board of Education to adopt a budget that anticipates $700,000 in state aid, not the $2.9 million aid figure the board insists it should receive.

title: Big and Bigger
description: ODD COUPLE AT THE TOP -- The two executives who will run the new financial colossus to be made up of Citicorp and the Travelers Group could hardly be more different. Page D1.

title: Pilots Stage Strike At All Nippon Airways
description: Pilots at the All Nippon Airways Company, Japan's second-largest airline, went on strike yesterday to oppose a cut in pay. Two flights between Kansai International Airport in western Japan and Rome will be canceled today, affecting 170 passengers. Ten flights may be canceled tomorrow, affecting 1,880 passengers.

title: Akzo Nobel Makes Bid For Courtaulds of Britain
description: Akzo Nobel N.V. of the Netherlands said yesterday that it wanted to buy Courtaulds P.L.C. of Britain and would pay $:1.83 billion ($3.03 billion) in cash to become the world's largest maker of paints and coatings. The bid of 450 pence a share is below Courtauld's Friday closing price. Akzo Nobel's shares closed at 423.4 guilders yesterday, up 10.3. Courtaulds, the world's biggest maker of aerospace and marine paints, slipped half a pence yesterday, to 465. Shares of Courtaulds hit a five-year low of 238.5 pence on Jan. 23.

title: Ulster Talks Get Urgent Compromise Plan
description: With only three days left until the deadline for a Northern Ireland peace settlement, the American former Senator George J. Mitchell, chairman of the talks, gave Protestant and Roman Catholic negotiators early today a set of urgent compromise proposals for ending the province's sectarian warfare.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, OSCAR H.
description: ISRAEL-Oscar H. Passed April 2 at his home in Stamford. Memorial service at Campbell's, 1076 Madison Ave, Wednesday, April 8, 11 AM. Burial will follow at the High Ridge Cemetery, High Ridge Road, Stamford, CT at 3 PM.

description: The Schering-Plough Corporation said today that it had paid Centocor Inc. $20 million for the rights to sell Avakine, a drug for Crohn's disease, in Europe and other parts of the world, except the United States, Japan and some of the Far East.

title: Vowing Noise Crackdown, City Shuts 4 East Side Bars
description: Prompted by neighbors' complaints about noise, the city shut four Upper East Side bars over the weekend in what officials said would be a crackdown on rowdy Manhattan bars and clubs that would last through the summer.

description: Propelled by news of the biggest corporate merger in history, the Dow Jones industrial average closed above 9,000 for the first time yesterday.

title: The Big Band as a Basis, But Without Restriction
description: The big-band vocabulary is so static nowadays that hearing a band like the one led by the French composer and arranger Magali Souriau is a surprise. Ms. Souriau wants to do something different.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ANDREAS, ALFRED
description: ANDREAS-Alfred. On April 3, 1998. Since one of his parents was Jewish, he fled his homeland Poland when Nazis were in power. He came in time to NYC where he lived for many years and worked as an Engineer. He was a member of NYC Tennis Club with a fine passion for the sport. Recently he used his intellect to create computer graphics. His final act was to donate his body to science; intention was that his disease might be conquered. He will be missed by all who knew him. Donations should be made in his memory to Sloan-Kettering Cancer Research.
