description: The proposed merger of Citicorp with the Travelers Group challenges the Depression-era notion that America's financial house can best be kept in order if bankers and brokers stay in separate rooms -- an idea embodied in the Banking Act of 1933, or the Glass-Steagall Act.

description: OTIS-E. Constance Maxfield. On April 5, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Henry Witte Otis. Service Wednesday, 11 A.M., at Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 7 W. 55 St, NYC. For information call Frank E. Campbell, 212-288-3500.

title: No Headline
A Snoop Thwarts A Suicide In Finland
description: Unexpected intimacies occur throughout ''Junk Mail,'' as befits the story of a postman who tampers with letters. Even the film's abrupt opening sequence, in which a man who is being beaten swallows a set of keys, there is a sense of privacy being invaded. That sense is made more acute with the arrival of Roy (Robert Skjaerstad), a bored Oslo mailman who finds creative ways to editorialize while doing his job. A citizen who treats Roy rudely may find his most personal mail steamed open and covered with spaghetti stains as signs of Roy's ill humor.

title: A Chance To Shine (Or Relax) At the Met
description: For the young singers performing in the 1998 Metropolitan Opera National Council Winners Concert on Sunday afternoon at the Met, the event must have been at once thrilling and terrifying.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREGORY, BLANCHE C.
description: GREGORY-Blanche C. Literary Agent, Blanche C. Gregory, Inc., on April 6, 1998. Beloved sister of William E. Gregory. Loving aunt, great aunt, and great great aunt, associate and friend. Services and interment private.

title: Metro Business; Echlin Sues Suitor Over Tally of Votes
description: Echlin Inc. of Branford, Conn., said yesterday that it had filed suit against the SPX Corporation, charging that it improperly claimed to have Echlin shareholder support for a special meeting on SPX's $3 billion hostile takeover bid.

description: BASEBALL

title: Queen Of Blues Is Royally Annoyed With Life
description: As Dinah Washington in ''Dinah Was,'' an impassioned retrospective of the troubled life of the great blues singer, the vivacious Yvette Freeman takes no guff. Oliver Goldstick's spirited and tuneful play with music at the WPA Theater sets the action in 1959, when Washington is making her debut as a headliner at the Sahara Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev. And she is fuming. The management has assigned her a room in a trailer out back, with members of a dog act for neighbors: hotel policy forbids black entertainers from staying in the main building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAGAN, ESTHER ''SIS'' MILLER
description: KAGAN-Esther ''Sis'' Miller, 94. Died at her home in Mount Airy, PA, March 28, 1998. She is survived by her 2 sons Jonathan M. Kagan, M.D. and Jeremy Kagan; her sister Sally Brash; her brother Louis Miller; two daughters-in-love Ginnie and Anneke; 4 granddaughters Deborah, Eve, Ali, and Joanna; and her nieces Devra and Linda; a nephew Edward, and his children Julian, Rachel, and Kate. A memorial service will be held at Rodeph Shalom Temple, 615 North Broad Street, Philadelphia, PA, on Sunday, April 12 at 11 AM. (215-627-6747).

title: Prosperous Bid To Ship East
description: Prosperous Bid will run in the Wood Memorial at Aqueduct on Saturday, said Bob Baffert, his trainer.

title: Review/Fashion; Karan's Comfort and Calm
description: Donna Karan's stock may be shaky, but her fashion esthetic is rock solid. Despite a soundtrack of Indian love poetry inspired by her admiration of Deepak Chopra -- a distracting soundtrack that seemed to irritate the audience at Friday afternoon's fall show -- it would be difficult to fault the clothes. They were designed for comfort and beauty, to form a flattering background for a woman's personality.

title: Gerrit Jan van Ingen Schenau, Clap Skate Creator, Dies at 53
description: In the past two winters, speed skating has been revolutionized by a clap skate that allows skaters to go so much faster that they have rewritten the entire record book. Gerrit Jan van Ingen Schenau, a Dutch scientist who developed the skate, died last Thursday in Weteringburg, 25 miles south of Amsterdam. He was 53.

title: Where Books Are a Success Story; Festivals Booming Amid Publishing Gloom
description: John Grisham, it turns out, has a philosophy of writing, almost as concisely calibrated as his gazillion-selling legal potboilers are.

title: Trail of the Jet
description: Q. Why do contrails form?

title: BBDO Executive To Leave Company
description: Arnie Semsky, a longtime media executive at the BBDO Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group in New York, unexpectedly announced yesterday that he would leave the agency at the end of the year to consult for media and entertainment companies and teach students about the importance of media.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKLEY, JOHN LUTHER
description: BECKLEY-John Luther. Of Livingston, NJ formerly of North Caldwell, NJ, April 5, 1998, husband of Eleanor Beckley (nee Howe), father of Georgia May Jervey of Murray Hill, NJ, Jean B. Crane of Little Falls, NJ, and William H. of Meguon, WI, also survived by six grandchildren and three greatgrandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held on Wednesday, April 8, 1998 at 11:30 AM, from the William R. Dangler Funeral Home, 309 Springfield Avenue, Summit, NJ. Interment private. In lieu of flowers donations in his name may be made to The University of Vermont, Burlington, Vermont.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPRITZER, MARJORIE
description: SPRITZER-Marjorie. The President, Chancellor, Boards of Governors and Overseeers, faculty, administration and students of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion record with profound sorrow the tragic death of Mrs. Marjorie Spritzer, a dedicated and devoted member of the Board of Governors and New York Board of Overseers. She was a tenacious advocate for the wellbeing of Reform Judaism and her commitment to Jewish education and the needs of her Miami Jewish community were well known to all who knew her. Her broad, winsome smile embraced both old and new friends. To her dear husband Michael, their children Jeffrey and Blaire, her mother Anne and her family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. May Marjorie's memory be a blessing for us all. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman, President Dr. Alfred Gottschalk, Chancellor Burton Lehman, Chair, Board of Governors Robert M. Heller, Chair, NY Board of Overseers

title: Microsoft Billionaire Buys Dallas Cable-TV Operator
description: Making his biggest personal investment yet, Paul G. Allen, co-founder of the Microsoft Corporation, said yesterday that he had agreed to acquire the Marcus Cable Company, the nation's 10th-largest cable television operator, for an estimated $1.3 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, RUTH
description: PARKER-Ruth. In her 86th year on April 4, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Manny. She will be missed by her many good friends, Betty Bowers, and her cousin Frances Rosenbusch.

title: When Swelling in a Limb Persists
description: MOST people have experienced feet that won't fit back into shoes after a long airplane ride, legs that resemble piano stools after a daylong shopping spree, fingers that won't make a fist after a long aerobic walk or an arm that swells from an insect bite or sunburn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZENBERGER, SAM
description: SCHWARZENBERGER - Sam. Young Israel of Forest Hills mourns the passing of its member Sam Schwarzenberger. May the Almighty console the family together with all the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem.

title: New Wang Unit Leads to Charge
description: Wang Global said today that it would take charges totaling as much as $380 million for the costs of dismissing employees and closing offices at its newly acquired Olsy unit, to reduce overlap with Wang's operations.

title: Heritage Financial Deal
description: The Heritage Financial Corporation said today that it would buy North Pacific Bancorp as it expands in Washington State. Heritage, based in Olympia, will buy all stock of the closely held North Pacific for an undisclosed amount. Heritage, a bank holding company with assets of $323 million, owns Heritage Bank, a bank with 10 full-service branches in the south Puget Sound region of Washington. North Pacific, based in Tacoma, Wash., owns North Pacific Bank, a bank with two branches in the Tacoma region. It has $74.7 million in assets.

title: 11th-Hour Rescue Of Late Leis
description: It's a lost-luggage-at-the-airport story to beat them all. Missing: a refrigerated crate filled with more than a thousand handmade Hawaiian orchid leis, flown Saturday night from Honolulu to Kennedy International Airport and bound for the necks of the powerful guests at a fund-raising dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night.

title: Financial Services Heavyweights Try Do-It-Yourself Deregulation
description: For two decades Washington has tried and failed to update the Depression-era laws governing the rapidly changing financial services industry. Today the industry took matters into its own hands.

title: Call It Transcendental Complication
description: In 1841, Nathaniel Hawthorne went to live at Brook Farm, a new commune in Massachusetts dedicated to creating a transcendental utopia. He left after several months, disillusioned with transcendentalism, but with enough material for a novel, ''The Blithedale Romance,'' which he published a decade later. ''Blithedale: A Virtual Utopia,'' which is being performed at Here in SoHo, is a theater piece that resembles nothing so much as a CD-ROM version of the novel.

title: Union Organizer's Warm and Chilly Reinstatement
description: More than a year after being dismissed from her job, Kathy Saumier went back to work at a plastics factory here today with a little band of union supporters outside to applaud her, and her dogged effort to unionize workers still ahead.

title: Networks Turn to Affiliates To Defray Program Costs
description: Since the earliest days of radio in the 1920's, one principle has governed the relationship between networks and the hundreds of stations around the country affiliated with them: The networks put on the programs and they paid the stations a fee to broadcast them.

title: South African Military Chief Quits Over False Coup Report
description: The chief of South Africa's Army, under attack for his role in presenting President Nelson Mandela with a bogus report on a left-wing plot to overthrow the Government, resigned today, saying he had lost the trust he needed to function properly.

title: Once Again, The Mayor Hogs the Ball
description: GIVEN his behavior as Mayor, you have to wonder sometimes if the young Rudolph W. Giuliani flunked recess in grade school for never learning to pass the ball to other children. The thought arises because once again an arm of local government has taken Mr. Giuliani to court in an attempt to pry data from him that it needs to do its job.

title: With Few Layoffs Planned, a Collective Sigh of Relief
description: Some Travelers Group and Citicorp employees heard the news about the proposed merger of their companies yesterday morning while exercising on treadmills in the office gym. Others got it off the Bloomberg wire. Still others learned about it from company Web pages, while traveling to work on the subway, or when it came over the ticker.

title: Computer Plant in Mexico
description: Acer Computec Latino America, a subsidiary of Acer Inc. of Taiwan, said today that it planned to build a second Mexican plant, in the United States-border city of Ciudad Juarez, to expand production of computers. Construction will begin on April 16, said a spokeswoman for the company. Its other plant is in Mexicali. Acer would not say how much it planned to spend on the new plant.

title: Ferraro Says Fund-Raising Shows Her Strength
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro announced yesterday that she had raised $1.35 million for her United States Senate campaign in the nearly three months since she bounded into the race, proclaiming that her success at reeling in contributions demonstrated the vigor of her candidacy.

title: One Name Is Liberty, And Another Is License
description: If ''In Your Face, America'' is not exactly the final face-off between the exponents of dirty talk and of coarse actions and their family-values opponents, don't blame Bernard Goldberg, tonight's correspondent on ''Public Eye With Bryant Gumbel.'' The terms of the argument challenge definition; the debate comes down to feelings.

title: As It Confronts Growth, School Board Is Stripped of Power
description: What began last fall as a parent's battle against a decision by the Board of Education of the Freehold Regional High School District to eliminate class ranking and do away with a grading policy that rewarded students in honors classes has left the board virtually stripped of its power and a Federal judge in charge.

title: Military Discharges of Homosexuals Soar
description: The military is discharging 67 percent more gay and lesbian troops today than when the Clinton Administration adopted its ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy, according to a Defense Department report to be issued later this month.

title: Court Panel's Ruling Limiting Medicaid Services Is Appealed
description: A recent court ruling that allows Connecticut, New York and Vermont to deny some Medicaid funds to severely disabled poor people is under attack from lawyers around the state and nation, who today began an effort to overturn the decision.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK RALLIES. The mark rose on a strong German manufacturing report and expectations of lower unemployment, evidence that Germany's economy is improving. In New York, the dollar cost 1.8403 marks, down from 1.8472.

title: Plans Offered To Cut Power Of Microsoft
description: Concerned computer industry executives have approached the Justice Department with a wide-ranging set of 10 proposed remedies that they believe would help rein in the monopoly power of the Microsoft Corporation.

title: Cassell, the Talk of the Game, Burns Hornets for 35 Points
description: Sam Cassell was moving through the crowd of fans outside the locker rooms at Continental Arena tonight, deftly signing autographs to his left and right while never slowing down a step.

title: Dartmouth Appoints A History Professor As Its New President
description: James Wright, the provost of Dartmouth College and a scholar of American history who is writing a book about the Republican Party from Wendell Willkie to Ronald Reagan, was named the 16th president of Dartmouth yesterday. He will take office in August, succeeding James O. Freedman.

title: By Design; Standing Tall (Securely)
description: The alternative to the stiletto for spring is a sandal or mule perched securely on a platform sole.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''What's recess?''

title: Rangers' Rookies Take a Futuristic Stance
description: For several Rangers, next season is now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOVERS, PATRICIA
description: BOVERS-Patricia. Of Edgewater, NJ on April 5, 1998. Devoted sister of William, Eileen and Kathleen. Friends may call at the Barrett Funeral Home, 148 Dean Drive, Tenafly, NJ, Tuesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass on Wednesday 10 A.M., Madonna Church at the Cemetery. Interment Madonna Cemetery, Fort Lee, New Jersey.

title: Hamas Killed Its Own, Say Palestinians
description: The Palestinian Authority said today that a suspected bomb-maker killed in the West Bank last week was slain in a feud within the militant Islamic group Hamas, and not by Israel.

title: Many Schools Putting an End to Child's Play
description: Sitting in a kindergarten classroom filled with story books, colorful drawings and dazzling computers, Toya Gray was daydreaming about playing outside in the sunshine.

title: BMW Says Its Offer For Rolls-Royce Is Final
description: BMW A.G. said yesterday that it would not raise its bid for Rolls-Royce Motor Cars Ltd. even though Volkswagen A.G. increased its offer for the British maker of luxury cars last week. VW raised its bid a day after BMW's offer of $:340 million ($554.2 million) was accepted by Vickers P.L.C., the owner of Rolls-Royce.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WALERSTEIN, JEFFREY DAVID
description: WALERSTEIN - Jeffrey David. April 7, 1964-April 14, 1989. Time has not been much of a healer. Miss you more and more. Love ya Mom and Dad

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERSE, HARRY H.
description: PERSE-Harry H. 81 years, died on April 4, devoted husband of Ann, beloved father of Thomas, Ilsa, Richard and Laura. Loving grandfather of Tobias, Allison, Rachel, James and Zoey. Harry, you'll be missed. Your humor and warmth will live on. A memorial service will be held Thursday, April 9, 1998 at 2PM at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, Madison Avenue and 81 Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Center for Family Life,. 345 43rd Street, Brooklyn, New York 11232.

title: Crown Heights Trial Had Vigorous Prosecution; Apology Required
description: To the Editor:

title: . . . But With Luck and Diligence, Treasure-Troves of Data Can Be Preserved
description: IF you use a personal computer, you are probably generating your own ever-growing accumulation of fragile digital information without giving much thought to its survival. Financial and tax records, inventories, genealogies, photographs and even love letters are increasingly created and stored as ones and zeroes whose meanings may be impossible to reconstruct someday.

title: Rheingold's Return
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: LEVEL 3 COMMUNICATIONS ADDING XCOM TECHNOLOGIES
description: The information-services company Level 3 Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the closely held Xcom Technologies Inc. for $165 million in stock. Level 3, based in Omaha, is seeking to build a national Internet-based communications network. It recently completed its split from Peter Kiewit Sons Inc., the diversified holding company. Xcom, based in Cambridge, Mass., is an exchange carrier and communications software development company. Level 3's stock fell $1 a share yesterday, to $61.50

title: CBS SELLING SECURITY SYSTEMS BUSINESS TO HONEYWELL
description: Honeywell Inc. agreed yesterday to buy Westinghouse Security Electronics Inc., a subsidiary of the CBS Corporation, for an undisclosed sum. Honeywell has been struggling to reverse sagging sales at its security system controls unit, which has been hurt by declining United States demand for thermostats, alarms and other home products. Westinghouse Security is the latest business to be shed by CBS, which is focusing on its media and entertainment businesses. CBS, formerly the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, has said it plans to sell all of its industrial businesses by the middle of the year. Westinghouse Security, based in Santa Clara, Calif., has 150 employees.

title: Supreme Court Will Move Up Ruling on Lawyer-Client Privilege
description: The Supreme Court yielded today to a request by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, for a speedy resolution of a dispute over whether the attorney-client privilege outlives the death of a client.

title: Dutch Insurer Considers Sale of a U.S. Unit
description: ING Groep N.V. said today that it was considering selling the Netherlands Insurance Company, its United States property and casualty business, to focus on its life and annuity lines.

title: DII GROUP TO REPORT LOSS BECAUSE OF $54 MILLION CHARGE
description: The DII Group Inc. of Niwot, Colo., said yesterday that it would report a loss for the first quarter because of a charge of $54 million, or $1.54 a basic share, for revamping its Orbit Semiconductor unit. The company also revised its estimate of earnings per share before the charge to about 28 cents to reflect lower operating results at Orbit, which DII acquired in August 1996. DII had been expected to earn 36 cents a share. While the company's other three business units, which design and make printed circuit boards and assemble electronics components, are performing well, the Orbit problems will result in a loss after the charge of about $1.26 a basic share, the company said. Shares of DII fell $2.3125 yesterday, to $18.3125.

title: Van Gundy Seeks Effort From Staggering Knicks
description: The Knicks have a groggy, punch-drunk look right now. They are acting as if they are on the verge of falling asleep a tick before the ball drops on New Year's Eve.

title: Aftershocks of Assimilation
description: As the wars in the former Yugoslavia have so tragically demonstrated, history can never be swept under the rug. Sooner or later, the poisonous dust balls of old resentments slip out and begin contaminating the atmosphere. ''The Other Shore,'' directed by Dominique Cabarera, is not the only recent French film to explore the continuingly painful legacy of France's colonization of Algeria, which ended in 1962 with Algerian independence. But it is more blunt than most. When its main character, Georges Montero, a prosperous ''pied noir'' (an Algerian-born Frenchman) returns to France for the first time in more than 30 years for a cataract operation, his mere presence in the country ignites an anguished chain reaction of questions and recriminations.

title: Scientist at Work: James D. Watson; Impresario of the Genome Looks Back With Candor
description: NOT every day do you see a renowned biologist dancing vigorously with an unclothed woman. But here indubitably is Francis Crick, his head thrown back in laughter, his arms around a partner who does not seem very intent on asking him about deoxyribonucleic acid.

title: SHAPING A COLOSSUS: THE CHIEFS -- The Odd Couple; Success to Hinge On How Intellect And Savvy Mix
description: The two men who will run the huge new financial powerhouse to be made up of Citicorp and Travelers Group could hardly be more different.

title: A New Squeeze on Gun Imports
description: ''You do not need an Uzi to go deer hunting,'' President Clinton said yesterday in announcing a permanent ban on the importation of 58 types of semiautomatic assault weapons. That principle should have been recognized years ago. Mr. Clinton's directive will at last close a loophole that has allowed foreign gun dealers to infiltrate the legal barrier against imports of assault weapons.

title: On My Mind; A Lady Of Arkansas
description: The young woman who walked into the Governor's hotel suite looked as she did every workday -- trim, dressed in a simple, elegant suit, hair cut in short chic, just the right amount of lipstick. She did not know why she had been called to meet the Governor; the trooper did not say. But she was tickled to be there.

title: Williams Plans To Return Soon
description: Jayson Williams was on the court tonight, long before the Nets and the Charlotte Hornets squared off, with just a ball boy feeding him gentle passes. With his right hand still in a cast, Williams repeatedly drove across the lane, flicking in short left-handed hook shots. He insisted that it is more than the idle work of a bored player, predicting a return to the lineup in 10 days.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, BENJAMIN
description: YOUNG-Benjamin. On April 6, 1998. Lawyer and community leader of Riverdale, NY, died at age 94. The oldest practicing attorney of New York Law School (Class of '24), he served his profession and community until age 92, was Counsel for the National and New York Associations for Meat and Poultry Purveyors and for the Marketmen's Association of the Port of New York. He served his fellow men as a Government Appeal Agent for the Selective Service Board during WWII, President of the Bronx High School of Science Parents' Association, assisted by his devoted wife of 48 years, Bess, and as Trustee and Vice President of Riverdale Temple. His pride in his children, Ellen Rosenberg of Riverdale, NY and Laurence of Cambridge, MA, his grandchildren Eliot, Leslie, and Robert Young, and Lauren and Elizabeth Rosenberg and great grandchildren Bess, Ella, Joshua and Evan, was matched by their admiration and love for him. He is survived by his wife Bernice, sonin-law Jerry Rosenberg, daughterin-law Jody Young and sisters Celia and Molly. Services Wed, April 8 at 11:30 A.M., Riverdale Temple, West 246 St. and Independence Ave, Riverdale, NY. Contributions in his memory may be made to Riverdale Temple.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KITSON, THOMAS M.
description: KITSON-Thomas M. Belated (3/22/97) seventh anniversary. You were some piece of material. Your friends and family will always love and miss you.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, MURIEL GURDON KIESSLING
description: COOPER-Muriel Gurdon Kiessling Died at the Honey Hill Rest Home in Norwalk, Connecticut, Sunday, April 5, 1998. She was a resident of New Canaan, Connecticut. Mrs. Cooper was the daughter of the late Calvin Kiessling and Grace Saltonstall Kiessling of New Canaan. She is survived by two sons, Richard Saltonstall Fay of New York City and William Bayard Cooper of Phoenix, AZ, as well as two grandchildren, Lisa and Keith Fay. Mrs. Cooper was active for many years as a volunteer with the New Canaan Historical Society, the Red Cross, Silver Hill Hospital & Inter-Church Driving Service. There will be no funeral service.

title: Anatomy of the Left Coast Without the Sunshine
description: FROM WEST TO EAST

title: Accounts
description: * Certified Angus Beef Program, Wooster, Ohio, a nonprofit division of the American Angus Association, to Meldrum & Fewsmith Communications, Cleveland, a division of Wolf Group, as the first agency to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $6 million to $8 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HINTON, BRUCE MICHAEL
description: HINTON-Bruce Michael. Suddenly, on April 4, 1998. Survived by his friends Michael Davis, John Gnerre and Eric Niemand. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to God's Love We Deliver.

title: Pena Resigns as Energy Secretary, Citing Concerns for Family
description: Federico F. Pena said today that he would resign as Energy Secretary in June and return to private life because the demands of being a Cabinet secretary were too much for his family.

title: 2 Brazil Towns Fight for Road Closed for a Wildlife Park
description: All of the people demonstrating here recently had a vivid where-were-you-when-it-happened memory of the closing of the road into the Iguacu Falls National Park a dozen years ago.

title: Mets' Staff Is Top Shelf; It Has to Be
description: Bobby Valentine was asked whether he thought other teams in the league respected the Mets' pitching. ''I hope not,'' the manager replied. ''I hope they think we're a bunch of ham-and-eggers.''

title: Iran and Iraq Begin Big Trade of P.O.W.'s
description: In an important step toward resolving their bitter enmity, Iran and Iraq have begun a major exchange of prisoners held captive since the two Persian Gulf powers ended their long and bloody war a decade ago.

title: CBS and the Masters Keep Business Simple
description: On the list of expensive TV deals, count the Masters out. It is an anomaly -- a sports event that spurns top dollar. If the Masters were opened to bidding, it would easily surpass the $4 million to $5 million that CBS pays and the price tags for the three other majors: the United States Open, about $13 million, the P.G.A. Championship, $10 million, and the British Open, $8 million.

title: A 'Right' to Bear 50 Assault Weapons?
description: Growing up as an Army brat in the 1950's and 60's, I could have been a poster boy for the National Rifle Association. When I was 12, I started competing in N.R.A.-sponsored shooting contests every Saturday morning. When I was 13, I was given my first single-shot 16-gauge shotgun as a Christmas present and started going hunting with my father and brother in the forests surrounding the Army posts and small rural towns where we lived.

title: Study Says Passaic River Is Choked With Toxins
description: The Passaic River, which winds through Passaic, Morris and Essex Counties, is among the 20 most endangered rivers in the country, according to a study released yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KAHN, E.J., JR.
description: KAHN-E.J., Jr. Your Red Arrow buddies miss you.

title: Courier Rallies to Save Americans
description: In the end, after Jim Courier's tortuous trip to the equivalent of no-man's land, the fifth set of the fifth and deciding match of the Davis Cup clash between the United States and Russia, an ecstatic United States team paraded beneath the canopy of an American flag. There were war whoops and tears and bearhugs, evidence of the camaraderie Davis Cup can bring to a tennis court: where else would four grown men and their captain hunker down and perform a pig pile in public?

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Citicorp and Travelers Plan Biggest Merger Ever

title: Nikko Shares Rebound As Legal Concerns Ease
description: The shares of the Nikko Securities Company were sharply higher yesterday, after the Finance Ministry's decision late Friday to impose trading penalties removed uncertainties that had recently affected the stock, brokers said. Shares of Nikko, a leading financial company, closed at 432 yen ($3.20), up 54 yen.

title: A Violinist's Intense First Visit
description: Priya Mitchell, a 27-year-old British violinist who gave her New York recital debut at Weill Recital Hall on Friday night, brings an intriguing mix of qualities to her playing.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  KEMPLER, EDWARD
description: KEMPLER - Edward. Twenty years have passed today that you left us; tomorrow is your birthday. We think of you every day. Phyllis, Mark and Roy

title: New Light Shed on Normal Sex Behavior in a Child
description: WHEN the third-grade teacher noticed a student habitually touching her genitals as she sat in class, she became concerned and did what Federal law requires of teachers: she told the school authorities that the girl displayed one of the signs of sexual abuse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LESLIE, GEORGE
description: LESLIE-George. Of Westwood, Massachusetts, and Fishers Island, New York, peacefully on April 5 at age 85, George Robert III. Beloved husband of Catherine (McIntire) Leslie. He attended Bovee and Pomfret Schools and New York University, and was a former Vice President of the Irving Trust Co of New York. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his loving family, Alexander G. Leslie, Peter D. Leslie, Rhoda MacCallum, H. Ashley Smith, Catherine S. Leonard, Patricia S. Perron, William T.M. Smith, 12 grandchildren and one great grandchild. Contributions to the American Field Service International, 313 East 43rd Street, NYC, New York, 10017 in his memory would be appreciated. Interment will be in Mount Auburn Cemetery, Cambridge, Massachusetts.

title: Father of Country Claimed Executive Privilege
description: To the Editor:

title: A Weighty Conclusion
description: The more television children watch, the greater the chance that they will be sedentary and overweight, researchers say.

title: THE 62D MASTERS: The Nightmare Green; The Putts on Augusta's 16th Can Add Up in a Hurry
description: Jack Nicklaus almost had a hole-in-one there, but Tom Watson once five-putted there.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HERTZBERG, ROBERT
description: HERTZBERG-Robert. Beloved husband of Myra. Devoted son of Alice and the late Nelson. Loving father of David, Steven and Gregory and their spouses. Dearest brother of Edward and Richard, and wonderful grandfather of Rebecca, Tara, Natasha, Daniel, Dane, Zachary and Joshua. He blessed us all with his love, caring and generosity. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'', corner of Park and Passaic Streets, Hackensack, New Jersey, Tuesday, 12 noon.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MEDESKE, MARY ANN
description: MEDESKE-Mary Ann. May 30, 1904-April 7, 1996. Dearest Mother, you are alway with us. We thank God very day for making you our mother. Rest in heavenly peace. Enternal love, Catherine and Dolly

title: Mayoral Spleen
description: When MAYOR RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI decides something isn't good, he isn't wishy-washy. He says so. And things that aren't good often seem to have happened in previous administrations.

title: Silver Is Down 3% on Rumor Buffett Sold Some of Holdings
description: Silver fell 3.1 percent yesterday, hurt by speculation that the billionaire investor Warren E. Buffett had sold about a third of his silver holdings since amassing a sizable stockpile early this year.

title: More on Benefits of Alcohol
description: STUDIES involving tens of thousands of men and women have strongly suggested that moderate consumption of alcohol can reduce the risk of heart attacks. But how? One mechanism seems to be an alcohol-induced increase in protective high-density-lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol, which helps to keep arteries free of fatty deposits.

title: Unfair Airline Practices
description: In the 20 years since Washington deregulated the nation's airline industry, consumers have benefited from discount fares, more frequent flights to many destinations and promotional awards like frequent-flier miles. But one does not have to be an antitrust lawyer to notice that fares have gotten unnervingly steep on routes where there is insufficient competition. One of the probable reasons became obvious yesterday when the Department of Transportation said that major airlines had driven out new competitors by such unfair practices as sharply cutting fares and by saturating routes with more planes until the challenger withdraws.

title: Norman Says Layoff Gives Him an Edge
description: Greg Norman declared himself ready to play the Masters today, despite having withdrawn from the Players Championship two weeks ago with an inflamed left shoulder.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Personal Shopper column of House & Home on Thursday about bathroom furnishings misstated the address for Totem Design in Manhattan, which sells them. It is 71 Franklin Street, not 52.

title: Think New Ideas Buys Seattle Partner
description: Think New Ideas in New York said yesterday that it had acquired Herring/Newman Inc., one of the largest agencies in Seattle, for $3 million in cash and stock.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about viewership of television coverage of the dismissal of Paula Corbin Jones's suit against President Clinton misstated the rating of MSNBC on Thursday, the day of the development. It was 0.2, not 0.5. (A point represents 361,000 homes for MSNBC.)

title: Guidant to Pay Bard To Settle Patent Suits
description: The Guidant Corporation said today that it would pay C. R. Bard Inc. $100 million in the second quarter to settle two patent-infringement suits.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO CURB UNFAIR PRACTICES OF MAJOR AIRLINES
description: The Secretary of Transportation announced today that the Government would levy fines, if necessary, to stop major airlines from driving out new carriers through the use of unfair practices like flooding the market with cheap seats on competitive routes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FASS, DAVID
description: FASS-David. Beloved husband of Phyllis (Jagoda). Devoted father of Steven and Marjorie and loving father-in-law of Steve Ryall.

title: Physical Laws Collide In a Black Hole Bet
description: TO an outsider, nothing might seem more ridiculous than the spectacle of grown men and women sitting around a conference table soberly discussing what would happen if a volume of the Encyclopedia Britannica were dropped down a black hole. Yet this very question lies at the heart of the ''information paradox,'' a seeming contradiction to the laws of physics that is causing scientists to re-examine some of their most basic assumptions about how the universe is made.

title: Boeing Falls Short on Plane Deliveries
description: The Boeing Company said today that it had delivered 108 planes in the first quarter, two short of its previous estimate, as the company tries to clear up production bottlenecks.

title: Wynalda To Miss Six Weeks
description: Eric Wynalda of the San Jose Clash, the career leading scorer for the United States national team with 32 goals, injured a ligament in his left knee a game Sunday and will miss at least six weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDSON, BEATTY
description: DAVIDSON-Beatty. Dear sister of Mary Kalish and Anna Decovick. Loving aunt and great aunt. Graveside service on Tuesday, at 1 P.M., at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, Long Island.

title: MidAmerican to Buy Real Estate Group
description: In an unusual move to market electricity and natural gas to homeowners, the MidAmerican Energy Holdings Company, a utility in Iowa, said yesterday that it would buy a large real estate brokerage group for an undisclosed price.

title: Fateful Crash In Africa: Link to U.S. Is Denied
description: A former French Government minister said today that missiles from American stockpiles were used to shoot down a plane carrying the Presidents of Rwanda and Burundi in 1994, an act that led to a massacre that took at least 500,000 lives. The United States immediately denied that there was any evidence to support those allegations.

title: Tandy's Chief Will Retire at End of Year
description: The Tandy Corporation said today that John V. Roach would resign as chief executive at the end of the year and be replaced by the company's president, Leonard H. Roberts, who is credited with reviving the company's Radio Shack chain.

title: At Queens School, Boy, 8, Is Found With Loaded Gun
description: An 8-year-old boy was arrested yesterday for taking a loaded gun to an elementary school in Queens on at least two days last week, the police said, and the independent investigator for the city's schools said he would look into why the school principal did not immediately report the incident.

title: Man Found in Subway Died of Head Injuries
description: The Brooklyn man who was found dead in a subway tunnel on Sunday apparently died of a fractured skull and massive head injuries shortly after his disappearance on March 11, a spokeswoman for the city Medical Examiner's office said yesterday.

title: Tammy Wynette, Country Star Known For 'Stand by Your Man,' Dies at 55
description: Tammy Wynette, whose 1968 hit ''Stand By Your Man'' established her as a queen of country music, died yesterday in her sleep at her home in Nashville. She was 55.

title: SCIENCE WATCH; The Curse of the Cure
description: THEY are a special breed, those cat owners who are allergic to their cats and put up with sneezes and coughs and itchy eyes out of love and loyalty.

title: Whimsy and Charm, Courtesy of the French
description: For 20 years, Charles Wadsworth's Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center thrived as much on its choice of music as on the way that music was performed. Mr. Wadsworth's delicate programs, where whimsy, charm, oddity and substance seemed happily to meet, could satisfy the spirit just by the reading of them.

title: COMPANY REPORTS: THE MARKETS -- Market Place; Motorola issues some relatively good news, then some bad.
description: MOTOROLA Inc. reported late yesterday that it had managed to match Wall Street's diminished expectations for its first-quarter earnings, but any likelihood that investors in technology companies would take that as good news was dashed when the company warned that its second quarter was shaping up much more poorly than projected.

title: Dow Passes 9,000
description: The Dow Jones industrial average closed above 9,000 for the first time yesterday, propelled by news of the biggest corporate merger in history. The average climbed 49.82 points, to 9,033.23.

title: An Evolution of Pre-Victorian Pin Stripes to One Big Red Umbrella
description: They are two of the most venerable names in American capitalism, but Citicorp and Travelers Group have taken decidedly different paths to the pinnacle of the financial services business.

title: Energy Head to Resign
description: Federico F. Pena, the Secretary of Energy and a former Transportation Secretary, said he would resign in June because the demands of being a Cabinet secretary put too much strain on his family.

title: A Single PC Chip That Almost Does It All
description: The National Semiconductor Corporation announced today that it would offer the industry's first microprocessor that places most of the functions of a personal computer on a single chip.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Jewish Groups Go to Capitol Squabbling Among Themselves
description: A battle of competing letters on the Middle East has broken out in Congress, reflecting tensions among American Jewish groups about the Clinton Administration's attempt to revive a peace effort in trouble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINBERG, EDITH
description: STEINBERG-Edith. On April 4. Devoted wife of the late Benjamin. Loving and cherished mother of Susan Sills and Steven Steinberg. Devoted sister of Henry Lasker. Beloved grandmother of Deborah and Eric, great grandmother of Jacob. Services on Tuesday, at 11:30 AM, Schwartz Bros, Jeffer Memorial Chaples, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HANLEY, CHARLES J.
description: HANLEY-Charles J. April 7, 1977. In loving memory of a wonderful father. The Children

title: Snoring Can Damage Throat
description: Researchers at the Karolinska Institute in Stockholm report that snoring may be hazardous to your health.

title: Physicists Study the Honeybee For Clues to Complex Problems
description: HOW doth the little busy bee improve each shining hour? By making honey, of course. But also by prompting scientists to think about the deep significance of gooey coils that pile up when honey is poured on toast, and how quantum mechanics might choreograph the dancing of bees.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in the sports pages yesterday listing the Mets' starting lineup showed an incorrect flag for Alberto Castillo's native country, the Dominican Republic. The flag was from the Caribbean island nation of Dominica. The correct one appears above.

title: Much Ado About Balking for Mets
description: The unexpected entertainment provided by the Mets occurred in the fourth inning this time, not the ninth. The intriguing display was an annoyed Bobby Valentine being ejected for vigorously arguing a balk call, not another successful comeback by his team. The eventual outcome was Francisco Cordova and the Pirates silencing the Mets, 4-2, not more late magic at Shea Stadium. Not yesterday.

title: IN LARGEST DEAL EVER, CITICORP PLANS MERGER WITH TRAVELERS GROUP
description: Two of America's largest companies, Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc., agreed yesterday to a merger that would create the world's largest financial-services concern. Not since the freewheeling pre-Depression era would so many different financial businesses be corralled under one roof in this country.

title: Time to Restore Affirmative Action?
description: To the Editor:

title: Improving the Housing Court
description: In New York City, landlord-tenant relations are a never-ending war, and Housing Court is ground zero. Landlord groups say the court has an overwhelming pro-tenant bias. Tenant organizations say the chaos of the courts and the generally poor quality of the judges are frightening and discouraging for poor people who often cannot afford legal representation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALABRESE, BENJAMIN

The business, Time Warner Telecom Inc., filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell an unspecified number of class A common shares. Proceeds could be used to repay debt. The unit, which provides telecommunications services to midsize and large businesses, is worth as much as $1.5 billion, analysts said.

They played to enthusiastic audiences with collections for devotees, rather than customers seeking uniformity, Mr. Galindo luring guests to his affair with a bus ride populated by drag queens.

title: U.S.A. FLORAL TO BUY 8 FLORAL PRODUCTS COMPANIES

Floral Products, based in Washington, is a wholesale flower distributor. It agreed to buy David L. Jones Wholesale Ltd. of Canada; it completed the acquisitions of: Edfrancor Inc.; AFS Marketing Inc.; Pacific Floral Wholesale Inc. and Rose City Inc.; Master Flowers Inc.; Maxima Farms Inc. and Maxima Farms Ltd.; the Saint Ann Trading Corporation, and Elite Farms Talent Inc. and Anvacu Inc.. description: Leica A.G. of Switzerland said yesterday that it had sold its microscope division to a group of international investors for a total of $500 million. Schroders Ventures of Frankfurt and London headed the group that is buying Leica Microsystems G.m.b.H. of Germany.

title: For Alexei Shirov, There's Just One Goal: Attack!
description: When a player wins the most games outright in a supertournament like that at Linares, Spain, and still does not take first prize, it's a good bet it is Alexei Shirov. No one else won an incisive five games at the event this year, but the Spanish (formerly Latvian) grandmaster lost three, too many if you want to come out on top against the world's best.

title: Time and Technology Threaten Digital Archives . . .
description: JEFF ROTHENBERG, a senior computer scientist at the Rand Corporation, is fond of quoting Shakespeare's 18th sonnet, the one that begins ''Shall I compare thee to a summer's day?'' But in keeping with his interest in the preservation of digital data, he prefers the final couplet: ''So long as men can breathe or eyes can see/So long lives this and this gives life to thee.'' Referring to the poem itself, the lines attest to the poet's faith in the staying power of ink on paper.

title: Sharpton's Lawyer Is Given Contempt Threat by Judge

But within minutes, the judge reversed himself after defense lawyers furiously accused him of siding with the plaintiff in the case, Steven A. Pagones.

title: TRIZECHAHN TO SELL RETAIL PROPERTIES FOR $2.55 BILLION
description: The TrizecHahn Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its retail property holdings to Westfield America Inc. and the Rouse Company for $2.55 billion in cash, taking advantage of the lofty prices being paid for shopping malls that serve affluent consumers. The 20 properties include some of the best-performing malls in the United States, including Bridgewater Commons in Bridgewater, N.J., and Fashion Show in Las Vegas, Nev. The sale will net the Toronto-based TrizecHahn $1.2 billion after the retirement of debt. Westfield, which is based in Los Angeles, is acquiring 12 malls in California and one in Washington for $1.44 billion, and Rouse, based in Columbia, Md., is buying the remaining seven malls for $1.11 billion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CELLA, RICHARD
description: CELLA-Richard. Brigadier General Richard Cella was a command fighter pilot who flew more than 200 combat missions over the Pacific during World War II. He entered military service in May, 1939, as a Second Lieutenant in the Coast Artillery Corps reserve. He received his Master's Degree in Aeronautical Engineering from M.I.T. in 1947. In December 1962, he assumed the position of Deputy Chief of Staff/Systems, Ballistics and Space Systems, AFSC. During his services, Brigadier General Richard Cella was awarded, Legion of Merit, Distinguished Flying Cross with Oak Leaf Cluster; Air Medal with two Oak Leaf Clusters; Air Force Commendation Medal; Presidential Unit Citation with Oak Leaf Cluster; American Defense Service Medal; American Campaign Medal; Asiatic-Pacific Campaign Medal with 9 Campaign Stars; World War II Victory Medal; Army of Occupation Medal-Japan; Philippine Liberation Ribbon with One Star. In 1994 he was knighted by the President of the Italian Republic, Pertini. Brigadier General Richard Cella also managed his family restaurant ''Christ Cella'', which was founded in 1926 by his father Christopher Cella. General Cella is survived and dearly missed by his beloved wife, Ivana, his dear sons, Christopher, Richard B. and Renzo. Also his loving granddaughters Lillian and Elizabeth. Mass of the Resurrection, St. Vincent Ferrer, on Tuesday, at 11 A.M. Interment is at Ferncliff Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Information Louis DeLuca Mayflower Funeral Home, 718-256-1212.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, BENJAMIN
description: YOUNG-Benjamin. On April 6, 1998. Lawyer and community leader of Riverdale, NY, died at age 94. The oldest practicing attorney of New York Law School (Class of '24), he served his profession and community until age 92, was Counsel for the National and New York Associations for Meat and Poultry Purveyors and for the Marketmen's Association of the Port of New York. He served his fellow men as a Government Appeal Agent for the Selective Service Board during WWII, President of the Bronx High School of Science Parents' Association, assisted by his devoted wife of 48 years, Bess, and as Trustee and Vice President of Riverdale Temple. His pride in his children, Ellen Rosenberg of Riverdale, NY and Laurence of Newton Centre, MA., his grandchildren Eliot, Leslie, and Robert Young, and Lauren and Elizabeth Rosenberg and great grandchildren Bess, Ella, Joshua and Evan, was matched by their admiration and love for him. He is survived by his wife Bernice, son-in-law Jerry Rosenberg, daughter-in-law Jody Young and sisters Celia and Molly. The company withdrew a proposal to bill customers, or their new phone companies, 49 marks ($26.64) if they switch to a rival like Mannesmann Arcor or Otelo. title: German Jobless Rate Is Unchanged at 11.5%
description: Germany's unemployment rate was unchanged at 11.5 percent in March, as jobless demonstrators jeered the news at Government offices to protest Chancellor Helmut Kohl's bid for a fifth term in office. The number of unemployed fell by 2,000 in March, the third straight monthly drop, the Federal Labor Office said yesterday. The decline, which is adjusted for seasonal influences and is the first three-month drop since 1995, was unexpected. A poll of economists had forecast a rise of 10,000.

title: Watching a Saudi Succession

Power has been shifting to his half-brother, Crown Prince Abdullah, since the King suffered a debilitating stroke in 1995. The Crown Prince is not as quick to embrace some American policy positions as King Fahd, and is more sympathetic to Arab and Islamic causes. But the coming transition need not upset relations between Washington and Riyadh.

Saturday, three hours before he and his team serve dinner to 350 people, and with just two torches, caramelizing the tops of 350 cremes brulees to brittle, umber perfection is agonizingly slow.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SACKETT, ELIZABETH GRAY
description: SACKETT-Elizabeth Gray. Died at Lenox Hill Hospital, on Sunday, April 5, 1998. She was 94. Mrs. Sackett was the daughter of the late Paul Robert Gray of Grosse Point Farms, MI., and granddaughter of John Simpson Gray, the first president of Ford Motor Company. She is survived by her sons, George Olney Sackett of Germantown, PA., and Nelson B. Sackett Jr, and Paul R.J. Sackett both of New York City, three grandchildren of her daughter, the late Frances Sackett Borst and 3 great grandchildren. Mrs. Sackett married the late Dr. Nelson B. Sackett, Founding Fellow of the National College of Obstetricians in 1926. Mrs. Sackett was active for many years in the Women's National Farm and Garden Club which she served as president from 1966-1968 and which she supported by establishing two agricultural scholarships. Donations in her memory may be sent to the Women's National Farm and Garden Scholarship Fund, C/O Judith Bronk, 31 Willow St., Hudson Falls, New York 12839. She also was a sustaining member of the National Society of Colonial Dames, the Mayflower Society, the Junior League of the City of New York, the Friends of Reade Sanctuary and the Bar Harbor Music Festival. A funeral service will be held at Park Avenue Christian Church, 1010 Park Ave., Thursday, 11 AM, followed by burial in the Hillside Cemetery in Wilton, CT.

title: Tammy Wynette, Country Singer Known For 'Stand by Your Man,' Is Dead at 55
description: Tammy Wynette, whose 1968 hit ''Stand By Your Man'' established her as a queen of country music, died on Monday in her sleep at her home in Nashville. She was 55.

title: The Pop Life; Celine Dion Says No on All Points
description: Celine Dion's lawyer would like to make it clear that his client has never been enamored of Michael Jackson. She has never dressed up as Michael Jackson for Halloween. She has never danced at a screening of a Michael Jackson video. She never thought that this video was great. She never had a crush on Michael Jackson. She never met Naomi Campbell with Michael Jackson. And she and Mr. Jackson do not both come from large families.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NYRO, LAURA
description: NYRO-Laura. America's greatest songwriter. Your fans everywhere will love you and remember you forever.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about three students' efforts to get into Stuyvesant High School misidentified the Brooklyn neighborhood for Bishop Ford High School, which one girl considered as an alternative. It is in Windsor Terrace, not Bay Ridge.

title: A Sweet Sound Curdling Into A Cliche
description: I used to love the sound of the penny whistle. It's a well-nigh perfect instrument: portable, cheap and low-tech, with no moving parts. It's easy to play yet capable of great subtlety; a skillful player can make notes bend and quiver and sigh. And it immediately invokes a long and precious tradition. The penny whistle and tin whistle, with or without a mouthpiece, provide one of the primal sounds of Celtic music, plaintive in slow airs and dizzyingly nimble in dance tunes. When a musician pulls a whistle out of a pocket and joins in a melody, it's a surviving link to centuries of homemade music.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL WEAKENS. Crude oil fell for a second day on growing market sentiment that production cutbacks by OPEC producers and others will not ease a surplus. May contracts fell 23 cents, or 2 percent, to $15.22 a barrel.

title: Liberties; 1,000 Points of Lust
description: James Carville sounds sick of James Carville.

title: To Go; Croquettes, a Meal in Themselves
description: NEVER eat at a place called Mom's, Nelson Algren famously advised, but MA'S FOOD in Little Italy slides by on a technicality. For one thing, you can't actually eat there. This tiny place, the takeout branch of Dine by Design, a personal chef service, is barely big enough to hold its delectable display. But there's nothing constrained about the food: you get huge portions and generous flavors.

title: The U.S. Should Come Clean On 'Dirty Wars'
description: Seventeen years after the crime, four Salvadoran national guardsmen convicted of murdering three American nuns and a church lay worker in 1980 have publicly confessed for the first time that they had acted on ''orders from above.'' The United Nations Truth Commission for El Salvador had reached the same finding in 1993, concluding that high Salvadoran officers, including the Defense Minister and the commander of the National Guard at the time, were involved in covering up the crime.

title: Not Like Egypt: Passover in Alaska
description: THEY call themselves the ''Frozen Chosen.'' The 5,000 or so Jews who live in Alaska will have a different experience celebrating Passover than their kin in the lower 48.

title: Rangers Waste Gretzky's Gifts Again
description: Before last night's Ranger game against Montreal at Madison Square Garden, Wayne Gretzky added another award for the warehouse where he keeps such stuff. In a local news media poll, he was elected most valuable player of the overvalued 1997-98 Rangers. During the game, Gretzky showed why he was worthy of the honor. He scored a goal and added an assist in a 3-2 loss to the Canadiens. The points gave Gretzky 86 for the season, second best in the National Hockey League scoring race.

title: Paris Journal; If You Hear Mozart Arias, This Is a Metro Station
description: There was a time when the sound of an accordion playing in the cars of the Metro brought commuters respite from ''le stress.'' But that was before France's economic troubles spilled underground and the battle for loose change was joined by homeless newspaper vendors, unemployed men making speeches and immigrant mothers carrying babies. By the mid-1990's Parisians were thoroughly fed up.

title: CNA FINANCIAL TO ACQUIRE MARITIME INSURANCE OF BRITAIN
description: The CNA Financial Corporation agreed yesterday to acquire the Maritime Insurance Company, a British-based marine insurer, from Norwich Union P.L.C. for $:56 million, or $93 million. Norwich Union, based in Norwich, England, is the third-largest publicly traded insurance company in Britain. The Chicago-based CNA, a unit of the Loews Corporation, is an insurance company with annual revenue of $17 billion. In Britain, Maritime will operate as an independent unit of CNA U.K. Holdings. In Canada, CNA will integrate Maritime with its MOAC unit, a global ocean marine operation.

title: Now, a Stamp to Be Sent 'Round the World
description: They are going to make a stamp commemorating a home run -- not any home run, to be sure, but the one called ''The Shot Heard 'Round the World.''

title: Restaurants; Beyond Paella and Pitchers of Sangria
description: FROM the street, Solera looks so cozy it is almost impossible not to be drawn into the long room, with its terra-cotta tiles and romantic lighting. Once inside, it is equally impossible to resist the display of tapas by the bar: the white beans tossed with chorizo, the garlic shrimp in sherry vinegar, the fabulous marinated anchovies. You want to perch on a stool, order a glass of sherry (the restaurant offers a baker's dozen) and spend the evening.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHALEN, JAMES
description: WHALEN-James. The Officers, Executive Board and Members of The Association of Contracting Plumbers of The City of New York, Inc. mourns the passing of our member James Whalen of Kay Mechanical, Inc. Mr. Whalen served as President and Executive Board Member for many years and made a valuable contribution to the plumbing industry. Our deepest sympathy to his wife Kay, his brother Ed and all his bereaved family. Association of Contracting Plumbers of The City of New York Lawrence J. Levine, Pres. John O'Donnell, Exec. Vice Pres.

title: Bigger Paycheck Is Seen for Citicorp Chief
description: The chairman of Citicorp, John S. Reed, made $14.4 million last year, including stock options. If the company's merger with Travelers Group goes through, Mr. Reed can look forward to earning even more.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: STAPLES IN $685 MILLION DEAL FOR OFFICE-SUPPLY CONCERN
description: Staples Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire the Quill Corporation, a privately held office-supplies concern, for about $685 million in stock. The move will bolster the Staples position in the large, highly fragmented market for delivered office products. Quill, based in Lincolnshire, Ill., sells office supplies through mail-order catalogues, the Internet and telemarketing. It had full-year sales of $550 million last year and more than 1,200 employees. Staples, based in Westborough, Mass., a $50 billion retailer of office supplies, furniture and technology, has a delivered office products business, called Staples Contract and Commercial, which recorded full-year sales of $1 billion last year.

title: Meat on the Bone, a Primitive Delight
description: IN this age of shrink-wrapped this and preboned that, there is something especially satisfying about gnawing at meat on the bone.

title: Terrell, a Safety, Signed by Packers
description: The Green Bay Packers signed have signed safety Pat Terrell, who spent the past three seasons with the Carolina Panthers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIGHTFOOT, PAUL R., M.D.
description: LIGHTFOOT-Paul R., M.D., of Claremont, California. April 7, 1939 to April 4, 1998. Regis High School (1956), Fordham College (1960), Yale University Medical School (1964). Distinguished career at Kaiser Hospital in Fontana, California. Survived by wife Patricia, daughter Deborah, son Paul, brother Michael, sister Cathy, niece Deirdre and nephews John and Michael. In lieu of flowers, contributions for a disabled student scholarship fund may be sent to: Paul R. Lightfoot M.D., Memorial Endowed Scholarship Fund, c/o Gloria Backer, Fordham University, 33 West 60th Street, Room 924, New York, NY 10023.

title: FIGURE SKATING ; Lipinski Turns Pro To Unite Her Family
description: A month and a half ago, at age 15, Tara Lipinski became the youngest athlete to win a gold medal at the Winter Olympics. Yesterday, she announced that she was turning professional, a decision based more on life style than on money.

title: A Folk Singer, Willfully Undomesticated
description: Shortly after midnight on Saturday at the Bottom Line, Dan Bern went electric. ''You can boo if you want to,'' he said as he strapped on a pink solid-body guitar. Mr. Bern, the ascendant folk singer, was acknowledging his debt to Bob Dylan, whose similar switch from acoustic music in 1965 famously rankled folk fans. Mr. Bern can do a mean Dylan imitation. But the rebelliousness he shares with that burdensome shadow makes him an original today.

title: A Monster Merger
description: Congress dithers, so John Reed of Citicorp and Sanford Weill of Travelers Group grandly propose to modernize financial markets on their own. They have announced a $70 billion merger -- the biggest in history -- that would create the largest financial services company in the world, worth more than $140 billion. If the merger is approved by regulators, Citigroup, as the company will be called, will serve about 100 million customers in 100 countries. In one stroke, Mr. Reed and Mr. Weill will have temporarily demolished the increasingly unnecessary walls built during the Depression to separate commercial banks from investment banks and insurance companies.

title: Offshore Oil Rig Is Sold
description: Pride International Inc. said today that it had agreed to buy the M.S.V. Amethyst semisubmersible drilling rig for $85 million. Pride, based in Houston, provides drilling services to oil and gas companies. Pride will pay $63.8 million in cash and a convertible note valued at $21.2 million for the rig. The self-propelled rig can operate in water depths of up to 4,000 feet. It is currently working off the shore of Brazil for the oil conglomerate Petroleo Brasileiro S.A. under a contract that expires in 2001.

title: And Now for a Presumptuous Little Drink
description: SOFT drinks used to have modest goals. Basically, they slaked thirst while delivering a mild sugar-caffeine rush, plus a few intangibles dreamed up by the advertising agencies, like instant membership in the Pepsi Generation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOGAN, HOWARD T.
description: HOGAN-Howard T. Justice Hogan was a great judge but a greater friend to all lawyers. His opinions were widely quoted. He educated the American Bar in the principles of Condemnation Law. He was considerate to those who practiced before him, often staying late at night to hold court to accomodate lawyers, clients & witnessess so they would not have to return the next day to complete their cases. Eve & I mourn his loss. Eves Searles and Sidney Searles

title: Richard Ellner, 69, Dance Center Operator
description: Richard Ellner, a specialty T-shirt manufacturer who was behind the Broadway Dance Center, a busy commercial studio offering ballet, jazz, tap and other dance classes, died on March 31 at his home in Manhattan. He was 69.

title: 9,000 Job Cuts To Save Xerox $1 Billion
description: The Xerox Corporation, citing the need to compete against more efficient rivals, announced yesterday that it would eliminate about 9,000 jobs, or nearly 10 percent of its worldwide work force, over the next two to three years.

title: Harvard Endowment to Buy White River
description: The White River Corporation said today that it had agreed to be acquired for $442 million by the Harvard Private Group Inc.

title: Yeltsin Tries to Garner Legislators' Votes for His Premier Nominee
description: In a meeting that was as much political theater as substance, President Boris N. Yeltsin summoned his opponents to the Kremlin today in an attempt to show that he has a steady grip on the reins of power and to drum up support for his new Prime Minister.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KEOGH, JOSEPHINE R.
description: KEOGH-Josephine R. On April 6, 1998. Beloved daughter of the late Michael McKeogh and the late Margaret (nee Mannix). Dear sister of the late Margaret Martin. Niece of Michaelene Barrett. Also survived by grandnieces, grandnephews and cousins. Reposing at Riverdale Funeral Home, 5044 Broadway at 214 Street, NYC, on Tuesday 6:00-9:00 PM. Mass of Christian Burial at Good Shepherd RC Church on Wednesday 10:00 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Conseco and Green Tree, an Improbable Merger
description: On Wall Street, where disputes about arcane accounting practices can lead to blows and lawsuits, almost no company is argued over more than Conseco Inc. -- except maybe Green Tree Financial. Yesterday, they announced they were merging to become one very controversial company.

title: Debate About Tribal Rights Turns Rancorous
description: Amidst a din of drumbeats on one side and hoots from a flag-waving crowd on the other, the Senate Indian Affairs Committee today held its only hearing in the West on a bill that would sharply alter the power of the nation's 554 American Indian tribes.

title: Starr's Aides Compiling Evidence for Report
description: Anticipating a formal decision about whether they will send an impeachment report to Congress, prosecutors in the Whitewater independent counsel's office have begun compiling the most damaging evidence against President Clinton that has surfaced in the Monica S. Lewinsky investigation, lawyers familiar with the inquiry said today.

title: The Minimalist; Giving Water-Based Soup a Boost
description: ALMOST no one would deny that while a good water-based soup can be a fine thing, time-consuming stock bases are far richer and generally preferable. That gets to the question of whether you have the inclination to make the stock from scratch or the foresight to have saved some of a previous batch in the freezer. Or maybe you've reached that point of resignation where the canned stuff will just have to do.

title: Cassell Has a Key Role, But Longs for Security
description: On the court there is little doubt that the New Jersey Nets are Sam Cassell's team. But when the game is over, Cassell wonders how long it will stay that way.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, RENEE
description: GROSS-Renee. On April 7, 1998. Beloved wife. Loving mother of Allan and Howard Wagenheim. Dear sister of Jeanette Miller. Cherished grandmother and great grandmother.

title: Two Settle Insider Charges
description: Two women agreed today to pay a total of $58,123 to settle charges they made illegal profits by trading the stock of the MidSouth Corporation based on inside knowledge of the railroad company's pending acquisition by Kansas City Southern Industries. The women, Julia P. Mobley and Rosamond S. Brown, were friends of a lobbyist for Kansas City Southern, who tipped Ms. Mobley about merger negotiations, the Securities and Exchange Commission charged. Ms. Mobley then tipped Ms. Brown before the merger was announced, the S.E.C. said.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: USG CORP., Chicago, a building products company, said it planned to build a $112 million wallboard plant in Aliquippa, Pa.

title: New U.S. Diplomat Tries to Speak Japan's Language
description: As everyone from President Clinton down hammers Japan these days to stimulate its economy, Thomas S. Foley is being a little bit more polite.

title: Commercial Real Estate; From Its Cookies Glory To Warehouse to Offices
description: For more than half a century, until the mid-1950's, 15th Street just east of 10th Avenue was filled with the freshly baked aromas of vanilla wafers and Marshmallow Fancies, animal crackers and Fig Newtons.

title: Milwaukee and N.L. Back Together After 33 Years
description: Henry Aaron, the most productive home-run hitter in the history of major league baseball, circled the basepaths 755 times.

title: 15 Years, 1,000 Performances
description: Since it opened in 1983, the Sylvia and Danny Kaye Playhouse has been happily counting its days and nights. On Monday night, it added up the total with a flourish and presented its 1,000th Performance Gala.

title: Muslims Celebrate Holiday at Coney Island
description: In her native Egypt, Zeinab Olley celebrated the Muslim feast of sacrifice, Id al-Adha, with prayers at her mosque and the ritual slaughter of a sheep. Relatives showered money on Ms. Olley's daughter, Eva, and everyone spent the afternoon at the zoo or even the Pyramids.

title: Duel in Albany Over Banning Some Abortions
description: In a policy reversal, Sheldon Silver, the Speaker of the State Assembly, will introduce a bill Wednesday that would ban a form of late-term abortion, his aides said today.

title: Jury Still Out, And at Odds, In L.I. Beating
description: For the second time in seven days of deliberations, jurors told the judge today that they could not reach a verdict on whether Austin Offen, a 27-year-old white man from Queens, severely beat a young black man during a brawl outside a Westhampton Beach nightclub two years ago.

title: Harlem's Kings Of Tap Take a Bow
description: The Nicholas Brothers epitomized flashy acrobatic brilliance during their long career as a star nightclub, film and Broadway dance duo. They sailed through 10-foot jumps, danced up walls and flipped off into full ballet splits. In the 1941 film ''The Great American Broadcast,'' they jumped through the window of a moving train and landed in time to wave goodbye.

title: GENCORP TO BUY A COMMERCIAL WALL COVERING BUSINESS
description: Gencorp said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the commercial wall covering business of Walker Greenbank P.L.C. of Britain. Terms were not disclosed. Walker Greenbank makes wallpaper and fabrics. Its commercial wall covering business has sales of about $70 million. Gencorp, based in Fairlawn, Ohio, makes plastics and other products for the aerospace, military and automotive industries. In the year ended Nov. 30, it had sales of $1.6 billion. Gencorp plans to integrate the business into its Decorative and Building Products unit, as part of a plan to expand that unit internationally.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NOVICK, WILLIAM
description: NOVICK-William. Devoted husband of the late Bernice. Loving father. Cherished and adoring grandfather. Dear brother. Bill will be missed by all who knew him as he was always ready to greet people with a big smile and a wry sense of humor. He was a kind and loving man. Services today 12:30 at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, Long Island.

title: Consumer Debt Level Surged in February
description: Borrowing by American consumers increased by more than double the expected amount in February on a surge in credit card debt, data released today by the Federal Reserve showed.

title: TV Notes; Children Approve
description: Nickelodeon's 11th annual ''Kids Choice Awards'' on Saturday night tied with pro wrestling as the most-watched show on cable last week, drawing 7.6 million viewers and a 3.4 national Nielsen rating, its highest ever. (Each rating point represents 980,000 homes.)

title: Oil Embargo Could Help End Nigerian's Rule; Human Rights in Congo
description: To the Editor:

title: Business Travel; The airlines may face some new regulations on how to calculate a flight's on-time performance.
description: THE airlines' battle for on-time bragging rights, giving the carriers the right to boast in ads that they are No. 1 in flights arriving on schedule, may undergo some wrenching moments if the Department of Transportation follows the recommendation of its Office of Inspector General.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUKMAN, WENDY
description: SUKMAN-Wendy. Of Hermosa Beach, CA. Beloved spouse of Jacquelin Welter. Daughter of Richard and Carole Sukman. Died April 5, 1998 after a long courageous battle with breast cancer. Former V.P. of Paine-Webber & Smith Barney. Services April 8 at Hillside Memorial Park, 1-800-576-1994.

title: TV Notes; Enough Already?
description: Is the public getting fed up with the coverage of the allegations of sexual misconduct against President Clinton?

title: Davis Goes on Disabled List
description: Chili Davis, bothered by soreness in the lower half of his right leg for six days, was placed on the 15-day disabled list.

title: Excerpts From the Discussion About Social Security
description: Following are excerpts from a discussion today on the future of Social Security among President Clinton, members of a panel and an audience.

title: Confined by an Ankle Bracelet, in a Tight Race for Congress
description: Hobbled by a campaign finance conviction, an ankle bracelet and a judge's order, Representative Jay C. Kim worked from afar today to fend off three primary challengers in California.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEFF, JAMES J.
description: LEFF-James J. The Board of Justices of the New York State Supreme Court, First District, notes with sadness the passing of our former colleague, James J. Leff, who retired last year after 27 years on the bench. Our deepest sympathies are extended to his wife and family. Beatrice Shainswit, Pres.

title: Sports of The Times; Fan Shows New Twist On Defense
description: REMEMBER the other day when I recalled Casey Stengel's theory that every day in baseball you see something you never saw before?

title: The Quiet Star Of New Orleans
description: IN a town famous for its flamboyance, Susan Spicer is the city's stealth chef. Unlike Emeril Legasse or Justin Wilson, she speaks softly, has no desire to build a restaurant empire and serves neither Cajun nor Creole food.

title: For the Last 'Seinfeld,' Family Only
description: The entertainment industry thrives on a thinly disguised hierarchy of exclusivity. Even well-known producers and directors fight ferociously -- through their agents or assistants, of course -- for tickets to major events. Still, ''Seinfeld,'' NBC's enormously successful sitcom and cultural icon, has trumped the crowd. The taping of the final segment of the final episode of the show, which is shutting down after nine years, is shrouded in dense secrecy and is proving all but impossible to get into.

title: Gore Orders Changes In E.P.A. Procedures
description: Vice President Al Gore, trying to mollify an anxious agriculture industry, is ordering the Environmental Protection Agency to revamp the process it uses to decide whether pesticides are dangerous to children.

title: Seinfeld as master of his own advertising domain? A boutique agency is a possibility, he says.
description: JERRY SEINFELD knows the Upper West Side of Manhattan. And he knows Yankee Stadium. But does he know Madison Avenue?

title: Friendly Advice For Ewing
description: Dikembe Mutombo had dinner Monday night with Patrick Ewing, a friend from Georgetown, and advised him to skip the heroics.

title: Student With a Flashy (and Risky) Business
description: The rapper Ice Cube makes his directorial debut with ''The Players Club,'' a hearty throwback to the formula behind 70's blaxploitation films: sex, violence, cash, trash and flash. Set in what is euphemistically called ''a gentleman's club,'' it constructs a 100 percent predictable soap opera around clean-cut Diana Armstrong (LisaRaye), who is a college student and single mom. ''All this dancin', and finals was just around the corner!'' she complains, articulating the film's central dilemma: Diana is wholesome and nice, but she has to strut her stuff at the club for fiscal reasons. She uses Diamond as her nom de strip.

title: Accounts
description: * Conxus Communications Inc., Greenville, S.C., to FGI Inc., Chapel Hill, N.C., as the first agency to handle strategic marketing and advertising. FGI's initial assignment is to introduce Pocketalk, a pocket-size mobile voice pager. Billings of as much as $15 million are anticipated.

title: Executive Changes
description: BARCLAYS CAPITAL, the investment banking unit of Barclays P.L.C., London, named Thomas L. Kalaris chief executive of its Americas operations.

title: Metro Business; Mercedes Rethinks Move to New York
description: Mercedes-Benz of North America, which said last October that it was moving its headquarters from New Jersey to New York, now says it is having second thoughts and may stay in New Jersey instead.

description: Brasserie With a Twist

title: The Chinese Burst Onto the Tourist Scene
description: At a wildlife park called the Nong Nooch Tropical Garden, a gaggle of camera-toting tourists from China jostled for position at a souvenir stand to buy gaudy knickknacks, while others took turns riding elephants adorned with red-and-green silk saddles.
