description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AREY, MARGARET ENGLE
description: AREY-Margaret Engle. Born June 7, 1896, deceased April 5, 1998. Survived by devoted sister Vera Bever of Kearny, N.J., and beloved Aunt of Mary Mintz of Roseland, NJ, Judith Sullivan of Basking Ridge, N.J., and Sally Zwiebach of Glen Cove, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEICHTLING, ROSLYN
description: LEICHTLING-Roslyn. Members of the Board of Directors of Friends of Israel Disabled War Veterans (Beit Halochem) note with sorrow the passing of Roslyn Leichtling, the beloved mother of our esteemed Board Member and Assistant Secretary, Michael Leichtling. Susan Aberbach, National Chairperson Joel C. Breslauer, Executive V.P.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times yesterday about the geology of Yellowstone National Park misstated the location of Duke University, the employer of Dr. Stuart Rojstaczer, a hydrologist who studied Old Faithful. Duke is in Durham, N.C., not Chapel Hill.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Blair Flies to Belfast After Serious Snag in Peace Talks
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain flew into Northern Ireland today in an urgent effort to remove a serious snag in the peace negotiations between Protestant and Roman Catholic political leaders in this mostly Protestant British province.

title: The Skies Are Getting Friendlier for the Rest; F.A.A. Needs Overhaul
description: To the Editor:

title: The Chef
description: STUFFED cabbage is a dish you encounter all over the world, in different forms. It doesn't have any one ethnic origin or base; every country or region adds its own spices and somehow makes the dish its own. In the Middle East, you find cabbage stuffed with rice and lamb, and seasoned with cumin and coriander. In Hungary, it's spiced with paprika and dill. It's a humble dish, but satisfying.

title: By the Book; Flavorful Fare, No Patter
description: IN ''The Cafe Cook Book'' (Broadway Books, $35), Rose Gray and Ruth Rogers offer none of the usual patter of today's countless chefs-turned-authors.

title: CITIZENS FINANCIAL IS ACQUIRING WOBURN NATIONAL
description: The Citizens Financial Group agreed to acquire the Woburn National Corporation, the parent of Woburn National Bank, for $45 million in cash, further building up its branch network in the Boston area. The Royal Bank of Scotland P.L.C., which has a 76.5 percent stake in Citizens, said in a statement that the acquisition meant the unit now had $5.5 billion in assets within Massachusetts and would increase the number of branches near Boston by 5, to 105. The Bank of Ireland P.L.C. owns the other 23.5 percent of Citizens. The acquisition is the 12th for Citizens, based in Providence, R.I., since 1992.

title: Underground History Surfaces Again in Berlin
description: For 10 years or so, Dietmar Arnold has been seriously, heavily into the underground. Not the political or musical underground, but the physical underground -- the tunnels, caverns, bunkers, sewers and cavities that, he says, provide a subterranean history of Berlin that may soon be lost under the city's gargantuan rebuilding.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KING, ROY M.
description: KING-Roy M. On Sunday, April 5, 1998. Roy King, beloved husband of Miriam King, (nee Schiller), devoted father of Justin King and the late Melody Ann King. Devoted father-in-law of Cynthia King. Loving brother of Arthur Feigenbaum of New York. Adoring grandfather of Bradley and Aaron King. Please omit flowers. Contributions in his memory may be directed to the Melody Ann King Memorial Fund, College of Education, University of Denver, PO Bx 100864, Denver, CO 80250. For further information, please contact Sol Levinson & Bros., Inc. 1-800-338-1701.

title: Baby Is Hospitalized After Swallowing Cocaine
description: A 7-month-old girl was in serious condition last night after ingesting cocaine that her mother said was lying in the hallway of their Jackson Heights, Queens, apartment building, the police said.

title: Cooler Heads Evaluating Citigroup Deal
description: When Travelers Group Inc. and Citicorp announced on Monday that they planned to merge, investors' eyes grew almost as big as the deal itself. The prospect of a financial services powerhouse with nearly $700 billion in assets, making it the world's largest, caused investors to snatch up shares in both stocks, sending them to their 52-week highs and instantly creating $30 billion in new market value.

title: Corrections
description: A headline yesterday about ''Junk Mail,'' which is being shown at the New Directors/New Films festival, misstated the film's setting. It is Norway, not Finland.

title: Alarm on Admissions
description: To the Editor:

title: Twisted Lives in a Provincial Irish Setting
description: His body a study in conflicting angles, as if contorted by unseen winds, Cripple Billy moves athwart through a world where most people are either ramrod vertical or flat on their backs. The other villagers on the island off western Ireland where Billy lives are fond of pointing out how his twisted form sets him apart from them, and his name is seldom pronounced without the distancing epithet of ''Cripple.''

title: Eating Glue and Biting a Snake
description: Werner Herzog tells a real-life tall tale in ''Little Dieter Needs To Fly,'' a documentary that describes enough breakneck adventures for any action hero. But the swashbuckler who is the film's subject, Dieter Dengler, mostly describes his exploits from memory. Now a garrulous extrovert living a comfortable life near San Francisco, he talks of extraordinary early hardship and of the drive that sustained him. With a German childhood seared by images of World War II, and with an American military career that saw him shot down over Laos in 1966, he has many a hair-raising story to tell.

title: Company Gets Record Antitrust Fine for Price Fixing in Electrodes
description: The Justice Department announced the largest antitrust fine in United States history yesterday as Ucar International, a Connecticut company that makes components for steel mills, agreed to pay $110 million for participating in an international price-fixing cartel.

title: MOTOROLA SHARES FALL ON FIRST-QUARTER PROFIT PLUNGE
description: The shares of Motorola Inc. fell yesterday after the company's first-quarter profit plunged and it warned that the Asian crisis would cause prices for its phones and semiconductors to sink further. Shares of Motorola fell $6.375, to $53.50, in trading of almost 11.7 million shares. Motorola's chip sales rose just 1 percent in the quarter, leading it to slash its forecast for this year's semiconductor industry growth by half, to 6 percent to 8 percent. Sales of new digital phones in Japan fell and orders for pagers dropped, particularly in China. The company reported a 50 percent drop in first-quarter earnings on Monday.

title: After Compromises, Indonesians Reach 3d Pact With I.M.F.
description: Indonesia and the International Monetary Fund reached basic agreement on Tuesday on the third plan in six months for rescuing the country's economy. The plan is yet another effort to get Indonesia to comply with conditions allowing it to receive $43 billion in aid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAUFMAN, MARILYN
description: KAUFMAN - Marilyn. Devoted wife of Wallace. Loving mother of Alan, Howard and Jane. Loving daughter of Rose Swartz. Sister of Lila and Edward. An adored grandmother. Funeral services Wednesday, 10:30AM, I.J. Morris, 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead.

title: Smithsonian Shuts Down Book and Record Units
description: The Smithsonian Institution in Washington has shut down three divisions producing books, records and videos, most notably the Smithsonian Collection of Recordings, which has issued widely praised albums of jazz and popular music.

title: Advanced Micro Devices' Deficit Larger Than Analysts Expected
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. reported a substantially larger loss than Wall Street analysts had expected today, citing continuing production problems in its core microprocessor chip business, and poor demand in some markets, particularly Korea and Japan. Advanced Micro reported its results after the market had closed. Advanced Micro closed at $30.50, up 6.25 cents on the New York Stock Exchange. Its shortfall came on the heels of an earnings warning from Motorola.

title: A Priest Finds Hints of the Divine in Politics
description: THE Rev. Joseph A. O'Hare, a Jesuit 50 years this summer, is well trained in his order's mission to find God in all things, to pluck the moment of the spirit from a working day. But even he was surprised to encounter traces of the divine at the New York City Campaign Finance Board.

title: PRESIDENT PRESSES DEBATE ON CHANGE IN SOCIAL SECURITY
description: With charts at his side and an array of solutions being debated before him, President Clinton began trying to build consensus today on addressing Social Security's looming financial problems, and he said he thought the job could be accomplished without raising the payroll taxes that finance the retirement system.

title: CVS AND MCKESSON IN $700 MILLION EXPANSION AGREEMENT
description: The McKesson Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a $700 million agreement with the CVS Corporation as it expands its business with the drugstore chain to more regions and to CVS's mail-order prescription business. McKesson, a drug wholesaler, said it expected the three-year agreement to generate sales of more than $225 million annually. It will supply drugs and other health care products to about 1,100 CVS stores in the Midwest and Southeast, as well as the mail-order unit. McKesson, the largest drug wholesaler in the United States, had sales of about $12.9 billion in the year that ended last March. Shares of McKesson rose $1.062, to $63, while CVS fell $1.4375, to $77.9375.

title: 'Nanny Tax' Law Should Be Revised; Unfair Worker Burden
description: To the Editor:

title: Unit of McDermott Quits French Venture
description: J. Ray McDermott S.A. said today that it had received $105 million for dissolving its joint venture with ETPM S.A. of France.

title: Roland Schwartz, 85, Coach Of Prominent Amateur Boxers
description: Roland (Rolly) Schwartz, a major figure in American amateur boxing for almost 60 years and a coach of the 1976 United States Olympic team, died yesterday in the Hospice of Dayton in Ohio. He was 85.

title: British Leader Tries To Save Ulster Talks
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain flew into Northern Ireland in an urgent effort to remove a serious snag in the peace negotiations between Protestant and Roman Catholic political leaders.

title: The Skies Are Getting Friendlier for the Rest
description: To the Editor:

title: Cellular License Is Sold by Brazil
description: A group led by the DDI Corporation of Japan and Suzano de Papel e Celulose S.A. of Brazil bought a license today to offer mobile phone service in Brazil's southern states for at least 913 million reais ($802 million).

title: Beneficial and Household To Merge in $9 Billion Deal
description: The Beneficial Corporation and Household International, which have competed with each other to provide loans to low- and middle-income American consumers for most of this century, said yesterday that they would merge to create a lender with more than 30 million customers.

title: British Petroleum To Buy Back Stock
description: The British Petroleum Company, the oil giant, said yesterday that it would buy back up to $2 billion of its stock next year. The buyback will increase earnings per share by reducing shares outstanding. British Petroleum has about 1.89 billion shares outstanding. The United States-listed shares of B.P. rose $0.6875, to $88.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Concerns Over First-Quarter Profits Send Markets Lower
description: One day after the Dow Jones industrial average posted its first closing above 9,000, it reversed course yesterday, losing 76.73 points to close at 8,956.50. Analysts attributed the decline to rising concerns about first-quarter profits, which sent other major market indexes down sharply as well.

title: In Crown Heights Mayoral Fight, an Invitation Is Rebuffed
description: Declaring that he wanted to end an ongoing war of words with his successor, former Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday asked Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to come over for dinner and ''see if there are bridges to be built.'' But Mr. Giuliani politely, though firmly, said no thanks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MINNEMA, JOHN
description: MINNEMA-John. The Board of Trustees of The Jaqua Foundation express our deepest sympathy to the family of our dear friend and devoted colleague, John T. Minnema. Our thoughts and prayers are with his wife, Gertrude and his children, Jill Worth and Joan Minnema. John's insight and wisdom will be truly missed. Eli Hoffman W. Fletcher Hock, Jr. Samuel Pollock

title: CONSOLIDATED CAPITAL IS SEEN IN DEALS FOR 4 COMPANIES
description: The Consolidation Capital Corporation, which has been acquiring companies in the janitorial-services and electrical-contracting services industries, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire one company and intended to buy three others for $21 million in cash and $71 million in stock. It will also assume debt of $34 million. The acquisitions are part of the company's plan to add $200 million in annualized revenues each month in 1998. Consolidation Capital will purchase United Service Solutions, a Denver-based provider of janitorial services; the Perimeter Maintenance Corporation, based in Atlanta, and its affiliates, and two undisclosed electrical contracting service companies with annual sales of $87 million.

You will be forever in the memories of your family and friends.

description: To the Editor:

Son of Frank and Frieda Boes Smith, dedicated and loving husband to Abby, devoted father to Frank M. Smith III, Braddock M. Smith, Thaddeus M. Smith, Nathaniel M. Smith, and Caleb M. Smith. Contributor to the golden days of Broadcasting, the world of sports, and his community. Memorial service at the Greenville Community Church, Scarsdale, New York, on April 8, 1998 at 11 A.M. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to the Frank Smith Memorial Fund at Deerfield Academy, Deerfield, MA. 01342.

title: Wine Talk; Burgundy Meets Its Match: American Pinot Noir
description: AFTER a half century of stumbling efforts and too many premature pronouncements of success, it can finally be said with certainty that the pinot noir produced in the United States has arrived as a world-class wine. The best pinots of California and Oregon are now the worthy rivals of the great wines of the fabled Cote d'Or in the heart of Burgundy.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Beneficial and Household Merging in $9 Billion Deal

title: Girl Is Held After Yonkers Teacher Is Hit With Hammer
description: A 15-year-old student, apparently upset that a teacher had called her parents to express concern over her academic performance, attacked the teacher with a hammer in a Yonkers classroom yesterday, leaving the teacher with two skull fractures, school officials said.

title: The Trouble With 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell'
description: A new Defense Department draft report shows that the number of homosexuals being forced out of the military under the ''Don't ask, don't tell, don't pursue'' policy is 67 percent higher than when the policy was adopted in 1993. The report is silent on what might be causing this surprising rise. Yet the Pentagon seems resistant to examining the most disturbing and obvious possibility, which is that base and unit commanders are subverting a policy that was intended to stop witch hunts and to insure some measure of privacy for gay men and women in the ranks.

title: AIRLINER REWIRING IS URGED TO REDUCE RISK OF EXPLOSION
description: The National Transportation Safety Board recommended today that thousands of airliners built by Boeing and other companies be rewired to reduce the risk of a fuel tank explosion like the one that destroyed Trans World Airlines Flight 800 two years ago.

title: Uproar Over Jailing of Teheran Mayor Reveals Political Divisions in Iran
description: A growing outcry in Iran over the detention of Teheran's powerful Mayor in an investigation into corruption has exposed deep schisms between the moderates who triumphed in presidential elections a year ago and the conservatives who have dominated the country since the Islamic Revolution of 1979.

title: Principal Thought a Gun Was a Toy, Officials Say
description: The principal of a Queens elementary school delayed notifying the police about a third-grade boy found carrying and displaying a loaded handgun in school last week because he thought the small, 70-year-old weapon was a toy, school officials said yesterday.

title: About New York; Starting Over: Good Move, Bad Karma
description: AFTER years at building a successful jewelry business in Australia, Ray Griffiths knew it was time to move on. Although his work had appeared on dozens of magazine covers and in countless fashion spreads, he had tired of appearing at the same places on the Sydney party circuit. He could have chosen Paris or London as his new home, but those towns didn't have the allure of New York. He saved his money and planned to move to the city and get a fabulous job designing jewelry at some funky atelier before striking out on his own.

title: Sought: 300-Pound Head Of Brontosaurus Statue
description: Millions of years ago, the brontosaurus endured the ultimate affront when its species became extinct. But two weeks ago, a cement replica of the dinosaur suffered a fresh indignity when its severed head was stolen by thieves.

title: Corrections
description: A picture of Yishay Yefet, a Sephardic Jew in Israel, with a group of articles on Monday portraying the variety of ethnic and religious groups there, carried an erroneous credit. It was by Rina Castelnuovo.

title: The One-Stop Financial Mall: Is It What Peoria Longs For?
description: Though the planned combination of Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc. has drawn superlatives on Wall Street, it gets much of its inspiration from the more mundane confines of the shopping mall.

description: An elephant of a merger raced down Wall Street on Monday, chased by a pack of journalists. Like the proverbial blind men's examinations of the elephant, newspaper reports of the value of the deal between Citicorp and Travelers Group Inc. also differed.

title: Members of Motorcycle Gang Are Charged in Extortion Case
description: Federal prosecutors today charged that the Pagan Outlaw Motorcycle Club extorted thousands of dollars annually from topless dance clubs and other adult businesses throughout Long Island and planned to murder one club manager who refused to pay.

description: The losing would have been reason enough for the Yankees' team meeting today, but the players had more on their minds. Believing that the Seattle Mariners had treated them disrespectfully on Monday night, the Yankees did something about it.

title: CBS Names Heir Apparent for the Chairman's Position
description: CBS put a new top management team in place for its long-term future when it announced the promotion yesterday of Mel Karmazin and Leslie Moonves to two newly created positions under Michael Jordan, the chairman and chief executive.

title: TV Notes; Real or Not, No Fights Please
description: The powers behind ''The Jerry Springer Show'' have decided to cut back on its famous fisticuffs, risking the loss of the very viewers who have made the usually lurid talk show No. 1 in the latest daytime Nielsen ratings. The producers say they will admonish guests not to get physical and will ask the off-duty Chicago police officers who are security guards to intervene sooner when guests put up their dukes.

Daniel Boulud's smoked salmon, which is cured to the chef's specifications, is now being sold at Dean & DeLuca.

title: Jury Hears of a Conversation Between Volunteer and Willey
description: Harolyn Cardozo, a former White House volunteer who is the daughter of the Democratic fund-raiser Nathan Landow, appeared today before the Federal grand jury investigating President Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, a former White House intern.

title: Lowe Acquires Pace For New Health Unit
description: Lowe Group in New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Companies, said yesterday that it had acquired Pace, a health care communications agency in Parsippany, N.J. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Patchwork of School Financing Schemes Offers Few Answers and Much Conflict
description: If there is anywhere where the struggle over school-financing disparities ought to be over by now, it is in New Mexico.

title: Clinton Aides Step Up Attacks on Starr Inquiry
description: White House officials, feeling liberated in the aftermath of the dismissal of the Paula Corbin Jones lawsuit, are anticipating a report to Congress from Kenneth W. Starr by aggressively trying to undercut the reliability of his witnesses and questioning their ties to top Republican officials.

title: Frank Lloyd, Prominent Art Dealer Convicted in the 70's Rothko Scandal, Dies at 86
description: Frank Lloyd, the Vienna-born entrepreneur who built the Marlborough Gallery into the wealthiest, most important art gallery business in the world and then sullied his reputation with his criminal role in the Rothko art scandal of the 1970's, died Tuesday at his home in Nassau, the Bahamas. He was 86 and also had homes in Manhattan and Paris.

title: The Jets Banish Murrell To Arizona
description: Trader Bill continued to stockpile draft picks yesterday, trading the Jets' 1,000-yard rusher Adrian Murrell to the Arizona Cardinals.

title: Legislature Clears New Law On Day Before Its Dissolution; 'Just the Beginning,' Foes Say : Beijing Gains Wide Immunity In Hong Kong's Legal System
description: HONG KONG  China's handpicked provisional legislature adopted a bill Tuesday that exempts some mainland Chinese agencies from Hong Kong law.

title: ANDREA ELECTRONICS IS IN $47.8 MILLION DEAL FOR LAMAR
description: The Andrea Electronics Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the closely held Lamar Signal Processing Ltd. for about $47.8 million in stock and cash to improve its computer speech-recognition line. Andrea, based in Long Island City, Queens, will pay Lamar shareholders 1.8 million shares plus $3 million in cash. The stock cannot be sold for five years. The Israel-based Lamar makes advanced hearing aids, microphones and software to clean up background noise so computers can recognize human speech more accurately. Andrea will use Lamar's technology to improve the flexibility and performance of its existing noise-reducing headsets and other communications equipment and add new ones. Shares of Andrea fell $1.375, to $23.50.

title: Home Insurers Barred From Considering Sites
description: Responding to complaints from people who claimed that they were denied property insurance because they lived along the New Jersey Shore, state officials issued regulations yesterday that would stop insurance companies from, among other things, refusing to sell coverage because of the sites of homes.

title: Can Masterpiece Be Copied? Woods's Rivals Wait to See
description: From the moment Tiger Woods completed his domination of last year's Masters, shooting 18 under par and setting the tournament record at 270, people have wondered what is next.

title: Nicklaus Honored at Augusta
description: At a dedication ceremony that moved him to tears, Jack Nicklaus was honored with a plaque at Augusta National Golf Club today. The plaque, honoring the six-time Masters champion, will be affixed to a drinking fountain between holes No. 16 and No. 17.

title: Brown Cleared in a Sexual Harassment Suit
description: A Federal jury has cleared Brown University of wrongdoing in a sexual harassment case involving a student and a visiting chemistry professor who she said touched her thigh and rubbed her breasts in a private study session in his office.

title: City Council Hearing Ends in Chaos After Shouts and Curses
description: Outraged by the soaring decibels of a city councilman's voice, Jason A. Turner, the newly appointed Commissioner of the Human Resources Administration, stormed out of a City Council hearing yesterday, saying the councilman's thundering tone was not ''civilized.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Breast Cancer Breakthrough
description: Dr. Harold Varmus, director of the National Institutes of Health, was amply justified in calling the latest findings on the drug tamoxifen ''a big deal.'' For the first time, scientists have demonstrated that breast cancer can not only be treated but actually prevented. The discovery could affect the medical management of many women at high risk of breast cancer and could lead the way toward a new generation of drugs designed to protect people from a wide range of cancers.

title: Carvel makes a $5 million attempt to show that there are many reasons to celebrate.
description: IN Tom Carvel's day no agency creative types were consulted on clever ways to sell ice cream. Carvel, who had borrowed $15 from his future wife to begin selling ice cream in 1934 and went on to build a multimillion-dollar business, simply went into his Yonkers studio and was filmed saying, ''Please visit your local Carvel ice cream store.''

title: Rubin Postaer Wins VH1 Assignment
description: The VH1 cable television network said yesterday that it had awarded Rubin Postaer & Associates in Santa Monica, Calif., a new assignment, to handle the creative and media duties for a television and print image campaign with a budget of $10 million.

title: Metro Business; Study Says Rents Fail To Meet Rising Costs
description: In the city's annual fight over rent-stabilization increases, the Rent Guidelines Board found a modest jump in landlords' expenses two years ago but only a slight rise in rents, officials said yesterday.

title: For More Consumers, Scanners Are a Must
description: Scanners, once used primarily by businesses, are becoming a must-have peripheral for an increasing number of home PC users, according to a report by the Infotrends Research Group.

title: Investors Show Faith In Korean Rebound
description: South Korea, financially destitute just four months ago, won an enormous vote of confidence from investors around the world yesterday with the successful sale of $4 billion in Government bonds.

title: Judge in Brawley Trial Bars Review of Files
description: The judge in the Tawana Brawley defamation case barred the defense today from examining the investigative files of the special grand jury that declared that Ms. Brawley's 1987 account of being raped by a group of white men was a hoax.

title: Wendy O. Williams, 48, Star Of Explosive Punk Rock Act
description: Wendy O. Williams, the leader of the 1980's punk band the Plasmatics, a group more famous for their destructive onstage antics than for their music, died on Monday at her home in Storrs, Conn., in what officials called a suicide. She was 48.

title: Sonny Bono's Widow Chosen To Succeed Him in Congress
description: Three months after Representative Sonny Bono's death in a skiing accident, his widow, Mary, easily won a special election on Tuesday to succeed him in Congress, defeating her nearest Democratic rival, the actor Ralph Waite, by more than 2 to 1.

title: Building's Demolition Uncovers a Sign of Another Time
description: Broadway's latest super-sign has waited more than 120 years to be seen again.

title: Prosecutor Clears Family In Drowning of Son, 9
description: The Monmouth County Prosecutor said yesterday that he had found no evidence of foul play in the death of a boy who drowned when his parents' truck rolled into a lake in the Assunpink Wildlife Management Area on Jan. 11.

title: Technology Extends Reach of Aid for the Troubled
description: WHEN Ramona Schroeder, a clinical social worker in Kearney, Neb., began treating a suicidal 16-year-old girl, she faced two major obstacles. One was a sullen, listless teen-ager with little desire to live; the other was the daunting expanse of rural Nebraska.

description: MARK GAINS. The mark rose to a six-week high against the dollar after a Bundesbank official suggested higher interest rates would be needed by summer. In New York, the dollar cost 1.8123 marks, down from 1.8356.

description: JAZZ 98, SPURS 88

title: Risky Budget Optimism
description: After three years of preaching austerity, Gov. George Pataki proposed a New York State budget in January with tax cuts and generous spending increases designed to appeal to voters in an election year. Now the Legislature is proposing even more spending and tax cuts. The lawmakers assume that the money to pay for their programs will continue to flood in from the Wall Street boom, and it is true that the state's fiscal situation is better than it has been in years. But the Legislature's budget is risky. It would saddle New York with multibillion-dollar deficits in future years that will be difficult to close if the economy turns sour.

title: Currents; GLASSWORKS -- Blown Gold
description: All that glitters at Rose Tattoo, a studio in Key West, Fla., is gold-coated blown glass. The six-inch vase, right, $259, is made of pleated glass that looks like an Etruscan seashell. The glass is blown in Italy; the gold leaf is applied in Florida. For information: (305) 293-1941.

description: To the Editor:

title: Couple Accept an Opera From the Met
description: The tenor Roberto Alagna and the soprano Angela Gheorghiu, the glamorous married couple at odds with the Metropolitan Opera over one production, have signed a joint contract to sing in another, Joseph Volpe, the Met's general manager, said yesterday.

title: City in Accord With Sanitation Workers
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the city had reached a deal with the sanitation workers' union -- the last major municipal union still at the bargaining table -- that would grant its members pay raises as well as extra money for carrying more trash.

title: Metro Business; First Dorms for St. John's
description: St. John's University said yesterday that it would build dormitories for 2,800 students on its 100-acre campus in Jamaica, Queens, the first on-campus housing it would offer since it was founded in Brooklyn in 1870.

title: A Tragedy in the Family, A Voyeur in the Family
description: Julia Loktev's father, Leonid, was hit by a car in 1989 and left severely disabled, vacant-eyed and virtually immobilized in his wheelchair. As viewers of Ms. Loktev's documentary, ''Moment of Impact,'' discover, Mr. Loktev now needs intensive care from his wife, Larisa, who spends much of her time attending to him in brusque, vigorous fashion. As the couple's only daughter trains her camera on the Loktevs, Mr. Loktev is seen being bathed, fed, dressed and moved about. He is also seen trying to speak, which he does only with great difficulty after Julia or her mother has prodded him.

title: A Switch? Many Mac Fans Say 'No'
description: The New York Times received more than 150 letters from readers -- nearly all from outraged Mac fans -- in response to ''Clan Macintosh Feels the Pain'' (April 2). Here are a few of them:

title: Clerical Counterattack in Iran
description: Indirection is an art form in Iranian politics, and it is now being used by clerical ideologues to undermine President Mohammad Khatami. The detention and interrogation of Teheran's Mayor, Gholamhossein Karbaschi, is their way of attacking Mr. Khatami and his effort to ease repression at home and improve relations with America. The campaign reflects the broader struggle between a people weary of rigid Islamic fundamentalist rule and a clerical leadership unwilling to yield power.

title: Sports of The Times; Put the Fear Of Riley In Ewing
description: IF the Knicks' recent nose dive hadn't yet persuaded Patrick Ewing to start thinking about next year, maybe last night's courtside sighting of Pat Riley would. The tanned face of a man in perpetual competitive heat might be just what the doctor ordered for Ewing to realize how the risks of return may outweigh potential reward.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINKELSTEIN, LENA (NANY)
description: FINKELSTEIN-Lena (Nany). April 7, 1998. Beloved mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Lived life to the fullest, in our hearts forever. Services Today 12:30pm at Boulevard Riverside, Hewlett, L.I.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHITE, ELIZABETH M.
description: WHITE-Elizabeth M. A memorial service for Elizabeth M. White, of Hilton Head Island, SC and formerly of Darien, CT, who died March 7, will be held Tuesday, April 14, 1998 at 11:00 AM at Noroton Presbyterian Chapel, 2011 Post Road, Noroton Heights, CT. A reception will follow at Wee Burn Country Club in Darien, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NANCE, ARLENE
description: NANCE-Arlene. We are saddened by the death of our esteemed colleague and friend. Arlene served both the real estate industry and the community with distinction, combining care and wisdom with the highest standards of integrity. She was widely acknowledged as the leading townhouse expert for the Village and the downtown market & was a significant figure for so many years in our industry. We are grateful to have been associated with her and send our deepest sympathy to her husband Harry and her daughter Erika. Howard P. Milstein Chairman Joan Ambrose Nan MarElia Douglas Elliman

title: Tolls Are Increasing For Web On-Ramps
description: after several years of sharply declining prices, connecting to the Internet is getting more expensive again.

title: At Wake, Police Tell Family the Body Is Not Their Daughter's
description: In a bizarre twist to what the police thought was a solved missing persons and murder case, the corpse of a girl that a family was about to bury in the belief that it was their 16-year-old daughter's body turned out to be someone else's, the police said yesterday.

title: Economic Scene; Partial privatization of Social Security looks very possible.
description: TWO years ago Social Security privatization probably had no more support in Washington than the legalization of marijuana. Today, the notion is being entertained by such heavyweights as Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the senior Democrat on the Senate Finance Committee. Privatization has become a very real possibility in part because big budget surpluses are apparently available to help pay for the transition.

title: Perhaps No Better Time To Add Computer Memory
description: While some Internet prices are going up, the cost of computer memory is continuing to fall. That is bad news for the companies making memory chips but good news for anyone shopping for a new computer or upgrading an old one.

title: Metro Business; New Offices for Baseball
description: Major League Baseball has a new home: three floors at 245 Park Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Garden Q.& A.
description: To Beard the Iris

title: House Proud; To Rescue A Wreck: Brush It, Sweep It, Scrub It
description: ''AN old natural history museum in Vienna,'' Don Freeman, a photographer, said when asked to recall his most inspiring interior.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINLAY, REV. TERENCE JOHN, D.D.
description: FINLAY-Rev. Terence John, D.D. Died peacefully in his sleep in his 92nd year, April 8, 1998 at Maplecrest Village, Grimsby, Ontario. Beloved husband of the late Sara McBryan Finlay; adored father of Terry (Alice-Jean) and Bryan (Carol); much loved grandfather of Sara-Jane and Rebecca, Molly and Charles; will also be sorely missed by his sister Kathleen and his brother Patrick. He served his Lord faithfully in the Anglican Church in London, Ontario, then as Rector of Holy Trinity, Winnipeg; St. John the Evangelist, Ottawa, and St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, New York City. A Service of Thanksgiving and Celebration of his life will be held Monday, April 13, 1998 at 2PM, St. Andrew's Anglican Church, Grimsby, Ontario. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to St. Andrew's Anglican Church, 154 Main Street West, Grimsby, Ontario L3M-1S3. Christ is Risen. The Lord is risen indeed. Alleluia!

title: A Switch? Many Mac Fans Say 'No'
description: The New York Times received more than 150 letters from readers -- nearly all from outraged Mac fans -- in response to ''Clan Macintosh Feels the Pain'' (April 2). Here are a few of them:

title: Departures Spur Lazard Freres To Remake Itself
description: A string of key departures after recent years of rapid expansion is causing Lazard Freres & Company, the prestigious 150 year-old investment bank, to try to act more like other established financial institutions -- with committees and governance. The firm is even stressing collegiality.

title: Metro Business; Bias Deal Goes to Judge
description: Smith Barney and the women who settled a national class-action sex discrimination case against the securities firm will ask a Federal judge to approve the settlement.

title: Garden Notebook; The Same Design, Only More So
description: JEFF MENDOZA, of J. Mendoza Gardens, a design firm in Manhattan, recalled the scene last summer when he and his crew went to demolish a rooftop garden he had created in 1985 for an advertising agency that was leaving the premises. While he was working, the new occupants, also an ad agency, came by and saw what was turning back into a bare tar-paper roof.

title: Queens Foster Father Charged in Sexual Abuse
description: A Queens foster parent who the police said disciplined three children in his care by putting plastic bags over their heads and locking them in a closet has been charged with raping and sexually abusing them as well.

title: DuPont Shifts Focus To Sciences Unit
description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company, the largest United States chemical company, said this week that it would reorganize to focus on its fast-growing agricultural, biotechnology and pharmaceutical businesses.

title: Undone by 'Don't Ask, Don't Tell'
description: I think it's working,'' said Defense Secretary William Cohen, referring to the Pentagon's ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy for gay members of the armed services. He said this while announcing that discharges of homosexuals have increased by 67 percent since 1994. When you factor in the military's downsizing, the real figure is closer to 80 percent. If this is Mr. Cohen's definition of success, one wonders what failure would look like.

title: $15 Million a Team, Even for a V.I.P.
description: The price for a team in Major League Soccer has climbed $15 million in three years, and not even being a founder of the league warrants a discount.

title: Design Notebook; Cruise Ship Design Challenge: Find the Ocean
description: BEFORE the jet age, when ocean liners were built to cross seas, not cruise them, passengers would sit in wooden deck chairs and promenade the long teak decks to exult in the grandeur of the world's biggest landscape.

title: Father Is Charged In a Girl's Restraint
description: A Queens man was charged with unlawful imprisonment yesterday after his daughter was found sealed in a room during a fire, the authorities said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYKO, JEFFREY
description: BOYKO-Jeffrey. Park East Synagogue mourns the untimely passing of our devoted member Jeffrey Boyko, beloved husband of Leslie, father of Alexander, gifted student of our Fromer Religious School, and nephew of our Founder Benefactor and past President of Sisterhood, Charlotte Wool. Heartfelt condolences to them and the entire family. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSHENBERG, MIRIAM
description: KIRSHENBERG-Miriam. On April 7, 1998. Beloved wife of Gerald, devoted mother of Howard and Robert, cherished grandmother to Zoe and Aaron. ''You will always be with us. Your beauty and caring will forever be missed.'' Services Thursday, 12 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISRAEL, SYLVIA
description: ISRAEL-Sylvia, 87. Died April 6, 1998 in Sioux City, IA. Beloved wife of the late Arthur J. Survivors include two sons, Dr. Jerry Israel and his wife Carol of Sioux City, and Alan Fredericks and his wife Catherine of Old Bridge, NJ; six grandchildren and three great grandchildren. She was preceded in death by a brother Joseph Herzberg. Services Friday, 9:45 AM, Parkwest-Riverside Chapels, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: TV's Tastelessness Is Only Half of Story; Vast Wasteland Indeed
description: To the Editor:

title: Tobacco Stocks Rally
description: Tobacco stocks rallied yesterday after the industry said it would not work for comprehensive legislation to regulate tobacco and limit advertising.

title: Versatile System Aims to Teach Cooking in the Kitchen
description: IN the 1960's, Lady Bird Johnson had some succinct advice on acquiring the culinary arts. ''If you can read, you can cook,'' the First Lady announced to her two daughters, who were heading off to independent lives. By all accounts, Lady Bird was quite a live-in role model, as adept with barbecue as she was at keeping up with L.B.J.

title: Opera Plus CD-ROM: A Promising Duet
description: OPERA was multimedia long before the word was coined. The marriage of music and drama. The ballets so often thrown in, especially by the French. The occasional libretto that merits the name poetry. And, in the best of productions, the medley of painterly scrims, striking set design, dazzling lighting and sumptuous costumes that makes vital visual art out of stagecraft.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EYRE, PELLINE
description: EYRE-Pelline. Pelline Acton Eyre died peacefully April 7 in her 92nd year in London, England. She is survived by her seven children: Edward, James, Peter, Patrick and Caroline of England, John Eyre of Newport, Rhode Island, Dorothy Reminick of Jupiter, Florida, eleven grandchildren and three great grandchildren. Funeral arrangements private.

title: Committee Says C.I.A.'s Secrecy Threatens to Make History a Lie
description: The official record of United States foreign policy stands in danger of becoming ''an official lie'' if the Central Intelligence Agency keeps refusing to release cold-war documents from the 1950's and 1960's, a State Department historians' committee warns in a forthcoming report.

title: California Voters Face New Canvas for Electoral Politics
description: In just two months, California voters will begin sifting a pile of options to choose a new governor for the most populous state, decide on whether to retain Senator Barbara Boxer and set statewide law and policy on issues like bilingual education and the use of union dues in political campaigns.

title: Survival Tonight, Peril Tomorrow
description: John Starks showed up at Madison Square Garden at 5 o'clock, more than three hours before last night's game and one hour before the Knicks are required to arrive. He walked onto the court with a basketball. A Knick ball boy wanted to rebound for him, but he shooed the young man away.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Feb. 13 about architecturally significant Los Angeles houses that have become favorite settings for Hollywood filmmakers misidentified the one featured by the Coen Brothers in ''The Big Lebowski.'' It was the Doheny mansion, not the James Goldstein house. This correction was delayed by an editing lapse.

title: The Politics of Needles and AIDS
description: Debate has started up ds xabout whether the Government should renew its ban on subsidies for needle-exchange programs, which advocates say can help stop the spread of AIDS. In a letter to Congress, Barry McCaffrey, who is in charge of national drug policy, cited two Canadian studies to show that needle-exchange plans have failed to reduce the spread of H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS, and may even have worsened the problem. Congressional leaders have cited these studies to make the same argument.

title: True North Names Seasoned Executive
description: Gary Moss, who has worked for several well-known advertisers and agencies, has joined Tierney & Partners in Philadelphia, part of True North Communications, in the new position of senior vice president and director for brand development. Mr. Moss, 47, will focus on wooing new clients as well as providing strategic counsel for present accounts.

title: Starr Has Had Enough Latitude in Inquiry; Spin and Stonewall
description: To the Editor:

title: 9 Workers Injured In Explosion at Plant
description: Nine workers were injured following an explosion at a chemical plant last night, officials said.

title: White House Easter Eggs To Roll on the Internet
description: The White House is scrambling to make the annual White House Easter Egg Roll, scheduled for Monday, a technological eggstravaganza. The day's events on the South Lawn will be broadcast live (www.easter.earthlink.net) on the Internet for the first time.

title: Indians Striving to Save Their Languages
description: At the age of 88 and blind in one eye, James Jackson Jr. keeps a crystal clear memory of a tiny linguistic skirmish in a continental campaign that has brought most of North America's Indian languages to the brink of extinction.

title: Efamol Unit Selects Kirshenbaum Bond
description: Efamol Neutraceuticals in Boston, a unit of Efamol Ltd. in Guildford, England, said yesterday that it had named Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners in New York as the first agency to introduce its nutritional supplement products in the United States. Billings were estimated at $10 million. The decision came after a two-month review that had been narrowed to Kirshenbaum Bond and one other finalist, Arnold Communications in Boston.

title: In the Goo Below, Primordial Secrets
description: Tonight's edition of ''The New Explorers'' is worth watching for the strange beauty of Yellowstone National Park. But, Bill Kurtis promises, its geysers, hot springs and mud pots hold deeper mysteries. Within those steaming pools, scientists conjecture, may reside the single-celled creatures with which life on earth began some three and a half billion years ago. There are differences of opinion about specifics. One school of investigators traces the creation of amino acids, the building blocks of life, to electric sparks' striking receptive chemicals. Others think the secret can be found in Yellowstone's superhot breeding grounds, which continue to hold surprises for the future as well as revelations of the past.

title: Dedicated to the Outrageous
description: If everyone has a figurative 15 minutes of fame, Joe Coleman's comes in the form of an 85-minute documentary film by Robert-Adrian Pejo titled ''R.I.P,'' which stands, in this case, for ''Rest in Pieces.''

title: Need Chinese Art? Call Diplomats; Even Kissinger Aided Guggenheim Negotiations for a Show
description: On a clear, cool day in the late winter of 1995, the director of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum arrived in North Carolina on an improbable mission: to lure a 76-year-old authority on Asian art, Sherman Lee, out of retirement to organize an exhibition of 5,000 years of Chinese art at the Guggenheim.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PARKER, RUTH
description: PARKER-Ruth. The Klau family mourns the passing of a devoted friend and cousin.

title: Cairo Journal; Blazing a Fresh Trail, Getting a Rancid Welcome
description: A photograph on the cover of Egypt's most popular magazine last month depicted the new United States Ambassador here wearing the black hat and sidelocks of a strict Orthodox Jew.

title: U.S. and France Reach Air Accord
description: The United States and France announced an agreement yesterday to expand access to each other's aviation markets, a move that could drive down fares as competition increases for trans-Atlantic flights.

title: From Hitchhiker Spoofs to Starship Titanic
description: OH DEAR oh dear oh dear oh dear,'' exclaims Fentible the Doorbot shortly after the Starship Titanic, the intergalactic luxury liner ''that cannot possibly go wrong,'' crashes unceremoniously into your living room. ''We've had a little accident,'' he says in the well-measured tones of an English butler.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  D'AQUINO, CARL SR
description: D'AQUINO-Carl Sr, beloved husband and father, leaving wife, Josephine; sons, Victor, Roger, & Carl, & granddaughter, Stephanie. Service at Perazzo Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker St., today, 9:15 AM. May God be with you.

title: HUNTSMAN PACKAGING BUYING BLESSINGS FOR $216 MILLION
description: The Huntsman Packaging Corporation agreed yesterday to buy the Blessings Corporation for $21 a share, or about $216 million, expanding its plastics business in fast-growing Latin American markets. Blessings, based in Newport News, Va., had 1997 sales of $175 million. The closely held Huntsman Packaging, based in Salt Lake City, has annual sales of $500 million. The Blessings plastic films, which are used in personal-care and medical products like diapers and surgical supplies, will add to Huntsman's line of packaging for consumer, agricultural and industrial goods. Blessings is also stronger in the growing Mexican and Latin American markets. Blessings shares rose $3.0625 each, or 17 percent, to $20.75, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMULIAN, BARRY S.
description: SMULIAN-Barry S. Beloved husband of Judge Laura A. Ward, loving father of Ian and Faith Smulian. Devoted brother of Toni B. Gasser. Adoring son of the late Nathan L. and Florence B. Smulian. Services Thursday, April 9, 11:30 AM, Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the American Cancer Society and the National Multiple Sclerosis Society would be appreciated.

title: Jets' Special Teams Star Gets Offer From the Rams
description: Chad Cascadden, the Jets' top special teams player two years ago who became a valuable role player last season, has been offered a multimillion-dollar deal by the St. Louis Rams that the Jets are unlikely to match.

title: Irabu and Curtis Keep Yanks From Sinking in West
description: Like Pavlov's dog, the Yankees were conditioned. Pitch to Ken Griffey Jr. in a crucial moment here, and he would get a big hit. Play in the Kingdome, and the Yankees would lose. That goes a long way to explaining the ecstatic faces in Joe Torre's clubhouse today, when the Yankees reversed the natural order and the brutal start to their 1998 season.

title: Clinton, in Chicago, Presses Congress on School Repairs
description: Saying that the nation's children are as worthy of investment as its transportation system, President Clinton pressed Congress today to pass his school construction and renovation plan as speedily as it did legislation allocating hundreds of billions of dollars to roads and mass transit.

title: In the Glow of a Merger, A Fight Over a Neon Sign
description: Forget such trivia as whether the merger of Travelers Group and Citicorp would create a global behemoth that will alter the financial services industry. What residents of TriBeCa want to know is whether the chairman of Travelers will take that four-story red neon umbrella with him when he moves his headquarters from Greenwich Street to midtown.

title: Turf; The Agent as Hot Property
description: WHEN he was a child, Tom Abbate, now 44 and a real estate agent in Middletown, Conn., did not know he was destined to be the star of his own billboard, much less nine of them.

title: IN YANKEE STADIUM WITH -- Dan Cunningham; Cleats, Squirts and Other Lawn Indignities
description: EVERY homeowner wants a thick, green lawn. And there's a man in the Bronx who knows more about how to grow one than just about anyone.

title: Chilean Is Likely To Join Club
description: Sunil Gulati, the league's deputy commissioner in charge of signing players for all teams, said yesterday that he was on the verge of signing Marcello Vega, a member of the national team of Chile, and awarding him to the MetroStars, with whom Vega worked out last week. Vega would become the fifth foreigner on the team.

title: Nurses Put on Fast Forward In Rush for Cost Efficiency
description: Click, click, click, click. Heidi Jowett, R.N., snapped her fingers in describing the speed with which she and the nurses she supervises in the new 21-bed short-stay unit of the Kaiser Permanente hospital here perform their tasks. They are what Kaiser, the nation's biggest health maintenance organization, calls accelerated-care nurses: they move patients from suture to discharge in under 48 hours.

title: Bridge; When the Deceiving Face Is Hidden on the Internet
description: There are some subtle differences between playing in a normal, face-to-face setting and playing at home on a computer with the other three players in distant locations.

title: Mistrial Called In Beating Of Black Man
description: Five weeks after it began, the trial of Austin Offen, a white Queens man charged in the near-fatal beating of a young black man in the early morning hours of May 26, 1996, ended in a mistrial today after the jury said for the third time that it was hopelessly deadlocked.

title: R. O. Mithun, 89, Retired Ad Executive
description: Raymond O. Mithun, who helped found the Campbell-Mithun Inc. advertising agency with $1,500 and three clients, died March 31 in Scottsdale Memorial Hospital in Scottsdale, Ariz. Mr. Mithun, who was 89, lived in Indian Wells, Calif., and died from complications from pneumonia, an agency spokesman said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISENBERG, FLORENCE
description: WEISENBERG-Florence. On April 7, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Joseph M. Weisenberg. Loving mother of Susan Auerbach and her husband Kenneth, and William Weisenberg and his wife Kathleen. Adoring grandmother of Philip and Peter Auerbach and Lisa and Leslie Weisenberg. Devoted sister of Lee Kolker and loving aunt of Anne Kolker. Service Thursday, April 9, 11:30 A.M., at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave at 81 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her name to Temple Emanu-El, New York City.

title: WNET Appoints a New Chairman
description: After helping WNET, Channel 13 in New York, raise $78 million in a capital campaign that was the largest ever by a public television station, the financier Henry R. Kravis has told the station's board that he will step down as chairman. The board has chosen Steven Rattner, deputy chief executive of the investment firm Lazard Freres & Company, to succeed him.

title: Hospital and Striking Nurses Face Off Over 12-Hour Shifts
description: In her 10 years as a nurse at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn, Jackie Francois has become a big fan of her unusual work schedule: three 12-hour shifts a week.

title: A Switch? Many Mac Fans Say 'No'
description: The New York Times received more than 150 letters from readers -- nearly all from outraged Mac fans -- in response to ''Clan Macintosh Feels the Pain'' (April 2). Here are a few of them:

title: The Tobacco Industry's Defiance
description: Cigarette manufacturers pulled out of the search for a comprehensive tobacco deal yesterday after Steven Goldstone, the chairman of RJR Nabisco, railed against the tobacco bill approved by the Senate Commerce Committee as sure to produce bankruptcy for tobacco companies, the loss of countless jobs and creation of a rampant black market for cigarettes. But the industry's resistance and unrealistic doomsday scenarios should not weaken Congressional resolve to forge ahead with strong legislation to protect public health and curb smoking among youths. This exercise, after all, is not about protecting the financial interests of the cigarette producers.

title: The Knicks Win One They Needed Desperately
description: This is what desperation looked like at the end of the game for the Knicks: A weary Allan Houston was grabbing his shorts like a life preserver, Charles Oakley was rubbing his tired eyes and John Starks was absorbing another head-shaking shooting night. Only Chris Childs, who had entered the game and painted a wild streak at point guard, seemed fresh in the final seconds.

title: Palffy's 2 Help Isles Trip Devils
description: In a season of disappointments for the Islanders, Zigmund Palffy has been a bright spot.

title: Metro Matters; Please Pass The Peace (With Gravy)
description: ''I'll say welcome, and then the usual cocktails and hors d'oeuvres and chitchat. And then there will come a time, I hope, when I can say, 'Mr. Mayor, you and I may never agree on everything, but I hope we can agree on this city and how important it is.' ''

title: Currents; ARCHITECTURE -- Some Advance Praise For Projects In Utero
description: None of the projects have been built yet, but they have already been judged. The Progressive Architecture awards are among the few that reward concepts rather than finished buildings. This year's winners will be celebrated in the May issue of Architecture magazine, which arrives on newsstands tomorrow.

title: Bold Step for Citigroup On Shaky Asian Ground
description: John S. Reed first realized his vision of Citibank as a financial supermarket for the emerging global middle class in Asia during the 1980's, when the bank opened hundreds of branches, granted thousands of mortgages and sold millions of credit cards from Taiwan to Thailand.

title: Human Rights in China
description: To the Editor:

title: Schumer Enters Race for Senate Saying He Can Unseat D'Amato
description: Declaring that Democrats had historically erred in trying to defeat Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato with attacks on his ethics, Representative Charles E. Schumer entered the Senate race yesterday by assailing Mr. D'Amato's ideological record. He asserted that the Republican Senator ''voted much more like a senator from Mississippi than like a senator from New York.''

title: Indonesian Stocks Post Another Advance
description: Indonesian stocks rose yesterday for a second time in three days as a new agreement with the International Monetary Fund raised hopes for progress on the problem of the country's $71 billion foreign debt. The benchmark Jakarta Composite Index of 288 stocks rose 3.90 points, to 530.04.

title: With a Deadline Tonight, Ulster Negotiators Study Compromises
description: Straining to meet a midnight Thursday deadline for a peace agreement in Northern Ireland, the British and Irish Prime Ministers sought today to work out compromises on disputed issues between Protestant and Roman Catholic political leaders.

title: Starr Has Had Enough Latitude in Inquiry; Playing With Words
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  COHEN, IRVING S.
description: COHEN-Irving S. 5/6/28-4/9/96. Second year in heaven. We love and miss you daily. The Lord bless you and keep you under His wings. Your wife Mary, children, grandchildren

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  NYRO, LAURA
description: NYRO-Laura. One year ago. We love you & cherish the music. May you sing and play sweet harmonies with the angels. Barbara, Barry, Michael, Regina.

title: Personal Shopper; Seating for One and a Half or for Two Really Close Friends
description: ''ONE can lounge -- or two can cuddle,'' said Ilene Wetson, a New York interior designer, speaking about a piece of furniture called a chair-and-a-half. It's larger than a club chair but smaller than a love seat.

title: Are 'Smart' Cards Getting Too Wise to Get Off the Drawing Board?
description: PARIS  Almost no one disputes the potential of "smart" cards. The ubiquitous plastic cards embedded with foil-covered computer chips are being used for everything from pay phones to parking meters, from vending machines to mobile phones.

title: Q & A / Edmund Jensen, President of Visa : Large Retailers May Spur Revolution in Chip Cards
description: Edmund Jensen, president and chief executive of Visa International Inc., is retiring in December after a four-year tenure that saw Visa expand into chip-card technology. He recently discussed the future of smart cards with Gina Rarick of the International Herald Tribune.

title: Press Appeals for Access To Grand Jury on Clinton
description: A lawyer for major news organizations asked an appeals court today to open court proceedings about executive privilege and other issues involved in the grand jury investigation of President Clinton but appeared to win little sympathy.

title: James J. Leff, 77, Outspoken New York Judge
description: James J. Leff, who was an outspoken New York State Supreme Court justice for three decades and helped the Conservative Party in its early days while he was a Manhattan lawyer, died on Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 77 and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: Morocco Finds Fundamentalism Benign but Scary
description: A group of students at the University of Casablanca were comparing notes about how they were being courted by militants of an Islamist movement.

title: Starr Has Had Enough Latitude in Inquiry; Media Responsibility
description: To the Editor:

title: FUNDAMENTALS: User's Guide; It's Time to Hunt For Easter Eggs
description: I DON'T think Microsoft believes in the Easter bunny.

title: Currents; HOSPITALITY -- No More Jail Cell Styling
description: Anyone who endures a hospital stay knows that hospital decor is often one step above a prison ward and nearly as bad as hospital food. Barbara White Fishman, an artist and philanthropist who has battled breast cancer since the mid-1980's, had the means to do something about it.

title: Currents; CERAMICS -- Creations of Bloomsbury's Last Witness
description: Quentin Bell, inset, who died in 1996 at age 86, was the last living witness to the Bloomsbury group. His parents were Vanessa and Clive Bell. Virginia Woolf was his aunt. His famous extended family of artists, writers, friends and lovers frequented his parents' farmhouse, known as Charleston, in Sussex, England.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEET, GLEN
description: LEET-Glen. On April 7, two weeks short of 90 years, in New York, a community development innovator. Beloved husband and partner of Mildred Robbins Leet. Loving father of Carla Leet, Frederika Leet and Glen Leet, Jr. Stepfather to Aileen Robbins and Jane Marla Robbins. Cherished grandfather to four and great grandfather to two. As a trained public administrator, he devoted his life to helping people help themselves move out of poverty, from helping to write social security laws in the 1930's, in the 1940's with UNRWA in Greece, in the 1950's as first chief of Community Development at the UN, in the 1960's as president of Save the Children, and in the 1970's as cofounder and president of Trickle Up. Always dedicated to service to humankind, always a caring, concerned and giving man. A great loss. Interment will be private. Memorial service will be announced at a later date. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Trickle Up Program, 121 West 27th Street, New York, New York 10001.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: NEWS WATCH
description: A NEW TEMPLE -- built by the Hare Krishna movement in New Delhi opened this week with nine robots, or ''mechanical gods,'' built by a special-effects company in Los Angeles. The robots move their heads and arms, the British Broadcasting System reported, and they recite Hindu scriptures like the Bhagavad-Gita and the Vedas.

title: Taking Care of Workers And Business, Too; When Quality Is Key in Health Benefits
description: Four months after multiple-bypass heart surgery, Gordon Kernan, 52, was back at work testing products at the Black & Decker Corporation. But his diabetes grew worse after the operation, so he now monitors his health with the help of a counseling program that his employer helped create.

title: Defragmenting a Drive
description: Q. Recently I was told to defragment my hard drive. What does this mean and how and why should I do it?

title: Essay; End the Secrecy
description: Never in modern constitutional history has the Federal judiciary so undermined the First Amendment.

description: To the Editor:

title: American Topics : A School in California Starts Suspending the Parents, Too
description: Teachers and administrators in San Juan Capistrano, California, are fed up with rudeness and foul language. So under a new school policy, cursing a teacher can lead to suspension. The rule, however, aims not at students but at their parents.

title: Democracy in India as a Cup Half-Full
description: THE IDEA OF INDIA

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERSTEIN, ARNOLD S.
description: ALPERSTEIN-Arnold S. Goldstick, Weinberger, Feldman & Grossman PC note with profound sorrow the passing of Arnold S. Alperstein. Arnold was a dedicated and devoted member of our firm for more than two decades and a caring human being. Our sincere condolences to his children and family members.

title: A Saxophonist's Warm-Up Ends
description: A decade ago, major record labels yanked promising jazz players out of music school, offered them contracts and asked them to earn a place in history. Such invitations are rare these days, but the tenor saxophonist Mark Turner, who's into his 30's and has only now released his first big-label record (''Mark Turner,'' on Warner Brothers), is a beneficiary of current jazz economics: he's ready, whereas many who came before him were not.

title: As Boom Fails, Malaysia Sends Migrants Home
description: They leave as empty-handed as they came, their heads shaved like those of prisoners, bowing and smiling deferentially as police officers in cherry-red helmets herd them into the holds of cargo ships.

title: Enforcement Chief Named At the S.E.C.
description: Richard H. Walker, general counsel at the Securities and Exchange Commission, will become the commission's top enforcement officer, Arthur Levitt Jr., the chairman, announced yesterday.

title: Packwood, Sensing Change of Climate, Weighs a Race
description: Bob Packwood is out to test a theory: If President Clinton can survive -- even thrive under -- an avalanche of sex-related accusations, then maybe the political climate has changed enough for Mr. Packwood to seek redemption.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOOKMAN, SEYMOUR M.
description: BOOKMAN-Seymour M. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Seymour M. Bookman, associated with The Times from 1961, until retiring in 1995.

description: ''We are not like a Brinks truck overturned in the middle of the highway.''

title: Corrections
description: A music review on March 30 about a performance of Bach's ''St. Matthew Passion'' on March 25 at the Church of the Ascension in Manhattan misidentified the oboe soloist. She was Diane Lesser, not Marcia Butler.

title: Sports of The Times; Irabu Makes Promising New Start
description: TANTALIZING. That's the adjective Joe Torre uses for Hideki Irabu. Ever since that stunning spring-training night in Orlando, Fla., in March, Torre has known with certainty that there is something special in Irabu's right arm. The trick is to find it again.

title: Nets All Business in Quieting Celtics
description: The Nets appeared on the verge of falling apart midway through the fourth quarter tonight, and Chris Gatling simmered as he walked to the bench. When he reached his seat, he removed his headband and threw it at a taunting fan in the front row at the Fleet Center. The fan scooped it up and used it to whip the Boston fans into a frenzy.

title: Windows 95 Is Hanging On Even as Windows 98 Nears
description: With Windows 98 set to arrive in late June, one would think that sales of Windows 95 would trickle to a halt between now and then unless Microsoft offered some sort of coupon or rebate. Not so.

title: U.N. Agrees to Return to Cambodia to Monitor Volatile Election
description: Five years after the United Nations organized and ran the most democratic election in Cambodia's history, Secretary General Kofi Annan announced today that the organization will go back this year to monitor the next, more problematic, vote in July.

title: LENNAR ADDING TO HOLDINGS IN SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA
description: The Lennar Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to buy three home builders for $370 million in cash and stock, continuing its expansion into the booming West Coast market. The Miami-based home builder said the three closely held companies are Colrich Communities, which builds homes in San Diego; Polygon Communities, which builds in Southern California and Sacramento, and Communities Southwest, a land developer in Southern California and Phoenix. The three companies own a total of 37 communities with 14,000 lots.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NARDIELO, RALPH
description: NARDIELO-Ralph. In Melbourne, FL. Longtime resident of Pelham Manor. April 5. Loving husband of Mary (deceased). Father of Linda (deceased). Loved by his extended family. Devoted companion of Janet Brennan. We will miss the walks, talks, races, five o'clock cocktail hour, but most of all you. Rest in peace, dear friend. Love, Beverly and Alan Schpero

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRAND, JOSEPH
description: BRAND-Joseph. The Board of Governors and Members of the Elberon Bathing Club mourn the passing of our longtime member and friend Joe Brand on March 31, 1998. His counsel and advice have been invaluable throughout the years. He will be sorely missed. Robert Fagenson, President Ellen Winik, Secretary

description: Manhattan

title: Yahoo's First-Quarter Earnings Exceed Expectations of Analysts
description: Yahoo Inc., the Internet directory service, reported first-quarter earnings today that exceeded Wall Street analysts' expectations. Yahoo said traffic on its World Wide Web pages had increased by nearly 50 percent since the fourth quarter of 1997.

title: One in Every 8 Plant Species Is Imperiled, a Survey Finds
description: At least 1 of every 8 plant species in the world -- and nearly 1 of 3 in the United States -- is under threat of extinction, according to the first comprehensive worldwide assessment of plant endangerment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENBERG, JULIUS L.
description: GREENBERG-Julius L. Age 72 of Aberdeen, NJ, Tues., April 7, 1998. Beloved husband of Christina (nee Marchisa Greenberg). Dearest uncle of several nieces and nephews. Service Saturday 8:00 AM, at the Day Funeral Home Inc., 361 Maple Place, Keyport, NJ, 9:00AM at The United Methodist Church of Matawan, NJ. Entombment in Garden of Memories Cemetery, Paramus, NJ. Friends may call Friday 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 P.M.

title: Daimler Says Mercedes Aids Its Sales Increase
description: Daimler-Benz A.G. said yesterday that its sales rose 22 percent in the first quarter, fueled by Mercedes-Benz A.G., whose new line of sports utility and small cars is seen helping annual brand sales 28 percent by the year 2000. Daimler said first-quarter sales rose to 31.58 billion marks ($17.1 billion) from 25.906 billion a year earlier. By the year 2000, Daimler's annual sales will rise 29 percent and sales of Mercedes 28 percent, the company said.

title: A Police Prosecutor Asserts a Cover-Up In a Beating Inquiry
description: A New York City police sergeant assigned to prosecute officers accused of brutality has charged in a Federal lawsuit that commanders ordered him to cover up evidence about two detectives under investigation in the beating of a Queens man in 1994.

description: To the Editor:

Devoted brother of Florence, Virginia, Juliet, and Louis. Cherished grandfather of two and one great grandchild. Friends may call Thursday 2-5 and 7-10 PM at the Thomas F. description: An article yesterday about Susan Spicer, the chef at Bayona in New Orleans, misspelled the surname of another noted New Orleans chef. He is Emeril Lagasse, not Legasse.

description: SBC Communications Inc. said today that it had reached tentative agreements with the Communications Workers of America for contracts covering 74,000 of the phone company's union workers.

description: READER, meet your new lawyer.

title: Brooklyn School Official Is Accused of Sex Abuse
description: The acting principal of a Brooklyn high school was charged yesterday with sexually abusing a school aide who complained that he had lured her into a basement storage room last week and then groped her, according to the school system's independent investigator.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COLLAGEN CORP., Palo Alto, Calif., a medical technology company, plans to sell its Lipomatrix Inc. breast implant unit to improve its profits and focus on treatments for human tissue.

title: Public Service Chairman Announces Resignation
description: The chairman of the State Public Service Commission, who presided over the deregulation of the utility industry in New York, announced his resignation yesterday. The chairman, John F. O'Mara, oversaw the deregulation of utilities in the state. For the electric utilities, that means customers will ultimately be able to shop for the cheapest supplier of electricity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SULLIVAN, CATHERINE C. (NEE QUINLAN)
description: SULLIVAN-Catherine C. (nee Quinlan). Of Newfoundland in her 43rd year on April 7, 1998. Cherished wife of Timothy. Devoted mother of Meghan, Lauren and Catherine. Beloved daughter of William and Mary. Dear sister of Thomas, William, Patrick and Raymond. Visiting Thursday and Friday, 2-4 and 7-9PM at Clavin Funeral Home, 7722 4th Avenue, Brooklyn. Mass of Christian Burial, on Monday, 10 AM, Saint Joseph's Church, Garden City. Burial Holy Rood Cemetery.

title: Making Books; Bardolatry In the Backlists
description: Yo, Shakespeare! American book publishers should lift a draught for you on your upcoming birth- and death day, and vow not to drumble the plays and sonnets but to publish them featly, since the work makes up the greatest backlist of any writer in history.

title: Airbus Profits Hurt By a Price War
description: Airbus Industrie posted a 61 percent drop in its profit in 1997 as the European plane maker was squeezed by a price war with its archrival, the Boeing Company. The profit was 268 million marks ($147 million), Daimler-Benz, an Airbus partner, said in its annual report. Airbus, which is structured as a partnership, does not disclose its earnings.

title: Winter Took a Holiday, So the Groundskeepers and Some Players Did Not
description: For the hardier golfers in the area, last year's golf season never really ended. In this exceptionally mild winter, golfers played a lot of golf -- 5,500 rounds in February alone at four of the five Bethpage State Park courses (the fifth, Black, was being renovated for the United States Open to be played there in 1999; it will open in June for public play).

title: 21 Years After Chinatown Killing, Police Charge Queens Man
description: On Oct. 1, 1977, Yam Kit Yuen joined some friends for a late afternoon movie at the Pagoda Theater in Chinatown. They walked out before the credits, perhaps disappointed that the movie did not have enough of the action and over-the-top comedy so popular with young moviegoers in Chinatown at the time.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Public Lives column yesterday about a party for the playwright Jon Robin Baitz misidentified the employer of a guest, the news correspondent Elizabeth Vargas. It is ABC, not NBC.

description: President Clinton has ordered the Departments of Defense, State and Justice to devise plans for the arrest and trial of Pol Pot, the shadowy Khmer Rouge leader responsible for the death of perhaps a million Cambodians in the 1970's.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Who gets information first on auto sales figures can be critically important, and controversial.
description: INVESTORS, stock analysts and even Federal Reserve officials eagerly await the release each month of auto makers' sales for signs of the condition of individual companies and the health of the economy as a whole.

title: PLATINUM TECHNOLOGY REVISES TERMS OF MASTERING DEAL
description: Platinum Technology Inc. said yesterday that it had changed its agreement to buy Mastering Inc. for about $181.7 million, to reflect a decline in Platinum's shares since the acquisition was announced. Under the amended agreement, Platinum will exchange $12.50 worth of its common stock, or between 0.448 share and 0.540 share, for each Mastering common share. Platinum's shares have fallen 10 percent since Feb. 19, when the Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., computer company, which is based in announced it would buy Mastering, of Scottsdale, Ariz., to expand its computer-training business. Platinum's shares rose $2, to $24.5625, while Mastering's shares rose $2.1875, to $12.0625.

description: * Ranch 1, New York, to Posnick & Kolker, New York, as the first agency to create campaigns for the fast-food chain. Billings were estimated at $2 million.
