description: BERGER-Harold. Beloved husband of Rosalie. Devoted father of Dr. Irwin Berger and Dennis Berger. Loving grandfather of Andrew, David and Joshua. Dear brother of Rose Waldman, Sylvia Oser and Helen Kantor. Service 12 noon Friday at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Minnesota Senator May Challenge Gore
description: Paul Wellstone of Minnesota, one of the most liberal Democrats in the Senate, today announced that he had formed an exploratory committee to help him build support and pay for his travel as he considered whether to run for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 2000.

title: Teamsters Group Backs Reform Candidate for Union's President
description: Teamsters for a Democratic Union, a group of teamsters that long supported Ron Carey, the union's president, announced yesterday that it was backing Ken Hall, head of the union's small-package division, in the upcoming election for the union's presidency.

title: Reversing Course, Levi Strauss Will Expand Its Output in China
description: Five years after announcing that it would pull out of China because of what it called pervasive human rights violations, Levi Strauss & Company said today that it would expand its manufacturing in the country and start selling its clothing there.

title: Prime Minister Says China and Taiwan Should Cooperate to Help Asia : Taipei Doubts Japan's Ability to Lead
description: TAIPEI  CORRECTION PUBLISHED IN THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE DATED APRIL 10, 1995

title: Sports of The Times; Dinner Helps Relieve Masters Heartburn
description: THERE is no other gathering in sports quite like it -- what is known at the Masters as the ''champion's dinner.'' And after a year of heartburn for both Tiger Woods and Fuzzy Zoeller, the matter of the menu was finally digested.

title: A Revered Relic Stolen From France Is Going Home
description: For more than 1,200 years the story of young Maxellendis, a seventh-century Frankish noblewoman who preferred the pious life of a Roman Catholic nun to an arranged marriage to a pagan prince, has been part of the local lore in a string of small agricultural towns in northeastern France.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SONENCLAR, BERNICE
description: SONENCLAR-Bernice. Beloved wife of Joseph. Loving mother of Judy and Stanley Adelsheimer and Leslie and Larry Chalson. Cherished nana of Michael and Alan Levy, Maggie and Andrew Chalson, Erica and Toni Adelsheimer. We miss her already.

title: USA Networks Chief Quits In Wake of Its Acquisition
description: Kay Koplovitz, the founder, chairman and chief executive of USA Networks Inc., said today that she was leaving the cable television company. Barry Diller, whose HSN Inc. agreed to acquire USA Networks last October, is expected to assume direct control.

title: ATC COMMUNICATIONS BUYING IQI FOR $64.1 MILLION
description: The shares of ATC Communications Group Inc. jumped yesterday after the company agreed to buy the closely held IQI Inc. for about $64.1 million in stock, based on Tuesday's closing price. Shares in ATC, a Dallas-based telecommunications company, rose $1.3125, to $3.1875, in Nasdaq trading. IQI is a Los Angeles telecommunications company. The combined 1997 revenue of the two companies was about $250 million. The new company would have more than 8,000 employees, about 6,000 work stations and 21 call centers. ATC operates call centers for customer service and telemarketing for large companies.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about Tuesday's trading in the stock market misstated the regulatory status of a drug, tamoxifen, made by the Zeneca Group P.L.C. of Britain. (The drug was the subject of a study that helped drive up the company's American depository receipts on Monday; they retreated the next day.) Tamoxifen has been approved for use in breast cancer treatment in the United States since 1978; it has not been approved by the Food and Drug Administration for cancer prevention. The company has not decided whether it will seek Federal approval for such use.

description: Blue-chip stocks fell yesterday for a second day in a decline led by telephone, oil, drug and bank issues.

title: Lil's Lad Has Speed, Status, and Fast Foes
description: He is big and fast and seasoned, and he has finished first in all four races that he has run this year. He has the best jockey in the country, Jerry Bailey; he is trained by Neil Howard, who conditioned the renowned Summer Squall, and he is owned by a consortium headed by Will Farish, chairman of Churchill Downs and one of the aristocrats of racing.

title: Sweet Slips Of the Ear: Mondegreens
description: THERE is something consoling about Web pages that collect ''mondegreens.'' Sites featuring these often hilarious examples of misheard song lyrics offer proof, at last, that botching the words to popular songs is a nearly universal human failing. Rest assured: a quick glance through the lyrical mishaps to be found on such sites is sure to reveal a mondegreen far sillier than any you have sung in the shower.

title: Raising Obscurity to an Art, a Book Gives a Painter Undue Fame
description: Nat Tate was a brilliant but almost forgotten American artist of the mid-20th century whose greatest work, a series of drawings of bridges inspired by Hart Crane's famous poem ''The Bridge,'' was mostly lost when he committed suicide at the age of 31.

title: Exploring the Future, Without Going Out on a Limb
description: HOUSES of the Future are always good for a chuckle, retrospectively. The technology that promised to do revolutionary things -- the 1933 Century of Progress Exhibition's House of Tomorrow featured a residential airport hangar in place of a garage -- ricochets in another direction (you can't get much more earthbound than a Hummer) or turns out to be a dead end. (Remember jet-propelled backpacks and the domestic robot?)

title: Public Eye; A Lure Shines. Will the Fish Bite?
description: BEHOLD the Bunny People, those disco-loving, jumpsuit-wearing figures who have populated Intel's upbeat television commercials and print ads for computer hardware over the last few months. Clad in brightly colored iridescent bunny suits (the space-age get-ups worn by workers in ultra-clean computer chip factories), Intel's mascots are a hybrid of 2001 technology and Studio 54 glitz, of high tech and low culture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PASHMAN, RITA
description: PASHMAN-Rita. Loving wife of the late Benjamin, beloved mother of Sheila. Service at Gannon Funeral Home, 152 East 28th Street, NYC, 2 P.M. April 9th.

Graveside service at Knollwood Park Cemetery, Ridgewood, Queens, NY, 11AM, 718-386-6700. Donations to American Heart Association please, 800-242-8721.

title: Ruffled, Japan Advises U.S.: Mind Your Own Business
description: As a parade of American officials all the way up to President Clinton have told Japan how to fix its slumping economy, the Japanese have grown increasingly offended.

title: Hot Game in Bosnia: Where in the World Is Karadzic?
description: Radovan Karadzic, the Bosnian Serb wartime political leader who has roamed freely since being indicted on war-crimes charges in 1995, is under pressure from NATO forces and appears to have left his headquarters here. But how far he has gone is a matter of debate.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COPPER RALLIES. Copper rose a third day on news London Metal Exchange stockpiles had fallen to a three-and-a-half-month low because of higher demand. In New York, May contracts rose 0.55 cent, to 78.25 cents a pound.

title: Edsel Ford 2d To Leave Auto Maker
description: Edsel B. Ford 2d, the son and grandson of the men who built the Ford Motor Company into the world's second-largest auto maker, has decided to step down from his post as president of Ford's auto lending unit and will not take another executive position.

title: British Company Chosen To Run Stewart Airport
description: In what would be the nation's first privatization of a publicly owned airport, the Pataki administration announced yesterday that it intends to lease Stewart International Airport in New Windsor, N.Y., to a British company for 99 years.

title: IDT TO BUY INTEREXCHANGE FOR $120 MILLION
description: The IDT Corporation agreed yesterday to buy Interexchange, a closely held company in Piscataway, N.J., for about $120 million in cash and stock to build its telephone service operations in Latin America. IDT, a long-distance phone service company based in Hackensack, N.J., said the purchase of Interexchange would cut its costs and bolster earnings. IDT sells a variety of phone services, including prepaid calling cards and Internet calls. Its shares rose $3 each, to $35.0625, in Nasdaq trading. On March 31, IDT offered $125 million for Trescom International Inc., which also provides long-distance service to Latin America, but the offer was rejected.

title: Panel Set Up to Settle Insurance Claims of Holocaust Victims
description: An agreement to create a commission to settle insurance and annuity claims by Holocaust victims or their heirs was reached yesterday in New York by four major European life insurance companies, state insurance regulators and the representatives of two Jewish organizations.

title: Picket Line Halts Classes In a District In New Jersey
description: Striking teachers picketed this morning outside the 36 public schools here, halting classes and sending thousands of students home, after negotiations through Tuesday night failed to produce a contract agreement between their union and this city's state-operated school district.

title: Sanyo Shares Jump On a Buyback Plan
description: The stock of the Sanyo Electric Company jumped yesterday after the company, a Japanese maker of consumer electronics, said it would buy back up to 35 billion yen ($263 million) worth of its own shares. Sanyo Electric rose 23 yen, to 372, on trading of 3.43 million shares.

title: Investors Snap Up Korea Bonds in a Big Vote of Confidence
description: South Korea, financially destitute just four months ago, won an enormous vote of confidence from investors around the world yesterday with the successful sale of $4 billion in Government bonds.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLIS, SAUL
description: GELLIS-Saul. Devoted husband of Sherry. Loving father of Stuart, Richard and Andrew, and daughters-in-law Bonnie, Teresa and Yvette. Adored grandfather of Karen, Lauren, Jason, Isaac, Alec, and Alyse. Brother of the late Abe Gellis. Funeral service Thursday 12:30 PM, I.J. Morris, Hempstead.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today for the Muslim holiday Id al-Adha, the Feast of Sacrifice, and for Holy Thursday; tomorrow for Good Friday, and Saturday for the first day of Passover. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Lawmakers Say Budget Bills Could Be Completed Today
description: After the swiftest and most public budget negotiations in recent years, the Legislature began voting tonight on a state budget that officials say will triple spending on child care and will increase overall state spending by more than 7 percent.

title: James T. Pyle, 84, a Pioneer In Air Safety Systems, Is Dead
description: James T. Pyle, who got such a boyhood thrill from Charles A. Lindbergh's pioneering solo flight across the Atlantic that he devoted his life to aviation, died on April 1 at a hospital near his home in Oyster Bay, N.Y. He was 84 and had become something of a pioneer himself. As the first Deputy Federal Aviation Administrator, he was widely known as a father of modern air control systems.

description: To the Editor:

title: Seth R. Thomas, 56, Clockmaker's Scion
description: Seth R. Thomas, a sixth-generation descendant of a 19th-century clockmaker of the same name and himself a keeper of timepieces, died at the Cleveland Clinic on Monday. He was 56 and lived in Brecksville, Ohio, near Cleveland.

title: Douglas's Next Step: Savarese
description: The world's reaction to a James (Buster) Douglas-Lou Savarese heavyweight bout might be a big yawn. But for Douglas it is cause for celebration, because it will end an 11-month layoff from the ring and end the frustration of having two previous proposed bouts slip through his gloves.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOHNSON, MARCELLE
description: JOHNSON-Marcelle. 92. Allergy nursing pioneer and veteran. Memorial Services will be at St. Paul the Apostle Church, 59 St. & Ninth Avenue, Monday, April 20, 11 AM.

title: Taking Too Much Vitamin C Can Be Dangerous, Study Finds
description: Those who think that if a little vitamin C is good, more must be better should think again, says a team of British researchers, who found that a supplement of 500 milligrams a day could damage people's genes.

title: Measure to Ban Some Abortions Fails to Reach Floor of Assembly
description: The State Assembly tonight voted narrowly to block a broad measure to ban a form of abortion that has been the focus of fierce debate in Congress and in state legislatures around the nation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUFF, CARL N.
description: RUFF-Carl N., 84. Died on April 7, 1998. He is survived by his wife Edith Jordan Brener Ruff, his daughter Carla Ruff and his son Charles Ruff, his granddaughters Carin Ruff, Christina Wagner and Eliza Strauss, his nephews Clark Ruff and Todd Ruff, and Edith's son, Thomas Brener, and daughter, Jordan Brener. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests a contribution to the East Harlem Tutorial Program, 2050 Second Avenue, New York, New York 10029, or Planned Parenthood. A memorial service is planned.

title: CIGARETTE MAKERS QUIT NEGOTIATIONS ON TOBACCO BILL
description: The leading American cigarette manufacturers said today that they would no longer work for comprehensive legislation to regulate tobacco because Congress was moving in such an unfavorable direction.

title: In Second Stint, Goneau Uses Different Language
description: Back for a second stint with the Rangers, Daniel Goneau feels he is older and wiser at the age of 22, less likely to commit the sort of linguistic faux pas that delayed his career last season. In seven games since being called up from Hartford of the American Hockey League, Goneau has two goals. The left wing from Montreal is getting a long look from Coach John Muckler, who is auditioning young players for next season's team.

title: It's Confirmed: Web's Size Bogs Down Searches
description: FOR anyone who believes that despite all those search engines, the Internet has grown into an uncontrollable, unwieldy, amorphous mass, computer scientists have a study with one message: You're right. They asked two simple questions: How big is the Internet? And how much of the Internet is covered by search engines? The numbers they came up with suggest that the answers are ''huge'' and ''not much.''

title: Augusta Story Lines May Create Modern Classic
description: It is already one of the most compelling events in sports, but this year's Masters has the potential to be a classic.

title: Have You Listened to Your Computer Lately?
description: VERY early one recent morning, Rob Gibson was having a hankering for home. For almost a month Mr. Gibson, the executive producer and director of Jazz at Lincoln Center, had been far away from New York on tour with the center's celebrated jazz orchestra. After a concert, he found himself sitting in his hotel room in Adelaide, a coastal town in southwestern Australia, reading E-mail on his laptop computer.

title: A Switch? Many Mac Fans Say 'No'
description: The New York Times received more than 150 letters from readers -- nearly all from outraged Mac fans -- in response to ''Clan Macintosh Feels the Pain'' (April 2). Here are a few of them:

title: Horse and Blender, Car and Crockpot
description: IN AMISH communities in Lancaster County, Pa., technological choice is a matter both grand and trivial. The pursuit of simplicity has deep spiritual meaning. And yet the working out of theology in practice can seem contradictory to the larger culture.

title: Johnson & Johnson Realigns TV Buying
description: Johnson & Johnson in New Brunswick, N.J., has consolidated responsibilities for national television buying by naming McCann-Erickson New York as agency of record for network, cable and syndicated TV. Johnson & Johnson spends an estimated $568 million annually on national TV ads.

title: Safer Skies
description: The National Transportation Safety Board's recommendations for minimizing the risk of a fuel tank explosion similar to the T.W.A. Flight 800 tragedy would expand the depth and reach of corrective measures undertaken by Boeing and the Federal Aviation Administration. For the first time the safety board has asked the F.A.A. to require the inspection of wiring, replacement of damaged wiring and related equipment changes in thousands of aircraft built by Boeing and other manufacturers, not just the older Boeing 747's.

title: Chicago and Nashville Get New Teams
description: The women's American Basketball League, down to eight teams after the Atlanta Glory folded because of disappointing attendance, added a team in Chicago yesterday and will add one in Nashville today.

title: $76 Million for Man Shot by the Police
description: In one of the largest police brutality judgments rendered against New York City, a Bronx jury awarded $76.4 million in damages yesterday to a 33-year-old man who was shot by a police officer in 1988.

title: TV's Tastelessness Is Only Half of Story; Throw Out the Tube
description: To the Editor:

title: In America; The Dream Ignored
description: The recent tributes to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. have been folded and put away. They'll be hauled out again 20 years from now on the 50th anniversary of his death.

title: A Clangor To Awaken A World Of Spirits
description: In a small courtyard tucked away in a neighborhood here called Libertade, a cultural exchange was under way as part of the fifth annual Panorama Percussivo Mundial festival. The courtyard is at the headquarters of Ile-Aiye, a combination of a carnival band, drum school and community association; it's called a bloco afro, because one of its missions is to celebrate the African heritage of Salvador, the capital of the state of Bahia.

title: New Warning Label Order for Sport Vehicles
description: The Government will propose on Thursday that bright cartoonlike labels be required in smaller sport utility vehicles, warning that the vehicles can tip over and kill the occupants.

title: G.E. Earnings Climb 12.5% In Quarter;
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that its earnings rose 12.5 percent in the first quarter as the company's efforts to cut costs and to find new markets apparently continued to pay off.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WIENER, GABE
description: WIENER-Gabe. Gaber, you will always be with us. We hold you close each day with great love. M, D, and J.

title: Wilson to Get Elbow Test
description: Although rain washed away the Mets' scheduled game with the Cubs at Wrigley Field this afternoon, at least there was the certainty that they would be playing sometime soon, even though the forecast called for more rain Thursday.

title: Currents; CRAFTS -- The Skyline in Swirls
description: Way beyond the typical craft fair, the Sculpture Objects Functional Art show, known as Sofa, runs from today through Sunday at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue at 67th Street. Show stoppers include Lino Tagliapietra's ''Manhattan,'' left, a grouping of swirly-striped glass pieces that sold this week to the International Museum of Glass, being built in Tacoma, Wash. Pieces by Mr. Tagliapietra run $14,000 and up. Work by Czech glass artists is also well represented. Admission, $10. Hours: today through Saturday, 11 A.M. to 8 P.M.; Sunday, noon to 6 P.M.

title: Currents; FABRICS -- In Remembrance Of the King
description: The classic window fabric called Royal Monkeys is a comment not on current politics but on a French king with bad luck. Hint: He lost his head. The raised pattern (velvet over a translucent or sheer ground of cotton batiste) shows Louis XVI as the lion king surrounded by royal monkeys, temples and garlands. Based on an old design at the Louvre, the fabric ($253 a yard) is from Yves Gonnet Textiles in France, available to the trade through Blumenthal, 979 Third Avenue (58th Street); (212) 752-2535.

title: YOUNG & RUBICAM OFFERS DETAILS OF PUBLIC OFFERING
description: Young & Rubicam Inc., the world's fifth-largest advertising agency company, dislosed details of its planned initial public offering yesterday. In papers filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said it planned to sell 16.16 million shares -- or about 25 percent of the company -- at $21 to $24 apiece. Such a price range would give the company, with billings estimated at $12 billion, a market value of between $1.4 billion and $1.6 billion. The long-awaited I.P.O. was announced in late February, but did not include details of the size or price range. The offering is expected to be priced sometime next month. Y.& R. plans to use the proceeds from the I.P.O. to repay a portion of its bank debt.

title: When Rock Was Young And Prey To Wolves
description: The English film ''Mojo'' revisits the dawn of rock-and-roll mass hysteria, but this is no nostalgic homage to the Mersey beat. While the film's would-be Elvis gyrates in a Soho club called Ezra's Atlantic, the most important rhythm to be felt is that of money rolling in. Dark-suited, middle-aged businessmen stand ready to capitalize on teen-age phenomena, privately excited by all the hot-blooded young potential they see. ''Tickle, tickle,'' says Harold Pinter, as a suave, predatory gangster with his eye on a helpless young rocker.

title: Brokerage Settles Lawsuit On Racial and Sexual Bias
description: A brokerage house has agreed to pay $1.75 million to settle a Government lawsuit in which top managers were accused of sexually harassing female workers and discriminating against women and blacks in raises and promotions, a Federal agency said yesterday.

title: Rail Link Is Planned To Pennsylvania Station
description: Officials of New Jersey Transit announced plans yesterday for a direct commuter rail link from Morris, Passaic and Essex Counties to Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan.

title: 'Documentary' Within a Film
description: For a tightly budgeted film about a small and overlooked segment of the population, Cheryl Dunye's acclaimed ''Watermelon Woman,'' to be released on tape on Tuesday by First Run Features, is unusually well traveled on the festival and theater circuits. Not to mention the flap in Washington.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Lindbergh Flies, Author Learns

title: RICHFOOD AGREES TO BUY DART GROUP FOR $207 MILLION
description: Richfood Holdings Inc. said it had agreed to acquire the Dart Group Corporation, which came to prominence under the Haft family, for $160 a share, a total of $207 million. Dart shares jumped past the offer price, gaining $23.50, to $163.50. Richfood rose 87.50 cents, to $28.6875. Richfood, based in Richmond, is a wholesale distributor and supermarket operator. Dart, based in Landover, Md., consists of the Shoppers Food Warehouse supermarket chain as well as majority stakes in Trak Auto, a parts retailer; Crown Books, a bookstore chain, and Total Beverage, a retailer. Richfood said it had bought Dart Group primarily for Shoppers Food; it plans to divest itself of other Dart assets.

title: FILM IN REVIEW
description: 'Three Ninjas'

title: Union Pacific to Ease Its Mexican Embargo
description: The Union Pacific Corporation's railroad unit said today that it would ease its partial freight embargo of Mexico on Tuesday after two weeks because a backup of southbound shipments had eased.

title: Swap of Cable TV Systems
description: Time Warner Inc. and the Cablevision Systems Corporation have agreed to swap cable television systems in the Northeast. Time Warner will exchange its system in Litchfield, Conn., for Cablevision's system in Rensselaer, N.Y., plus cash. Cablevision said the deal was part of its plan to concentrate its system in geographic clusters.

title: Dutch Company to Take A Charge for Revamping
description: Royal PTT Nederland N.V., the Dutch telecommunications and mail company, said yesterday that it expected to take a reorganization charge this year of 500 to 800 million guilders ($245 million to $390 million), and that profit before the charge would be slightly higher than in 1997. Shares fell after the disclosure of the charge even as PTT posted a 9.3 percent increase in 1997 net income to 2.69 billion guilders, in line with preliminary figures reported last month.

title: LEAR CORP. TO BUY TWO ITALIAN MAKERS OF DOOR PANELS
description: The Lear Corporation, the automotive parts maker based in Southfield, Mich., agreed yesterday to buy two closely held Italian makers of automobile door panels and overhead liners for an undisclosed amount of cash. The acquisitions of Gruppo Pianfei and Strapazzini Resine, Lear's latest expansion in Europe, are expected to help Lear's business with the Italian auto maker Fiat. Pianfei, Europe's 10th-largest independent door panel supplier and the No. 5 seller of overhead systems, and Strapazzini had $130 million in combined revenue in 1997. Lear shares rose $1.375, to $56.375. Gruppo Pianfei employs 870 workers in six plants throughout Italy. Strapazzini Resine, with headquarters in Pesaro, has 200 workers in two plants.

title: Merger or No, The Umbrella Still Glows
description: IT is understandable that a corporation in the thick of merger negotiations worth a mind-numbing $70 billion-plus might not feel it has time for distractions like neighbors with a grievance.

title: A Jailing That Starts Bleak And Gets Much Worse
description: ''Anadarko'' is one nasty piece of work. In it, the playwright Tim Blake Nelson, author of the concentration-camp drama ''The Grey Zone,'' returns to a favorite theme, the terror of a confined space. Only this time the space is an Oklahoma jail where bizarre events are always on the daily roster.

title: Justice Dept. Wants Inquiry Into Anti-Clinton Witness
description: The Justice Department told Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater prosecutor, today that one of his principal witnesses against President Clinton should be investigated to determine whether he was tainted by payments from Clinton opponents.

title: Ousted Adelphi Leaders Lose Preliminary Rulings
description: A year after New York State removed Adelphi University's president and trustees, contending that they had mismanaged the school's affairs, the former officials have lost three preliminary rulings in lawsuits stemming from their ouster. All three rulings, filed yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, were handed down by Justice Charles Edward Ramos.

title: Cantor's Widow Wins Judgment
description: Cantor Fitzgerald L.P. must pay Iris Cantor, the widow of the securities firm's founder, more than $4.6 million to cover taxes and other expenses she paid when the brokerage firm acquired her holding company, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JESSELSON, LUDWIG
description: JESSELSON-Ludwig. On the occasion of the fifth yahrzeit of Ludwig Jesselson, of blessed memory, we remember this extraordinary and humble man whose very being radiated kindness, dignity and modesty. A captain of industry, he viewed his charitable activities, undertaken with his wife and partner Erica, as strengthening the future of Israel and K'lal Yisrael. Surely his leadership and patronage of so many vital organizations helped to shape the history of the Jewish People in our generation. As a devoted benefactor and friend of Shaare Zedek Medical Center, Luddy was a true visionary and leader par excellence. Together with Erica, they made the dream of a comprehensive heart institute a reality. The Jesselson Heart Center has developed an international reputation for state-of-the-art medical excellence and compassionate care. As the beneficiaries of his wise counsel and guidance we miss him dearly. American Committee and International Board of Governors Shaare Zedek Medical Center in Jerusalem

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MYERS, ALLEN MURRAY
description: MYERS-Allen Murray. Dear brother-in-law and uncle of Annabelle, David and Benjamin. Fondly remembered and sadly missed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINLAY, REV. TERENCE JOHN, D.D.
description: FINLAY-Rev. Terence John, D.D. Died peacefully in his sleep in his 92nd year, April 8, 1998 at Maplecrest Village, Grimsby, Ontario. Beloved husband of the late Sara McBryan Finlay; adored father of Terry (Alice-Jean) and Bryan (Carol); much loved grandfather of Sara-Jane and Rebecca, Molly and Charles; will also be sorely missed by his sister Kathleen and his brother Patrick. He served his Lord faithfully in the Anglican Church in London, Ontario, then as Rector of Holy Trinity, Winnipeg; St. John the Evangelist, Ottawa, and St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, New York City. A Service of Thanksgiving and Celebration of his life will be held Monday, April 13, 1998 at 2PM, St. Andrew's Anglican Church, Grimsby, Ontario. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his name to St. Andrew's Anglican Church, 154 Main Street West, Grimsby, Ontario L3M-1S3. Christ is Risen. The Lord is risen indeed. Alleluia!

title: Lives Redeemed in the Boxing Ring
description: Shane Meadows's ''Twentyfour seven'' is a study in contrasts, and not only because it has been shot by Ashley Rowe in especially handsome black and white. Such cinematography gives an air of gravity to Mr. Meadows's ambitious first feature, but the mood doesn't always suit the material. By turns antic, tumultuous and maudlin, this story of aimless urban youth and a saintly boxing coach (Bob Hoskins) is as uneven as it is inventive. Mr. Meadows's striking, versatile direction is often more daring than his story (written with Paul Fraser) warrants.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-10

title: BOEING TO TAKE ADDITIONAL $350 MILLION CHARGE
description: The Boeing Company, which has already cited production problems for $2.6 billion in charges, said yesterday that it would take an additional pretax charge of $350 million in the first quarter for its 737 jetliner and that it might have to take further charges for it later. Boeing said it expected pretax earnings, before the charge, of $400 million to $450 million. The first-quarter charge, which is larger than expected, shows that the company is still having a hard time assessing its problems as it aims to double production in 18 months and introduce new 737 models. Boeing shares declined 6.25 cents, to $55.1875.

title: Tenure Is Not Enough
description: A few days ago, Harvard students went to their beds secure in the knowledge that Robert J. Barro, the esteemed Robert C. Waggoner Professor of Economics, would be there when they woke up. Little did they know that as they slept, Columbia University's Board of Overseers had hatched a devious scheme to lure their beloved economist away.

title: Experts Dispute Iraq On Germ Weapons
description: Independent experts who reviewed Iraq's progress in eliminating biological weapons at Baghdad's request have rejected President Saddam Hussein's contention that he no longer has a germ warfare program.

title: WEEKEND WARRIOR; Forget the Rec Room! We're Talking Some Tough Table Tennis
description: For me, Ping-Pong is a family affair -- me against my father-in-law, mano a mano in his New Hampshire basement. The handicapping: I'm 30 years younger, the proud owner of a $30 Butterfly foam paddle, and I play once, maybe twice, a year. He uses a chewed-up hard rubber paddle that came with the table, plays a couple of times a week down at the church and knows just how to take advantage of the watermelon stain on my side of the table.

title: On My Mind; The Missile Business
description: ''I, WILLIAM J. CLINTON, President of the United States of America, find that the proliferation of nuclear, biological and chemical weapons ('weapons of mass destruction') and of the means of delivering such weapons, constitutes an unusual and extraordinary threat to the national security, foreign policy and economy of the United States, and hereby declare a national emergency to deal with that threat.''

title: City Taxi Industry Starts Conversion to Natural Gas
description: When state officials teamed up with New York City and two private companies to devise financial incentives to sell a new natural-gas-powered taxi, Winner's Garage in Queens did not miss a beat. It bought 100 of the Ford vehicles, replacing its entire fleet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KESTENBAUM, SIDNEY
description: KESTENBAUM-Sidney. Beloved husband of Ann. Devoted father of Sherri Keiler-Lane and Marilyn Zinovoy. Dear brother of Malka Horowitz. Adored grandfather of Stacey, David, Sandy and Scott. Services on Friday 11:30 A.M., at ''Gutterman's'', 98-60 Queens Boulevard corner 66 Ave (Parkside Building), Forest Hills.

title: Play Ball! Now Where Are All the Teams?
description: Signs in store windows here say that people in this economically troubled old city are ''Hooked on the Bluefish,'' a new minor league baseball franchise. Bluefish hats and T-shirts -- the logo features a tough-looking fish with a bat -- are for sale downtown. A new $15 million stadium, paid for by the city and the state, is under construction on Main Street, which has been rerouted to make the ball park an urban centerpiece.

title: Anomie's Insidious Grip On Suburban Affluence
description: Could middle-class suburban life be as empty and soulless as it is portrayed in Gary Burns's scathingly funny satire ''Kitchen Party?'' The dialogue, especially the aimless, hostile banter among a group of teen-agers guzzling beer in a suburban kitchen, is so dead-on it convinces you that contemporary suburbia just might be a sprawling, sterile anteroom to hell itself.

title: 'Cabaret' and 'Side Show' Win Tony Rulings
description: The Tony Administration Committee voted yesterday afternoon to allow the Roundabout Theater Company's revival of ''Cabaret'' to compete as a Broadway show in this year's awards, even though it is being performed in a converted nightclub.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEET, GLEN
description: LEET-Glen. All of us who have worked with the Trickle Up Program and have had the privilege of having known Glen Leet deeply mourn his death. Together with his wife Mildred Robbins Leet, he created and tested the wonderful poverty alleviation program that is Trickle Up. He guided and steered the program from ten businesses in 1979 to more than 68,000 in 1998. Glen delighted in the stories of the changed lives as a result of the Trickle Up process and pioneered the use of computers to track the businesses and their successes. Until the last weeks of his life, he worked hard to help the truly impoverished of our world. He looked to the day when the ranks of the pool would be lessened. Together with Mildred Robbins Leet, we, the staff he so carefully trained, encouraged and nurtured, are pledged to see to it that this day comes soon. A memorial service will be held Friday, May 15, 1998 at 12 Noon at the United Nations Church Center, 777 U.N. Plaza, (1st Ave and 44 Street) NYC. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to the Trickle Up Program, 121 West 27 Street, NY, NY 10001. The Staff of the Trickle Up Program

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILMAN, MARVIN S.
description: GILMAN-Marvin S. On April 7, 1998. Husband of Muriel Gilman; father of Peter Gilman and Martha Smith; brother of Bertrand Gilman. Also survived by six grandsons. Relatives and friends are invited to attend funeral services at 11 AM, Friday, April 10, 1998 from Arsht Hall of the Wilmington (DE) Campus of the University of Delaware. Interment in Jewish Community Cemetery, Wilm., DE. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions to Marvin S. Gilman/National Housing Endowment Scholarship, c/o The College of Human Resources, Education, and Public Policy, University of Delaware, Newark, DE. 19716.

title: 'Partial-Birth' Abortion
description: the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about the art dealer and gallery owner Frank Lloyd misspelled the title inherited by an employee in his first gallery, in London. The employee, David Somerset, later became Duke of Beaufort, not Beauford.

title: JAPANESE PROPOSE A $75 BILLION PLAN TO SPUR ECONOMY
description: Under pressure from foreign leaders, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto on Thursday proposed Japan's largest package yet of tax cuts and new spending in an effort to reverse an economic decline that could have ripple effects on other economies around the world.

title: Air Jamaica's American Problem; A Small Airline Holds Its Own Against a Much Bigger Rival
description: In 1993, American Airlines gave Gordon Stewart, owner of 10 Caribbean resorts and this island's most celebrated entrepreneur, an award for his contribution to developing tourism in the region.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: ''How is it?'' asks A. Jay Shaffer, running around his new restaurant with the manic energy of a first-time owner. He's peering at your lobster cocktail, wondering if your halibut is all right, worrying over your fried oysters.

title: FAMILY FARE
description: Exotic Eggs, Even of Emus

description: Big Business And a Big Deal

title: Rome Journal; Pope's Little Army Scrambles to Recruit a Chief
description: Wanted: Swiss gentleman with military experience to lead the world's smallest army. Must be 5 feet 9 or over and Roman Catholic. Should be noble.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYKO, JEFFREY A.
description: BOYKO-Jeffrey A. Your direction, guidance, strength and inspiration formed our company. You were the builder and our leader. You have left a legacy of accomplishments. You will always be a large part of us-what we are and who we are. We will do our best without you. You will be missed. Our love and deepest sympathy to Leslie and Alexander. Staff, Silbo Industries

title: Tighter Rules On Deporting State Inmates
description: Responding to criticism on an issue that could loom over Gov. George E. Pataki's re-election campaign, state officials announced new restrictions today on a program that speeds up deportation of illegal immigrants convicted of nonviolent crimes. Many of the inmates have been released long before completing their minimum prison sentences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRANT, MICHAEL J.
description: GRANT-Michael J. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Michael J. Grant, a Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Cronin, President Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: Conair Buys Waring Unit
description: The CTS Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell its Waring Products division to the Conair Corporation, a New York consumer appliances company. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed. Waring, a consumer appliances company, is a division of the Dynamics Corporation of America, a unit of CTS. The sale is part of CTS's integration of Dynamics, which the company acquired in October. CTS, an Elkhart, Ind., manufacturer of electronic components, said it would continue to review its other assets that do not fit its business strategy.

title: Eleanor C. Lambertsen, 82; Introduced Use of Nurse Teams
description: Eleanor C. Lambertsen, a leader in American nursing education who introduced the concept of team nursing for better patient care, died on March 30 at Waverly Heights, a nursing home in Gladwyne, Pa. She was 82 and a former resident of the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: A Recital of American Works, With Copland at the Core
description: Sara Laimon, the pianist in the new music ensemble Musicians Accord and a member of the piano faculty at Yale, played a compelling recital of American works on Tuesday evening at the Miller Theater. The program, in which a handful of works composed since 1985 were balanced against Aaron Copland's 1957 Piano Fantasy, showed Ms. Laimon to be a commanding and confident player with a strong technique and an ability to find the drama and wit in works that often had daunting surfaces.

title: N.F.L. Council Upholds The Jets' Deal With Martin
description: The National Football League's Management Council decided yesterday that there was no evidence of collusion between the Jets and Curtis Martin.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEBAN, ADA
description: LEBAN-Ada. On April 8, 1998 in Wilmington, DE. Leaves loving son and daughter-in-law Abbott and Janet Leban of Wilmington, and grandchildren, Alexandra Leban, of San Francisco, Joanna Leban of NY, NY, sisters and brother Claire Levinson, San Rafael, CA and Ruth Keller and Irving Grossman, Sacramento, CA., aunt of Helen Domin of New York City, and nephews Alan Stein, Warren Levinson, Victor Levinson, and George Grossman. Services 12:15PM, April 12, 1998 at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave., New York City. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to The Kutz Home, 704 River Road, Wilmington, DE 19809.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  YIAVASIS, ANTHONY ANESTIS, M.D.
description: YIAVASIS-Anthony Anestis, M.D. ''I love you more than yesterday and less than tomorrow.''-20th year. Hillary

title: Britain and the Irish, North and South, Work Toward Ulster Accord
description: Negotiators in the Northern Ireland peace talks missed their midnight deadline for a settlement but worked feverishly into the morning hours.

title: France Agrees to Sale Of More of Bank's Assets
description: Bowing to pressure from the European Union, France will double the amount of assets that Credit Lyonnais, the state-owned bank, must sell to gain approval of a 100-billion-franc ($16.6 billion) Government bailout. The French Finance Minister, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, said yesterday that the Government had agreed to the sale of the larger amount of assets but would allow no more than that. Neither the bank nor the European Union has ever put a figure on the amount of assets that must be sold.

title: A Sip of the Time Before Parenthood
description: ''I feel like I'm backpacking,'' my wife, Cynthia, said, zipping closed the single suitcase at the foot of our bed. In our years as parents, years of family vacations, we had usually traveled with enough luggage, diapers, crib liners, stuffed animals and bedtime books to strain a forklift. Now, incongruously, we were packing just for ourselves, and for our first night sans children since our son, Aaron, had been born 5 years, 11 months and 23 days earlier.

title: Foreman Says Race Split Jurors in L.I. Beating Trial
description: Roosevelt Price was glad to be back at home today eating home-cooked meals, but his mind and emotions were still back at the Suffolk County Courthouse, where he and 11 other jurors failed to reach agreement on Wednesday on whether a white man from Queens nearly bludgeoned a young black man to death two years ago.

title: ON STAGE AND OFF
description: Hardly Time To Warm a Seat

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  LIPSYTE, MARJORIE
description: LIPSYTE-Marjorie. April 10, 1932-Oct 28, 1996. We love you and miss you. Sam and Susannah

title: Conquests on Canvas: Picasso in the Flesh, de Kooning in Spirit
description: On the subject of women, few 20th-century painters have declared themselves with such fervor as Pablo Picasso (1881-1973) and Willem de Kooning (1904-1997). Each wrestled the theme with a passion that amounted to obsession. While particular women inspired Picasso, de Kooning's muses could not be named. Picasso's imagery was personal; it changed with each new lover. De Kooning's had a constancy fed by classical goddess motifs. Yet inevitably de Kooning came under Picasso's influence. Few avant-garde artists born after 1900 escaped it.

title: Coalition Seeks to Oust Officer Accused of Slur
description: A coalition of civic and religious leaders called yesterday for the dismissal of a Springfield police officer who is accused of using anti-Semitic language in a taped telephone call made to police headquarters last month.

title: Disabled and Jobless
description: To the Editor:

title: Romanian Confesses to Role In a Religious Artifact Ring
description: NEWARK, New Jersey  A Romanian citizen living in the United States admitted in court this week that he was part of a ring that had stolen religious artifacts from France and that he was trying to sell them in the United States, federal officials said.

title: U.N., Stymied by Congo Leader, Halts Inquiry on Rwanda Killings
description: The United Nations today suspended its investigation into allegations of massacres of Rwandan refugees in Congo, after weeks of harassment and the detention this week of a Canadian member of the team.

description: To the Editor:

description: The Ice Storm

title: Jury Awards Two Brothers $105 Million
description: Not realizing the water was just five feet deep, Virgil and John Brown dove off a pier at Coney Island in 1992 and paid for their mistake with paralysis. Yesterday, a Brooklyn jury decided New York City should have warned the brothers and must pay them $104.7 million.

title: Anchoring Piano to Orchestra in a Battle With Brahms
description: Andras Schiff's extended visit to New York has been presented like a resume. Mr. Schiff, in other words, wants us to know that he is a pianist of many musical parts. At a number of New York Philharmonic events and on his own, he has been ticking off assets ranging from delicacy in Scarlatti sonatas, collegiality in Schumann lieder and mightiness in Brahms concertos. There have been master classes and forums; little musical has been left undone.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  CERTNER, JOEL
description: CERTNER-Joel. In loving memory of our beloved Joel, killed 32 years today. Mother, Naomi and Jerry

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HECKER, HENRY
description: HECKER-Henry. The Officers and Staff of Israel Bonds mourn the untimely passing of our dear friend and beloved colleague, Henry Hecker. His warmth, integrity and sweet nature touched us all. We will miss him deeply. May his memory be blessed. Our sympathy to his family. Gideon Patt, President & CEO Burton P. Resnick, Chairman of the Board

title: Kelly Michener Wins 5 New Accounts
description: Kelly Michener Inc. in Lancaster, Pa., said yesterday that it had been awarded five accounts that will increase billings by more than 50 percent to an estimated $22 million.

title: Sports of The Times; 'Which Way Is the Wind Blowing?'
description: YOU could hear the wind. Hear it blowing through the swaying boughs high on the loblolly pines. Hear Augusta National's yellow flags flapping on each green. Hear the golfers' slacks rippling as they waited for the wind to lessen. Even on the greens.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 12.

description: 'Stolen Moments'

title: Alou Doesn't Even Have Smoke and Mirrors
description: When the Yankees cut the ribbon on their home season today, Joe Torre's biggest worry will be which multimillionaires to position in the limited positions provided him. Payrolls of $63 million do have their inconveniences.

title: Make Your Own Tradition: Redefining Seders for Today
description: Thematically, Tuesday night's pre-Passover seder with the Tibetan monks held up poignantly well, resonating with passages about slavery, diaspora and the return to a promised land.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRSHENBERG, MIRIAM
description: KIRSHENBERG - Miriam. Dear Jerry, Howard, Robert, and Jill, grandchildren, Zoe, Aaron. Our deepest sympathies to the entire family. We loved Miriam. Connie and Eddie Katz and Family

title: Clinton, Visiting Tobacco Country, Tries to Win Over Farmers on Legislation
description: President Clinton vowed today that he would continue to fight for tobacco legislation despite the intransigence of the cigarette manufacturers, and he promised the residents of this tobacco-growing community that their livelihoods would not be threatened by the bill.

title: The Sea Turtle's Warning
description: Conservationists were rightly angry when the World Trade Organization ruled on Monday that the United States had violated international trade agreements by prohibiting shrimp imports from countries whose boats trap and kill endangered sea turtles. Yet anger is at best a temporary response to a much larger problem. Although the trade organization is required by its charter to pay attention to environmental values, its central mission is to promote free and fair trade. When the two conflict, trade tends to win and the species lose.

title: CANADIAN COMPANY TO BUY REFRIGERATED STORAGE IN U.S.
description: Associated Freezers Ltd., a Canadian operator of refrigerated warehouses, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the assets of a company in the United States for $42 million. It said the company, whose name was not disclosed, operated 15 million cubic feet of public refrigerated warehouse space. The acquisition will increase Associated Freezers' public refrigerated warehouse space by more than 40 percent, to 52 million cubic feet, the company said. Associated Freezers operates warehouses in central and eastern Canada. It is a unit of Associated Freezer Income Trust, based in Toronto.

On Wednesday, RJR Nabisco announced that it would no longer take part in Congressional efforts to draft tough new tobacco legislation, and would oppose a bill by Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican, that enjoys bipartisan support. The other big companies quickly lined up behind RJR. Good for them. Making Big Tobacco seem like a sympathetic victim takes some doing, but Congress has managed it.

The Democrats seek to regulate managed-care plans that deny their members adequate care. Though each proposal is flawed, neither is extreme. There is room to find common ground.

description: New York City's Schools Chancellor, Rudy Crew, made the right decision to take over the Michael J. Petrides School on Staten Island. He has removed the principal, Gregory Gallo, and installed an interim principal to restore community confidence shattered by gross mismanagement of the school's admissions lottery. He should also take action against superintendent Christy Cugini of District 31, which covers Staten Island, for failing to monitor the admissions process more closely.

title: How Do You Say 'Take It Easy, Big Guy' in Romanian?
description: ''My Giant'' is not the feature-length sight gag that might be expected. Though Billy Crystal, as a hustling talent agent named Sammy, barely comes up to the armpit of the 7-foot-7-inch title character (Gheorghe Muresan), the film's odd-couple jokes are relatively scarce. Instead, this is a more sentimental story in which two characters meet, go on the road together and become better and wiser in the process. The actors are easygoing and likable, but the road they travel is awfully familiar.

title: No Rest for the Weary In a World of Violence
description: Near the end of ''Sonatine,'' Takeshi Kitano's haunting elegy to the gangster way of life, an assassin's sidekick crouches in the driveway of a hotel in the middle of the night and gazes up at a window that is suddenly lighted by repeated orange flashes and muffled popping sounds. What's happening in the room isn't a photo shoot or a fireworks demonstration. It's a brutal mass execution carried out with automatic weapons.

title: OFFER FOR BELL SPORTS IS LOWERED BY 25 CENTS A SHARE

The amended deal is valued at about $163.75 million, based on 13.9 million common shares outstanding and 2.2 million shares issuable. The acquirers will also assume $86.25 million in debt. In February a Pennsylvania jury ordered Bell Sports to pay $6.8 million to a motorcyclist who had sued the company over a defective helmet. HB Acquisition was formed by the investment funds Harvard Private Capital Holdings Inc. and Brentwood Associates Buyout Fund II L.P. Bell Sports shares rose $1.34375, to $9.59375.

Unova, an industrial technology company in Beverly Hills, Calif., had revenue of $1.43 billion in 1997. Amtech, based in Dallas, makes wireless identification and electronic security management systems and software. In 1997, it lost $17.7 million on revenue of $117.7 million. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WING, ARTHUR KYLE, JR.
description: WING-Arthur Kyle, Jr. Of Lenox, MA, an authority in early power and microwave tube technology, died on April 8th, 1998, at the Sweetbrook Nursing Center in Williamstown, MA. He was 89. A native of Brooklyn, New York, he worked in vacuum tube research and development for Federal Telephone and Telegraph and RCA in the 1930s and during World War II. In 1944 he joined International Telephone and Telegraph Laboratories (ITTL) and retired in 1972 as vice-president of engineering, ITT Electron Tube Division. During his career with ITT he developed a large number of special purpose and microwave vacuum tubes. He was the holder of eleven patents on vacuum tube design and authored several articles in scientific and technical journals. In 1984 he was a recipient of the centennial medal for extraordinary achievement from the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers. Born on July 1, 1908, he graduated from Phillips Exeter Academy and Yale University's Sheffield Scientific School, Class of 1930. He received an M.S. in electrical engineering from MIT in 1931. He is survived by his wife of 66 years, Phebe Adams Wing, of Lenox; a son Arthur K. Wing, III of Suffern, NY and a daughter, Delight Wing Dodyk of Ridgewood, NJ; five grandchildren, and two great-grandchildren.

title: Myths Made Potent Through Stylistic Somersaults
description: Pop music has so thoroughly permeated the cultural soil that high-minded young composers who turn their backs on pop nowadays risk narrowing their focus into a kind of musical tunnel vision. At the same time, serious composers who embrace pop often end up creating diluted pop-classical pastiches. But a few songwriters, including the brilliant young theater composer Adam Guettel, are finding ways to reconcile the best of both worlds. And in ''Saturn Returns,'' Mr. Guettel's majestic, sprawling song cycle at the Public Theater, he has created a kaleidoscopically heady musical-theater piece in which Gabriel Faure meets Stevie Wonder, Caetano Veloso embraces Earth, Wind and Fire, and they all dance together around the tribal hearth.

title: DOZENS ARE DEAD AS TORNADOES HIT SOUTHERN STATES
description: Amid a scene of devastation that some survivors described as ''like the end of the world,'' frantic rescue workers hacked through splintered trees and clawed through ruined houses in the South today, searching for survivors from tornadoes that left roadsides littered with bodies, whole communities destroyed and at least 38 people dead.

title: Heaven, He's From Heaven, But His Heart Beats So . . .
description: All the elements of a blockbuster Hollywood sobfest are sumptuously laid out in ''City of Angels,'' a film that wants desperately to outdo ''Ghost'' and ''Titanic'' in the love-from-beyond-the-grave movie sweepstakes. Adapted from Wim Wenders's 1987 poetic cult film, ''Wings of Desire,'' ''City of Angels'' tells the story of a droopy sad-sack angel who falls in love with a mortal and in a supernatural leap of faith turns himself into a human who can taste, smell, bleed and, of course, die.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRATT, JOHN T.
description: PRATT-John T. Born in Harlem, NY, in 1940, died on April 8, 1998 from complications, arising from lung cancer in Miami, FL. He is survived by his loving wife and partner of twenty-three years, Marie Adele Lee and his six children, John, James, Christine, Jerome, Joseph and Jermamine and foster son, Bernard Manson and his 12 grandchildren, Jelani, Ayana, Amina, Phillip, Nicholas, Sasha, Lauren, Imani, Ian, Sade, Andre and Kate. He is also survived by the extensive work he did for decades in community and human development in the Farragut/Fort Greene, South Bronx and Harlem communities in New York, institutionalizing bank community development outreach and financing prototypes in the midseventies, now in common use by banks across the nation as part of their Community Reinvestment Act compliance and part of ordinary community development practice. His work, for example, through the Chemical Bank Streetbanking program with community-based organizations in the South Bronx, such as the MidBronx Desperadoes, was one of the key foundation blocks for the development of the Local Initiatives Support Corporation, a prominent, national community development intermediary. John retired after 28 years at Chemical Bank to Miami, Florida in 1991, but continued his community development work at a Miami-Dade community development corporation and after Hurricane Andrew, as director of an affordable single family housing initiative, capitalized in part by Allstate Insurance Company. John will be remembered by his wife and partner, children, colleagues and friends as a strong, vital man whose life was compelled by his integrity, vision and love for the other.

title: Argentina Says Israel Can Have Croat Who Headed Camp

title: Agreement Set On Housing Of Mentally Ill
description: The State Legislature agreed today to renew a pioneering program that has built housing for thousands of mentally ill homeless people in New York City, while ending the Transit Authority's experiment of running subway trains with one crew member, rather than two. Convergent acquired about 80 percent of the firm, leaving the rest with Swan employees, said Rick Adler, managing director. Swan caters to wealthy individuals and related foundations. Transaction terms were not disclosed.

title: An Easter Peace in Ireland

The accord, born of a convergence of political courage, perseverance and sheer good luck, will not end the division of Protestant and Catholic. But it will address some historic grievances and promote the use of politics, rather than violence, to solve the rest.

title: REMINGTON ARMS HIRES GOLDMAN, SACHS TO EXPLORE SALE

Remington, based in Madison, N.C., may also form a strategic alliance or pursue acquisitions, said Thomas Franco, an outside spokesman. The owner, the New York investment firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice Inc., has not set a deadline for its decision, he said. Remington was founded in 1816 when Eliphalet Remington 2d began crafting guns on his father's forge in Ilion, N.Y. Clayton Dubilier bought Remington in 1993 from E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company.

title: Two Women Work at Dangerously Close Range

The film follows two college-age girls, both named Mei-li, from different backgrounds, who end up working side by side as ticket takers in a movie theater in a teeming shopping arcade.

title: KOREAN BANK AND BANKERS TRUST IN INVESTMENT TALKS
description: Seoulbank of South Korea and the Bankers Trust New York Corporation entered into a collaboration yesterday to help Seoulbank restructure, with an eye toward attracting new investment. Under the agreement, Bankers Trust will advise Seoulbank on restructuring its loan portfolio and asset-backed securitization, risk management and credit analysis, and its overseas businesses. The agreement may also include mutual minority equity investment, which will be small enough not to affect the management control of either bank. The details and potential amount of investment are still being discussed. George Vojta, vice chairman of Bankers Trust, estimated that it would take six to 12 months to make significant progress in Seoulbank's restructuring.

title: MORRISON RESTAURANTS IN TALKS ON POSSIBLE SALE

Morrison said in January that it had hired the investment banker Wheat First Securities Inc. to advise it on ways to raise the company's value. The Atlanta-based Morrison operates 142 cafeteria-style restaurants. Fewer restaurant customers, higher costs from an increase in the minimum wage in September and the closing of six stores last quarter resulted in a loss of $90,000, or 1 cent a diluted share, in the quarter that ended Feb. 28 compared with profit of $701 million, or 8 cents, a year earlier.
