title: Northeast Utilities Rejects a Bid for a Unit
description: Public Service of New Hampshire, a unit of Northeast Utilities, has again rejected a $1.4 billion cash bid from a small electric cooperative for its transmission and distribution business.

title: A Quiet Man's Bequests Have a Community Talking
description: Getting John Wilcox to talk about himself was no easy task, his friends say. The retired millionaire banker from New Jersey had to be coaxed into leaving behind approval for his obituary to be published. His will was devoid of demands that buildings or rooms be named in his honor in exchange for his generosity.

title: New York Doctors Group Faults Aetna on Payments
description: A professional society of New York cancer specialists asked state officials yesterday to investigate complaints by doctors who said they were encountering long delays in payments by one of metropolitan New York's largest insurers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLES, RABBI M. ARTHUR, PH.D.
description: OLES-Rabbi M. Arthur, Ph.D. Died April 8, 1998, in Highland Park, NJ. Beloved husband of Eva Oles; cherished father of Miriam Oles (Dr. James Weinberger), and Dr. Deborah Oles. Grandfather of six. Born in 1918 in Munich. Attended yeshiva in Montreux, Switzerland. A student of Rabbi Y.B. Soloveichik. Received smicha in 1947 from Yeshiva University and Ph.D in 1958. Rabbi of several congregations and community chaplain at Mt. Zion Hospital, San Francisco for 24 years. A Judaic scholar and a man of chesed.

title: Bridge; For Haters of Match Points, Computer Scoring Is a Boon
description: Computers have made a major impact on tournaments in the last decade. Scoring is now faster and more accurate, with directors freed from the drudgery of adding large numbers of match points and balancing the results. And some forms of competition are possible that used to be excessively slow and burdensome to score.

title: Frustration Starting to Show After Two Rocky Starts by Cone
description: When David Cone blew a three-run lead and lost in Oakland last weekend, Manager Joe Torre said that he was a bit shocked. Cone is typically a strong finisher who is used to carrying a three- or four-run lead into the late innings, like an unbeatable anchor of a relay team.

title: At Building Where Masonry Fell, Regrets but No Answers
description: As a 32-year-old woman lay unconscious and on life support, an owner of the Lower East Side building where a section of facade fell and struck the woman said yesterday that the building had been trouble free and that the incident was ''a terrible accident.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the Chrysler Corporation's first-quarter results misstated the percentage change in earnings compared with last year's first quarter. They rose 2.2 percent, not 2.9.

title: On Brink of Peace, Catholics and Protestants Pray
description: As word spread through Belfast this morning that politicians were close to an agreement that could bring peace, a small group of Catholics and Protestants gathered in a park to pray.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARLEY, NELLIE
description: MARLEY-Nellie. Reposing Williams Funeral Home, 5628 Broadway at 232 St., Bronx, Saturday and Sunday, 2-4 and 7-9.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today for the first day of Passover. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Study of Physics Begins on the Monkey Bars; A False Dichotomy
description: To the Editor:

title: Babe, Mickey and Joe D Never Saw One Like This
description: Joe DiMaggio threw out the first ball at the Yankees' home opener yesterday, and the 10 pitchers who followed him on the mound labored to match his effort. DiMaggio worked fast and threw a strike. Most of the other pitchers did neither.

title: Judge Orders City Hall to Let Reporters Review Welfare Records
description: A State Supreme Court judge ordered New York City officials yesterday to allow news reporters to review records of the names and address of people who have left welfare, rejecting City Hall's contention that such access would violate state confidentiality rules.

title: Dollar Falls Against Yen as Bank of Japan Acts
description: The dollar tumbled against the yen in Asian trading yesterday as the Bank of Japan sold dollars for a second consecutive day to prop up the Japanese currency.

title: F.C.C. Urges Policy Change In Cyberspace
description: Marking a profound shift in the way the Government views cyberspace, the Federal Communications Commission said yesterday that at least some companies that provide telephone service over the Internet should be regulated in some of the same ways that traditional phone companies like AT&T are regulated.

title: Volvo Subsidiary to Buy Korean Equipment Unit
description: Samsung Heavy Industries, one of South Korea's remaining shipbuilders, said yesterday that it expected to sell its construction-equipment division to the Volvo Construction Equipment Corporation of Sweden in deal valued at $765 million. A formal agreement will be signed by the end of this month, the company said.

title: Study of Physics Begins on the Monkey Bars; Imagination Denied
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Shoot. Run for Mommy.
description: In the wake of the Jonesboro school killings, the National Rifle Association has been on the defensive. Most people are disturbed by the photo of one suspect in the shootings as a toddler hugging a rifle. The N.R.A., instead of showing common sense in addressing the issue of children and guns, has been issuing pro-gun statements that verge on parody.

title: Microsoft-Intel Television Effort
description: The Microsoft Corporation and the Intel Corporation said this week that they would work jointly on technology for interactive television, as the companies try to increase their roles in home entertainment.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Bank of Japan Continues Rescue Effort for the Yen

title: Low Taxes Help All
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOROWITZ, HENRY
description: HOROWITZ-Henry-April 11, 1994. TO MY FATHER A giant pine, magnificent and old, Stood staunch against the sky and all around Shed beauty, grace, and power. Within its fold Birds safely reared their young. The velvet ground Beneath was gentle, and the cooling shade Gave cheer to passers-by. Its towering arms A landmark stood, erect and unafraid, As if to say, ''Fear naught from life's alarms.'' It fell one day. Where it had dauntless stood Was loneliness and void. But men who passed Paid tribute-said, ''To know this life was good, It left its mark on me. Its work stands fast.'' And so it lives. Such life no bonds can holdThis giant pine, magnificent & old. In loving memory-always. Linda and family

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEPERINO, MARIE C.
description: DEPERINO-Marie C. Of Northport, NY, on April 9, 1998, 93 years of age. Beloved wife of the late Ernest. Devoted mother of the late Jane M. Tafuri and the late Rosaria P. Loving Grandmother of Joseph J. Tafuri and his wife Beth, and Dr. Robert J. Tafuri and his wife Loretta. Cherished great grandmother of Christina, Anthony and Laura. Visiting at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 Second Avenue, NY, NY. Funeral Mass Monday, 9:30 AM, at St. Francis Xavier Church, NYC. Interment at Calvary Cemetery, Woodside, NY. Hours Saturday 2-5 and 7-9 PM.

title: Sex and the Single Hideous Monster
description: In the spring a monster's fancy lethally turns to thoughts of lust. This thought, reduced to a level contemptuous of taste and reasonable intelligence, underlies ''Species II.''

title: Feminists Nurture a More Tolerant Christianity
description: Mother Church, indeed.

title: Predecessors' Woes Make Diet Drug a Tough Sell
description: Seven months after two popular prescription diet pills were yanked off the market because of health fears, another drug maker is trying to sell the public on the latest weight-loss medication.

title: Religion Journal; On Holidays, Questions Of Religion and Behavior
description: This weekend, the calendar brings together the Jewish holiday of Passover, which began last night, and the Christian holiday of Easter, tomorrow. But it is a weekend that has also followed two instances in which questions were publicly raised -- in vastly different forums -- about how religious teachings should guide personal behavior.

title: The Politics of Partial Birth Abortion
description: Speaker Sheldon Silver is trying to walk a difficult political line on the so-called partial birth abortion issue. He successfully mustered enough votes in the Assembly this week to block a measure that would have made certain abortion procedures illegal in New York State. But recognizing that there is political momentum behind the issue, Mr. Silver has indicated that he will offer up some weaker version of the ban in the next two weeks that will be acceptable to pro-choice lawmakers but still allow them to tell constituents that they voted for a ban on partial birth abortion. As politics goes, that strategy may be shrewd, but the message it sends would be wrong.

title: A Carpenter and a Miracle: It's Easter in Santa Fe
description: Mother Madalyn is not your standard-issue nun, especially in the New Mexico territory in 1878. Even if she weren't being played by Barbara Hershey, who can't help exuding a worldliness in her radiance, Madalyn would raise eyebrows. She uses four-letter words, not in describing the fate of sinners but as expletives. She dares to suggest that church doesn't have all the answers. (After seeing a famous actress in person, she tells the other nuns, ''Madge Kendall's absent soul taught me more than a thousand Hail Marys.'') And when a mysterious handsome stranger comes to town, she seems a little too glad to see him.

title: Bonds That Go Well With Meat or Pasta
description: Forced to keep step with globalization in the wine industry, but dismayed by the cost of raising capital, a major Italian winery has for the first time issued bonds and warrants for a vintage Tuscan red wine.

title: Police Say School Officer Had Heroin in Pockets
description: A man who the police said is a high school safety officer was arrested yesterday morning in a Brooklyn housing project and accused of having two packets of heroin in his trouser pockets.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: About New York; Missing a Man Who Tapped Their Dreams
description: RICHARD ELLNER was an amateur hoofer, but he knew balance was central to the dancer's art. By day, he ran a T-shirt factory whose silk-screen designs celebrated the joys of culture for clients like the New York City Ballet. At night, he donned his dancing shoes and presided over his other business, the Broadway Dance Center, a thriving studio that attracted everyone from Broadway show stoppers to folks with footloose fantasies.

title: Biological Warfare, Circa 1750
description: Donald Henderson is the scientist who led the campaign to eradicate smallpox, helping to eliminate the need for vaccination worldwide. Recently, he said the United States should resume making the vaccine to deal with the threat of biological warfare.

title: Mitchell Feared the Killing of a Leader
description: The former American Senator George J. Mitchell, the departing chairman of the Northern Ireland peace talks, said tonight that he had accelerated the pace of the negotiations because he feared that one of the leaders involved in the talks would be assassinated.

title: A Star Inspires Young Singers
description: The Young People's Chorus of New York, an acclaimed performance-based choral program that draws some 150 children aged 8 to 18 from all areas, economic groups and ethnic cultures of the city, has sung for some illustrious guests, including the pop singer Celine Dion, the composer Marvin Hamlisch and Hillary Rodham Clinton.

title: Hurtado and MetroStars in Double Debut
description: Eduardo Hurtado of Ecuador was the protagonist in the worst loss at home in the history of the MetroStars, but he will be on their side this afternoon when the MetroStars open their third season at Giants Stadium on natural grass.

title: Samsung to Guarantee More Debt for U.S. Units
description: The Samsung Electronics Company said yesterday that it would increase debt guarantees for two United States affiliates by $365 million, raising concern that the Korean semiconductor maker could pay a heavy price to sustain its overseas investments. The company said it would guarantee the debts of Samsung Electronics America Inc. and Samsung Austin Semiconductor Inc. to help them buy production plants.

title: Steinbrenner Hushes Whispers About Torre (for Now, Anyway)
description: Joe Torre anxiously inched up the dugout steps. One, two, three. Bob Sheppard was about to announce the starting lineup for the Yankees in gorgeous weather for what would become a gory home opener at Yankee Stadium, and he obviously started with the manager. Sheppard did not have to check Torre's office to know he was here. Yesterday, Torre was still safe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSTELLO, GENEVIEVE
description: COSTELLO-Genevieve. Of Head of the Harbor, N.Y. on April 9, 1998 in her 81st year. Beloved wife of Dr. Timothy W. Costello. Devoted mother of Peter, Joseph, John, Jeannie Costello, Mary Kay Theoharidies, and Barbara Lyons. Dear sister of Peggy Curley. Cherished grandmother of fourteen. Reposing Moloney's Hauppauge Funeral Home, 840 Wheeler Road (Rte. 111), Hauppauge, NY, where a religious service will be held on Saturday afternoon. Funeral Mass 11 A.M., Monday at St. Philip & James R.C. Church, St. James NY. Interment following in Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury NY. Visiting Friday and Saturday 2-4 & 7-9 PM. In lieu of flowers the family request donations be made to the Smithtown Parkinson's Center.

title: A Choice and a Challenge
description: Following are excerpts from statements yesterday by George J. Mitchell, the chairman of the peace talks, and Mo Mowlam, Britain's Secretary for Northern Ireland, as provided by the British Government.

title: CRITICAL LESSONS: A special report.; A Push for a New Standard In Running Nuclear Plants
description: The most ambitious nuclear power recovery effort since the Three Mile Island disaster in 1979 is under way in this southeastern corner of Connecticut, and Federal regulators are about to hand down a final grade -- pass or fail.

title: Williams on Way Back, But Ewing Must Wait
description: Buck Williams stood in the hallway outside the gymnasium, explaining the mental obstacles that go with returning from an injury. And just a few feet away, Patrick Ewing, more convinced than any doctor that he could return, finally succumbed to science and admitted that he would not be back for the regular season's final four games.

title: Casino in Atlantic City Loses Gehry as Principal Architect
description: Frank O. Gehry, one of the nation's leading architects and celebrated most recently for his design of the Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, Spain, says he will not be the principal architect of a $2 billion hotel and casino project in Atlantic City planned by Mirage Resorts.

title: Hunting the Bright Side, With Shared Birthdays
description: ''Wednesday,'' Viktor Kossakovsky's revealing documentary mosaic about life in St. Petersburg, Russia, opens and closes with extremely graphic scenes of the birth of children. In the second scene, the mother is a grotesquely fat, unhealthy-looking former drug addict who lives in a dingy apartment with her husband, an artist, and their huge dog.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BECKENSTEIN, ANNA
description: BECKENSTEIN-Anna. On April 10, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Murray. Loving mother of Norma and Sidney Kosann, Selma and Herbert Bleustein. Adoring grandmother of Carol and Steven Kosann, Marci and Robert Dew, Rod and Monica Kosann, Vicki and Brad Londy, Fran and Howard Wenbert, Sandor and Gwen Bleustein. Great-grandmother of 11. Service Sunday 1: 15 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLBY, ROBERT L. ESQ.
description: GOLBY-Robert L. Esq. In his 97th year, on April 9th at home. He is survived by his wife of 70 years, Berthe (Topsy) Eller Golby.

title: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL SEEKS 20TH CENTURY
description: American International Group Inc. intends to increase its stake in 20th Century Industries to more than 50 percent, 20th Century said late on Thursday. A.I.G. intends to file for the purchase within one year. 20th Century Industries said that the offer was not solicited and that it was ''satisfied with the present balance of ownership arrangements.'' As of Dec. 31, 20th Century had 51.6 million common shares outstanding. A.I.G. held 900,000 common shares, preferred shares that are convertible into 19.8 million shares and 16 million warrants to buy common shares at $9.10 each. The stock of 20th Century closed Thursday at $27.875, giving the company a market capitalization of $1.44 billion. A.I.G. and 20th Century, are insurance companies.

title: Journal; New Improved Newt
description: If Paula Jones and Linda Tripp can do it, why not Newt Gingrich? With the publication of his new book, the Speaker of the House has now officially joined the makeover club -- albeit the male auxiliary, founded by Michael Milken -- in which the nation's foremost pariahs attempt to transform themselves into lovable folks through the twin modern miracles of kinder cosmetics and gentler spin.

title: Robert Lasch, 91, a Pulitzer Prize Winner
description: Robert Lasch, who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1966 for editorial writing in The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, died Monday of kidney failure at a hospice in Green Valley, Ariz. He was 91 and had lived in Green Valley since 1971, when he retired from The Post-Dispatch as editor of the editorial page.

title: Now for the Hard Part: Making It Work
description: While politicians put the finishing touches this week on the historic settlement aimed at bringing Protestants and Catholics in Northern Ireland together, surveyors in a bleak Belfast neighborhood a few miles away from the talks were busy building a new wall separating the two groups.

title: Footlights on 42d St.
description: To the Editor:

title: Study of Physics Begins on the Monkey Bars; Don't Lower Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: Burnitz Haunts Valentine And Mets
description: Bobby Valentine and Jeromy Burnitz know each other well. Too well, perhaps, as far as Valentine is concerned after Burnitz and the Milwaukee Brewers defeated the Mets, 5-3, tonight at County Stadium.

title: Couples and Duval Lead After Steady Play
description: After another challenging day at the Masters, every player had been tested and nobody was in control.

title: GALVESTON'S STEAKHOUSE TELLS OF ACQUISITION PLANS
description: The Galveston's Steakhouse Corporation disclosed on Thursday that it was negotiating to acquire steakhouse chains in Florida and California. Galveston's Steakhouse, based in Riverside, Calif., operates steakhouse restaurants in California. On Feb. 28, Galveston's completed a $6.25 million initial public offering. Galveston's said the California steakhouse chain it seeks has annual revenue of more than $140 million. The Florida chain has revenue of more than $36 million. It declined to give the names of the chains.

title: Defending U.S. Forests
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about modern Passover seders misidentified a monk who participated in one and misstated the day. The monk was Lama Pena, not Lobsang Ngodup; the seder was held on Tuesday, not Thursday.

title: B. Tornqvist, An Innovator In Shipping, 82
description: Bengt Tornqvist, a sea captain who came up with the concept of building cargo ships with ramps and openings so that motor vehicles could be driven into and out of their holds, died April 3 at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in New York City and Stockholm. He died of intestinal problems, a business associate said.

title: Rebuffed, Yeltsin ReoffersHis Premier to Parliament
description: Insisting that he has no other candidate up his sleeve, President Boris N. Yeltsin today resubmitted the name of Sergei N. Kiriyenko for the post of Russian Prime Minister, less than an hour after the 35-year-old former banker, political novice and Acting Prime Minister was rebuffed by Parliament's lower house.

title: John Tate, 43, Troubled Heavyweight Champ
description: John Tate, whose tormented life went uphill during a five-month reign as a world heavyweight boxing champion and then downhill again, was killed early Thursday morning in a one-truck accident in Knoxville, Tenn., where he lived. He was 43.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENIVEGNA, DR. SALVATORE L.
description: BENIVEGNA-Dr. Salvatore L. On April 9, 1998 after a long illness. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle, friend. He grew up and lived most of his life in Bklyn, NY where he practiced medicine as a general practitioner and surgeon. During World War II he served in the army medical corps at front line field hospitals in the Pacific. His intelligence, compassion and generosity to his family, friends and patients, inspired their loyalty, love and respect. A funeral mass will be held at St. Peter's Church, Danbury, CT, April 14, 1998 at 10:30AM. Contact Green Funeral Home 203-748-2131 for more information.

title: Foreign Affairs; The Internet Wars
description: Three years ago I visited Microsoft to ask its top managers these basic questions: How does Microsoft measure power, and which countries have it and which ones don't? They answered that Microsoft measured power by one ratio: personal computers per household. And on Microsoft's power map South Korea ranked highest in the world, with the U.S. and Japan also near the top; Europe was all on the rise, except for France; but the Middle East, save for Israel, was a black hole.

title: IRISH TALKS PRODUCE AN ACCORD TO STOP DECADES OF BLOODSHED WITH SHARING OF ULSTER POWER
description: The Northern Ireland peace talks produced a landmark settlement today that forged concessions from fiercely antagonistic Catholic and Protestant figures in an effort to settle one of the century's most enduring conflicts.

title: Sports of The Times; Woods and Zoeller Play a Chilly Round
description: WHEN Tiger Woods was asked for his reaction to being grouped with Fuzzy Zoeller in the second round of the Masters, he said, ''Just another pairing.''

title: At Center of Any Impeachment Inquiry, Rep. Hyde, a Man of the Old School
description: When he is back home in his district, just outside Chicago, sipping a glass of iced tea at the Sun Mist Restaurant, Representative Henry J. Hyde never mentions President Clinton's troubles. Nor does he ever say that he is Congress's point man in a possible impeachment inquiry.

title: Marijuana's Much-Maligned Cousin
description: Traditional jurisprudence frowns on guilt by association -- unless the defendant is a plant called industrial hemp and the prosecutor is the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration. Recently a coalition of farmers, environmentalists and businesses petitioned the drug agency and the Department of Agriculture to stop treating this plant as a criminal just because it is related to marijuana, a controlled substance. Otherwise, America's farmers and entrepreneurs will be at a disadvantage as other industrial democracies try to exploit hemp's commercial potential and environmental benefits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEB, ETHEL (NEE STRAUSS)
description: LOEB-Ethel (nee Strauss). Died peacefully at home on April 9, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Milton B. Loeb. Survived by her daughter Felicia Lemonick, son Henry Steiner, and step-son Michael Loeb; grandchildren Jim and John Lemonick, Julie A. Feldman, Bradford Steiner and Wendy Steiner Schwartz. Great grandmother of four. Interment private. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Taking the Shame Out of Plagiarism
description: The first time I went on line and was granted access to all mankind's accumulated knowledge, I immediately did what everybody does: I looked up my own name.

title: Nets' Playoff Possibilities: Rise, Hold On or Tee It Up
description: Shortly after practice today, Keith Van Horn walked off the court and was shown a news release announcing that the Nets were putting playoff tickets on sale on Monday.

title: Siren Was the Same but Not the Storm
description: For as long as even the very oldest can remember, the wail of warning sirens atop courthouses, little police stations and volunteer fire departments has pierced the calm of the drowsy Alabama communities of Rock Creek, Oak Grove and Sylvan Springs. It chases the people here deep into their basements and down on their knees, till the skies clear and they walk outside to see who was spared, who was not.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYKO, JEFFREY
description: BOYKO-Jeffrey. Our special friend. We will miss you and always remember all the wonderful times we've shared together. Our hearts go out to Leslie and Alexander. Gimme a holler. Love, Jill, Sandy and Johnny

title: MCI Restates 4th-Quarter Result After Questioning by the S.E.C.
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said yesterday that it had restated fourth-quarter results to move $147 million in charges to the first half of 1998, after the timing was questioned by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: A Down-to-Earth Iago, Evil Made Ordinary
description: If you had just walked into the war room, where matters of grave international importance were under discussion, you probably wouldn't notice him, any more than you would a simple wooden chair. He's one of several soldiers, the second from the left, and in his khaki uniform, standing immobile at attention, he blends right into the sand-colored column behind him.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANOK, JESSE PAUL ''YSAYE''
description: SHANOK-Jesse Paul ''Ysaye'', on April 10th. in East Brunswick, NJ. Beloved husband of Toby Gross Shanok; devoted father of Frederick D., Dede Shanok Drucker and Amy Volpe; adored brother of Victor, and Pearl Zale; loved grandfather of 10. Services on Monday April 13, 1998 at 2 PM in the Schwartz Brothers Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills. Interment to follow in the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: Study of Physics Begins on the Monkey Bars
description: To the Editor:

title: Photography Sales Set Records at Four Houses
description: Manhattan's annual spring week of major photography auctions has concluded with record sales at every participating house and record prices for work by several artists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADELMAN, RENEE (NEE GRATUM)
description: ADELMAN-Renee (nee Gratum). Passed away on April 9, 1998. Much beloved wife of Robert P. Adelman, cherished mother of Michael O. Adelman of Chester, New Jersey; Susan A. Moran of Swampscott, MA; and John W. Adelman of Falmouth, ME, adored grandmother of Matthew, Kayla, Julia, Sarah, Rebecca and Katherine. A Memorial Service will be held at the Unitarian Church of All Souls, 1157 Lexington Avenue, New York on May 4, 1998 at 5:30 PM. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to The American Cancer Society.

title: COMPUCOM SYSTEMS IN AGREEMENT TO BUY DATAFLEX
description: Compucom Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Dataflex Corporation for $24.4 million in cash to gain a foothold in the Southeastern United States for its services, which help corporations set up and manage computer networks. Compucom will pay $4.10 a share to buy the outstanding shares of Dataflex, based in Clearwater, Fla. ''Florida is strategically important to Compucom,'' said Ed Anderson, Compucom's chief executive. Dataflex has existing government and corporate accounts in the region, Mr. Anderson said. Compucom said it had also completed the acquisition of the Computer Integration Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., for $17.25 million in cash.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAKE, JOAN
description: LAKE-Joan, 61. Died April 6, 1998 in Manhattan. A graduate of Skidmore College, Saratoga Springs and Columbia University School of Social Work, she was a social worker in New York for many years. Leaves her companion Felix Transport and several cousins. Burial in Cambridge, NY, Tuesday, Apr. 14. Memorial service, Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, 3 P.M., Friday, April 17.

title: Coaxing From Clinton
description: President Clinton, whose 1994 overture to the leader of Sinn Fein helped bring the political wing of the I.R.A. to the peace table, was deeply involved as the Ulster talks concluded, urging both Catholics and Protestants to take risks for peace.

title: U.S. Seeks China's Help In Arranging Pol Pot Trial
description: The Administration turned to China today for help in arranging an international war-crimes trial for Pol Pot, the Khmer Rouge leader responsible for the deaths of more than a million Cambodians in the 1970's.

title: For the Frugal, It's the Season for Bargain Boats
description: Gerald Plante, a small-boat sailor from Smithfield, R.I., decided last spring that it was time to sell his 22-foot day-sailer and buy a new boat. But instead of taking out a newspaper ad, he put the craft in a used boat show. Within an hour, he had sold it for $6,000, his asking price.

title: A John Cage Work Suggests a Music Box
description: At Here in SoHo on Tuesday evening, the California pianist Julie Steinberg reminded us of several things in and about John Cage's ''Sonatas and Interludes'' for prepared piano. One of them was, inevitably, the work's allusions: rattles, dull thuds suggestive of wood drums and metallic clangings that have escaped the piano's normal tuning.

title: A Britten-Auden Down-Home Romp
description: Benjamin Britten's ''Paul Bunyan'' is an opera one runs across in biographies but rarely meets in person. Britten, who wrote it with W. H. Auden during their wartime retreat to America, seems himself to have lost interest, at least until he revised the piece much later in life. The first performances, in 1941, were not that gladly received.

title: For the Long Final Hours, Clinton Coaxed
description: President Clinton, whose 1994 overture to Gerry Adams of Sinn Fein helped bring the political wing of the Irish Republican Army to the peace table, was deeply involved as the Ulster talks concluded, cajoling and prodding both republicans and Unionists to step out of their parochial interests and take historic risks for peace.

title: A Baritone From the Opera Lends a Spiritual Touch
description: The trumpeter Terence Blanchard's engagement at Iridium this week includes an extensive walk-on by Jubilant Sykes, an operatic baritone with whom Mr. Blanchard has just made a recording. The album (''Jubilant,'' on Sony Classical) is measured and chamberlike; Mr. Blanchard's neat arrangements of black American spirituals skirt jazz, gospel and film music; Mr. Sykes treats them as a cross between pop breathiness and the Leontyne Price approach. It's a bit perfumed and overly arty but well contained; inasmuch as the album is contrived, the contrivances don't make a mess.

title: A Big Solo in a Small Space
description: Yves Musard could have been dancing ''Splinter'' in a fishbowl on Tuesday night. Instead, he performed it at CBGB's Gallery. But because the stage at this club on the Bowery is tiny and dancegoers were seated very close to it, they might have been peering into a fishbowl.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, GWENDOLYN. (NEE KIEVE)
description: FELDMAN - Gwendolyn. (Nee Kieve). Of Tenafly, NJ on April 9, 1998 following a valiant battle with ovarian cancer. Beloved wife of Bud (Edgar J.) for 45 years. Dear mother of Amy Feldman & Nena Colligan. Adored grandmother of Ted, Will and Kieve Colligan. She died as she lived, with dignity and grace, surrounded by her family. There will be a service at Wien & Wien, 129 Engle Street, Englewood, New Jersey, on Monday, April 13 at 11:30AM. Visiting at the chapel 10:30AM before funeral. Contributions to the National Ovarian Cancer Coalition, P.O. Box 4472, Boca Raton, FL 33472, in her memory would be appreciated.

title: Girardi Finds His Stroke
description: After starting the season 0 for 8, Joe Girardi slapped his first four hits of the year yesterday and gave Joe Torre something to consider when he goes to choose a catcher for this afternoon's game against the A's. But Girardi, ever the professional, refused to speculate about whether one superb game meant he should start over Jorge Posada.

title: Maxwell House Price Cut
description: The Kraft Foods Inc. unit of the Philip Morris Companies will cut the price of Maxwell House regular and decaffeinated coffee by 25 cents for a 13-ounce can, effective May 11. The suggested price of Maxwell House regular ground coffee will be lowered to $2.51 a can, from $2.76, while a can of decaffeinated coffee will drop to $3.21, from $3.46, said Patricia Brown Resso, a Kraft spokeswoman. Maxwell House will also cut the price of an 8-ounce jar of instant coffee by 12 cents, to $3.64.

title: A Little Border War Over Mexican-U.S. Phone Traffic
description: In the long-distance telephone wars, Maria Trejo is a prime target.

description: Apple Computer Inc. today denied claims made in a $1.1 billion patent infringement suit filed in February by Imatec Ltd. and said that it would ''vigorously defend'' itself.

description: I HAVE always made sure my kids got to the doctor regularly and my husband made an appointment for his physical, but I dreaded the hassle when it came to taking care of myself,''said Susan Datz, a teacher from Oceanside.

title: Question About Landfill Is a Foul Ball for the Little League
description: For the 300 players in the Little League teams of the College Point Sports Association, the start of the season is only two weeks away, on April 25. But the youngsters may not get to see the first ball thrown out. The city has padlocked their fields, saying that a contractor hired to repair them dumped demolition debris illegally -- an assertion that the contractor denies.

title: Scene on Sidewalk Rivals the Party Itself
description: THE SCENE -- The first anniversary party for Icon magazine, a slick SoHo-based bimonthly geared to the cult of celebrity worship. On Wednesday night, a crowd flocked to the Ace Gallery, a cavernous space at 275 Hudson Street, to soak up free drinks and try to catch a glimpse of Evel Knievel, the daredevil motorcyclist who once tried to leap the Snake River Canyon in Idaho on a rocket-powered skycycle. (He almost made it.)

title: April 5-11; Asking or Telling?
description: The military is discharging 67 percent more gay and lesbian soldiers today than when the Clinton Administration's ''don't ask, don't tell'' policy began in 1993, a new Pentagon study shows. Gay-rights advocates say homosexuals are being outed and ousted in defiance of the policy; the Pentagon says recruits are declaring their sexuality to leave the military. Both agree that commanders need the policy explained to them again, five years after its creation. TIM WEINER

title: Methods to Use in Caning Chairs
description: THERE are two ways to restore caned webbing in a damaged chair seat. The seat can be replaced with prewoven cane webbing or it can be rewoven with individual strands of cane. It is easier to easier to replace the entire seat with a single piece of prewoven cane webbing. To do this, however, the chair must have a continuous groove running around the seat opening. If the chair has a series of holes drilled around the seat opening, it must be recaned by weaving strands through the holes.

title: The Mystery of the Well-Behaved Strawberries

title: An Unorthodox Portrayer (Betrayer?) of Hasidism

Mr. Yakin wanted to be sure that every detail in his movie about Hasidic Jews, every ritual and Talmudic reference, was authentic.

title: Spotted in New York: Shiny Cars

This year's show, which opened yesterday and runs through next Sunday at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan, is no exception. The New York economy is booming, gas prices are at record lows and Wall Street bonuses were exceptionally rich last year.

title: Desk Set

The high-powered equipment to be used at 21 work stations there requires a big 21-inch monitor, which would block a student's view of the teacher and the blackboard.

title: CLASSICAL MUSIC; New Day for the Timeless Passion?
description: WHEN Seiji Ozawa leads the Boston Symphony Orchestra in Bach's ''St. Matthew Passion'' at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday and Thursday evenings, music lovers of all religious and cultural backgrounds will bathe their souls in this glorious effusion of faith. Yet few hear this famous piece remembering that it is but one of hundreds of musical treatments of the most profound series of events of Christian doctrine, the capture, sentencing and execution of Jesus.

title: Why Aren't More Geeks With the Gizmos Girls?
description: FOR two nights last month, in nightclubs and performance spaces throughout Miami, disk jockeys and musical groups were playing the latest forms of electronic-based dance music as part of the Winter Music Conference, an annual international gathering. It was after 2 in the morning, and for the first time all weekend a woman was controlling the syncopated pulse of the dance floor. But the woman, DJ Rap, was not visible. On stage, technicians cleared the previous act's equipment, and the only sign of DJ Rap was her grainy image projected on a large screen in the hall. A visitor had to search the multilevel club before spotting DJ Rap in a small booth in the rafters.

title: Sunday, April 12, 1998: KIDS; Dome Boy

A dimple-faced 8-year-old from North London, Christian has been working with the designers of the Millennium Dome, a $1.25 billion structure that is now rising on the Thames's south bank in Greenwich. The Dome is scheduled to open Dec. 31, 1999, and is supposed to highlight Britain's best as the new millennium dawns. Since the Dome is costing a fortune -- culled mainly from national lottery proceeds -- the British people naturally are clamoring to know what will be in it.

title: Correction

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Very Good For Nothing
description: William, the firstborn of twin boys, has determined to spend the rest of his life making sure he will never be first again. In the course of Benjamin Anastas's fine, funny debut novel, AN UNDERACHIEVER'S DIARY (Dial, $15.95), William provides exquisitely detailed explanations of his strategies for falling short -- even backing them up with a vague attempt at scholarship. In clinging to the depths, William is aided most of all by the fact that his twin brother, Clive, can do no wrong; his destiny is to travel smoothly from success to success, impressing parents, teachers, therapists and girlfriends (although there turns out to be a small cloud of doubt about the last) through his incredible ease of accomplishment and the wealth of his potential. With such a paragon of achievement available for ready comparison, William doesn't have to try very hard to disappoint. Instead, he drifts rather gracefully -- it must be admitted -- down the plane of life until he reaches the zenith of underachievement: ''Having disappointed every expectation that my parents held for me, I had finally been cast out of their constructive thoughts.'' Imbued with a kind of half-serious mockery, William's account of his misadventures sometimes recalls Frederick Exley's masterpiece of the genre, ''A Fan's Notes.'' Similarly, Benjamin Anastas makes his protagonist a successful failure, happy to be written off, perhaps, but understanding his world pretty well: ''Life has been an experiment in trial and error, without any guiding principles . . . like prayer without a God to listen.'' James Polk

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SPIEGEL, MARGARET JUDGE

Born in Scranton, PA, Margaret with her late husband in 1945 founded Spiegel's Flowers in Butler, NJ, which they sold in 1978 upon retirement. She is survived by a sister and a brother, her three children and seven grandchildren. Her ashes will be buried next to those of her late husband at Our Lady of the Magnificat Cemetery in Kinnelon, NJ later in the year. A memorial service will be held at noon Monday, April 13 at Delia Funeral Home, Rte 70W, Lakehurst, NJ. Donations may be made to the Annie R. Tinker Fund, 369 Lexington Ave., NY, NY 10017. Margaret will be remembered by her family and friends as a strong, energetic, vital and compassionate woman whose life was compelled by her integrity and love for the other.

title: Flip Curls

The books -- ''The Stick Twist,'' ''The Chignon Twist'' and ''The French Twist'' -- show a very low-tech black-and-white movie as the pages are rapidly flipped. Smaller than a pack of cigarettes, they were created to clear up the confusion Ms. Malouf's customers had about styles like the stick twist.

title: FILM; In the Shoes of a Stalker Nearing His Prey
description: DURING science fiction films, you watch the skies. In movies based on Patricia Highsmith's novels, you should watch the feet. Stalking is central to some of these pictures. As one man grimly follows another in the Paris Metro or a giggling woman is tracked through an amusement park while a carousel plays ''Casey would waltz with the strawberry blonde,'' the victims-to-be don't realize that they're about to die. Only the spectators know what's ahead -- the shooting or the strangling -- and they can experience that helpless moment that occurs in dreams, when you witness a horrific event but cannot possibly intervene.

title: Chasing an Eclipse

My companion, David, studied road maps of Guadeloupe, calculating at what vantage point we would have the greatest mobility if a passing thunderhead threatened to obscure the sun. Of course, if the sky remained overcast, driving would be futile. David's anxiety was contagious. I was beginning to look forward to Friday -- the day after the eclipse.

It singes whatever it touches. So it is not surprising that in August Sicilians happily join the general European exodus to the beach. The fishing village and resort of Mondello near Palermo grows thick with bathers, who spread elbow to elbow along the beach and cram into tiny cabanas. Along the northern coast, towns like Cefalu, Capo D'Orlando and the cliff-ringed San Vito do Capo offer much less crowded beaches, with a few tourists wandering around, looking dazed or lost.

title: Anonymous Tribal Artisans? Look Again

The characters who inhabit Phyllis Gotlieb's FLESH AND GOLD (Tor/Tom Doherty, $23.95) have little time for anything else. Much of the action (and there is a great deal of it) takes place in a far-future brothel of labyrinthine design, where connoisseurs of the more than ''15 kinds of humanity'' come to gratify their outre desires.

description: THE problem with labeling yourself the world's ''indispensable nation,'' as Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright is fond of calling the United States, is that you become hypersensitive if other nations, less convinced or more uneasy, start meeting without you.

Services at Schwartz Bros. Jeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY. Funeral on Monday. Please call chapel for time of service, 718-263-7600.

description: A THEATERGOER en route to an Off Broadway show recently passed three men who had apparently just met on Ninth Avenue in Manhattan. ''So are you going to 'Follies' at Paper Mill?'' she overheard one of them asking. ''Everybody I know is going.'' The woman restrained herself from chiming in, ''I certainly am.''

title: ON THE TOWNS

title: Installations of Light That Respond to Visitors
description: IMMENSE fiber-optic butterflies, glowing cocoons and light that dances ''like a spinning jump rope'' are all part of three large-scale interactive light installations that will be on view at the New York Hall of Science beginning this Friday.

title: Celebrity Overkill
description: ''TOO much of a good thing can be wonderful,'' Mae West liked to say. But she didn't have to sit through Versus and Emporio Armani. Showings of those Italian secondary collections -- Donatella Versace's Versus line on March 28 at Roseland, and Giorgio Armani's Emporio collection on April 3 at Cipriani Wall Street -- bracketed the most recent Seventh on Sixth runway presentations. Beginning and ending a week of shows, they stood as exemplars of where fashion has gone wrong of late. Today, there are too many Hollywood celebrities off the runways, and too few fashion celebrities on them.

title: POSTINGS: 77 Grants in 37 Counties; Helping Rural Areas Survive in New York
description: Seventy-seven disparate projects have received start-up funds from a consortium of nonprofit groups called the Rural New York Grant Program. They all share one goal -- to sustain a rural way of life in New York State.

title: Top-Ranking Football of Irish Persuasion
description: THE Ancient Order of Hibernians Gaelic Football Club in Stamford is making sporting history as the first Gaelic football, or soccer, team in Connecticut to have achieved the sport's highest ranking, First Division.

description: MUSICAL activity on campus is back in full swing following the Easter break. On Tuesday evening at 8, the University of Connecticut Concert Band, conducted in turn by William Halpin and Brian Sparks, plays a free program of traditional and popular music in von der Mehden Hall in Storrs.

title: Phoning Home

We use M.C.I. for long-distance service on one of our phones. We added their $3 monthly fee plan because we were led to believe calls from abroad would be the same as calls from home, with no added service charge.

description: JANE ALEXANDER has a few words of advice for anyone thinking of running the National Endowment for the Arts any time in the near future.

title: A Stunner in Looks With Exciting Food
description: SOLO is a stunner. I watched as a young woman entered this new Hauppauge restaurant. She stopped short, frozen in mid-step with eyes wide and mouth slightly open. Solo is as unexpected as it is beautiful. Located in a commercial area of Hauppauge (with a furniture factory outlet next door), it is an unlikely spot for one of the Island's most gorgeous restaurants.

title: Natural High
description: For all the ballyhoo about synthetics, when it comes to looking crisp and elegant, linen is still king of the mountain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREGORY, BLANCHE C.
description: GREGORY-Blanche C. Literary Agent, Blanche C. Gregory, Inc., on April 6, 1998. Beloved sister of William E. Gregory. Loving aunt, great aunt, and great great aunt, associate and friend. Services and interment private.

title: Boys and Girls First in Relays
description: Boys and Girls High School of Brooklyn finished first and third yesterday in the 1,600-meter relay to edge South Shore of Brooklyn for the boys' team title in the eighth annual Kings Relays at Midwood Field, Brooklyn. The 9 relay points gave Boys and Girls 33 points to South Shore's 32.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPONIS, AUDREY L.
description: JOSEPONIS-Audrey L. On April 11, 1998 of Roslyn Hgts. Beloved wife of Anthony. Loving mother of the late William A. Also survived by a niece Maureen McNamara. Reposing Roslyn Heights Funeral Home Inc., 75 Mineola Ave., Roslyn Heights, Monday 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral service Tuesday, 10 AM Trinity Episcopal Church, Roslyn. Interment LI National Cemetery, Calverton.

title: A Pre-Derby Shake-Up For Favorites
description: Two horses who appeared near certainties to run as top choices in the Kentucky Derby took major steps backward today. And a colt who appeared to have run himself out of the picture proved he might belong after all, though he very likely will not participate.

title: FROM THE DESK OF; A Parents' Bill of Rights Would End a 30-Year War
description: FOR the last three decades, a silent and undeclared war has been waged against parents. The major culprits are myopic big businesses (fueled by managerial greed), parent-hurting Government policies and mass media that ridicule the parental role. These forces are undermining the most precious nonmarket activity in our market-driven society: the caring and nurturing of our children.

title: Correction
description: The Coping column last Sunday, about the recent death of a lawyer who fought for opportunities for women in the profession, misidentified the group that gave her credit for inventing the political cocktail party. They were the Young Democrats, not reform Democrats. Because of an editing error, the column also misstated her given name at one point. She was Hilda Schwartz, not Hannah.

title: Italian, Dependable and Attractive, Too
description: IF Connecticut ever adopted an official state cuisine, it would surely be Italian. No village seems too small to have at least one Italian restaurant. Fairfield, where we found Ristorante Cinzano's, has several.

title: Let Juries Decide Whether Lie Detectors Lie; Too Narrow a Ruling
description: To the Editor:

title: Gifts to Colleges
description: Purchase and Iona Colleges each recently received $5 million in gifts. Bill Lacy, president of Purchase College, said the college received a pledge of $5 million from Roy R. Neuberger, adding to $4.2 million that the college had received in other gifts since July. In New Rochelle, Iona received a $5 million pledge from Mr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Murphy -- the largest contribution in that college's history.

title: Neighbors Troubled by St. John's Dorm Plan
description: When officials of St. John's University announced a $300 million expansion plan on Wednesday, they noted proudly that when it was finished St. John's would no longer be known as a commuter college. Part of the plan calls for a village of up to a dozen dormitories for 2,800 students in a lowland area near the Grand Central Parkway known as ''the pits,'' on the southwestern edge of the 100-acre campus.

title: Residents Fight Mormon Temple Plan
description: ON one side stands a group of indignant town residents and on the other stands the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. At issue is how high the church can build a Mormon temple on the 24-acre lot it owns on the corner of Kenilworth Road and Westchester Avenue here. Teams of lawyers represent both sides -- the residents have employed two teams -- and in the middle, faced with the daunting task of deciding the dispute, is the Harrison Planning Board.

description: To the Editor:

title: Memorial for Brendan Gill
description: A memorial tribute to the author and critic Brendan Gill is to be held at 4 P.M., Tuesday, at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street, Manhattan. Calvin Trillin, Arthur Schlesinger Jr., Brooke Astor and Roger Kennedy are among the scheduled speakers, and Cherry Jones and Victor Garber will read from the work of Mr. Gill.

title: Trash Hauler Fined
description: Suburban Carting, one of Westchester's largest private trash haulers, was sentenced in Federal Court late last month to five years' probation and ordered to pay more than $5 million to the Government, John L. Kase, the lawyer for the Mamaroneck-based company, said. Suburban will also have to pay Westchester about $800,000.

title: Livery Law
description: The Westchester Taxi and Limousine Commission has proposed a new law to regulate and license limousine drivers and their companies. It is a first step by the commission to regulate cars for hire, said William R. Randolth, an assistant to County Executive Andrew J. Spano. The commission also expects to set standards for taxis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLAUNER, JESSIE
description: BLAUNER-Jessie. The Board of Governors of the Palm Beach Country Club expresses its sorrow at the passing of its esteemed member Mrs. Eugene (Jessie) Blauner and extends its heartfelt sympathy to her family and friends. David L. Rudnick, President Robert S. Puder, Secretary

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BRUN, MARCIA
description: BRUN-Marcia. Happy birthday in heaven. April 11 (Passover). We miss you. Lovingly, your girls

title: IN SEARCH OF; When School Spirit Is on the Shopping List
description: BOOKS? Sure, college bookstores sell books. That's 65 percent of their business nationwide. But they also sell computer products (8.5 percent), magazines and popular books (6.7 percent), school supplies, including old-fashioned pencils and paper (7.9 percent), candy and a host of life's other miscellaneous necessities (6.5 percent).

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVENE, ARTHUR
description: LEVENE-Arthur. Of Southampton, NY, died April 9, 1998. He is survived by his beloved wife of 26 years, Madeleine Mono; his daughter, Ronia Kuklin, (LA); daughter and son-in-law, Lesley and Mark Steiner (NY); stepchildren, Gail Berry, Louise and Rodger Bass (London, UK); Craig and Kimberly Berry (CT), and Grant and Donna Berry (NY); and his sister Rose Emanuel of (London, UK). Mr. Levene is also survived by 17 grandchildren and two greatgrandchildren, and by his motherin-law, Lily Mono; his brother and sisters-in-law, Patricia and Stephen Mono and their children, Benjamin and Rebecca. Services for Mr. Levene were held at Brockett Funeral Home in Southampton, NY, with Rabbi David J. Gelfand and Cantor Debra Stein Davidson of the Jewish Center of the Hamptons in East Hampton officiating. Interment was at the Independent Jewish Cemetery in Sag Harbor. In lieu of flowers donatons may be made to the Southampton Village Volunteer Ambulance, PO Box 832, Southampton, NY 11968.

description: ''I'M 42,'' Alexander H. Cohen told Newsweek in 1963. ''With a big, big, big break, I've got 30 years left.''

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: A Standard-Bearer

title: The Magical Mystery Block
description: The last tenant left the once thriving block of Court Street between State and Schermerhorn Streets in the early 90's, and, ever since, people in the neighborhood have speculated about what would become of the abandoned row of small shops, a bar, a restaurant and a movie theater.

title: Who Booed? Voice Lovers, With Reason
description: THE reception of Robert Wilson's production of ''Lohengrin'' at the Metropolitan Opera not long ago was more operatic than the piece Wagner wrote. Reviews included praise but leaned generally to the negative side. People still marvel at the near-violent wall of boos that greeted Mr. Wilson's curtain calls on opening night.

title: The Power of Self-Loathing
description: Larry David's mother is worried that her son is going to do something terrible to some people she cares about a lot. ''She's afraid I'm going to kill the characters,'' says David, a co-creator of ''Seinfeld'' who left the show two years ago but has come back to write and produce the final episode. ''Every time I talk to her on the phone, she says, 'Don't kill them.''' And what does he tell his worried mother about the much-anticipated finale to ease her mind? ''I don't tell her anything,'' David says. ''I say, 'That's up to me, not you.'''

title: Officials Reluctant to Answer Workfare Inquiries
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and the senior aides who oversee the city's vast workfare program often praise it as one of the administration's hallmark achievements. But neither the Mayor nor his aides would discuss workfare with the New York Times reporters preparing this series of articles on the program.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: Night of Many Dreams

title: Echoing Christ, the Devout Trace Their Personal Stations of the Cross
description: The Rev. Tom Schirmer prepared his Good Friday meditations over a glass of red wine and a pack of Doral cigarettes on Maundy Thursday, the piano concertos of Camille Saint-Saens muffling the sounds of the lashing rain.

title: Bookend; The Cold Mountain of Central Park
description: Irwin plotted his way by Trump Tower, its silhouette a smudge against the nightly rotation of stars, using the brass telescope with the fine optics from Germany. An ancient peddler had told him the smudge was the burning fire of evicted souls, but Irwin put no stock in myth, he had seen too much reality on the western side. His own soul yearned for the east, where perfumed johnny-hock bloomed on humid terraces, and so he stumbled on, a hand pressed to the festering scrape on his hip where he had tumbled into a pothole on Amsterdam Avenue. He had seen men survive worse, men whose entire heads had come disconnected from their bodies and who still shopped for sushi at Fairway and went to readings at Barnes & Noble. But though he had fashioned a poultice of ripe juniper berries and the bark of the Borneo poplar and fastened the contraption with the twined root of huckleberry, still he limped and still the wound festered.

title: Into the Wilderness
description: QUARANTINE

title: Patient at Bat and Impatient on the Bases, the Yankees Concoct a Victory
description: The best offensive team in baseball, as the Yankees have been called many times this spring, has been out-hit in seven of its first nine games of the season. But the Yankees' ability to collect hits isn't why opposing managers and scouts rave about this lineup.

title: Your Name Here
description: IN the long run, as John Maynard Keynes pointed out, we are all dead.

title: April 5-11; A Death Toll, Truce and Now . . .
description: Officials from Northern Ireland, Britain, the Irish Republic and the United States announced a comprehensive agreement designed to bridge centuries of hatred and end three decades of harrowing violence.

title: Big Disparities Seen In Income Tax Audits
description: Nothing touches off panic in taxpayers more than the prospect of an audit. But there are wide disparities across the country in who gets audited. Newly released data from the Internal Revenue Service show, for example, that Los Angeles County taxpayers are four times as likely to be audited as those in New Jersey, even though the two areas have roughly the same population and the same average income.

The correct numbers are, for the Prague Spring Festival, (420-2) 53 60 40; and, for the Valtice Festival, (420-2) 242 16343. (The country code is 420, no longer 42; the code for Prague remains 2.)

description: Dallek, a professor of history at Boston University, is the author of Flawed Giant: Lyndon Johnson and His Times, 1961-1973.

title: Aid Groups Are Hands That Help In Bosnia
description: Every month, the brain trust of the local chapter of Bosnia's ''mini-Marshall Plan'' -- the military, the United Nations and voluntary agencies known as NGO's -- meets in a revived neighborhood of concrete office buildings and smoky pizza parlors to plan how to spend the next allotment of hundreds of thousands of dollars to rebuild the region.

title: With One Round to Go, Couples Holds an Uneasy Lead
description: It would be difficult to have a stronger leader board, a more picturesque setting, or more potential for Sunday golf drama.

title: The World; Surprises in the Global Tourism Boom
description: IF those spring holiday airport crowds seem worse than ever this year, think of that suitcase on your foot as merely a harbinger of even bigger things to come. Travel -- yearround and around the world -- is taking off on a phenomenal upward trajectory, with the numbers of tourists growing faster, proportionately, than the population of the countries they come from, or go to visit. Trips closer to home are also on the increase almost everywhere. Spending on travel is expected to grow fivefold in the next two decades.

title: Fishing (and Fish) Stories
description: Trout season started yesterday in New Jersey. Do you have any stories to tell about fishing in the state?

title: Spoleto to Welcome Janacek, Fugard, et al.
description: A new production of Leos Janacek's ''Jenufa,'' whose dramatic libretto and score inspired by Moravian folk tunes established Mr. Janacek as a major operatic composer, will open the 22d season of the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. on May 22. The festival, based in the historic district of Charleston, S.C., runs through June 7 and features more than 130 opera, theater, dance, chamber and jazz programs.

title: Creative Writing Classes Filled With Hope
description: THE room was dense with re membered lives old lovers, dead parents, bullying brothers, lost friends. One woman described the magnetic pull of her boyfriend's sexy red car; another recalled the white-knuckled panic of learning to drive. The 10 students wrote at a large oval table, the past a silent guest among them. Then Patty Dann called time, and the students began reading their work aloud.

title: San Jose
description: It's been 30 years since Dionne Warwick first sang ''Do You Know the Way to San Jose?'' about a woman who longs to return to a simple town just south of San Francisco Bay. These days, though, the woman who couldn't wait to get back to San Jose probably wouldn't recognize the place.

description: At least 38 people died when tornadoes swept through Mississippi, Georgia and Alabama, destroying property and, it seemed, nature itself.

title: THE BOATING REPORT; Happily for Sailors in Whitbread Race, Leg 6 Is History
description: The nine boats in the Whitbread Round the World Race are in the midst of a three-week layover in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The 31,600-nautical-mile odyssey restarts on April 19, on the seventh of nine legs, 870 nautical miles from Florida to Baltimore. The current standing places EF Language first over all, with Swedish Match in second. Katie Pettibone, an American on the all-women's crew of EF Education of Sweden, which stands ninth over all, will continue to file periodic updates of life at sea until the race's scheduled return to Southampton, England, in May. This is her 16th report.

title: A Party Tonight, but Don't Tell the Birthday Girl

description: BURT BACHARACH has the kind of problem every artist should have. While flattered by all the attention his music is getting these days from the alternative-rock crowd, he's at a loss to explain why it's happening. He prefers to let the pundits weigh in on such matters.

title: Climbing A Mountain Named Beethoven
description: WHOEVER decreed that you can't have it both ways evidently failed to tell the superbly gifted German violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter. The more Ms. Mutter trades on a glamorous image, it seems, the more surely she is recognized for her essential seriousness as an artist and a person. That seriousness, though well established by now, still catches newcomers by surprise and is therefore played up all the more whenever she is spoken of or written about.

title: Fast Forward; The Digital Attic: An Archive of Everything
description: You probably haven't spent much time worrying about what will happen to your Web site when you're dead. That's all right. David Blatner is worrying for you. ''I keep thinking,'' he says, ''if my grandparents had built a Web site, wouldn't I want it archived and available on the Net in the years to come for their grandchildren?'' So he is ready to help with his new Web-preservation organization in Seattle: Afterlife.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOWARD, JACK ROHE
description: HOWARD-Jack Rohe. A memorial gathering with his family will be held on Tuesday, April 14th, from 4:30-7:30PM at the Sky Club, 200 Park Ave, 56th Floor, NYC.

title: The World: America Frets as Its Chums Pay Their Own Games; Saudis Make Nice With The Iranians
description: FOR half a century, the Persian Gulf has held a crucial place in American policy making. Repeatedly, its oil and its leaders have drawn the United States into its sometimes deadly games, even as its rivalries and intrigues have confounded American strategy.

title: Good Fortune in Belfast
description: There is a small, municipal, open-air zoo high on the hill that rises above Belfast. Its gentle persistence up there, through all the years of the Troubles, says something about the nature of the Northern Ireland conflict. The animals were never for a moment neglected, much less abandoned, as they have been in wars elsewhere.

title: Food; The Musical Chef
description: For most of his career, which is to say, most of his life, Paul Bertolli has chased flavor by surrendering to the process of cooking. So absorbed is he in the means to an end that the sauce or salad that results from his aged balsamic vinegar (decades in the making) often takes this 43-year-old chef and co-owner of Oliveto in Oakland, Calif., by complete surprise.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; He's Still Back Again
description: In the heyday of both the singer and his country, Frank Sinatra was brash, talented and on top of the world. Plenty has been written about him over the years; his achievements and contradictions have been irresistible to authors as different as Kitty Kelley and E. B. White. Now comes a new picture book about the skinny kid from Hoboken, N.J., who became the Chairman of the Board, John Lahr's SINATRA: The Artist and the Man (Random House, $32.50). For true fans, the 100 black-and-white photographs are the book's biggest asset. Particularly in the behind-the-scenes photographs by Bob Willoughby and William Read Woodfield, these dramatic images give us a glimpse of the aura that attracted Presidents and bobby-soxers alike. Lahr's essay (a shorter version of which originally appeared in The New Yorker, where he is a drama critic) is an appreciation of Sinatra's gifts that does not shy from delving into the subject's raging dark side. Lahr quotes from many previous books and articles to construct his concise history, so the book's freshest contribution comes with his ability to articulate grand themes with a nice turn of phrase. Sinatra evoked a particularly American loneliness, Lahr writes, ''that of the soul adrift in its pursuit of the destiny of 'me,' and thrown back onto the solitude of its own restless heart.'' Unfortunately, every page of Lahr's text is overlaid with the word ''Sinatra'' in three-inch-high gray lettering -- a distracting and un-Sinatralike lapse of cool in an otherwise fairly swingin' book. Ted Loos

description: It is the rare Congressional field hearing that provokes ancient hatreds and old-fashioned shouting, but when the Senate Indian Affairs Committee visited Seattle for comments on a bill that would alter tribal power, it did just that. title: Gathering Together, in the Spirit of Doo-Wop

title: Sunday, April 12, 1998; SEEING HER
description: Reported apparitions of the Virgin Mary have increased from a low of 17 sightings in the 18th century to more than 400 so far in the 20th -- most of them since the 1960's. * In the past year alone, the faithful have seen Mary on a California tree trunk and in a water stain in a Mexico City subway station. * In 1996, after Mary appeared on one side of a highway office building in Clearwater, Fla., hawkers sold ''Miracle on U.S. 19'' T-shirts. * Today, hundreds will gather at the farm of Nancy Fowler, a Georgia visionary who says she communicates with Mary every month. * ''My opinion is that a lot of these sightings are authentic,'' says the Rev. Edward O'Connor, a retired theology professor at Notre Dame. What's the intent? ''Our Lord is trying to warn His people about the trouble we're getting ourselves into.''

title: Women Wary of Retirement Plan
description: SINGLE female baby boomers on Long Island have begun to confront retirement in the same way they would heed the rumblings of an approaching storm. They know some turbulence may be headed their way, but they are not quite sure how to prepare for it.

title: Five-Part Tribute to a Local Hero
description: Most people who stand at Ruth Wittenberg Triangle, where Greenwich Avenue, the Avenue of the Americas and Christopher Street meet, are unaware that they are standing on a spot of any significance. The paved concrete triangle bears a tiny plaque with the name of the civil rights worker, suffragist and historic-perservation pioneer.

title: Beauty, Brains and a Knack For Giving the Censors Pause
description: ALTHOUGH their rules forbid them to admit it, the people at the Motion Picture Association of America have been seeing a lot of the actress Heather Graham lately. Early last fall, members of this watchdog group saw her glide across the screen portraying the bewheeled pornography star Rollergirl as ''Boogie Nights'' was shown to them on 14 occasions before they gave it an R rating.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VAHEY, EUGENE E.
description: VAHEY-Eugene E. For all of those who shared in his life and in his death, in prayer, with a story, with a tear, or with love, our family extends our sincere appreciation. Carole, Mary, Hugh, Deborah, Doris, Katherine, Patricia, Eileen and Thomas

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOYKO, JEFFREY
description: BOYKO-Jeffrey. Sincere sympathy, Leslie, on the passing away of dear Jeffrey. (Parents of Carol Shalom) Lynn and Marty Kritzer

title: U.S. Wish List: Fill Gaps Along Appalachian Trail
description: BY the year 2000, the Clinton Administration hopes to bring the last few sections of the Appalachian Trail under public control, completing the longest natural thoroughfare in the world after a campaign of more than seven decades.

title: Palestinian Police Arrest Suspected Hamas Killer
description: The Palestinian police arrested dozens of Hamas members in the West Bank and Gaza Strip today, including a man they say led a plot to kill another member of the militant Islamic movement.

title: Serious Treatment for Folk Whimsies
description: FOLK ART is the art of the common man, and that is a vital reason for its growing popularity. Mainstream art of the moment has grown ever more conceptual and recondite, and therefore removed from the comprehension of the general public. Folk art, on the other hand, delivers a warm embrace.
