description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLBY, ROBERT L.
description: GOLBY-Robert L. Esq. In his 97th year, on April 9th at home. He is survived by his wife of 70 years, Berthe (Topsy) Eller Golby.

title: Expos Have Eyes on Downtown to Turn Around the Team's Fortunes
description: Claude Brochu, managing partner of the Montreal Expos, expects the club to turn a profit this year. With a $9.2 million payroll, that economic trick should not be hard to execute. But Brochu is looking well beyond this year.

title: Buck Williams Is Ready to Play
description: The Knicks received one of their big men back yesterday when forward Buck Williams was activated, making him available for today's game against the Heat in Miami.

title: 11 Foreigners Are Detained In Mexico Raid
description: About 500 federal and state police swept through a farming cooperative in Chiapas state at dawn today, after Indian residents there who support the Zapatista rebels declared their independence from the state government.

title: Confronting Social and Political Issues
description: Nils Norman/Christopher Whittey

title: 72d St. Subway Renovation Gets Prod From Committee
description: The large-scale renovation of the overcrowded West 72d Street subway station will apparently go forward with a recommendation against narrowing a heavily traveled sidewalk above ground. But city transportation officials could reject the plan if they found that it would worsen traffic congestion at one of Manhattan's busiest intersections.

title: When School Spirit Is on the Shopping List
description: BOOKS? Sure, college bookstores sell books. That's 65 percent of their business nationwide. But they also sell computer products (8.5 percent), magazines and popular books (6.7 percent), school supplies, including old-fashioned pencils and paper (7.9 percent), candy and a host of life's other miscellaneous necessities (6.5 percent).

title: At a Wax Museum, Black History Runs in Red
description: Raven Chanticleer, a Harlem artist, dreams big dreams even when his current dreams fall short.

title: Mr. Corporate or Mr. Carefree?
description: At the height of the Heisman Trophy hoopla last season, Washington State quarterback Ryan Leaf picked up the telephone and left a message for quarterback Peyton Manning at Tennessee's athletic department. Leaf was afraid that reporters would pit him against Manning and that the two would end up hating each other. His message was akin to a peace offering. Manning returned the call, and over the months, the two became friends.

title: Word & Image; Dishing Darwinian Dirt
description: All this spicy stuff, why do we relish it so? Why do we say we don't really care, then beg the media for more and more?

title: Big Tobacco Is Right to Call Congress's Bluff
description: To the Editor:

title: Shoring Up and Sprucing Up at 3 Land's End Landmarks
description: WITH THE tide of summer tourists nearing, three of the state's historic lighthouses are undergoing renovation work with the hope that all will done by the end of spring.

title: SOAPBOX; The Waste Land
description: IN September, I was sitting in my 1995 Nissan Maxima on the entrance road to Bergen Community College, waiting for my car to explode. Ahead of me were more than 400 cars whose drivers were doing exactly the same thing. Our cars were loaded up, Beverly Hillbillies-style, with what New Jersey officially calls Household Hazardous Waste: old aerosol cans, batteries, barbecue propane tanks, photographic chemicals, varnishes and such.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: SINGING IN THE COMEBACK CHOIR

title: Under Bill, Teen-Agers Could Drive More at Jobs
description: Fifty-nine auto dealers in Washington State say it never occurred to them that they could be breaking the law by giving part-time jobs to 16- and 17-year-olds, some of them students in vocational education programs, some of them disadvantaged minorities and many of them the children of dealership employees.

title: Devils Rebound, And Are Tied For Best Record
description: The Devils' slide briefly carried them out of first place in the race for the National Hockey League's best record today, following victories this afternoon by Detroit and Dallas.

title: Ex-Bosnian Serb Chief Maneuvers
description: There is a 144-page blue paperback book circulating in the Bosnian Serb area of Bosnia, published in Serbo-Croatian and English, with the title ''The Hague Against Justice Revisited: The Case of Dr. Radovan Karadzic.''

title: A Census of Botanical Risk
description: Reminders of the global threat to botanical diversity surround us, but we tend to think of them as disparate events rather than parts of a broad pattern. The forest fires in Indonesia and the Amazon seem unrelated to the spread of purple loosestrife, an invasive wetland plant, across the Northeastern United States. The appearance of a housing development on former oak savanna in California seems unconnected to the destruction of native hemlocks by a parasitic Asian insect called the woolly adelgid.

title: Makeup of American Religion Is Looking More Like Mosaic, Data Say
description: Several mainline Protestant denominations have reported losing fewer members over the last three years, easing a trajectory that once suggested the nation's largest moderate to liberal churches were sliding toward the margins of religious life.

title: The Last Neon Light by the Side Of the Road
description: Mark Jacobson's essay ''The Last Neon Light by the Side of the Road,'' with photographs by Scott Thode, was great (March 15). Hope you guys didn't miss Agent Dana Scully plunking quarters into the Magic Fingers at the Davy Crockett Motor Inn on ''The X-Files'' several weeks ago. For that matter, there have been a number of noirish motels on that show.

title: The Robber's Bride
description: THE HACIENDA

title: The Other Ellis Island
description: During the Korean War, the ''sad'' south side of Ellis Island housed a port security unit of the United States Coast Guard (''The Other Ellis Island,'' photographs by Stephen Wilkes and text by Clyde Haberman, March 22). I served with that unit and was billeted in what had been the ward for immigrants arriving with contagious diseases. I often explored deserted corridors and rooms. A wall of man-size refrigerators in a crumbling autopsy amphitheater remains a vivid memory.

title: Vacation Home Sales: Water Adds Heat
description: THE house on Shore Road in the Cape Cod community of Chatham, Mass., wasn't selling at $500,000. Rather than fix it up, the owner tore it down and is building something new. ''He feels there's a better market at $1 million for a new house,'' said Marie Connolly, owner of Connolly Real Estate in Chatham.

title: Thriving at the Edge of Mr. Buffett's Neighborhood
description: MAYBE it's the air in Omaha. Richard F. Lawson, manager of the Weitz Hickory fund, at first swears that he has no other connection with Warren E. Buffett, who lives just about five miles from him. He has never worked for Mr. Buffett, the legendary sage, or even met him. In fact, he's never even driven by Mr. Buffett's modest suburban house.

title: The Forecast for Saturday
description: How the first round of the draft might shape up. Included in the selections are three projected trades in which teams will swap first-round positions. The trades involve New England and Arizona, Dallas and Oakland, and the Giants and Baltimore. BY MIKE FREEMAN

title: The Tone Is American but the Accent French
description: THE French-born Lannuier brothers -- one a master confectioner, the other a master cabinetmaker -- took the spirit of Paris to New York in the early 19th century. The confectioner, Auguste, filled the windows of his fashionable shop on lower Broadway with fanciful creations like a spun-sugar monument to George Washington. At the back of the store, his younger brother, Charles-Honore, made and sold elegant chairs and tables embellished with lacy gilded ornaments.

title: Strong Stuff
description: Imbibing alcohol is a part of life, and doing so responsibly should be taught as one reaches adulthood (''Strong Stuff,'' by Michael Massing, March 22). A major reason for the rise in binge drinking on campuses is that young people often learn to drink in the back of a car with a case of beer, rather than at a restaurant, bar or nightclub surrounded by adults of all ages. If we want to reduce the deaths from alcohol, we ought to raise the driving age to 21 and lower the drinking age to 16 or 17 (as is the case in many European countries). Young people should learn to drink responsibly before, rather than after, they get behind the wheel of a car.

title: Corrections
description: The Correspondent's Report article on March 29, about stepped-up security at United States airports, included one airline erroneously among those operating at Terminal One at Kennedy Airport, and omitted another. Lufthansa operates at that terminal; British Airways does not.

title: Beyond the Costa Smeralda
description: ''THE land has been humanised, through and through: and we in our own tissued consciousness bear the results of this humanisation,'' D. H. Lawrence observes in ''Sea and Sardinia.'' ''So that for us to go to Italy and to penetrate into Italy is like a most fascinating act of self-discovery -- back, back down the old ways of time.''

title: Stoddard Journal; Two Stores Divide a Town's Loyalty
description: Funny thing, many a visitor comments upon driving into the lakeside hamlet of Stoddard, pop. 640 or so.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SELIGMANN, ELIZABETH SIMON
description: SELIGMANN-Elizabeth Simon, 84, died peacefully in her sleep on April 9. Beloved wife of Arthur for 62 years; loving mother of Jean Seligmann, Mary Ascheim and mother-in-law of Robert Ascheim; dear sister of George Simon; adored grandmother of Thomas, Jane and Nicholas; great-grandmother of Sam, Hannah and Emma, and devoted aunt of 14 nieces and nephews. We will always love you. A memorial service will be announced.

title: Italian, With a Hudson View, in Irvington
description: WITH the balmy days of early summer just ahead, many a diner's fancy will turn to dining out -- outdoors, that is. Winter woollies at fireside will be exchanged happily for sunglasses on terraces, decks and sidewalks.

title: A Great Walk Spoiled
description: THE MASTERS Golf, Money, and Power in Augusta, Georgia. By Curt Sampson. Illustrated. 263 pp. New York: Villard Books. $25.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILL, CHARLES
description: MILL-Charles. 81, of Madison, CT, formerly of Scarsdale, NY. Died Friday, April 10 in the hospice unit at Middlesex Hospital, Middletown, CT. Longtime business magazine publisher, he was president of the American Business Press from 1971-82. At his death, he was a director of the Thomas Publishing Co. He married Jane Baggott Maguire in Providence, RI on July 12, 1941. She survives, as does a son Jeffrey, of Mystic, CT. He was predeceased by another son, Lt. Col. Charles S. Mill Jr., USMC Ret., and by three brothers. He was an Army Air Force Veteran of World War II. A memorial service will be held at St. Margaret RC Church, Madison at noon, April 18. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that donations be made to the Weiss Hospice Unit, Middlesex Hospital, Middletown, CT 06457.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, WALTER JACQUES
description: COHEN-Walter Jacques. Age 36. Died on March 29, 1998. Beloved husband of Deborah. Loving son of Isabelle. Brother of Joseph, Rina and Maureen. Dear uncle, son-in-law and brother-in-law. ''The Lord hath given, the Lord hath taken away''.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: The Bront s: A Life in Letters

title: Whose Building Is It Anyway?
description: GEOVANNY DAVID goes to Housing Court on Wednesday, unsure, she says, if she will go home afterward. She is fighting with landlords determined, she says, to evict her; this time, she says, their tactic is to have her arrested on contempt of court charges. Who will take care of her two daughters, she asks?

title: Duane's Council Seat Is Not Open Yet, but a Line Is Forming
description: For years, gay politics in Manhattan have been divided, with infighting over personalities and power as well as ideological differences. A looming City Council race could deepen the rift.

title: April 5-11; The News on Diversity
description: In 1978, the group representing the nation's newspaper editors pledged that by the year 2000, 15 percent of their newsrooms on average would be black, Asian, Native American or Hispanic.

title: Service Cutbacks Are Planned At Sandy Hook Beaches
description: Starting this summer, visitors to Gateway National Recreation Area at Sandy Hook will have the protection of lifeguards for a shorter period of time, they will have to carry their own trash out with them, and they may have to pay more to get onto the beach. The changes are part of money-saving efforts being made at Sandy Hook and other National Park Service sites countrywide.

title: At Even Par, Steady Teen-Ager Has Reason to Smile
description: Matt Kuchar's grandfather often told him how he would someday walk up the 18th hole at the Masters. Today, thousands cheered as he took that walk. With a sheepish smile and his father as his caddie, the 19-year-old Georgia Tech sophomore shot a four-under-par 68 for even-par 216 going into Sunday's final round, six strokes off the lead.

title: Creative Women at Work in a Century Past
description: A GALLERY of women greets the visitor to the Connecticut River Museum in Essex these days. The exhibition, ''Extraordinary Yankees: Women of the Connecticut River Valley in the Arts and Literature,'' presents biographies of writers, painters, sculptors, musicians and actors, each with period photographs and samples of the subject's work.

title: Starks Admits Impact of His Grandmother's Illness
description: This is the granny who used to wow the kids with a mean jumper, and reveal a playful spirit when setting off the backyard fireworks on the Fourth of July.

title: The Nation: Freedom of Expression; In Europe, Campaign Spending Is a Human Rights Issue
description: IS campaign spending a human right?

title: Princeton Wins The Childs Cup
description: Princeton's men's heavyweight crews swept the Harlem River yesterday, winning the Childs Cup for the fifth consecutive year. The event is the oldest intercollegiate cup race in rowing, dating from 1879. The Tiger varsity, last year's undefeated Ivy and Eastern Sprint champion, defeated Pennsylvania and Columbia, sustaining its undefeated status in its third regatta this season.

title: And What Some Think of His City; Boom Seems to Bypass Those Outside Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: American Blueprint
description: SHAPING A NATION

title: Why I Do What I Do; Howard Smith, I.R.S. Agent
description: They are the most abused, threatened and assaulted workers in the entire Internal Revenue Service. The revenue officers. The Office of Personnel Management identifies them as G.S.-1169's. For short, they call themselves R.O.'s. But in plain English, they are the Federal Government's bill collectors, the men and women dispatched when all else fails to bring in those overdue taxes, even if it means seizing a business to auction its assets. ''I don't know how they do it,'' says David Sullivan, a Federal prosecutor in New Haven. ''I work with F.B.I., D.E.A., Customs, Postal, but the I.R.S. collection guys, without doubt, have the most difficult, the most thankless job.''

title: Style; Creative Accounting
description: Dear Herb, I'm sorry I threw that tantrum and a copy of Allure in your office yesterday. I'll try to come up with some of the receipts you asked for, even though I don't believe in paperwork. As I already explained, I consider being a freelance Muse a totally valid reason for all the deductions I'm taking. With so much income from my inheritances, I have to deduct everything I can, and for me, staying ahead of the fashion curve and being in the public eye are legitimate business expenses.

title: Combative AIDS Group Says City Cut Financing Out of Spite
description: The details of a private conversation within the Giuliani administration last fall have largely been forgotten, but some notes taken at the time spell out the topic: the city's trouble with Housing Works, one of the largest and most outspoken providers of housing for people with AIDS.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Brooklyn Heights; Serenity Looking Out on Stunning Vistas
description: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS is in some ways like a historic theater with no cheap seats and a center aisle, busy Montague Street, leading to a blockbuster scene like no other.

title: Idea Man
description: ERRATA

title: A Boon for Commuters On the Boonton Rail Line
description: The Township of Montclair and New Jersey Transit reached a settlement last week ending a long legal scuffle over the Montclair Connection, a rail link that would permit thousands of commuters in Morris, Passaic and Essex counties to travel by train directly into Manhattan's Pennsylvania Station.

title: Bold, Bolder, Boldest
description: It's not the circus -- it's fashion changing its colors, outside the ready-to-wear collections in Paris last month. Color-mixing and strong patterns contrasted with low-key Chinese designs. The boldest examples, right and below, were by Japanese designers; the coziest, bottom right, were by the English.

title: POSTINGS: $6.6 Million Restoration of an Englewood Theater; An Up-to-Date Recapturing of the Past
description: The John Harms Center for the Performing Arts in Englewood, N.J., will soon undergo a renovation that will modernize the old theater while recapturing the way it looked when it opened as a premier vaudeville house in 1926.

title: Video Explores History of Peekskill Basketball and Players
description: BASKETBALL is so hot that when the Los Angeles Lakers play, celebrities like Jack Nicholson are always courtside.

title: A Straight-Arrow Policeman Turns Loose Cannon at C.I.A.
description: Douglas F. Groat, the former Central Intelligence Agency employee charged with espionage, was a man who went by the book.

title: April 5-11; Tobacco Industry Walks Away From Government Negotiations
description: Realizing that the political winds had turned against them, the leading American cigarette manufacturers announced that they would no longer work with Congress and the Clinton Administration for comprehensive tobacco legislation.

title: Maui Marine Park Opens Hawaiian Waters
description: The Maui Ocean Center, an aquarium and five-acre marine park, opened on March 13, recreating underwater environments of the Hawaiian islands. Visitors can learn how Hawaii's volcanic formations, deep-water channels and isolation from other land masses have combined to create a distinctive reef environment.

title: Where Bread Is Taken Seriously
description: BREAD is such a basic part of our diet that we scarcely think about it: toast for breakfast, slices for sandwiches, rolls for dinner. It's on the shopping list, automatically on the table at restaurants, always beside the soup, and at cookouts arrives in the form of hamburger buns. We eat it every day, and for some of us, raised in the postwar days of ''batter whipped'' bread, we assume it should be soft, spongy white stuff.

title: Rewards Are Posted For Those Tagged Trout
description: New Jersey has 200 lakes, streams and rivers that are accessible to the public for trout fishing, and 170,000 trout were released into these waters for anglers to catch starting yesterday. This year 1,000 of those fish were tagged by the state Division of Fish, Game and Wildlife in an effort to learn more about the fish.

title: TELEVISION; Solutions for a Nation Where Children Kill
description: IN the mid-1990's, a young American man age 15 to 24 was 37 times as likely to die by homicide as his counterpart in England, and more than 60 times as likely as a young man in Japan. Three-quarters of all homicide deaths among children under 15 in the entire industrial world took place in the United States.

title: State of Withdrawal
description: LIFT EVERY VOICE Turning a Civil Rights Setback Into a New Vision of Social Justice. By Lani Guinier. 336 pp. New York: Simon & Shuster. $25.

title: Lives; Family Worship
description: Easter always piques the curiosity of my agnostic friends, and they ask, ''How can a skeptic like you be a practicing Catholic? I remind them of what my grandmother once had inside her house: a church. Growing up, this didn't seem unusual, not for south Louisiana. My cousins, my siblings and I would barrel in from the backyard covered in grass stains and dog slobber and romp through the kitchen toward the one-room chapel, where my Uncle Wil, a Roman Catholic priest, would be waiting in his robes. With a pork roast in the oven and dirty-rice dressing on the stove, Uncle Wil made quick work saying Mass -- no hymns, a few readings, skip the sermon and head straight into holy communion.

title: April 5-11; A Record Mega-Merger
description: The differences between banking, Wall Street and insurance have been blurring for years, and two of the biggest financial services companies, Citicorp and Travelers Group, eliminated them altogether. They announced a merger that would be the biggest in any industry to date.

title: Stodgy, But Not Without Some Oomph
description: BANK funds are for losers. At least that is the general perception about the 1,700 mutual funds run by banks.

title: The Nation's Pulse, in Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Updating the Residential Space at a Y.W.C.A.
description: IN Lillian Beckford's youth the residences that the Young Women's Christian Association ran in urban centers mainly provided temporary housing to young women living in unfamiliar surroundings after a relocation from out of town.

title: Sunday, April 12, 1998; NOT QUITE BIGFOOT
description: For years, folks in Darrington, Wash., a logging town 60 miles northeast of Seattle, talked about ''the mountain man,'' a mysterious figure who supposedly lived high on the slopes of Whitehorse Mountain and came down to plunder cabins on occasion. Last month, trackers solved the mystery, capturing Mincio Donciev, a 67-year-old Bulgarian on the run from a criminal charge back home. A few weeks later, they found Donciev's 4-by-6-foot hideout halfway up the mountain. ''It was elaborate, a miniature log cabin dug under a tree with walls, a floor and a ceiling,'' says Matt Condon, a tracker. Donciev has said little since his capture and faces trial on state burglary charges -- after he recovers from dog bites he suffered while trying to escape.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: A GOOD DOCTOR'S SON

title: Diana Epstein, a Passionate Seller of Buttons, Dies at 61
description: Diana Epstein, a onetime New York book editor whose prosaic need to replace some plastic (ugh!) buttons on a stylish new jacket led her down a rabbit hole of miniature wonder into an enchanted world awash in buttons, died on April 3 at Beth Israel Hospital North near her tiny town house on the Upper East Side. She was 61 and a founding proprietor of Tender Buttons, the small East 62d Street shop devoted exclusively, ecstatically, extravagantly to buttons.

title: TAKING THE CHILDREN
description: Ride

title: Commercial Property/Harlem; Around 125th Street, New Interest and Optimism
description: IF your mother had a fur coat, the chances are that it spent its summers in Harlem. The brick building at Amsterdam Avenue and 126th Street was a fur-storage center for almost 50 years, with armored trucks carrying the coats from retailers across the city for storage during warm weather months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GIZELT, CHARLES
description: GIZELT-Charles. Born March 9, 1914 in Fiume, Austria (now Croatia), passed away April 8, 1998. Charles majored in Politial Science at the University of Rome, Italy. He came to America in 1951, and worked in Manhattan as a wine consultant specializing in Italian wine imports. He became a Manhattan icon, known for his profound knowledge of the art of winemaking, and was frequently quoted in many publications. He tirelessly commuted to New York from Stamford Connecticut where he ultimately retired and lived for the past 13 years. A violinist, opera and classical music enthusiast and avid soccer fan, Charles touched many and inspired all who knew him to live life with passion and purpose. He leaves behind his beloved wife of 52 years, Italia, and loving children Renata Castiglia and Alessandra Formentin of Stamford, Paul Gizelt of Rhode Island, and grandchildren Marc, Neal, Joshua, David and Justin. We will miss you, Carlo, your charm and smile will always have a special place in our memories.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAW, RAY
description: SHAW-Ray. Broadway singer and nightclub entrepreneur, died of congestive heart failure on March 24. He was 71. Shaw is survived by his wife Carole, daughters Lori and Victoria, and grandchildren Joshua, Drew and Logan.

title: Voters League Seeks Reform In Campaigns
description: CAMPAIGN finance reform may be dead on the Federal level, but the League of Women Voters of Westchester County is determined to resurrect it at the county level.

title: The Triple Crown Isn't Just for Horse Lovers
description: It is Triple Crown festival time again. The Kentucky Derby Festival in Louisville begins Friday, two weeks before the 124th run for the roses on May 2 at Churchill Downs. General admission tickets for race day remain available, for $30, from (502) 636-4402.

title: Wowing the Crowd
description: THE best portobello mushroom I've eaten in a decade (and I was sick of them by 1990) was served at Grissini Trattoria. Slick, expensive, glitzy and full of itself, the famously haughty restaurant serves excellent mushrooms.

title: QUICK BITE/Edgewater; A Sure Sign of Spring, From Across the Pacific
description: In Japan, throngs of people have been taking to the outdoors for the last week or so, sitting and strolling in the parks day and night under graceful branches from which blossoms of the palest pink and white cascade. Yes, it's cherry blossom time.

title: Coalition and Builder Battle in Riverhead
description: When the East End's principal business was farming, Riverhead was the commercial hub for both forks of Long Island. But for almost 20 years, while South Fork towns have boomed as chic resorts and second-home havens, and the North Fork has evolved into elegant wine country, Riverhead, a town of 23,000, has been languishing. And for almost as long, the town's preservationists, planners and Main Street merchants have been arguing with large-scale commercial developers over the real key to Riverhead's rebirth.

title: A Devotion to Healing Through Prayer
description: IT was a picture perfect life, all right, for Nigel W. D. Mumford, a transplanted Englishman: a thriving picture-framing business in Wilton, president of the Wilton Rotary Club, a comfortable home he shared with his wife, Catherine, in Newtown; a dog, a boat and, in his words, ''plenty of other toys.''

title: Hartford Ponders Billboards and a Park
description: FOR Brad Comer, a Hartford resident, life has always been connected to the city's Pope Park. ''I got four stitches on the side of my nose from playing basketball there -- I love the park and want to be a part of it.''

title: Sharing in a Sudden Wealth of String Quartets
description: GREAT Performers at Lincoln Center just completed a musical lecture series titled ''What Makes It Great?'' That question came to mind during last week's magnificent concert at Alice Tully Hall in Manhattan by the Emerson String Quartet, which performs at McCarter Theater in Princeton tomorrow night.

title: At the Bull-Market Party, Distributions Cause a Hangover
description: APRIL is a month for cruel surprises. And if you're a late tax filer just getting ready to tear into your mutual fund's distributions statement for 1997, you may very well be in for a big one.

title: Rancor Eases As the Koreas Open Talks After 4 Years
description: In a basement hotel conference room, North and South Korean officials held their first face-to-face talks in almost four years today, breaking a long, hostile silence with friendly overtures.

title: It May Be Your Rush-Hour Route, But It's His Store
description: Mike Ali has parked his white van along Jersey Avenue near the Holland Tunnel most days in the last four years. This is where he sets up shop, literally.

title: INSIDE
description: MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 8/

title: Q&A/William Hughes Mulligan Jr.; Son Remembers Judge's Humor and Wit
description: FOR years, William Hughes Mulligan was in demand as an after-dinner speaker. A lawyer who became dean of Fordham Law School, then a Federal judge, then a resignee from the bench because it paid too little and a lawyer again, he was funny and knew how to be brief. It was his Irish wit that other judges wanted at their retirement dinners; it was his ability to turn a phrase and surreptiously throw in a serious remark that brought him invitation after invitation.

title: MAKING IT WORK; Stacked
description: THEY no longer belch black plumes, but Manhattan's surviving smokestacks are graceful, ghostly reminders of an era when manufacturing drove the city's economy. Today, these idle tapering towers rise above power plants and old factories along the city's rivers.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  JACOBS, NATHAN
description: JACOBS-Nathan. Dear husband & best friend. Incredibly ''yesterday'' is 6 years and I miss you and will love you always-Julia

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: Waiting for Fidel By Christopher Hunt. Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, paper, $13.

title: Passion That Built A Museum Collection
description: FROM the last quarter of the 19th century through the first decade of the 20th, American museums raced to collect prime American Indian artifacts. They were acting, in part, out of a fear that the Indians' culture would soon disappear. The extensive Indian collection of the Montclair Art Museum grew out of this attitude. It numbers more than 4,000 objects, of which 1,500 were acquired for the museum from 1911 to 1929 by Grace Nicholson, a dealer in Pasadena, Calif. The current exhibition ''Collecting Culture'' illuminates Nicholson's methods and attitudes through 150 of these items.

title: Escalator Repair Is Double Jolt to Riders at West 4th
description: For Carl Tendler, a resident of Waverly Place who had quadruple bypass surgery last year, the two escalators inside the West Fourth Street subway station offered a small measure of relief. Granted, he still had to climb some stairs once he arrived at the station after a wearying day, but the escalators spared him and other riders two tiring flights in the four-story station.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: April 12, 1998
description: Weeks

title: The World: East and Eden; America Is Prosperous and Smug, Like Japan Was
description: COMPARING Japan's raw hubris in the late 1980's and America's in the late 90's has become the latest international parlor game. To economic forecasters, dispensers of global-sounding sound bites and nervous investors -- and who isn't nervous? -- the eerie similarities are a reminder of what can happen when boom times beget a boom psychology. First, Americans were sounding more and more like the Japanese did in late 1989, just before they reached the mountaintop and blindly stepped into the void. Now, by some measures, Americans are beginning to act like them too.

title: Savoring the Rich, Earthy Flavors of Toulouse
description: PROSPERITY begets restaurants. And Toulouse, France's aeronautics capital, a telecommunications research center and a university town, has sired a staggering multiplicity of places to dine: auteur-driven temples of haute cuisine, grand cafes, simple bistros and, thanks to its large immigrant population, an abundance of foreign establishments, from tapas bars to salsa clubs to Korean grills. La Ville Rose, as Toulouse is called because of the pink-orange bricks used in its architecture, draws on a rich gastronomic heritage as well. It gave birth to one of the classic versions of cassoulet -- with duck confit and Toulouse sausages. Other mainstays of its table overlap with those of neighboring regions: foie gras, confit and truffles as in Perigord and Quercy; brandade de morue and tapenade from the Midi (Toulouse, at the western edge of Languedoc, is 95 miles from the Mediterranean).

title: For the Belmondo Look
description: When Peter Kearnan travels to Paris, he always packs his Pierre Emile Lafaurie shirts. An executive for an international advertising agency in Manhattan, he goes to Paris about once a month and became hooked on buying them there. ''When I heard they were carrying them at Sean, I had heart palpitations,'' he said. ''I bought a bunch for myself, a few for my brother and a couple for my dad.'' Sean, at 132 Thompson Street (Prince Street), which opened last September, is the sole American seller of the traditional men's cotton shirts. They come in 23 shades and cost $88. Lavende (lavender) and bleu royale (royal blue) are the most popular. The shop's owner, Sean Cassidy -- no, not that Sean Cassidy -- was approached by the Mercer Hotel to outfit its staff in lavender, and he is negotiating. ''The nice thing about these shirts is people collect them,'' he said. ''They go with a tie or a pair of jeans.''

title: A Cool, Clear Vision From a Distant Land
description: LOUISA MATTHIASDOTTIR'S paintings include still lifes, landscapes, animal studies and portraits, but amid all these traditional motifs, there is another recurrent, underlying theme to her work: the color blue. Just as it sometimes seems as if the secret goal of the painters of the Venetian Renaissance was to put the appropriate admixture of red in their paintings, so as to lend each one the pulsating warmth of circulating blood, Ms. Matthiasdottir seems inclined to endow everything she paints with the cool, refreshing clarity of a cloudless sky.

title: Rare Breed
description: David Miller's LONELY ARE THE BRAVE (1962) is a ''sleeper'' worthy of any screen buff. The picture opened quietly in New York as the lower half of a double-bill, drew rave reviews and promptly slid into oblivion. Beautifully crafted, from a sensitive script by Dalton Trumbo, it depicts the plight of an aging, misfit cowboy buffeted by fate and modern realities. Kirk Douglas's tense performance, which ranks up there with his Vincent van Gogh in ''Lust for Life,'' carries the picture through to its rueful conclusion. There is sturdy flanking by Gena Rowlands as a sympathetic woman and Walter Matthau as a relentless sheriff. Mr. Douglas made bigger pictures, but seldom a better one -- Saturday at 9 P.M on Channel 13. Howard Thompson

title: A Retired Priest's Art Form Is Unorthodox Yet Orthodox

''It's called 'writing,' '' he explained, ''because the tradition of painting Orthodox icons is akin to a translation of Scripture. It's the word of God conveyed by visual image.''

title: Editorial Observer; The Quota Bashers Come In From the Cold
description: California's decision to outlaw the use of race in public college admissions was widely viewed as a death sentence for affirmative action. But Proposition 209 may actually have saved its life. The abruptly diminished black and Latino enrollment in California has raised the specter of ''white-outs'' not just on campus but in the professions and in the next generation of state leadership. Californians are looking for ways to undo the mess and other states have been frightened into slowing down. A recent survey by The Chronicle of Higher Education finds legislatures from South Carolina to South Dakota back-pedaling furiously from California-style proposals. Texas has ordered its university to accept any student who finishes in the top 10 percent of a public high school.

description: Ken Miller has tried every remedy on Earth to try to treat a crippling condition that leaves his brain starving for blood whenever he stands up.

title: PULSE; Fashion Spoken Here
description: For Ana Abdul and Lipe Medelros, Brazilian artists, your style is your language. The couple's store, Language, opened this month at 238 Mulberry Street (Prince Street), in hopes of luring shoppers with global tastes. It combines furniture, housewares and art with avant-garde clothing from a veritable United Nations of designers, like Fred Sathal of Paris and Amaya Arzuago of Madrid. The clothes range from $47.50 for a T-shirt to $2,150 for a beaded Sathal dress.

title: After the Ball
description: NO TIME TO DIE

title: Mayor Says Release Of Records Is Likely
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that he hoped city officials would abide by a State Supreme Court judge's order to release records of former welfare recipients, unless the city needed a higher court's ruling to avoid lawsuits by the former recipients.

title: The Nation; A Double Latte Is Just Another Way to Be Cool
description: THE coffee culture has become a teen-age concept. One Starbucks coffee shop in New York City is standing room only for the under-18 set on weekend nights, and both the beverage and the hangout seem to have parents' blessings.

title: Itzhak Perlman In Concert
description: BACK in September, the Westchester Philharmonic began its 15th-anniversary season with the pianist Andre Watts. Next Saturday at 8 P.M. and next Sunday at 3 P.M. at Purchase College, another superstar, the violinist Itzhak Perlman, is continuing what Paul Lustig Dunkel, the Philharmonic's music director, calls ''our biggest season ever.''

title: When School Spirit Is on the Shopping List
description: BOOKS? Sure, college bookstores sell books. That's 65 percent of their business nationwide. But they also sell computer products (8.5 percent), magazines and popular books (6.7 percent), school supplies, including old-fashioned pencils and paper (7.9 percent), candy and a host of life's other miscellaneous necessities (6.5 percent).

title: April 5-11; Rewiring Urged
description: Still without a precise cause of the TWA 800 crash more than 20 months ago, aviation authorities are moving toward very broad cures. The aircraft that exploded was an old Boeing 747, but the National Transportation Safety Board recommended extensive wiring changes on numerous models of passenger jets, Boeings and others, many of which the Federal Aviation Administration said it already had in mind. Meanwhile, airlines are moving toward permanent changes in jet fuel, which should prevent fuel tank explosions, no matter what the cause. MATTHEW L. WALD

title: Succeeding Modestly Where The Mozarts Failed Miserably
description: IT is the Mozart story with a few twists. The father, a violin teacher of local renown, hoped that his son would become a violinist of genius. Sensing early talent, the father determined to promote the child as a prodigy. He gave up his teaching position and devoted all his energy to the boy. For 16 years, he was his son's only teacher, and he is still his manager. The mother was also drafted into this cottage industry as piano accompanist.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  RUBIN, IRA L.
description: RUBIN-Ira L., M.D. A Memorial Tribute and Reception celebrating the life of Ira L. Rubin, M.D. will be held Mon., April 20, 1998 beginning at 4 PM in Cherkasky Auditorium at Montefiore Medical Center, 111 East 210th Street, Bronx, NY. Dr. Rubin was Director of Electrocardiography at Montefiore Medical Center and Emeritus Professor of Clinical Medicine at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the Gazetteer chart last Sunday about Muttontown, N.Y., misstated the acreage with a house at 10 Brookville Road. It is 5.25 acres, not 25.

title: A Hand With a Tan
description: Salons in New York are finding that lots of people will pay for something they can easily get at home: an application of self-tanning lotion to mimic that natural sun-kissed glow. The Equinox Spa at 140 East 63d Street has now hired a full-time esthetician just to apply self-tanner. Why not do it yourself? Mary Greendale, a Wall Street analyst and Equinox client, said: ''I grew up with QT and suffered through spring with an orange glow. I feel pampered having someone apply my tan, and I don't have streaks and tan lines.'' The hourlong treatment, $85, includes a coarse-salt body rubdown, moisturizer and application of lotion.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Fifth Avenue will be closed between 49th and 57th Streets from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. today for the Easter Parade.

title: Investors Seek Sale Of Nuveen
description: IT is, undoubtedly, a quixotic quest: A little-known analyst at an even less-known money management firm tries to get a giant fund group to put itself up for sale.

title: EARNING IT; Deadlines, Dismissals and Health
description: BEING a manager is tough work. Now, it turns out, it may pose a serious and potentially deadly health risk, too.

title: El Nino Persuades The Deserts to Bloom
description: The heavy rains in California this winter, while certainly destructive and sometimes deadly, have spawned a riot of life in the desert that has not been matched for several years. Normally arid and sunburned, the Mojave and Sonoran Deserts have been transformed into colorful gardens of flowers. At many Southern California and Arizona parks, staff members report extraordinary landscapes of blooming verbena, primrose and brittle bush. In some places, cactus are flowering among the thorns until the petals wither away in the heat in late spring.

title: Nguyen Co Thach, Hanoi Foreign Minister, 75
description: Former Foreign Minister Nguyen Co Thach of Vietnam, the urbane diplomat who struggled but failed to normalize relations with the United States in the 1980's, died on Friday at the age of 75, foreign diplomats in Hanoi said today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSYNS, MAX
description: COSYNS-Max. Anne, his daughter, mourns the loss of Max Cosyns - Mathematician - Nuclear Physicist-Researcher-Pioneer of the stratosphere, the bathyscaphe, the caverns. Hero of the Resistance, survivor of the Nazi death camps. A Renaissance man of Peace, courage and compassionand the best Dad.

title: Making Short Work Of Long Commutes
description: IF you think you have a long commute, consider where a typical day may take Richard Jacobs. From his home in Nantucket, Mass., it is down to Washington to meet with fellow officers of the Futures Industry Association; then to Charlottesville, Va., where he lectures at the University of Virginia; then back to Nantucket or, if needed the next morning at the Manhattan headquarters of CTC Fund Management, where he is director of business development, to his pied-a-terre in Englewood, N.J.

title: Gas Plan Draws More Opposition
description: OPPOSITION continues to mount to a proposal by Columbia Gas Transmission to thread a 422-mile pipeline from Lake Erie in Canada through Rockland and Westchester Counties as far as Mount Vernon.

title: Adding a Couch To the Calculator; As April 15 Looms, Accountants Turn Into Therapists
description: Like many wage earners, Dan Shulman, a freelance cinematographer, hates everything about tax time -- pulling together the paperwork, assessing his productivity over the last year, paying the Government. ''I do feel very vulnerable in that moment of having to discuss my finances,'' he confided.

title: U.S. Bill Has Egypt's Copts Squirming
description: A proposed American law aimed at reducing persecution of religious minorities abroad has aroused anger here, even among the people it is intended to help, and has brought an outcry against American interference in the domestic affairs of other nations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHANOK, JESSE PAUL ''YSAYE''
description: SHANOK-Jesse Paul ''Ysaye'', on April 10th. in East Brunswick, NJ. Beloved husband of Toby Gross Shanok; devoted father of Frederick D., Dede Shanok Drucker and Amy Volpe; adored brother of Victor, and Pearl Zale; loved grandfather of 10. Services on Monday April 13, 1998 at 2 PM in the Schwartz Brothers Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard, Forest Hills. Interment to follow in the Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, New York.

title: Let Juries Decide Whether Lie Detectors Lie
description: To the Editor:

title: Carried by the Wind in Sicily
description: LAST spring, I took a couple of days to roam through 28 centuries of history on the northwest coast of Sicily, in the province of Trapani. There, I visited the windmills of Marsala, the Phoenician island of Motya and the heights of Erice, an ancient town perched 1,873 feet above the Mediterranean.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Postings column on March 15 about redeveloping the former Arthur Hammerstein estate misspelled the name of the estate's Queens neighborhood. It is Beechhurst, not Beechurst.

title: Unconventional Wisdom: Newest Can Be Best
description: WHEN Fidelity Investments recently offered two new mutual funds, conventional wisdom would have dictated: steer clear. After all, the common opinion among mutual fund experts is to wait until a fund builds a track record before taking a plunge.

title: And What Some Think of His City; Boom Seems to Bypass Those Outside Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENHALL, ARTHUR M.
description: GREENHALL-Arthur M. On April 8, 1998. Beloved husband of Elizabeth. Dear father of Alice and Paul Greenhall. Grandfather of Michael Arthur Greenhall. Arthur was a zoologist who specialized in vampire bats. Reposing at Redden Funeral Home, 325 West 14 Street, NYC on Monday, April 13, 7-9 PM. An informal service at 8 P.M.

title: Evidence Is Scant That Workfare Leads to Full-Time Jobs
description: Three years ago, when a national overhaul of welfare was still a Republican dream in Washington, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani began his own ambitious experiment. At its heart was a vast expansion of workfare -- sending tens of thousands of New Yorkers into parks, city offices and hospital wards to work for their welfare checks.

title: Audits Spread Unevenly Across U.S.
description: Nothing touches off panic in taxpayers more than the prospect of an audit. But there are such wide disparities across the country in who gets audited that residents in New York City and its suburbs continue to be treated with kid gloves by the Internal Revenue Service while those in California have been hit comparatively hard.

title: Airlines Scramble To Add Flights to Japan
description: Despite the economic softening in Japan, United States airlines have been quick to jockey for permission to fly there more frequently and on new routes since the Jan. 30 signing of an airline agreement between the United States and Japan ending most restrictions on travel between the two countries.

title: Protecting the Press
description: Imagine going to work each day knowing that a job well done could end your life. You change your children's schools, hire a bodyguard and drive to work with one eye on the rearview mirror. This sounds like a James Bond movie, but it's reality for many journalists in Latin America and the Caribbean, where reporters are often independent, front-line soldiers in both the battle against drugs and corruption and the struggle to deepen democracy.

title: April 5-11; Race and the Death Sentence
description: Is America's death penalty racist? A body of evidence suggests that it is: cases in which the crime is the same but punishment differs. A special United Nations investigator has issued a report asserting that skin color is a ''key determinant'' in consigning prisoners to death row. The report urged the United States to halt all executions until it can show that this ultimate punishment is doled out fairly. The racism is at its worst, the report said, in the deep South. HUBERT B. HERRING

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LIEBERMAN, MORRIS
description: LIEBERMAN-Morris, 86, Died April 7, King of the Gate Crashers, leaves an unparalleled legacy, mementoes of royalty and stars, surpassed only by his love for Fay, his wife of more than sixty years, children, grandchildren and greatgrandchildren.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEALEY, BARBARA CAHILL
description: HEALEY-Barbara Cahill. On April 11, 1998. Mother of Robin H. Gibson. Grandmother of Kaley H. Gibson. Mother-in-law of Gary T. Gibson. Daughter of Helen F. Cahill and the late Robert L. Cahill. Sister of Robert L. Cahill, Jr. Mass of The Resurrection Tuesday, April 14, 11 AM, St. Thomas More Church, 65 E. 89 St. In lieu of flowers, contributions in her memory may be made to the St. Aloysius School, 223 W. 132 St., NYC 10027.

description: THE explosion of communications methods spurred by the Internet has transformed the work of an important but little known part of every securities firm: the compliance office.

Maybe there was a professional photographer who carefully posed everyone, then mailed off proofs of the pictures to one person, who forwarded them to another, who forwarded them to a third. And maybe you waited and waited for final pictures of the happy day.

description: MY intention, honest, was not to scar these Japanese kids for life. I just wanted to give them a fun game to play.

title: Nursery School Celebrates 50th Anniversary in Yorktown
description: THE wooden easels still have the same kinds of paintings displayed on them, resplendent in primary colors and enthusiastic brush strokes. The unforgettable smell of Play-Doh, mixed with the aroma of apple juice, permeates the air as if conjured up by some Proustian memory. The tidy cubbies hold smocks and sneakers, construction-paper art projects and stuffed animals, the comforting talismans of preschoolers.

title: Hasidic Housing a Letdown
description: When the former Bommer Hinge factory, at 263 Classon Avenue, near Willoughby Avenue, was converted into 91 spacious condominium apartments, many Hasidic families from Williamsburg thought they had found relief from their neighborhood's chronic housing shortage and gracious shelter for their large families.

title: Sculptures Figure in Two Shows in Yonkers
description: MOST restored buildings look like illusions, but those in the downtown section of this city are illusions, for they were painted by the master of trompe l'oeil, Richard Haas. These Yonkers facades are startling as works of art and even more so as evidence of the city fathers' efforts to abolish drabness with help from both the public and private sectors.

title: Old Places, New Faces
description: SATURDAY is not Nathilee Caldeira's Sabbath, yet she feels a certain reverence for the day. As Orthodox Jews dressed for worship walk to synagogues, she and other blacks in the neighborhood go about their business. They do so with an understanding that it is a sacred day. ''Somehow on Saturdays, nobody really gets crazy,'' she said.

title: A Failing Grade For School Report Cards
description: I went to school in New York City. Some very fine teachers taught me that newspapers report the news, the facts only. Your newspaper seems to create the news. I refer to your ''Report Cards for Middle and High Schools'' (March 22) and creative little boxes as part of your school report card. It is unheard of that a newspaper would decide what makes a school's reading performance better. You indicate that reading performance ''is based on percentage of students at reading mastery level, after adjusting for student family income and percentage of students with limited English proficiency.'' Who decided on these criteria? What about the transiency rate? How was ''family income'' decided upon? How much weight was given to each category?

title: First Lessons in the Power of Money
description: THE eighth graders at Macopin Middle School in West Milford, N.J., a rural town about 40 miles northwest of Manhattan, are learning some basic lessons about economics.

title: Backtalk; The Day It Rained Candy Bars
description: Can it really be 20 years ago? It seems as if both more and less should have happened in that time -- like George Steinbrenner imploding under the mass of his own bile. It's hard to believe that, instead, both Thurman Munson and Billy Martin are gone, and the bald spot on Reggie Jackson's head is growing steadily, like some expanding halo.

title: To Florida, Land Of Empty Tees
description: LIKE a number of golfers I know, I have the Groucho problem. Even if I could afford it, I wouldn't dream of joining any country club that would consent to admit me. For people like us in the New York area, where public courses are both few and desperately overcrowded, this particular philosophy poses enormous hardships and indignities.

title: Ehrlichiosis Study
description: A three-year, $220,000 grant from the National Institutes of Health will be used to track ehrlichiosis, the most recently discovered tick-borne disease, researchers at the Louis Calder Center of Fordham University in Armonk announced last week. The researchers will conduct blood testing on dogs to determine the rate and location of ''hot spots'' for infection, said Richard Falco, the study's principal investigator.

title: No Ordinary Woman
description: Pearl C. Scher, 83, a Somers Councilwoman, says she is an ordinary woman, but the Women's Federation for World Peace, a United Nations affiliate, thinks otherwise and recently named her one of its 1998 Women of the Year.

description: High fashion sportswear? Iceberg resolves the paradox as it opens its first New York store at 772 Madison Avenue, between 66th and 67th Streets. The brand used to be associated with sweaters featuring cartoon characters, but it has gone exotic with spangled short skirts, knit dresses, translucent tank tops and metallic vinyl hooded jackets.

description: To the Editor: The first section of the Sunday Times I reach for is the Travel section, and the monthly Deals and Discounts column by Janet Piorko is the first thing I read.

title: Name That Goop And Make It Personal
description: JOHN SAHAG, his green leather pants slung low around his waist, was snipping bits of a client's hair with studied care. He finished the cut, lit a Camel and explained why he started his own line of shampoos, conditioners and styling goop. ''It's not about selling things,'' said Mr. Sahag, whose salon is at 49th Street and Madison Avenue. ''We are obsessed with beauty, and people who dig that will buy our products.''

description: To the Editor:

title: ART; Capturing Sleek Subjects That Refuse to Be Still
description: EVER since the late 1880's, when a boy named Frank Beken peered in curiosity through the window of his father's chemist shop in Cowes, on the Isle of Wight, and caught sight of a packed harbor of towering masts and flapping sails, a member of the Beken family has been photographing yachts. In the last 100 years, the family has amassed one of the world's largest archives of maritime photographs, and in Britain and sailing circles around the globe, the Bekens have become known as the Old Masters of marine photography. An exhibition of 45 Beken prints now at the South Street Seaport Museum shows why.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NANCE, ARLENE
description: NANCE-Arlene. Died April 8, 1998 at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital. She was the loving wife of Harry and mother of Erica. She served her community in her work at Educational Facilities Laboratory of the Ford Foundation, the New York Civil Liberties Union and as a social worker in several agencies. In 1981 she joined Ambrose Mar-Elia as a real estate broker and became a specialist in Greenwich Village townhouses. She was devoted to preserving the historic character of the buildings and her neighborhood. She was loved by many and will be sadly missed. Contributions may be made to the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation, 47 Fifth Ave., NYC 10003. A memorial service will be announced later. Harry Nance and Erica Nance

title: In New York, as in Belfast, A Blend of Irish Voices

title: A Man Who Stored Memories in Rooms and on Streets
description: In some of his more unusual theatrical creations, Peter Brook has explored the dramatic possibilities offered by the workings of the brain, most famously in his 1960's production of Peter Weiss's ''Marat/Sade,'' set in a Paris insane asylum in the early years of the French Revolution, and most recently in ''L'Homme Qui,'' inspired by Oliver Sacks's study ''The Man Who Mistook His Wife for a Hat.''

title: She's a Free Spirit, Forever Toying With Men
description: When the Met first staged Janacek's ''Makropulos Case'' two years ago, the central role of Emilia Marty, the deathless diva, was sung by Jessye Norman. In this exciting first revival, which opened on Saturday night, the part has been taken over by Catherine Malfitano, who sweeps through the production like a breath of fresh air, one might say, though the atmosphere that emanates from her is also musty and decadent.

title: On Internet, Playing Fair May Mean Paying Up
description: An old adage swirled around the Federal Communications Commission last week as it proposed levying network access fees against some companies that provide telephone service over the Internet.

title: Phone Competition, Finally
description: Bell Atlantic may well become the first regional Bell company to enter long-distance service. In exchange, Bell Atlantic will relinquish its monopoly over local phone service by opening up its wires and switches to AT&T, M.C.I. and other carriers. Bell Atlantic's plan, engineered by the New York State Public Service Commission, is good for consumers. It creates competition for local service among companies that offer both local and long-distance service with the convenience of one monthly bill.

title: Pope's Words On Easter Call For Dialogue Toward Peace
description: Pope John Paul II delivered a grave and at times dark Easter message today, warning about the ''fratricidal strife and slaughter'' that are still ''sowing in the earth the seed of death.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABELES, ELIZABETH F.
description: ABELES-Elizabeth F. Age 72. Died early Sunday, April 12. Beloved wife of the late Lowell Abeles. Beloved mother of Andrew, Abigail Spirer, Marjorie Vangenewitt, Clifford Abeles and seven grandchildren, Jennifer, Jeffrey, Jeremy, Grant, Elinor, Lowell and Jack. Loving sister of the late William Frank. Elizabeth is survived by her sister-in-law Arynne Simon and brother-in-law Morris Gerstenhaber. Throughout her life, Elizabeth devoted many hours of service to the blind, teaching literacy and other community related activities. Funeral service will be held at RiversidePark West Chapel, 333 Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY, on Wednesday, April 15, at 12:15 PM. Visitation one hour prior. Family suggests contributions be made to Visions or donor's choice.

description: Mets Manager Bobby Valentine saw what happened to Bobby Jones last season after Jones developed a sore lower back. This time around, Valentine is being extra cautious to make sure it does not happen again.

In her Las Vegas, Nev., living room, she relaxes to music and watches her fireplace, not her television, from one of her two new La-Z-Boy armchairs.

But in recent years, as Idahoans have become more and more disenchanted with the Federal Government's heavy presence in the state's ranching, wilderness and mining regions, Idaho has tilted heavily Republican, to the point that it is now one of the Republican Party's most reliable strongholds.

title: The New Party of Pork

But now that they control Congress and are facing surpluses instead of deficits, the party is more divided over budget policy than it has been in a generation. There is confusion about which, if any, tax cuts to favor. Some members have developed a strong taste for pork. Their divisions give President Clinton an upper hand not contemplated a year ago.

title: When Memories of Artistry Do Not Play Any Tricks

title: Mission to Afghanistan

That gives Washington special responsibility to work for an end to the fighting and greater respect for human rights, especially those of women victimized by Islamic fundamentalist rule.

It commissioned big-band arrangements of his compositions from the 1960's through the 90's, placing early-70's pieces in the context of his long career. Mr. Corea joined the band with his trio, including Avishai Cohen on bass and Adam Cruz on drums.

title: Social Security's Gender Gap
description: Proposals to reform Social Security by allowing individuals to open personal retirement accounts are attracting bipartisan support. These accounts, which could be invested in stocks and bonds, would provide a much higher rate of return than the present pay-as-you-go system. But there is a risk that the existing inequality of income between elderly men and elderly women will become worse if these accounts are introduced without adjusting for the different work patterns of men and women.

title: A Valuable Guide to Successful Aging
description: ONCE in a great while an outstanding health book comes along that should be featured on every radio and television talk show and in every major newspaper. Yet it fails to attract the attention it deserves because it isn't ''sexy'' enough. It doesn't rashly promise that you can live healthfully to 100 if only you would take this, that or the other pill, potion or supplement.

description: Since winning the race for Mayor last month, Andrei Klimentyev has had some trouble meeting with his constituents.

description: The Microsoft Corporation will announce on Tuesday that it will begin selling the long-awaited version of its Windows 98 operating system on June 25.

title: Court Weighs Execution of Foreigner
description: The Supreme Court is considering whether to intervene in a Virginia death penalty case that has unusual international implications as well as possibly unsettling consequences for thousands of other cases involving the incarceration of foreign citizens in American prisons.

title: For Final Shuttle Science Mission, a Payload of Brain Studies
description: NASA is about to launch the last space shuttle mission devoted to scienctific experiments in this century, as it prepares to devote its resources to assembling the International Space Station. The shuttle mission, known as Neurolab, will offer a flourish of scientific and technological firsts. They include the initial mission devoted entirely to the study of neuroscience and the first space tests involving virtual reality.

title: Defensive Formation
description: Like a football team of little guys in tight formation, tiny bacteria organize themselves with a set of signals to collectively ward off their antibiotic enemies, scientists have reported.

description: AH, the heady days of gasoline shortages, when ingenious remedies bloomed like the flowers of spring!

title: Mothers Poised for Workfare Face Acute Lack of Day Care
description: In the Bronx, a city caseworker searching for licensed baby sitters finds only six names in her computer, and all six have let their certification expire. She prints the useless list for a welfare mother with worried eyes and says, ''You'll just have to do the best you can.''

description: ABELES-Elizabeth F. Age 72. Died early on Sunday, April 12th. Beloved wife of the late Lowell Abeles. Beloved mother of Andrew, Abigail Spirer, Marjorie Vangenewitt, Clifford Abeles and seven grandchildren, Jennifer, Jeffrey, Jeremy, Grant, Elinor, Lowell and Jack. Throughout her life, Elizabeth devoted many hours of service to the blind, teaching literacy and other community related activities. Funeral service will be held at RiversidePark West Chapel, 333 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY, on Wednesday, April 15, at 12:15 PM. Visitation one hour prior. Family suggests contributions be made to Visions or donor's choice.

title: Ex-Newark Mayor Seeks to Pioneer as County Executive
description: Kenneth A. Gibson, the former Mayor of Newark, is stepping out of the history books, where he was one of the first black mayors of a major city and a spokesman for the plight of deteriorating urban areas, to run for Essex County executive.

title: Spiritualist Author Is Found Dead In Surf Near His L.I. Estate
description: The police in Suffolk County said yesterday that they had tentatively identified a body found off Setauket, N.Y., as that of Dr. Frederick P. Lenz, the controversial new age guru, spiritualist and author of the best-selling book, ''Surfing the Himalayas.''

title: Yankee Stadium Closed as Beam Falls Onto Seats
description: A 500-pound concrete and steel beam suspended beneath the upper deck of Yankee Stadium came loose and crashed into the empty seats below yesterday afternoon, prompting city officials to close the landmark stadium and forcing the Yankees to postpone last night's and tonight's games with the Anaheim Angels.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ARTERIAL VASCULAR ENGINEERING INC., -- Santa Rosa, Calif., agreed to acquire the closely held World Medical Manufacturing Corp., Sunrise, Fla., another medical device concern, for $62 million in stock.

title: Economics All-Star Says He Will Stay With Home Team, After All
description: One of the nation's most prominent economists, Robert J. Barro, has decided to back out of a highly publicized, exceptionally lucrative deal he had negotiated with Columbia University and will instead remain at Harvard University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  THATCHER, EDWIN D.
description: THATCHER-Edwin D. Born February 21, 1915 in Brooklyn, NY. Died April 7, 1998. He is survived by his wife, Pauline. Mr. Thatcher attended Brooklyn Friends School and Princeton University, Class of 1936. He practiced architecture in Manhattan and was a member of the AIA. He was buried at Greenwood cemetery in a private ceremony on April 9, 1998.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: A Mighty Pen Gives an Edge to a Digital Note Pad
description: GIVE the new Crosspad high marks for originality. This ''portable digital note pad'' looks like a sleek black clipboard, right down to the standard letter-size yellow lined pad of genuine paper that fits on top. But thanks to a ballpoint pen that emits radio signals, what you write ends up not just as real ink on real paper but also as virtual ink on electronic pages.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DRENNAN, JOHN A., SR.
description: DRENNAN-John A., Sr. Beloved husband of the late Philomena, devoted father of Daniel, Maureen Finn, John Jr., and the late Kevin P. Also survived by four cherished grandchildren. Reposing Scotto's Funeral Home, 106 First Place (near Court Street), Brooklyn, until Wednesday. Mass of Christian burial St. Agnes R.C. Church, at 10:30 A.M. Visiting hours from 2-5 and 7-9:30 P.M.

title: On Far Right, A Soft Voice Undermines French Center
description: For the French, the face and voice of the far right have long been those of Jean-Marie Le Pen, the blustery former paratrooper who, 25 years ago, founded the National Front. But the brain that quietly devised the maneuvers that convulsed French politics recently belongs to Bruno Megret.

title: AIDS Research Yields Clues Linking Viruses and Cancer
description: WHEN AIDS was first recognized in New York in 1981, it was not as a viral infection but as Kaposi's sarcoma, a rare type of cancer affecting the skin and internal organs. After realizing that AIDS was a new disease, doctors then noticed that two other unusual types of cancer -- non-Hodgkins lymphoma and primary lymphoma of the brain -- also occurred with unusual frequency among people with H.I.V., the AIDS virus.

title: BOWATER TO ACQUIRE SOUTH KOREAN NEWSPRINT MILL
description: Bowater Inc. agreed yesterday to buy a South Korean newsprint mill from the Halla Pulp and Paper Company for $175 million. Bowater said in January -- a month after Halla Pulp's parent company, the Halla Group, was declared bankrupt -- that it was in talks to buy a stake in the mill. Bowater, the largest United States newsprint maker, will become the world's second-biggest producer when it completes the recently announced purchase of the Montreal-based Avenor Inc. Shares of Bowater, which is based in Greenville, S.C., rose $1.125 yesterday, to $56.50.

title: On My Mind; Lean Back Or Fight
description: ''It's nice to think that in another five or ten years maybe the right over one's consciousness, the right to possess and consume drugs, may be as powerfully and as widely understood as the other rights of Americans are.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINER, MALCOLM
description: STEINER-Malcolm. On April 11 in his 91st year. Beloved husband of Betty. Dear father of Lawrence and Nanci and the late Susan. Adored grandfather of Jennifer and Jeffrey. Services were held Monday, April 13.

title: Big Mergers: Economies That Could Break the Scale
description: The old American financial system -- with banks unable to cross state lines and barred by law from getting into some other financial businesses -- was a messy and inefficient one. But it encouraged a diversity that may have helped the economy.

title: Adjusting the Tone to Suit Haydn's Stately Forms for Good Friday
description: Haydn faced a daunting challenge in 1786 when he agreed to compose a set of orchestral works for a Good Friday service at the Cathedral of Cadiz. The movements were to be interludes between sermons on the seven statements, quoted from the Crucifixion accounts in Matthew, Luke and John, and in the spirit of the occasion, they were to be slow and meditative. Yet even without access to the variety of tempos usually available to him, Haydn wrote a palpably dramatic, urgent and at times pictorial work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELTMAN, LILLIAN D.
description: GELTMAN-Lillian D. Beloved mother of Jan Shakofsky, Jo, Beth and Steven Geltman. Adored mother-in-law of Karen Geltman and Jerry Shakofsky. Cherished grandmother of Sean. Contributions to the Jacob Perlow Hospice, Beth Israel Hospital appreciated.

title: Takeover Offer Rejected
description: Global Motorsport Group Inc. today rejected Golden Cycle L.L.C.'s $82 million takeover bid, saying it did ''not represent fair value for the company.'' Golden Cycle is offering $18 a share for the 89.6 percent of Global Motorsport it does not already own. Global Motorsport makes parts and accessories for Harley-Davidson motorcycles. For the year ended Jan. 31, it had revenue of $122.7 million. Golden Cycle is a private company formed by the investors Alex Grass and his son, Roger, who is chairman of Biker's Depot Inc., which also sells Harley parts.

title: Gore Will List New Priorities In Air Safety
description: Vice President Al Gore will announce priorities for airline safety on Tuesday, so that the airline industry and the Federal Aviation Administration can focus on the most important efforts, like more rigorous checks of engine parts, new equipment to help planes avoid flying into mountains and a new campaign to increase seat-belt use.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RIGGIO, CHRISTOPHER MICHAEL
description: RIGGIO-Christopher Michael. Son of Drs. Maureen A. Relland and Robert R. title: A Korean Dance Troupe With a Russian Look
description: The Universal Ballet, which opens today in a weeklong New York debut season at City Center, has been preceded by speculation and anecdotal history, most of which revolves around the South Korean company's involvement with the Rev. Sun Myung Moon's Unification Church. The troupe has been sponsored financially in large part by the church, and its leading ballerina and general director, Julia Moon, is Mr. Moon's daughter-in-law. (She had been engaged to the minister's son, who died in a 1984 car crash; the marriage ceremony took place after his death.)

title: New Federal Express Hub
description: The FDX Corporation's Federal Express unit said today that it planned to build a $300 million air hub and package-sorting facility in Greensboro, N.C., to help meet demand for its express delivery services on the East Coast. The company will start building its fifth hub at the Piedmont Triad International Airport in 2000 and open it in 2003.

title: Sports of The Times; Knicks Feel Time's Arrow
description: THE clock had one-tenth of a second remaining and the red light signaling the end of the game was already on. There was, it turns out, a mechanical malfunction in Miami on Sunday afternoon, which by any means of rational thinking had to expand the margin for human error.

title: Fashion Salutes No Single Flag, but Many
description: American fashion is based on the ease and comfort of sportswear. European fashion grew out of haute couture, with its emphasis on precision cut and the art of decoration. The United States put the world into T-shirts and jeans, while France contributed the New Look and the pouf. But those verities are changing. The cross-pollination in recent years has made it almost impossible to look at a piece of clothing today and pinpoint its country of origin.

title: U.S. to Remap Routes to Ease Air Congestion
description: Hoping to cut down on delays for passengers and the noise endured by people on the ground, the Federal Aviation Administration plans to redesign air traffic routes around the country, starting with the highly congested New York area, the head of the aviation agency said today.

title: Facing Up to the Nanny Tax
description: When Zoe Baird's nomination for Attorney General collapsed because she failed to pay employment taxes for her child's nanny most people were unaware that such an obligation even existed. Now every April 15, the moment of truth arises for hundreds of thousands of families who must decide whether to declare the employment of a nanny and pay the taxes owed.

title: Rome Journal; A Delphic Oracle Has Seen the Future, and Likes It
description: When he falls and breaks a bone, it is front-page news. Any time he makes an offhand comment on anything from politics to soccer, it is picked up and replayed as if he were Italy's own Delphic oracle. His family is treated like royalty, the way royalty used to be treated -- with respect, distance and, above all, discretion.

title: First Union Merges Direct Marketing
description: The First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C., said yesterday that it had consolidated its direct marketing account at two shops: Hill, Holliday Direct in Boston, which will serve as the lead direct marketing agency, and Earle Palmer Brown Direct in Philadelphia, which will handle projects and special assignments. The account, with billings estimated at $30 million, had been divided among several agencies.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDGELL, DOUGLAS C.
description: EDGELL-Douglas C. Brookside, NJ, died Friday in Atlanta, GA. Death was the result of a massive head injury. A second generation publishing executive, Doug Edgell was born in Greenwich, CT in 1951. His father Robert Edgell, a longtime publishing executive served as vice-chairman of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. Doug began his publishing career in 1973 and held sales and management positions with Ziff Davis, Conde Nast and Gordon Publications. In 1984, he started Edgell Communications with his wife and business partner Gabriele and he launched the first in a series of successful technology-based business magazines ''Automatic ID News''. In addition to serving as publisher, Doug became widely known and respected in the technology and business communities. Edgell Communications moved to its present sight in Randolph, NJ in 1991. It currently publishes seven magazines founded by the Edgells including ''RIS News'', ''Retail Systems Reseller'', ''Consumer Goods Manufacturer'', ''Hospitality Technology'', ''Data Capture Reseller'', ''Selling Christmas Decorations'', and ''Selling Halloween''. Doug was an avid sportsman and enjoyed spending weekends in the Adirondacks. Doug was an elite amateur waterskier, snowskier, snow mobiler and off-road enthusiast. He is survived by his immediate family of Gabriele, his wife, Katherine, 14, his daughter and Gregory, 10, his son. He is also survived by his mother Kathleen Edgell of Alexandria, VA and four sisters; Robin Davis of Hamilton, MA, Sarah Edgell of Denver, CO, Deborah Oberg also of Denver, CO and Jane Edgell of New York City. Doug is also survived by four nieces and three nephews. Visiting hours are 3-5 and 7-9 pm Tuesday at Tuttle Funeral Home. The funeral service will be Wednesday at 11 AM at Mendham Hills Chapel in Chester, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers the family suggest that donations be made to St. Barnabas Burn Foundation, 94 Short Hills Rd, Suite 101, Livingston, New Jersey 07039 or Residents Committee to Protect the Adirondacks, POB 27, North Creek, New York 12853.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UPTEGROVE, KATHLEEN
description: UPTEGROVE-Kathleen. Beloved mother of Kathleen. Died April 12 at age 83 after a courageous battle with lung cancer. She died with grace and dignity at Calvary Hospital. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street Tuesday 1 to 4 and 6 to 9 P.M. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday 10 A.M., Our Lady of Good Counsel, 230 E. 90 St, NYC.

The Corpuels and All Your Camp Wayne Friends

title: Apartheid-Era Chief Said to Yield to Panel
description: South Africa's leading news agency reported today that former President P. W. Botha had finally agreed to appear before the country's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, a day before he was to stand trial for refusing to obey repeated commission subpoenas.

title: Beam May Be The Leverage
description: The future of the Yankees and Yankee Stadium was lying last night in the second row of Section 22 on the loge level of the 75-year-old ball park in the Bronx. The back of Seat 7 was on the ground between the first two rows. The bottom of the seat, ripped apart by two holes, was on the ground in the row behind. A hole in the concrete floor had replaced Seat 7. The concrete and steel beam that obliterated the seat lay on the steps next to the row.

title: Volvo Plans to Buy A Unit From Samsung
description: The Samsung Heavy Industries Company said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its construction equipment business to the Volvo Construction Equipment Corporation for about 1.074 trillion won ($767 million), the biggest asset sale since South Korea's financial crisis erupted in November. The sale is expected to close June 1, said a spokesman at Samsung, a subsidiary of Korea's second-largest business group.

title: Hands in a Lot of Markets And a Foot on Each Coast

title: 1998 Candidates Advertise Early And Expensively
description: Taking a lesson from the 1996 Presidential campaign, an array of candidates in this year's midterm elections has begun buying television advertising months earlier than usual, promising another election year likely to break spending records.

title: Some Japanese Pilots Continue Their Strike
description: Pilots of the All Nippon Airways Company began their second week of a strike over a 15 percent pay cut, forcing the airline to cancel 16 more international flights through Thursday. The strike, which has canceled 64 flights affecting 11,500 passengers, will continue because the airline refused another ultimatum from the pilots to enter talks. All Nippon said it would not enter talks unless the pilots returned to work.
