Box 220, Summit, NJ 07901, or to The Presbyterian Church in Westfield, 140 Mountain Ave., Westfield, New Jersey 07090.

title: SINCLAIR BROADCAST TO BUY MOST OF OHIO TV STATION
description: Sinclair Broadcast Group Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire most of the assets of WSYX-TV, an ABC affiliate in Columbus, Ohio, from River City Broadcasting L.P., for $228 million. River City will retain the Federal Communications Commission license for the station, enabling Sinclair, which already owns the Fox affiliate WTTE-TV in Columbus, to avoid rules prohibiting a company from owning multiple licenses in the same market. Sinclair said the Justice Department had said it would not oppose the purchase. Including pending acquisitions and sales, Sinclair, based in Baltimore, will own or program 57 television stations and 51 radio stations.

description: One Saturday night at the Willson Auditorium on Main Street, a creaky 1,100-seat theater in a school that is the busiest entertainment venue in this growing Rocky Mountain town, the attraction was the Chord Rustlers, a local singing group that, with 44 members, represents Montana's largest chapter of S.P.E.B.S.Q.S.A.

title: Beethoven With Fond Familiarity

They are a fine ensemble; their music-making is at once solid and lively, and they respond to one another with civility and imagination.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Pop CD's; Hip-Hop With a Novel's Complexity
description: The long-playing album needn't simply be a collection of songs; it can assume a more richly integrated form, like a novel with multiple narrators and discourses. A few musical eccentrics in the 1960's started to take stabs at the idea, but hip-hop producers made it commonplace. Since Public Enemy, De La Soul and the Wu-Tang Clan, a tradition has been established for the album as an omnium-gatherum of soundtrack excerpts, speeches, jokes and demonstrations; at best, these new records shatter predictable form and demand obsessive listening.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES

title: Fish Market Mutiny
description: By 4 A.M., New York's Fulton Fish Market buzzes with people full-tilt into their workdays. Brightly lighted displays proffer fish from around the world. But nowadays, some customers think twice about buying one part of the catch: swordfish. Their reticence should make the fishing industry and its regulators pay attention.

title: PARAGON IN $581 MILLION DEAL FOR MARINER
description: Paragon Health Network Inc. said yesterday that it would acquire Mariner Health Group Inc. for about $581 million in stock, plus some assumed debt, expanding its reach in long-term care. Mariner shareholders will receive one Paragon share for each Mariner share held. That will give them 44 percent of the combined company, which will have annual revenue of about $3 billion. The Atlanta-based Paragon, formed through last year's merger of Grancare Inc. and Living Centers of America Inc., is a nursing home chain. Mariner, based in New London, Conn., provides rehabilitation, nursing, pharmacy and other health care services. Its shares slipped 43.75 cents yesterday, to $18.1875, while Paragon's shares were down 62.5 cents at $19.125.

description: Kia Group said yesterday that it would continue its fight to remain independent. At a hastily arranged news conference, group officials said a cost-cutting drive was paying dividends, enabling the Kia Motors Corporation to turn its first profit since 1993.

title: Fingermatrix Halts Work
description: Fingermatrix Inc., a developer of electronic fingerprinting technology, said today that it had halted all operations because of a shortage of funds. Fingermatrix said that it had exhausted its operating funds and failed to receive financing that had been expected from a source in Southeast Asia. The company said that it was seeking private investors or interested buyers. The company, based in Dobbs Ferry, lost $577,922 on revenue of $8,845 in the quarter ended June 30.

The attack occurred at sunset in a crowded section of the park, long considered one of the safest in the city.

title: Qwest Link Advancing
description: Qwest Communications International Inc. said today that it had completed a third of its $1.8 billion fiber optic telephone network that will connect California and New York. More than 5,400 miles of the planned 16,285-mile network are now in operation. The entire network, which will connect 125 cities, is expected to be completed by mid-1999. Qwest is betting that the high-capacity network will give it an edge as more businesses and consumers demand faster Internet, video conferencing and other data services.

Funeral Services will be conducted at 1 PM Wednesday, at Riverside Nassau North Chapel, Great Neck. Calling hours will be at the funeral chapel Wednesday, from noon to 1 PM. Burial will be in New Montefiore Cemetery.

title: The Volatile Search for Truth and Blame
description: His name is Darryl Cummings, but his friends know him as Fly. He's a young black New York graffiti artist with a style like ''a combination of the Smurfs and 'Nightmare on Elm Street,' '' as one acquaintance (Alphonso Johnson) says. One day, at the West 23d Street subway station, Darryl is arrested. On the way to the police station he dies, of a heart attack, the police say, but that seems doubtful. Even the arresting officer (Robert Austin), who is white, acknowledges that Darryl was beaten.

title: O'Meara Acts Out His Boyhood Fantasy
description: One day last week, Mark O'Meara was at a restaurant near Augusta National Golf Club when he was interrupted.

title: Ukraine's Dangerous Decline
description: Last year, Ukraine and Turkmenistan were the only former Soviet republics to see their official economies shrink. Ukraine's steady decline is the main reason that voters abandoned the relatively reformist governing party in parliamentary elections two weeks ago. The big winner was the Communist Party, a group so troglodyte that it favors ''voluntary reunification'' with Russia. The vote practically insures that Ukraine will see none of the reforms the country needs.

title: Rainout Wrenches Leiter's Schedule
description: If the first couple of weeks of the 1998 season have demonstrated anything in relation to the weather, it is that when there are rain clouds up above, it's a good bet Al Leiter will not be far behind.

title: Oz Eludes Capital Wizards
description: In an act of modest but authentic civic propriety, they changed their name from the Bullets to the Wizards. The owner spent $200 million for a modern arena, choosing not to build it in the suburbs, but rather downtown so that a broader commercial life might return. He then spent $105 million to hang onto the team's emerging star.

title: Indonesian Currency Gains Against Dollar
description: The Indonesian rupiah climbed to its highest level against the United States dollar in two months during Asian trading yesterday as the market cautiously welcomed Indonesia's latest pact with the International Monetary Fund. The dollar was sold at 7,550 rupiah, its lowest level since Feb. 13.

title: Embracing the Masters a Bit Too Much
description: A review of CBS's Masters coverage is a tale of good news and so-so news.

title: Corrections

The article was by Kenneth N. Gilpin. (David Berry, research director at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, a bank-stock research firm, was quoted as saying that he thought the combinations of First Chicago with Banc One and of Nationsbank with BankAmerica were strong possibilities.)

title: BankBoston Unit Sale
description: The BankBoston Corporation is selling its document custody business to the Banc One Corporation for an undisclosed amount to free up capital for use in other ventures, a BankBoston spokeswoman said yesterday. Bank One said it would offer jobs to the 55 employees of Banc One's custody business, which keeps records for about 30 clients out of its main offices in Jacksonville and Clearwater, Fla. The transaction is expected to be completed in the second quarter.

title: Alex Ritchie, 52, Balloonist, Dies After Sky-Diving Mishap
description: Alex Ritchie, a British balloonist who clambered atop an airborne balloon's gondola last year to jettison fuel tanks, halting a crash-dive, died on Saturday at Middlesex Hospital in London. He was 52 and had been undergoing treatment at the hospital since January.

title: Black Dancer Is a Forgotten Man No Longer; Found Wandering the Streets, He'll Soon Be Reunited With a Big Family

title: Putting Women's Rights in Population Policy
description: WHEN all the international development policy-speak common to her tribe is set aside, Joan Dunlop's essential achievement is simple. This woman who began her career as a white-gloved secretary, with parents who forbade her to go to Vassar, has helped transform the world's view of overpopulation from that of problem to symptom.

title: For Some Americans, Mexican Citizenship

title: I.M.F. Warns U.S. Markets Could Tumble

title: Vacco Ad on Smoking Attacked by Democrat
description: A Manhattan Democrat who is seeking her party's nomination for attorney general said yesterday that taxpayers were unfairly paying for a television commercial in which Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco warned about the dangers of smoking among minors.

title: A Stonewall at City Hall

Yet the Mayor, his appointees and press staff often look like people with something to hide instead of a story worth telling. More seriously, Mr. Giuliani acts as if the government owns information that belongs to the public.

title: Tom Cora, 44, New-Music Cellist With Flair for the Avant-Garde

title: Mystery and Whimsy, In Jarring Contrast
description: It would be hard to find two more dissimilar choreographers than Jeanine Durning and Sara Hook, who shared the ''Splitstream'' program on Saturday night at Dance Theater Workshop. At times, their differences were almost jarring.

title: HERTZ AGREES TO BUY FRENCH EQUIPMENT RENTAL COMPANY
description: The Hertz Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Boireau Group, a French equipment rental concern, for an undisclosed amount of cash and assumed debt. Boireau, with annual revenue of $25 million, has 26 locations in France. Hertz, the car and equipment rental company, had 1997 revenue of $3.9 billion, with its equipment rental businesses generating $444.6 million. The acquisition gives Hertz a total of 43 corporate equipment rental offices in France and Spain. Shares of Hertz, which is based in Park Ridge, N.J., and majority-owned by the Ford Motor Company, rose 87.5 cents yesterday, to $47.875.

title: Case Against Heirs of Art Thief Is All but Over
description: A Federal appeals court in New Orleans has all but put an end to the prosecution of two Texans and their lawyer on charges that they trafficked in stolen property in their efforts to sell world-famous artwork taken from Germany after World War II.

title: Hip-Hopping Past Borders To Pleasure
description: The idea behind Bran Van 3000, the rambunctious Montreal collective founded by the director Jamie (Bran Man) Di Salvio and the synthesizer wizard Electronic-Pierre Bergen, is to turn a really good party into a musical artifact. Tapping into the giddy multifariousness of a mainstream dominated by songs that sample other songs, and remixes that push everything from country to opera onto the same dance floor, Bran Van 3000 preaches the pleasures of musical miscegenation.

title: Metro Business; Starrett Gets New Leader
description: Starrett Corporation, which built the Empire State Building, has named Joel Simon, a former executive of Olympia & York Companies (U.S.A.), as its new chief executive.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, RABBI SAMUEL
description: COOK-Rabbi Samuel, 91. Died in Cincinnati, on April 12. His great distinctiveness was directing NFTY-National (now N. Amer.) Federation of Temple Youth. Developed by the Union of American Hebrew Congregations to maintain Jewish affiliation of young Jews, NFTY itself became the driving force giving direction to the entity creating it, spawning the majority of rabbis, cantors, educators, and lay-leaders of Reform Judaism who were motivated to become such by experiences at summer camps and regional conclaves. He is survived by his wife, Ray Cook, and two sons, Michael and Joel Cook, and eight grandchildren. Memorial contributions may be made to NFTY.

title: SYLVAN LEARNING SYSTEMS ADDING LANGUAGE INSTRUCTOR
description: Sylvan Learning Systems Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Aspect, a closely held provider of English as a second language programs, for $65 million in stock. Sylvan said it would take acquisition charges of $9 million to $10 million in the second quarter. With the purchase, Sylvan, of Baltimore, will add Aspect's intensive English instruction to its Wall Street Institute program, which teaches English to professionals. The combined company will have annual revenue of about $300 million and will employ 3,100 people in 105 countries, Sylvan said. The company added that it would not dismiss any employees of Aspect, which is based in San Francisco. Shares of Sylvan slipped 6.25 cents yesterday, to $48.4375.

description: LAWSON-Beulah, April 14, 1988. Beloved and treasured mother, you are forever in my heart, in my thoughts, and in my daily lifenever to be forgotten. With a heart overflowing with love, your adoring daughter Norma.

title: An Unusually Dim Kasparov Wakes Up to Defeat Anand
description: Garry Kasparov played in the doldrums through most of the Linares, Spain, Supertournament. Out of 12 games, he had 11 draws. The only game he won was against one of his most serious rivals, Viswanathan Anand, in the third round. But that did not discourage Anand. He went on to take first prize.

title: A Mystery Unraveled, Twice
description: HALF a millennium ago, a German abbot wrote a book on communication with spirits. It gained instant notoriety. The author, Johannes Trithemius, was an adviser to emperors and a leading humanist. But he also was a magician, and his book was couched in the language of the occult. It outraged Renaissance intellectuals who said it showed that Trithemius was a dabbler in demonic magic and that he could conjure up spirits.

title: Golota Feels Pain of Lost Chances
description: Andrew Golota steps into the ring tonight against Eli Dixon in a 10-round heavyweight bout with at least one crucial bit of knowledge gathered from his last fight -- it's better to give a shot than take one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MITOFSKY, JOEL A.
description: MITOFSKY-Joel A. The members and staff of Mitofsky & Shapiro remember their beloved friend, Joel Mitofsky, and his daughter Jenna. All our love is with his wife, Joyce and daughters Ilysa and Lara. Although our hearts and lives have been forever touched, ''the music never stops''.

title: Editorial Notebook; The Art of Building a Brush Pile
description: Spring rushes onward, and yet the season seems strangely more patient than it often does in New York's Columbia County in mid-April. Perhaps it's the long light at evening or the abundance of fair-weather days recently, but a time of year that is emblematic of swift change has offered a consistency, a duration, no one really expects. The grass has risen through old thatch and blossoms have begun to appear on old wood, which remind you that spring is also a season for demarcating the living from the dead -- the plants that can't revive, the leaves blown into drifts below the hemlocks, the old stems that will not bud again. Everyone in this neighborhood builds a brush pile about now, and when the conditions look right, it is set afire, as though it were a pyre on which winter burned, the last purification before summer.

title: N.C.A.A. Plans Weight-Loss Rules
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association, responding to the deaths late last year of three wrestlers who had taken drastic measures to lose weight quickly, has proposed new rules to make the sport safer. After those deaths, the N.C.A.A. made emergency rules changes. Yesterday, its wrestling rules committee recommended permanent changes that, among other things, limited the amount of weight a wrestler could lose. The changes are expected to be approved by the end of the month.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OTHMER, MILDRED TOPP
description: OTHMER-Mildred Topp. The Board of Trustees, President David C. Chang, Chancellor George Bugliarello and the entire Polytechnic University community mourn the passing of Mildred Topp Othmer, beloved wife of the late Dr. Donald F. Othmer, after a long illness. Dr. Othmer, who passed away in 1995, was a longtime Polytechnic faculty member, co-author of the landmark KirkOthmer Encyclopedia of Chemical Technology and one of the nation's most influential and inventive chemical engineers. Mrs. Othmer, a member of the prominent Topp family of Omaha, NE, attended the University of Nebraska in the years when relatively few women earned four-year college degrees. After graduation, she taught English, economics and foreign languages in the Midwest before becoming a successful fashion buyer for her family's clothing outlet. Her flair for fashion and her skill in marketing helped turn the business into one of the region's most exclusive and fashionable women's clothing stores. Several years later, Mrs. Othmer struck new educational ground again when she came to New York and earned an MBA from Columbia University. Her marriage to Dr. Othmer in 1950 opened a new chapter in a life already marked by a spirit of adventure and accomplishment. She was her husband's friend and inspiration and constant traveling companion, accompanying him on numerous worldwide trips to locales as far away as Southeast Asia and South America. She also devoted many hours as an education consultant and community volunteer. She and Dr. Othmer were generous benefactors of Polytechnic University, and their names grace the libraries or buildings of the Brooklyn History Museum, the Long Island College Hospital, in Brooklyn, the American Chemical Society, in Washington, D.C., and the Chemical Heritage Foundation, in Philadelphia, PA. The entire University family extends its heartfelt condolences to the Othmer family.

title: WELLSFORD VENTURE'S DEAL FOR BOSTON-AREA PROPERTIES
description: Wellsford Real Properties Inc. and a Goldman, Sachs & Company real estate fund agreed yesterday to buy 13 office buildings in suburban Boston from the closely held Saracen Properties for $77 million in cash and securities and the assumption of $69 million in debt. The properties, which Saracen will manage, have about one million square feet. After the deal, Wellsford will have 27 properties with 3.5 million square feet of space in Boston, northern New Jersey and Washington. Shares of Wellsford fell 25 cents yesterday, to $14.625. The purchase comes eight months after Wellsford and Goldman, Sachs's Whitehall Street Real Estate L.P. VII fund set up its $400 million venture.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Venture capital for an orphan: agricultural biotechnology.
description: LEADING biotechnology analyst and deal maker, backed by some big European drug and chemical companies, is creating a fund of more than $100 million to invest in start-up companies in an area long ignored by most venture capitalists: agricultural biotechnology.

title: Torn Between Nations, Mexican-Americans Can Have Both
description: On the day she became a United States citizen seven years ago, Ericka Abraham Rodriguez recalls, she felt a deep ambivalence, her excitement tinged by a feeling that she was somehow betraying her native Mexico. ''I love both countries,'' said Ms. Abraham, a 34-year-old freelance translator. ''It was like I was being asked to choose between my mother and my father.''

title: B/E AEROSPACE PLANS TO BUY AIRCRAFT MODULAR PRODUCTS
description: B/E Aerospace Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy the closely held Aircraft Modular Products for $118 million in cash. Aircraft Modular Products has a 60 percent share of the market for new business jet interiors and more than 10,000 installed interiors that may need replacement parts. B/E Aerospace, based in Wellington, Fla., is the world's largest maker of aircraft cabin seats, kitchens, storage areas and bathrooms. With Aircraft Modular, which is based in Miami, B/E Aerospace would also be the largest manufacturer and supplier of interiors for the business jet industry. Shares of B/E Aerospace rose 56.25 cents yesterday, to $34.1875.

description: Chateau Communities Inc. bought 12 manufactured-home communities in Michigan and North Carolina for $79 million, increasing its holdings about 6 percent. The communities, 10 of which are in Michigan, contain about 3,417 home sites, including 381 expansion sites. Chateau did not identify the sellers. Chateau completed the purchase of seven of the communities. The acquisition of the other five is expected to be completed by the end of April. Chateau now owns 165 manufactured-home communities in 29 states with a total of 50,690 sites.

title: Yanks' Schedule Is Disrupted by Stadium Accident
description: Joe Torre huddled in his office yesterday with Brian Cashman, Yankee manager and general manager, shortly after last night's game at Yankee Stadium was postponed by city officials because of structural safety concerns. George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' owner, was on the speakerphone. ''What do you need?'' Cashman asked Torre.

title: PRESIDENT OF EXCEL COMMUNICATIONS RESIGNS
description: The president and chief operating officer of Excel Communications Inc., John J. McLaine, has resigned to spend more time with his family. Mr. McLaine, 48, had been with Excel, one of the country's largest long-distance phone companies, for four years. Excel's founder, Kenny A. Troutt, 50, who holds the titles of chairman and chief executive, will reassume the president's position. The chief operating officer job will be eliminated. Shares of Excel, which is based in Dallas, fell 75 cents yesterday, to $20.875.

title: Breast Cancer Drug Dilemma: Who Should Take It, and When?
description: WHEN Bernice Olson heard in 1992 that a nationwide study was under way to determine whether the drug tamoxifen could prevent breast cancer in high-risk women, she volunteered right away. One of her sisters, who is now healthy, had had the disease in 1980, at the age of 43. That, combined with Mrs. Olson's own age, 51, defined her as high risk.

title: L. L. Bean Puts Account in Review
description: L. L. Bean Inc. in Freeport, Me., has placed its account in review. The account has been handled for five years by Bronner Slosberg Humphrey in Boston. Billings were estimated at $20 million to $25 million.

title: SCIENCE WATCH; Dreaming of Oxygen
description: For years, researchers believed that the quick eye movement during sleep was a sign of vivid dreams. Instead, a researcher at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center suggests, this rapid eye movement, known as REM, is caused not by dreams but by the eyes' need for oxygen.

title: Researchers Crack Code In Cell Phones
description: In successfully cracking a widely used encryption method designed to prevent the cloning of digital cellular phones, a group of University of California computer researchers believe they have stumbled across evidence that the system was deliberately weakened to permit Government surveillance.

description: J. P. Morgan & Company said yesterday that earnings weakened in the first quarter as costs for investment banking outpaced revenue. Still, the earnings surpassed Wall Street expectations.

title: SEAGATE REPORTS $128.5 MILLION LOSS FOR QUARTER
description: Facing falling prices amid a worldwide oversupply of computer disk drives, Seagate Technology Inc. yesterday reported a loss for its fiscal third quarter. Seagate had warned Wall Street last month that results would be weak. Excluding charges, the loss matched analysts' revised expectations of 10 cents a share. Shares of Seagate, based in Scotts Valley, Calif., closed at $29, up $4.1875. Analysts said there were no surprises in Seagate's report, released after the close of the market. For the quarter ended April 3, Seagate lost $128.5 million, compared with earnings of $256.8 million, or $1.04 a fully diluted share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. Sales fell 33 percent, to $1.68 billion from $2.50 billion.

title: For Greek Orthodox Easter, a Hearty Soup
description: THE midnight feast that ushers in Greek Orthodox Easter on Saturday will be rigorously authentic at Molyvos, the celebrated Greek restaurant in midtown. The multicourse meal that breaks the Lenten fast will begin with the traditional soup known as magirit sa. And there will be no escape for the faint-hearted.

title: Turkish Commandos Capture a Kurdish Leader in Raid Into Iraq

title: Gershwin (Posthumously), Graham and Roth Are Among Winners of 22 Pulitzer Prizes
description: George Gershwin, Katharine Graham and Philip Roth, three figures whose names have special resonance in modern music, journalism and literature, were awarded Pulitzer Prizes yesterday.

title: Now Starring, Good and Evil
description: Paulo Ribeiro takes on the large and amorphous topic of human good and evil in ''Blue Emerald,'' presented by the Paulo Ribeiro Dance Company on Friday night at the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark. Mr. Ribeiro, a leading modern-dance choreographer from Lisbon, does not make things easy for himself or his audiences by focusing on one defining character or event. Instead, he presents a panoply of contradictory impulses over the hourlong work, impulses that are merged in a very human way, suggesting history unfolding before us.

title: American Airlines' Chief To Step Down
description: Robert L. Crandall, the combative chief of American Airlines who helped develop many of the modern airline industry's most significant innovations, including frequent-flier programs and sophisticated computer reservation systems, will retire as chairman and chief executive next month, an executive close to the company said yesterday.

title: Wine Talk; The 1855 Ratings, Etched in Stone (Almost)
description: THE 1855 classification of the wines of Bordeaux is probably the most important wine list ever written. Yet, few people, even many knowledgeable wine drinkers, know why it is important or even why it was made in the first place.

title: $25 and Under; Caribbean Cruise Ship Docks in the East Village
description: DESPITE remnants of the rough-and-rowdy East Village, Avenue A has taken on the look of a themed party street, as if a Disneylike central-planning commission had decided to put in -- one after the other -- a sushi bar, a pan-Asian restaurant, a dissolute French lounge, a diner and, now, a Caribbean place.

title: Maurice Stans Dies at 90; Led Nixon Commerce Dept.
description: Maurice H. Stans, a former Commerce Secretary and fund-raiser in the Nixon administration who pleaded guilty to accepting illegal campaign contributions in the Watergate scandal, died of heart failure yesterday in Pasadena, Claif. He was 90.

title: Harvard Breaks a Housemaster Mold
description: Lowell House, one of the grand Georgian dormitories on the river side of Harvard University, prides itself on traditions like a weekly tea social, an annual opera production and a ritual performance of the ''1812 Overture'' featuring the Russian bells in the house bell tower.

title: Experiments On Children Are Reviewed
description: Federal research-ethics officials are investigating several psychiatric experiments in which 100 New York City boys, many of them black or Hispanic, were given the now-banned diet drug fenfluramine.

title: A Violin Recital, Alert and Refined
description: In the late 1960's, three Juilliard violinists, all students of the noted teacher Ivan Galamian, all the same age, emerged as young dynamos of the violin: Pinchas Zukerman, Kyung-Wha Chung and Young Uck Kim. Each turns 50 this year. But of the three, the Korean-born Mr. Kim has not attained quite the prominence of his former student colleagues. This is curious, for his recital on Thursday evening at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with Andre Previn as pianist, provided a reminder of his rewarding artistry.

title: Arts in America; HBO Programmer Likes to Kindle Both Heat and Light
description: One of the worlds of Sheila Nevins looks like this: At a Hollywood studio a few months ago, Ms. Nevins was presiding over a screening of Spike Lee's poignant documentary ''4 Little Girls,'' about the bombing of a black church in Alabama in 1963. Ms. Nevins, a senior vice president who runs HBO's documentary division, which helped produce the Oscar-nominated film, was effusive but never more so than when she exchanged hugs with Alpha Robertson, the sad-eyed mother of one of the girls killed in the attack.

title: One Who Has Found Her Job Within the System
description: Nancy Jimenez tells new workfare participants arriving at the main offices of the New York City Housing Authority, on Broadway across the street from City Hall, that they will like workfare. ''I feel workfare is good,'' she says. ''It gives people an opportunity to do something for themselves.'

title: Parolee Is Charged In Rape in Harlem
description: A violent felon who had been out on parole for little more than two weeks raped and robbed a 77-year-old woman yesterday afternoon in her Harlem apartment, the police said.

title: The Old Tax Dodge; While the Affluent May Lead the Way, Others Eagerly Follow
description: You cheated a little on your taxes, right? Join the club.

title: Russian-Fueled Rally Lifts Price Of Palladium Past That of Gold
description: The price of palladium, a precious metal used in catalytic converters, computers and cellular phones, shot up to an 18-year-high yesterday, making it more expensive than gold.

title: Ameritech to Cut 5,000 Jobs In an Effort to Save $3 Billion
description: Putting flesh on a previously announced plan to cut $3 billion in costs over five years, the Ameritech Corporation said yesterday that it would eliminate 5,000 jobs this year.

title: A Rage Behind the Laughter
description: More than 40 years after it was written, ''Trouble in Mind'' by Alice Childress still has the power to make one feel its anger and humor. In 1955 the play made Childress the first female winner of an Obie award for the best Off Broadway play of the year, and a revival of it by the Negro Ensemble Company at the Samuel Beckett Theater is a refreshing reminder of the energy and elegance of the imagination of this black actress, playwright and novelist.

title: As First Step in Peace Accord, Ireland Frees 9 I.R.A. Prisoners

title: ETHAN ALLEN SHARES DROP ON EARNINGS DISAPPOINTMENT

Before the market opened, the company, based in Danbury, Conn., reported earnings of 64 cents a diluted share, excluding charges, for the quarter ended March 31. Including a $802,000 charge for early redemption of debt, the company earned $18 million, or 61 cents a diluted share, in the quarter. In the corresponding period a year earlier, the company earned 44 cents a share. Analysts polled by the First Call Corporation had predicted 62 cents for the latest quarter. Shares of Ethan Allen dropped $5.4375 to close at $56.6875.

The President, Chancellor, Boards of Governors & Overseers, faculty, administration and students of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion record with profound sorrow the death of Rabbi Samuel Cook, the beloved father of Prof. Michael Cook, a member of our Cincinnati faculty. As a devoted rabbi and educator, Rabbi Cook was the National Director of the National Federation of Temple Youth of the UAHC. His gifts of leadership and spirit made his pioneering work among our youth a singular success. During World War II he served as an Army Chaplain and administered to the needs of our men and women overseas. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his dear wife, Ray Clara, and their sons and grandchildren, whose loss we share. May the family be comforted among all those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Sheldon Zimmerman President Burton Lehman, Chair Board of Governors

title: WSMP TO BUY PIERRE FOODS FROM TYSON FOR $122 MILLION
description: WSMP Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Pierre Foods sandwich and precooked meats business from Tyson Foods Inc. for $122 million. Pierre, based in Cincinnati, packages and distributes precooked food to the food service industry. It became a part of Tyson in January, when Tyson acquired Hudson Foods Inc. Pierre's sandwich business, with annual revenue of about $150 million, will increase WSMP's revenue to $300 million to $325 million. WSMP, based in Claremont, N.C., is a food processing and restaurant company. For the nine months ended Nov. 27, it posted revenue of $76.5 million.

title: UAL TO PAY UP TO $3.2 BILLION FOR 23 BOEING JETS
description: The UAL Corporation ordered 23 jumbo jets worth up to $3.2 billion from the Boeing Company yesterday, underscoring the airline's optimism about its international expansion plans even as traffic slows in the financially troubled Pacific Rim. The Chicago-based parent of United Airlines ordered a 747-400, 16 777-200's and 6 767-300's for delivery through 2002. The planes, used largely on overseas or transcontinental routes, have an aggregate list price of $2.8 billion to $3.2 billion. The move is the second phase of United's plan, disclosed last month, to add 68 planes to its 571-plane fleet by the end of 2001.

Adored ''Papa Bobby'' to grandsons Daniel and Jayson. Mr. Teitelbaum was the Sr. Managing Director at the brokerage firm of Ladenburg, Thalman. He had been with the company since 1975. He was a member of the board of Happiness is Camping, a camp for children with cancer. He was the financial advisor pro bono for the United Odd Fellow and Rebekah Home. His sense of humor and love of life will be remembered by all who knew and loved him. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday, April 15, 12:30 at Riverside Chapel, 180 West 76 Street, NYC. Contributions can be made in his memory to Happiness is Camping, 2169 Grand Concourse, Bronx, New York 10453.

title: SILICON TO SPIN OFF MICROPROCESSOR DESIGN UNIT
description: Silicon Graphics Inc. said yesterday that it would spin off its microprocessor design subsidiary as part of a strategy to build computers using the Intel Corporation's chips. Silicon Graphics also said that it had an agreement with Intel intended to advance the graphics performance of the Intel design. The company also said that it expected to trim its work force by about 1,000, or 10 percent, through selloffs and attrition as part of an overhaul aimed at simplifying its organization and reducing costs. Silicon Graphics said it would file with the Securities and Exchange Commission for an initial public offering of up to 20 percent of the outstanding shares of the microprocessor design subsidiary, MIPS Technologies Inc. Shares of Silicon Graphics fell $1.25, or 7.8 percent, to $14.8125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Mitsubishi Chemical To Buy Out 3 Ventures

Hoechst, based in Frankfurt, will sell its 33.3 percent stake in Diafoil Hoechst in Japan, its 66.7 percent of Hoechst Diafoil in Germany and its 66.7 percent stake in Hoechst Diafoil in the United States.

title: By the Book; Soul Food With Lots of Heart
description: THE pages of ''Soul Food: Recipes and Reflections From African-American Churches'' (HarperCollins, $25) are filled with grainy black-and-white snapshots of church suppers and women in aprons tending big pots of greens on the stove. It is not the first African-American cookbook to wander down this memory lane.

The plant closing, the first since Sunbeam acquired a controlling interest in Coleman two weeks ago, was under study before the acquisition, the company said. Shares of Sunbeam rose $1.625, to $30.

title: SHARES OF CYTYC FALL ON LARGER-THAN-EXPECTED-LOSS
description: Shares of the Cytyc Corporation fell 34 percent after the maker of medical test kits warned of a greater-than-expected loss yesterday amid slowing demand from laboratories for one of its cancer tests. Shares of Cytyc declined $8.375, to $15.875. The company said it expected to lose 36 cents to 38 cents in the first quarter, more than the 13-cent average estimate of analysts polled by I.B.E.S. International Inc. A drop in purchases by medical laboratories of Cytyc's Thin Prep Pap Test, used to screen women for cervical cancer, caused revenue to fall 25 percent from the fourth quarter, to $8 million. Cytyc attributed the decline to health insurers' delay in using a new reimbursement code for the test, which slowed payments to labs and soured them on using the test.

title: Tough Workfare Rules Used As Way to Cut Welfare Rolls
description: By restoring the luster of the work ethic and providing a path to real jobs, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani often says, his workfare program has played the central part in the dramatic reduction of New York City's welfare rolls. The numbers he cites are stark and indisputable: the rolls have dropped more than 30 percent in the last three years, to 797,000 from 1.16 million.

title: More Merger Mania
description: BankAmerica of California proposed this week to merge with Nationsbank of North Carolina to form the country's largest bank chain, spanning the continent and serving almost half the states. Banc One of Ohio proposed to join with First Chicago. These colossal marriages, which follow last week's proposed union of Citicorp and Travelers, raise two questions. Are small banks doomed and, if so, need anyone care?

title: Kodak Earnings Slide 17% In 6th Consecutive Decline
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, unable to stop Fuji Photo Film USA from gnawing at its American film market, posted its sixth consecutive quarterly decline in profits yesterday. The company earned $225 million, or 69 cents a share, a 17 percent drop from the $272 million, or 80 cents a share, earned in the first quarter of 1997, before the effects of a one-time charge. Sales were down 7 percent, to $2.91 billion from $3.13 billion.

Celine Dion may be the only real music business news this year, but radio stations like K-Rock (WXRK 92.3 FM) still thrive within bubbles of self-generated excitement. On Thursday at Irving Plaza, K-Rock presented another concert in its Lo Do showcase series: each features three bands currently receiving radio exposure, for a 92-cent ticket. With parts selected for broadcast, the evening held all the excitement of a well-staged pseudo-event.

title: Conflict Avoidance

Now there are fresh allegations that a key witness in Mr. Starr's Whitewater inquiry may have financial ties to longtime critics of President Clinton. These charges need to be examined quickly and by someone appointed by the Justice Department, not by Mr. Starr.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MURRAY, ROGER F.
description: MURRAY-Roger F. The Board of Trustees, Headmaster, Faculty, Staff, and the entire Collegiate School community mourn the loss of our Distinguished Alumnus and Life Trustee, Dr. Roger F. Murray 2nd'28. A dedicated educator who believed strongly in the importance of pre-college education, Dr. Murray provided leadership and meritorious service to the school for fifty years, serving on its Board of Trustees from 1949 until the present and as President of the Board from 1968-72. Dr. Murray's long stewardship of Collegiate was marked by both eloquence and warmth. His unwavering commitment to the traditional values of Collegiate School along with his clear view of the future served as guidance over many years to his colleagues on the Board and to Collegiate School. His encouragement of faculty enrichment and development will serve as a living legacy of his devotion to education. We shall miss him greatly and extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Agnes, his son, Roger F. Murray 3rd'64, and the entire Murray family. Jeffrey P. Klein '61, President of the Board of Trustees Jacob A. Dresden, Headmaster

title: Fold the Umbrella
description: Shortly before his company agreed to merge with Citicorp, the chairman of Travelers Group, Sanford Weill, had a fancy birthday party at the Four Seasons restaurant. Guests who were asked to come up with one word to describe him inevitably produced laudatory adjectives like smart, loyal and bold. We would happily add ''magnanimous'' to the list if Mr. Weill would agree to remove the enormous red neon umbrella from the north face of his headquarters in downtown Manhattan. The four-story Travelers logo casts off so much light that it can be clearly seen from New Jersey and even more clearly from the bedroom windows of the company's dyspeptic Tribeca neighbors.

title: About New York; Restoring Past With an Eye To the Future
description: IN the foyer of Washington Irving High School, Rene Nunez clambered up an aluminum scaffold and into the past. In a half-crouch, he studied one of the 12 murals tucked into the archways lining the mahogany walls, a mural that depicted the city's era of Dutch settlers, fur traders and American Indians. Slowly, the teen-age artist took a slender brush and began gluing back tiny flecks of paint that were about to crack away from the mural.

description: Confounding the skeptics again, Apple Computer Inc. reported quarterly earnings today that were more than twice the consensus forecast of Wall Street analysts.

title: One Stadium, Four Teams, No Problem
description: The Bronx was in Queens. There were two home teams. No one could begin to figure out who was in either dugout, no less who was on first.

title: 4 Pedestrians Injured as Car Plows Into Cafe
description: A car that careered out of control after colliding with another vehicle slammed into a Morningside Heights bakery cafe yesterday, pinning a Columbia University student against the building and injuring three other pedestrians, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOBKIN, LILLIAN
description: DOBKIN-Lillian. Loving sister of Tillie and Abe. Beloved aunt and great - aunt. Services today 10:30AM at Parkside Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd. at 66th Ave.

title: Indonesia's Telkom To Delay Collections
description: PT Telkom, Indonesia's domestic telephone monopoly, said it would allow a group of joint-venture partners to delay payments to help them survive the country's economic slowdown.

title: Microsoft May Solicit 'Spontaneous' Support
description: The Microsoft Corporation, facing antitrust investigations by a dozen states' attorneys general as well as by the Federal Government, is planning a public relations blitz intended, in a phrase taken from a confidential memo, to ''provide media air cover for a state public affairs campaign,'' The Los Angeles Times has reported.

title: The Road Ford's Taken; Auto Maker Places Biggest Bet Yet on the Behemoths
description: After years of cranking out low-profit heavy-truck tractors through a maze of conveyor belts and robot welders covering more than 100 acres here, North America's largest auto factory has a new product. And it is beginning to earn a fortune for the Ford Motor Company.

title: Disney Financial Officer Named Chief at Starwood
description: Deepening the talent pool in its executive suite, Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide Inc., the world's largest hotel company, said yesterday that it had hired Richard D. Nanula, the young, highly regarded senior executive vice president and chief financial officer of the Walt Disney Company, as president and chief executive.

title: Soaring at 4,500 Feet, Steps From the Fridge
description: THE altimeter shows 4,500 feet as my single-engine plane drones on through the gathering dusk over Connecticut. The radio is silent, the only noise the steady thrum-thrum-thrum of the propeller. I'm edgy about my fuel level, about crossing the Long Island Sound in blackness, about picking out Republic Airport's feeble beacon from the radiant clutter of suburban Long Island. Should I descend through the darkening hills to refuel at Danbury, Conn., or press on?

title: U.S. Is Trying to Defuse a Growing Russia-Latvia Confrontation
description: The United States has been working quietly with other nations to defuse a growing confrontation between Russia and Latvia that threatens to damage Washington's already fraying relationship with Moscow.

title: A Good Ear For the Music of His Own Life
description: Charles Wright has won many prestigious prizes for his poetry, but 1998 is quickly developing into a halcyon year. Last month he won the National Book Critics Circle Award for his collection ''Black Zodiac.'' On Tuesday he received a Pulitzer Prize for the same book.

title: U.S. LIQUIDS BUYING 13 COMPANIES TO REACH NEW MARKETS
description: U.S. Liquids Inc. said yesterday that it planned to buy 13 companies with combined 1997 revenue of $97.6 million for an undisclosed amount to expand into new businesses and geographical markets. The Houston-based processor of nonhazardous waste will finance the cash part of the acquisitions with a credit line recently extended to $100 million. U.S. Liquids said the deals, which were separately negotiated, would let it enter eight unidentified markets outside Texas and Louisiana. This brings to 19 the number of acquisitions U.S. Liquids has announced since its initial public offering in August. Shares of U.S. Liquids, which had 1997 operating revenue of $38.2 million, rose $2.50 yesterday, to $24. Two of the acquired companies will allow U.S. Liquids to enter new markets: outdated beverage processing and the solvent processing and recovery business. Five will become part of its industrial waste division, and one will become part of its oilfield waste division.

title: Court Rules Against Government E-Mail Deletion
description: AS the National Archives and Records Administration tries to come up with a workable plan for preserving electronic records produced by the Federal government, a Federal judge ruled last week that the archives administration cannot continue its policy of allowing Government agencies to delete E-mail messages and computer files as long as they print and save paper copies.

title: With a Big Vacuum in the Pivot, Nets Fall Into Tie With Knicks
description: The Nets scrapped gamely into the final seconds tonight, but after Kerry Kittles misfired on a 3-point attempt that would have tied the game, the Charlotte Hornets put them out of one misery and into another by going on to a 109-103 victory.

title: New Jersey Lab Is Fined Over Care of Animals
description: The United States Department of Agriculture has fined a New Jersey company $50,000 for violating a Federal law that regulates the care and treatment of laboratory animals. But in a settlement, the company, Huntingdon Life Sciences of East Millstone, N.J., agreed to pay the fine without admitting to the charges.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALZER, BERNICE
description: PALZER-Bernice. On April 14, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Alvin. Loving mother of Joanne Wagner and the late David Palzer. Cherished grandmother of Alyssa Weinberger, Steven Moskowitz, Lauren, Allison and Jennifer Palzer-Kramberg and great grandmother to Drew Weinberger. Dear sister of Rhoda Shaw. Services are on Thursday at 1:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Hardly 'Our Crowd': A Jewish Underworld
description: TOUGH JEWS

title: Thousands on L.I. Lose Power After Lilco Transformer Fire
description: A fire at a Long Island Lighting Company power plant in the coastal town of Glenwood Landing this afternoon cut off electricity for about two hours to parts of north-central Nassau County, including Garden City, Carle Place, Mineola and Williston Park.

title: Internet Phone Calls, No Computer Necessary
description: MAKING a phone call over the Internet used to be a challenge. For one thing, there was no phone involved.

title: Out of Left Field, Fans Theorize A Vast Steinbrenner Conspiracy
description: To the list of great conspiracy theories -- the second-gunman theory, the U.F.O.-crash cover-up theory -- New York Yankees fans have added one of their own over the last two days: the Steinbrenner theory.

title: COMPANY REPORTS: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Robert Crandall leaves American Airlines in the hands of 'a user-friendly version' of himself.
description: IF Robert L. Crandall wanted to leave on a high, he certainly picked the right time.

title: Kenyan Runners in the U.S. Find Bitter Taste of Success
description: At the 1997 Bolder Boulder, one of the country's top distance races, Kenyan men captured six of the first eight places. The year before, 8 of the top 10 finishers were Kenyan men.

title: Tamro Will Purchase Danish Drug Distributor
description: Tamro Oyj, a Finnish drug retailer, said yesterday that it would acquire a Danish rival, Nomeco A/S, in a share swap worth 1.2 billion markka ($214 million), to become the Nordic region's largest pharmaceuticals distributor. While Tamro's offer is a 13 percent discount to Nomeco's closing price yesterday, Nomeco will get 34.5 million new Tamro shares, or 28.1 percent of the Finnish company. Monberg & Thorsen Holding A/S, which holds a 60.5 percent stake in Nomeco, is backing the bid.

title: An Aviation Innovator Departs
description: Robert Crandall of American Airlines, who is expected to retire next month, always believed he knew exactly what was right for the airline industry and never hesitated to challenge anyone who disagreed. But he also recognized, to the great benefit of his shareholders, when to junk nostrums that circumstances proved false.

title: Guard Is Fatally Shot At a Roller Rink
description: A security guard at a Brooklyn roller-skating rink was shot and killed early yesterday by a man whom he had refused to allow in, the police said.

title: INSIDE
description: Columbia Student Convicted

title: In Toys' Micro World, a Macro Wallop of Reality
description: MICRO MACHINES V3 is to video games what ''Toy Story'' was to the silver screen. It's a world where, in the absence of human beings, toys take on lives of their own. Everything in this computer-generated world is seen from the perspective of a tiny speedboat, die-cast soapbox racer or toy tank as it zooms across a kitchen floor, speeds up the Evel Knievel ramp of an ironing board and onto the breakfast table, veers around a lake of spilled milk and slaloms between salt and pepper shakers in an adrenaline-pumping race against the clock.

title: Mets Share Everything, Except for First Place
description: When the Mets volunteered to share Shea Stadium for a day with the Yankees, the club had to know that the hoopla of surrounding a historic day-night, American League-National League doubleheader would conspire to overshadow the glory that should be theirs.

title: Too Short a Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: As Idaho Booms, Prisons Fill And Spending on Poor Lags
description: Come to fast-growing Idaho, the people behind the prosperous new economy here like to say, and you will find a nearly crime-free state with no visible poor people.

title: Officials' Incomes Rank in the Top 1%
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey said today that she and her husband made more than $1 million in 1997, while New York City Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his wife earned more than $400,000, and Gov. George E. Pataki of New York and his wife reported more than $300,000. The tax information they made public today showed that their incomes are all comfortably in the top 1 percent of American families.

title: One Digital Day in Her Life
description: NOT even a mundane cough escapes notation in Jennifer Healey's diary. Instead of waxing poetic about the simple pleasure of a cup of coffee or bemoaning the process of writing a thesis, Ms. Healey, a doctoral candidate in electrical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Media Laboratory, has begun recording her physiological responses to her environment in the stark language of bits and bytes.

title: AUTO PARTS MAKER SEEKS STAKE IN BRAZILIAN COMPANY
description: The Dana Corporation, an auto and truck parts manufacturer based in Toledo, Ohio, said it had offered to buy a controlling stake in Nakata S.A., a producer of drive shafts and shock absorbers. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. Dana would gain Nakata factories in Sao Paulo, Brazil, where the company is based, and in Buenos Aires. Nakata had sales of $110 million in 1997. Dana's Brazilian operations already employ 350 people at factories in Osasco, a suburb of Sao Paulo, and Curitiba. The company sells its products to Scania, Volvo, Daimler-Benz, Chrysler and Ford Motor.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Spring Lawn Ritual

title: A Response From Apple
description: To the Editor:

title: Currents; LIGHT FOR THE PARAMOUNT -- Just Meet Me in the Lobby (This Time You'll See Me)
description: Warm and fuzzy the Paramount Hotel on West 46th Street is not. But a seven-month, $7 million renovation has turned the seven-and-a-half-year-old hotel from pitch dark to dusk. The menu in the restaurant is now actually legible.

title: Time Warner Results Flip To Net Loss in the Quarter
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it had swung to a loss in the first quarter, after a profit a year earlier, primarily because of a weak performance at its music division and continued losses at the WB television network.

title: Sports of The Times; The Flights Of Fancy And Reality
description: THE ''retro ball park'' had not been invented when David Cone and Darryl Strawberry called yesterday's temporary baseball shelter home sweet home. Never sexy, Shea Stadium was at least a suitable site for the mid-to-late-1980's Mets' annual autumn run, even when the inevitable jet soared out of nearby La Guardia like the 402-foot retro home run launched to left-center yesterday off Strawberry's bat.

title: Metro Business; Guilty Plea in Fraud Case
description: The owner of a railroad equipment business pleaded guilty yesterday to bank fraud for cheating a West Paterson bank out of more than $15 million in loans in 1989, Federal prosecutors said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAMESON, DOROTHEA
description: JAMESON-Dorothea. On April 12 in her 77th year. Beloved wife of Leo M. Hurvich. University Professor emeritus of Psychology and Visual Science, Department of Psychology and Institute of Neurological Sciences, University of Pennsylvania. Elected to the National Academy of Sciences and The American Academy of Arts and Sciences. Arrangements private. Dottie would be pleased by contributions in her memory to The Center for Constitutional Rights, 656-66 B'way, NY, 10012

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Pennzoil and Quaker State Plan a Combined Company

title: Mannesmann Has Gain In First-Quarter Sales
description: Mannesmann A.G., the operator of Germany's largest mobile telephone company, said first-quarter sales rose 23 percent, more than expected, on strong demand for its mobile and fixed-line telephone services.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the awarding of the Pulitzer Prizes misstated the publication sequence for Philip Roth's novel, ''Sabbath's Theater.'' It was his 21st book, not his first. The prize for fiction was awarded on Tuesday for Mr. Roth's 22d book, ''American Pastoral.''

description: To the Editor:

title: Talking Business With: Fran Reiter; Head of Tourism Unit Sees Plenty of Room for Growth
description: As Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's Deputy Mayor and campaign manager, Fran Reiter earned a reputation as a smart, aggressive lieutenant who got things done. A lifelong New Yorker and alumna of the public schools, Ms. Reiter can talk a blue streak about the greatness of New York City.

title: Tech Support, Part II
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMAN, DR. RUTH LINK, SALINGER
description: HYMAN-Dr. Ruth Link-Salinger. Beloved wife of Dr. Arthur, cherished mother of Jeremy Saul (Lynn), Michael Samuel, and Joseph Isaiah (Rena), dear sister of Adolph Salinger and Rosemarie Salinger Golburg. Adored grandmother of Samuel Ariel. Services Thursday, 1 P.M., Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VINEIS, NORMAN DEMETRIUS
description: VINEIS-Norman Demetrius. Age 83, long-time advertising agency and art studio principal died on Tuesday, April 14, 1998. Mr. Vineis was a co-founder of Monogram Art Studios; founder of Norman Affiliates Ltd. and the Vineis-Mead Agencies. He specialized in the field of creative pharmaceutical advertising until his retirement in 1979. Born in Haledon, N.J., he graduated Paterson Central High School and attended The School of Commerce of New York University. Enlisted in the Army-Air Force, was appointed an aviation cadet and was commissioned in 1943. Posted to the United Kingdom he served as Fighter Control Officer during the invasion of France. Mr. Vineis was a long-time resident of Haworth and member of First Congregational United Church of Christ, Haworth. He served on the Board of Governors of North Jersey Country Club and later became a member of Hackensack Country Club. He is survived by two sons; Paul Jonathan Vineis of Columbus, Ohio and Robert Scott Vineis of Malvern, PA. Also survived by two grandchildren; Drew Jonathan and Reid Patrick Vineis both of Columbus, Ohio. Predeceased by his beloved wife Myrtle M. (nee Lanigan). Funeral Service Friday, April 17, 1:30 PM at First Congregational United Church of Christ, 276 Haworth Avenue, Haworth. Interment George Washington Memorial Park, Paramus. Visiting 12 Noon to 1:15 PM at Church. For information, Volk-Leber Funeral Home, Oradell.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JUROW, IRVING H.
description: JUROW-Irving H. Died peacefully on Friday, April 10, 1998 at his home in Chevy Chase, MD., in his 93rd year. He is survived by his wife of 69 years, Mae Wechsler Jurow. He is also survived by his sister, Edna J. Hirst of New York City, his brother Martin Jurow of Dallas TX, four nieces: Ellin J. Hirst (Ella) of Oakland, CA, Jane Wechsler-Gurganus of Berkeley, CA, Erin Jurow-Eliscu of Dallas, TX, and Antonia Wechsler of New Orleans, LA, 2 nephews: Richard Wechsler of Los Angeles, CA, and David M. Hirst of New York City, and three grandnephews: Gabriel Marshank of New York City, Luke F. Gurganus of Berkeley, CA, and William G. Eliscu of Dallas, TX. There will be no memorial service. If you wish, contributions may be made to your favorite scholarship fund or to the Irving H. Jurow Scholarship fund at New York University, 25 West 4th Street, New York, New York 10012.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Author's Archive

title: Workfare Seen Through Four Pairs of Eyes
description: Last May, ''Dateline'' took to monitoring four single mothers in Wisconsin who were losing welfare as they had known it in accord with their state's much-publicized reform of a discredited system. Tomorrow night, in ''Checks and Balances,'' Maria Shriver traces their experiences from welfare to workfare, from dole to joblessness to job hunting to jobs and back and forth.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOTTENROTH, SR. CONSTANCE MARY
description: HOTTENROTH - Sr. Constance Mary. Beloved member of the Sisters of Charity and former college professor and artist on April 14, 1998. Dear sister of James Hottenroth, retired colonel, and Fred Hottenroth. Also survived by nieces and nephews. Reposing at the Convent of Mary the Queen, 35 Vark St, Yonkers, New York, on Thursday, 1 to 8 PM. Mass of Christian Burial, Friday, 9:30 AM at the Convent. Interment at St. Joseph's Cemetery, Yonkers. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, 6301 Riverdale Ave, Bronx, New York 10471.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on April 9 about James J. Leff, a retired New York State Supreme Court Justice, misstated the source of his bachelor's degree in 1942. It was New York University; ''school'' was not part of the name.

title: Players and Agents Fight Over the N.F.L.'s Spoils
description: This weekend, hundreds of players will be selected by National Football League teams in the yearly ritual of the college draft. Those players may not know it, but when they sign their contracts, they will become part of what is being described as a revolt by veteran players, one that could drastically change the way billions of dollars a year change hands in professional football.

title: Big=Bad, Unless It Doesn't
description: In his 1996 State of the Union Message, President Clinton proclaimed the end of big government. Those who applauded did so with a certain ambivalence. Was it the end of bigness they welcomed? Or the end of government?

title: Phil North, 79, Ex-Tandy Chief Executive
description: Phil R. North, a journalist and former president, chairman and chief executive of the Tandy Corporation between 1978 and 1981, died Sunday in All Saints Episcopal Hospital in Fort Worth, after a long illness. He was 79.

title: Merrill Lynch Narrows Review
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it had named three finalists to compete in a review for its account, with billings estimated at $70 million. The account had been handled for 12 years by Bozell Worldwide in New York, a unit of True North Communications, which resigned rather than take part in the review as it began in February.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSSMAN, HAROLD
description: GROSSMAN-Harold. On April 10, 1998. Loving husband of Gloria, beloved father of Sandy, caring grandfather of Rikki and Ross and dear brother of Ralph. It can be said that Harold Grossman had an active, productive life with its share of satisfying moments, mostly because he had the opportunity at the Allentown Jewish Community Center and on the basketball court to tell so many youngsters that living according to the rules is the best way and they would benefit from it. This they did because of Harold. May he rest in peace.

title: Ancient Hindu Festival Thrives in Computer-Age India
description: The rushing grey-green waters of the Ganges were as chilly as they have been in years today as A. K. Sharma stripped to his underwear, plunged into the shallow edge of India's holiest river and raised cupped handfuls of water towards the rising sun.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, IRVING
description: GOODMAN-Irving. On April 14, 1998. Loving husband of the late Sherry, devoted father of Adrienne, Stan, and Meryl, adoring grandfather of Sara and Shana.

title: 2 Speedster Chips Joining a Clunker
description: The Intel Corporation yesterday formally unveiled several new Pentium II microprocessors, including two speedsters that are rated at 350 megahertz and 400 MHz. Intel said that both chips were most likely to be used initially in server computers, which act as hubs for computer networks, but that megahertz machismo would cause some consumers to put them on their desktops.

title: Our Towns; In Wildwood, Bets Are Still On Gambling
description: FRED WAGER is getting impatient with all the nattering naysayers. As Mayor of this great little resort, he promised to give tourist-chomping Atlantic City a poke in the eye. He told voters he would try to bring a casino here, and, three years later, by golly, that's just what he's going to do.

title: Compaq Earnings Fall 96%, Meeting Lowered Expectations
description: After warning in early March that it would have disappointing first-quarter financial results, the Compaq Computer Corporation reported revenues and earnings yesterday that met Wall Street analysts' lowered expectations.

title: New Disney Kingdom Comes With Real-Life Obstacles
description: Having transformed a cow pasture into an African savanna and 500 acres of Central Florida into yet another theme park, the Walt Disney Company is about to unveil the most un-Disney of entertainment: an amusement park that relies on live animals rather than fake ones and that is already proving to be a challenge before its inauguration.

title: Agency to Delay Installation Of Disputed Air Traffic Plan
description: The Federal Aviation Administration agreed today to delay the phase-in of a $1 billion air traffic modernization project until it can reach agreement with the controllers who argue that the new equipment is less capable than the 30-year-old equipment it is meant to replace.

title: Making Books; Popularizing Western History
description: Thomas Cahill, a Christian, would like Passover to last at least until Christmas, averaging about three seders a week until then. This hankering ecumenism springs mostly from the fact that he is the author of ''The Gifts of the Jews: How a Tribe of Desert Nomads Changed the Way Everyone Thinks and Feels,'' which is popping off bookstore shelves this holiday season into the hands of eager readers or gift givers.

title: Currents; STEEL NETTING -- For Stretching Out
description: Like a Slinky, it's a simple metal thing that's fun to play with. Called X-Tend, the stainless steel stretchy netting is made in Germany by Carl Stahl. It has found use in railings and zoo enclosures, as well as in furniture. Thomas Ferwagner, an engineer who invented the product, has designed indoor-outdoor furniture with stainless frames to support it. The Zammy chair is $650 ($950 with arms) and the Lazy chaise longue is $1,825. X-Tend is also available separately ($20 a square foot, 50 percent stretched). All from Decor Cable Innovations in Chicago, (800) 444-6271.

title: Audrey Freedman Dies at 68; Specialized in Labor Issues
description: Audrey Freedman, an economist who specialized in labor issues while working for the United States Government and in the private sector, died on Sunday in Mount Sinai Hospital in New York. She was 68 and lived in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Honk if You Like Ecological Housing
description: SOMEWHERE between the pantries for bulk produce and the fireplaces with the catalytic converters, a brave bit of eco-history is being made as the 41-unit Cambridge co-housing project, now nearing completion, vies for the honor of the most excruciatingly earnest politically progressive apartment complex in the country.

title: A Switch Made in Detroit Saves Revenue
description: George Steinbrenner was walking briskly in the bowels of Yankee Stadium yesterday, but he stopped to lavishly compliment Mike Ilitch, the owner of the Detroit Tigers, for switching the series with the Yankees while Yankee Stadium undergoes repairs for structural defects. It made sense for the owner to be so praiseworthy because Ilitch helped save the Yankees.

title: Botha Trial Begins After Talks to Avoid It Fail
description: The trial of the former President, P. W. Botha, began here today after negotiations to avoid proceedings against the defiant apartheid-era leader broke down early this morning.

title: TECH DATA TO ACQUIRE COMPUTER 2000 FOR $386 MILLION
description: Shares of the Tech Data Corporation rose as much as 22 percent after it agreed to buy an 80 percent stake in Computer 2000 A.G. from Viag A.G. of Germany for about $386 million. The shares rose $8.8125 to close at $47.6875. Tech Data, a computing equipment distributor based in Clearwater, Fla., acquired the German computer distributor Macrotron A.G. last year. The new deal strengthens Tech Data's foothold in Germany, France and other European markets as it vies with Ingram Micro Inc. of Santa Ana, Calif., as the world's biggest computer distributor. The deal creates a company with about 9,000 employees and 27 billion marks ($15 billion) in sales this year, Viag said.

title: Turf; Dreams, and Now Hope, Among the Ruins
description: EXPOSED steel girders stand out rudely against the sky, rusted reminders of what were once finely detailed brownstones. On the same block, the interiors of prime examples of High Victorian architecture are mostly gone. The evening light shines through Gothic windows missing their glass.

title: House Proud; A Loft That Meditates On Design
description: ADAM DOLLE, who was a monk for five years, had to wait to get to New York to find a life of pure design.

title: Fingerprinting Program A Success in 8 Cities
description: A pilot program that began using electronic fingerprinting in heavy crime areas 10 months ago has led to the arrests of 649 people on outstanding warrants who might otherwise have been released after they gave false names to the police, officials said yesterday.

title: Theft of the Big Berthas Is a Growing Problem
description: The masked bandits were armed with the walkie-talkies and the police scanners usually associated with professional bank or jewelry heists. But these thieves weren't after cash or gems. What they wanted were expensive designer golf clubs, specifically Ely Callaway's Great Big Berthas and Biggest Big Bertha drivers, the titanium stars of the line.

title: Putting an End to Puddle Jumping; Ragged Track in Central Park to Get a Makeover, and a Tilt
description: The 1.577-mile oval track around the Central Park Reservoir is a path of pain, patience and pure joy. The heart of running in New York City, it is where a bare-chested man runs 20 miles every day of the year. It is where the world's marathoners tune up, and where couples with thumping hearts meet and sometimes marry. Celebrity joggers from Madonna to Iron Mike have been sighted like rare birds.

title: When Diversity Comes at a Price; Fueling Resentment
description: To the Editor:

title: Swiss Banks Report Combined Earnings Gain
description: The Swiss Bank Corporation and Union Bank of Switzerland, which are merging to form UBS A.G., Europe's biggest bank, had combined net income of 1.3 billion Swiss francs ($871 million) in the first quarter of 1998, more than their combined average quarterly earnings last year. In 1997, Union Bank and Swiss Bank had combined profits from operations of 5.04 billion francs.

title: Easing Its Stand on Detentions, Israel Frees a Palestinian
description: Israel today freed the longest-serving Palestinian prisoner held without trial, signaling a softening of a policy criticized as one of the country's most serious violations of human rights.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN RALLY HALTED. The yen's rise stalled after Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said the Group of Seven would maintain its current policy. The dollar cost 129.36 yen in New York, little changed from 129.55 yen on Tuesday.

title: Y2K Bug? A Simple Fix.
description: To the Editor:

title: Latin American Agenda
description: The Summit of the Americas in Chile later this week finds both Latin America and its relationship with the United States in far better health than in the recent past. Except for Cuba, which was barred from the summit, all the nations are nominally democracies. On most issues the mistrust and even hostility that once characterized Washington's relations with Latin nations have been replaced by cooperation. Still, Latin America has enjoyed a wave of elected civilian leadership twice before in this century. Insuring that this one lasts requires deepening democracy and extending the benefits of growth to the poor. There is more Washington can do on both counts.

title: Amid Uncertainty, Policymakers Talk Up Currency : Trans-Atlantic Cheer for Euro
description: WASHINGTON  The European commissioner overseeing the historic shift to a single currency brought a message of reassurance here Wednesday, saying that while the advent of the euro will represent "an unprecedented challenge," the transition from 11 currencies to one should bolster the global economy without unduly roiling foreign exchange markets.

title: Finding Even More Ways To Listen to Your Computer
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethics Training Planned For Union County Police
description: The Union County prosecutor said yesterday that he would order the county's 1,800 law enforcement officers to undergo ethics training in the wake of findings that preferential treatment was given to an Elizabeth police officer charged with beating his elderly brother and sister.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLADSTONE, MILTON
description: GLADSTONE-Milton. Congregation Kol Ami of White Plains, New York records with sorrow the passing of our cherished member, and conveys sincere condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Shira Milgrom Rabbi Tom Weiner Cantor Annie Bornstein-Howard Mark A. Hershey, President

title: When Diversity Comes at a Price; Berkeley's 'White-Out'
description: To the Editor:

title: Radio Show's Host Is Charged With Stock Promotion Scheme
description: The host of a radio program broadcast in New York and other cities was charged yesterday with taking thousands of dollars in secret payments from companies in return for promoting their stocks on the air in a scheme that prosecutors said defrauded hundreds of novice investors out of more than $1 million.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: ICC TECHNOLOGIES INC., Hatboro, Pa., a maker of humidity-control systems, agreed to acquire Rare Medium Inc., New York, a closely held Internet-services company, for $45 million in cash, stock and notes.

title: One Tough Robot To Brave Chernobyl
description: It has been 12 years since the reactor meltdown at Chernobyl, the world's worst nuclear accident, and the rubble is still far too ''hot'' to allow a thorough human inspection. Even in protective suits, people would absorb more than the recommended lifetime allowance of radiation in just a few minutes. Even robots can be killed by radiation at the levels found at Chernobyl, as unshielded silicon chips erode quickly, glass camera lenses turn brown, and joints become brittle.

title: New Projects Seek to Revive Battered Oklahoma City
description: For many, this city evokes the image of a dying child pulled from a smoldering ruin.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: 13.2% Fall in Coca-Cola's Net Tied to Devalued Currencies
description: The Coca-Cola Company reported a 13.2 percent drop in first-quarter earnings yesterday, sending its stock down $1.188 a share to close at $76.6875.

title: Cendant Finds $115 Million Accounts Error
description: The Cendant Corporation, one of the nation's largest franchisers and direct marketers, announced late yesterday that it had uncovered accounting irregularities that would force the company to lower its 1997 earnings by as much as $115 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, ESTELLE
description: BERNSTEIN-Estelle. On April 15, 1998. Beloved wife of William for 53 years. Loving and cherished mother of Dr. Michael R. Bernstein of Madison, Wisconsin, Susan Penny Bernstein of Queens, New York and the late Barry S. Bernstein. Dear sister of Laura Tilzer. Visits by relatives and friends welcome at home evenings, 7-10 PM through Friday, April 17.

title: Taking the Show on the Road
description: David Wells was wobbling around the sedate clubhouse at Yankee Stadium at 7:45 A.M. yesterday, pouring more coffee than a Starbucks employee. Paul O'Neill was slouched motionless in his chair, looking like someone who needed a pillow. Darryl Strawberry was teasing his teammates about being so bleary-eyed, an hour after his wife had awakened to cook him pancakes and bacon.

title: Logitech Gains Immersion Stake
description: Logitech International S.A., the world's biggest computer-mouse maker, said Tuesday that it had bought a 10 percent stake in the software company the Immersion Corporation to speed development of new mice and joysticks.

title: Pennzoil and Quaker State Plan a Two-Stage Merger
description: Pennzoil and Quaker State, striving to endow motor oil with the clean cachet of toothpaste and detergent, announced plans today to combine into a new, dominant force in the sale and manufacture of automotive lubricants, waxes and additives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HUGHES, ANITA D.
description: HUGHES-Anita D. Died peacefully in her sleep at home April 11, 1998, after suffering from emphysema (although a non-smoker her whole life). Anita is survived by her husband, John; daughter, Stephanie; son, Wesley; grandchildren, Robert, Jane, Jeannie, Richard, David, Susan, Shane; 21 great-grandchildren, and one great-great-grandchild. Contributions in her memory may be made to a charity of your choice.

title: Kwan Signs TV Deal With Disney
description: Tara Lipinski may have won the Olympic gold medal, but the silver medalist Michelle Kwan is so far winning the endorsements battle. Yesterday, Kwan signed a deal with Walt Disney, the parent company of ABC television, to perform four prime-time skating specials on the network over the next four years.

title: Brazil Power Asset Sale Attracts Few Bidders
description: Brazil said yesterday that it had sold its largest power distributor for 2.026 billion reals ($1.78 billion), though it failed to sell a second distributor as demand for the electric assets being sold proved weaker than expected.

title: Earnings Up 7% At BankAmerica
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, which plans to merge with the Nationsbank Corporation to create the second-largest bank in the United States, said yesterday that its earnings had risen 7 percent in the first quarter.

title: Just Good Buddies, At Home in Queens
description: George Steinbrenner and Rudy Giuliani have become an item. Their words (''my kind of Mayor, a great Mayor,'' George said of Rudy) and actions have made that development obvious. Why, look at them sitting there so cozily next to each other next to the Yankees' dugout. George's right arm is even around the back of Rudy's chair, and they couldn't be any closer.

title: Statehouse Journal; A Wisp of Scandal, but Nothing More
description: Below the gilded dome of Colorado's Capitol, it was business as usual for Gov. Roy Romer this week, signing bills, vetoing a tax cut and endorsing Democratic candidates for statewide offices.

title: Personal Shopper; Table Magic: Now You See It, Now You Don't
description: THE tables are turned, you might say. Tilted. Even raised and lowered. These problem-solving trickster tables do double duty: low coffee tables turn into dining tables, and handsome folding tables wait demurely against the wall for dinner to be served.

title: Parking Rules
description: Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today for Orthodox Holy Thursday, tomorrow for Orthodox Good Friday and the seventh day of Passover, and Saturday for the eighth day of Passover. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Scouting a Path For Home Networks
description: I OPENED the door of my refrigerator the other night and gazed upon a few limp scallions, a cucumber and a forlorn can of tuna.
