title: Stadium Is to Remain Closed Another Week for Repairs
description: Yankee Stadium will remain closed for another week so workers can repair concrete that was in danger of crumbling from the 75-year-old ballpark's facade, city officials said yesterday.

title: The Pop Life
description: ''I'd be just as comfortable doing this interview at the drive-through at Taco Bell,'' Ice Cube said as he sat down to his first meal at the Ivy. A Hollywood industry haunt, the Ivy is a restaurant he will have to get used to if he continues along the trajectory his career is on.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on March 5 about Gregoris Staktopoulos, a Greek journalist, misstated the availability of a book about the 1948 death of George Polk, a CBS correspondent, in Greece. (Mr. Staktopoulos was convicted in 1949 as an accessory in the murder.) The book, ''The Salonika Bay Murder: Cold War Politics and the Polk Affair,'' by Edmund Keeley, is available from Princeton University Press, not from Books on Demand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FITZPATRICK, EDWARD J.
description: FITZPATRICK-Edward J. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York, records with profound sorrow the death of Edward J. Fitzpatrick, a Life Member of the Society, and extends sincere sympathy to his family. William J. Cronin, President Robert J. Reilly, Historian

title: Trade Secrets; Radiant Fabrics Play the Role Of Furniture
description: WHEN in Nepal, Erich Theophile, an American architect, does as the Nepalese do. He abandons most Western amenities (except a drafting table, dining table, some chairs and a flush toilet) and, in the Nepalese style, sleeps on the floor, entertains on the floor and sends his guests to bed on the floor of his 2,500-square-foot five-story house in Patan, a city of 80,000 people. The city is across the Baghmati River from Katmandu, the capital. What gives the house warmth, sensuality and color is not furniture, but Mr. Theophile's extravagant use of textiles.

title: Italian Banks to Merge In $10.7 Billion Deal
description: Credito Italiano S.p.A., Italy's sixth-largest bank, agreed yesterday to acquire Unicredito, the nation's eighth-largest banking group, for 19 trillion lire, or $10.7 billion. The transaction would create a financial institution with 300 trillion lire ($168 billion) in assets.

title: Recalling Brendan Gill, Literary Man About Town
description: The writer Brendan Gill, in his lifetime a sought-after speaker at dozens of memorial services, had definite ideas of what such a service should be.

description: BASKETBALL

title: Council Hearing Barred From Harlem Hospital
description: City Council members thought Harlem Hospital Center would be a fitting place for a public hearing on layoffs planned in city-owned hospitals. The Giuliani administration disagreed, so the members of the Council's Health Committee staged a rally in the rain yesterday and then took the meeting across the street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEALY, JOSEPHINE CIRIGLIANO
description: HEALY-Josephine Cirigliano. On Tuesday, April 14, 1998. Loving wife of Patrick. Loving sister of Frank and Jerry Cirigliano, Victoria Matranga and Mary Weinberg. Also survived by numerous nieces and nephews. Mrs. Healy was a forty year employee of the Union Labor Life Insurance Company. Friends may call on Friday from 2-4 and 7-9 PM, Demaine Funeral Home, 520 S. Washington Street, Alexandria, VA. Mass of Christian Burial will be held on Saturday at 11:30 at Our Lady of Lourdes Catholic Church, 830 South 23 Street, Arlington, Virginia. Interment to be held privately at a later date at Arlington National Cemetery. Memorial contributions may be made to Hospice of Northern Virginia, 6400 Arlington Boulevard, Suite 1000, Falls Church, Virginia 22042.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There are good reasons for building prisons, but our one solution to everything -- drugs, alcohol abuse, minor offenses -- is prison, and that is simply not cost-effective.''

title: An Evening of Drama, and Not All of It Beethoven's
description: The first 5 of Beethoven's 10 sonatas for violin and piano, played in order on one long evening, may not seem like the most sensible idea for a recital program. But the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter and her frequent musical partner, the pianist Lambert Orkis, had an audience at Carnegie Hall on its feet and vociferously grateful when their recital concluded on Tuesday night.

title: It May Be Boilerplate, but Read Before You Click
description: IT'S a common experience. You're surfing the Web and you come upon a service you would like to sign up for, or you rush home from the store to install a computer game you can't wait to try. Pages filled with small type splash on your screen. Impatiently, you click on the ''I Agree'' or ''I Accept'' button at the end of each page.

title: Man Is Convicted of Assaulting Woman He Met on the Internet
description: Oliver Jovanovic, a doctoral student at Columbia University, was convicted yesterday of kidnapping and assaulting a Barnard College student who met him on the Internet and who said he tortured her for more than 20 hours. After the verdict was read, Mr. Jovanovic wept quietly in the Manhattan courtroom.

title: Thai Troubles Drive a Dynasty To Sell Its Crown Jewel Bank
description: Photos of the Thai King adorn the walls of most local companies and homes. But at the Wanglee Company, that honor is reserved for the sage, sepia-toned likeness of Tan Siew-Wang, forefather of one of Thailand's most famous business clans.

title: A Korean Debut, Traditional but Hybrid
description: The Universal Ballet from South Korea is not your everyday classical ballet company. For one thing, it has unusual international antecedents. But for its New York debut on Tuesday night, the troupe opened a week at City Center with an apt bow to native tradition. ''Shim Chung: The Blind Man's Daughter'' draws on Korean legend and is a fairy tale ballet about virtue rewarded.

title: Currents; NEW ART SCHOOL -- Umbrella of Tourcoing: Where Imagination Finds Shelter
description: How did a bunch of old yellow buildings end up parked in an airplane hangar in France? To house Le Fresnoy, a new Government art school near Lille, the architect Bernard Tschumi built a metal shell over a cluster of modest sports arenas that had been erected in the 1920's. The 304-foot-long bristly steel roof looms like the mother ship in ''Independence Day.''

title: The New Budget Game in Albany
description: The halls of the Capitol in Albany echoed with self-congratulation this week as the Legislature approved a $71 billion budget only two weeks late. In truth, the lawmakers' accomplishment was noteworthy. Not simply was this the earliest budget in five years, it resulted from the most open and participatory legislative process in modern times. Some maneuvering went on behind the scenes, but the Legislature achieved a procedural watershed that ought to be hard to reverse in the future.

title: Metro Business; Wall Street Buildings Are in High Demand
description: The hot commercial real estate market on Wall Street seems to be reaching a fever point.

Adored husband of Betty, fabulous father, special grandfather, beloved uncle, cousin and friend. Graveside services were held. Donations to American Cancer Society.

title: Currents; RECYCLED REJECTS -- A Finish With Shine: Tuna-Can Veneer
description: Francois Jantzen, a French interior designer, was so taken with the way West Africans veneer their wooden briefcases with recycled metal that he worked with Senegalese craftsmen to develop a line of decorative objects covered with colorful tuna tins (factory misprints). A 47-inch-high chest of drawers lined with Senegalese comics costs $750. The designer, who ships all over the world, can be reached at (213) 850-5526.

title: DVD Movie Rentals Will Begin Next Month
description: Circuit City said the first Digital Video Express systems will be ready for sale in a few selected cities by this time next month, with a nationwide rollout scheduled for late July or early August.

In lieu of flowers donations to Rice H.S. of NYC Annual Fund in his memory would be appreciated.

title: Congress Investigating Sales of Satellite Technology to China
description: Several Congressional committees are investigating whether the Administration's policy of exporting space satellite technology to China has helped China and other countries to develop and use nuclear missiles.

description: If the Knicks are going to avoid the Farewell to the Bulls as We Know Them Tour in the first round of the playoffs, they will have to do it without a healthy Larry Johnson.

title: Somali Gunmen Kidnap 9 Foreign Red Cross Workers
description: Somali militiamen kidnapped nine foreign Red Cross workers today in Mogadishu, the capital, even as the main Somali faction leaders ended talks here with an agreement to set up a new government in that lawless, shattered city.

title: Two Locals Have Nothing to Fight About
description: Madison Square Garden was filled for a meaningless game last night between two teams in the final week of disappointing seasons. There were extra security guards, too, and a larger news media contingent than usual. Many came to see if the Rangers and Islanders, both eliminated from the post-season, would take out their frustrations with the sort of multiplayer, fist-fighting melee they engaged in earlier this month.

title: Group of 7 Has Words but No Action for Japan
description: Finance ministers and the heads of the central banks of the world's largest industrialized nations said today that the yen had fallen too far as Japan struggles to pull out of its worst financial straits in years.

title: Long-Distance Deal Proposed in Canada

The combined company would operate a network with more than 9,100 miles of fiber serving more than 1.35 million customers across Canada, with connections into the United States and overseas.

title: Teheran Mayor Is Freed From Jail, Easing Factional Tensions
description: The Mayor of Teheran, Gholamhossein Karabaschi, was freed from prison on bail today, 11 days after his arrest on corruption charges threw Iranian politics into a wave of upheaval.

title: Clinton Sweeps In to Promise Storm Aid
description: A week after a tornado roared into existence and then vanished just as abruptly here, President Clinton appeared in Alabama today to survey the jumble made so swiftly of lives and belongings and to promise that the Federal Government would assist with the recovery ''all the way.''

title: Can Intelligent Life Be Found On Line? Gorilla Will Go Looking
description: If millions of humans type on millions of computer keyboards for one hour, will they be able to write anything of interest to an ape? The world will find out on April 27, when Koko the gorilla will answer questions from America Online subscribers in what AOL contends will be the first interspecies chat on the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JONES, HOWARD H.
description: JONES-Howard H. Passed away March 16, 1998 in Ft. Lauderdale, FL. Mr. Jones was born May 15, 1908 to John Jones and Lillian Spindler in New York City. Mr. Jones graduated from Concordia Seminary in St. Louis, and was a veteran of World War II. Mr. Jones retired as Vice Chairman of the Board of Directors of the F & M Schaefer Brewing Co. He served as president of the NY State Brewers Assoc., and the Metropolitan Brewers Institute. He was a member of the Lambs Club and served on its board of governors, and was a director of the Lambs Foundation. Mr. Jones was pre-deceased by his wives Gloria N. Jones and Eleanor W. Jones. He is survived by his sister Viola Hentz.

description: The speed limit on 475 miles of state roads will be raised to 65 miles per hour starting May 19, the State Department of Transportation announced yesterday.

title: Integrated Electrical Deals
description: Integrated Electrical Services Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire nine electrical contracting and maintenance companies with combined 1997 revenues of $140 million. Terms of the deals, expected to close by the end of next month, were not disclosed. Integrated Electrical, based here, provides electrical contracting and maintenance services. For the three months ended Dec. 31, it reported revenue of $86.3 million.

description: David Verklin, the top media executive at Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco, said yesterday that he would leave after 11 years to join Carat North America in New York, the media services agency owned by Aegis Group P.L.C., in the new position of chief executive.

description: Usinor S.A., Europe's No. 2 steelmaker, said yesterday that its 1997 second-half profit nearly doubled, and predicted that first-half earnings this year would jump.

title: Led by Technology Issues, Dow Marches to Another High
description: Technology stocks rallied yesterday, with I.B.M. and Hewlett-Packard leading the Dow Jones industrial average to its second consecutive record and Microsoft and Cisco Systems lifting the Nasdaq composite index to its first new high in a week and a half.

description: WHILE the timing was dramatic, the news this week of two gigantic bank mergers shocked few economists who specialize in financial markets.

title: Ancient Machines For Making Text
description: FOR most people, typewriters are beside the point, a relic of a past age. For Richard Polt, however, a typewriter collector who has established one of the Web's most elaborate sites about typewriters, being a relic of the past is the point, like discovering that a sword happens to be Excalibur.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KILBORNE, VIRGINIA W.

Wife of the late William S. Kilborne, survived by her sister, Mrs. Bethuel Webster, 3 nieces, Elizabeth Mills, Susan Hyde and Penelope Davis and four stepchildren. Memorial service, May 16, 11 AM, Nassau Presbyterian Church, Princeton, New Jersey.

description: PRAGER - Karsten. Time - Life Building, on April 20th, 8th Floor auditorium. 4:30 PM. The fund will support mid-career fellowships for journalists from other countries studying at the university or American journalists studying international affairs. Gifts can be made to the University of Michigan, noting their purpose for the Prager fund and sent to the Michigan Journalism Fellows, 620 Oxford Road, Ann Arbor, Michigan 48104.

title: Connecticut Lawmakers Approve Electric Deregulation
description: The General Assembly took a big step today toward ending the monopolies enjoyed by the state's electric utilities, passing a bill that would allow residents to choose a power company in much the same way they now select a long-distance telephone service.

title: NEWS WATCH
description: A NEW SOFTWARE system in Singapore allows people to call for a taxi by E-mail. The system, introduced last week, sends a request to an automated cab dispatcher system and returns a confirmation by E-mail.

title: There Are Divas, and There Are Divas
description: Five singers were on the bill for ''Divas Live,'' a concert at the Beacon Theater that was telecast by VH1 on Tuesday night, and six women performed. Mariah Carey, Celine Dion, Gloria Estefan, Aretha Franklin and Shania Twain were joined by Carole King as an unannounced guest. But there was only one real diva onstage: Ms. Franklin, who presented the true diva's combination of a remarkable voice, a commanding presence and a whimsical, imperious assumption of power. With Ms. Franklin around, the rest were only troupers.

description: KREMER-Charles P. In his 97th year after a brief illness. Beloved father of David, Jerry and Suzan. Grandfather of Nora and Howard, Robin and Fred, Katherine, Lindsey, Marc and Rick and Mindy. Great-grandfather of Benjamin, Brett, Gabrielle, Jenna, Justin and Sam. A wonderful warmhearted man who lived his life to the fullest and who gave unconditional love to his family. To know him was to love him. Services Friday 11:15 AM at ''Gutterman's Inc.'' 175 Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, Long Island. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Long Beach Medical Center, 425 East Bay Drive, Long Beach, New York 11561.

title: Design Notebook; Living Askew in a Community of Tilted Terrains
description: IN a decision that has surprised the Japanese architectural establishment, the city of Tokyo recently awarded the New York artists-turned-architects Shusaku Arakawa and Madeline Gins a special award for their plan to develop a two-phase, $7 billion housing and commercial project on approximately 75 acres of landfill in Tokyo Bay.

title: Pol Pot Is Dead, Thai Army Says; Made Cambodia a 'Killing Field'
description: Pol Pot, who turned Cambodia into a slaughterhouse in the 1970's, causing the deaths of more than a million people, died on Wednesday of a heart attack in his jungle hideout, Thai military and Khmer Rouge sources said today.

title: Acclaim for Outspoken Voice of Riverdale
description: TUESDAY afternoon, Bernard L. Stein, the co-publisher and editor of The Riverdale Press, the weekly Bronx thumb-in-the-eye, politely declined an impromptu sit-down interview.

title: BRITISH GROUP BUYS SOFTWARE MAKER FOR $128.7 MILLION
description: The British engineering group Siebe P.L.C. said it had agreed to buy Simulation Sciences Inc., a commercial simulation software maker, for $128.7 million, or $10 a share. News of the deal drove Simulation Sciences shares up $1.75, to $9.8125. Simulation Sciences, which is based in Brea, Calif., expects to report a first-quarter loss of 38 cents to 48 cents a share on revenue of $9 million to $9.6 million. Analysts had predicted profit of 4 cents a share in the quarter that ended on March 31. In the quarter a year earlier, Simulation posted a net loss of $3.7 million, or 35 cents a share, on revenue of $13.6 million.

title: State Legislature Approves $950 Million Increase in Spending for Education
description: In what is by far the steepest spending increase in this election-year state budget, the Legislature has approved raising the allocation for public schools to $11.9 billion, a $950 million increase over last year.

title: NEWPORT NEWS SHIPBUILDING TO LAY OFF 600 WORKERS
description: Newport News Shipbuilding Inc. said yesterday that it would lay off 600 workers in its commercial and military shipbuilding units. About half the employees are being laid off in connection with the discontinuation of commercial shipbuilding operations, announced last month. The rest of the layoffs result from the nearly simultaneous completion of work on the aircraft carriers the U.S.S. Theodore Roosevelt and the U.S.S. Harry S. Truman. Newport News said it expected to return to the current level of employment by early 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GEWIRTZ, HERMAN
description: GEWIRTZ - Herman. Former Chairman of the Physics and Chemistry Departments at the Bronx High School of Science, died on April 12, 1998. Devoted and beloved husband of the late Matilda Gewirtz. Deeply loved and admired father of Paul Gewirtz, Jonathan Gewirtz, and the late George Gewirtz, and grandfather of Julian, Alec, Arden and Emery. Brother of Sam, Willie, and Nettie. A man who possessed the finest of minds, and, even rarer, a man of true goodness and decency.

title: German Court Revokes Ruling on Ownership Of a Schiele Painting
description: In a setback to an American family seeking to reclaim an Egon Schiele painting confiscated by the Nazis during World War II, a German court has revoked the declaration of heirship, granted in 1963, that provides a basis of its claim. But the family members said the ruling was made without their knowledge and would not deter their efforts to insure the work's ''rightful disposition.''

title: Commerce Secretary Seeks Compromise on Encryption
description: The Clinton Administration's attempts to control encryption technology have been a failure and are forcing American software makers to concede ground to foreign competitors, Commerce Secretary William M. Daley said today.

Holly will also bring to the new company a refinery in Montana, where Giant has no operations. Holly shares rose $3.875, to a 52-week high of $30.50; Giant rose 93.75 cents, to a 52-week high of $21.5625. Giant had 1997 sales of $657.3 million, while Holly had sales of $719.4 million. title: Making Yankee Stadium Safe
description: After the 1988 Williamsburg Bridge crisis, New Yorkers hoped, perhaps foolishly, that the era of benign neglect of the city's public assets had ended. Monday's incident at Yankee Stadium, where a heavy chunk of steel and concrete came loose and crashed into empty seats below the upper deck, proves otherwise. Neither the city, which owns the stadium, nor the Yankees, who play there, had given the venerable ball park a comprehensive inspection for 19 years. Even worse, it turns out that there is not even a local ordinance that requires either side to conduct structural inspections to spot problems that are not visible to the eye. This gaping hole in the city's public safety regulations and in its lease with the Yankees will have to be closed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KANZER, MARK, MD.
description: KANZER-Mark, MD. A noted psychoanalyst, author and educator, died April 14th at the King Street Nursing Home in Rye Brook, NY of congestive heart failure at the age of 89. In 1994, shortly after Dr. Kanzer's retirement, the Journal of the American Psychoanalytic Association published a tribute to him (Volume 42, Issue 3, page 695), noting ''His scholarship was awesome, and his prolific contributions enriched the psychoanalytic literature...'' Dr. Kanzer was a founder of the Division of Psychoanalytic Education at Downstate Medical Center, now the Psychoanalytic Institute at New York University, and served as Director of the Institute. Dr. Kanzer was the co-editor with Jules Glenn, MD of Volumes 1 and 2 of ''Freud and His Self-Analysis'' (1979). His many published articles include ''Freud and the Demon'', ''Freud and His Literary Doubles'', ''The Passing of the Oedipus Complex'' in Greek drama, ''The Oedipus Trilogy'', ''On Interpreting the Oedipus Plays'', and ''Oedipus: History, Legends, Plays, Complexes.'' Dr. Arnold D. Richards, Editor, Journal of the American Psychoanalytic Association, said ''Dr. Kanzer should be remembered for his extraordinary psychoanalytic philanthropy as well as his scholarship.'' Dr. Kanzer established the Mark and Viva Kanzer Fund in the 1970's under the editorship of Harold Blum and funded an annual journal prize and made possible many other important journal publishing projects. Dr. Kanzer is survived by his son, Alan, a New York attorney.

title: Survivors' Voices
description: These are accounts by people who were children in Cambodia in the 1970's, when the Khmer Rouge came to power there. They are excerpts from ''Children of Cambodia's Killing Fields,'' published by Yale University Press.

title: Metro Business; Armory in Chelsea Sells for $15 Million
description: The State of New York has agreed to sell the 14th Street Armory in Manhattan for $15 million to a group of investors that includes Care Matrix Corporation.

description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 14.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Circuits section yesterday about typewriter collectors misstated the Web address of the Classic Typewriter Page. It is: xavier.xu.edu/polt/typewriters.html

title: Harmful Silence on Algeria
description: More than a month has passed since the United Nations Commission on Human Rights began its annual meeting in Geneva, and no one has introduced a resolution criticizing Algeria. The repeated massacres in villages there are among the world's worst human rights abuses, yet the Algerian Government has defied international efforts to investigate them. Today is the deadline for introducing resolutions in Geneva. The United States should call for a U.N. special rapporteur on Algeria to visit regularly and report on abuses.

title: It's Almost Like a Woody Allen Movie, but Wait: It's Real Life!
description: In her unexpectedly delightful documentary about Woody Allen as jazz musician, Barbara Kopple demonstrates cinema verite at its most seductive. Her ''Wild Man Blues'' invites its audience to take a grand tour of Europe, listen to jauntily exhilarating music and regard Mr. Allen in a colorful new light. There he sits, legs crossed but feet tapping, playing vintage New Orleans music with a joyfulness and abandon that have no place in his own films. In these exuberant, unguarded moments, Mr. Allen comes alive through his art just as his recent alter egos have on screen.

title: Ex-Chief of Peregrine Is Hired by Templeton
description: Philip Tose, who built Peregrine Investments Holdings Ltd. into the No. 1 underwriter of Asian stocks only to watch his firm collapse in January, was hired by Templeton Franklin Investment Services (Asia) Ltd. to scout for investments.

title: SPRINT SAYS FIRST-QUARTER EARNINGS FELL 27%
description: The Sprint Corporation said yesterday that first-quarter profit fell 27 percent, less than expected, with strong sales to business customers and lower fees helping to offset wider losses from new wireless and international ventures. Sprint, the nation's third-biggest long-distance company, kept a lid on costs in its local and long-distance operations while increasing sales of the newer, more profitable services. Net income fell to $211.8 million, or 48 cents a diluted share, from $289.7 million, or 67 cents, a year earlier. Analysts had expected earnings of 42 cents a share. Revenue rose 9.3 percent, to $3.91 billion from $3.58 billion. The company's shares rose 62.5 cents, to $68.625.

title: ROBERTS BUYS U.S. RIGHTS TO HOECHST COLITIS DRUG
description: The Roberts Pharmaceutical Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired the marketing rights in the United States for Pentasa, a drug to treat ulcerative colitis, from Germany's Hoechst A.G. for $130 million. Roberts said it expected sales of $40 million from Pentasa in the next year. Roberts, based in Eatontown, N.J., had 1997 revenue of $122.5 million. Ulcerative colitis is the most severe of the disorders involving the lower intestine, or colon. The ailment produces ulcers in the colon's inner lining and can eventually lead to arthritis and liver, skin and eye damage. Shares of Roberts rose 43.75 cents, to $14.625.

title: Assembly Bill Would End Caps on Rates for City Drivers
description: In a move that threatens to delay the overhaul of New Jersey's auto insurance system, the Assembly Speaker, Jack Collins, outlined new legislation today that he said would reduce premiums for suburban and rural drivers but increase rates for drivers in urban areas.

title: Doubts Don't Slow Flow Of Juniors Into the Draft
description: Entering the Orange Bowl against Tennessee last January, the junior running back Ahman Green pondered whether it would be his last game for Nebraska. The Cornhuskers had won a mythical national championship two seasons before, and a victory over Tennessee would very likely mean another. For Green, that would be two titles in three seasons.

title: Survivor of Killing Fields Is Resolute in Quest for Justice
description: Dith Pran, the Cambodian journalist whose ordeal of forced labor, starvation and beatings by the Khmer Rouge was portrayed in the 1984 film ''The Killing Fields,'' said yesterday that Pol Pot's death may have dashed hopes to try him for crimes against humanity. But it would not end a quest for justice by survivors of his four-year reign of terror, he added.

title: LOWER FUEL PRICES LIFT CONTINENTAL AIRLINES PROFIT
description: Continental Airlines Inc. said yesterday that earnings rose 9.5 percent in the first quarter, lifted by lower fuel prices and increased ticket sales. The carrier said net income increased to $81 million, or $1.06 a diluted share, from $74 million, or 96 cents a share, a year earlier. Analysts had expected the carrier to report earnings of 99 cents a share. Revenue climbed 9.2 percent, to $1.854 billion from $1.698 billion. Capacity, the number of seats available over each mile, increased 11 percent. Continental's class B shares declined $1, to $62.6875.

title: Executive of N.B.A. Joins Edelman Unit
description: Edelman Public Relations Worldwide in New York said yesterday that it had named Peter Land, the director for marketing communications at the National Basketball Association in New York, as executive vice president and co-general manager of its Creative Solutions unit. Mr. Land, 36, will oversee Edelman's worldwide sports, entertainment, event marketing and promotions interests. He assumes those duties from Jody Quinn, 44, who was named to the new position of director for client development at Creative Solutions. Nancy Ruscheinski is the other general manager of Creative Solutions. She is based in Chicago and oversees operations like media services and interactive media.

title: New Video Releases
description: L.A. Confidential

title: Apple Removes the Dalai Lama From Its Ads in Hong Kong
description: Apple Computer, the self-styled rebel of the American computer industry, has removed images of the Dalai Lama from an advertising campaign in Asia for fear of offending China.

title: Modern Music, Tied to the Past
description: It becomes harder every day to determine just what the term ''classical music'' means. But any definition would have to include the idea of lasting value, of a connection to the past. And so it is also hard to determine the nature of the relationship of classical music to the present and the immediate past.

title: On My Mind; The Execution Report
description: Next month, the month after that -- anytime it suits his interests, Saddam Hussein will again create a crisis that will bring the world press to Baghdad by the hundreds.

title: Student Journalists Without a Newspaper; School Halts Publication, Raising Question of First Amendment Rights
description: The principal of Stuyvesant High School, one of the most prestigious public schools in the nation, has halted publication of the school newspaper indefinitely after months of infighting that pitted student editors against one another and against their faculty adviser. Those disputes were inflamed in recent weeks by a handful of articles criticizing the conduct of individual teachers and the policies of the city teachers' union.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL RISES 2.8 PERCENT. Prices rallied on expectations of extraordinarily heavy demand for gasoline this summer and new signs of United States tension with Iraq. May-delivery crude oil rose 44 cents, to $15.90 a barrel.

title: Assembly Proposes Fund To Fight Blood Diseases
description: A bill was introduced in the State Assembly yesterday to spend $5 million to create a storehouse for umbilical cord blood to be used in fighting several potentially fatal blood diseases.

title: Part Glass, Part Wilson, Part Film, Part Opera
description: ''Monsters of Grace'' is a work of mysterious possibilities born of practical needs. Philip Glass wrote the music; Robert Wilson designed the scenes, and the words are from the 13th-century Persian mystic Jelaluddin Rumi. But there is another co-creator. For want of a more precise term, call it machinery.

description: Alternate-side street-cleaning regulations will be suspended in New York City today for Orthodox Good Friday and the seventh day of Passover, and tomorrow for the eighth day of Passover. Other regulations will remain in effect.

title: Roger Murray 2d, 86, Economist Who Was an Adviser to Congress
description: Roger F. Murray 2d, an economist whose financial acumen made him a frequent adviser to members of Congress and business leaders during the 1950's and 60's, died on Monday at his home in Wolfeboro, N.H. He was 86.

description: Five foreign journalists were escorted by Khmer Rouge guerrillas across the Thai border into northern Cambodia today to confirm the death of Pol Pot, the 73-year-old Khmer Rouge founder. Pol Pot's comrades said he had died late Wednesday night of a heart attack.

description: President Clinton pleaded with the leaders of Latin America today to be patient with the United States as it conducts a painful internal political debate over the merits of free trade throughout the hemisphere.

title: Shades of Meaning From a Black Modernist
description: In the sacred, all-white pantheon of first generation Abstract Expressionists, the name of Norman Lewis (1909-1979) is not enshrined. A black artist who was based in Harlem, he is hard to find in chronicles of the New York School. Nor did he appear in the defining photograph of the group, identified as the Irascibles, that ran in Life Magazine on Jan. 15, 1951, and included the usual suspects: Jackson Pollock, Robert Motherwell, Mark Rothko, Willem de Kooning, Barnett Newman, Ad Reinhardt, et al., along with one female painter, Hedda Sterne.

title: In Tears, Paula Jones Says She'll Press On With Misconduct Suit
description: Paula Corbin Jones choked out only a few words at a news conference today before tears stopped her for a long moment. It seemed that she might not be able to continue. She pulled her hair over her face in what looked like an instinctive effort to hide, and whispered apologies as her husband stood to comfort her.

Saunders, who spent half a century as such a quietly dedicated minister, missionary and religious official that he became known chiefly for a single, instinctive act of Christian duty, died on April 5 at his home in suburban Dallas. He was 88 and the man who gave Lee Harvey Oswald a Christian burial.

description: Kofi Annan, the first United Nations Secretary General from sub-Saharan Africa, said today that it was time for Africans to hold their political leaders -- and not colonialism -- responsible for the civil wars and economic failures that ravage their lives.

title: M.S. Gilman, 76, Builder
description: Marvin S. Gilman, a builder and developer for nearly 50 years in New York, Maryland and Delaware, died April 8 in the Christiana Hospital in Wilmington, Del., where he had undergone surgery for a staphylococcus infection. He was 76 years old and had been living in Wilmington.

title: Violence-Prevention Plan Is Proposed for Children
description: The American Red Cross chapter in Camden, a city whose murder rate ranks among the top three in New Jersey, is sponsoring a series of violence-prevention programs aimed primarily at children as young as 2.

title: A Meditation on the Meaning of Hong Kong
description: When it comes to East meeting West, Communism colliding with capitalism, and clashing cultural myths swirled into a dramatic vortex, you couldn't find a more potent symbol than the city of Hong Kong. Wayne Wang's poetically resonant movie ''Chinese Box'' was filmed there during its final six months as a British colony, and includes scenes of the actual ceremonies in which it was officially handed back to China after 156 years of British sovereignty.

title: New York Times Company Reports 24.7% Rise in Profit
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that earnings rose 24.7 percent in the first quarter.

title: Night Work At a Morgue? That Job Is Murder
description: All the world's a morgue and the people in it either corpses or panting homicidal necrophiles in Ole Bornedal's laughably garish thriller, ''Nightwatch.'' Well, not all the people. Although an obsession with necrophilia doesn't apply to everyone in this putrid fun house of a movie, it often feels that way.

title: Racial Divide Found on Information Highway
description: At a time when the Clinton Administration is promoting the Internet as an engine of commerce and a tool of democracy, a new study has found that black Americans are far less likely to use the global computer network than are whites.

title: Indian Fare
description: Indian food is as complex and varied as the country itself, but the repertory of many Indian restaurants in New York is narrow. Here are a dozen Indian restaurants where you can taste a wide range of Indian dishes. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

But hours after the announcement, the Giuliani administration warned in a blunt statement that the city had not yet formally approved the plan.

title: GEC Alsthom to Produce $1.3 Billion Dividend
description: Alcatel Alsthom S.A. and the General Electric Company P.L.C. of Britain P.L.C. will get a special dividend of about $1.3 billion from their GEC Alsthom venture before its initial public offering in June, Alcatel said yesterday. The dividend, which will be split between Alcatel, the French telecommunications equipment maker, and General Electric of Britain, the electronics producer, will compensate for investments made since GEC Alsthom was formed in 1989.

description: While foreigners have been buying South Korean bonds and pouring cash into the country's resurgent stock market, direct foreign investment in Korean companies remains sluggish.

title: Motorola Is Set To Revamp Unit
description: Motorola Inc. said today that it would revamp its phone-equipment business to better coordinate product development and named Merle Gilmore to head the effort.

title: New York's Big Senate Race
description: New Yorkers who regard the field of Democratic gubernatorial candidates this year as weak and most legislative contests as so one-sided as to be meaningless have little cause to complain about the Senate race. Three of the state's top politicians are vying to take on the Republican incumbent, Alfonse D'Amato, this fall. Representative Charles Schumer, a nine-term veteran, may be the most effective member of New York City's generally uninspired Congressional delegation. Public Advocate Mark Green is one of the city's strongest Democratic vote-getters. The former Congresswoman and Vice-Presidential candidate Geraldine Ferraro is still an icon to many party members.

title: TENNIS: Heart Stays Home As Seles Plays On; Father's Illness Takes the Edge Off Triumphs
description: Outside, a flash thunderstorm turned the Florida sky the color of charcoal and bent the palm and pin oaks double, but even when the kitchen lights in her tournament-issued town house at Amelia Island blinked with every lightning strike, Monica Seles calmly spooned down her post-practice ration of vegetable soup.

description: The wriggling graffitilike credits of ''Suicide Kings,'' Peter O'Fallon's feature film debut, signal that this is a movie that wants to be hip above all else. What hip means in this uneven comic suspense film is maintaining the ironically distanced tone of a deadpan ''Married to the Mob'' or a tongue-in-cheek Coen Brothers caper.

title: Fine Silver, Both Lavish And Useful
description: Louis XIV may have been called the Sun King, but he committed many dark deeds, and France paid the price. When the King revoked the Edict of Nantes in 1685, the law that granted religious liberty to the Huguenot Protestants, thousands of Huguenots fled France, taking their considerable skills with them. Paul Revere, for example, was a descendant of Huguenots.

description: Declaring that there was no end in sight to his investigation of President Clinton, Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel, announced today that he would give up high-level positions at a university with close ties to a millionaire who has financed attacks on the President.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Design; A Designer's-Eye View
description: TALK about taking your work with you: Chrysler's top designer, John E. Herlitz, was on a spring-break trip to New York, his hometown, but he kept finding his way to the auto show at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: Earnings Setbacks and Asia Fears Send the Dow Sliding
description: Disappointing earnings from the drug maker Merck, a reversal among technology stocks and a wisp of trouble in Asia helped send the stock market lower yesterday.

title: It's New, but Is It Brave? Huxley Redux
description: The scariest moment in this adaptation of ''Brave New World'' comes when a disgruntled factory worker from the none-too-bright Delta caste is shown a video to recondition him into happiness. Filled with quick-cut images of athletic bodies, hard rock music and phrases flashed across the screen (''History is bunk'' and ''I'm happy I'm a Delta'') it is indistinguishable from any number of shoe or sports drink commercials likely to crop up during breaks in this television film.

title: WOOLWORTH TO SHUT 82 KINNEY STORES IN CANADA
description: The Woolworth Corporation plans to close 82 money-losing Kinney Shoe stores in Canada and dismiss 600 employees as it focuses on its profitable Foot Locker, Champs and other sporting-goods chains. Woolworth said the 32-year-old Canadian Kinney division would close by June 30, putting 200 full-time and 400 part-time employees out of work. The New York retailer will convert about 40 of the stores to its other chains by August. Woolworth has moved away from its roots in discount retailing to focus on sporting-goods stores. Shareholders are to vote on its proposed new name, Venator Group Inc., on June 11.

title: Iran's Leader Asks for Unity After Release of His Moderate Ally
description: Iran's supreme leader called for unity today in a renewed effort to head off a political rupture over a legal case involving the Mayor of Teheran, who was freed from prison on Wednesday.

title: Political Briefing; 3 Rare Battles Loom in the South
description: The last Congressional elections seriously undercut the old assumption that black Congressional candidates in the Deep South could not win in majority-white districts.

title: Several Veterans Rest As Devils Manage a Tie
description: First place over all translates into a home-ice advantage throughout the National Hockey League playoffs, a sizable chunk of change and a fairly convincing claim to being the best team in hockey.

title: Residential Real Estate; Developer Plans to Build Rental Apartments in Historic Chelsea
description: For nearly three decades the Getty gas station stood on the southeast corner of 20th Street and 10th Avenue in Chelsea. But now a Manhattan developer who has leased the land is advancing plans to build a rental apartment building on the site.

title: Yankee Trip Inconveniences Many, but Not Steinbrenner
description: George Steinbrenner said he was adamant about switching sites for the Yankees-Tigers series for this weekend and next weekend. He said yesterday that he wanted to get his players away from the potential distractions of playing more games at Shea Stadium, and also said he did not want to ask the Mets for additional assistance after Wednesday's day-night doubleheader in Queens.

title: Black Mayors Protest Being the Focus of a Federal Housing Inquiry
description: A decision by the Administration's chief housing investigator to examine Federal housing and economic development programs in three cities has touched off protests from black mayors around the country, some of whom have called the move racially motivated.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Robert Cumming

title: Yearning For a Psychic Sanctuary
description: In Marc Cohn's new songs, there's no place like home. Put him on the road, and all he can think about is the comfort, physical and psychic, that he left behind. He gazes at other people's mansions with admiration and mistrust, and when he comes to his own refuge, he's not sure it's the right one. ''This is where they show me that a man's not so alone,'' he sang on Monday night at the Supper Club. ''Maybe I'm already home.''

title: Warsaw Journal; Trying to Make the Twain of East and West Meet
description: Bronislaw Geremek, the Foreign Minister of Poland, is an ineffably polite man and a practiced listener. But there are occasions that try his patience.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Big and Little Edie Return
description: Headlines were made in 1972 by the revelation that two recluses living in a cat-littered East Hampton mansion were Edith Bouvier Beale and her daughter, Edie Jr., the aunt and cousin of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. And in 1976, Albert and David Maysles made their own kind of news with ''Grey Gardens,'' a troubling yet utterly transfixing portrait of the Beales in their decaying home. If ever a documentary played like a gothic novel, ''Grey Gardens'' does: it watches mother and daughter bask in the filmmakers' attention while trumpeting half-buried old grievances and memories of a patrician past.

title: Sex Evidence Claimed In Brawley Lawsuit
description: Claiming that he had evidence as positive as a fingerprint, C. Vernon Mason, a defendant in the defamation suit arising from the Tawana Brawley case, said yesterday that a sexually transmitted disease would prove Steven A. Pagones raped Ms. Brawley in 1987, when she was 15.

title: Sun Earnings Rise 3.5%; Revenue Trails Forecasts
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. said yesterday that its earnings rose modestly in the most recent quarter, meeting analysts' forecasts. But it said that revenue growth fell short of expectations because of unfavorable currency-exchange rates and the effects of the economic trouble in Asia.

title: James Conkling, 83, Executive Who Helped Begin Grammys
description: James B. Conkling, a music and broadcasting executive who helped create the Grammy Awards and the Columbia Record Club, died on Sunday at the Sutter Oaks Alzheimer's Hospital in Sacramento, Calif., where he had been living. He was 83.

title: Metro Business; Jersey City Site for Met Life
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company signed a long-term lease on Wednesday to move some of its operations into a building on the Jersey City waterfront. The building, at 2 Montgomery Street, is being renovated and modernized, and one and a half stories are being added, increasing the total floor space to 164,000 square feet.

title: Red Cross Staff Quits Somalia After Abduction
description: The Red Cross evacuated its remaining foreign staff from Somalia this morning, as negotiations got under way for the release of 10 aid workers who were kidnapped on Wednesday by militiamen in Mogadishu, the divided capital.

description: As findings from the T.W.A. Flight 800 crash continue to ripple through aviation, the Federal Aviation Administration said today that it would propose changes in wiring and in fuel vents on Boeing 737's to cut the risk of fuel tank explosions.

title: In the Dark Script of German, Everyday Art and Forms of National Identity
description: Its strang to assert that an exhibition devoid of artworks or artifacts is extraordinary, especially one when lots of mandatory reading is involved. But this is the case with ''Blackletter: Type and National Identity'' at Cooper Union in the East Village. Relying entirely on photostat reproductions, this show sorts out much of the early development of European typefaces, surely one of civilization's most essential, widely used forms of artistry.

title: Modern Ideas That Recall History Too
description: Anthony Wilson, a young guitarist, came to the Jazz Standard on Tuesday night and did two unusual things. First, he performed with a small big band, using complicated, swinging orchestrations to surround his improvisations. And then he brought out the saxophonist Bennie Wallace to play several tunes.

description: Prices of United States Treasury securities posted gains for the third consecutive day yesterday on the strength of the dollar and a report that suggested that manufacturing was slowing, easing concern that inflation could accelerate.

title: Pol Pot's Lingering Influence
description: Historians and politicians have suggested many fatuous theories to explain Pol Pot's terrible reign. One was that he and his comrades were normal people driven crazy by American bombing in the Indochina wars in the 1970's. But despite having been bombed more intensely than the Khmer Rouge, the Vietnamese and Laotian Communists, though brutal, were less intensely violent in victory than Pol Pot's regime.

title: Schemes, Twists of Fate And a Sense of Deja Vu
description: Larry David, the co-creator and longtime writer of ''Seinfeld,'' makes the transition to the big screen without leaving the slightest doubt as to where he came from. While ''Seinfeld'' may be leaving television, the essence of the show is alive, well and funny -- if also slightly threadbare -- here. Working without the pizazz of his television cast, and with backdrops much too bland and static for a feature film, Mr. David still invokes the very same spite, pettiness and scheming that are at the heart of America's most beloved weekly comedy. Expect coffee-shop conversations, escalating wild twists of fate, and a strong sense of deja vu.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on April 4 about Michael W. McCarthy, a former chairman of Merrill Lynch & Company, misstated the year Merrill Lynch became publicly held. It was 1971. (The firm was incorporated in 1959.)

description: Clearing a hurdle to their planned merger, Loews Theaters Exhibition Group and Cineplex Odeon have agreed to sell 14 movie theaters in Manhattan as part of an agreement with state and Federal officials.

description: By Republican count, 366 elected Democrats have joined the ranks of the Republicans over the last six years, many of them in the South, once proudly called the Solid South by Democrats.

description: William D. Payne, a State Assemblyman, was assaulted last month by a husband who found the legislator in bed with the man's estranged wife, the police said yesterday.

description: Merck & Company said yesterday that its profit rose by a lower-than-expected 14 percent in the first quarter, prompting a small selloff in most of the major American pharmaceutical stocks.

title: Cendant's Share Price Plunges 46% on 'Accounting Irregularities'
description: A week ago, when three high officials of the Cendant Corporation suddenly resigned, the company told investors that all was well and that the resignations reflected normal executive suite tensions following a large merger.

description: To the Editor:

title: Pol Pot, Brutal Dictator Who Forced Cambodians to Killing Fields, Dies at 73
description: Pol Pot, who created in Cambodia one of the 20th century's most brutal and radical regimes, died on Wednesday of heart failure, according to his Cambodian jailers. He was 73 years old.

title: THEATER GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy Broadway and Off Broadway shows this weekend. Approximate running times are in parentheses. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Psychic Healing in the Uncanny
description: The landmark 1968 exhibition ''Dada, Surrealism, and Their Heritage'' at the Museum of Modern Art seemed to cover the modernist waterfront, from Dali's drooping clocks to Claes Oldenburg's Pop. Yet of the nearly 90 artists included, only four were women.

title: Playing Angles to Capture the Truth
description: Every avant-garde photographer in the 1930's had an angle. Laszlo Moholy-Nagy shot from above. Aleksandr Rodchenko shot from below. Ilse Bing was the master of the oblique. She presented literally what Emily Dickinson called truths ''told slant.'' She not only followed Moholy-Nagy's practice of turning her finished pictures upside down and on their sides to see whether they were formally balanced, she also liked to take pictures that way, with her camera slightly askew.

title: Strong Sales For Texas Instruments
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said today that first-quarter profit before special charges rose 28 percent, reflecting strong sales of its specialty communications chips that helped it outperform Motorola Inc., the Intel Corporation and other semiconductor makers suffering from falling prices and slumping demand.

title: F.A.A. Expects No Delay in Equipment
description: An agreement on Wednesday between the air traffic controllers' union and the Federal Aviation Administration not to use new radar screens except late at night, when traffic is light, will probably not delay implementation of the new equipment, the agency's acting deputy administrator said today.

title: A $30 million campaign will strive to make the Yellow Pages directories appear less musty.
description: THE publishers of the nation's Yellow Pages will sponsor their first comprehensive advertising campaign, meant to convince consumers that their directories are as relevant in the information age as they were when most telephones still had dials.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Hey, You Never Know'

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: ''Oh, you don't want to sit there,'' says the hostess, flopping down in one of the low sofas to demonstrate. Her knees hit the coffee table. ''See? They're really low and uncomfortable if you're trying to eat.''

title: CREDITORS OF BARNEY'S FREE TO FILE RIVAL PLAN
description: Creditors of Barney's Inc. will be allowed to file a rival reorganization plan for the retailer under an agreement worked out yesterday in Federal Bankruptcy Court. Barney's has until June 15 to file its own plan to exit Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. But creditors for the first time are now free to file a rival plan in an effort to recoup their $350 million in claims. The impetus for the agreement came from Barney's biggest unsecured creditors, Bay Harbour Management and Whippoorwill Associates Inc., which together are owed $150 million. James Garrity, the United States Bankruptcy Court judge overseeing the proceedings, said he would approve the agreement. Barney's, which operates eight specialty fashion stores and 13 smaller outlet shops in the United States, entered Chapter 11 protection in January 1996.

title: Beyond Recordings: A Performance Guide
description: Here is a sampling of concerts in New York City featuring composers mentioned by Times critics in their record reviews, along with a selection of forthcoming performances featuring post-World War II music.

title: Big ESPN Deal Means Certain Cable Rate Hike
description: When ESPN decided that it had to acquire the entire Sunday night National Football League package that it used to split with TNT, it elected to escalate its annual rights fee from $131 million to $600 million.

title: Give Them This: They Know Perseverance
description: Well, they're in. So the voicemails imploring someone to back up a truck and dispose of everyone die for a while. How far the Knicks go in the playoffs, no one can be sure. Along with the Nets, they've been like Pamplonans, running from the Bulls for two weeks.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Albert Marquet

title: The Demons Of a Despot
description: This was a nation bereaved today, but not a nation in mourning. It was a nation liberated in some small measure from the shadow of its past traumas, but it was left empty-handed, without answers to some of its most painful questions.

title: Status of Once-Elite Bureaucrats Declines as Japan Does
description: Until last year, Tadashi Nakamura knew just what he wanted to be. He would become a bureaucrat and help run Japan.

title: Teen-Age Meditation, Silent and Not
description: At 9 on Tuesday and Friday mornings, a hundred or so sleepy teen-agers straggle into the austere and extraordinarily beautiful Friends Meeting House, an 1860 landmark building on Rutherford Place, between 15th and 16th Streets in Manhattan. The young people -- in baseball caps, baggy sweatshirts and jeans -- stretch and squirm as would any other teen-agers on the long gray benches covered with dark red cushions. These are the original horsehair cushions, the original men's and women's benches; the backs of the women's benches have been cut out to make room for the voluminous skirts that even the traditionally plain-dressing Quaker women wore.

title: Modern Music CD's, With Ties to the Past
description: Here are favorite recordings of post-World War II music by the classical-music critics of The New York Times. Compact disks range in price from $12 to $16.98 for one CD to $31.99 to $51.98 for a multiple CD package. (An introduction appears on page 1 of Weekend.)

title: HARBORSIDE HEALTHCARE GETS $291 MILLION BUYOUT OFFER
description: The Harborside Healthcare Corporation, a medical services company, said yesterday that it had accepted a buyout offer from Investcorp, a Bahrain investment group, valued at $291 million, or $25 a share. The Boston-based Harborside operates a regional network of long-term- care centers and provides specialty medical services through its Theracor unit. It had 1997 revenue of $221.7 million. Under the agreement, Investcorp would own about 91 percent of Harborside. Harborside managers would retain a 3 percent interest. Other shareholders may elect to receive $25 a share in cash or to retain their shares, up to 6 percent of the total shares outstanding. Shares of Harborside rose $2.4375, to $23.9375.

title: Pol Pot's Lingering Influence
description: Historians and politicians have suggested many fatuous theories to explain Pol Pot's terrible reign. One was that he and his comrades were normal people driven crazy by American bombing in the Indochina wars in the 1970's. But despite having been bombed more intensely than the Khmer Rouge, the Vietnamese and Laotian Communists, though brutal, were less intensely violent in victory than Pol Pot's regime.

description: To the Editor:

title: Haitian Art Bursting Out
description: When more than 100 works of Haitian art were displayed at the Brooklyn Museum in 1978, critics hailed the exhibition as a triumph for artists from the tiny Caribbean nation, many of whom had been toiling for decades in near obscurity. The two-month show thrust those featured onto the international art scene, catapulted awareness of the genre to a broader American audience and prompted Sotheby's and Christie's to begin auctioning Haitian art.

title: Cardinal Scolds League For Play on Good Friday
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, known about town as a Mets and Yankees fan, said he will not attend any Major League Baseball games this year because the league insisted on playing on Good Friday.

title: A Transcendental Tourist in a Moody Carnival on the Streets of Dreams
description: The miracles of strength and agility performed under the big top are of an understated sort. An acrobat who turns a metal cylinder into a one-man Tilt-a-Whirl. An aerialist who gyrates in midair, entwined in a trellis of red silk. A quartet of women who give wooden spools the fanciful properties of yo-yos.

description: Michel Camdessus, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said today that the depreciation of the yen was excessive, and he urged Japan to reform its banking system and stimulate its economy to strengthen the currency.

description: ''Usually you are sad when you have lost a loved one. This time we are sad because we have lost a criminal we cannot punish. I wish to see him in court. I wish to see him in handcuffs. I wish to see him suffer the way he made me suffer.''

title: MARK CENTERS TO BUY 17 PROPERTIES FROM RD CAPITAL
description: Mark Centers Trust, a shopping-center real estate investment trust, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 12 shopping centers and five apartment complexes from RD Capital Inc. in exchange for partnership units and common stock valued at $184.5 million. Under the agreement, RD Capital will also give Mark Centers Trust, which is based in Kingston, Pa., $100 million in cash. RD Capital is a real estate company that owns and manages shopping centers. The shopping centers are in Indiana, Illinois, Minnesota, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Connecticut, New Jersey and New York. The apartments are in Missouri, Maryland and North Carolina.

George W. Bush of Texas (16), Steve Forbes (13), Jack Kemp (12), former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee (11), Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia (4), Gov. Tommy G. description: Versions of the same question were put today to both Kenneth W. Starr, the independent counsel, and the financial backers of Paula Corbin Jones: Did they have any ties to Richard Mellon Scaife?

title: Nights of Nostalgia, Plain and Simple
description: One stage talent that should never be underestimated is the ability to be natural, or at least to seem natural. Nancy Dussault, who opened a three-week engagement at the Firebird Cafe (363 West 46th Street, Clinton) on Tuesday evening, brings an instant likability to the stage. By turns bustling, playful, self-deprecating and sentimental, she effuses the infectious can-do verve of the kind of kick-up-your-heels suburban matron who single-handedly founds a local theater group.

title: Forget Barney. Forget Teletubbies.
description: I was on the floor with my 8-month-old daughter, partaking of our favorite shared activity -- the spirited chewing of plastic toys -- when the phone rang. It was a friend offering me free tickets to the Knicks game that afternoon.

title: In Death, Indignity for Despised Killer
description: Today was a day of indignity for the body of Pol Pot, the brutal Khmer Rouge leader who died in a spare wooden hut on Wednesday, abandoned by most of his friends and vigorously pursued by his enemies.

title: Columbia Soars Into Space With a Menagerie on Board
description: The space shuttle Columbia soared into orbit from the Kennedy Space Center here today, carrying seven humans and more than 2,000 other mammals, fish and insects for 16 to 17 days of neurological research.

title: Statehouse Journal; Texas Legislator Proposes the Death Penalty for Murderers as Young as 11
description: State Representative Jim Pitts, a Republican from Waxahachie, admits his idea sounds jarring. ''This is a drastic step,'' he says. ''But some of the kids that are growing up today, they just aren't the 'Leave it to Beaver' kids that I grew up with.''

description: BASEBALL

title: She's a Gentile, He's a Jew. Hmm, Sound Familiar?
description: A young man sits uncomfortably in his prospective father-in-law's study. In a blustery Southern accent, the father-in-law, Bo Metcalf (Leo Burmester), says, ''So I understand you're a Jew.'' Then he calls out to his wife: ''Mary Chase, what was Cousin Reese? Was he a Jew?'' As it turns out, Reese was a Mormon, but Bo knew it was ''something funny.''

description: Industrial production rose unexpectedly in March, increasing two-tenths of 1 percent, the Federal Reserve said today.

description: With the lull in the White House sex-and-perjury scandal, the chattering classes in Washington have both the time and the energy to engage in a big argument.

description: Four hits. That was all the Mets could muster in seven innings off Mike Remlinger tonight. Not really a formula for winning, so the Mets lost, 4-3, to the Cincinnati Reds.

description: PHILLIPS-Irene Vlasta. May 11, 1906-April 18, 1997. You are always in my thoughts. Your daughter, Olga K. Heisler

title: Retooled U.S. Squad Ready for Netherlands
description: The last time the United States squared off against the Netherlands in Fed Cup competition, the round was the same, but everything else was different. Martina Navratilova was filling in as captain while Billie Jean King took her 1997 hiatus; neither Lindsay Davenport nor Monica Seles were around to anchor the first-round singles positions, and Brenda Schultz-McCarthy and her serve-heard-round-the-world were on hand to give the Netherlands additional home-court punch.

title: Is Another Homer Jones Out There?
description: Informed that it has been 30 years since the Giants had an All-Pro wide receiver, the old Giant sounded surprised.

title: History's Likeness in Black and White
description: What Americans tend to remember of Matthew Brady's work is the Civil War photographs. Officers in encampments, wearing Union Army uniforms, turn to the daylight and settle into postures they can hold for the 5 or 10 seconds Brady's camera required. Only Gen. Ulysses Grant manages to look relaxed when he stops for the photographer and leans against a tree. Sometimes Brady himself appears in the picture, caught by one of his camera operators. Standing almost out of the frame, Brady's figure is blurred by a faint motion he would have found unacceptable in his subjects. The blurring seems almost intentional, a refusal to yield to the camera, to surrender to the visual coherence its long exposure times created.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CRANE, FAY L.
description: CRANE-Fay L. On April 15, 1998. Loving wife of Louis J. Beloved mother of Margie, and son-in-law Fred, Andrew and daughter-in-law Ingrid, and grandmother of Lauren and Jonathan. Loving sister of Kate and brother-in-law Ed. Funeral service to be held at Schwartz Bros., Queens Boulevard and 76 Road, Forest Hills, New York, Sunday at 10AM. Interment New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, Long Island. She was loved and cherished by all who knew her and we will miss her dearly.

title: California Finishes What It Started
description: California retained its National Collegiate Athletic Association men's gymnastics championship last night, beating Iowa and Illinois in the finals at Penn State.

title: Ploys of Summer: Underdogs Make Miracles
description: ''Major League: Back to the Minors'' may look like a baseball movie. It may sound like a baseball movie. But this amiable compendium of recycled cliches could probably best be marketed as some kind of primer on workplace problems: midlife career choices, corporate infighting, small-firm hustle vs. big-company complacency, managerial styles, the value of teamwork and dealing with dysfunctional personnel.

title: Jonesboro Dazed by Its Darkest Day
description: The white ribbons, symbolic of the city's grief, are beginning to fray. It has been almost a month since the schoolyard murders of four girls and a teacher, apparently by an 11-year-old boy and his 13-year-old buddy, and the shock and rage have given way to dull anger, a nagging, heartbreaking puzzlement.

title: Ex-Mayor Pleads Guilty To Peddling Influence
description: The former Mayor of Edison, Samuel V. Convery Jr., admitted yesterday in Federal court that he offered to help a former town official secure a new job in exchange for the official's help in persuading two members of the Township Zoning Board to approve a building permit that would benefit one of Mr. Convery's legal clients, prosecutors said.

title: Nets Lose, And Now They're Desperate
description: The Nets' locker room here was quiet after tonight's defeat, with none of the usual banter. Sam Cassell sat on the trainer's table, one ice pack pressed to his strained left groin and another pushing into his bruised back as he sat with his head down. Across the room, Kendall Gill rocked back and forth. No one rushed to dress. The players just sat quietly, deep in their own thoughts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CIBEU, ANTOINETTE
description: CIBEU-Antoinette died April 4, in Shelby, Montana, dear wife of the late Albin Cibeu, mother of Dr. Lew E. Cibeu of Great River, Gladys Caterinicchio of Mt. Kisco (husband Dr. Ben), Maria Harrison of Shelby, MT. Grandma to Ben and Maria Caterinicchio, Erika and Rebecca Harrison, Stephanie and Donna Schneider, great Grandma of Ben S. Caterinicchio III. Mass was held at St. William Catholic Church, in Shelby. Interment later at St. Charles Cemetery, LI. Donations to NGCC Pastor's Discretionary Fund, 606 Riversville, CT 06831 or Gift of Life, P.O. 7008 Great Falls, MT 59406.

description: The General Motors Corporation worried Wall Street today by reporting first-quarter earnings that suggested underlying weaknesses in the company's prospects later this year.

title: Sports of The Times; Two Teams Stagger To Finish
description: TWO moments stand out in the fortunes of the Knicks and the Nets this season, when one got the sudden impression that the end result may be disastrous, like seeing smoke curl from the toaster.

title: 2 Men Jailed Over Refusal To Aid Inquiry
description: Federal judges in Manhattan have jailed two men for refusing to testify before a grand jury that is investigating fund-raising in the United States by the militant Islamic group Hamas, one of the men and a lawyer for the other said yesterday.

title: Presidents' Trophy Is Nice, But Devils Eye Bigger Prize
description: The Devils weighed all the pros and cons, then decided they would not burn themselves out chasing the Presidents' Trophy.

title: SHAW COMMUNICATIONS BUYS WIC WESTERN INTERNATIONAL
description: Shaw Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to buy WIC Western International Communications Ltd. for $975 million (Canadian), or $682.5 million (United States), topping a $710 million (Canadian) hostile offer by CanWest Global Communications Ltd. for the television and radio broadcaster. Shaw would offer $43.50 (Canadian) a share in cash, or a combination of 25 cents (Canadian) cash and 1.8058 Shaw class B shares, for each of the WIC class B shares it does not already own. CanWest is offering to pay $39 (Canadian) a share in cash. WIC, of Vancouver, British Columbia, said its board would recommend shareholders accept Shaw's offer. Shaw is Canada's third-largest cable television operator.

title: In the Battle for Pompeii, A Plan to Reverse Decay
description: POMPEII  Buried in a matter of hours under several meters of ash and pumice stone during a cataclysmic eruption of Vesuvius in 79 A.D., Pompeii is the most perfectly preserved city to come down to us from the ancient world. Last year almost 2 million people visited the site, well over half a million more than the Uffizi Gallery in Florence, making the antique ghost town the most popular single attraction in Italy.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BLASER, ANNA
description: BLASER-Anna. April 18, 1989. Cherished mother, we will never forget you. Love Blaser Family

description: A three-day rally in the Treasury market ran out of steam yesterday as traders took profits.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURKE, KATHLEEN M.
description: BURKE-Kathleen M. On April 16, 1998 of Pelham, N.Y. Wife of the late Thomas J. Burke. Dearest mother of Frances Hynes, John Burke and Mary O'Prey. Sister of Brigid Bartley and the late Annie Hall, Michael and Jimmy Durkin. Beloved grandmother of eleven. Great grandmother of 6. Reposing Pelham Funeral Home, 64 Lincoln Avenue, Pelham, New York. Mass will be at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Church, on Monday, at 10 A.M. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery. Visiting hours Saturday and Sunday 2-4 and 7-9 P.M.

title: WESTERN BANCORP IS ACQUIRING BANK OF LOS ANGELES
description: Western Bancorp said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Bank of Los Angeles for $71.8 million in stock, expanding its reach in the Los Angeles area. Western, based in Newport Beach, Calif., would pay 0.4224 share for each Bank of Los Angeles share, worth $20.22 based on Thursday's closing price. Western, parent of Santa Monica Bank and Southern California Bank, has $2.1 billion in assets and 29 branches in Los Angeles, Orange and San Diego counties. Bank of Los Angeles will add $275 million in assets and six branches.

title: Israel Redefines Its Dream, Finding Wealth in High Tech
description: The exit for Kibbutz Givat Brenner, the largest of Israel's proud old collective farms, is marked by a bright sign for ''House of Dreams.''

title: Garbage In . . . and In . . . and In; Greenpoint Residents Unite to Fight Influx of Trash
description: The air that Irene Klementowicz breathes is perhaps the worst in New York City. Her apartment is near one of the largest underground oil spills in history. Her neighborhood is dotted with garbage transfer stations, and when she opens her window, she can sometimes smell ''the Greenpoint stink'' from the nearby city sewage plant.

title: About New York; Bronx Actors Play the Roles Of Their Lives
description: THE words to ''God Bless the Child'' echoed in the cavernous space, although the tune hardly calmed a baby squealing in the audience. Undeterred, a dozen people filed onto the stage and stood in a semicircle against a burlap backdrop. The house lights dimmed and their voices rose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLERMAN, MURRAY
description: KELLERMAN-Murray. Beloved husband for 59 years of Florence; devoted father of Steven, Martin and Susan; adoring grandfather of Jenny, Anna, David and Andrew; loving father-in-law of Isabel, Nancy and Wil and dearest brother of Sylvia Levine. A self made man, who founded and was president of Kellerman Manufacturing Company. He will be greatly missed and always in our hearts. Service 1PM, on Sunday at Sanctuary of Abraham and Sarah, Cedar Park Cemetery, Paramus, New Jersey.

description: The Bundesbank left its full set of interest rates unchanged at a meeting yesterday, though analysts expect an increase later this year as European central banks pave the way for a common currency.

title: Awash in U.S. Aid. Could Float Fine Without It.
description: Israel's newfound economic success through its embrace of high-profit, high-technology industries has led many Israelis and Americans to question why the nation still needs so much American foreign aid.

title: A Long Olympian Life, in Careful Balance
description: In the 1924 Paris Olympics, Leon Stukelj, then a 26-year-old lawyer and gymnast from Yugoslavia, was photographed on his way to winning one of his two gold medals that year: raised up on his hands above the mat, every muscle etched, his legs extended in front of him at a precise elevated angle, he gazed intently into the distance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARLING, ROBERT C., M.D.
description: DARLING-Robert C., M.D. Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center mourns the passing of our colleague, Robert C. Darling, M.D. He began his long, distinguished career at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center as a medical intern in 1935. In 1945, he joined the faculty of Columbia University College of Physicians & Surgeons and of the Presbyterian Hospital. He served as Chairman of the Department of Rehabilitation Medicine from 1952 to 1973, and, in 1961, became the first Simon Baruch Professor and Chairman. Dr. Darling was considered a founding father in the field of rehabilitation medicine. He was an outstanding teacher, scholar and clinician, devoted to rehabilitation medicine and the medical center. He served as an advisor and friend to generations of medical students and colleagues. We extend deep condolences to his children Thomas and Nancy. Memorial donations, in lieu of flowers, should be made to the Department of Rehabilitation Medicine, Columbia University for the Robert C. Darling Library in c/o John A. Downey, M.D., 180 Fort Washington Ave, Room HP167, New York, N.Y. 10032. Herbert Pardes, M.D., V.P., for Health Sciences and Dean of the Faculty of Medicine at Columbia University Colleges of Physicians & Surgeons William T. Speck, M.D., President and Chief Operating Officer of The New York and Presbyterian Hospital

description: Following is a list of signers and nonsigners of a petition intended to bring campaign finance legislation to a vote in the House. If 218 members sign, the measure can be brought up at any time. So far, 7 Republicans, 188 Democrats and 1 independent have signed the petition. Five Republicans have said they would sign once the House reconvenes next week. They are Representatives Brian Bilbray of California, Thomas M. Davis of Virginia, Amo Houghton of New York, Jack Metcalf of Washington and Zach Wamp of Tennessee. Y reflects a signature on the petition; N is not signing.

title: STERLING COMMERCE ADDS XCELLENET FOR CASH AND STOCK
description: Sterling Commerce Inc., a maker of software for electronic commerce, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Xcellenet Inc. for $200 million in cash and stock. Xcellenet's main product is Remote Ware, which allows employees to connect to their company's computer network from outside the office using a cellular phone, telephone or the Internet. The Atlanta-based company has 300 employees and full-year revenue of $53.6 million. It earned $3.8 million, or 44 cents a share, for 1997. Sterling, based in Dallas, makes software that allows businesses to ship invoices and purchase orders electronically. For the year ended Sept. 30, it posted a loss of $133 million, or $3.45 a share, on $489 million in revenue.

title: Running Scared
description: Some of the organizers and corporate sponsors of men's distance racing in the United States think they have a problem. The best men keep winning, and most of them these days come from Kenya. American runners may be slower, but they give better interviews, attract more coverage and provide a focus for the nationalist emotions of some racing spectators.

title: Net for Rebel Leaders
description: Since Pol Pot's death, the Clinton Administration has intensified its effort to bring the leaders of the Khmer Rouge to trial, asking experts to prepare indictments of several figures for gross rights abuses, American officials said.

title: Death Penalty Sought In Gas Station Slaying
description: Prosecutors in Morris County said yesterday that they would seek the death penalty for John Kenny Diloreto, the 19-year-old drifter charged a week ago with shooting a gas station attendant to death in an attack captured on the station's video security camera.

title: Drugs That Kill Instead of Cure
description: A report this week estimated that more than 100,000 hospital patients die each year from adverse drug reactions, more than from diabetes, pneumonia or many other serious illnesses. According to the report, in the Journal of the American Medical Association, an additional two million hospital patients suffer nonfatal reactions to drugs. What makes these numbers especially alarming is that the study says it does not count drug incidents resulting from mistaken prescriptions by doctors or the administration of wrong doses by nurses.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'CONNOR, ELEANOR (NEE STUART)

title: Leftist Scholars Look Right At Last, And Find A History
description: Since postwar leftist radicalism peaked in 1968, conservatives have affixed Ronald Reagan's name to a revolution, the South has deserted the Democrats for the Republicans, the Christian right has pushed its way onto the national stage, and liberal confidence in government action has become about as commonplace as the rotary phone.
