description: HARRIS-Sylvia. 87. Formerly of New York City and Boca Raton, FL. Longtime Secretary of H.S. of Music & Art. Died Friday. Services 1 P.M. Sunday, New Mount Lebanon Cemetery, Iselin, New Jersey.

title: Marie-Louise Meilleur, 117, And Felicie Cormier, 118
description: Felicie Young Cormier and Marie-Louise Febronie Meilleur, who lived through more tumultuous history, saw more social and technological change and endured more late-life congratulations than any two people known to be alive, died within two days of each other this week, ending their rival reigns as the world's oldest living person.

title: Miami Publisher Declines to Run for Governor
description: A group of Florida Democrats seeking a stronger challenger to the Republican candidate for governor, Jeb Bush, have failed to persuade the publisher of this city's only major newspaper to join the fray.

title: Cell Phone Leads to Suspect in Sex Attack
description: A Brooklyn man claiming to be a cabdriver robbed and tried to rape a woman he picked up as a fare yesterday, the police said.

title: You Haven't Seen This Before
description: A catcher playing first base in the major leagues for the first time covers second base on a bloop hit to the outfield, beats the runner to the bag and makes the putout. Bobby Valentine had never seen it before.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLER, DELLA S.
description: BERLER-Della S. On April 16th. Devoted wife of the late Harry. Beloved mother of Joan and David Berler. Cherished grandmother of Daniel, Matthew and Melissa Berler. Loving great grandmother of Jackson and Ellie Berler. Funeral Service Sunday, 9:30 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment Mount Moriah Cemetery.

title: A Pioneer's Rear and Ranging Vision
description: The road is long and winding that has led the pianist and composer Frederic Rzewski to the Kitchen this weekend for three concerts marking his 60th birthday. In his 20's he was a pioneer performer of avant-garde European and American music. In his early 30's he turned to live electronic music, systematic minimalism and improvisation with a group based in Rome. After a few years he switched to a shockingly orthodox style of composition, closer in its manic piano virtuosity to Kaikhosru Sorabji than to Karlheinz Stockhausen. More recently his music has loosened up, so that it can reflect anything from his previous experience while traveling on.

description: MUTTERPERL-George. Aged 83, on April 16, 1998. Beloved husband of Constance. Loving and devoted father of Joan and Jeffrey Leeds and Mark and Barbara Mutterperl. title: All Nippon Airways Cancels 54 More Flights
description: The All Nippon Airways Company, Japan's second-biggest airline, canceled 54 more flights through Thursday as a second day of talks failed to resolve its pilots' two-week strike over pay. Talks continued yesterday.

title: Playing Out a Slam Denied At a Tournament in the Alps
description: Many bridge tournaments offer tennis, golf, swimming and gambling as possible alternatives to sitting at the card tables. Only one gives an opportunity for energetic participants to ski, bobsled or luge. It is the International Bridge Week played each January in St. Moritz, Switzerland, and it attracts participants from many parts of Europe and a few from farther afield.

title: A Bad Year for Terrorism in Peru
description: If you don't mind the commercials for Alberto K. Fujimori, the President of Peru, tonight's account of the taking and freeing of hostages in Lima in 1996 is an attention-holder. The news clips, many of which were shown as the events unfolded, are exciting, and the interviews offer insiders' asides from a few of the hostages, one of the commandos who freed them and the omnipresent President Fujimori, who is celebrated as the presiding genius of this victory over terrorism.

title: Journal; All in the Family
description: James Hormel Jr. was 11 when he learned that his father was gay. ''It was kind of a shock to me,'' he says. ''I knew what society thought being gay was. I'd heard fag jokes growing up. It was a burden to me in that sense. But it wasn't a burden to me in being close to my father. I'm proud of my father.''

title: Deal of the Day
description: The Broadcom Corporation offered its shares to the public yesterday at $24, twice its original target price, and those shares more than doubled. The company specializes in digital data transmission through set-top cable boxes, cable modems and other high-speed networks, and it has a contract to provide General Instruments with chips for set-top boxes. That's not all: Intel and Cisco are among its investors. Though Broadcom had revenues of only $37 million last year, after one day of trading, the company had a market capitalization of $2.3 billion.

title: Gingrich Says Bill on Tobacco Has Little Hope
description: Speaker Newt Gingrich said today that the tobacco bill proposed by his fellow Republican, Senator John McCain of Arizona, was too liberal and had virtually no chance of passage in the House.

title: New Chief Named At Big Coke Bottler
description: Coca-Cola Enterprises Inc. named its president and chief operating officer, Henry A. Schimberg, to the additional post of chief executive today.

title: Beliefs
description: Catherine M. Wallace never imagined that her short, sophisticated brief for sexual fidelity would come off the presses at the very time when that topic was pre-empting war, peace, crime, drugs and just about every other item on the public agenda.

description: McGIllICUDDY-Mary Elizabeth, 89. Died on April 15, 1998. She is survived by her three children, Clement McGillicuddy of Virginia; Barbara Bolton of New York City; and Charles McGillicuddy of Augusta, Maine.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Thursday about Connecticut legislators' passage of a utility deregulation bill misidentified a lawmaker conferring with Representative Mary U. Eberle. He was Representative Lawrence F. Cafero Jr., not Emil Altobello.

title: TEXAS UTILITIES WINS CLEARANCE ON ENERGY GROUP BID
description: The Texas Utilities Company won British Government clearance for its $:6.3 billion ($10.4 billion) bid for Energy Group P.L.C., putting pressure on its rival, Pacificorp, to top the company's bid for the power company. The Dallas-based Texas Utilities bid 840 pence a share on March 3 for Energy Group, trumping an earlier offer of 820 pence by Pacificorp. Texas Utilities, which is also offering a stock alternative worth 865 pence, has already bought 22 percent of Energy Group. Pacificorp holds 8.8 percent. They are fighting for control of Energy Group as United States utilities seek to invest in British utilities because they offer higher returns and a foothold in the expanding European market.

title: 2 Mayors' Groups Attack Inquiry as Biased
description: Two prominent groups of mayors today criticized a decision by the Housing Department's chief investigator to examine public housing programs of three cities led by black mayors.

title: In Search of Joe Six-Pack 2001; Sales Sag and Brewers Battle to Quench Future Thirsts

''Actually, I've been meaning to try it,'' she said of the Cranberry Lambic, which would mean branching out from her usual Corona or Sapporo.

title: Judge Upholds Limit on Artists Selling Pictures Near Museum
description: A New York City Parks Department plan to limit the number of artists allowed to sell their wares in front of the Metropolitan Museum of Art does not restrict the artists' free speech, a Federal judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday.

title: Mayor Takes Political Road Show to Phoenix
description: Brenda from the Upper East Side complained that riders in New York City buses do not give up their seats to the elderly anymore. Joe over in Brooklyn has a serious problem with his sidewalk in Gerritsen Beach. And Jim in Queens thinks there is something suspicious about the people who turned a home into a church on his block in Bayside.

title: Harlem Hospital Is Symbol Of Troubled Public System
description: Walk around Harlem and it is hard to find a person who, for better or worse, has not been cared for at Harlem Hospital Center. It is a matter of pride and history. James Baldwin and Tito Puente were born there. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. was taken there -- doctors had to crack his sternum with a hammer and chisel -- when a deranged woman plunged a knife into his chest in 1958.

title: U.S. Wants to Try Khmer Rouge Leaders
description: The Clinton Administration stepped up its efforts today to bring Khmer Rouge officials to trial, commissioning experts to prepare indictments for gross human rights abuses, senior American officials said.

title: Ladybugs to Be Used To Fight Hemlock Pest
description: State agricultural officials are preparing to save some of the largest trees in New Jersey with one of the smallest known types of ladybug.

title: Museum for the Wyeths to Open in Maine
description: ROCKLAND, Maine  The rocky coastline, rugged landscape and people of Maine have long inspired American artists. Among them have been three generations of one of America's most prominent artistic families  the late N.C. Wyeth, his son Andrew Wyeth and his grandson Jamie Wyeth. The three are now the focus of a new museum and study center that will open on June 21 in the scenic coastal town of Rockland.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NAESS, MARGARET DIXON.
description: NAESS-Margaret Dixon. December 15, 1903-April 17, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Ragnar D. Naess. description: Dan Pollard, a Baptist missionary from Oregon, settled his wife and teen-age daughters in Vanino, a remote town in eastern Russia, four years ago, built a congregation of local families and a church of local timber.

title: Shedding Light on Elusive Art of Nepalese Bronze Statues
description: NEW YORK  Every now and then, an auction drags into the limelight a major art to which little attention is paid because the ancient land in which it blossomed is impoverished, its culture complex and unfamiliar, its language or languages barely understood in the West.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSOHN, FLORENCE A.
description: MENDELSOHN-Florence A. On April 15, 1998. Devoted wife of the late Max, loving sister of Philip F. Acker, cherished aunt of Mollyann Anmann and Peggy Kestenbaum and great-aunt of Matthew, Russell Kestenbaum and Shari Rae Ammann. description: In the corridor just north of its great stairs, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has since the mid-1980's displayed a 15-piece collection of ancient silver that dates to the third century B.C.

title: Bank Merger Fever Spreads To Canada
description: Two more of Canada's largest banks announced plans today to merge, compressing the country's already highly concentrated financial services industry to just four large national banks and raising concerns about competition.

title: Moving, a Bit Capriciously, Inside a Medley of Moods
description: Tere O'Connor Dance offered the choreographic equivalent of idle chatter on Thursday night. Mr. O'Connor's two new works at Dance Theater Workshop had clever moments. But moods kept coming and going with such arbitrariness that watching these pieces was like listening to a compulsive babbler.

title: Clinton, in Chile, Calls for Deepening of Restored Democracy
description: President Clinton, speaking to a joint meeting of the Chilean Congress with one notably empty chair, praised Chile for the restoration of democracy but said freedom requires more than elections and open markets.

title: Court Upholds Tribe's Ownership Of Prime Southampton Property
description: In another skirmish in the more than 100 years of battles over Shinnecock Indian lands, the tribe's ownership of half an acre of bayfront property on the edge of its reservation in Southampton was upheld today by a state court.

title: For the Thinking Student, a Hotbed of Gay and Lesbian Ideas
description: The current issue features an article about gay characters in prime time television, a review of an anthology of gay Buddhist writings, an essay that asks, ''How Gay Was Walt Whitman?''

title: Too Little Cooperation From Iraq
description: It has been eight weeks since Saddam Hussein promised to open a new, more cooperative chapter in Iraq's handling of international weapons inspections. Access has improved somewhat during that time, and the confrontational climate has cooled, but so far little progress has been made toward the central objective of the inspections, which is to rid Iraq of chemical and biological weapons and the means to make them.

title: Host Marriott to Become REIT and Buy 13 Hotels
description: Hoping to become more competitive in acquiring upscale hotels, the Host Marriott Corporation said yesterday that it would convert into a real estate investment trust and buy 13 luxury hotels, including the Ritz-Carlton and Four Season brands, from the Blackstone Group for about $835 million in cash and $945 million in assumed debt.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: COLA-COLA ENTERPRISES INC., Atlanta, said it would increase its quarterly dividend by 60 percent, to 4 cents a share from 2.5 cents. It will be payable July 1 to shareholders of record on June 19.

title: Novel Petition Drive May Save House Campaign Finance Bill
description: In an unusual bid to revive a seemingly doomed campaign finance bill, supporters of the legislation spent the Congressional recess pressuring Republicans to sign a petition that would force the issue to the House floor for a vote.

title: Laura Ashley Selling 40% Stake to Get Cash
description: Laura Ashley Holdings P.L.C. announced yesterday that it would sell a 40 percent stake to a Malaysian property and retailing company to get a quick cash infusion that would ease the effects of spiraling losses, help pay pressing debts and strengthen the company's faltering operations in North America and Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATNER, FRANK, M.D.
description: RATNER-Frank, M.D. The members of the Medical Society of the County of Queens express their profound sadness on the loss of their beloved colleague and friend, Frank Ratner, M.D. A distinguished and dedicated physician, Dr. Ratner proved to be a steadfast leader as he served the society as past-president, secretary and chairman of the Board of Censors. He will be sorely missed. Our deepest sympathies to his wife Helen, his children Dr. Lee Ratner, Beth Lyons, Dr. Jill Ratner Rosenberg, his nine grandchildren and his sister, Dr. Hilda Ratner. Leah S. McCormack, M.D., President Fred N. Flatau, M.D., Chairman, Board of Trustees

title: U.S. TRADE DEFICIT SOARS AS EXPORTS TO JAPAN DECLINE
description: American exports to Japan plummeted in February, helping send the United States trade deficit to its widest gap in a decade and demonstrating how the effects of Japan's stalled economy are spreading beyond its shores.

title: EARNINGS AIDED BY LATIN AMERICA AND EUROPE
description: First-quarter earnings at the McDonald's Corporation rose 5 percent, meeting analysts' estimates, as the fast-food chain benefited from gains in Latin America and Europe. The company said yesterday that net income rose to $362.2 million, or 52 cents a diluted share, from $344.5 million, or 49 cents, in the period a year earlier. Revenue rose 7 percent, to $2.80 billion from $2.62 billion, following the addition of more than 200 stores since the first quarter of 1997. McDonald's is based in Oak Brook, Ill.

title: Notes That Whinny And Purr
description: Von Freeman's stay at the Blue Note this week is as close as a two-shows-a-night jazz club gig can come to a revue. In Tuesday's early set there was a stretch featuring his son, Chico, the tenor saxophonist; a solo bass piece for Santi Debriano; a good long walk-on by the singer Dianne Reeves, and finally some quality time with Von Freeman himself, whose 75th birthday is the occasion for the fuss.

title: Corrections

title: Rose Maddox, 72, Country Singer of the 40's
description: Rose Maddox, a singer who was a leading figure in the West Coast country music of the 1940's, died on Wednesday at the Linda Vista rest home in Ashland, Ore., said Jonny Whiteside, her biographer. She was 72 and died of kidney failure.

description: A cloud will hang over Prince Naseem Hamed (29-0) when he steps into the ring tonight at the Nynex Center in Manchester, England, against Wilfredo Vazquez (50-7-3) to defend his World Boxing Organization featherweight championship. But it probably will not rain on Hamed's dance show and ring parade, at least not for a while.

title: Nissan Motor Expects Profit To Plummet 79% for Year
description: Hurt by slumping sales in Japan and the United States, the Nissan Motor Company estimated today that its group profit tumbled 79 percent in the fiscal year that ended March 31.

title: For Kurt Vonnegut in 1998, A Real Graduation Speech
description: It was a transcript of a commencement address that ricocheted from one E-mail box to another last summer, one in which the author Kurt Vonnegut purportedly advised graduates of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to ''wear sunscreen,'' ''get plenty of calcium'' and ''be kind to your knees.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORTE, SHELDON H.
description: PORTE-Sheldon H. The entire Nassau Association for the Help of Retarded Children family mourns the death of Sheldon H. Porte. A long time board member, Shelly, was always the first to volunteer to lend a hand. His warmth and good humor touched everyone around him. He was a strong advocate and true friend to all children and adults with developmental disabilities. He will be deeply missed at AHRC, where he has been a member for over 40 years. Our deepest sympathy to his wife Anne, his son and daughter-in-law Randall and Eileen, his daughter Janis, and all his family and friends. Jack Garofalo, President Michael Mascari, Exec Director Association for the Help of Retarded Children Nassau County Chapter

title: Snag Suggests Campaign Overhaul Is Easier Said Than Done
description: Despite initial agreement among Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and other prominent officials, a measure to prohibit candidates in New York City from accepting campaign contributions from corporations has unexpectedly bogged down in a dispute over its scope.

description: This was George Steiner, the author, scholar and literary critic known for his ferociously demanding and mordant meditations on culture, literature and language?

description: Whether Paula Corbin Jones succeeds in her efforts to reinstate her lawsuit against President Clinton may depend on a different case that will be argued in less than a week before the United States Supreme Court, lawyers who deal with sexual harassment issues said today.

title: Corrections

title: Raw, Relevant History
description: ''Thucydides, an Athenian, wrote the history of the war between the Peloponnesians and the Athenians.'' With those words a disgraced Athenian admiral matter-of-factly opens ''The History of the Peloponnesian War,'' his monumental, though unfinished, narrative of the 27-year war (431-404 B.C.) between Athens and Sparta that left the Athenian empire and the entire culture of the Greek city-state in ruins.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVIT, MORRIS
description: LEVIT-Morris. Of Larchmont, New York, died on April 15. He is survived by his wife Sylvia and three children Peter, Linda, Robert, and two grandchildren. description: Juarez is a city of factories set in the Chihuahua desert, with most of the assembly lines worked by women. And one or perhaps several sexual predators are prowling its vast industrial parks and honky-tonk saloons where workers go to kick back.

title: 3 Charged With Sending Child Pornography on Internet
description: Attorney General Dennis C. Vacco brought his campaign to rid cyberspace of child pornography to New York City yesterday, charging three Queens residents with using the Internet to send photographs of young children engaged in sexual acts.

title: Marvin E. Wolfgang, 73, Dies; Leading Figure in Criminology
description: Marvin E. Wolfgang, who found new ways of looking at and thinking about crime and criminals, died on Sunday at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. He was 73 and a professor of criminology at Penn and the president of the American Academy of Political and Social Science.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ARNOLD, PHILIP W.

title: ZENITH DOUBLES LAYOFF AT ILLINOIS PICTURE TUBE PLANT
description: The Zenith Electronics Corporation doubled to 800 yesterday the number of workers at an Illinois color picture tube plant it will dismiss starting this summer. The Melrose Park, Ill., plant is eliminating one daily shift and moving to a five-day production schedule from seven days, the company said. The cuts were discussed with unions and employees, Zenith said. Earlier this month, the Glenview, Ill., company said it would dismiss 400 workers at the plant beginning June 1. The 800 jobs represent about 8 percent of the company's total employment of 10,000. The Melrose Park plant received $100 million in improvements in mid-1996 that were supposed to make it profitable.

title: Corrections

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  PRAGER, KARSTEN

The fund will support mid-career fellowships for journalists from other countries studying at the university or American journalists studying international affairs. Gifts can be made to the University of Michigan, noting their purpose for the Prager fund and sent to the Michigan Journalism Fellows, 620 Oxford Road, Ann Arbor, Michigan 48104.

title: Kidnapping and Assault Bring a 19-Year Sentence
description: A Manhattan man who pleaded guilty to kidnapping and sexually abusing an immigrant woman during an 11-day attack was sentenced yesterday to 19 years to life in state prison.

title: Daewoo to Sell Piece Of Stake in Power Plants
description: The Daewoo Group, South Korea's third-largest industrial group, plans to sell half its stake in a $1.3 billion Indian power plant project to ABB Asea Brown Boveri Ltd. The decision is the latest attempt by a Korean company to scale back overseas investments.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOLLENDER, SELMA
description: HOLLENDER-Selma. Your beautiful spirit is with us every day. Alex, Jane, Beth, Wendy, Herb and Pearl

title: Dana Buys Unit in Brazil
description: The Dana Corporation said today that it had acquired through a Brazilian subsidiary 98 percent of Nakata S.A. Industria e Comercio of Sao Paulo, Brazil. Terms were not disclosed. Nakata, which makes suspension components and shock absorbers, had 1997 sales of more than $110 million. Dana, based in Toledo, makes products for the automotive, engine, heavy-truck, off-highway, industrial and leasing markets. It had revenue of $8.3 billion in 1997. Dana said the stock it acquired included publicly held shares that were tendered on the Brazilian stock exchange and all of the founding Nakata family's interest.

title: Foreign Affairs; Techno-Nothings
description: I don't think I like Silicon Valley.

title: Cendant Promises to Complete Takeover
description: Henry R. Silverman, the president and chief executive of the Cendant Corporation, said yesterday that all pending takeovers would be completed and that the company had access to enough money to do more big deals.

title: Knicks Get Their Wish: Rematch With the Heat
description: The Knicks were hurt and angry as they sat in a small locker room tucked away in Miami Arena last May. A couple of tears fell, and a few remarks were spilled about feeling cheated and wanting revenge.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COCOA RISES 1.5 PERCENT. Cocoa rallied after the Chocolate Manufacturers Association said first-quarter demand from big American chocolate makers rose 3.9 percent. May contracts settled at $1,596 a metric ton, up $24.

description: To the Editor:

description: Afghan Cease-Fire Accord

title: No Matter the Park, Yankees Hit It Out and Win
description: Detroit threw Justin Thompson, its best pitcher, in the path of George Steinbrenner's juggernaut tonight and he was blown away like a dried-up leaf. Get used to it. Grow accustomed to thrashings like the Yankees' 11-2 thrashing of the Tigers tonight.

title: OWENS CORNING SELLING GLASS-FIBER AND SPECIALTY UNIT
description: Owens Corning said yesterday that it planned to sell the glass-fiber yarns and specialty materials division of its Composites Systems business. Owens Corning, based in Toledo, Ohio, makes glass composites, and building and industrial materials. It had sales of $4.4 billion in 1997. The division to be sold had sales of $300 million in 1997, Owens Corning said. Glass-fiber yarns are used in laminates for printed circuit boards, reinforcing fabric for packaging, and roofing materials. The sale would include plants in Aiken, S.C., and Huntingdon, Pa., and affect 1,500 employees. Owens Corning will keep its glass-fiber yarn plants in Battice, Belgium, and Guelph, Ontario.

title: Plenty of Hitters to Step In for Davis
description: Joe Torre figured he would find a way to play his three left fielders on a regular basis this season, though the Yankee manager was not sure how. But today, the Yankees announced that designated hitter Chili Davis will have surgery on Monday to repair a torn tendon in his right ankle and will miss 8 to 10 weeks.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK WEAKENS. The mark fell after Bundesbank policy makers left interest rates unchanged, eliminating speculation of a possible German rate increase. In New York the dollar cost 1.8083 marks, up from 1.8057.

title: PRIMUS TELECOMMUNICATIONS INCREASES TRESCOM BID
description: Primus Telecommunications Group Inc. said yesterday that it had increased its takeover bid for a rival international phone company, Trescom International Inc., to $155 million from $122 million. In February, Primus agreed to buy Trescom for $10 a share in stock. The new offer is worth $12 a share. Trescom shares rose 13 percent on news of the new bid, rising $1.375, to $11.625. Shares of Primus rose 18.25 cents, to $27.875. In exchange for the higher bid, Primus will receive stock options from Warburg Pincus Investors L.P., which owns about 51 percent of Trescom's shares, as well as certain Trescom officers, allowing Primus to acquire more than 50 percent of Trescom's shares if the merger is not completed. Trescom, based in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., provides international long-distance calls that originate in the United States. Primus, based in McLean, Va., and also a long-distance phone company, said the acquisition would help it enter the Caribbean and Latin American markets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRESLIN, ANNE
description: BRESLIN-Anne, 83 years. Died on Mar. 31, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Samuel, devoted mother of Bonnie Ephraim and Ellen Krane; adored grandmother of Barry, Jonathan and Daniel Ephraim; and Justin and Ryan Krane.

title: A Matter of Love, Trust And, in Short, Family
description: These days, the fine actress Judy Davis so completely represents a frenetic urban brittleness, by way of Woody Allen, that it's startling to contemplate her against the lush, incompletely tamed vistas of western Australia, her homeland. And that's exactly where she's placed in ''The Echo of Thunder,'' a quiet but effective Hallmark Hall of Fame movie that will be shown on CBS tomorrow night at 9.

title: City Hospital Workers Sue Over Layoffs
description: New York City's largest public employees union filed a lawsuit in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on Thursday accusing the city of laying off union members at city-run hospitals and illegally replacing them with workfare participants.

title: SGS-Thomson's Profit Exceeds Expectations
description: Shares of SGS-Thomson Microelectronics N.V. rose after the chip maker's profit topped expectations for the first quarter amid strong sales to the car and telecommunications industries. SGS-Thomson, Europe's second-largest chip maker, earned $90.2 million, or 65 cents a diluted share, compared with $90.5 million, or 65 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Analysts had expected 62 cents a share. Sales rose to $1.01 billion from $944 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOENIG, IRVING
description: KOENIG-Irving. August 2, 1919April 15, 1998. We mourn the loss of our beloved husband, father, brother and grandfather, CPA, attorney and World War II veteran, caring, generous, witty, passionate in his beliefs, honorable in business and in personal affairs. Leah Koenig (wife), Karen Schochet and Anne Koenig (daughters), Hattie Feit and Daisy Berman (sisters), Avraham Zvi and Elisheva Rachel (grandchildren), and many other in-laws, nieces and nephews. Shiva at his home following the holiday.

title: Graft Charge Hurts Nation, Ex-President Of Iran Says
description: In unusually direct remarks, one of Iran's most influential leaders warned today that corruption allegations against the Mayor of Teheran had poisoned the country's political environment and posed a risk to its health.

title: Yeltsin's Premier Loses A 2d Time in Parliament
description: As Russia's three-week-old political crisis neared a showdown, President Boris N. Yeltsin left tonight for a two-day visit to Japan, leaving the Government in the hands of a 35-year-old Prime Minister-designate who today was dealt his second defeat in Parliament's lower house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, ANDREW
description: BRODSKY-Andrew. In his 79th year. On April 16th, at his home, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Sivia, loving father of Ann and Greg, father-in-law of Bob and Leigh Anne, devoted grandfather of Allison, Daniel and Jake. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, April 19, 12:30PM at Congregation Emanu-El at 5th Avenue and 65th Street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERELSON, ROSLYN
description: PERELSON-Roslyn. Beloved wife of the late Jacob. Devoted mother of Stephen, Stuart and Arlene Linder. Adored mother in law of Jack (Linder) and Carol. Dear sister of Natalie Lerer and Elaine Gan. Loving grandmother of Andrew, Adam, Melissa, Robert, Randi, Aaron and Jeffrey. Services Sunday, 10 AM, at Plaza Memorial, 91 St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: German Social Democrats Unite Around Schroeder
description: FRANKFURT  The German opposition leader, Gerhard Schroeder, added to his front-runner momentum for the September election on Friday when his Social Democratic Party confirmed him overwhelmingly as its candidate against Chancellor Helmut Kohl.

title: Drugs and Technology Rise To Lead Rebound in Shares
description: What the stock market takes away one day, it can give back the next. And that is what happened yesterday, with most of the major market indicators rebounding to new highs.

title: Bird-Watchers to Be Held Longer, Colombian Rebel Says
description: A Central Park bird-watcher and two other Americans who were kidnapped by rebels in Colombia a month ago may not be released for another six months, a high-ranking official with the rebel group holding them said this week.

title: Pakistan Frees Drug-Enforcement Employee
description: After months of high-level American pressure, Pakistan has freed a Pakistani employee of the Drug Enforcement Administration who was jailed in Pakistan after helping gain the arrests of two Pakistani Air Force pilots who smuggled heroin into the United States.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OSWALD, WILLIAM E.
description: OSWALD-William E., 59. Passed from this life on April 8 due to complications from lung cancer. He will be sorely missed by Tom Skews and Charles McGlinnen, his partners in business and life. Bill was known to many in the display industry as an example of a true gentleman and friend. Due to his wishes, there was no service held, but a future tribute is being planned. We will always love and think of you, Billy.

title: Ideas & Trends; A Wakeup Call for Workfare's Advocates
description: IN polishing his achievements in town hall meetings in Brooklyn and fund raisers as far away as Arizona, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani always mentions one that sets him apart from other politicians: His creation of the country's largest workfare program, a welfare work force of 34,000 people who sweep streets, clean parks and answer phones for their welfare checks.

title: Lives; The Spoilers
description: It was late April last year, and I had just arrived in New York. Not yet in possession of an apartment, I was billeted by my employers at the Paramount Hotel, near the border of one of Manhattan's seamier districts. One night, fed up with work, but with no friends as yet in this vast, strange city, I slipped on my jeans and went to a dive on nearby Eighth Avenue in search of a Scotch.

title: Huge Bank Mergers Worry Consumer Groups
description: With the latest wave of bank mergers announced in recent days, most of the public attention was focused on what the mergers would mean to profits, stock prices, executive salaries and corporate synergy. Increasingly, though, citizens' advocates and some lawmakers are questioning what this consolidation in the banking industry will mean to a very basic group: consumers.

title: Rhubarb, Perfect for Compotes, Crumbles and Fools
description: LAST year, on a tour of one of the more spectacular gardens in northwestern Connecticut, I was struck by the beauty of giant rhubarb plants, which had been cultivated not for eating but for decoration. Indeed, until the 17th century, rhubarb was considered an ornamental plant, with roots that were used as a medicine. The wide, frilly leaves are, in fact, toxic (they contain oxalic acid), and the idea of eating the stalks did not catch on until the 19th century. Even then, it was chiefly in northern Europe that the stalks captured the imagination of cooks, who made them into jams and jellies, desserts or a sauce to go with meat and even fish.

title: 3 L.A. Hotels Offer Shuttle Service to Getty
description: The new Getty Center is fast becoming one of the most popular attractions in Los Angeles, with more than 667,000 visitors since opening last December. The museum is free, but parking costs $5, and reservations are required. Currently, reservations are not available until November, with the exception of a few late-afternoon or evening weekday slots. Without a parking reservation, visitors must take a bus or taxi. (Note that parking in the neighborhood is restricted to those with permits.)

title: Wild Dogs' Reign of Terror
description: Since December, residents of the quiet community of Sunnyside Gardens have been awakened on many nights by the piercing cry of yet another cat dying from an attack by a roaming pack of wild dogs. They fear that a child may be the next victim.

title: A Child Psychiatrist and Pedophile; His Therapist Knew but Didn't Tell; a Victim Is Suing
description: The revelation came without any special buildup, tacked onto a reminiscence about a trip to South America. One moment, Joseph DeMasi was telling his psychiatrist, Douglas H. Ingram, that he had gone there to see the night sky in the Southern Hemisphere. The next, he was confessing an additional agenda: to meet a nice child.

title: April 12-18; Palestinian Leader Released
description: Israel freed itself of a public relations nightmare by releasing a 46-year-old Palestinian who had been held without trial since 1992. Ahmad Qatamesh, who returned to his home in the West Bank, had been jailed on suspicion of being a leader of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, a militant group opposed to the Israeli-Palestinian accords.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STRYKER, ARTHUR
description: STRYKER-Arthur. Of Hallandale, FL, died April 17, 1998. Attorney for 65 years. Beloved husband of Elsie and Frances. Loving father of Madeleine Hirschhorn and Alice Weinstein. Adored grandfather and great grandfather. Services Tuesday, 12:30 at Gutterman's, Jericho Tpke., Woodbury, NY.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KRAUS, SYLVIA BRACHFELD STIEFLER
description: KRAUS-Sylvia Brachfeld Stiefler. Of Rye, New York, died April 18, 1998. Beloved and adored wife of Dr. David Kraus for 23 years, devoted mother of Barbara Schlein and Jeffrey Stiefler; loving sister of Julian H. Brachfeld; proud grandmother of Robert and Jennifer Schlein and Todd, Zachary, Timothy and Robert Stiefler. Her former husband, Robert M. Stiefler, died in 1966. Born April 29, 1920. Graduate of Cornell University, 1941. Former English teacher at Harrison High School. She will be deeply missed by those who loved her. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be made to American Lung Association, 35 Orchard Street, White Plains, NY 10603. Funeral services will be held at Rye Community Synagogue, 200 Forest Avenue, Rye, NY on Sunday, April 19 at 12 noon.

title: Sandra J. Holmes, 57, Creator Of Yonkers Group to Aid Poor
description: The Rev. Sandra Jishu Holmes, a Zen Buddhist priest, teacher and co-founder of the Greyston Mandala, an organization in Yonkers dedicated to helping the poor, died on Feb. 20 at a hospital in Albuquerque, N.M. She was 57 and had moved last month to Santa Fe, N.M., from Yonkers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAHL, ELLY (NEE WOLF)
description: STAHL-Elly (nee Wolf). Of No. Miami, FL, died on April 14, 1998 at 90. Loved by her husband, Siegfried; son, Howard; daughter-inlaw, Irene; three grandchildren, Lisa, Jonathan, and Deborah Kerchner; son-in-law, Daniel Kerchner; and Bill Kravitz. Shiva observed in Scarsdale until Friday morning.

title: A Bar in Debate Even Before Opening
description: The northwest corner of 109th Street and Amsterdam Avenue is still marked by drug-dealing, despite several efforts by the police to halt it, and there has been little commercial development on that bleak stretch of the avenue in 30 years.

title: Rare Breed
description: The warmly appealing heroine of DARK VICTORY is a stricken woman who weds her loving doctor (George Brent) and won laurels for Bette Davis, whose career was founded on roles of dazzling witchery. ''I loved doing Judith,'' the actress told me at her Maine home a few years before her death, but I saw it again not long ago and some wise ones -- Hollywood friends, who picked it to pieces and I agreed on some points, like those angel voices at the end. Her director, Edmund Goulding, had told Hollywood that his star had ground him into powder. However, a co-star, the beautiful Geraldine Fitzgerald, became a close friend. ''I saw Gerry not long ago and you know what she told me: 'Bette, give us more worlds' '' -- MONDAY at 10 P.M. on TCM. Howard Thompson

title: Bank Stocks: Have the Fireworks Ended?
description: SHOULD I cash in -- or hang on?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLER, DELLA S.
description: BERLER-Della S. On April 16th. Devoted wife of the late Harry. Beloved mother of Joan and David Berler. Cherished grandmother of Daniel, Matthew and Melissa Berler. Loving great grandmother of Jackson and Ellie Berler. Funeral Service Sunday, 9:30 AM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Interment Mount Moriah Cemetery.

title: The Nation: Free Lunch; Feeding the New Work Ethic
description: MOST lotteries offer such low odds of winning that they invite comparisons to rare lightning strikes. But there's a new lottery with terrific odds and lots of winners: It's called Corporate America.

title: Rome Church
description: To the Editor: Aptly characterized by Celestine Bohlen as an overlooked gem ''full of light and space'' (''What's Doing in Rome,'' March 29), Santa Sabina Church figured in ''The Seven Storey Mountain'' by Thomas Merton.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on March 15 with a Frugal Traveler column, about Puerto Vallarta, Mexico, misidentified a building. It was an apartment house, not the neighboring Hotel Los Cuatro Vientos; the pool shown belongs to the hotel.

title: Of Basses, Baritones And Hedges
description: PAUL ROBESON, the renowned actor, activist and concert singer, usually identified his voice type as baritone. This fact led to an interesting internal debate at The New York Times recently, when Robeson was posthumously given a lifetime achievement award at the Grammy ceremony. In reporting the story, the Times arts editors, quite defensibly, deferred to Robeson's preferred description of his voice.

description: To the Editor:

title: For 75 Years, a Raucous Stage in the Bronx
description: There was supposed to be a party and a cake at Yankee Stadium yesterday, with the third- and fourth-generation descendants of a team and its following on hand to trace their spiritual birth to the 1923 afternoon when Yankee Stadium -- sports cathedral, stage for popes and politics, urban touchstone -- welcomed its first crowd.

title: A Mini-Holland Tunnel for New Amsterdam's Art Crowd
description: It was for the sake of her dozen geranium plants that Paulien Lethen decided to put a shed in the back of the building that she owns on South Third Street in Williamsburg. The pre-fab structure from Home Depot was raised onto cinder blocks and insulated, and windows were cut out to let sunlight in. ''It was beginning to feel like a room,'' Ms. Lethen said.

title: U.S. Set to Turn Fed Cup Tables
description: The Dutch imported their own cheering section, and the fans bloomed in the bleachers like a field of coral tulips. But because the Netherlands does not have players who can handle the power and precision of the A-list squad recruited by Billie Jean King, the United States Fed Cup captain, the home team took a commanding 2-0 lead today in the three-of-five-match competition.

title: Social Services Shakeup
description: County Executive Andrew J. Spano has released state figures showing what he termed ''the poor leadership and goal-setting performance'' of the county's Department of Social Services in 1996-97.

title: Where Opium Reigned, Burmese Claim Inroads
description: In the remote valleys and rugged mountains here in northeastern Myanmar, opium offers more than a narcotic high. For years, it has provided a livelihood for hill tribes who inhabit the northern expanse of the Golden Triangle, the lush, lawless area of Southeast Asia that is the source of much of the world's heroin.

title: An Adventure in Textures and Flavors
description: IN two years, Barcelona Wine Bar in South Norwalk has transformed itself into Barcelona Restaurant and Wine Bar, adding an attractive low-key dining room to the long narrow room that originally doubled as bar and dining space. There is even a new third dining area, a large tent with wood-burning grill, open on weekends now (to handle overflow) and nightly in warm weather.

title: Union Chief Calls Workfare 'Slavery'
description: After years as a close and enthusiastic ally of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the leader of the city's largest municipal union denounced the Giuliani administration's workfare program yesterday, equating it with slavery because, he said, it did not lead most of its participants to meaningful jobs.

title: William G. Congdon, 86, Abstract Painter
description: William G. Congdon, an American painter well known in the 1950's and 60's for his painterly fusion of abstraction and representation and his depiction of religious themes, died of a heart attack on Wednesday, his 86th birthday, in a hospital in Milan, Italy. He had a home in Milan and had lived in Italy since the early 1950's.

title: W. B. Fitzgerald, A Founder of a Minority Bank, Dies at 65
description: William Burwell Fitzgerald, a Washington community leader and an entrepreneur who over 30 years built a small thrift institution into one of the country's largest black-owned businesses, died on Monday at Inova Fairfax Hospital in Washington. He was 65 and lived in Washington.

title: April 12-18; Court Rejects F.C.C. Rule On Minority Recruiting
description: In a decision that could have an impact on the future of affirmative action, a Federal appeals court in Washington threw out a Government requirement that television and radio stations make a good faith effort to increase minority employment through recruitment.

title: A Clean Bill For the Iraqis On A-Arms? Experts Upset
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency is moving close to declaring Iraq free of nuclear weapons, and some American experts are raising alarms and charging the agency with complacency. They say Iraq's record of deception and its wealth of talented scientists point to both the intention and ability to recreate an atomic program quickly.

title: Mr. Pataki's Adirondacks Opportunity
description: Gov. George Pataki is earning an unexpected reputation as a friend of the environment, but his permanent legacy in this field will depend heavily on whether he seizes every available opportunity to protect the Adirondacks. New York's Adirondack Park, the crown jewel of America's state parks, is a six-million-acre expanse that could accommodate Yellowstone, Yosemite, Glacier and Grand Canyon National Parks with room to spare. Half of it is protected state land, the other half private, and the struggle has always been to find ways to acquire large parcels of private land when they come on the market, thus enlarging the wilderness before the speculators arrive on the scene.

title: 5 Years After Waco Standoff, The Spirit of Koresh Lingers
description: As the wind kicked up on the prairie and a dull yellow sun dropped in the evening sky, Kimberly Martin handed a bouquet of wild primrose to her mother and scampered over to the rubble of Mount Carmel, the place where she was born nine years ago and where, she dimly recalls, David Koresh used to ''teach, teach, teach'' for hours on end.

title: Turning the Tables: This Time, a Shareholder Is Being Sued
description: HERE'S a twist for the closed-end fund industry: The Emerging Germany fund has filed a lawsuit against two activist shareholders, contending that they violated Securities and Exchange Commission rules on proxy solicitation. In recent years, it has generally been the shareholders who have been suing the closed-end funds, trying to compel them to convert to open-end status or to buy back shares.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURDEN, JOYCE
description: BURDEN-Joyce, 61, of Boca Raton, FL. Formerly of Manhattan, N.Y. Passed away April 16, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Edward. Loving mother of Randi Brown, Patti Josepher (Jerry), and Michael Burden (Maria). Cherished and forever loved grandmother of Adam, Lauren, and Jordan. Her love and generosity will be her legacy for all who were fortunate enough to have known her.

title: The Years of Sears
description: Got a bare-back halter and boy-cut pants? Can't put the look together? A new book of 1970's fashions reproduced from Sears, Roebuck & Company catalogues is packed with ensemble tips for the retro-impaired.

title: The Views From Her Windows Are Enough
description: FOR more than 30 years, the artist Jane Freilicher has been quietly painting the same two views over and over again. One is from her penthouse on lower Fifth Avenue, across the brown-gray buildings stretching to the Hudson River. The other is from her country house in Water Mill, on Long Island, looking out across the fields, often with Mecox Bay in the background. Every painting is different, but usually there is a vase in the foreground, filled with flowers painted in lush, riotous colors, the light behind it, especially in the South Fork paintings, pulsating with a blue intensity.

title: Little School With Lots of Sports Spirit
description: WHEN the Trinity Catholic High School hockey team in Stamford won the state championship with a 3-1 victory over New Canaan last month, it was somewhat surprising in one respect. New Canaan had won the teams' three previous meetings. But in another respect, Trinity Catholic's title run, in which it outscored the opposition 23-4 in four games, raised nary an eyebrow. It marked the school's 10th state championship this decade.

title: Caught in a Yellow-Bordered Trap
description: IT IS the hardest decision many of us will ever have to make. Indeed, some of us will not have the courage to make it; we will avoid the issue until we die, passing the burden on to our children.

title: Amanda Dealy, M. H. Haverstick
description: Amanda Garcin Dealy, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John T. Dealy of Newport, R.I., was married there yesterday to Matthew Hermann Haverstick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Scott H. Haverstick of Washington Boro, Pa. The Rev. Gregory A. M. Cole performed the ceremony at Emmanuel Episcopal Church.

title: Critics See a Barrier in a Fence Around Central Park Reservoir
description: Elvira Payer came from a small town in Austria to visit New York last week, and was pleased, sometimes dazzled by the array of things to see. Then she laid eyes on the chain-link fence around the Central Park Reservoir.

title: The Day the Mail Brought a Bonanza in Two Crates
description: DEBORAH FEDERHEN, the curator of collections, was on her way to the postage machine in the mail room at the Bennington Museum in Bennington, Vt., when she stubbed her toe. Looking down, she saw that she had bumped into the larger of two wooden shipping crates someone had stashed under the mailing table. The parcels were addressed to Steven Miller, executive director of the Bennington Museum.

title: Patriarch of a New, Uncelebrated Family
description: MARK P. HURLEY first caused an uproar in the money management business in 1995 when, as a vice president at Goldman, Sachs he wrote a report predicting the demise of midsize investment firms. Mr. Hurley's view was that the marketing prowess of larger firms would force the smaller guys to sell out to the giants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, ANDRA (NEE SCHUTZ).
description: DAVIS-Andra (nee Schutz). Of Huntington, LI. Beloved wife of Peter, mother of Conner, daughter of Ethel and Seymour, sister of Jed. Died March 17, 1998. A public memorial service will be held at 2 PM, Sunday, April 26 at Touro Law School, 300 Nassau Rd., Huntington. For directions, call 516421-2244, ext. 303.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JOSEPH, SAMUEL
description: JOSEPH-Samuel, died April 15, 1998, 90 years old in Bethesda, MD. Born in Paterson, NJ. Married to Helen Kronenberg (deceased), an artist. A lawyer and CPA specializing in public utility rate regulation. Chief Economist for the Federal Power Commission during World War II. Partner at H. Zinder & Associates. In the 1950s and 60s, he pioneered in the use of the computer for investment strategies and research and in the devlopment of hedge funds. Co-founded in 1966 of CDA Investment Technologies. Dear father of William K. and Stephanie Joseph, Carol and Don Van Reenan. Grandfather of Donald, Derek, Dennis, Max, Lisa and Dan. Great-grandfather of Hunter Anne and Hayden. Private funeral. Donations can be made to: ESCAPE, a child abuse prevention center. 16 S. Market St., Frederick, MD 21701

title: Buffet Breakfast
description: To the Editor: Robert Packard's delightfully cranky lament for room service (''If It's Not Breakfast, Do Not Disturb,'' Feb. 22) reminded me of the reasons I enjoy the grand breakfast buffet he strives so mightily to avoid. I admire the huge bouquets of fresh flowers nodding over the astonishing array of food; but most of all, I enjoy watching the partakers of this early feast.

title: The World; 50 Years Ago in Israel: Trying to Imagine the Future
description: BY declaring itself independent 50 years ago, Israel announced its intention to give Jews a new future. The past, especially the still gaping wound of genocide, had been too terrible. So there was a great temptation to peer into the future and imagine what it held.

title: SOAPBOX; Auto Insurance Reform Is Near
description: LAST year, New Jerseyans demanded auto insurance reform. They presented New Jersey's policy makers with a clear message: reduce our rates without slashing benefits.

title: Mirror, Mirror, Who's the Best Dressed of All?
description: FOR a woman who refuses to talk about her boyfriend, China Chow sure brings him up a lot.

title: Sports of The Times; Manning or Leaf: And Who Cares?
description: WHO will be the better pro quarterback, Peyton Manning or Ryan Leaf?

title: Sand Won't Get Into the Wheels in This Playground for Preteens
description: The word ''playground'' usually conjures up images of swings and sandboxes, but the Mercer Playground, being built on a narrow strip of land on the west side of Mercer Street between Bleecker and West Third Streets, will have none of those. Instead, it will include a long snake path for in-line and roller skating, a spray shower, plantings, benches and open space where youngsters can get together and talk.

title: Back to the Drawing Board, With Pen and Pulitzer Prize in Hand
description: STEVE BREEN was 4 years old the last time a New Jersey journalist won a Pulitzer Prize. And he was living a continent away, in Orange County, Calif.

title: I Am Woman, Hear Me Whine
description: BITCH

title: Checking What Is on Your Plants' Plate
description: IF plants could cry out when they were hungry, we gardeners would pay more attention to their fertilizer needs. Actually, plants do tell us when they are hungry, very hungry, with poor or distorted growth, and with leaf discolorations that indicate which nutrients are lacking. But rather than wait until your plants become desperate, when it may be too late to correct problems, why not see what's on their plate? Take a soil test, which you can do anytime that the soil is not frozen.

title: The Globe Straddler Of the Art World
description: THE other day Thomas Krens, the Guggenheim Museum's director, heading east on 89th Street toward Madison Avenue, pointed at an apartment building behind the museum. At the nadir of the New York City real estate market in 1974, long before he arrived, the museum sold the building for $1.8 million.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORN, SARAH
description: HORN-Sarah, Scranton, PA. Died April 14, 1998. She was the widow of Rev. William S. Horn, Cantor Emeritus of Temple Israel, Scranton. Surviving is a daughter, Rissel Kaggen, Brooklyn, N.Y., 8 grandchildren, 16 great grandchildren. Funeral services were held on Thursday in Rochester, New York.

title: Go, Girl!
description: Israel is famous for many things, but transsexual divas are not among them. That could change when Dana International (pictured) takes the stage next month to represent Israel at the annual Eurovision competition in Birmingham, England, an international song contest. title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Awwwwwww!
description: Legend has it that rather than disturb his sleeping cat, the prophet Mohammed cut his robe in two. This is the sort of story that makes dog people roll their eyes and cat people smile indulgently. And this is the sort of sensibility that explains why cat people have enabled the German-born photogapher Hans Silvester to make such a comfortable living. ASLEEP IN THE SUN (Chronicle, $29.95), the latest in a series of books documenting the feline good life as enjoyed in the Greek islands, may be his most attractive yet. Certainly it's his most comfortable. Think of it as a wordless primer in the art of the nap, a sequence of handsome images of cats mostly doing what they do best -- lying around with their eyes closed, looking more relaxed than we can ever hope to be. And more stylish. It's no slur on Silvester's talent to note that cats seem to have a knack for displaying themselves to their best advantage: consider, for example, the tabby he finds sprawled across the top of a trellis, one leg dangling just so, or the ginger-and-white cat lolling decoratively behind a curtain of ginger-colored fishing nets. Even the cat caught snoozing against the windshield of a car looks terribly clever rather than in imminent danger of becoming road kill. (And the blue of the car does contrast nicely with his fur.) ''For those who would learn to siesta well,'' Silvester writes in his introduction, ''I advise taking a cat as a teacher.'' All well and good, but remember one thing: any lessons will be offered in the cat's own good time. Alida Becker

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAVES, BRADFORD
description: GRAVES-Bradford. July 26, 1939 April 16, 1998. Sculptor, musician, teacher, loving and beloved person. Brad took his inspiration from his love of art and creativity's limitless forms. He gave his unique synthesis to us all through his generous desire to share the gifts of his life. Born in Dallas, Texas in 1939, Brad came to New York in 1958. With the city as his base, he pursued an extraordinary range of interests. Brad taught at Parsons School of Design and was Professor of Fine Arts at Fairleigh Dickinson University. He participated in many solo and group exhibitions, received numerous grants, awards and critical recognition from many admirers who recognized that his art, like his life, was both deeply felt and finely crafted. Brad will be deeply missed. He is predeceased by his mother, Madge D. Graves and his father, David Graves. He is survived by his wife and partner in life, Verna Gillis, their cat, Cody Bumpkins, brother, David, loving step-mother, Helen Graves, aunt, Jean Dalrymple, brother and sister-in-law, David and Renee Gillis, mother-inlaw, Dr. Freda Gillis, nephews and niece Ivan, Sarah and Aram Rubenstein-Gillis. The public's fascination with the tragedy, which claimed more than 1,500 lives and which marked its 86th anniversary last week, appears to be focused on the romantic aspect of ocean liner travel and the era's feminine style of dress -- Empire waistlines, swallow-tail coats, parasols, enormous hats that are elaborately decorated, and men in top hats, morning coats, walking sticks and spats.

title: Children's Books; Let's Go Fly a Kite
description: Adults may differ about what makes a perfect day. But for a young child, it would surely be like the one Vera B. Williams creates for Evie in LUCKY SONG (Greenwillow, $15; ages 2 to 5). It's a slight, bright book with the color-saturated pictures and joyous spirit familiar to readers of such beloved earlier works as ''A Chair for My Mother'' and ''Scooter.'' For Evie, unaccountably, everything goes right: ''She wanted something new to wear and on the hook she found it. She wanted something new to play with, and her grandpa made it for her. She wanted to go out, and the door flew open.'' Everyone and everything respond to her every wish: ''She wanted to fly her kite, and the wind took it. When she shouted, 'Look how high!' her mother ran to look. When she wanted to go home for supper, her grandma had it ready. When she wanted her blanket, her sister wrapped it around her.'' It is just the opposite of those terrible, horrible, no-good, very bad days when children -- storybook or real -- are slighted, misunderstood and out of luck. But as Evie's day winds down, and the book comes to a close, Williams lets on that every tale of perfection is an incantation, a kind of wish-song. ''When she wanted a song, her father came and sang to her -- all about Evie, who flew her kite up with the clouds and the speedy planes,'' the ending goes. ''If you want to hear that song again, go back to the beginning.'' Tamar Lewin

title: They Let the Talking Heads Talk, but They Set the Tone
description: IN the mists of television past, the on-screen interviewer was likely to be an anonymous scholar or an uncomfortable newspaper reporter, but by the time the rabbit ears had vanished and long before you could say ''Hi, Larry!'' a transformation had occurred. Tilling the fields of journalism, entertainment and hospitality, interviewers sowed a new profession: the reporter as video artist.

title: Fannie Spelce, Cardiac Nurse And a Folk Artist, Dies at 89
description: Cardiac patients who were lucky enough to make it to Houston in the days Michael E. Debakey and Denton E. Cooley were pioneering open heart surgery at Methodist Hospital were doubly fortunate that the nurse in charge of the operating room was Fannie Lou Spelce, a well-grounded, no-nonsense woman with a scalpel-sharp eye for detail and a spirited commitment to professional excellence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TEITELBAUM, ROBERT P.
description: TEITELBAUM-Robert P. On April 13th, 1998 of a heart attack. He was 68. Beloved father of Bonnie, Sheila and Barry. Cherished father-in-law to Steven, Paul and Michael. Adored ''Papa Bobby'' to grandsons Daniel and Jayson. Mr. Teitelbaum was the Sr. Managing Director at the brokerage firm of Ladenburg, Thalman. He had been with the company since 1975. He was a member of the board of Happiness is Camping, a camp for children with cancer. He was the financial advisor pro bono for the United Odd Fellow and Rebekah Home. His sense of humor and love of life will be remembered by all who knew and loved him. Contributions can be made in his memory to Happiness is Camping, 2169 Grand Concourse, Bronx, New York 10453.

title: Green Acres Project Isn't Green; Some Neighbors See Red
description: In a crowded state, the Green Acres program has been presented for nearly 40 years as a source of respite. The cause of securing land for parks and preserves, which is the Green Acres mission, has taken on new urgency, too, with the larger open-space initiative that Governor Whitman announced three months ago.

title: Shanghai
description: Shanghai is in the middle of a huge make-over. As the largest and most cosmopolitan city in China, it often seems determined to be at the forefront of the nation's fast-changing ways. Today that means that Shanghai is undergoing a boom in construction so vast that officials like to boast that nearly one-fifth of the world's cranes are at work in their city.

title: Polyglot Penang, A Special Place, La!
description: AFTER nine years of fairly regular visits to Penang Island, off the northwest coast of peninsular Malaysia, my vision is still that of a romantic: Bicycle rickshaws peddled by old men with bulging calves through the capital of Georgetown, the smell of joss sticks burning and curries sizzling, and the sound of the muezzin calling the Muslim faithful to prayer. Like many Southeast Asian cities, Georgetown has grown during these years. Shiny cereal boxes pierce the skyline here and there, and buzzing traffic overwhelms the slower pace of former days. But more than almost any of its neighbors, Penang retains its exotic charm and historic grace.

title: April 12-18; Death by Medication
description: More than 100,000 people die in American hospitals each year from adverse reactions to medication, researchers say, revealing a problem that is far more serious than the medical profession had realized.

description: Jack London

title: Brazilian Yes, Coffee No
Miss Bernhardt and Mr. Stefansson
description: Coryann Siobhan Bernhardt and Christer Ake Anders Stefansson were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York. The Rev. William Bergen performed the ceremony.

title: Publication Gives 2 Neighborhoods Unwanted Local Color
description: The violet-colored plastic newspaper boxes that popped up recently along the bluestone sidewalks of Cobble Hill and Brooklyn Heights left residents angry and baffled.

title: The Second Most Beautiful Laundrette, Hoping to be No. 1
description: Shortly after opening his Bellmawr Maytag LaundraMaxx in 1995, George Giangrante was informed by the Maytag appliance company that his coin-operated laundry was the second most beautiful in America. He was never told whose was the first. Since then, he has been waiting for Maytag to hold its next coin laundry beauty contest, and hoping to be No. 1 someday.

title: A Mountain Voice and Other Signs of Folk Life
description: AS a social worker at the Henry Street Settlement in Manhattan, Jean Ritchie often sang and played the dulcimer for the children who lived in the neighborhood. One day a New York University graduate, touring the facility, heard Ms. Ritchie and asked her to bring her unusual instrument to an alumni tea. The young redhead, known to the children of the settlement as Kentucky because that's where she had come from, accepted the invitation and, in a grand room with Queen Anne sofas, played for adult strangers for the first time.

title: Cone Overlooks the Flaws and Gets His First Victory
description: Worried that the cold affected his grip of the baseball, David Cone had become a confessed Weather Channel junkie. Fretting about his delivery, he lost all sense of his mechanics. In other words, Cone, one of baseball's most aggressive, proactive pitchers, was reactive in his first two starts this year and the first two innings today.

title: McCarter Theater Getting A Second, Smaller Stage
description: The McCarter in Princeton has been producing various small-scale theater pieces over the years, even though the theater has not had an intimate performing space to call its own.

title: Sarah Rockwell, Thomas Cabot 3d
description: Sarah Finnie Rockwell, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David H. Finnie of New Canaan, Conn., was married on Tuesday to Thomas Dudley Cabot 3d, the son of Anne Cabot Ogilvy of Philadelphia and Mr. Cabot Jr. of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Roy A. Benjamin performed the ceremony at Trinity Episcopal Church in Shelburne, Vt.

title: Combative Council Is Sparring With Giuliani's Agency Heads
description: The City Council hearing will not be held until tomorrow, but the sniping started last week. Councilman Victor L. Robles of Brooklyn, who will be the hearing's chairman, referred to the scheduled witness from the Giuliani administration as a ''joker'' and promised biting questions about layoffs planned at Harlem Hospital Center.

title: The Now Bag, No Waiting
description: The J. P. Tod's calfskin tote bag, popularized last year by Diana, the Princess of Wales, is so popular that devotees are waiting as long as three months to get one. But some women need immediate gratification, even if not from the real thing. Two shops known for high-quality copies of tony bags -- Rene, 1007 Madison Avenue (77th Street), and Suarez, 450 Park Avenue (57th Street) -- have recently received look-alike calfskin bags from Italy. The originals (above) come in three sizes -- for $900, $1,000 and $1,200; the copies in small and medium. At Rene (left), they are $485 and $525; at Suarez, $500 and $550. The differences are slight but telling: the knockoffs are a tad smaller, and though they have swivel handles, they lack the oval disk with the Tod's logo.

title: A Sparkling Shift in Culinary Direction
description: LITTLE remains of the Fusion Grille in East Setauket. There is a new name, Metropolis; new chef and part-owner, Jeffery Baruch, new decor and new outlook. Gone is the cross-cultural cuisine. Tuna-sushi tempura and calamari-conch fritters with a banana-guava dipping sauce have been replaced by more straightforward bistro fare: roast chicken with garlic crust and steak and french fries.

title: Ideas & Trends; The Brink Isn't What It Once Was
description: THESE are banner days for those who believe the world is on the verge of momentous change. Indeed, so many people have been described recently as standing on the brink of this or that huge development that they ought to watch their step. It can be dangerous out there on the rim.

title: Afoot Alone
description: To the Editor: I am a longtime single traveler, and enjoy the Practical Traveler column. ''Trips for Those Going Solo'' (March 22) was very informative, but left out the very best way to go ''alone and with others'' at the same time. Walking! I have taken a number of walking tours with British Coastal Trails and have found this to be a wonderful compromise.

title: When a Company Splits Its Identity
description: THIS is the tale of two offices.

title: Mystical Bali, Refined
description: WHEN the car door opens under the portico of the open-air lobby of the Four Seasons at Jimbaran Bay in Bali, the first thing you notice is the smell of frangipani. Delicate, but all-pervasive, the flower's sweet scent is the ambient perfume of this luxury resort.

title: Taking A Landlord To Court
description: WHEN a landlord and a tenant are in conflict in New York City -- a not uncommon occurrence -- the most common way to resolve the dispute is for the tenant to file a complaint with the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, the agency charged with enforcing the city's Housing Maintenance Code. The method often works -- eventually.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATNER, FRANK
description: RATNER-Frank. On April 16, 1998, after a six month battle with Leukemia. Beloved husband of Helen, loving father of Jill, Beth and Lee and their spouses Joel Rosenberg, David Lyons and Andrea Ratner and grandfather of Sam, Naomi, Andrew, Michael, Monica, Jane, Stephen, Nicole and Jennifer, he passed on an inheritance of love, loyalty and unflinching dedication to the highest standards of ethics. Devoted brother of Hilda Ratner Dressler. His career included pioneer work in hepatitis research, followed by thirty-nine years of private practice of internal medicine. Among his most cherished accomplishments was the teaching of medical students and doctorsin-training, through his affiliations with Long Island Jewish Hospital Medical Center, Booth Memorial Medical Center (now NY Hospital in Queens) & the Flushing Hospital Medical Center. Past President of the Queens County Medical Society, Past President of the Staff Society of Booth Memorial Medical Center, Chairman of Continuing Medical Education at Booth Memorial and Flushing Hospital. Director of Ambulatory Care at Flushing Hospital, he officiated in numerous other capacities at the Medical Society and the hospitals with which he was associated. He will remain always in our hearts. Funeral services will be held on Sunday, April 19, 1998 at 2 P.M. at Driscoll Mortuary, 138 Migeon Avenue, Torrington, CT.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, MARION G.
description: DAVIS-Marion G. Sister of Capt. Lewis M. Davis, Jr. Burial Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, New York, on Monday, April 20 at 10 A.M.

title: 'Moderne' Lives On In a Colonial City
description: SNAPSHOTS from Hanoi: A woman in a conical straw hat, her cargo balanced fore and aft, rides her bicycle past the Beaux-Arts magnificence of the former residence of the Governor of Tonkin. Near the Ho Chi Minh mausoleum, smart 20's and 30's buildings, inspired by jazz age ideas of nonconformity, house the favored socialist embassies. Around the storied Opera House, now called the Municipal Theater, just reopened after a $20 million refurbishing, stern guards shoo Westerners away -- no admittance except during performances.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KONIGSBACHER, DR. KURT S.
description: KONIGSBACHER-Dr. Kurt S. Of Stamford, CT., and Basel, Switzerland. Passed away suddenly on April 14, 1998. Beloved husband of Renee; father of Susan and Peter; grandfather of Jeffrey, Pamela, Danielle and Michele.

title: Remembering a Period of Unrest, When Paul Robeson Went Unwanted
description: A SINGLE red rose lay on Paul Robeson's grave on what would have been the singer and actor's 100th birthday. The quiet, deserted gravesite near the grave of the writer James Baldwin at Ferncliff Cemetery here contrasted sharply with the memories evoked by the centennial in interviews with those who knew him.

title: Miyake's Way With Pleats To Be Available in SoHo
description: The first Pleats Please Issey Miyake boutique in the United States is to open in mid-May at 128 Wooster Street, at the corner of Prince Street in SoHo. The 600-square-foot shop will join Pleats Please stores in Tokyo, Paris and London in selling the line that Mr. Miyake inaugurated in October 1993.

title: Dance Festivals Are Giving Jazz Equal Billing
description: JAZZ began as an anonymous art, the spontaneous music of the cities and fields of Southern black America late in the 19th century. American modern dance was born a few decades later, a star turn for Isadora Duncan. For all their differences, however, jazz and modern dance each looked within the individual for inspiration, with few rules to guide expression. There the two arts parted, though jazz and social dancing were long and inextricably linked.

title: Expert to Study Ethics of Hospital Hiring
description: IN the aftermath of a legal opinion that could have major ramifications on its future, the Westchester Medical Center is hiring an outside lawyer who specializes in ethics issues to help determine if the center's two top lawyers did anything wrong when they took jobs with the hospital after helping to negotiate its spinoff from the county government last year.

title: Corrections
description: The Streetscapes column last Sunday, about the Manhattan House apartment block, misstated the given name of one of the architects who designed the project. He was Albert Mayer, not Charles.

title: Missing Rahway Man Found Dead in Maine
description: A body discovered on Friday in west-central Maine has been identified as that of a 21-year-old New Jersey man who disappeared from a bar in Maine on New Year's Eve, officials said yesterday.

title: Singers Taking Center Stage
description: VOICES are in abundant supply this week, starting with a pair of matinees today. At 3 o'clock, a concert in von der Mehden Hall at the University of Connecticut in Storrs offers the University of Connecticut Festival Chorus, Men's Chorus, Women's Singers and another women's group, called the Grace Notes; the groups are conducted by Peter Bagley, Joseph D'Eugenio and Jack A. Pott. The free program lists works of Holst, Debussy, Wagner and more.

title: POSTINGS: $5 Million Renovation Begun at Serbian Orthodox Cathedral of St. Sava; For Landmark Manhattan Church, a Restoration
description: Modeled after the 13th-century Sainte Chapelle in Paris, the church that was built as the Episcopalian Trinity Chapel in 1855 between Fifth Avenue and what is now Avenue of the Americas once served the gentry of Madison Square. Edith Wharton, who had lived across from the church at 28 West 25th Street, was married there on April 29, 1885.

title: Hospitality Italian Style in Port Chester
description: POTTED trees and discreet pinlights define the outdoor cafe on the broad sidewalk fronting Tony May's Hostaria. Inside, the rooms remain fresh and inviting from the beautiful, huge fabric ''flowers'' of the ceiling lighting fixtures to the polished floors. The place appeals for all kinds of dining. Dark paneling gives it dignified clubbiness. A stunning copper-crowned pizza station indicates informal family dining. Sunny geometric paintings in the far dining room generate a light-hearted mood, and a table laden with platters of antipasti suggests the abbondanza associated with Italian hospitality. Often on weekends Tony May, the perfect congenial host, stops by every table, greeting regulars and newcomers alike.

title: Minor-League Baseball
description: Can New Jersey support the six minor-league baseball teams that will be playing this season?

title: April 12-18; Yeah, Sure, I Do the Ironing
description: Women's lib? As in liberated to work all day, then come home and mop the floor, change the diapers and cook the pasta while the male of the species vegges out in front of the tube? Sounds like a pretty raw deal for the American female, but is it an outdated image? Perhaps.

title: A Storied Sports Car, on the Road Again
description: AS the home of a well-known auto race track, Lime Rock has grown accustomed to roaring engines, dented sheet metal, burning rubber and wild maneuvers by drivers risking it all to cross the finish line first. But few local racing enthusiasts can say they have witnessed anything that compares to the gamble undertaken by the Cunningham Company.

title: With 2 Takes on One Tale, Sinn Fein Chief Bargains
description: In the week since the announcement of a Northern Ireland peace agreement, Gerry Adams, leader of the Irish Republican Army's political wing, Sinn Fein, has taken two quite different approaches with different Roman Catholic political groups in order to win their support for the agreement in next month's referendum.

title: In the Region/New Jersey; Fuji the Latest Addition to Bustling Raritan Center
description: BY next January a patch of land in the 2,300-acre Raritan Center business park in Edison will be transformed into the Northeast regional office and distribution center for Fuji Photo Film U.S.A., ushering in a new stage of growth for the giant park, and by extension, the city and that area of Middlesex County.

title: Aim High
description: Next weekend in Albuquerque, N.M., several hundred sci-fi fans, retired astronauts and ''space lawyers'' will gather for United Societies in Space Inc.'s 1998 ''countdown conference.'' Since 1992, U.S.I.S. -- a Denver-based group dedicated to creating a human space colony -- has been counting down to a big event it has scheduled for the year 2000: a three-day ''constitutional convention'' in Mile High Stadium to solidify plans for a new society in space, a ''Metanation.''

title: In Pursuit of Gold
description: They're back, and badder than ever. In DALLAS: THE WAR OF THE EWINGS, the clan of ''Dallas,'' CBS's long-running nighttime soap -- wily J.R.; his ex-wife, Sue Ellen, and his younger brother, Bobby (Larry Hagman, Linda Gray and Patrick Duffy) -- are geared up to divide and conquer, with oil at the root of the evil. So what's new? This time around, Bobby and Sue Ellen are manning Ewing Oil, while J.R., just not satisfied at the helm of competitor Weststar, schemes and manipulates to reclaim the family fortune for himself. Will he succeed? Not if an assailant out for blood hits his mark. It's enough to get even a rotten man down -- FRIDAY at 9 P.M. on CBS. Kathryn Shattuck

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EMANUEL, ELIAS
description: EMANUEL-Elias. West End Temple, Neponsit, NY, mourns the death of a dedicated long-time member. The Elias and Pauline Emanuel Library of the Temple indicates our respect of him. We join with his wife Pauline, son Matthew, and family in sorrow. Rabbi Joseph I. Weiss Sylvan Klein, President

title: SOAPBOX; Auto Insurance Reform Is Far Away
description: BURIED deep in the statutes of New Jersey is a little-known but very important clause that reveals the true power of the insurance industry and its control of state government. The curious clause helps explain why New Jersey suffers with the highest auto insurance rates in the nation.

description: THANK goodness for Jim Brown and the cap. That's all I could say after the little love fest last week in President Clinton's Town Hall meeting on race and sports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHAR, DIANE S.
