Devoted aunt of Sam and David. Treasured friend of the hundreds of lives she touched. Our bright light has gone out. Services Beth Israel, Delray Beach, FL, 561499-8000. Memorial service pending.

title: INVESTING WITH: Brian S. Posner; Warburg Pincus Growth and Income Fund
description: IF sheer assets were the benchmark for success in the fund business, then the move of Brian S. Posner to Warburg Pincus Asset Management would have been a humbling one.

title: A Calling for Care Of the Terminally Ill
description: AS Ellen Marks told her story, Florence Wald listened quietly, occasionally offering advice. The women sat side by side inside the medical unit at the York Correctional Institution in Niantic where Ms. Marks is an inmate. In the past three years, she has survived uterine and lung cancer. Her cancer has gone into remission, she told Mrs. Wald, but she has not heard from her children in years and her nearest relatives live on Cape Cod. Because of her health, she said, she hopes the Correction Department will release her under a policy called compassionate leave.

title: Fire Seriously Damages a Harlem Building
description: A building that houses a Harlem sporting goods shop was badly damaged yesterday in a suspicious fire three days after an angry customer warned an employee that the store would be gone soon, the police said.

title: New Museum Honors American P.O.W.'s
description: A museum honoring the 800,000 Americans ever held as prisoners of war -- from the Revolution to the Persian Gulf war -- opened this month in Georgia, near Andersonville, the Civil War prison camp.

title: Spano Cites Goals Met and Ahead
description: HIS goal for Westchester, he says, is a ''quiet renaissance,'' but Andrew J. Spano's first State of the County speech as County Executive, in contrast, was anything but quiet.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  MAYER, LAWRENCE MICHAEL
description: MAYER-Lawrence Michael. Dearest son, miss you more and love you more each day, especially on your birthday. Love, Mother

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CLOPTON, BENJAMIN H.
description: CLOPTON-Benjamin H. Died of AIDS on April 16, 1998. Ben is survived by his loving partner, Keith Pajkowski of Manhattan, his loving parents Ned and Marcia Clopton of Chevy Chase, MD., and his brothers Bryan, Geoffrey and Marc. Mr. Clopton, a painter and sculptor, lived in Manhattan for 15 years. Class of '67 Bethesda-Chevy Chase High School in Maryland and Class of '73 University of Maryland, College Park where he earned a BFA. Memorial service at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue at East 50 Street, 2 P.M. Monday, April 20. Reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to NY Episcopal Diocese AIDS Committee, C/O St. Bartholomew's.

title: Crime
description: Peter Bowen's strange, seductive mysteries are set in the cattle-ranching country of eastern Montana, where the major scenic attraction is ''a whole lot of nothing.'' The earthquake that hits this lonesome land in THUNDER HORSE (St. Martin's, $22.95) rearranges the monotonous topography by lifting mountains, shooting out fresh springs and heaving up two long-buried treasures -- a dinosaur tooth and some skeletons of an ancient race known to local Indians as the Horned Star People. When the Indians start fighting over the bones and rival archeologists start slugging it out over the dinosaur, the restoration of the peace falls to Gabriel Du Pre, a part-Indian lawman with a mystical attachment to his ancestral past and its legends.

title: Katherine Feldman, Stephen Davies
description: Katherine Anne Feldman, an instructor in veterinary medicine at Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y., and Stephen John Davies, a veterinary student at Cornell, are to be married today at the Waterfowl Pavilion of the Baltimore Zoo. The Rev. Jarrett T. Wicklein, a United Methodist minister, is to perform the ceremony.

title: Yale Regains Title
description: Yale's varsity heavyweight crew recaptured the Blackwell Cup yesterday in Philadelphia, defeating Pennsylvania, last year's winner, and Columbia, which finished third. Yale's victory was its fourth Blackwell Cup victory in the last five years.

title: Claire Keating, Joseph Strupp
description: Claire Keating, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John C. Keating of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church to Joseph Strupp, a son of Margo Strupp of Summit, N.J., and James Strupp of New York. Msgr. Edward Howley performed the ceremony, in which the Rev. Bonnie Vegiard, a Unitarian minister, participated.

title: Jordan (Who Else?) Torments Knicks in Finale
description: Somewhere along the way, the Bulls and the Knicks found meaning in a game that had the impact of a feather on the outcome of the regular season.

title: Buyers Finding Smaller Inventory of Homes for Sale
description: TWO years of unrelenting buyer demand has reduced the inventory of homes for sale throughout the New York metropolitan area.

title: Togetherness
description: To the Editor: I read ''Setting the Tone for Togetherness'' (March 29) hoping to see if someone had found another wonderful place to take the entire family. At the end, the author, the late Richard F. Shepard, says ''Tell me, is there somewhere in between?'' Kutsher's and Grafton, Vt.

title: Herbs: So Easy to Grow, And So Full of Flavor
description: THERE is nothing like having fresh basil leaves to snip from the garden for pesto, or being able to clip a few stems of mint when brewing iced tea.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  ASKENASE, DAVID
description: ASKENASE-David (My Dad). Today is your 97th birthday. Memories of You, Mother, and Irwin are my most treasured possessions.

title: Another Practitioner Of Circumcision
description: The article ''Female Practitioner of Circumcision in a Male World'' (March 8) was very educational. However, the quote ''Dr. Greenbaum believes she is the only one on Long Island'' may not be accurate. My daughter, Natalie Lampert Sohn, an obstetrician-gynecologist now in practice in Florida, was trained as a mohelet and performed in this capacity on Long Island before she left for Florida over a half a year ago.

title: Fight in Bronx Leaves One Dead and Four Hurt
description: One man was killed and four others were wounded when an argument outside a Bronx social club early yesterday turned into a battle with guns and knives, the police said. Three men were arrested after the melee.

description: The nation's trade deficit rose to $12.1 billion in February, its highest level in a decade, as American exports to Japan plummeted.

title: For Now, Bulls Trying To Keep It Together

Scream and bow when his name is announced. This could be the last time Michael Jordan misses a left-handed free throw in a regular-season game.

title: PBS's Newest Sleuth Is an Amateur
description: NEXT to Comdr. Adam Dalgleish, the poet-detective of Scotland Yard, Cordelia Gray may seem innocent and even naive, more of an amateur than a fully trained professional. P. D. James -- Baroness James of Holland Park -- introduced Cordelia in the 1973 mystery novel ''An Unsuitable Job for a Woman'' as someone who has ''no qualifications or relevant past experience'' to be a private detective, and added that she has ''no capital, except for her slight but tough 22-year-old body.'' Once on the (unsuitable) job, however, she learns very quickly.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FALKENSTEIN, MARGARET (HOLUB, NEE NEUBERGER)
description: FALKENSTEIN-Margaret (Holub, nee Neuberger). Died April 14, age 91. Beloved wife of Henry. Mother of Harriet, Martin (deceased). Loving grandmother of Mark, Thomas, Cindy, Richard (deceased), Howard, and Noah. Past president of True Sister Minerva Lodge 25. Employee of New York Exchange for Women. Shiva: April 19, 640 W. 239th St. Riverdale, NY.

title: Reece Zeitzer, Andrew Spivack
description: Reece Jamie Zeitzer, a daughter of Linda Seitzer and Melvyn L. Seitzer of Forest Hills, Queens, is to be married this afternoon to Andrew Keith Spivack, a son of Stefanie K. Spivack and Dr. Jerome Spivack of Watchung, N.J. Rabbi Charles Kroloff is to officiate at the 200 Fifth Club in Manhattan.

title: Style; History in the Unmaking
description: Among the latest fashions in academic discourse is a new pursuit called counterfactual history, which explores what might have happened if a single fact had been otherwise and thereby changed the course of events. What if the Spanish Armada had triumphed after all? What if the fog that blanketed the East River one night in August 1776 had cleared before George Washington escaped from the British troops? Sweeping developments that we now take for granted turn out to have hinged on a random occurrence or on the action of a single individual. Counterfactualists contend that any particular outcome appears inevitable only in retrospect, and that simply by imagining a different set of circumstances, we come to what Philip E. Tetlock, a professor at Ohio State University, has called ''a more sophisticated appreciation of causation.''

title: Rufus, Son of Loudon, and His Take on Love
description: AT the age of 24, Rufus Wainwright is tall and lanky, with long, pointed sideburns shaped like knife blades. The songs he sings on his remarkably assured, beguiling debut album, ''Rufus Wainwright,'' have their sharp points. They also have a creamy melodicism that draws as much from Tin Pan Alley classicism as they do from Randy Newman, Joni Mitchell and Tim Buckley -- rock's more idiosyncratic wing of singer-songwriterdom.

title: Turkey Doubles Visa Fee for Americans
description: Turkey has raised its fee for a visa to $45 from $20. The change took effect Feb. 1, said Yasemin Aktas, a spokeswoman for the Turkish Government Tourist Office in New York, as a response to a United States increase (on the same day, United States fees also rose to $45 from $20). The Turkish fee may be paid in cash or with a money order, but not by credit card or check. Visitors must leave their passports at a consulate for 48 hours for the visa. According to Ms. Aktas, the visa may also be obtained on the spot on arrival in Turkey. Turkish Consulate, 821 United Nations Plaza, Fifth Floor, 46th Street; (212) 949-0160.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article last Sunday about heroin use in the suburbs misstated the origins of the drug. title: Steal This Burger

Or forget the 50's. If we could just go back 15 years, to a time when McDonald's and Burger King were both growing domestically at a corn-in-July rate and it seemed possible that the American appetite for burgers, fries and Cokes was so insatiable that as long as you kept building quick-service hamburger restaurants, new customers would appear. Anything to escape from the boxers' clinch of today, as the expansion of the fast-food hamburger category slows and it becomes increasingly obvious that the only way for McDonald's or Burger King to sell more food is to steal the other guy's customers. ''We are fighting for crumbs in this industry,'' Steven Kent, an analyst at Goldman Sachs, observes. ''The industry right now is in a state of aggravated competition, because the unit count has grown so high.''

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; A Deep and Distant Time
description: Throughout Anjana Appachana's first novel, we are reminded to pay careful attention to the voices of the women who speak in its pages -- Padma and her daughter, Mallika; Padma's sister, Shanta; her mother, Rukmini; and her confiding neighbors, Madhu and Anuradha. Each of the female characters in LISTENING NOW (Random House, $25) recounts her own version of Padma's ill-fated liaison with her college lover, Karan, and its bitter consequences. Thirteen years after his disappearance, Karan remains a haunting, riddling figure in the lives of Padma and their daughter. ''In that deep and distant time,'' Mallika recalls, ''there lived in my house my permanently stricken mother, my mother's vivacious, laughing sister, and my absent father, whose presence in our house was shaped by my grieving mother's awful silence. Our house was like a well, holding his absence and her silence, and within those waters, my story began.'' In an eloquent interweaving of perspectives, Appachana's novel revisits the wrenching episodes at the heart of Padma's ''awful silence'' before erupting in ''the unrelenting heat of one revelation, and then another, and yet another.'' Blending emotional depth with elements of melodrama reminiscent of popular Indian films, Appachana succeeds in drawing us deep into this complex vision of shattered happiness and withered dreams. At the same time, she convincingly portrays the strains on women in modern India -- confined by their extended families, diminished and betrayed by the men they look to for security. Ultimately, the reader is compelled, like Karan, to lean in close and truly hear Padma's sad, assailing voice -- and, in the process, discover how cruelly both their lives have been misshapen. Anderson Tepper

title: For Compotes, Crumbles and Fools

Indeed, until the 17th century, rhubarb was considered an ornamental plant, with roots that were used as a medicine. The wide, frilly leaves are, in fact, toxic (they contain oxalic acid), and the idea of eating the stalks did not catch on until the 19th century. Even then, it was chiefly in northern Europe that the stalks captured the imagination of cooks, who made them into jams and jellies, desserts, or a sauce to go with meat and even fish.

Clure Morton, a retired Federal chief judge in Tennessee who furthered racial integration in Nashville's public schools and prompted reforms in the state's mental health, welfare and prison systems, died on April 11 at the University of Tennessee Hospital in his native Knoxville. He was 82 and lived in Nashville.

title: Visitors From a Land of Sons and Dottirs
description: LAUFEY SIGURDARDOTTIR, 31 years old and mother of five, had to show her driver's license for identification one day at a Connecticut store. She says the sales clerk looked the license over and obviously drew a blank on the geography. ''Is that a state?'' the clerk asked. No, she was informed. ''Well, where is it?'' the clerk said.

title: What's a Few Bloodstains? It's an Apartment!
description: It has long been a not-so-well-kept secret that there is, among New Yorkers, a certain ghoulish, opportunistic element who, seeking better habitat, has been known to peruse the obituary pages in search of a freshly vacated living space.

title: A Human Face for Hong Kong's Identity Crisis
description: IN an early scene of Wayne Wang's new movie, ''Chinese Box,'' which was filmed on location in Hong Kong last year during the final months of 156 years of British rule, a woman's voice rises from the crowd on a bustling street. ''Hi! I've got some goodies for you!'' she says with the smug inflection of a car salesman. ''Hey guys! Rolexes, Dunhill lighters!'' It is a voice that is neither purely Chinese nor English, but resonant of both. ''Come on, a bargain! Hundred dollars!''

title: Drop in Asian Travelers Affects Tourism in U.S.
description: THE economic malaise that broke out in Asia last fall has helped make much of that continent a bargain basement for American travelers. But the conditions that have made Asia such a good value for visitors portend bad news for the tourist industries of Hawaii, California, Australia and New Zealand. And the ripple effects, mainly the tighter grip that Asian visitors will keep on purse strings, are expected to be felt from the casinos of Las Vegas to the Mall of America in Bloomington, Minn.

title: Multiple Exposure
description: I was pleased to discover, in James Barron's Lives column ''Multiple Exposure'' (March 29), that others have bonded with absolute strangers whose names, nonetheless, they know as well as their own. It was difficult to accept that my parents' grasp of nomenclature lacked originality, but in time I got used to my doppelgangers. For years, while Mike O'Neill was a Daily News editor, I rested on his laurels, among former classmates with whom I had lost touch but who, during our undergraduate years, had pegged me for a successful journalism career. More recently, I have been besieged with phone calls, letters, club invitations and messenger deliveries for Michael O'Neill, a photographer who, judging by the offers my voice mail receives, pulls in the kind of money that makes me wish I had paid more attention back in camera club.

title: How to Stay a Titan
description: On May 15, 1911, in a soft voice that belied the supreme drama of the moment, Chief Justice Edward White read aloud a 20,000-word opinion, ordering the breakup of Standard Oil for violating the antitrust laws. Thus ended a morality play that had riveted America for five years, ever since Teddy Roosevelt's trustbusters decided to teach the trust and its founder, John D. Rockefeller, a lesson in corporate citizenship.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: PANDORA New Tales of the Vampires. By Anne Rice. Knopf, $19.95.

title: Executioner's Song
description: Saints and Villains

title: Facing West on China's Silk Road
description: THE train left Xian late on a warm evening last August, rocking gently past the Ming Dynasty city wall. The ancient wall was the last thing I saw before going to bed, and then in the morning, we were in the dry loess hills of southern Gansu Province, where steep terraced slopes crumbled away into dusty gorges. There were walls here, too -- simple walls of packed earth that formed neat rectangles around tile-roofed houses. But something in the rugged landscape made the walls seem desperate in comparison with the grandeur of the Xian city wall.

title: Colleen O'Rourke and Philip Carson
description: Colleen Louise O'Rourke, a banker, and Philip Carson, a recording executive, were married on Friday at the Miramar Hotel in Montecito, Calif. The Rev. C. D. Franklin, a nondenominational minister, officiated.

title: Confusing Deities
description: To the Editor:

title: The Eccentric Lives Of the Edie Beales Gets New Viewing
description: SOME houses are haunted, but Grey Gardens simply haunts. Located where Lily Pond Lane meets West End Road in prime south-of-the-highway East Hampton, the 28-room mansion was home to Big and Little Edie Beale, mother-daughter extraordinaire, aunt and cousin respectively of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis and her sister Lee Radziwill, who used to live down the road at Lasata.

title: April 12-18; Doctors' Incomes Surge
description: Ever see a doctor standing on a street corner with a sign saying, ''Will do surgery for food''? Didn't think so. ''There's virtually zero unemployment among doctors,'' said David Gans, survey director of the Medical Group Management Association, ''but they are working harder.''

description: DIANA BUCHANAN, who plans to marry in August, spent much of last week in and out of linen shops on the Upper East Side that sell what might be called the Rolls-Royces of sheets.

description: SEEING LIKE A STATE How Certain Schemes to Improve the Human Condition Have Failed. By James C. Scott. Illustrated. 445 pp. New Haven: Yale University Press. $35.

title: Terry Sanford, Pace-Setting Governor in 60's, Dies at 80
description: Terry Sanford, who lowered racial barriers as Governor of North Carolina in the 1960's, setting the style for a new kind of Southern politician, and later became a United States Senator and Presidential candidate, died today at his home in Durham, N.C. He was 80.

description: SHNEYER-Hedy. 76, of Delray Beach, FL, died April 17, 1998. Activist, writer and good friend to many. Lifelong companion to William Shneyer. Survived by loving children Paul (Laura) and Hannah (Joel), grandchildren Elana and Danya, and beloved family members Sue, Evy, Jeanne, Gail and Howard. Services at Riverside Memorial Chapel, Amsterdam at 76th St., New York, NY, Tuesday, April 21, at 11 AM.

title: Asia Lures Travelers With Bargains
description: ASIA'S recent economic woes have made much of that region a bargain again, with air fares, hotel rates and package tours lower than they have been in years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MACGREGOR, IAN K.
description: MacGREGOR-Ian K. The partners of McFarland Dewey & Co. mourn the loss of their beloved friend and partner Ian K. MacGregor.

title: Celebrities In a Cloud Of Scent
description: THE invitation suggested scintillating and mixed company: ''Ron Silver! Duchess Sarah Ferguson! Shoshanna Lonstein!'' (She's already experienced her last episode of ''Seinfeld.'') There was also the promise of a spectacular skyline, incredible vistas, rarely seen aeries in a famous building.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOENIG, IRVING
description: KOENIG-Irving. August 2, 1919April 15, 1998. We mourn the loss of our beloved husband, father, brother and grandfather, CPA, attorney and World War II veteran, caring, generous, witty, passionate in his beliefs, honorable in business and in personal affairs. Leah Koenig (wife), Karen Schochet and Anne Koenig (daughters), Hattie Feit and Daisy Berman (sisters), Avraham Zvi and Elisheva Rachel (grandchildren), and many other in-laws, nieces and nephews. Shiva at his home following the holiday.

title: Swamp Dreams
description: THE MEADOWLANDS

title: Lori Guthart, Jeffrey Lesser
description: Lori Michele Guthart, a daughter of Marlene and Michael Guthart of Scottsdale, Ariz., is to be married tonight to Jeffrey Alan Lesser, a son of Marilyn Lesser and Dr. Milton Lesser of Fresh Meadows, Queens. Rabbi Morton Gordon, the bridegroom's uncle, will perform the ceremony at the Jericho (N.Y.) Jewish Center.

title: What Is British Music?
description: WHAT is British about British music? We might better be able to answer the question if we heard more of the stuff, but apart from the operas of Benjamin Britten, which have a solid place in the American repertory, not much British music gets across the Atlantic.

title: Bankers' Credo: Bigger Is Better
description: Only a week after Sanford I. Weill of Travelers Group and John S. Reed of Citicorp announced plans to merge their companies into the world's largest financial services concern, some of the biggest names in banking joined the trend toward gargantuan institutions.

title: In the Age of Supertitles, A Place for Opera in English
description: THE Kirov Opera's 17-day residency at the Metropolitan Opera, beginning on Thursday, figures to be a high point of the current musical season. The repertory consists of four Russian operas little known in the United States: Glinka's ''Ruslan and Ludmila,'' Borodin's ''Prince Igor,'' Tchaikovsky's ''Mazeppa'' and Prokofiev's ''Betrothal in a Monastery.'' And the venerable St. Petersburg company, long sheltered from homogenizing international influences by Soviet seclusion, lives and breathes these works, two of which -- the Borodin and the Prokofiev -- had their premieres at the Kirov's own Maryinsky Theater.

title: A Therapist's Silence And Another's Crime
description: Four months after admitting in therapy to being a pedophile, Dr. Joseph DeMasi, a child psychiatrist, molested a 10-year-old boy at a Connecticut hospital. A lawsuit filed by the boy's family claims that Dr. DeMasi's therapist should have taken action after the confession.

title: 'Cinderella,' Musical, At Library
description: THIS is National Library Week, so it seems appropriate to call attention to four concerts this afternoon and two others later in the week being held at libraries. At 1:30, ''Cinderella'' loses her slipper and finds true love in a musical for children at the North Castle Library in Armonk. The Open Stage production is said to update the story as a hip musical with live accompaniment.

title: Linda Jordan, Stephen Willard
description: Linda Christin Jordan and Stephen Hopkins Willard were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in Washington. The Rev. Luis Leon performed the ceremony.

title: Latin America Fears Stagnation in Trade Talks With U.S.
description: President Clinton and 33 other leaders from the Western Hemisphere opened talks here today aimed at making good on their commitment four years ago to create a free-trade zone stretching from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego.

title: 2 Newspapers Share Office; Probleme? Nyet!
description: On the surface, it seems an odd coupling. Sharing a single, cramped office in the Actors Equity Building at 46th Street and Broadway are two vastly different newspapers serving two distinct communities.

title: Habitats/23 East 10th Street; 2 Physicians Find a Home And Then Doctor It Up
description: JOANNE MAGRO and Christopher Dennis, young physicians in the middle of their medical residencies, had a goal and a budget.

title: Honoring Artists of the National Academy
description: THAT Andrew Johnson fulfilled his term as 17th President of the United States was to the credit of his Attorney-General, William Maxwell Evarts, who defended him against impeachment with a Senatorial address that lasted 12 hours. As filibusters go, this hardly compares with the current Presidential trial by media, but it seems to have inspired Jared B. Flagg's portrait of Evarts, painted in the 1880's and now in New York State's Court of Appeals in Albany. With one hand tucked in his coat, the subject, who looks remarkably like George C. Scott, stands alone in architectural space evidently in the act of addressing his invisible and doubtless comatose audience.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRODSKY, ANDREW
description: BRODSKY-Andrew. In his 79th year. On April 16th, at his home, after a long illness. Beloved husband of Sivia, loving father of Ann and Greg, father-in-law of Bob and Leigh Anne, devoted grandfather of Allison, Daniel and Jake. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, April 19, 12:30PM at Congregation Emanu-El at 5th Avenue and 65th Street.

title: Nurses and Maimonides Medical Center Reach Tentative Deal to End a 3-Week Strike
description: Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn and the New York State Nurses Association have reached a tentative agreement to end a three-week strike prompted in part by a proposal for shift changes for some nurses, officials on both sides said yesterday.

title: Melissa Bonney, Bennet Ratcliff
description: Melissa Lee Mary Bonney, the press secretary of the Democratic National Committee, and Bennet Clifford Ratcliff, the senior vice president of Squier Knapp Ochs & Dunn Communications, political media consultants, both in Washington, were married there last evening. The Rev. Louise Lusignan performed the ceremony at St. Columba's Episcopal Church.

title: Schubert Praised Salieri. Why Don't We?
description: MANY of us can recall a time, not so long ago, when music history was taught in terms of periods and styles, and the Classical style was defined by the music of only three composers, each rather atypical in his way. According to this telling, Haydn, Mozart and Beethoven were the only musicians to grasp what the music historian Charles Rosen called ''the coherence of the musical language.''

title: Commercial Property/North Bergen, N.J.; Work Begins on a 350,000-Sq.-Ft. Retail Center
description: THE site should have been a retailer's dream: Seventeen acres atop a rocky slope in the Hudson County community of North Bergen, N.J., visible to drivers along the Route 3-Route 495 corridor on the way to or from the Lincoln Tunnel, just over a mile away.

title: The Big City; Civil Obedience
description: When mayor giuliani announced his campaign to introduce civility into New York, he was promptly greeted with Bronx cheers. New Yorkers proclaimed their historic right to be rude and insisted that this is too tough a town for anyone to tame. But there is now startling evidence that New Yorkers can be polite, thanks to some fieldwork I conducted under the guidance of Antanas Mockus, a pioneer of urban civility.

title: The South Shore Estuary Gets Impetus to Improve
description: FROM the Atlantic Beach Bridge in the west to the far eastern reaches of Shinnecock Bay in Southampton, Long Island's 70-mile-long South Shore estuary is hard to overlook.

title: The View From/Larchmont; Tulips and Roses Signal New Gardening Season
description: LAST weekend, John and Molly Evans were at Tony's Nursery, strolling among the azaleas. That is a lot of strolling, because at this time of year at the six-acre establishment on Boston Post Road here, there are 10,000 azalea plants in 60 varieties.

title: The Richer Rich, and Where They Live
description: CONSIDER: The income of the top 1 percent of Americans, or about 2.6 million people, now equals that of the bottom one-third of the population -- or 88 million people.

title: Liberties; We're NOT Worse Than Lawyers
description: Reporters are cowering at the imminent arrival of their very own Godzilla, Steven Brill.

title: Car Rental Fees: Adding Them Up
description: YVONNE FREUND of Bellevue, Wash., rented a Thrifty car in Los Angeles in January and her charges included a ''license fee'' of $5.35 for her seven-day rental. Ms. Freund, a retired picture researcher, asked Thrifty about this fee and was told that California had authorized car-rental companies to charge an extra amount to recover what they paid to license the car. In the case of Ms. Freund's rented Neon, the license fee came to about 76 cents a day.

title: Checking Medicine's Vital Signs
description: Three jumbo jets crashing every two days. If the airlines killed that many people annually, public outrage would close them overnight. Hospitals kill that many patients every year because of missed diagnoses, medication mishaps and other preventable errors. Yet there's hardly a whimper of protest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DARLING, ROBERT C., M.D.
description: DARLING-Robert C., M.D. The faculty and staff of the Department of Rehabilitation Medicine, College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University mourn the passing of Dr. Darling on April 13, 1998 and extend our condolences to his family. Dr. Darling was the first Simon Baruch Professor of Rehabilitation Medicine at P&S and contributed greatly to the scientific and academic aspects of Physical Medicine. At the request of the family, gifts may be made to the Robert C. Darling Library, 212-305-5954.

description: Michael Massing provided an excellent account of the influential and largely effective lobbying efforts of the alcohol industry (''Strong Stuff,'' March 22). Sadly, some of these groups push the bounds of responsibility in promoting their product, endangering the public's health in the process.

title: 30 Years After Battle, Uneasy Truce on Heights
description: IF Harlem were flat, the yawning distance between Morningside Avenue and Morningside Drive would seem small -- a few dozen yards. But from 116th Street and Morningside Avenue, where West Harlem ends, you ascend 161 steep steps past green gum wrappers, purple Bic lighters and white plastic syringes to Morningside Drive, the beginning of the Columbia University campus, known to local people outside the university as ''up the hill,'' or ''the folks with the money,'' or, simply, ''those people.''

description: REMEMBER the thrill of first riding a bicycle without training wheels? Does that first ride free of Dad's steady hand or the security of training wheels remain exciting?

title: Child Abuse On Internet Heightens Vigilance
description: TO educators and parents, the news reports were disquieting: a tenured fourth-grade teacher with more than 25 years in the Yonkers school system was indicted earlier this month for sexually molesting students; another tenured elementary school teacher in Scarsdale was sentenced to more than seven years in Federal prison for sending child pornography over the Internet.

title: Doctors and Risks Of Dangerous Pastimes
description: Regarding your March 29 article on Dr. Michael Burt [''The Death of a Brilliant Surgeon Who Lived in the Fast Lane''], I do not think that there is any great mystery as to why he tragically died in the motorcycle accident.

title: Nets Hobble Into Season's Biggest Game
description: They emerged from the practice facility one by one today. Jayson Williams was first, stalking out with his right hand still encased in a protective cast. Then Sam Cassell came, moving gingerly and cautiously, navigating the stairs one at a time, stopping, then trying the next one. Michael Cage stayed behind longer than most, seemingly trying to wish his way onto the court, but admitting that he probably could not.

title: Another Insult to Immigrants
description: Trent Lott, the Senate majority leader, and Senator Phil Gramm are holding up a floor vote on a conference bill that could restore food stamps for 250,000 legal immigrants, ameliorating the most odious remaining provision of the 1996 welfare law. The law removed the only federally guaranteed support program for immigrants, stripping food stamps from about 800,000 of them. In New York State alone, the law has driven 140,000 immigrants into soup kitchens and other desperate measures.

title: April 12-18; Roth and Graham Among Pulitzer Prize Winners
description: George Gershwin, Katharine Graham and Philip Roth might not have much else in common, but they all won 1998 Pulitzer Prizes.

Festival organizers, filmmakers and cast members mingled with independent film executives and V.I.P.'s on the prowl for fresh young talent. The 20-to-30-somethings in the crowd talked with a mix of youthful passion and idealism.

title: They Kept Lawns Green And Children Squealing
description: THE lawn, the grassy carpet that makes the home presentable, is in jeopardy. It used to be an open invitation to a raft of sprouting sprinklers and neighborhood children. Today's high fences and decks have turned the lawn into a more private domain.

title: Information, Please
description: Caryn James's column ''Information, Please'' (Culture Zone, March 29), on the realism of television medical dramas, reminded me of an E.R.'' episode. The young Dr. Carter diagnosed an illness that I had had and that my own doctors couldn't identify for nine harrowing months. During much of that time, I was bedridden and my lungs filled with fluid. Every breath was an effort.

title: A Tenor With a Talent for Friendship, Too
description: THIS afternoon in Montclair, Robert White, the tenor, plays host to another gathering of his musical friends. That is, he will tell engaging anecdotes about his personal connections to the myriad songs he sings, accompanied by cherished colleagues. Today's include the pianists Samuel Sanders and Stephen Hough, the flutist Carol Wincenc and the cellist Eugene Moye. The public is invited, and embraced.

title: Low-Rise Residents Fight Commodities Tower Plan
description: From a Greenwich Avenue rooftop Bernard D'Orazio watched the sun ambling toward New Jersey on a Wednesday afternoon. Just beneath him was the L-shaped asphalt parking lot between Murray and Warren Streets, where he wants to see a park, not a commodities exchange building.

title: What's Ahead for Ocean Beach?
description: OCEAN BEACH PARK in New London was glamorous in the 1940's. Vacationers from Hartford and from Springfield, Mass., rented cottages and rooms near the beach, known for its fine-grained sand and spectacular views of Long Island Sound. Visitors strolled on the boardwalk and in the evening danced to the music of the big bands in the recreation hall.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KUCHLER, IRA
description: KUCHLER-Ira. 90, of Rockville Centre and West Palm Beach, FL, on April 17, 1998. A noted Long Island architect, whose work consisted of designing both commercial and residential buildings. He was a graduate of Boys High School (Brooklyn) and New York University School of Architecture. Mr. Kuchler, born and raised in Ogden, UT, moved with his family to Brooklyn, NY, in 1921. Married to Victoria Reba for 58 wonderful years, he is survived by daughters Merle Gross of Oceanside, NY, and Janine Rubens of Tucson, AZ, eight grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren. Services Sunday, April 19, 1998, at Gutterman's, 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY, at 10 AM. Interment Beth Moses, Pinelawn. Shiva to follow in Oceanside, NY.

title: On Language; Weapons Of Mass Destruction
description: ''Weapons of mass destruction has become the stock phrase in describing Saddam Hussein's threat,'' Jack Gescheidt of San Francisco writes. ''Is this some sort of shorthand for 'chemical and biological agents'? Does it include 'delivery systems' like missiles, or exclude weapons everyone else has, like conventional bombs? And where does this infectious phrase come from?''

title: Ulster Peace Accord Wins Backing of Protestant Party
description: Northern Ireland's largest political party, the Ulster Unionists, beat back growing internal opposition today and voted to support the week-old peace agreement aimed at settling decades of violent struggle between the British province's two principal religious groups.

description: New York Medical College in Valhalla and Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan are taking part in a clinical study of a new cancer drug called Onconase, thought to be useful combating two of the most deadly forms of cancer -- pancreatic and malignant mesothelioma (asbestos exposure).

title: 'And What Is Your Educational Background?'
description: To hear the folks in human resources tell it, interviews bring out the oddest behavior in some applicants. The fund will support mid-career fellowships for journalists from other countries studying at the university or American journalists studying international affairs. Gifts can be made to the University of Michigan, noting their purpose for the Prager fund and sent to the Michigan Journalism Fellows, 620 Oxford Road, Ann Arbor, Michigan 48104.

description: An advocacy group has filed a Federal law suit accusing the state of failing to provide Federally mandated voter registration services at its seven psychiatric hospitals.

description: ON the corners where the women sell sex, there was talk for a week or so about a john or two or three who might turn out to be a killer.

title: Retired Businessmen Offer Start-Up Seminar
description: ''I KNEW my business, but I didn't know anything about starting a business, so I went to Score,'' said Mario Portillo, president of Digital Entertainment Systems in Congers. ''They gave me counseling and hands-on advice about starting my own business. They not only became my mentors but provided me with teams of marketing, legal, financial and advertising pundits, which are invaluable to a new entrepreneur like myself.''

description: WHILE many antiques exhibitions take place in armories and gymnasiums, the Southport-Westport Antiques Show is held in the converted barns of the Fairfield County Hunt Club.

title: Exit Rangers, After a Season Only Masochists Will Want to Recall
description: The most emotional moment of the Rangers' wretched 1997-98 season was the triumphant visit of an opposing athlete. Not just any high-salaried superstar, he was Mark Messier, their former captain, whose memory haunted their entire schedule.

title: Colts Agonize to the End, Then Pick Manning
description: Sometime after midnight, in the early hours of yesterday morning, Leigh Steinberg, the agent for Washington State quarterback Ryan Leaf, got a telephone call from Jim Irsay, the Indianapolis Colts' owner. Irsay hinted that the Colts would probably select Tennessee quarterback Peyton Manning with the first pick in the National Football League draft, but it was not definite.

title: Welfare Rolls Cut by Seeking Child Support
description: An aggressive campaign by New York State to force delinquent parents to pay child support has helped move 120,000 women and children off the state's welfare rolls in the last three years, roughly 7 percent of all the people who have gone off welfare in that time, according to state officials.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKEIST, DR. IRVING
description: SKEIST-Dr. Irving. A talented polymer chemist, an accomplished musician, the founder and buiilder of a global consulting business, a writer, editor and speaker of clarity and humor, a patient teacher to siblings, his children, grandchildren, employees and customers. A loving husband to Dorothy. An understanding father to Judy and Ron, Robbie and Joan, Laurie and Ken, and Helen and Bill. A doting grandfather to Sarah, David, Sam, Miriam, Michael, Rick and Ariel. Respected and loved by his brother and sister-in-law, Merrill and Marian Skeist, and their children, Lisa, Avi, Barry, Destiny, Loren, Marlene, and all their grandchildren. His death creates a void in our family. In cherished memory, Merrill Skeist

title: County Was a Ski-Jump Destination

But winter sports people think it was equally famous as a Northeast ski-jumping area for two decades.

title: FM Mouse Roars at F.C.C.
description: Since late 1995, 88.7 FM has broadcast an odd assortment of radio entertainment to the Lower East Side, from a Monday night hard-rock show called ''Apocalyptic Themes for a Darker Future'' to a Saturday morning children's program whose deejays are in grade school.

The Rev. Charles A. Amstein performed the ceremony at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: When Garth Brooks Startled Everybody
description: By 1996, Garth Brooks began to strain under the pressure of living up to his image as a modern-day singing cowboy. The man who had redefined country music in the 1990's had become riddled with self-doubt. In a new book, ''Dreaming Out Loud: Garth Brooks, Wynonna Judd, Wade Hayes and the Changing Face of Nashville,'' Bruce Feiler uses these artists' stories to chronicle Nashville's rise to prominence against a background of social conservatism in America. In this excerpt, he describes what happened at the American Music Awards ceremony in 1996, when Mr. Brooks was up for the top honor.

title: Glittering Glass
description: The latest jewelry seen on fashionable wrists comes not from Paris or Madison Avenue but Mexico and Guatemala. Beaded-glass bracelets (above) by the Huichol Indians of Mexico have found their way to Manhattan via Fragments, a shop at 107 Greene Street (Prince Street). Janet Goldman, an owner, first saw them on a Hollywood costume designer, who referred her to the tribe. They cost $68, $88 and $118 at Fragments, which donates 10 percent of profits to the tribe, and $95 and $125 at Barneys New York. Rondi Cooler, YM magazine's fashion director, wears similar bracelets made by Mayan Indians in Guatemala for Dunitz & Company in Los Angeles. ''People ask me about them constantly,'' she said. The Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square (Columbus Avenue near 65th Street), sells narrow ones for $19. MARYELLEN GORDON

title: Q&A/Donald T. Meeker; Specialty of Making Sense of Road Signs
description: YOU are driving along a certain stretch of highway, not exactly sure where you are going. There is a sign up ahead, but it still remains a blur. Is it your exit? Should you get in the right-hand lane? If only they had made the sign larger, or somehow more discernable sooner.

title: Harvard Crew Upsets Princeton
description: The Harvard men's varsity crew rowed a typical race for the Crimson on the windy Charles River in Boston yesterday to upset undefeated Princeton in the Compton Cup. In the third 500-meter portion of the 2,000-meter race, the eight oarsmen powered through a small Princeton lead to take over and then win the race by four-tenths of a second, 6:12.5 to 6:12.9.

Adored grandfather of Nina, David, Laura and Jenny. Cherished brother of Leo and Blanche. Services on Sunday, April 19 at 10AM at Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, Long Island.

title: Gifted Choices of a Sort of Guest Curator in Stamford
description: ''NEW ART ANNUAL,'' the Stamford Museum and Nature Center's art competition, has an afterglow: The judge picks four top winners to share the gallery in an exhibition later in the year. This willingness to, in essence, put curatorial duties in the hands of an outsider is the unique twist of this contest, open to artists living in Connecticut and Westchester County.

description: Tariogh Noel Redmon and Robert Perry Crawford 3d were married yesterday at the Davis Memorial Presbyterian Church in Elkins, W.Va. The Rev. Dr. Thomas Jackson performed the ceremony.

title: Politics of Picking Up the Pieces
description: Recycling hardly seems the sexy stuff of political wrangling. But this is New York and times are good: a combination fertile as compost for making public policy political. At issue is why only 18 of the city's 59 community districts have weekly recycling collection, while in the other districts residents must store their paper, bottles and plastics for two weeks.

title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; Sowing the Seeds of Compassion
description: TODAY the garden soil that looked so unyielding all winter gives way under my feet. I arc my hoe down, biting into the scented soil, turning it over for the new crop. I am sweating, fired with ambition: beginner's mind, full of plans. But this spring I resolve to imagine less and accomplish more. My arms feel taut and powerful.

title: Better Make Mine a Double
description: So far, Richard Seed, the Chicago physicist who said he wanted to clone people, has only produced comic relief. But Lee Silver, a Princeton biologist and the author of ''Remaking Eden: Cloning and Beyond in a Brave New World,'' claims the race is not over. ''I am aware,'' he says, ''of people trying to do what Seed wants to do. But they work in silence.'' Silver won't name names, but we do know that at the Oregon Primate Research Center in Eugene, they're already trying to clone monkeys. If that happens . . . who knows? In the spirit of spreading angst, here are human-cloning possibilities -- some likely, some just weird speculation -- under discussion right now.

title: Indian Nations Wary of Restrictions on Tobacco
description: TO get to Chief Harry B. Wallace's Smoke Shop and Trading Post, you have to drive over the railroad tracks in Mastic and wind through a maze of suburban streets until you reach a dirt road on the Poospatuck Reservation.

title: Despise a Guy for 50 Years? Put Him in a Play
description: ROBERT BRUSTEIN, the eminent theatrical gadfly and artistic director of the American Repertory Theater here, never met Lee Strasberg (''Chekhov, I wanted to meet; Lee, never!''). But he still hates the master teacher with a passion, even though Strasberg has been dead for 16 years.

title: From 'Sorta Nowhere' to MTV Pantheon
description: After a grueling week of interviews, pop quizzes and a nationally televised popularity contest to pick MTV's newest on-air personality, the winner is: Jesse Camp, 18, from ''sorta nowhere and sorta everywhere.''

title: Crew Cuts Forever
description: THE first time, I was 10. The barber swept the black plastic edge of his clippers through my winter hair like a thresher through tall wheat. When he snapped the white apron away, I jumped down from the high chair, rubbed my hands against the bristles of my new crew cut and ran out to the street. There I felt the sun touch my scalp and my hair tingle electrically in the summer air. It was a sensuous ritual, a cleansing.

description: Draft day is all about the road traveled. And, sometimes, the twists and turns in a life are so revealing that in one of few instances, what you see is exactly what you get.

title: Growing Accustomed to the Kirov
description: IF, 10 years ago, one were to have chosen an operatic sister city for New York, it would hardly have been St. Petersburg, or more properly at that time, Leningrad. Yet Valery Gergiyev, the director of the Maryinsky Theater and its Kirov Opera in St. Petersburg, has now taken up semi-residence at the Metropolitan Opera, as principal guest conductor. (See The New York Times Magazine today for a related article on Mr. Gergiyev.) And increasingly in recent years, the Met and the Kirov have been drawn into a working partnership.

title: Union Leader Equates Workfare With Slavery
description: Stanley Hill, the leader of the city's largest municipal union, lashed out yesterday at the Giuliani administration's workfare program, equating it with slavery because, he said, it did not lead most of its participants to meaningful jobs.

title: The Widow's Run
description: The Irwin Gertzog statistic about widows winning their deceased husband's seats 84 percent of the time, versus only 14 percent for other first-time female candidates, was somewhat misleading (''The Widow's Run,'' by Frank Bruni, March 29). Since a widow running for her late husband's seat is obviously campaigning for an open seat (that is, no incumbent involved), it would be more appropriate to compare this high 84 percent figure with one for women running for other open seats, which, according to a recent study by the National Women's Political Caucus, is 48 percent for United States House seats and slightly over 50 percent for state legislative seats.

title: All Eyes Are on Europe
description: GOLD fund managers are anxiously waiting on a handful of bankers in Europe.

title: Valery Gergiev's Esthetic Brinkmanship
description: ''Don't write about this performance,'' Valery Gergiev commanded in his low-pitched rasp as our car threaded its way through the southern French city of Toulouse one day last November. ''Come and hear us again in St. Petersburg.'' Gergiev, artistic director and principal conductor of the Kirov Opera and easily the most-talked-about figure in international opera today, was on his way to conduct his company in Wagner's turbulent ''Flying Dutchman.'' It was music they had never played in public before. Indeed, two hours before show time, there were pages in the score the musicians had never played together at all.

title: In America; Ball Pork
description: The multipurpose stadium that Mayor Rudolph Giuliani wants to build for the Yankees on the West Side of Manhattan would cost $1.06 billion, according to a study commissioned by the city, the state and the Yankees.

title: Corrections
description: A review on page 20 of the Book Review today, about ''Looking for Trouble,'' by Leslie Cockburn, misstates several events in her life. Her Yale degree is in English, not anthropology; she tracked down the Khmer Rouge in Cambodia to produce a ''Peter Jennings Reporting'' program for ABC News, not for the CBS News program ''60 Minutes''; she investigated the issue of unsecured nuclear weapons in Russia as a writer for Vanity Fair magazine and as research for ''One Point Safe,'' a book she later wrote with Andrew Cockburn, not for television. She was a correspondent, not a producer, for the PBS program ''Frontline,'' though her new book says PBS's job offer included producing as well.

title: Asia on the Cheap
description: ROVING around Asia on and off for the past dozen years, I've occasionally caught a glimpse of what it must have been like in the days when you could traverse some of the most exotic countries on earth for a few bucks a day.

title: SHE SAID, THEY SAID
description: Claudine Woolf, a 28-year-old Northern Californian, claims she was muscled out of her senior sales position with Mary Kay cosmetics after breast cancer and pregnancy thwarted her ability to meet a monthly $4,000-to-$8,000 sales quota. In a recently filed civil suit, Woolf says she asked the Dallas-based cosmetics giant for a brief reprieve while she endured a mastectomy, chemotherapy and childbirth. Mary Kay higher-ups allegedly rebuked her and even whistled in a tow truck to reclaim a Kay lady's prized possession: the company car, in Woolf's case a bright red Pontiac Grand Am. Mary Kay has responded with a statement that illustrates why courts are so very necessary. Curiously, they say she wasn't fired at all and retains her position.

title: Backtalk; Myths and Matters of Race
description: Although many people felt President Clinton's Town Hall meeting last Tuesday in Houston on race in sports was largely superficial and unfocused (with the occasional insightful outburst), many commentators congratulated Clinton and ESPN for ''creating dialogue,'' and having the courage to address ''such critical issues.''

title: SOAPBOX; The Cafes That Ate Downtown
description: FROM outside Greenwich Village, sidewalk cafes seem to fit the district like prosciutto on melon. Who wouldn't love these Paris-evoking oases where the likes of Cary Grant and Audrey Hepburn plotted romantic moves? New York cafes relax the pace and draw crowds to perk up streets.

title: Yes, America Has a Class System. See 'Frasier.'
description: DR. FRASIER CRANE'S apartment says a lot about him. The tan suede sofa is a copy of one Coco Chanel had in her Paris atelier. The view is the Seattle skyline. There are Lichtensteins on the wall, a baby grand in the alcove and a finely ground Kenya blend in the coffeemaker.

title: Lost in the Translation
description: Four characters in search of glamour find it in a sexy dialogue between sheath dresses and skinny three-button suites.

title: Quicker, Not Thicker Lawyering
description: Kenneth Starr finally, finally got it right in resigning his pending appointment as dean of the Pepperdine University law and public policy schools. Given his record of political clumsiness, his appointment of a communications adviser is probably a sound idea, too. But Mr. Starr's statement that ''the end is not yet in sight'' in his investigation of President Clinton is distressing and raises once again the question of why Mr. Starr is so thick when it comes to understanding his public obligation as independent counsel.

title: Deaths of Sea Turtles Create Split on Causes
description: Straight up the coast from here, a 100-pound loggerhead turtle named Bill -- with no front flippers -- lives in a water tank at a marine science institute, the apparent victim of someone with a big knife.

title: Senators Tune Up for Education Fight
description: Armed with dismal test scores and stories of illiterate teen-agers in crumbling schools, Senate Republicans and Democrats were conducting partisan dress rehearsals this week for the start on Monday of the first in-depth debate on education in years.

title: Diverse Sources of Indoor Pollution
description: INDOOR air pollution can cause some health problems, like eye irritation, lingering colds, runny noses and constant coughing, difficulty in breathing, chronic headaches, skin rashes, unaccountable lethargy and irritability, and infectious diseases. The air quality in your home is dependent upon the strength of pollution sources, how well you clean and how much fresh air circulates through the house.

description: MEASURING just under six feet and weighing nearly 300 pounds, Curtis Gunn can be distinguished by his visibility. Amid the noise and distractions on the Sands casino floor, Mr. Gunn is the easiest casino host to spot.

A performance by these forces from the dim past, in 1976 at the Tanglewood Festival, was remembered chiefly for its conductorial willfulness, as when Mr. Ozawa swelled and swooped from one phrase into the next in the chorales.

title: New Austrian Cardinal Apologizes for Predecessor's Sex Crimes
description: In an effort to ease the path for a visit by the Pope to Austria, the head of the embattled Roman Catholic Church here, Christoph Cardinal Schonborn, has apologized for the behavior of his predecessor, who is accused of having molested young seminarians.

The 1929 limestone and brick building will then be stripped down to its steel girders, and, in about two years, the blue construction tarps will be dropped to reveal -- a brand-spanking-new 1929 limestone and brick building.

title: How About a $5 Used Car? Good Luck
description: At 4:45 A.M. yesterday, Camella Thomas planted herself outside the Premier Ford dealership in East Flatbush, Brooklyn. For the next six hours, through darkness and rain, a single thought sustained her: as the first to arrive at the dealership, she was guaranteed a car for $5.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, RABBI ISRAEL
description: SILVERSTEIN-Rabbi Israel. On April 19, in his 89th year. Husband of Sadie, father of Lorraine S. Dauber and the late Dr. Jerrold Silverstein, grandfather of Paul Dauber, Jane D. Lewittes, and Daniel Dauber, great-grandfather of Joshua and Jack Lewittes, and brother of the late Max and Samuel Silverstein. A graduate of RIETS (Yeshiva University), a self made business man, communal leader, philanthropist, scholar and teacher at The Jewish Center, Chaplain at St. Luke's Hospital. title: Reporter's Notebook; First Lady Visits Real People in Chile
description: As 34 leaders of the nations of the Americas were gathering in a windowless hotel ballroom here to produce a lofty declaration of hemispheric cooperation, Hillary Rodham Clinton was demonstrating their intentions in action.

title: Linda McCartney, Photographer of Rock Stars, Dies at 56
description: Linda Eastman McCartney, the wife of the former Beatle Paul McCartney and a photographer whose portraits of 1960's rock stars have become classics, died on Friday in Santa Barbara, Calif., where the McCartneys were vacationing. She was 56.

title: Old-Line Retailers Resist On-Line Life
description: Executives at Saks Fifth Avenue were a bit dazzled in the fall of 1996 when Time Warner Inc. offered them space on an Internet ''mall'' for less than $100,000. It seemed like the right partner and the right time to try selling on the World Wide Web.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CORRADO, CARMELLA
description: CORRADO-Carmella. Age 93, died Saturday, April 18, in Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn. Wife of the late Anthony J. Corrado, she is survived by a son Fred L. Corrado and two granddaughters Christine and Caroline Corrado. A Funeral Mass will be held Wednesday, 10 AM, in St. Mary's R.C. Church, 178 Greenwich Avenue, Greenwich, CT. Friends may call at the Fred D. Knapp & Son Funeral Home, 267 Greenwich Avenue, Greenwich, CT, from 4-8 PM, Monday and Tuesday.

title: Banking on Congress
description: It was nervy of Citicorp and Travelers to announce the biggest merger in corporate history even though current Federal law would prevent the deal from being carried out in full. Both institutions exuded confidence that Congress would change the Depression-era banking laws that prevent banks, insurance companies and investment bankers from entering one another's turf. This page has long supported such a change. But their confidence also tells a sad story of how reliably money buys influence and preferential treatment in Congress.

title: Wang Dan, a Leader of '89 Protests, Arrives in Detroit : China Dissident Frail but Free
description: WASHINGTON  Wang Dan, a leader of the 1989 democracy movement in Beijing, arrived Sunday in Detroit, a day after being freed from a Chinese prison in the latest in a series of moves aimed at easing strains in U.S.-China relations.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, FLORENCE
description: KAYE-Florence. Died on Saturday, April 18, in her 91st year. Daughter, wife, mother, grandmother, great-grandmother and friend, she deeply loved and was devoted to her now deceased parents and her husband Edward; to her children Charlotte and Allen Finn, Judith and Stephen Kaye and Michele Weal; to her grandchildren Elizabeth and Andrew Finn, Andrea and Richard Finn, and Ellen and Gregg Finn, Luisa and Jan Hagemeier, Jonathan Kaye, Gordon Kaye and David Anthony; to her eleven greatgrandchildren; to her brothers and sisters Selma and Ray Halprin, Tobey and Charles Karp and Leonard Karp; to Jane and Norman Laskey and her many other friends and relatives. As we miss her, she shall remain in our hearts. Funeral services are at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 9:30 AM, April 20.

title: Don't Expect Americans In Boston's Top Finishers
description: When the 102d annual Boston Marathon begins at noon Monday, the starting area in suburban Hopkinton will be jammed with as many as 7,935 men and 3,539 women, mostly Americans. But up front, where the elite runners start, the 22 men will include no Americans and the 11 women will include only one American.

title: A RECORD BACKLOG TO GET CITIZENSHIP STYMIES 2 MILLION
description: More than two million immigrants throughout the country are waiting to become citizens of the United States, the largest backlog of naturalization applications since the Federal Government began keeping those records at the turn of the century.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, HARRIET D.
description: GOLDBERG-Harriet D. On April 18, 1998. Beloved wife of Victor J. Goldberg. Loving mother of Susan Goldberg Gevertz and Alan Jay Goldberg. Loving mother-in-law of John Neil Gevertz and Karen Beth Lipson. Adoring grandmother of Rebecca Caitlin Gevertz, Annie Elizabeth Gevertz and Jonah Samuel Goldberg. Service Monday, April 20, 1 PM, at the Westchester Reform Temple, Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Harriet David Goldberg Memorial Fund at Brown University, Providence, RI 02912.

title: John Barkham, 90, Prolific Book Critic Focusing on History
description: John Barkham, a prolific book reviewer who could deliver a stream of four, five or six reviews a week in his heyday, died on April 15 at a nursing home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 90.

title: Flush With Jets' Picks, Patriots Draft Superbly
description: Across the National Football League for the past two days, general managers, coaches and scouts have been crammed into their war rooms, and the scene in many of those rooms often resembled ''The Jerry Springer Show.'' Arguments and shouting matches -- it was all there. Dan Reeves once called the Giants' war room the most argumentative place he had ever been. Where are those Springer bodyguards when you need them?

title: Little Things Mean a Lot in Kite Competition
description: Scott Skinner looked like a mime or a man deep in hallucination. But on closer inspection there really was something fluttering from the end of the thread at the end of the clip at the end of the wand he held in his hand as he slowly twirled. It was a kite, the size of a hefty mosquito, and it occasionally soared higher than the 10-degree angle of flight required at the first World's Smallest Kite competition, held here this weekend to ''find the tiniest flyable kite on the planet.''

title: Undoing an Act of God At an Italian Basilica
description: Ever since the back-to-back earthquakes on Sept. 26 that sent 13th-century frescoes crashing to the ground, killing four people, the effort to save and restore the magnificent Basilica of St. Francis has been a dramatic race against time.

title: Renzo Piano Wins Architecture's Top Prize
description: Renzo Piano, a prolific Italian architect whose best-known works include the Georges Pompidou Center in Paris and the Menil Collection in Houston, has been awarded the Pritzker Architecture Prize for 1998, the prize's 20th year. The announcement was made yesterday by Jay Pritzker, chairman of the Hyatt Foundation, which sponsors the award. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHASE, REV. WILLIAM JAMES
description: CHASE-Rev. William James. Died Saturday, April 11, 1998, at home in East Hampton, NY. He was 82 years old. Rev. Chase was born in Boston in 1915, to Herbert and Ethel Chase. He was the eldest of three sons. He graduated from Hamilton College in 1936, and the Episcopal Theological Seminary in Cambridge, MA, in 1939. After ordination, he served churches in Ithaca, NY, and in New York City. He attended the Air Force Chaplains School and served in the Pacific theater during World War II. He worked on General MacArthur's staff in Tokyo during the postwar period, and retired with the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. After the war he served from 1949 to 1971, as Assistant to the Rector at St. James Episcopal Church in New York City under the Rev. Dr. Arthur Lee Kinsolving. In 1971, he organized the Chaplain Program at Roosevelt Hospital and arranged funding so that the Chaplain's office became a 24 hour post with more than 20 churches cooperating in the program. After retirement to East Hampton he continued to volunteer as Chaplain at St. Luke's-Roosevelt, and was active in many institutions including the Nature Conservancy, Fountain House, South Fork Natural History Society, and the Peconic Land Trust. He is survived by his brother John L. Chase, his sister-in-law Helen Louise, and several nephews. Memorial service will be held in East Hampton at 2 PM, April 24, St. Luke's Episcopal Church, and at 11 AM, May 8, at St. James Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Ave, New York City. Memorial donations may be sent to the South Fork Shelter Island Chapter of the Nature Conservancy, or to St. Luke's Second Century Fund.

Giuliani suggested yesterday that a remark by Stanley Hill, the head of the city's largest municipal union -- likening workfare to slavery -- was a veiled attempt to further the union's position that the city plans to replace workers at municipal hospitals with workfare participants.

title: Two From Tower Air Flight Remain in Critical Condition
description: Two passengers of a Tower Air Boeing 747 that hit a pocket of turbulence as the plane crossed the Atlantic Ocean on Saturday were listed in critical but stable condition yesterday.

title: Who's Minding the Kids, Really?; Society Hasn't Changed
description: To the Editor:

title: America Online Alliance
description: America Online will announce an alliance today with thestreet.com, a financial news service on the World Wide Web. Under the arrangement, America Online subscribers will be given access to selected information from the Web site on a delayed basis, and offered a discount on its annual subscription fee. The alliance is the latest in a series of efforts to promote thestreet.com by James J. Cramer, a hedge fund manager who founded it with Martin Peretz, editor in chief of The New Republic, in late 1996.

title: In a Changed Sicily, a Film Dares to Laugh at the Mob
description: Feature films about the Sicilian Mafia used to be predictable fare, like cowboy or kung fu movies. Stock characters included the stern patriarch, the nasty killer, the silent wife, the corrupt businessman and, of course, the lonely anti-Mafia crusader. Put them together in a mournful struggle of good versus evil, and, poof, there it was: another in a long string of movies that regularly crowded Italian theaters and television screens.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARLOW, DAVID
description: MARLOW-David. His partner, colleagues and friends in the insurance industry offer their condolences to Ann, Marc and Ian, and his family.

title: Mets Are Too Touchy For Their Own Good
description: When your children start doing not-so-welcome imitations of the tykes on ''South Park,'' a retreat into the past is often called for.

title: Mayor Making Case for Yanks On West Side
description: Saying that he still preferred that the New York Yankees remain in the Bronx, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani nevertheless spent the better part of a Sunday morning justifying the more ambitious and controversial option of building a new stadium for the team on the West Side of Manhattan.

title: French and Israeli Players Take Top Honors in Corsica
description: The Generali Masters tournament which ended yesterday in Ajaccio, Corsica, is unlike any other. Fifty-two experts, about one-third of whom owned world titles, played an individual, placing a premium on adaptability and relegating elaborate systems and conventions to the sidelines.

title: In software development, a true ardor for Java.
description: WATCHING Sun Microsystems and the Microsoft Corporation quarrel over Java is a little like watching kids decide some issue by doing one-up with a baseball bat, hand over hand, until the winner cups the top of the handle.

title: For Moynihan, Fund-Raiser But No Word on 2000 Race
description: A long line of candidates is waiting in the wings for him to retire, and rumors abound in political circles that he is not enthusiastic about seeking a fifth term.

title: Police Officer Is Accused Of Molesting 2 Women
description: A New York City police officer was charged yesterday with forcing two women off a Brooklyn street and molesting them at gunpoint in an alley while off duty, the police said.

title: Critics Assail PBS Over Plan For Toys Aimed at Toddlers
description: Bemusement was the adult reaction when the roly-poly Teletubbies floated onto the public television landscape this month, four smiling, vividly hued plush characters with antennae on their heads. This was something new: television designed for 1- and 2-year-olds.

title: Giants to Sign Brown and Cut Hampton
description: The Giants completed their draft today by selecting three players who should fill reserve roles. More significant, they agreed to terms with the free-agent running back Gary Brown, resolving what little indecision remained about Rodney Hampton's future.

title: With 'No More Pol Pot,' the 'New' Khmer Rouge Hopes the World Will Forgive and Forget
description: As the smoke from Pol Pot's funeral pyre drifted away on a westerly breeze, a spokesman for the brutal Khmer Rouge movement he founded was voicing a fervent hope that the world would forgive and forget.

title: Corrections
description: A box in Weekend on Friday listing current works inspired by Victor Hugo, with a review of a show of his drawings at the Drawing Center in SoHo, misstated the given name and medical condition of the composer of ''Hunchback,'' a musical that producers hope to present on Broadway. He is Byron Janis, not Conrad. While he does have arthritis, he is not housebound.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHWARTZ, DAVID
description: SCHWARTZ-David. On your birthday and forever, we will miss you and keep you in our hearts. We love you. Your family

title: Alberto Calderon, 77, Pioneer Of Mathematical Analysis
description: Alberto Calderon, one of the leading mathematicians of the last half-century, died on Thursday in Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 77 and was professor emeritus of mathematics at the University of Chicago and lived in Chicago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLENER, HENRIETTA
description: GLENER - Henrietta. Beloved mother of Norman, Howard, Henry, Lawrence, Joel and Carl. Cherished grandmother, great-grandmother and mother-in-law. Services Gutterman Funeral Home, 2576 Flatbush Ave, Brooklyn, NY, Tuesday, April 21, 11:30 AM. Donations may be made to Shorefront YMHA, 3300 Coney Island Ave, Brooklyn, NY 11235.

title: Man Beat Ex-Girlfriend to Death With a Tree Branch, Police Say
description: Three days after being ordered by a judge to stay away from his longtime girlfriend, a Brooklyn man returned to the apartment they had shared and beat her to death with a tree limb, prosecutors said yesterday.

title: After 3 Failed Tries, the Nets Win and Are In
description: The clock was ticking down today, and for once the Nets were not waiting to turn into pumpkins. They were on top, soaking in the raucous applause that filled Continental Arena as Keith Van Horn held the ball, waiting for the clock to expire. But as he waited, Kendall Gill called for the ball from the other side of the floor. The rookie obediently obliged, tossing it to Gill, who turned and fired it high into the stands as the clock finally struck zero.

title: Out With the Old, In With the Old-Fashioned; In Country, an Effort To Keep Rustic Look Of Bridges and Roads
description: When Don Freibergs was a boy in this tiny village 20 years ago, the old iron bridge across the south branch of the Raritan River was so decrepit that schoolchildren had to cross the bridge on foot to lighten the school bus.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEVENS, BAYARD M.
description: STEVENS-Bayard M. Age 82 on April 15 in Vero Beach, FL, formerly of Bay Head, NJ. Beloved by his wife, Mary; his children, Elizabeth and Bayard; his grandson, Nathaniel and his sister, Nancy.

title: Executive Shuns Pay
description: James Barksdale, president and chief executive of the Netscape Communications Corporation declined virtually his entire pay package last year, as the company lost money amid pressure from its rival, the Microsoft Corporation in the Web-browser market. According to the company's annual proxy filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Barksdale did not take a salary or year-end bonus for 1997.

title: They Want You to Want Them, but Cheerfully
description: As one clamoring, melodious chorus after another filled Roseland during Cheap Trick's free concert on Saturday night, what might have been another sad example of a group cannibalizing old glories turned out to be a challenge aimed at anyone who considers rock music negative. The band's return to its famous 1979 set list from the Budokan in Japan created a holiday feeling of good will.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAYMOND, SUSIE
description: RAYMOND-Susie. On April 17, 1998, in her 89th year. Passed away peacefully at her residence in New York. Graveside services today, April 20, 1 PM, at Mt. Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY.

title: SCIENCE WATCH; Wren Families Stay In Tune
description: Among the stripe-backed wrens of Venezuela, music definitely runs in the family.

title: Building a Winner in San Diego
description: For a man who runs a major league baseball team, Larry Lucchino has an unusual memento in his home: a pair of bronzed steel-tipped steelworker's shoes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TOTA, JOSEPH L.
description: TOTA-Joseph L. On April 19, 1998. Devoted husband of Carmela (Nee Mercurio). Beloved father of Charles A. Tota. Loving brother of Anna Lops, Mary Maier, Helen Ciaccio, Anna S. Tota, and the late Robert Tota. Cherished grandfather of Joseph L. Tota, II. Dear (Uncle Joe) of many nieces, nephews and godchildren. Funeral Wednesday 9:15am from the MARINE PARK FUNERAL HOME, 3024 Quentin Road, Bklyn. Mass at St. Edmund's R.C. Church, 10:15am. Interment St. John's cemetery.

title: Court Challenge Lets Ice Cream Trucks Jingle
description: The jingles played by ice cream trucks will continue to call out to the children of Stafford Township, at least for now.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about merchandising connected with the PBS children's program ''Teletubbies'' misspelled the names of two stores that will sell show-related products and rendered a third incorrectly. The stores are Noodle Kidoodle, F. A. O. Schwarz and Learningsmith, not Noodle Cadoodle, F.A.O. Schwartz and Learning Smith.

title: Finding Out How Tennessee Williams Got That Way
description: A virtually unknown work written by Tennessee Williams in 1938 is causing a major stir at the Royal National Theater. The play, ''Not About Nightingales,'' is being seen not merely as a fine production from the National's new artistic director, Trevor Nunn, but also as one that extends critical understanding of Williams.

title: Ewing Put On Roster; Dudley Set To Play
description: There were no trumpets to announce Chris Dudley's return. The real hoopla is on hold until the franchise center gets a doctor's nod to slip on a uniform and make like a hero.

title: From Kmart to Big Kmart
description: The Kmart Corporation said today that it planned to convert more than half of its 2,126 stores to the ''Big Kmart'' format by the end of this year. The discount retailer opened 117 of the larger stores on April 19 at a cost of about $70 million, bringing the total number of converted stores to 787 in the last two years. The Big Kmart format consists of home fashions, children's merchandise and consumables. The stores have a ''pantry'' department in the front of each store, which stocks frequently used household items.

title: Abortion Foes Are Held Liable For Harassment
description: A United States District Court jury today ruled that three anti-abortion leaders had violated a Federal racketeering law by conducting a nationwide campaign to intimidate abortion providers and patients.

title: Studies Show Another Drug Can Prevent Breast Cancer
description: Two new studies reported in preliminary form yesterday suggest that a second drug can apparently prevent breast cancer, at least in the short term. But this drug, raloxifene, did not appear to raise the risk of uterine cancer, a side effect of the first drug, tamoxifen, whose benefits were reported earlier this month.

description: Ring Around the Collar

description: * NEC USA Inc., Melville, N.Y., to Marsteller Advertising, New York, a division of the Burson-Marsteller unit of Young & Rubicam Inc., to handle corporate advertising, which had been handled by Hampel/Stefanides, New York. Billings were estimated at $6 million to $10 million. Hampel/Stefanides continues to handle advertising for NEC's PC division.

description: JACOBS-Marianne K. On April 19, 1998 in her 89th year. Beloved wife of the late Louis Jacobs. Dear mother of John and mother-in-law of Susan Jacobs. description: Rewards in abundance await audiences fortunate enough to make their way to the New Victory Theater in Times Square before the all-too-brief run of ''The Great Gilly Hopkins'' ends on Sunday.
