title: Albright to See Netanyahu And Arafat In London
description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, will go to London on May 4 for separate meetings with Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright in an effort to revive stalled peace talks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RODER, LYDIA (DIETRICH)
description: RODER-Lydia (Dietrich). Age 90. April 16, after complications from heart surgery. Born in Stuttgart, Germany. Formerly worked as millinery designer. Recently served as volunteer worker, arts and crafts teacher, and chairperson and advisor for the ABSW Senior Center. Beloved wife of the late Hartmann Roder. Devoted mother of Herbert and Werner. Mother-in-law of Ingeborg and Carlene. Grandmother of Glenn, Meryl, Austin, and Gregg. Family will receive friends at Walter B. Cooke Funeral Home, 117 W. 72nd Street, NY, Monday 5-9, Tuesday 2-5, 7-9 (service). Wednesday at Trinity Lutheran Church, 168 West 100th Street, viewing 10:30, followed by funeral service, 12 noon. Burial at Mount Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson.

title: City Lays Off 905 at Hospitals Amid Protests
description: The Giuliani administration sent official layoff notices to 905 hospital workers yesterday, as union officials and Democratic politicians kept up their very public campaign to make the case that the cuts would create unnecessary personal and institutional hardships.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Guide column of the Connecticut section on Sunday about a book sale at the Wilton Public Library misstated the day and time of an early buying session. It is this Saturday, from 7 to 9 A.M., not Friday night.

title: Nets Laugh at Danger, Eager to Face the Bulls
description: When the inevitable questions about a first-round series with the Chicago Bulls invaded their playoff celebration on Sunday, the Nets insisted they were ready to challenge the two-time defending champions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AMENDOLA, GILDA G.
description: AMENDOLA-Gilda G. Of Mount Vernon, N.Y. on April 20, 1998. Dear sister of Lena D. Cavaliere, Anne G. Cacchione, Frank D. and the late Armand, Ida and Mario. Calling hours at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, 2-4 and 7-9 P.M. on Tuesday. Mass of Christian Burial at Saint Peter and Paul Church, Fleetwood, on Wednesday, April 22nd at 10 A.M.

title: CSX GETTING $850 MILLION TO START JOINT BARGE VENTURE
description: The CSX Corporation said yesterday that it would receive $850 million in cash and stock to set up a barge transportation joint venture with the privately held Vectura Group Inc. CSX will combine its American Commercial Lines Inc. unit with Vectura's National Marine Inc. unit. CSX will receive $695 million in cash and $155 million in securities, including a 34 percent stake in the venture. The new company, to be based in Jeffersonville, Ind., will operate 4,500 barges and 195 towboats, primarily on the Mississippi River system and the Gulf Intracostal Waterway. CSX, based in Richmond, provides rail and container shipping services. It had revenue of $10.6 billion in 1997. Vectura, based in New Orleans, provides barging and stevedoring services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NORDLICHT, IRVING
description: NORDLICHT-Irving. Loving husband of Perrie. Loving father of Karen and Joseph Levine, Michael and Linda, Alissa and Avi Ossip. Beloved stepfather of Judy Kamber Mendlowitz, Batya and Richard Spierer, Shira and Kuti Schwartz. Brother of Milton and Jules. Also survived by grandchildren. Services were held Monday, April 20th. Call 718-261-2493 for details of shiva.

title: Political Pressure Cited in Case Against Marines
description: The lawyer for the pilot of a Marine jet that clipped a ski gondola cable in Italy, killing 20 people, said today that political pressure had led to charges against the four-man crew.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, RUTH CARLSON
description: FRANK-Ruth Carlson, 89. Died Sunday at Kendal at Hanover, following a lengthy illness. She was born November 26, 1908 in Brooklyn, NY, a daughter of David and Jenny Carlson. She graduated from Maxwell Teachers College and taught school prior to her marriage. She was married on April 22, 1931 to Walter N. Frank. Mrs. Frank had great interests in art, interior design and especially her family. Formerly of Ho-HoKus, NJ, she had been resident of Hanover since 1991. She was predeceased by her son, Walter N. Frank Jr. in 1995. She is survived by her husband of 66 years, her daughter, Judith Frank Ketterer of Lyme, NH, six grandchildren and five great grandchildren. Visitation will be held Tuesday from 2:00 PM to 4:00 PM and 7:00 PM to 9:00 PM at the Rand-Wilson Funeral Home on School Street in Hanover, NH. Funeral services will be held on Wednesday 1:30 PM in Our Savior Lutheran Church of Hanover, NH with the Reverend William E. Nelson officiating. Burial will follow at the Pine Knoll Cemetery in Hanover, NH. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to the Cadbury Fund, C/O Kendal at Hanover, 80 Lyme Road, Hanover, N.H. 03755.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RINALDI, ANTHONY F., PH.D.
description: RINALDI-Anthony F., Ph.D. A beloved friend who will be greatly missed and forever in our hearts. Our deepest condolences to his family. Donna and Craig

title: Advocates of Remedial Work Barrage the Trustees at CUNY
description: Scores of indignant students, faculty members, public officials and alumni jammed into the green marble boardroom of the City University of New York yesterday to speak in a marathon of protest against proposals by the university's trustees to limit remedial work.

title: Archbishop Trevor Huddleston, 84, Dies; Fought Apartheid From Its Earliest Days
description: Archbishop Trevor Huddleston, a British Anglican who spent years fighting apartheid in South Africa and helped make its abuses widely known, died in northern England yesterday, the Church of England announced. He was 84.

title: Metro Business; 1 Times Square Store For Warner Brothers
description: Warner Brothers Studio Stores is to open its third store in New York on Saturday at 1 Times Square, the angular building known for the ''zipper'' that carries breaking news and for the 500-pound ball that descends from its top of on New Year's Eve.

title: Fighting the Drug War
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIOTT, BARBARA BURTON
description: ELLIOTT-Barbara Burton. The Executive Director of Il Piccolo Teatro Dell'Opera, a regional opera company in New York City died at New York Hospital on April 18 of complications from leukemia. She was sixty-three years old. Barbara was dedicated to Arts Education as an essential ingredient for a civilized society. She grew up in Austin, Minnesota. She majored in Organ and Fine Arts at Carleton College. She is survived by her mother Eunice Burton. Her husband Donald, her three sons Steven, Drew and Douglas. Four grandchildren, Zachary, Kaitlin, Tyler and Clay and her sister Vicky Swedish and brother Rob Burton. There will be a memorial service held at The Riverside Church on Thursday, April 23 at 10:00 AM. The family asks that in lieu of flowers people make donations in Barbara's memory to Il Piccolo Teatro dell'Opera, 118 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn, New York 11201.

title: No Mistaking the Stiff Upper Lip
description: It may trading in a cultural stereotype to say so, but there is something so very British about the singing of the splendid soprano Felicity Lott, who presented an enthusiastically received recital program at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday afternoon with the fine pianist Graham Johnson, also British.

title: Grand Examples of the Right Stuff for Aging Well
description: IN many ways, Mary Elizabeth is your average late 20th-century elderly American. Widowed at 51 with seven children then aged 7 through 21, she began working part time at her alma mater and worked her way up to become the college's alumni director, finally retiring at 78.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEERMANN, JAMES
description: BEERMANN-James. On April 19, 1998. Survived by his wife Ellen McGauley, his daughter and sonin-law, Ruth and Ron Krugler and their children Alexandra and Michael, his daughter and son-in-law Elizabeth and Brett Lincoln, and their children Lauren and Kyle, and his son John Beermann and daughter-in-law Joanne and their children Erin, Brendan and Sean. He is also survived by his brother Frank Beermann. Reposing at Walter B. Cooke-Kennedy Funeral Home, 117 West 72 Street, between Amsterdam and Columbus Avenues, New York City, on Wednesday, April 22, and Thursday April 23, 2-5 and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass Friday, April 24, Saint Paul the Apostle R.C. Church 9:30 AM.

description: LUKOMNIK-Joanne. Died April 20, 1998. Tireless advocate for social justice and the public's health, former Chair of Executive Board of APHA, co-founder of Westside Yiddish School. Survived by husband Len Rodberg, loving children Josie and Simon, mother Mary Lukomnik, brothers David and Jon (Lynn) and niece and nephew Julia and Aidin. Services will be held Thursday, April 23 at 11:15 A.M., Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers contributions should be made to the International Myeloma Foundation, 2129 Stanley Hills Drive, Los Angeles, California 90046.

description: LICHTENSTEIN - Fay. Beloved wife of the late Sol, devoted mother of Joel H. and Susan; Richard G. and Laurie. Service 2 P.M., on Tuesday at Wien & Wien, 129 Engle Street, Englewood, New Jersey.

title: Utility Faces New Penalties For Mistakes
description: Proposing a penalty rarely seen in the nuclear power industry, Connecticut regulators recommended today that the state's largest utility no longer charge customers for costs associated with a nuclear reactor that has been idle for two years.

title: Two Doctors Charged In a Bribery Scheme
description: Two Belleville, N.J., doctors have been charged with paying a former Newark school official more than $60,000 in bribes to steer $1 million in workers' compensation cases their way from 1992 to 1996, officials said yesterday.

title: Heineken Chooses Lowe & Partners
description: Heineken USA Inc. said yesterday that it had named Lowe & Partners/SMS in New York to handle advertising for its Heineken, Amstel Light, Murphy's and Buckler brands, with combined billings estimated at $40 million.

title: Fallon McElligott hires a new chief creative officer.
description: FALLON MCELLIGOTT, the hot creative shop in Minneapolis, is unexpectedly poaching a top talent from BBDO Worldwide to help provide the next generation of creative leadership for the agency.

title: As Wings Defend Title, Questions Start With Goalie
description: Like screened wrist shots and deflected slap shots, the questions flew at Red Wings goalie Chris Osgood from many angles. Phrased diplomatically, they amounted to one doubt-laden inquiry: is Osgood psychologically tough enough to replace Mike Vernon in the net and lead Detroit to its second consecutive Stanley Cup championship?

title: More Job Training Will Shrink Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Big Board Was Leader in Pricing Cendant's Stock
description: When the stock price of the Cendant Corporation collapsed last Thursday, there was much talk of how embarrassed the New York Stock Exchange must be. After all, 12 million shares of Cendant had traded in other markets that morning before the Big Board was able to open the stock, at 11:04 A.M., or 94 minutes after the exchange opened for business that day.

title: Several New Jersey Districts Sue, Saying School Financing Formula Is Unfair
description: Some two dozen New Jersey school districts in largely middle-class areas filed a lawsuit today challenging the state's current formula for financing its public schools.

title: Improvement Seen For German Labor
description: Germany's central bank said yesterday that there were ''signs of stabilization'' in the German labor market but that the improvement was largely confined to the western part of the country. The bank, the Bundesbank, said in its April monthly report that the ''signs of stabilization of the labor market are growing'' in western Germany but that in the east there was no end in sight to job reductions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUGER, DR. BERNARD
description: ZUGER-Dr. Bernard. On April 19, age 92. Practicing pediatrician and psychiatrist in New York City for more 60 years. Born in Ludmir, Russia, on September 20, 1905. Son of Mendel and Adell. Brother of Max, Ira and Joe. Graduate of Columbia College and Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons. Clinical Associate Professor of Psychiatry at New York University Medical School. Husband of Miriam Troop Zuger. Father of Abigail Zuger. A memorial will be announced.

title: U.S. AND BRITAIN RELOCATE A CACHE OF NUCLEAR FUEL
description: The United States and Britain have begun a secretive operation to remove nuclear material from the volatile Caucasus nation of Georgia, Western officials say.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Anti-Loitering Laws Will Be Revisited
description: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether the police can use anti-loitering laws to keep gang members from congregating and to arrest those who refuse to move on.

title: Guide Covers Territory Suicide Law Does Not Explore
description: AT first blush, Oregon's Death With Dignity Act -- the first and only law in the nation that permits physician-assisted suicide -- seems simple enough. A terminally ill patient who wants to die consults a doctor. The doctor writes a prescription for a lethal mix of drugs. The patient obtains the drugs, takes them and dies. This, at least, is the scenario envisioned by the new law, adopted by Oregon voters last November after three years of judicial and legislative wrangling.

title: Rich Parks, Poor Parks
description: To the Editor:

title: As Polls Rise for Ferraro, So Do Expectations for Her Message
description: Geraldine A. Ferraro was sitting with a small group of Democrats in the dusty Onondaga County party headquarters here the other afternoon, handing out poll results attesting to her political strength and recounting the warm reception that she said her return to politics had received from voters and contributors alike. The evidence was overwhelming, Ms. Ferraro asserted, that she was the only Democrat who could defeat Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.

title: Hoboken Voters Polled On Picking School Board
description: Voters in Hoboken will be asked in a binding referendum today if they want to forfeit the right to elect their school board members in favor of a board appointed by the Mayor.

title: Wonderful Life? Not In Capra's Movies
description: The arrival of a documentary about a movie maker, produced by his sons and featuring blurbs from Hollywood directors and actors, may rouse fears among viewers that they are in for a banquet tribute. Be reassured. Although ''Frank Capra's American Dream'' has moments of eulogy, the man and his work defy easy assessments and bring out the best in those who may have come to praise but who stay to reflect.

title: Tanui Wins In a Sprint And Roba In a Romp
description: Moses Tanui was worried about the downhill parts of the course, and indeed he dropped almost 300 yards behind the leaders during one such stretch. Fatuma Roba was worried about the pain in her right leg that forced her to curtail her training the last three weeks.

title: Welfare-to-Work That Is Working
description: In the effort to find jobs for welfare recipients, one private group, the Welfare to Work Partnership, led by Eli Segal, is making notable progress. Mr. Segal has signed up more than 3,000 companies that pledge to hire and retain welfare recipients. But he needs thousands more.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  VAZQUEZ, INEZ
description: VAZQUEZ-Inez. Beloved mother of Cookie. Miss you, Moo. Happy Birthday. God Bless.

title: Chinese Political Yeast
description: Nine years after it crushed the Tiananmen Square democracy movement, China's leadership seems ever so slightly to be loosening its stranglehold on political dissent. It is too soon to know whether the new openness will last, or grow, but something is stirring in China that bears encouragement and close monitoring by the United States.

description: A decade ago, Denver's ''brown cloud'' was such a national joke that a CBS sportscaster joked after the Broncos lost the 1989 Super Bowl that Denver had ''never been No. 1 in anything -- but carbon monoxide.''

title: CLEAR CHANNEL COMMUNICATIONS IN 2 RADIO STATION DEALS
description: Clear Channel Communications Inc. said yesterday that it would buy six radio stations in West Palm Beach, Fla., for $85 million in cash from Fairbanks Communications Inc. and then swap three of the stations as well as another one in Florida for WTPX-FM, which is also in West Palm Beach, and $47 million in cash from James Crystal Broadcasting. The moves give Clear Channel, which is based in San Antonio, a broader reach in Florida, especially in the fast-growing West Palm Beach market. Clear Channel also owns television stations and billboards.

title: Foreign Affairs; Imbalance of Power
description: Clinton Administration officials insist that this time, for sure, no kidding, absolutely, positively, the Mideast peace process is entering its endgame. Either Yasir Arafat and Benjamin Netanyahu say yes to the U.S. compromise plan for tying up all the outstanding issues before final-status negotiations or else . . . or else . . . or else what?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NIEDERGANG, FLORENCE
description: NIEDERGANG-Florence. Devoted wife of the late Murray. Loving mother of Mark, Paul and Eve. Proud grandmother of Sam, Miriam and Rae. Contributions to The Niedergang Fund at the Ethical Culture Fieldston Schools.

title: Assembly Passes Plan to Cut Car Premiums
description: After almost five hours of heated debate, the New Jersey General Assembly approved auto insurance legislation today that is intended to reduce premiums for some drivers in suburban and rural areas while sharply raising rates for urban drivers.

title: Unnerving Master of Terror and the Absurd
description: Anniversaries in music prod us to pay attention, to pull together into one field of vision all of the far-flung parts of whoever or whatever is being remembered. Unfortunately, anniversaries are also marketing opportunities, a way to focus the ticket buyer's wandering eye on one easy-to-purchase, hard-to-resist package.

title: Gore and Democrats Honor Deputy Speaker
description: It was a long way from home for Arthur O. Eve, a Buffalo Democrat. But the Deputy Speaker of the State Assembly made the trip to Manhattan yesterday morning to be lauded for his 31 years in office by a host of his fellow Democrats, most notably Vice President Al Gore.

title: Depicting The Hurt Of Love Curdling Into Hate
description: Anna Manahan knew ''The Beauty Queen of Leenane'' was going to give her psyche a shellacking. Not long into rehearsals, she and Marie Mullen, cast as her daughter in Martin McDonagh's tragicomic tale of the raw grudge match between a brooding mother and her spinster daughter, began to take their work home, in the form of nightmares.

title: Schumann by Way Of Schiff, With A Challenge or Two
description: It may have been partly or even largely a question of marketing, but Andras Schiff's brief residency at the New York Philharmonic has offered a glimpse of how the orchestra is trying to reconfigure its presentation style. Listeners take the standard format for granted now: guest performers come and go, with conductors usually attracting the greatest attention, and soloists treated as celebrity walk-ons.

title: Hannover Races to Get Its Futuristic Expo Ready for Opening in 2000
description: HANNOVER  The Great Exhibition of 1851 in London, of which the Hanoverian Queen Victoria and her husband and cousin Prince Albert were prime movers, started the craze for giant international expositions. Curiously, although numerous similar events have been held around the globe since, no German city has ever hosted one. But today's Hanoverians will finally get the chance when the capital of Lower Saxony stages Expo 2000, which opens June 1 of the millennial year.

title: State Officials Urge Speed In Reforming Child Agency
description: Concerned that New York City's child welfare workers still fail to properly investigate reports of child abuse and to offer counseling to troubled families, state officials have asked the city to submit a written plan outlining the improvements made at the Administration for Children's Services since it instituted a reform plan more than a year ago.

title: Greenspan, Issuing Warning, Urges Changes in Medicare
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that the nation's ''overall economic performance will be seriously jeopardized'' unless Congress slows the growth of Medicare and redesigns the program to make patients more sensitive to costs.

title: PLAYBOY INCREASES ITS BID FOR SPICE ENTERTAINMENT
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. said yesterday that it had raised its offer for the Spice Entertainment Companies, an adult television entertainment company, to about $100 million in cash, stock and assumed debt from $95 million. Playboy Enterprises, the publisher of Playboy magazine, said it would pay stockholders of the New York-based Spice $3.60 in cash for each of their shares. They will also get 0.1371 of a Playboy class B share, subject to a collar designed to provide a minimum value of $2.20 and a maximum value of $2.88 for each Spice share. Spice shares would be valued about $6.21 each under the new deal. Shares of Playboy fell 25 cents yesterday, to $19.0625, and Spice was unchanged at $6.0625.

title: Protecting Patients, Not Society
description: To the Editor:

title: Taming The Biological Beast
description: For decades, the conventional view among American scientists was that biological weapons aren't much of a problem. Meanwhile, powerful bioweapons were developed and deployed by the Soviet Union and probably by other countries, and the knowledge of how to make them has spread. Smallpox virus can be made in glass jars the size of wine bottles and released into the air with a humidifier. One F.B.I. scientist said to me: ''We're seeing a lot of hoaxes, and incompetent people trying to make biological weapons. The incidents are happening at a rate of roughly one a month. My feeling is that sooner or later someone is going to get it right.''

description: MAKING HISTORY

title: 'Bloodless' Surgery Gains New Acceptance
description: KIMI Onoda was in mortal danger, but one doctor after another refused to operate to fix her aortic aneurysm, a bulge in the main artery of the body. The surgery usually involves a big loss of blood, but Mrs. Onoda, a Jehovah's Witness, would not accept a blood transfusion because her religion forbids it.

description: The Malaysian ringgit slid against the United States dollar yesterday in Asian trading. The currency was hurt by the news that the Standard & Poor's Corporation had downgraded Malaysia's long-term foreign currency rating to single-A-minus from single-A.

description: Intuit Inc. said yesterday that it would stop developing new versions of its flagship personal finance software, Quicken, for Apple Computer Inc.'s Macintosh computers, citing declining sales.

title: Europeans Drop Lawsuit Contesting Cuba Trade Act
description: The European Union is dropping its legal challenge to the Helms-Burton Act, which imposes American penalties on companies that use United States properties in Cuba that were seized by the Castro Government three decades ago.

description: George Young attended the National Football League draft in person this past weekend for the first time in several years. As the Giants' general manager, he had spent drafts huddled inside Giants Stadium.

title: LUCENT ADDS MAKER OF SOFTWARE FOR G.S.M. PHONES
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had bought the closely held Optimay G.m.b.H. of Germany for about $65 million in cash to add software to its line of products used to make wireless phones. Lucent, the phone-equipment maker, plans to take an unspecified charge in its third quarter, which ends June 30, to write down research and development costs at Optimay. Optimay makes software for phones that use the global system for mobile communications, or G.S.M., digital standard, the world's most popular. Lucent rose $2.0625 yesterday, to $71.4375.

title: ASSOCIATES FIRST CAPITAL IN $896 MILLION DEAL

Associates, based in Irving, Tex., is buying the assets of SPS, which issues credit cards for companies like Office Depot, from Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and public shareholders. The shareholders will get $32 a share; Morgan Stanley will get less. SPS closed yesterday at $31.0625, down $1.9375. The two units Associates is buying, SPS Payment Systems Inc. and Hurley State Bank, manage $2.3 billion in credit card receivables.

description: The top officer of the Union Pacific Railroad, the nation's largest, said today that it would resist plans by Federal regulators meant to restore competition because the results would only further erode service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDLAND, JERRY
description: FRIEDLAND-Jerry. The staff of Ambassador Construction mourns the loss of a most beloved member of our corporate family. Jerry was with us since 1977 and, as our Executive Vice-President, was instrumental in helping us grow from a tiny clan of 12 to the tight knit dynasty we are today, while retaining our traditional ''family values''. His calm manner and rational perception in the midst of chaos were always to be counted on. He was an icon of professionalism in his engineering, administrative and organizational skills and these earned him the respect of colleagues, clients, architects and subcontractors on projects ranging from elegant townhouses to a new, modern midtown atrium and indoor mall. He was an arbiter of good taste and left his imprint everywhere, from the design of our offices to our corporate image. His latest project was to update our logo to convey the growth and strength we have achieved over the years and to take us into the next century. His input was invaluable and the completed project will be a living monument to our friend and colleague. We send our love, prayers and support to his wife Benay, who he so cherished, and our deepest condolences to his mother Matilda and his brother Joel. He is finally at peace. The family has requested that in lieu of baskets, donations be made to the Mount Sinai Hospital, (designated on the check for Oncology Research, memory of Jerry Friedland) and sent to: Mt. Sinai Medical Center, Zmira Goodman, VP Development, 1425 Madison Avenue, Box 1049, New York, New York 10029 and advise notification to family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORISHIMA, AKIRA, MD, PHD
description: MORISHIMA-Akira, MD, PhD, Associate Professor of Pediatrics. The Department of Pediatrics of the College of Physicians & Surgeons at Columbia University and the Pediatric Service and Alumni Association of Babies & Children's Hospital of New York, ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center, mourn the loss of their esteemed friend and colleague. A former Director of the Division of Pediatric Endocrinology (1968-1995), Dr. Morishima was an early leader in the field of genetics and did innovative work with his mentor, Melvin Grumbach, MD, in describing normal characteristics as well as disorders of the X chromosome. He also was involved in collaborative studies on the mutagenic properties of marijuana and other recreational drugs. Most recently, and most importantly, Dr. Morishima, through his insights from work with patients, elucidated in a very exciting way the role estrogen plays in bone growth and bone calcification and in normal pituitary-gonadal interactions in both sexes. Dr. Morishima maintained professional ties with Japan as a visiting professor and keynote speaker at professional meetings and was active in the Japanese-American communities in New York and New Jersey. In recognition of these activities, in 1975 he received the prestigious ''Presentation of a Favour'' from the Emperor and Empress of Japan. Dr. Morishima was an enthusiastic teacher and generous colleague. We are grateful for the guidance and insights he gave us during his long years of leadership in the Department and in the field of pediatric endocrinology. John M. Driscoll, Jr., MD Reibem S. Carpentier Professor Director, Pediatric Service Chairman, Dept of Pediatrics

description: Imagine a car 8 feet 2 inches long, with just two seats, whose diesel engine, purring like an outboard motor, propels it at a top speed of 27 miles an hour. Imagine a transmission so basic that it has only two settings, forward and reverse.

title: Election Year May Make Social Security Too Hot to Handle

title: Devils Ready to Raise Their Game a Notch
description: The Stanley Cup playoffs cannot come soon enough for the Devils and Senators.

title: KEANE TO BUY BRICKER & ASSOCIATES, ANOTHER CONSULTANT
description: Keane Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Bricker & Associates Inc., a privately held information technology consulting firm, for $110 million in stock. Bricker, which is based in Chicago, had revenue of $15 million in 1997. The Boston-based Keane also provides information technology consulting, as well as application and help-desk outsourcing and year 2000 compliance services. It had revenue of $654 million in 1997. Under the deal, Keane will exchange about two million of its shares for all of Bricker's shares outstanding. Keane's stock rose $2.6875 a share yesterday, to $57.6875.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Classical CD's; A Dark Romantic in Modern Guise
description: The Hungarian composer Gyorgy Kurtag has a unique place in today's music. He keeps at his disposal many of the techniques of advanced modernism: extending the possibilities of instruments, reconceiving the orchestra, using Serial methods and other kinds of abstract speculation, freeing rhythm from regularity, involving improvisation. But at the same time he holds to a Romantic view of music as expressive utterance.

title: LAZARD FRERES UNIT TO BUY ASSISTED LIVING COMPANY
description: A unit of Lazard Freres & Company agreed yesterday to buy Atria Communities Inc. for about $750 million, strengthening its position in the assisted living industry. The Lazard unit, the Kapson Senior Quarters Corporation, will pay $20.25 for each Atria share. Among those selling shares will be the hospital and nursing home operator Vencor Inc., which holds 42.8 percent of Atria. It will sell around 88 percent of the shares it holds for about $177.5 million. Atria's stock was down 50 cents a share yesterday at $19.1875. Kapson is based in Woodbury, N.Y., and Atria is based in Louisville, Ky. Lazard, the New York investment bank, finished its purchase of Kapson earlier this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SILVERSTEIN, RABBI ISRAEL I.
description: SILVERSTEIN-Rabbi Israel I. Yeshiva University and its affiliated Rabbi Isaac Elchanan Theological Seminary extend heartfelt condolences to Sadie Silverstein, beloved wife of our eminent RIETS trustee, and their children, Lorraine (and Dr. Leonard) Dauber, grandchildren, and great-grandchildren on the passing of a highly esteemed colleague and leader in Jewish education at all levels. Rabbi Silverstein, a YU Guardian with his wife, was a stalwart supporter of his alma mater. He was a distinguished early rabbinic alumnus who, even as a businessman, devoted his life to community service. His hessed as a volunteer chaplain at St. Luke's Hospital, dedicated advocacy of Talmud Torah education, and pioneering work with Camp Morasha earned him the love and esteem of young and old alike. He and his wife established YU's Dr. Jerrold Silverstein Laboratory and RIETS' Dr. Jerrold Silverstein Memorial Scholarship Fund in memory of their beloved son. May the entire family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Dr. Norman Lamm, President Yeshiva University David S. Gottesman, Chairman Board of Trustees Judah Feinerman, Chairman RIETS Board of Trustees

title: Janus Closes a Fund To New Investors

title: Adelphi Trustees Hailed For Turnaround Efforts
description: Adelphi University's trustees, who took over last year amid campus turmoil, have received a national award commending their efforts to turn the school around.

title: At the Cloisters, A Crusade Against Chaos; Curators Spending Millions To Fix 12th-Century Masonry
description: The walls of New York are shedding beams and bricks these days with a dangerous regularity. So it should hardly come as a surprise that the 800-year-old walls at the Cloisters, the medieval museum on a hilltop in Fort Tryon Park in northern Manhattan, are showing signs of age.

title: FELCOR TO ACQUIRE 8 ALL-SUITE HOTELS FROM STARWOOD
description: Felcor Suite Hotels Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy eight all-suite hotels for $245 million from Starwood Hotels and Resorts Trust. Six of the hotels are to be run by the Promus Hotel Corporation, which now manages 66 of Felcor's 76 hotels. The other two hotels will be managed by ITT Sheraton, now owned by Starwood, as Sheraton Suites Hotels. The deal will increase Felcor's portfolio to 84 hotels. Felcor, a real estate investment trust based in Irving, Tex., had 1997 revenues of $176.6 million. Starwood is a REIT based in Phoenix.

title: Hussein Chalayan's High-Wire Act
description: Few designers can move an audience to tears -- they might bring people to their feet or bore them to distraction -- but clothes are rarely so poignant that they elicit crying.

title: Nasdaq and S.& P. Indexes Reach Highs for Second Day
description: Drug and technology stocks extended their rally yesterday, helping to push the Nasdaq composite index and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index to new highs for a second consecutive session.

title: Safer Skies, Here and Abroad
description: Last week Vice President Gore invoked three fatal airplane crashes, in Colombia, Guam and Bosnia, to reacquaint the public with a danger known as ''controlled flight into terrain.'' This refers to flying an airworthy craft into a mountain or other natural obstacle like the ocean because the pilot lost his sense of the plane's relation to its surroundings. It has been a major cause of accidents in America and abroad. The risks can be cut dramatically, but only if airlines invest more in pilot training and hasten installation of the latest terrain-avoidance warning system in cockpits.

title: Old Opening, Popular Again, Helps Win a Pivotal Game

Christiansen won the nine-round Swiss-system tourney with a 7 1/2-1 1/2 score. DeFirmian took second prize with a 7-2 tally. Neither player lost a game.

title: After Years of Gains, Wolf Population on Isle Royale Plummets
description: THERE are always surprises waiting when Dr. Rolf Peterson arrives on Isle Royale National Park in Lake Superior to continue a decades-old annual winter study of the wilderness retreat's wolf and moose populations. But the past few years have produced some startling developments, like the recent death of 80 percent of the moose herd. The latest is the crash of a wolf population that had seemed to be on the rebound after a decade of concern about its possible extinction.

title: Physics on the Web Is Putting Science Journals on the Line
description: Every day, tens of thousands of physicists in more than 100 countries point their Web browsers to a site maintained by the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico. There, they peruse research papers that have been posted since their last visit, trolling for new work in, say, quantum cosmology or statistical mechanics, and send E-mail to one another based on the day's postings.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES

The night was not going well. At one point fog had shut down operations, and roiling winds sometimes blurred vision. An electronics glitch erased some precious data and cost time.

title: Closing In on Campaign Reform

Today, as lawmakers return to work, five more Republicans in the House of Representatives are ready to sign a petition to release campaign reform legislation from committee and bring it to the floor for a vote, in defiance of Speaker Newt Gingrich. The petition now commands 201 supporters, only 18 short of the number needed to give the lie to those who cynically pronounced campaign reform a lost cause.

description: PALEY-Sylvia. Of New Rochelle, New York. Died April 21, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Shim Paley. Devoted mother of Sue Colker and Elizabeth Weinberg. description: From a rumbling Winnebago parked on an East Harlem street yesterday, Mikki Hidalgo had a few words for the Clinton Administration, which had declined to lift a ban on Federal financing for needle exchange programs the day before. She wanted to invite the Washington power brokers for a visit to see what she sees.

title: Happy Just to Listen, The Crowd Just Says No
description: There was a strange contradiction at the Terrastock festival, a three-day marathon of underground psychedelic folk, pop, rock and experimental music that ended on Sunday at the Custer Avenue Stages here: the music celebrated drugs for an audience that didn't.

description: The fourth-grade classroom in this affluent Chicago suburb might be more spacious than most, with room for computers and a red plaid sofa, but there was nothing costly about the way Glen Werner began her science class. She turned off the lights.

title: CMG INFORMATION STOCK HITS HIGH ON PLANS FOR SPLIT
description: CMG Information Services said yesterday that it would split its common stock 2 for 1 as its shares reached a 52-week high. CMG, which manages several venture capital funds that invest in start-up Internet companies, said the split would be distributed as a 100 percent stock dividend. Shareholders of record on April 27 will get one share of common stock for each share held, payable May 11. Shares of CMG rose $5.125, to $100, compared with a 52-week low of $33.125 on Jan. 27. The total shares outstanding of CMG, based in Andover, Mass., after the split will be about 22.7 million.

title: Held as Head of Cocaine Ring, Woman Is to Face U.S. Court
description: A Colombian woman who was accused of running a lucrative cocaine organization in which the top ranks were filled by women has been extradited from Brazil and is expected to appear in Federal District Court in Manhattan today, law enforcement sources said yesterday.

title: Short-Sellers of Compaq Increased Their Position
description: Short-sellers increased their bet against the Compaq Computer Corporation last month. Compaq, the leading personal computer maker, had warned last month that profits would suffer as it cut prices sharply to reduce bloated inventories.

title: Tape in Brawley Case May Backfire on Defense
description: Presenting what appeared to be evidence that contradicted his case, a defense lawyer in the Tawana Brawley defamation trial showed the jury a videotape of a 10-year-old television talk show yesterday in which the three defendants make some of the accusations for which they are now being sued.

description: The Supreme Court ruled today that white criminal defendants who are indicted by grand juries from which black people have been excluded have standing to challenge the constitutionality of the indictment.

description: COHEN-Daniel G. Beloved husband of the late Rebecca Cohen and the late Alice Mornick-Cohen; devoted father of Mitchell and Rosemary Cohen, Larry and Jill Cohen and step-father to Arlene and Kern Hildebrand, Neil and Linda Mornick; loving grandfather of Rebecca, Arielle, Josh, Aron and Noah Cohen, Howard and Josh Alperin, Marissa and Matthew Mornick. title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK AT 2 1/2-MONTH HIGH. The mark surged on a jump in Germany's money supply, increasing the possibility of higher interest rates there. In New York, the dollar fell to 1.7884 marks from 1.8012, its lowest level since Jan. 26.

title: Holding Students Back
description: Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew enunciated an important policy change in proposing to phase out social promotion of New York City students who are failing. Promoting students who have not mastered basic material at their grade level not only leaves them lost in the next grade; it also sends the message that achievement does not matter. But moving away from social promotion requires a huge financial and political commitment to school reform that will affect every aspect of the system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BRALOWER, WILLIAM ''HOOT.''
description: BRALOWER-William ''Hoot.'' Of Old Brookville, NY. With his usual wit and determination, celebrated his 80th birthday on April 16th. Died peacefully April 20. Devoted grandfather and father, wonderful husband and loving brother, he is survived by his wife, BeBe, sons and daughters-in-law, James and Linda, and John and Naomi, and grandchildren, Alex, Amanda, and Thomas, and brother, Stanley. Memorial service will be held on Wednesday, April 22nd at 11:30 at Riverside-Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, New York. Remembrances may be made to Saint Francis Hospital, Roslyn, New York.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: PALLADIUM AT 18-YEAR HIGH. Palladium rose 3.7 percent on increased anxiety over export delays from Russia, the leading producer. June contracts rose $10.45, to $296.55 an ounce, the highest since March 1980.

Notices of services will be announced at a later date. In lieu of flowers, in memory of Lala, contributions may be made to the Clinical Oncology Nursing at Suburban Hospital, 8600 Old Georgetown Road, Bethesda, MD. 20814.

title: CONSOLIDATED NATURAL GAS TO DROP WHOLESALE BUSINESS
description: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company said yesterday that it would drop its money-losing wholesale gas marketing and trading business, resulting in a pretax first-quarter charge of up to $75 million. The company will dismiss all 125 employees of the division, or about 2 percent of its work force. Consolidated will focus on selling gas to residential and small business customers, as well as its natural gas and oil exploration and gas pipeline operations. The Pittsburgh-based Consolidated warned last month that it would not earn as much in the first quarter as analysts expected and told analysts the gas trading and wholesale marketing operation would lose about $20 million.

title: Linda Schele, Pioneer in the Study of Mayans, Dies at 55
description: Linda Schele, a onetime studio art teacher who made a fateful vacation visit to Mexico that turned her life upside down and helped revolutionize Mayan scholarship, died on Saturday at a hospital near her home in Austin, Tex. She was 55 and widely known for her pioneering work in decoding inscriptions on Mayan monuments.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STANGEL, ABRAHAM
description: STANGEL-Abraham. On April 20, 1998. Beloved husband of the late Regina. Loving father of Dr. John and Lois Stangel. Cherished grandfather to Justin and Eric. Services Wednesday, 12:15PM at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: ALLIED DIGITAL CONSIDERS A $68 MILLION TAKEOVER OFFER
description: The Allied Digital Technologies Corporation said yesterday that it had received an acquisition offer from an undisclosed company for $5 a share, or about $68 million. Allied Digital, a copier of audio and video tapes for music and other companies, said it had agreed with a company, which wants to remain anonymous, that it will not solicit other offers while it considers the transaction. Shares of Allied Digital, based in Hauppage, N.Y., rose 50 cents, to $4.4375.

Go is scheduled to start flights to Rome beginning May 22 and Milan May 23, followed by Copenhagen on June 5, all on leased Boeing 737-300's.

description: Hoping to seize the political initiative from President Clinton, Republican leaders in Congress suggested today that legislation to keep teen-agers from smoking should be linked with an antidrug bill.

description: Northern Telecom Ltd. said today that first-quarter profit before a charge rose 31 percent, beating estimates, as the company increased equipment sales to wireless companies that are expanding networks or building new ones.

title: TV Notes; Cultivating A 'Seinfeld' Heir
description: Several networks are scrambling to find comedies that are direct descendants of ''Seinfeld,'' but one network already has a show created by a ''Seinfeld'' graduate, and it is taking unusual steps to try to keep it alive.

title: No. 1 Maryland Wins A.C.C. Title
description: With the regular season nearing its end, these were the highlights from the weekend: Maryland won the Atlantic Coast Conference's annual tournament for the first time and regained first place in the Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association poll; Princeton extended its string of Ivy League victories to 17; Georgetown gave Hobart its first loss, and third-ranked Johns Hopkins had a close call against 18th-ranked Navy, winning by 15-14.

title: Doctors' Pay Regains Ground Despite the Effects of H.M.O.'s
description: The nation's physicians still complain that managed care organizations drown them in paperwork and meddle with their prerogatives in treating patients. But their fears for their own livelihoods, that managed care would reduce their wages or drive them out of medicine, are proving overdrawn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUKOMNIK, JOANNE
description: LUKOMNIK-Joanne. The students, alumni, faculty and staff of the Columbia School of Public Health mourn the passing of our dedicated faculty member. A longtime advocate for public health issues and leader in the American Public Health Association, she will be missed. To her husband, Len Rodberg, children Josie and Simon and her many friends, we extend our deepest sympathy. Allan Rosenfield, MD, Dean Columbia School of Public Health

title: Concern Among Jews Is Heightened As Scientists Deepen Gene Studies
description: On a snowy night in January 1996, a handful of Boston scientists convened some of the city's most prominent Jews for a quiet, off-the-record briefing. Over sandwiches and cookies, the rabbis and leaders of Jewish groups learned of the latest research on a breast cancer gene that occurs with startling frequency in American Jews of Central and Eastern European descent.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUHLFELD, ELIZABETH BLAKESLEE
description: MUHLFELD-Elizabeth Blakeslee. Died on April 13 in Englewood, N.J. In the week preceding her death, she had been surrounded by her family whom she had loved so dearly-her husband of 55 years, Bearss, and their 5 children, Betsy Ingram of Manchester, MA., George, of Summit, N.J., Katie Bell of Northeast Harbor, ME., Lucy Muhlfeld Kazickas of Amagansett, and Louise Patterson of San Franciso, CA. She is also survived by 13 grandchildren. Betty Lou, as she was known, was born in Chicago and grew up in Pittsburgh, PA. until moving to Englewood, N.J. There will be a memorial service on May 31, in Englewood, N.J.

title: Georgia Professor May Seek Gingrich's House Seat
description: She says it is not payback, but Christina F. Jeffrey, the professor who was hired and then quickly dismissed as historian of the House by Speaker Newt Gingrich in 1995, says she wants to run for Congress. Against Newt Gingrich.

title: Winning, The Dull Way
description: In his five seasons as coach of the New Jersey Devils, Jacques Lemaire has won one Stanley Cup championship and more regular-season games than all but one other National Hockey League coach. As a result, Lemaire's franchise enjoys uncommon loyalty among its players. By these standards, Lemaire is a great coach.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CASSEL, SONIA
description: CASSEL-Sonia. On April 16, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Arthur; dear mother of Paul, David and Nina; adored grandmother of Jared and Justin, and Tirilee; cherished sister of Carmen Kline. Services today, at 11 A.M., New Montefiore Cemetery, Farmingdale, Long Island.

title: A Dreamer's Rough Awakening; Art Dealer to the Hollywood Elite Has a New Role, Inmate
description: Tod Michael Volpe recalls growing up poor, the son of a tailor in Yonkers, with dreams ranging far beyond the immediate landscape. A keen eye and a glib tongue got him into the burgeoning art and antiques scene of 1970's SoHo, where he helped transform objects of the Arts and Crafts movement from flea market finds to must-have collectibles.

title: A 'Faust' Semistaged And Even Offstage
description: Concert works with significant elements of theater invariably tempt the theatrically minded to see those implications through in some sort of staging. So it was no surprise to find Berlioz's ''Damnation of Faust'' in a semistaged version at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Friday evening, with Robert Spano conducting the Brooklyn Philharmonic and the New York Choral Society.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DONOGHUE, THOMAS F., JR.
description: DONOGHUE-Thomas F., Jr., 69. Of Stamford on Monday at Stamford Hospital. Survivors include his wife, Virginia C. Donoghue, two daughters, Kathleen D. Addazio, Maryann Donoghue, three sons, Thomas F. III, Michael E. and Edward J. Donoghue, five grandchildren and 2 step-grandchildren. He was a sales manager for International Paper of Purchase, NY for forty-one years, retiring in 1995. A mass will be celebrated at Holy Spirit Church, Scofieldtown Road, Stamford, Thursday, April 23rd, 1998 at 10:00 A.M. Interment will follow at the Queen of Peace Cemetery, Rockrimmon Road, Stamford, CT. For information, contact N.F. Cognetta Funeral Home, Stamford, CT.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Monday about Alberto Calderon, a leading mathematician at the University of Chicago, misspelled the surname of the math department chairman. He is Robert Fefferman, not Fifferman.

title: Utility Plan Would Let Users Pick Gas Providers
description: Some 300,000 customers of Public Service Electric & Gas would be allowed to chose their natural gas provider under a proposal announced by the utility yesterday.

title: At Inquiry, French Officials Say They Tried in Rwanda
description: Four former Government ministers told an unusual parliamentary hearing about France's military role in Rwanda today that they were proud of what they had done to try to stop killings that took more than 500,000 lives there in 1994.

title: Philip Morris Posts 6% Rise In Earnings
description: The Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that earnings rose 6 percent in the first quarter, as it sold more than half the cigarettes in the United States for the first time, even though it raised prices to pay for legal costs.

title: Joanne E. Lukomnik, 51, Public Health Advocate
description: Joanne Eve Lukomnik, a consultant and lifelong advocate of community health services who was also active in national professional and policy-making health groups, died on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 51.

title: A $276 MILLION BUYOUT OF PCA INTERNATIONAL IS PLANNED
description: Senior managers of the portrait-photography chain PCA International Inc. and the investment firm Jupiter Partners L.P. said yesterday that they had agreed to acquire between 95 percent and 97 percent of PCA for $276 million, including assumed debt. The shares of PCA rose 21 percent, gaining $4.4375 to close at $25.9375. PCA International, based in Matthews, N.C., was one of the first concerns in the portrait industry to invest heavily in digital-imaging equipment. The PCA managers include its president and chief executive, John Grosso. Under the agreement, PCA shareholders can receive $26.50 in cash for each share or a share of stock in the surviving entity. The cash portion of the deal has an indicated value of about $210 million.

title: Calendar
description: To Feed the Hungry

title: Nissan Shares At 23-Year Low
description: The shares of the Nissan Motor Company plunged 7.8 percent yesterday, reaching their lowest level since 1975, in the wake of the company's estimate on Friday that its profit fell 79 percent last year. Shares in Japan's second-largest auto maker, fell 35 yen, to 412, after falling 9 percent on Monday.

title: Topics of The Times; Cowardice on Clean Needles
description: In a calculated duck, the Clinton Administration has refused to lift a nine-year-old ban on using Federal money to finance needle exchange programs. Officials readily admit that repeated studies have shown needle exchange programs can help prevent the spread of AIDS without encouraging illegal drug use. But Barry McCaffrey, the Administration's drug czar, continues to insist that needle exchange programs send a message to children that drugs are acceptable.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLAVIN, KAY
description: GLAVIN-Kay. Age 66, of NYC on Thursday, April 16. Sister of Jane Wachsmuth of Mendham, N.J., and Charlotte Walter of North Fort Myers, FL. For information call Bailey Funeral Home, Inc., Mendham, N.J.

title: Baltimore Mayor Endorses Foe of Incumbent Democrat
description: Breaking from the state Democratic Party and raising political eyebrows across the state, Mayor Kurt L. Schmoke of Baltimore today endorsed a challenger to Maryland's Governor, Parris N. Glendening, a Democrat who is seeking a second term this year.

title: Treasury Prices Decrease as Several Corporations Issue Debt
description: Treasury securities prices fell yesterday amid a flood of new debt from corporate issuers drawn by low interest rates. Among the new supply was $3.25 billion of bonds priced yesterday by the Ford Motor Credit Company, its biggest global issue ever.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Many people don't know who we are. I played in Singapore in 1996, and people wanted to know if I kept a gun in my house or if I rode a camel. Now we have an opportunity to present our country, our culture, our people.''

title: The Chef
description: THE subtle interplay of sweet and sour is one of the most beguiling taste experiences there is, and it figures in both of these recipes, traditional preparations that I've twisted just a bit. The London broil is very basic, but the sauce features tamarind, an ingredient widely used in India and the Middle East. The vegetable dish is virtually identical with the Middle Eastern bamia, except that green beans are substituted for okra.

title: Officer, Shooting at Vicious Dog, Wounds Partner
description: A Newark police officer was wounded by a bullet from her partner's gun yesterday after he fired at a marauding dog who attacked him and broke his arm with a powerful bite, the police said. The dog was shot to death by the officers.

Memorial contributions to The Suzanne Young Scholarship Fund, C/O Our Lady of Mount Carmel Church, 59 East Main St, Elmsford, New York 10523, would be appreciated.

description: There cannot have been a more incongruous sight on America's cultural landscape so far this year than Stephen Sondheim's appearance last weekend in this prairie town of 11,000.

description: Reggie White is not done.

title: Hunt-Wesson Picks Euro RSCG Tatham
description: The Hunt-Wesson unit of Conagra Inc. in Fullerton, Calif., named Euro RSCG Tatham in Chicago yesterday to handle advertising for its Orville Redenbacher/Swiss Miss division, with billings estimated at $25 million to $30 million.

title: Pentagon Acknowledges Hacker Intrusion Into a Computer System
description: A group of hackers has penetrated a military computer system that serves as ''a telecommunications backbone for the Defense Department,'' the Pentagon said tonight.

title: Four Big Drug Makers' Nets Are Higher on Strong Sales
description: Four big pharmaceutical companies -- Bristol-Myers Squibb, American Home Products, Schering-Plough and SmithKline Beecham -- reported higher quarterly earnings yesterday, helped by strong sales for their top-selling drugs.

title: Hillenbrand to Sell Unit
description: Hillenbrand Industries has agreed to sell its Medeco Security Locks Inc. unit to Assa Abloy A.B. of Sweden for an undisclosed amount as it focuses on its funeral and medical equipment businesses. Assa Abloy, which makes mechanical and electronic locks, said that it had also bought a 49 percent stake in the Mexican lock maker Cerrajeras Scovill for about $70 million. Hillenbrand, which had $1.8 billion in sales for 1997, is the largest United States coffin maker through its Batesville Casket Company unit.

title: Georgetown President Ends Push to Replace Law School Dean
description: In the face of protests from alumni, faculty and students, the president of Georgetown University has backed down from his decision to replace Judith Areen, the dean who has guided the law school to growing wealth, prominence and autonomy.

title: Credit Lyonnais Shares Fall Sharply
description: Shares in the French state-owned bank Credit Lyonnais fell by their daily-allowable limit of 10 percent on the Paris Stock Exchange yesterday after a threat from the European Union Commission that the bank may be forced to repay 120 billion francs ($20 billion) in state aid. On Monday, the commission threatened to force Credit Lyonnais to pay back money the bank has been awarded in state aid because it believes the French Government has not kept its part of the bargain that allowed the aid in the first place.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Sunday about the Rev. Sandra Jishu Holmes, a Zen Buddhist priest and teacher and a co-founder of the Greyston Mandala in Yonkers, misstated the date of her death. It was March 20, not Feb. 20.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, MICHAEL A.
description: GORDON-Michael A. Loving husband of Jacqueline Jones Gordon , beloved father of Gabriel A. Gordon and Gideon Scott Gordon. Devoted brother of Eileen L. Gordon, beloved son of Emanuel Gordon and the late Myra Gordon. Artist and professor of fine arts at Hofstra University. Funeral services Wednesday 2 PM at Schwartz Brothers Chapel, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills.

title: Dump Site Could Clash With Park Plans
description: For years, residents in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, have hoped to turn an old industrial site along the East River into a waterfront park. Last week, when the State Legislature earmarked $10 million for the park and other projects, a victory seemed near, except for a major complication: state regulators are considering issuing a permit for a garbage transfer station on a piece of the same property.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BISCEGLIA, FRANK J.
description: BISCEGLIA-Frank J., 83. Died at his residence in Nashville, TN, on April 21, 1998, after a long illness. He was born in Rye, NY, and lived in Westchester County until moving to Nashville in 1992. He was a veteran of the Army Air Force and served during W.W. II in the African and European Theatres. He retired in 1980 as the President of The Bisceglia Plastering Corp, a company founded by his father in 1908. A long time member of The Knights of Columbus, Mr. Bisceglia was also active in local politics and was a member of numerous boards and commissions. He is survived by his wife of 56 years, Marita Curtin and six children, Marita-Jane Brown (Hoit), Francis X. (Margaret), Elizabeth Anne, Clare, Gerard T. (Anne), and Michael C. (Maura) Bisceglia, thirteen grandchildren, one great grandchild, and a sister also survive. Visitation at Marshall-Donnelly-Combs Funeral Home, 201 Twenty Fifth Avenue North, Nashville, TN. 37203.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PFEIFFER, DOLLY
description: PFEIFFER-Dolly. We mourn the passing on April 14th, 1998, of a wonderful mother, grandmother, sister, aunt, educator, and my special friend of forty years. I cherish the many years of friendship and will always remember your spirit, courage and warmth to us all. Barbara Chernow

title: Generous Servings of Chefs' Generosity
description: THE invitation did not specify black tie, but it should have suggested loose waistband.

title: Colorado Race Also Restricts U.S. Entries
description: Confronting strong concern over a plan intended to limit the number of Kenyan runners in the Bolder Boulder 10-kilometer road race next month, race officials have announced that all nations, including the United States, will compete for prize money with three-man teams.

title: Legislature Considers Limits For Politicians in Public Ads
description: Gov. John G. Rowland and his wife, Patricia, may be the state's First Couple, but does that mean they get to appear in television commercials acting like Regis and Kathy Lee?

title: Man Held on $250,000 Bail in '79 Kidnapping
description: A man accused of kidnapping his two young daughters from Massachusetts 18 years ago and moving them to Palm Beach, Fla., where he lived lavishly under an assumed name, was ordered held on $250,000 cash bail today, while his grown daughters sat in the courtroom.

title: Juggling Angels and Moguls on Broadway
description: ROCCO LANDESMAN, the New York showman who brought ''The Beauty Queen of Leenane'' to Broadway, said of Paul Simon's failure with ''The Capeman'' that ''it couldn't happen to a nicer guy,'' and is skeptical about the need to pay attention to Michael Ovitz, the new Hollywood mogul on his block. Since Mr. Landesman has a habit of saying whatever is on his mind -- his recent ex-wife cheerfully calls him ''a wild man'' -- this seemed a good week to drop by Mr. Landesman's office to see what he was willing to blurt out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YELIN, LIBBY
description: YELIN-Libby, 79. Of Tamarac, Florida died April 18, 1998. She had been an area resident since 1970, coming from New Rochelle, N.Y. Beloved wife of Paul for 59 years. She is also survived by sons Laurence Yelin of Secaucus, N.J. and Robert Yelin of Boca Raton, FL. and five grandchildren, Douglas, Daniel, Amanda, Samantha and Joshua Yelin; sister, Mrs. Francis Marks of Port St. Lucie, FL. She was an accomplished artist, business executive and an active member of Women's American ORT as well as The Women's League of Israel. She was highly recognized as a major charitable contributor to many causes, not only in Florida but around the world. Funeral services were held Tuesday, April 21, 1998 at Star of David Memorial Chapel in North Lauderdale, FL.

title: Restaurants; An Indian Restaurant Breaks the Mold
description: INDIA is a country without a serious restaurant tradition. New York, on the other hand, has evolved its own tradition for Indian restaurants, one that divides them into two basic styles. Some are cheap and cheerful, serving a standard repertory of similar dishes cooked with a standard repertory of similar spices. The others are proud and pompous places where costumed waiters glide across acres of marble to serve food decorated with edible gold. A few stellar establishments, however, stand outside this tradition. The new Chola, I am happy to report, is among them.

title: Corrections

Ira Gershwin was the sole lyricist for the musical, which won the 1932 Pulitzer for drama. George S. Kaufman and Morrie Ryskind wrote the book.

description: Silicon Valley is dismayed about rapid consolidation among its investment banks, Michael G. McCaffery, chief executive of BancAmerica Robertson Stephens, said yesterday in explaining the decision to seek a new buyer for the subsidiary he leads.

description: They will chase him as if he were delivering the mail. Allan Houston will touch the ball, look up and find men trimmed in red and black all but gnawing at his leg.

Upton and Jeanette Gannon. Loving grandfather of Jeremy and Christian Turner. Reposing Glascott Funeral Home, 102-03 Metropolitan Ave., Forest Hills. Visiting Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM. title: Live Girls at City Hall: Strippers Protest Sex-Shop Law
description: Leather skirts, fishnet stockings and a pink feather boa were deployed on behalf of the First Amendment yesterday as about 30 strippers and lap dancers rallied in City Hall Park to protest Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's crackdown on sex shops and clubs.

title: Campaign Reform Countdown
description: As support for campaign finance reform legislation builds in the House of Representatives, the lawmakers who have not signed on to the cause are getting more conspicuous. Yesterday we listed the Republicans in the New York metropolitan area who have supported a campaign overhaul in principle but have refused to put their names on a petition to release the legislation from committee, where it has been bottled up by Speaker Newt Gingrich. Today we urge voters to press other holdouts of both parties in New York and elsewhere.

title: Critic's Notebook; My Year in Provence Last August
description: I WON'T be going back to Provence this year.

title: Racing The Kenyans
description: Kenyans took the top two positions in the men's division of the Boston Marathon on Monday, while the best American man finished 17th. Some organizers of American races have pointed to results like these to support the argument that we need to limit foreign runners so that more Americans can win prize money. But keeping Kenyans out of road races is not the answer to improving American performance in distance running.

title: ALBANY WILL PAY HEALTH INSURERS TO FREEZE RATES
description: The Pataki administration announced yesterday that it would bar health insurance companies from raising rates this year for tens of thousands of New Yorkers who buy their own health insurance, saying the state would turn over $110 million to the companies to offset costs.

title: I.B.M. Leads Dow Higher As Most Indexes Set Records
description: Major stock market indexes set new highs yesterday, buoyed by quarterly corporate earnings reports that largely exceeded analysts' reduced forecasts.

title: An environmental campaign is 'Back by popular neglect.'
description: ONE of the best-known, most-honored commercials ever -- the public service announcement in which an American Indian sheds a tear at the sight of a littered landscape -- is being revived in a manner meant to resonate with contemporary audiences.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METZGER, EDYTHE ZUCKERMAN
description: METZGER-Edythe Zuckerman, 79. Of Boca Raton, FL. on April 20, 1998. Beloved wife of Morton for fifty-nine Years; Loving mother of Karen (Howard) Ganz of Greenwich, CT and Buddy (Julie) Metzger of Savannah, GA; Devoted Grandmother of Beth and David Ganz, Dina and David Levi and Michael Metzger. Mrs. Metzger graduated Adelphia College in 1940. She was past president of Pleasantville League in Westchester County and a member of UJA's Lion of Judah. She was a founder of Albert Einstein CoM. Contributions may be made to Dr. Charles Vogel, C/O Cancer Research Network 1200 N. Federal Highway Hollywood, FL. 33020 or The Edythe and Morton Metzger Endowment Fund for the Center of Judaic Studies at the University of Pennsylvania, 420 Walnut Street Philadelphia, PA. 19106. Services 10:45AM Wednesday, April 22, 1998 at Gutterman-Warheit Memorial Chapel, Boca Raton, Florida, call 1-800-992-9262 for information.

title: TV Notes; Skewing the Sweeps
description: What if they gave a sweep month and nobody came?

title: FORSTMANN LITTLE TO CUT ITS GULFSTREAM STAKE IN HALF
description: Forstmann Little & Company plans to sell about half its stake in the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation, raising about $675 million before expenses. Combined with $888 million that Forstmann made in Gulfstream's 1996 initial public offering, the planned stock sales would bring the investment firm's total proceeds to almost $1.6 billion. Forstmann bought Gulfstream for $850 million in a 1990 leveraged buyout and will still control 16.73 million shares -- worth about $751 million -- after the latest sale. The proposed sale, disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, comes as Gulfstream shares have risen 53 percent this year. Shares of Gulfstream dropped on news of the stock sale, falling $1.9375 to close at $44.875.

title: Koch Industries Is Buying Polyester Unit of Hoechst
description: Koch Industries, one of the nation's largest privately held companies, said yesterday that it was forming a joint venture to acquire the bulk of the assets of Trevira, the worldwide polyester business of Hoechst A.G., the German chemical and health care giant.

title: Doing the Math: In the Schools, Promotion Plan Starts to Sink In
description: This was one math problem that Mariel Carrero, age 10, had little difficulty figuring out.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KIRKHAM, RICHARD GEORGE
description: KIRKHAM-Richard George. Born in Hartford CT, June 5, 1931. Died Coral Gables FL, April 19, 1998. Survived by his sister Elizabeth Buckley of Eliot ME, and his longtime business partner and great friend Robert Houseman. A graduate of the Chicago Institute of Art, Richard Kirkham founded Kirk Brummel & Associates, an interior design resources firm renowned for its innovative designs, with Michael Brummel in 1966. Through his second company, Raintree Designs, he was the first to introduce the fabrics and wall coverings of Laura Ashley to the U.S. Visitation: Thursday, April 23, 2-5 and 7-9PM, Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. Funeral 9:45 AM Friday, April 24, at St. Vincent Ferrer R.C. Church, Lexington & 66th. No flowers; contributions to the American Cancer Society, 19 West 56 St, NYC 10019.

title: Polygram's Earnings Fall 88% in Quarter
description: Polygram N.V. said here today that earnings fell 88 percent in the first quarter, a steeper drop than expected. Its results were hurt by a shortage of new popular-music releases and by large provisions for bad debts in Asia.

title: Eager Williams Puts Nets to Work
description: When the Nets arrived here on Monday to prepare for their opening-round playoff series with the Chicago Bulls, John Calipari gathered the players for a meeting, detailing what he expected from them. But what he did not expect was what happened when he finished the meeting and sent them to their rooms.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks Hit Records As I.B.M. Pulls Dow Up

title: Food Stuff
description: Coal-Oven Pizza Near Carnegie Hall

title: Indonesia Raises Key Interest Rates
description: Indonesia raised key interest rates to as much as 50 percent, risking a deepening recession to bolster its currency and check runaway inflation. The widely expected rate increase was in line with policies pushed by the International Monetary Fund, which is considering resuming payments from a $40 billion bailout. The increase threatens, however, to bring more pain for the country's overextended companies, put more banks out of business, raise unemployment and fuel social unrest.

title: Hampton Leaves Quietly, But Wishes He Left Sooner
description: The Giants had hoped to avoid offending another veteran player as they remade their core and dumped their heftiest salaries. But like Dave Brown before him, Rodney Hampton exited yesterday wishing the team had cut him a few months earlier.

title: Fouling Iran's Airwaves
description: To the Editor:

title: Underdog Senators Showing Confidence
description: The Devils finished the regular season with 107 points and the Eastern Conference title. The eighth-place Ottawa Senators were a distant speck in their rearview mirror with 83 points.

title: A South African Black On a Road Never Traveled
description: OF all the enterprises in apartheid-ruled South Africa, none was whiter than the wine business. Of the 4,400 grape-growing members of the giant South African Cooperative Winegrowers Association, not a single one was black. Of the 250 small independent producers, not a single one was black.

title: I.B.M. to Introduce A Much Faster Chip
description: I.B.M. says it has developed a microprocessor that will make its supercomputers five times as powerful as Deep Blue, which beat the chess champion Garry Kasparov.

title: City Study Sees Big Revenues If Yankees Play in Manhattan
description: In yet another sign that the Giuliani administration sees Manhattan as the future home of the New York Yankees, a new study by city planners suggests that a new stadium on the West Side would have an economic impact worth at least $1 billion a year, more than 10 times the impact of a renovated or new stadium in the Bronx.

title: Seoul Won't Seek Japan Funds for War's Brothel Women
description: The South Korean Government said today that it would end its efforts to win compensation from the Japanese Government for South Korean women forced into Japanese military brothels in World War II.

title: Jays Find Wrong Side Of Williams In the 10th
description: Maintaining his left-handed swing is hard work to Bernie Williams, like heavy-duty geometry; sometimes he's got it, and sometimes he doesn't. But no matter how poorly or well he is swinging from the left side, his right-handed swing is always right.

title: The Minimalist; Thai Chicken, Fast and Tangy
description: ONE of my favorite dishes on a winter visit to Bangkok, Thailand, was chicken in a creamy but spicy lime sauce. I first thought the rich texture came from a pan reduction or a bechamel-like sauce. Then I detected the faint taste of coconut and realized it was little more than coconut milk spiked with lime.

title: BEHIND THE BATTLE FOR RUSSIAN POST, ECONOMIC CONTROL
description: The shadowy battle over the future of the Russian Government has burst into the open as a struggle that is less about ideology, Boris Yeltsin's health or even the qualifications of his choice for Prime Minister than about who will control economic policy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AARONSON, MICHAEL
description: AARONSON-Michael. The faculty and staff of the Ruttenberg Cancer Center, Mount Sinai School of Medicine wish to express their sympathy for the loss of Michael Aaronson, father of our colleague and friend, Stuart A. Aaronson.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Wish You Were Here; Marxist Cuba Beckons, And U.S. Capitalists Champ at the Bit
description: Last month, two Caterpillar Inc. executives had the kind of face-to-face meeting with a national leader that salesmen dream about -- except the leader was Fidel Castro, and they weren't allowed to sell him anything.

title: Gardner Dickinson, 70, Golfer And a Founder of Senior Tour
description: Gardner Dickinson, a founder of the Senior PGA Tour, a standout in Ryder Cup events and a seven-time winner on the PGA Tour with a knack for teaching other golfers, died on Sunday at his home in Tequesta, Fla. He was 70.

title: BBA IN $291 MILLION DEAL FOR INTERNATIONAL PAPER UNIT
description: The British engineering company BBA Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Veratec, a maker of nonwoven fabrics, from the International Paper Company for about $291 million. Veratec makes fabrics for a range of applications in the consumer and industrial markets. It has plants in the United States, Canada, Mexico, Hong Kong, Belgium and Japan. According to BBA, the business has annual sales of $250 million. International Paper, based in Purchase, N.Y., is a forest and paper-products concern. Its stock rose $1.875 a share, to $55.1875.

title: I Am Woman, Hear Me Expound
description: The essence of African violet mingled with sandalwood at Radio City Music Hall on Monday as the rhythm-and-blues singer Erykah Badu preached her mysteries. The fragrances drifted from the stage, where she had lighted incense, and met those worn by audience members to evoke the Afrocentric aura of black bohemianism. This atmosphere spanned earth and sky, embracing the physical world in the context of the cosmic.

title: TV Notes; CBS Drops Bradley
description: After 10 months, the CBS news experiment with Bill Bradley as a commentator on the weekend evening news has been abandoned.

title: GENERAL GROWTH TO BUY 8 SHOPPING CENTERS FROM MEPC
description: The shopping-mall giant General Growth Properties Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire eight shopping centers from the British investment company MEPC P.L.C. for $871 million. General Growth, based in Chicago, owns or manages 106 shopping malls, totaling 81 million square feet, in 37 states. Late last year, MEPC, based in London, said it would shed all of its American and Australian properties.

title: Lower Crude Oil Prices Cut Into Profit for Amoco and Exxon
description: Lower crude oil prices depressed the first-quarter earnings of the Amoco Corporation and the Exxon Corporation, and Amoco said yesterday that it would cut its capital and exploration budget by 8 percent this year.

title: Whitman Moves to Resolve Impasse on Auto Insurance
description: Gov. Christine Todd Whitman moved today to break a potential deadlock between the State Assembly and the Senate on auto insurance legislation.

title: Plea Expected From Mother in Infant's Death
description: With Delaware prosecutors ready to present her high school boyfriend as a central witness, Amy S. Grossberg is on the verge of accepting their plea offer and avoiding trial on charges that she murdered her newborn son in 1996.

description: USUALLY, George Lang walks as fast as he talks. But one morning recently, as he wended his way through the labyrinth of kitchens at the Plaza Hotel, this 73-year-old restaurant consultant and restaurateur lacked his usual speed and automatic best-foot-forwardism. Memory can be weighty.
