title: I.M.F. Loans to Rights Violators Are Attacked in Congress
description: Every year, the State Department's human rights report dwells at length on Indonesia's many forms of political repression, from its use of torture and killings to silence dissenters to its widespread military control of East Timor.

title: Troupe's Classical Training Displayed in Its 'Swan Lake'
description: Two weekend matinee performances of ''Swan Lake'' by the Universal Ballet at City Center were neatly and conscientiously danced. But in both cases the overall result tended to be a display of Classical schooling rather than the telling of a poignant fairy tale.

title: TV Notes; The Invisible Bunyan
description: From makeup to wigs to scenery, opera usually depends on elaborate illusion. But Benjamin Britten's ''Paul Bunyan'' is not your usual opera. So it is getting an unusual television production tonight on PBS's ''Live from Lincoln Center.''

title: Commercial Real Estate; As Stock Market Climbs Higher, So Do the Offices of Brokers
description: It has not taken LaSalle Partners long to find a tenant for some of the space in Citicorp Center that the law firm Willkie Farr & Gallagher is giving up. Willkie Farr is leaving 160,000 square feet and moving to 787 Seventh Avenue, at 51st Street, this summer.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBS, MARIANNE K.
description: JACOBS-Marianne K. On April 19, 1998 in her 89th year. Beloved wife of the late Louis Jacobs. Dear mother of John and mother-in-law of Susan Jacobs. Adored grandmother of Jeffrey and Lori. Services Wednesday, April 22, 12 noon at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: EQUITY INNS TO PURCHASE RFS HOTEL FOR $660 MILLION
description: Equity Inns Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire RFS Hotel Investors Inc. for $660 million in stock and $330 million in assumed debt. Equity and RFS, both based in Memphis, are real estate investment trusts that own and manage hotels. The acquisition will add 61 hotels from RFS to Equity's current portfolio of 95 hotels. The agreement calls for Equity Inns to issue 1.5 shares for each share of RFS, valuing RFS shares at about $23. Shares of RFS Hotel rose $1.25, to $20.75, while Equity Inns fell 56.25 cents, to $14.8125. If the average stock price of Equity exceeds $17 a share during a measurement period, the share exchange ratio will be adjusted to provide RFS shareholders with $25.50 in Equity stock for each RFS share.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, SIDNEY
description: SCHNEIDER-Sidney. On April 20. Of NY and Florida. Beloved by his wife Shirley, his daughters Leslee & Maxine, and his grandchildren, Jennifer, Stephanie and Michael. Services at Schwartz Chapel, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck on Friday, April 24 at noon.

title: Calling Itself a Healing Center, Defiant Marijuana Club Reopens
description: After a brief court-ordered closing, this city's most famous medical marijuana club reopened today under a new name and director, once again thwarting efforts by the California Attorney General to shut it down.

title: State Board Is Scheduled To Vote on Lilco Bonds
description: Today could be a crucial day in Gov. George E. Pataki's efforts to take over the Long Island Lighting Company's electricity service.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEE, DAVID
description: LEE-David. The Board and staff of the Joint Passover Assoc. of the City of New York mourns the passing of David Lee, beloved spouse of our long time Board member, Gertrude Lee. Gert's devotion and energy was directed toward caring for David in recent years, but she never forgot her ties to JPA and found time to continue her fund raising efforts on behalf of needy Jews. To Gert and to her family, we offer our love and deepest sympathy. Michael Stoler, President

title: The Rush to Finance Stadiums
description: Baseball fans and New Yorkers who appreciate the place the Yankees and Mets occupy in lore and in the city's social history wholeheartedly support Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's goal of insuring that both remain within the city limits. But the method the Mayor selected to signal that desire on Monday is quite worrisome. His plan to open the city's tax vaults and place nearly $600 million in commercial rent tax revenue on the negotiating table for stadium financing is premature. It could also damage the city's bargaining position with club owners. More important, there is no immutable law that says stadium financing deals must be heavily sweetened with public subsidies or taxpayer support in any form.

title: A Renewed Secular Passion Is Gripping Iranians: Soccer
description: Sixty thousand fans showed up at Azadi Stadium on Monday night to cheer on the Iranian soccer team, which has qualified for the World Cup for the first time in 20 years. Skydivers parachuted into the stadium, smoke bombs rained from the stands, and two fans nicknamed Mustache and Tarzan prompted rhythmic chanting, using horns the way cheerleaders use megaphones.

title: LEGG MASON IS NEGOTIATING TO ACQUIRE A HEDGE FUND
description: Legg Mason Inc. said yesterday that it was in talks to buy a hedge fund because wealthy clients wanted investments that could protect them if financial markets declined. Edward Taber, head of the brokerage's asset management unit, said the firm, which he declined to name, had ''well over'' $1 billion in assets under management. Talks, in an advanced stage, could fall apart, he said. Legg Mason, with $70 billion in assets, is eager to buy a hedge fund to help clients insure their profits after the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index tripled in the last six years. Hedge funds can buy shares, bet against companies and invest in options that could limit losses, among other things, to make money when markets rise or fall.

title: Fire Destroys Famed Monastery in the Himalayas
description: The Taktsang Monastery in Bhutan, one of the oldest and best known shrines in the Himalayan Buddhist world outside Tibet, was destroyed by fire on Sunday night, Bhutanese officials said yesterday.

title: Final Move? Ninth Free Agent Signed
description: The Jets made their ninth, and most likely final move in the college free-agent market yesterday by signing the Navy defensive end David Viger.

title: Baby Is Shot, and Raw Doubts Haunt South Africa
description: As the tiny white wooden coffin was carried down the aisle at the civic center here today, thousands of mourners crowded in to sing the slow, sad hymns that were once such a familiar part of South Africa's liberation struggle.

title: About New York; A Memorial to a Misunderstood Dog
description: TRAY was The Man,'' Junior Felix decreed as he mopped the dark stairway of a beat-up apartment building on East 159th Street in the Bronx. ''He showed mad love. He never used to flip. He just The Man.''

title: America's New Golden Harvest
description: CINDY MAJOR still winces remembering her first encounter with Steven Jenkins, who was then the cheese buyer for Dean & DeLuca.

description: FEBER-Rose. You were a gentle and loving lady, we will miss you very much. Graveside services Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, LI today at 1:30 PM.

description: RICHARDS-Harold J., 93, April 20, 1998. Most beloved husband for seventy years of Pam Spingarn, brother of Irving S. Richards, and the late Morton and Florence Lipton. Loving father of Nancy Richards Osman, and Peter S. Richards, cherished grandfather of Deborah Osman Fieber, Elizabeth A. Osman, Susannah Richards, and Alexandra Richards, great grandfather of Brian, Gregory, Sarah, and Jeffrey Daniel Fieber, and Matthew MacGregor. Graduate of The University of Pennsylvania Wharton School, 1925. No services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAHN, RUTH STEIN
description: KAHN-Ruth Stein. Beloved wife of Abraham, devoted mother of Randy, and Barbara Stewart, loving grandmother of Stacey, Lisa, Robin, and Laurel. Funeral services at The Riverside, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, on Tuesday, April 21, at 10:30 A.M.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TYRRELL, ANNABEL K.
description: TYRRELL-Annabel K. Died on Wednesday, April 15, at Oysterponds Manor, Orient, NY. She was born in 1911 to Takeji and Mary Kusanobu in New York City. A 1984 graduate of Smith College, she also studied at the Sorbonne in Paris. Before joining the staff of the United Nations Secretariat she was an editor at Oxford University Press, New York. She married Arthur Clifford Tyrrell in 1953. They lived in New York City, except for four years in Sydney, Australia, in the mid-1960's when Arthur represented the United Nations there. After his retirement they moved to Orient, New York. Arthur died in 1988. A memorial service in Orient will be announced later.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEARNS, VIRGINIA DAVENPORT
description: STEARNS-Virginia Davenport, widow of Hal H. Stearns, died April 19 in Seattle, WA. She was beloved by many friends and relatives who will greatly miss her participation in the NYC community, her special style and her wonderful sense of humor. Memorial donations may be sent to the East Side House Settlement, 337 Alexander Ave, Bronx, NY 10454 or the Manhattan Eye, Ear & Throat Hospital, 210 East 64th Street, NYC 10021. The Homrighausen, Mahon and the Woodyatt families will miss her love and friendship and extend condolences to her brothers.

title: Clinton Derides G.O.P. Tax-Break Plan as Boon for Rich and Threat to Schools
description: President Clinton lambasted the Senate Republicans' centerpiece proposal on education today, calling the plan for tax breaks a hollow gesture that would favor the rich and ignore the poor.

title: Administration Tries to Bar Testimony by Secret Service
description: Invoking a novel and untested legal theory, the Clinton Administration formally interceded in court today to block the Whitewater independent counsel from questioning Secret Service agents about what they saw and heard as bodyguards for the President, law-enforcement officials said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAGRO, JOHN L.
description: MAGRO-John L. Of Camden, ME. Loving husband and devoted father. Died Saturday, April 18, 1998 in Camden. He is survived by his wife, Nancy P. Magro; five children, Susan Pfeil of New Canaan, Connecticut; Jonathan Magro of Cincinnati, Ohio; Nancy L. Magro of Brookline, Massachusetts; Victoria Pfeil of Cincinnati, Ohio; Benjamin Magro of Union, Maine; nine grandchildren; a sister, Mary Wilder of Harpers Ferry, West Virginia; sister-in-law, Alice Magro of Sanford, Florida and his aunt, Lena Nasca of Silver Spring, Maryland. The Burial Service will be held at the Sea View Cemetery in Rockport, Maine on Wednesday, April 22, at 11:00. A memorial service will be held at the Indian Hill Church, Cincinnati, Ohio, 4:30, May 3, 1998. The family requests that memorial contributions be made to the John L. Magro ItalianAmerican Artist Fund, Cincinnati Opera/Music Hall, 1241 Elm Street, Cincinnati, Ohio 45210 (attention to: Nicholas Muni). For more information, contact Laite & Pratt Funeral Home, Nine Mountain Street, Camden.

title: Wine Talk; In Tuscany, Rules Are Meant to Be Broken
description: FOR almost a thousand years, some of Italy's finest wines have come from the Chianti region of Tuscany. Has that satisfied the Tuscans? No. They have been constantly tinkering with them, and these days, they don't even call some of their best wines Chianti; they are referred to as Super-Tuscans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOK, JOHN MILLER 'JACK'
description: COOK-John Miller 'Jack'. On April 20, 1998. Of Bethlehem, Penn. Age 70. Cook served as Executive Director of Northampton County Development Corp., Easton, Penn., from 1985 until 1997. He was previously employed in the Transportation Department of the Bethlehem Steel Corp. for 34 years at various locations in Bethlehem, Buffalo, Johnstown, Pittsburgh and Baltimore. He graduated from M.I.T. in 1949 and attended Baltimore Law School. Memorial services will be 4:00 PM, Friday, First Presbyterian Church, Bethlehem, PA. Information, contact Pearson Funeral Home, 1901 Linden St., Bethlehem. In lieu of flowers, the family requests memorials be sent to First Presbyterian Church, 2344 Center Street, Bethlehem, PA 18017, or the Jack Cook Memorial Scholarship Fund, C/O Pennsylvania Economic Development Association, 908 North Second Street, Harrisburg, PA. 17102.

title: Granadilla Journal; The Ghost of Old Spain Stirs and Welcomes Visits
description: The towering stone castle defended this walled hilltop village for five centuries but it was no match for the Government, which built a large dam, flooded the surrounding farmland and made Granadilla a ghost town.

title: Gore Asks Chemical Industry To Test for Any Toxic Effects
description: The Clinton Administration today asked chemical companies to test thousands of common chemicals and disclose their toxicity, threatening to require the tests if the companies do not comply voluntarily.

title: Clean but Not Safe
description: Donna Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, wanted it both ways this week. She announced that Federal money would not be used for programs that distribute clean needles to addicts. But she offered only a halfhearted defense of that decision, even stating that while the Clinton Administration would not finance such programs, it supported them in theory.

title: U.S. Offers China Incentive on Sanctions
description: Encouraged by the release of the noted dissident Wang Dan, the United States is offering to lift some sanctions imposed on China after the 1989 crackdown in Tiananmen Square.

title: Stifling Student Newspaper Sends a Bad Message
description: To the Editor:

title: Stock Exchange Weighs Move to Battery Park City
description: Applying new pressure in its bid to expand in lower Manhattan, the New York Stock Exchange has told city officials that it is prepared to leave its historic headquarters on Wall Street and move to a new building in Battery Park City.

title: Sponsor of Immigrant Charged With Raping Her
description: A Pennsylvania man surrendered to the authorities yesterday after a Queens grand jury charged him with raping an immigrant from Korea whom he had sponsored into the country, the Queens District Attorney's office said.

title: U.S. Deficit in March Lower Than Forecast
description: The United States posted a smaller than expected budget deficit in March as the growing economy helped the Government reap tax dollars -- keeping Washington on course for the first annual surplus since the 1969 fiscal year.

title: A Thorny Atonalist, 60, Says: Enjoy
description: Concertgoers who disdain new music have long regarded Charles Wuorinen as a fearsome atonalist, and from a certain perspective they are probably right. Still, Mr. Wuorinen clearly has a following -- some of it perhaps from the ballet world, which in recent years has adopted several of his rhythmically vital scores -- and when the New York New Music Ensemble celebrated his 60th birthday with a concert at the Kaye Playhouse on Monday evening, a large audience was on hand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, JACK
description: GOLDSTEIN - Jack. Fifty - three years. On April 12, 1998. Beloved brother, uncle and friend. Devoted attorney in private practice in New York City. Greatly loved for his humanity and humor. He leaves a deep void in our lives.

title: Chase and Citicorp Report Higher First-Quarter Profits
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation and Citicorp reported higher first-quarter earnings yesterday, led by trading and corporate banking, while big regional banks such as the Banc One Corporation and Wells Fargo & Company said fee income strengthened results. All met or beat estimates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIOTT, BARBARA
description: ELLIOTT-Barbara. The Board of Directors and the staff of the Isamu Noguchi Foundation, Inc. extend their deepest sympathy to trustee Donald Elliott for the loss of his wife, Barbara. We shall miss her as will the musical world which she so passionately supported. Our thoughts and prayers are with Donald and his family. Isaac Shapiro, President

title: Mets Revert to Poor Clutch Hitting and Are Shut Out
description: Call it a reversion to form. One game after pounding out season highs of 16 hits and 14 runs in Cincinnati, the Mets' hitters were back to their old selves at Shea Stadium last night.

title: Mining Music and Law For Original Meanings
description: How do we interpret something that was created long ago? Here is one answer: Put yourself into the thoughts of those long-ago creators. Reinvent the tools they used. Examine the people for whom they created. Do so, and you will have products pure, robust and uncontaminated by the subsequent passage of time.

title: Con Ed to Help Rebuild Queens Church Destroyed in Blast
description: In a settlement that precludes criminal charges, Consolidated Edison has agreed to pay more than $3 million to help rebuild a Flushing church destroyed in a 1996 gas explosion, the Queens District Attorney's office announced yesterday.

description: SZEKERES-Janos. Of Stamford, Connecticut. On April 20, 1998, at his home. Survived by his wife Erna Biller Szekeres, 2 daughters, Eva Levine and Andrea Szekeres, a sister Katalin Stapelfeldt, also four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held Sunday, April 26th, 4PM at the Unitarian Church of Westport, 10 Lyons Plains Rd, Wesport, CT. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Salvation Army, Stamford, CT. or the Stamford Museum and Nature Center, Stamford, Connecticut.

title: U.N. Panel Defeats U.S. Move to Censure Cuba on Human Rights
description: An effort led by the United States to rebuke Cuba for its human rights practices was voted down today by the United Nations Human Rights Commission.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUGER, DR. BERNARD
description: ZUGER-Dr. Bernard. On April 19, age 92. Practicing pediatrician and psychiatrist in New York City for more than 60 years. Born in Ludmir, Russia, on September 20, 1905. Son of Mendel and Adell. Brother of Max, Ira and Joe. Graduate of Columbia College and Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons. Clinical Associate Professor of Psychiatry at New York University Medical School. Husband of Miriam Troop Zuger. Father of Abigail Zuger. A memorial will be announced.

title: Temptation; Dainty Cookies With a Sneaky Crunch
description: THEY look rich, white and innocent. The pristine little cookies seem like the sort of thing you should eat with white-gloved hands while sipping tea out of bone china cups. Dainty, thin and ladylike, they certainly don't look like much fun.

title: $25 and Under; Korean Dishes, Mild or Fiery, in a Quaint Setting
description: ON entering the spare, bright dining room of Bo, where colorful antique quilts adorn the white walls and classical music plays softly in the background, it would be easy to believe that you've stepped into a quaint American parlor. But no, this is Kissena Boulevard in Flushing, Queens, just a block from the Long Island Expressway, and Bo is a Korean restaurant, though a very unusual one.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRAGER, JACK (YANKEL)
description: FRAGER-Jack (Yankel). On March 7, 1998 at 95, peacefully in his sleep after a long decline. Born in the Ukraine, he witnessed the Russian Revolution, escaped the Civil War at 18, arriving in the U.S.A. in 1923. He was: a lifelong anarchist, served on Committee to save Sacco and Vanzetti, spoke nationally, helped found the Libertarian Book Club, etc; a tireless trade unionist and reformer who taught labor history at Brookwood Labor College; an anti-war activist arrested repeatedly, in War Resisters League and Broward County Anti-Nuclear Committee. Devoted nurturer of Yiddish culture, on the Editorial Board of the Freie Arbiter Schtimme, member League for Yiddish, founder Sunrise Yiddish Culture Club. Wife Myra died 1985. Survived by three children: Michelle Louise, Sholom Dwight, and Cheshire Emily and their spouses, John Bellidori, Louise Frager, and Jerry Rotondi; four grandchildren: Shoshannah, Tam, Lincoln, and Rebecca Frager; and great grandson, Caleb Frager. Beloved uncle of Paul and Mannie Schweisberg. Contributions may be sent to the Alzheimer's Association. Memorial on June 9 at Brecht Forum.

title: Brothers in Devotion, Ecstatic and Mystical
description: When Mehr and Sher Ali led their group at the Asia Society on Sunday night, their concert spanned miles, cultures and centuries. The Alis, who are brothers, sing qawwali, the ecstatic devotional music of the Sufis (mystical Muslims), and on Sunday their program included songs from the 13th century and from the 17th century, in assorted languages from Persian to Punjabi to Purbi, an Indian language that predates Urdu.

title: Corrections

As the article noted, the decision affects the Quicken personal finance program; Intuit will continue to produce its tax program, Macintax.

title: Topics of The Times; Irresponsible Tax Amendment
description: The House is scheduled to vote today on a pernicious amendment to the Constitution that would require two-thirds majorities in each house before Congress could pass a tax hike. It purports to assure fiscal rectitude -- preventing Congress from lazily spending money and passing the cost on to taxpayers. In fact, the amendment would shift control of budget policy to a small minority.

title: Liberties; Prettier Than Barbie
description: It was an embarrassing week.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAISEL, ROSE
description: MAISEL-Rose. On April 20, 1998. Adored wife of the late Milton; loving mother of Jay and Diane, Howard and Joan; devoted grandmother of Mark, Jill, Steven, Miriam, David and Jennifer; dear great-grandmother of Matthew, Sydney, Aaron, Lauren, Jared, Michael and Jessie. She leaves a legacy of goodness, extraordinary grace and dignity.

title: Corrections

Gul Mohammad of Delhi, India, who at 22.5 inches held the distinction in the 1998 edition of the Guinness Book of World Records, died late last year. Guinness said this week that it had not determined a successor.

Berman. Adored father-in-law of Frank Barnett and Janet Ziff. Dear brother of Calie Loss and Jeanette Richman. Loving grandfather of four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Contributions to a favorite charity would be appreciated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLLIN, MICHAEL
description: WOLLIN-Michael. A retired Civil Court Judge in Kings County, died on April 17 in Oxford, New York. He was 83 and a former resident of Brooklyn. Mr. Wollin was born in Brooklyn and worked his way through college and Brooklyn Law School. After a thirty year career in private practice, he served as both Deputy Public Administrator and Public Administrator of Kings County. He served as a Civil Court Judge for nine years, following which he returned to private practice. In his last years, Mr. Wollin had suffered from Alzheimer's disease. Donations may be made to the Alzheimer's Association, 420 Lexington Avenue, Suite 610, New York, New York 10170.

title: Sports of The Times; The Ali Shuffle Is Not Lost!
description: A JEWISH Home for the Aged, peopled mainly by Holocaust survivors, was in danger of closing its doors in Upper Manhattan for lack of money. A spot on the television news described the plight. Soon after, a call was received at the home. ''This is Muhammad Ali,'' the voice said, ''and I want to donate a hundred thousand dollars so the old folks don't have to move out.'' The director of the home, who answered the phone, believed it to be a crank call and hung up.

description: Intimate Dining

title: 5 Airlines Given New Rights, Adding Better Service to Small Cities
description: The Transportation Department today gave two small airlines permission to fly to La Guardia Airport and let three airlines add 20 flights at O'Hare International Airport in Chicago to help competition and provide better service to small cities.

title: Putting the 'Nazi' Into Doctors
description: With chilling efficiency, the Israeli documentary ''Healing by Killing'' chronicles the subversive process that turned German health care professionals into Nazi doctors. In this process it finds the seeds of genocide, as the patients became prisoners and the Hippocratic oath became a travesty. Step by step, this businesslike account traces the progress of medical horror and explores the erosion of these doctors' ethics and independence. The film's matter-of-fact format belies the institutionalized depravity it describes.

description: NEWS

title: Astronomers Say a Disk of Dust Holds a Clue to Birth of Planets
description: Astronomers exploring celestial life cycles have caught glimpses of stars in birth and in death. They are well acquainted with the Sun as a star with a family of planets, and in the last three years, they have learned that other stars also have planets. Now, broadening their perspective, astronomers think they are seeing strong evidence of planets forming around young adult stars.

description: The newcomers Scott Brosius and Chuck Knoblauch have noticed that the Yankees don't dwell on success, even when they have every right to do so. Tonight, they thrashed Roger Clemens, completed a three-game sweep of Toronto, and won, 9-1, for the 11th time in 12 games. Afterward, there were no high-fives, no ear-splitting music in the clubhouse.

title: Siemens Profit News Puts Outlook in Doubt
description: The German electronics giant Siemens A.G. posted weaker-than-expected profit growth in the first half of its fiscal year, startling analysts and casting doubt over the company's ability to reach its full-year profit target. Siemens said yesterday that its net income for the six months that ended on March 31 rose 10 percent, to 1.19 billion marks ($665.1 million) -- well below forecasts of 1.28 billion marks. Sales rose 17 percent, to 52.1 billion marks ($29.1 billion).

The Japan that could once do no wrong has morphed into the Japan that can do no right, with every effort to turn around the lagging economy dismissed as too little, too late. ''This is a market that sees only bad news,'' said Richard Medley, managing partner of Medley Global Associates in New York.

He cited tobacco contributions made to Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato as an example of the problem.

title: AT LUNCH WITH: Tori Amos; Disclosing Intimacies, Enjoying the Shock Value
description: Tori Amos takes pains with her image. As she rehearsed for her appearance on ''The Late Show with David Letterman'' a few weeks ago, she had her keyboard and piano moved to improve the camera angle, then pondered just how high her microphone should be tilted. After she raised it and noted the exact level for the stage crew, a bystander asked whether lifting her head improved her vocals. ''It's never about the music,'' she said with a laugh. ''It's about the chin!''

title: America Online Libel Suit Dismissed
description: In a decision that was heartening for Internet access providers, a Federal judge today dismissed a libel suit brought against America Online by a high-ranking aide to President Clinton. But the judge let stand a similar suit against Matt Drudge, the cyberspace gossip commentator.

title: Blair Defends His Decision To Accept Atom Material
description: Faced with an outcry from political opponents, environmental groups and Scottish interests, Prime Minister Tony Blair today defended a decision to store and reprocess nuclear material in Scotland from an old Soviet reactor.

title: An Equal Chance
description: Now that the results are in, some opponents of affirmative action are having second thoughts. One year after California passed a referendum banning the use of race and ethnicity in public college admissions, the number of blacks, Hispanics and American Indians admitted to the University of California's two top campuses has dropped precipitously, leading to concern about the resegregation of higher education.

title: NATIONAL CITY BANCSHARES TO EXPAND IN INDIANA
description: National City Bancshares Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Hoosier Hills Financial Corporation for about $32 million in stock. National City's shares closed yesterday at $44, up 6.25 cents. Hoosier is the holding company for Ripley County Bank of eastern Indiana, which has three offices and total assets of $109 million. National City, based in Evansville, Ind., operates 13 banks with 44 branches in Indiana, Illinois and Kentucky. The company said the acquisition would help it expand into eastern Indiana. The company had total assets of $1.29 billion as of Dec. 31.

description: Two advertising organizations have bestowed their annual awards.

title: NOW Won't Back Appeal Of Jones Lawsuit Dismissal
description: The National Organization for Women said today that it would not support the appeal of Paula Corbin Jones's sexual misconduct lawsuit against President Clinton, saying that her claim against the President was legally weak and tainted by right-wing politics.

title: Sizing Up the N.B.A. Playoffs
description: Can Michael Jordan repeat the three-peat and win a sixth title? Have Karl Malone and John Stockton learned their finals lessons? And will Shaquille O'Neal be filming or dunking in June? With the notion that inquiring hoop minds want to know, here's a cursory guide to the National Basketball Association playoffs, which begin on tonight with four first-round series. While the Bulls, Jazz and Sonics should advance easily, Miami, Indiana and San Antonio will be lucky to survive in five games. Chicago should get out of the East with minimal mileage, but the Bulls farewell-tour bus will eventually be overturned in Salt Lake City.

Through Kurt's generosity, vision and leadership as Executive Chairman of Shaare Zedek Hospital Foundation in Canada and his tenure as a member of the Medical Center's National Board and International Board of Governors, the people of Israel, the ''Hospital with a Heart'' and countless Israeli-based organizations have greatly benefitted. Also dining were early reviewers and snoops from the insatiable food and gossip press. ''Aren't there any civilians here?'' said one. Tucked into banquettes, the lighting caressing them with kindness, they laughed and clawed and tasted, exchanging forks and meaningful glances and the occasional luxuriant sigh.

The merger is expected to be completed in the fourth quarter and will be structured as a pooling of interests for accounting purposes. Old Kent will pay 12.2 million shares for First Evergreen, which is based in Evergreen Park, Ill. Old Kent expects to take one-time merger-related charges of about $25 million. The combined company is expected have a market capitalization of more than $4 billion. Old Kent Financial is a bank holding company based in Grand Rapids, Mich., with assets of $14.2 billion and 114 mortgage lending sites in 27 states.

Dartmouth dethroned last year's champion, the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, which fell to third behind Dartmouth and the New Jersey Institute of Technology in Newark.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NEUMILLER, THOMAS G.
description: NEUMILLER-Thomas G. Professor of Theatre Arts at the State University at Stony Brook, died on April 22, 1998 at his residence in Stony Brook, NY. He was 61 years old, the cause of death was cancer. He was born January 5, 1937, to Harry J. Neumiller and Grace Gridley Meumiller in Peoria, Illinois where he attended Peoria High School. He received a B.A. degree from Knox College, Galesburg, Illinois, and an M.F.A. from the Yale Drama School where he studied stage direction. Upon graduation from college in 1959, he was awarded a Fulbright Scholarship and attended the Free University of West Berlin, Germany, where he studied theatre history. As an officer in U.S. Army Military Intelligence he was stationed in Stuttgart, Germany, where he was officer-in-charge of the Soviet Orientation Team which toured U.S. Army bases in Germany. He was discharged at the rank of captain. He taught theatre at Wheelock College, Boston, for four years. At SUNY Stony Brook he taught acting and directing and staged plays and operas for twenty-eight years before retiring in 1997 as Professor Emeritus. In affiliation with Stony Brook University he started the Stony Brook Summer Playhouse for which he served as Artistic Director for ten years. As a member of Actors' Equity Association he also worked in professional theatre. In the summer of 1966 he was a member of the Bayreuth Festival Master Classes, Bayreuth, Germany, where he studied opera production. He was a member of the American Institute for Verdi Studies, New York University. In 1997, the Tom Neumiller Opera Research Collection was established from material he donated to the S.B. University Libraries. He was a collector of posters, particularly performing arts posters; his collection will be housed at and exhibited by the Lakeview Museum in Peoria. Surviving are two brothers, Harry J. Neumiller, Jr. of Galesburg, Illinois and C. Richard (Dick) Neumiller of Peoria. Also surviving are five nieces and two nephews, one grand niece and two grand nephews. Cremation will be private with a memorial service held at the SUNY Stony Brook at a later date. Funeral O.B. Davis Funeral Homes, 4839 Nesconset Highway (Route 347) Port Jefferson Station, NY. Memorial gifts may be sent to Long Island Gay and Lesbian Youth, Inc. (LIGALY), 32 West Main Street, Bay Shore, New York 11706.

title: CIGNA INCREASES ITS SHARE REPURCHASE PROGRAM

The split, which was announced in February, affects shareholders of record on May 4, with trading on a post-split basis starting on May 18. Shareholders voted in favor of raising authorized common shares to 600 million from 200 million. Cigna currently has 72 million shares outstanding. Its board also declared a dividend of 86 cents a pre-split share, which will be paid July 10 to shareholders of record as of June 12. description: Gov. George E. Pataki today won approval for the biggest municipal bond issue ever, a crucial step in the long-elusive takeover of the Long Island Lighting Company, and vowed to complete the takeover in a few weeks.

title: Top Honors Won By Leo Burnett
description: The Leo Burnett Company in Chicago took top honors with two awards, including the $100,000 prize for general excellence, at the 17th annual M.P.A. Kelly Awards competition sponsored by the Magazine Publishers of America.

title: Yale Coach Has Second Career as Touring Pro
description: Not having taken up the game until she was 15 and then struggling to break 90 at Yale, Heather Daly-Donofrio was more notable for her academic performance than for her golf game when she graduated with honors in 1991.

title: INSIDE
description: Disclosure on Tobacco

title: Red Army Faction Disbands, Saying Its Cause Is 'Now History'
description: Heroes unto themselves, but reviled and once feared by the bulk of Germans, the last remaining urban guerrillas of the Red Army Faction announced this week that they had dissolved their organization because they and their cause were ''now history.''

title: Where Hawaiians Discover Paradise
description: Where do Hawaiians go to find their Shangri-la? Las Vegas, if you take the word of the Hawaiian playwright Edward Sakamoto, whose ''Aloha Las Vegas'' explores with amusement and compassion a growing migration of natives of the paradisiacal Pacific islands of the 50th state to the sands of the Nevada desert.

title: South Korea Union Rejects Cooperation
description: South Korea's second-largest labor union said yesterday that it would boycott talks with the Government and business leaders and step up strike action to safeguard job security. President Kim Dae Jung met with representatives of the union, Korea Confederation of Trade Unions, for two hours.

title: U.S. Revoking Licenses to Export Firearms to Britain
description: The Clinton Administration notified the British Government today that it was revoking all pending licenses for the export of American firearms to British companies, American officials said.

title: 7TH LEVEL ENDS AGREEMENT TO BUY PULSE ENTERTAINMENT
description: The internet software developer 7th Level Inc. said yesterday that it had canceled its pending acquisition of Pulse Entertainment Inc. The shares of 7th Level fell $1.5625 each, to $7.6875, on the Nasdaq stock market. Since announcing plans in November to acquire privately held Pulse Entertainment, 7th Level, based in Dallas, has turned itself from a games developer to a supplier of services and software for a wide variety of entertainment, consumer and business customers. Under the original terms, 7th Level would have issued about 21 million common shares to Pulse shareholders.

title: Wanted: A Fix With Finesse for Year 2000 Problem
description: THE Year 2000, or Y2K, problem, which is filling the media's need for a potential millennial apocalypse, is attracting a variety of solutions. Some are earnest efforts that expand the problematic space in software where dates are stored from two digits (e.g. 99,000) to four digits (1999,2000).

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: TRITON ENERGY LTD., Dallas, an oil and gas exploration company, signed a natural gas sales contract valued at $5.5 billion over 20 years with the Governments of Thailand and Malaysia.

title: Down Home On Avenue C, An 'Opry' Neither Grand Nor Ole; Fan of Country Makes Alphabet City Twang
description: When Greg Garing set out to resurrect what was left of authentic country music, he never figured the route would lead to the Alphabet City Opry and a tiny, Hades-red bar at the corner of Ninth Street and Avenue C in the East Village.

title: House Committee Releases 39,000 Tobacco Documents
description: An R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company document prepared in 1985 by outside lawyers hired to review the cigarette maker's legal defenses indicates that the company destroyed records and suppressed research about the cancer hazards and other toxic effects of smoking.

title: In Search of Cybercafes
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOCK, COMMANDER ALBERT F.
description: DOCK-Commander Albert F. Of Essex, CT., died on April 22. Graveside service on Saturday, April 25 at Riverview Cemetery, North Main Street, Essex, CT.

title: Faking Pain and Suffering In Internet Support Groups
description: A MONK who had taken a vow of poverty could not seek treatment for a rapidly advancing type of cancer and faced death with fear and loneliness. A 23-year-old woman, hospitalized for an eating disorder, suffered a stroke. A teen-age girl mourning the death of one premature baby gave birth to another, tinier and more fragile than the first.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OTTMAN, JOHN B
description: OTTMAN-John B, 75 died peacefully on April 21. Beloved husband of Joan (Kennedy), father of Josephine K. and John B., grandfather of three. Memorial service 11am Friday at St. Barnabas Episcopal Church, 954 Lake Avenue, Greenwich. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory to The Merry Go Round Mews, One Half Bolling Place, Greenwich, Ct 06830

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HINTON, BRUCE
description: HINTON-Bruce. Happy Birthday. Missing you more than ever, and loving you forever. Your friend, John.

title: SmithKline Head Sees No Further Glaxo Talks
description: The chief executive of SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., Jan Leschly, told British legislators yesterday that there was no chance the company would revive merger talks with Glaxo Wellcome P.L.C. ''We have lost the trust and confidence of working together with Glaxo,'' Mr. Leschly said in testimony before the House of Commons Science and Technology Committee. ''Theoretically, we could go back, but I don't see a possibility of merging the two companies.''

title: Shanghai Journal; Cry Goes Up: Let a Hundred Garbage Cans Bloom!
description: If you had a rotting pile of garbage sitting a few yards from your front door, day after day, it might make you mad too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BODKER, RUTH L.
description: BODKER-Ruth L. April 18, 1998. A 25-year-employee of Seagrams Distillers Inc. until her retirement in 1972. Beloved sister of Susan Kinsey. Loving aunt of Stephen and Richard Kinsey. Donations in her memory can be made to The 52 Association, C/O Allan Weinberg, Executive Director, 350 Fifth Avenue, Suite 3304, New York, New York 10118-0069. For more information call Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel, 212-288-3500.

title: A Gush of Profits From Water Sale?
description: While Warren E. Buffett, America's second-richest man, is taking a well-publicized flier in silver, the Bass brothers of Texas are betting on a humbler commodity: water.

title: Panel Chief Refuses Apology to Clinton
description: Representative Dan Burton, the Indiana Republican who heads the House panel investigating campaign finance abuses, today ignored demands by Democrats to retract derogatory remarks that he made last week about President Clinton.

title: 'Herbal Bed' to Close
description: ''The Herbal Bed,'' a drama by Peter Whelan, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Eugene O'Neill Theater, 230 West 49th Street, Manhattan. The play, directed by Michael Attenborough and starring Laila Robins, Armand Schultz and Tuck Milligan, will have run for 13 regular performances and 23 previews.

title: Currents; REDO IS DONE -- A Greater Great Hall at City College
description: The Great Hall at the City College of New York is once again pristine and aglow, after a 15-month renovation that was completed in February. Edwin H. Blashfield's mural, which depicts a graduate surrounded by fluttering cherubim and toga-clad figures (Wisdom, Alma Mater and Discipline), has been cleaned. The mural, which was completed in 1908, portrayed commencement (no longer held in the hall) as serious business, arming graduates for the battle of life, S. Willis Rudy wrote in a 1949 City College history.

title: Furniture Fair Report; In Milan, Design Gets A Grip
description: Umbrellas clashed, taxis halted and cell phones went into chatterlock as the crowd on Via Manin fought its way through a showroom's narrow 19th-century portal. Only the most determined, and tallest, glimpsed the audacious display: red heart-shaped lights impaled on a giant ball of twigs, suspended over a steel table polished to a mirror sheen. Inside, the fortunate snaked slowly around a long refectory table set with insect-shaped lamps made of folded rice paper, as if ready to take poetic flight.

title: G.O.P., RELENTING, AGREES TO TAKE UP CAMPAIGN FINANCE
description: Bowing to growing pressure from insurgents, the House Republican leadership reversed itself today and agreed to allow a full debate and vote on overhauling campaign finance laws by late May.

title: Aliant in Cellular Deal
description: Aliant Communications Inc. said today that it had agreed to raise its stake in Omaha Cellular L.P. to 82 percent from 56 percent for $24 million. Aliant Communications, based in Lincoln, provides telecommunication services and products. It had revenue of $286 million in 1997. The closely held Omaha Cellular partnership provides cellular services in Douglas and Sarpy Counties in Nebraska and Pottawattamie County in Iowa, including the Omaha-Council Bluffs area.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 11 about the abuse death last year of a 5-year-old Bronx boy, Daytwon Bennett, misstated the year the boy was temporarily taken from his mother. It was 1991, not while she was staying with two other children at the Covenant House shelter in Manhattan in 1989.

title: Four Businesses Are Sued Over Bankruptcy Work
description: The United States Attorney's Office in Newark filed a lawsuit yesterday charging four businesses with practicing bankruptcy law without a license and charging excessive fees to more than 1,000 tenants facing eviction.

title: Clinton Hits G.O.P. On the Environment
description: President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore planted phlox and patched a stone wall today along the scenic Appalachian Trail, a setting they used to emphasize the Administration's environmental priorities and to lambaste the Republican leadership for opposing them.

title: Nets Relying on Their Square Dance to Keep Bulls Out of Step
description: The Nets reached the playoffs this year with a defense that resembles a square dance. Players switching partners as John Calipari stomps his foot on the floor, setting a rhythm that sends his players trapping and rotating in constant motion.

title: Must Students Pay to Keep the Yankees in Town?; Profits Over People
description: To the Editor:

title: Starr Should Let Congress Know What He's Found So Far
description: To the Editor:

title: Garden Notebook; A Bench Is a Great Place to Rest . . . a Shovel
description: A GARDEN bench is never really unoccupied. Even if gardeners never actually sit down, their benches are filled with the alluring vision of themselves relaxing, instead of weeding and deadheading.

title: Abortion Harassers as Racketeers
description: A Federal jury's verdict that two militant anti-abortion groups and their leaders violated the Federal racketeering law in harassing abortion clinics should offer some badly needed protection for women and their doctors. The class-action lawsuit brought by the National Organization for Women and two clinics in Delaware and Wisconsin was filed 12 years ago to stop Operation Rescue and the Pro-Life Action League from waging a nationwide campaign to shut down hundreds of clinics through intimidation, threats and acts of violence. The case was unusual because it was brought under the Federal Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act, a statute not originally intended for use against political protest movements.

title: Atlantic City Race Course Is to Close After 53 Years
description: After 53 years, the financially troubled Atlantic City Race Course will close at the end of this horse racing season, which will run just five days, officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGAL, RABBI CARL AKIBA
description: SIEGAL-Rabbi Carl Akiba. Of Bayonne NJ. Cherished brother of Florence Siegal. Services were held ''Wien & Wien'' 1-800-322-0533.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a freeze in rates for many New Yorkers who buy their own health insurance misstated the date of the state law requiring health maintenance organizations to offer coverage to individuals. It was 1992, not 1996.

title: Peter Lind Hayes, 82, of Radio, TV and Films
description: Peter Lind Hayes, an affable, appealing entertainer whose career included work in everything from vaudeville to films, Broadway, nightclubs, radio and television, died on Tuesday in Las Vegas. He was 82.

title: Critic's Notebook; The Perils of Nonprofit Profits: Et Tu, Tinky Winky?
description: Let's take a moment out from celebrating the opening of the newest television boutique, for the 1-to-2-year-old market, and consider what it tells us about the perils of public television.

title: Showdown in Moscow
description: Tomorrow's showdown in Moscow between President Boris Yeltsin and the Russian Parliament is shaping up to be not only a crisis in Russian politics, but also a profound threat to Russian democracy.

title: Museum Exchanges Looted Art for a Show
description: Almost as soon as the Wadsworth Atheneum here purchased Jacopo Zucchi's ''Bath of Bathsheba'' in 1965, there was trouble. The painting turned out to be stolen, ripped from the walls of the Italian Embassy in Berlin in the waning days of World War II. The Italians, naturally, wanted the 16th-century work back, never mind that the Atheneum had bought it in good faith from a Paris dealer.

title: Must Students Pay to Keep the Yankees in Town?; Bronx Renaissance
description: To the Editor:

title: As the bride and groom walk down the aisle, companies hope to brand them for life.
description: FORGET the problem about whether to wear white or ivory. When they're walking down the aisle of advertising together, consumer-products companies think brides are the color of money.

title: APPLIED CELLULAR SEEKS PLAN TO INCREASE STOCK PRICE
description: Applied Cellular Technology Inc. said yesterday that it planned to hire an investment banker to help it explore ways to increase its share price, including mergers and joint ventures. The company, which builds wireless phone systems, said it was interviewing bankers and expects to choose one within six weeks, with a strategy to be mapped by October. Shares of the company, which is based in Nixa, Mo., rose 90.625 cents, to $4.59375, in Nasdaq trading, where the company's current market capitalization is about $102 million.

title: Building Tiles Fall; Street Is Closed
description: A Manhattan street was closed yesterday morning after tiles fell from the third floor of a six-story storage building on the Upper East Side, city officials said.

title: Gates's New Face: Red but Cheerful
description: As the world now knows, Bill Gates's computer crashed spectacularly as he and an associate were demonstrating Microsoft's forthcoming Windows 98 at the Spring Comdex computer exposition this week in Chicago. But that was not the real news. Very few executives in the technology industry have not suffered a similar embarrassment while demonstrating a prerelease, or beta, product in public. The demo gods are cruel.

title: Where Ibsen First Met His 'Hedda'
description: Giddiness helps at the Judith Anderson Theater, especially a capacity for giddiness over Henrik Ibsen. Although never present as a character, the great Norwegian playwright is nonetheless omnipresent in ''The Summer in Gossensass.''

title: Must Students Pay to Keep the Yankees in Town?; Just Buy the Team
description: To the Editor:

title: Hail to the Turkmen Dictator
description: For a textbook illustration of the intoxicating power of oil and gas, consider the visit of the President of the Central Asian Republic of Turkmenistan. Saparmurat Niyazov concludes his three-day visit to Washington today with a luncheon with President Clinton and a visit with Vice President Gore. Mr. Niyazov's trip has been full of such triumphal pomp. He gets these diplomatic goodies because he has two things Washington wants. One is political neutrality -- Turkmenistan offers a bulwark against the influence of its neighbor Iran. More important, Turkmenistan has the world's fourth-largest natural gas reserves, and Washington wants American companies to pump the gas through friendly nations to the West.

title: In Police Brutality Case, Penalty Was Lost Vacation Days
description: When police officers took Manuel Villa to St. John's Hospital in Queens on Nov. 10, 1994, his face was so bruised that doctors thought he had been in a car wreck.

title: Campaign Reform Turns a Corner
description: Newt Gingrich did not quite surrender to the forces of campaign finance reform yesterday, but he ordered a hasty retreat as a Republican rebellion against his leadership gained strength. Faced with the prospect of a majority of House members forcing him to submit reform legislation to a vote, Mr. Gingrich volunteered to bring the bill to the floor next month. But euphoria is premature. A great many obstacles still stand in the way of enacting a meaningful change in the law.

title: In California, Enron Curbs Power Sales
description: The Enron Corporation has temporarily stopped trying to sell electricity to residential customers in California, demonstrating the difficulties that many power marketers face in trying to attract business.

title: Starr Should Let Congress Know What He's Found So Far
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YOUNG, FRANCIS J.
description: YOUNG-Francis J. The Fordham Law Alumni Assn., WestchesterPutnam Chapter, extends its deepest sympathy to the family of our beloved past President. William H. Mulligan Jr., President

title: Police Say Man Stole Medicine Used for H.I.V.
description: A Bronx drugstore worker who the police said had portrayed himself as a Robin Hood for people who have the virus that causes AIDS was accused yesterday of stealing more than $171,000 in medication to treat the virus.

title: Constantine Caramanlis Is Dead at 91; Brought Greece Into the European Fold
description: Constantine Caramanlis, a principled statesman who returned with high drama from self-imposed exile in 1974 to restore democracy to Greece after a repressive seven-year military dictatorship, died early today at a hospital in Athens. He was 91.

title: Bank of New York Bids $23.7 Billion for Mellon
description: The Bank of New York Company, moving to stay near the top of the heap in the rapidly consolidating banking industry, announced an unsolicited $23.7 billion takeover offer yesterday for the Mellon Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh.

title: After Lots of Late Nights, Baby Bonds With Computer
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, BARBARA T.
description: PHILLIPS-Barbara T. The entire Beth Israel Medical Center (BIMC) family joins the staff of Jeanette and Morris Kessel Volunteer Services Dept in acknowledging with sadness the passing of Barbara T. Phillips, beloved wife of our dear friend and colleague, Lewis A. Phillips, cousin of Beth Israel Trustee Carol P. Green, and her brother, our generous benefactor Lawrence Phillips. To Lewis, the entire Phillips family, and all who loved her, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Morton P. Hyman, Chairman, Board of Trustees, BIMC Matthew E. Sink, M.D., President, BIMC Terry Williams, Director, Jeanette and Morris Kessel Volunteer Services Dept

title: Currents; THE FACE IS FAMILIAR -- 750 Landmarks
description: When the J. P. Morgan & Company bank was built at 23 Wall Street in 1913, it had no name on the front. ''For those wealthy enough to bank at Morgan, no introduction was needed,'' Andrew S. Dolkart says in the new second edition of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission's Guide to New York City Landmarks (John Wiley & Sons). Some 750 landmarked sites can be found on 70 maps. The paperback is $19.95 at Barnes & Noble.

title: Metro Business; New Office for Sumitomo
description: Anticipating an increase in the number of Japanese executives seeking to buy or rent homes in Fairfield County, Conn., Sumitomo Real Estate Sales of New York will open a five-person office in Greenwich on May 1, the company said yesterday.

title: Hot Goalie Defeats The Best
description: Martin Brodeur, the Devils' goaltender, is one of the best. The Ottawa Senators' goalie, Damian Rhodes, is one of the hottest. Sometimes, more often in the post-season, the hottest goalie comes out on top.

title: Tampering With the Judiciary
description: The nation has more to fear from Congressional assaults on the traditional powers and independence of the Federal judiciary than from the imagined legion of ''activist'' judges that right-wing politicians rant about. Doubters need only consult the judicial reform bill coming up today in the House. Thoughtful lawmakers will reject this attempt to weaken the Federal courts and their ability to enforce Americans' legal rights.

title: Starr Should Let Congress Know What He's Found So Far
description: To the Editor:

title: Currents; 300-YEAR-OLD DESIGNS -- Once Upon the Wicked Stage
description: Inspiration is sometimes one part recycling. In 17th-century Italy, itinerant acting troupes lighted their outdoor sets with candles set inside glass shades, said David Meitus, the owner of the Studium V showroom in New York. Three hundred years later, similar hand-blown Murano glass lamps have been fitted out with electrical wiring. They are available in clear, amber, pale green and pale pink.

title: Vote on Euro Is Briefly Snared in French Conservative Politics
description: The identity crisis racking President Jacques Chirac's conservative movement deepened today with a tortured decision by his party to abstain from a parliamentary motion of support for French participation in the euro, the common European currency. European leaders are to formally approve the euro in Brussels next month.

title: Living With the Palestinian 'Catastrophe'
description: At first, Ibrahim Shikaki is lost amid the widened roads, bowling alley and Toyota garage off Menachem Begin Avenue. But having spent his first 20 years here in what was once the village of Zarnouga, he insists that even at age 70 he will gain his bearings. At the intersection of streets honoring Israelis who fought in the 1967 and 1973 wars, he says: ''Turn right. The mosque used to be that way.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERGAMENT, MOLLIE
description: PERGAMENT-Mollie. Of Palm Beach, Florida and Kings Point, NY, on Wednesday, April 22, 1998, at age 92. Beloved wife of the late Louis Pergament. Devoted mother of Murray and Irene, Robert and Lois. Cherished grandmother of Linda and Richard Horowitz, Bruce and Randi Pergament, and the late Sherri Koeppel, Debra and Andrew Levine, Lori and Howard Dorman, Arthur and Jeffrie-Anne Pergament. Great-grandchildren Jill Horowitz, Kyle, Max and Sam Koeppel, Scott Pergament, Jenna and Mitchell Levine, Benjamin, Evan and Louis Dorman, Lizzy, Lucas and Harrison Pergament. Sister to Mary Rosensweig and Gertrude Freeman. Services Thursday, April 23, 12 o'clock Noon, at Temple Beth-el of Great Neck, 5 Old Mill Road.

title: '96 Stadium Study Found Fewer Benefits
description: An unpublished 1996 study found that a West Side stadium for the New York Yankees would generate $102.5 million a year for the city's economy, far less than the $1 billion projected by city officials in a new report.

title: Trade Secrets; The Touch That Crowns Room Design
description: SOME ceilings are so imposing that visitors stop to gape. Think of the skylight ceiling at the Guggenheim Museum or the frolicking zodiacs at Grand Central Terminal.

title: Behind Headlines on Study, a Couple Married to Their Work
description: LAST Friday, Donna L. HoffmanDonna L. Hoffman started the day knowing it would be far from routine. The journal Science had just published an article she co-wrote, a groundbreaking report demonstrating that lower-income black Americans are far less likely to have Internet access than whites of similar economic status. News reports about the study had already appeared.

title: People
description: * Fred Langbecker, client services director at Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners, New York, was named to the additional new position of chief operating officer.

title: Starr Should Let Congress Know What He's Found So Far
description: To the Editor:

title: Microsoft Beats Earnings Expectations, but Revenue Growth Slows
description: After alerting analysts last month that its third-quarter earnings would exceed Wall Street's expectations, the Microsoft Corporation reported results yesterday that surpassed their revised estimates.

title: Falling Bricks Close a School in Queens
description: Two layers of bricks fell from atop a four-story elementary school under repair in Maspeth, Queens on Tuesday night, forcing school officials to cancel classes yesterday, when hundreds of students were scheduled to take a citywide reading test.

title: Starr Should Let Congress Know What He's Found So Far
description: To the Editor:

title: The Pop Life; Horde Festival Offers a Surprise
description: The Horde Festival, a rock package tour founded by the group Blues Traveler in 1992, has announced its lineup for this summer's roadshow. The festival will feature some of the usual jam-rock suspects, like Blues Traveler, as well as surprises, like the alternative rock group Smashing Pumpkins, who will join the Horde for five shows in the Midwest. Also appearing are Ben Harper, the Barenaked Ladies, Alana Davis and Paula Cole, who will be replaced midway through the tour by the Austin, Tex., rock band Fastball. The tour begins on July 9 in Wisconsin and lands at Jones Beach in Wantagh, N.Y., on Aug. 5.

title: Queens Co-op Is Revived by New Mortgage
description: Hundreds of retirees and working-class families who three years ago thought they had lost their life savings because their Queens housing complex was saddled with $20 million in debt learned this week that the cooperative will be able to repay every penny to them, with interest.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  BECKER, HELEN. HANSHE
description: BECKER-Helen. Hanshe, you are always on my mind and in my heart. Rusty

title: James Earl Ray, 70, Killer of Dr. King, Dies in Nashville
description: James Earl Ray died yesterday at Columbia Nashville Memorial Hospital in Nashville while serving a 99-year sentence for the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. To the end of his life, he tantalized America with suggestions that his confession to the 1968 murder, which he had swiftly recanted, amounted to a lie. He was 70.

title: Fear of 12-Tone Repertory: Composer Offers a Remedy
description: ''I'm a 12-tone composer,'' Gunther Schuller told an audience at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday night. ''But don't let that scare you. There's been so much 12-tone trashing these days, I feel I have to apologize. But not all of my music is ugly and difficult.''

title: Today's Bargains, Tomorrow's Divas
description: Reasonable people can disagree about whether opera is the zenith of human artistic endeavor. But there are a few points about opera, both theoretical and practical, on which there is common consensus. On the theoretical side, there is a general agreement that as a conglomeration of the arts -- instrumental and vocal music, drama, stage and costume de- sign and often dance -- opera's ambitions are exceptionally high. And who would disagree that this has a practical consequence: that opera can be extraordinarily expensive both to produce and to attend?

title: FILM IN REVIEW
description: 'The Big Hit'

title: Leak Caused NATO to Drop Bosnia Effort On Fugitives
description: Plans for capturing people indicted on war-crimes charges in Bosnia, including the fugitive Bosnian Serb leader Radovan Karadzic, went awry last year after United States military officers learned that a French officer had been meeting secretly with Dr. Karadzic, senior American officials said today.

title: On My Mind; Clinton Policies Explained
description: Sometimes critical Americans complain that human rights policies of the United States have become so peculiar that there is no understanding what the Clinton Administration is doing or why.

title: Iraq Again Threatens to Halt Arms Inspections
description: President Saddam Hussein made his most direct threat today to provoke another crisis over arms inspections unless an economic embargo on Iraq is lifted next week by the United Nations Security Council.

title: Wolf Announces Shifts at Meldrum
description: Wolf Group announced changes yesterday at its Cleveland agency, Meldrum & Fewsmith Communications, involving a management reorganization, a name change and an acquisition.

title: For Oyster Lovers
description: Diamond Jim Brady, the 19th-century financier, was renowned for consuming dozens of oysters at a sitting. If he were around today, he wouldn't have to look far for his favorite food. Raw bars are turning up everywhere, not just in seafood restaurants, but in any place dedicated to hedonism. Here are a dozen restaurants that indulge the Diamond Jim in all of us. (These summaries, written by Eric Asimov, are taken from Ruth Reichl's and Mr. Asimov's dining reviews, columns and articles in The Times.)

title: The Love Triangle as One-Man Show
description: ''I've got the greatest boyfriend in the whole world!'' exclaims Lou (Natasha Gregson Wagner) while waiting on that boyfriend's doorstep to surprise him when he returns home. ''Omigawd!'' she says moments later, having discovered that Carla (Heather Graham), the other woman parked outside the building, is waiting for the same two-timing man.

title: GOLF: ROUNDUP
description: GREENSBORO CLASSIC

title: No Ruse Is Too Rash To Get a Reservation; Desperate Diners Lie, Cheat and Steal To Eat in the Hottest Spots in Town
description: The staff of the Grand Tier Restaurant in the Metropolitan Opera House waited expectantly, as it always does, on Paul Newman night.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARYN, HERBERT
description: GARYN-Herbert. Beloved father of Arthur, Allen, and Gregory. Cherished grandfather, dear brother. Services ''BoulevardRiverside'', 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, L.I., 12:30 P.M., Friday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Sunday with an article about efforts to eradicate opium in Myanmar misidentified an armed man in a poppy field. He was a Burmese soldier sent to guard the field after it was discovered, not a militiaman from the Wa hill people.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Paul Henry Ramirez

title: A Jagged Presentation Of Jagged Subject Matter
description: Like a good self-accompanying blues or bossa nova singer -- though he's not either -- Chris Whitley makes his guitar sketch in all the spaces around a song's words. All he needs besides that is a pulse to make his songs go forward, and at Wetlands on Wednesday night he was his own drummer, thumping his boot on an amplified board. This is what he naturally reduces to.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: Yang Yanping

title: Topics of The Times; The MetroCard Blues
description: New Yorkers are discovering that two new electronic toll and fare devices have different levels of difficulty. The E-Z Pass electronic tag attached to motorists' windshields makes payment a breeze because the motorist need not do anything -- the tag communicates with its toll-booth counterpart. The MetroCard requires humans and machines to interact, with many a misfire.

title: HEALTH INSURERS SEEK BIG INCREASES IN THEIR PREMIUMS
description: For the first time since 1992, many employers are facing double-digit increases in the cost of their health insurance next year, the highest inflation rate since the majority of employees moved into managed care.

title: Wizardry In Camelot
description: The Lady of the Lake, played by Miranda Richardson and looking as if she were spun out of light, rises from the water and tells her wizard of a nephew, ''It's human to make mistakes, Merlin, and part of you is human, the best part.''

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about growing attention to the development problems of boys misstated the surname of a researcher on the topic. She is Barb Wilder-Smith, not Wallis-Smith.

title: Japan Can Solve Its Economic Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Brighten the Corners: Five Artists from Los Angeles'

title: Exposing A Heart Seething
description: ''An Expressionist in Paris: The Paintings of Chaim Soutine,'' which opens on Sunday at the Jewish Museum, is a gantlet. Pushing in from every side are canvases thick with extravagantly manipulated paint, resonant colors and an aura of intense emotional engagement.

title: Federal-Mogul to Dismiss 10% of Work Force
description: The Federal-Mogul Corporation, a big auto parts maker, said yesterday that it would dismiss 4,200 people, or about 10 percent of its work force.

title: Baerga's Swing Is There, But Timing Is Way Off
description: Bobby Valentine contends that when Carlos Baerga was enjoying the salad days as an All-Star with Cleveland, the constant was not necessarily a beautifully precise bat swing.

title: Newsstand Operators Sue Over New Rules
description: A group of New York City newsstand operators, seeking to block new city regulations that limit the number of adult magazines they can display and sell, filed suit yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn.

title: Ruckins McKneely Jr. Dies; Earhart's Mechanic Was 89
description: Ruckins McKneely Jr., a mechanic who tended Amelia Earhart's plane just before she took off from Miami in 1937 for the round-the-world trip on which she vanished, died on April 16 at a nursing home in Murfreesboro, Tenn. He was 89 and lived in Murfreesboro.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARDS, HAROLD
description: RICHARDS-Harold. The Amateur Comedy Club mourns the passing of its esteemed member Hal Richards.

description: If playing Michael Jordan and the Chicago Bulls in the first round of the playoffs is not daunting enough, the Nets today added yet another name to the roster of ailing and injured players who will take on the two-time defending champions.

description: BASEBALL
