title: Metro Business; Earnings at Insurer Rise
description: American International Group of New York, the largest publicly held insurer, said yesterday that first-quarter earnings rose 13 percent, led by gains in its financial services unit.

title: Corestates Settles Bond Case With U.S. for $3.7 Million
description: The Corestates Financial Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $3.7 million to settle Federal allegations that its brokerage firm unit grossly overcharged investors and the Federal and local governments in a series of municipal bond deals in the early 1990's.

title: So Wet and Wild: Paddling for Thrills
description: I knew I had flipped my boat when I felt frigid water fill my nostrils. Squinting into a blurry montage of percolating water and submerged rocks, I frantically tried to execute an Eskimo roll, a nifty move I'd been taught earlier in the day that was supposed to right the kayak. When that failed -- and it failed miserably -- I segued to the next phase of self-rescue: squirming out of the kayak and swimming to shore.

title: Ramos Returning From Knee Surgery
description: Midfielder Tab Ramos said yesterday that he expected to play about 35 minutes tomorrow in the MetroStars' game against the San Jose Clash at Giants Stadium.

title: G.O.P. Snubs White House On Billions For the I.M.F.
description: Congressional Republican leaders dropped the Administration's request for $18 billion for the International Monetary Fund from a popular spending bill today, delivering a potentially fatal blow to one of President Clinton's top foreign policy goals.

title: Drought May Have Doomed the Lost Colony
description: On Aug. 18, 1587, on a coastal island called Roanoke in what is now North Carolina, a couple named Ananias and Eleanor Dare produced a daughter and named her Virginia, in honor of both the colony where they lived and of Elizabeth I, known as England's virgin queen. The baby, as schoolbooks have long noted, was the first English child born in America.

title: Finding Love On the Road Not Taken
description: If Peter Howitt's slender romantic comedy, ''Sliding Doors,'' were set in 1967, its vivacious main character Helen (Gwyneth Paltrow) would be referred to in the quaint parlance of Swinging England as a ''bird.'' Although the movie takes place in contemporary London, it seems intent on capturing some of the period effervescence of 60's English romps like ''Georgy Girl'' and ''The Knack,'' in which sashaying mini- skirted birds were as ubiquitous as Beatles songs.

title: A Skewering of Separateness With Exuberance and Unruly Combinations
description: Robert Colescott makes powerfully ugly pictures. Painted in raw strokes and garish colors, swarming with rubbery, popeyed cartoon characters who act out wildly scrambled blackface burlesques of race, sex, violence and death, these noisy, sprawling canvases could drive lovers of esthetic refinement screaming out of the room. Nothing if not contradictory, however, Mr. Colescott's paintings are also beautiful, smart and poetic. Though abrasive, they have a lush, painterly sensuality, and though bumptious, they speak to complex philosophical matters through metaphorically loaded images.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ISGUR, IRVING
description: ISGUR-Irving. Born September 23, 1920 in Brooklyn, New York, died Thursday, April 23, 1998 in San Antonio. Survivors include his wife of 56 years, Helen; sons and daughters-in-law, Stuart and Rebecca Isgur, Robert and Deborah Isgur, Ron and Martha Isgur; grandchildren, Benjamin, Shoshana, Jeremiah, Joshua, Sarah, Yonder, Brooke and Chris Isgur; also survived by his sister, Edythe Katz; and numerous nieces, nephews and cousins. Service Friday 4 P.M. Porter Loring Chapel, San Antonio, Texas. Rabbi Richard Spiegel and Cantor Joseph Lutman officiating. Interment in Agudas Achim Memorial Gardens. For information Porter Loring, 1101 McCullough, San Antonio, TX 78212.

title: Whitewater Figure Again Defies Starr Jury
description: In the final days left for the Whitewater grand jury here, the special prosecutor's efforts, after four years of investigation, to force Susan H. McDougal's testimony about President Clinton came down today to what her lawyer called a game of chicken.

title: Gay School? What Gay School? On Long Island, an Abrupt Reversal
description: A school for gay and lesbian teen-agers, which would have been the first on Long Island and one of the few in the world, was getting ready to open this week in Bay Shore.

title: Pain of Growing Up, in Girl's Voice or a Boy's
description: ''IT would be interesting to take 17-year-old boys to work,'' Carol Gilligan mused the other day, ''at a point when they've had the experience of falling in love, and when they're thinking about what kind of partners they'll be.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Any movement that results in the death of people, even if it's just one person, raises the question of the moral role of the participants. When so many people died, I have the feeling of moral guilt in this matter and I imagine I will have this all my life.''

title: Boy Stopped For Directions Is Molested In Bronx Park
description: A 12-year-old Bronx boy who stopped yesterday to give directions to a stranger was forced into the woods in Van Cortlandt Park by the man, who then sexually abused him before fleeing, the police said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIMIGIANNIS, HELEN NEE ANGELAKOS
description: SIMIGIANNIS-Helen nee Angelakos; on Wednesday, April 22, 1998, of Bayonne, NJ. Beloved wife of the late James J. Simigiannis. Cherished mother of Peter Simigan and the late John Simigan. Dear sister of the late Vasilios, Demetrios, Christos, Yanni, Georgios, Michaelis, Panagiotis Angelakos. Loving mother-in-law of Mary Jane Simigan. She is also survived by a host of cousins, nieces and nephews. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral from the G. Keenen O'Brien Funeral Home, 984 Avenue C, at 47th Street, Bayonne, on Saturday April 25, 1998. Funeral Mass will be at St. Demetrios Greek Orthodox Church, Jersey City, 9 AM. Interment to follow, Bayview Cemetery, Jersey City. Family will receive their friends on Friday 2-4 & 7-9. The Trisagion will be 8PM Friday, Very Reverend Kyrillos Markopoulos, Archimandrite, Officiating.

title: Retailer Offers to Buy Yankees or Start New Team in Bronx
description: Sy Syms, the multimillionaire who built a clothing store empire on the slogan ''an educated consumer is our best customer,'' offered to buy the New York Yankees yesterday and keep the team at its landmark home in the Bronx.

title: A Day to Urge Girls to Be All That They Can Be
description: For as long as she can remember, Bryn Harrison, whose mother is a music teacher, was dead set on also becoming a teacher. But that goal worried her father, who looked at her good math scores and thought she was ''kind of narrow-minded'' in her aspirations.

title: Juror in Brawley Case Is Injured in Crash
description: An alternate juror in the Tawana Brawley defamation case was critically injured yesterday when two cars collided and hit her as she walked toward the courthouse in Poughkeepsie. Officials said it was unclear whether she would return to the trial, which is in its sixth month.

title: A Death Camp Survivor's Hesitant Re-Entry Into the World of the Living
description: Shockingly gaunt, his soulful brown eyes peering shyly out from behind round, nearly rimless eyeglasses, his sensitive lips quivering with nervous exhaustion, John Turturro gives what may be the screen performance of his career in Francesco Rosi's deeply morose film ''The Truce.''

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about former President George Bush's support for a legal privilege that would exempt Secret Service security personnel from testifying about what they observed on the job misspelled the surname of the Secret Service Director. He is Lewis C. Merletti, not Marletti.

title: New Video Releases
description: Anastasia

title: $6.15 Minimum Wage Approved in Hartford
description: In the state with the highest per-capita income, lawmakers today passed a measure aimed at helping Connecticut's low-income workers: they raised the minimum wage.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Mellon Sues Its Suitor But May Encounter Hurdle

title: Observer; Encased In Black, Sees Red
description: On the supermarket parking lot my car, which is car-size, is walled in, as usual, by two sport-utility vehicles.

title: A Billet-Doux to Joie de Vivre in Tough Marseilles
description: Cement, weeds and lots of sunshine are the foundation for the French hit ''Marius and Jeannette,'' a love story that's also a romance in a larger sense. The director, Robert Guediguian, grew up in the Estaque district of Marseilles, and he puts his affection for the place and its hard-working people on screen. Scrappy yet tender, filled with a joie de vivre that transcends their tough circumstances, these characters share warm friendships and populist political ideas drawn from their daily experience. It's no surprise that Frank Capra is Mr. Guediguian's filmmaking hero.

title: House Approves Weakened Bill on Judges
description: The House passed a bill today that was intended to further a long-cherished goal of conservatives to restrain so-called judicial activism.

title: End of an Assassin
description: Until the day he lapsed into his final coma, James Earl Ray insisted he had not fired the rifle bullet that killed the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on April 4, 1968, and that he had been an incidental player in a larger cast of conspirators. Mr. Ray found believers not only among those Americans who insist that all crimes of great magnitude must necessarily spring from a collaborative effort, but also among members of Dr. King's family, who somehow managed to persuade themselves of Mr. Ray's innocence.

title: Japan Can Solve Its Economic Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Making a Religion of Mountains That Touch the Heavens
description: Few of nature's offerings moved Marsden Hartley (1877-1943) quite so much as mountains. During a life of restless travel, he painted them in New Mexico, Germany, France and above all in his beloved Maine. For him, they were symbols of permanence and aspiration, but they had a deeper significance, too. ''I know I have seen God now,'' he wrote to a friend in 1939, after a camping trip to Mount Katahdin, Maine's highest peak. Not unmindful of Cezanne's obsession with Mont Sainte-Victoire, he captured Katahdin's virile mountainhood in a series of nearly 20 views.

title: High Technology, High Rewards
description: A new Morgan Stanley Dean Witter index that goes by the ungainly name of Deep UV Photolithography Food Chain tracks the performance of five companies that make equipment used for etching tiny wires into the surface of microchips. The demand for this equipment has made these companies investor favorites.

title: A Change of Heart on Assisted Suicide
description: A recent survey, which I co-wrote, found that doctors are often asked by their patients for help in dying, but seldom honor these requests.

title: Seashells For Love And Money
description: In Mariah Carey's new music video for MTV, she is singing on a giant shell, a Herb Ritts take on Botticelli's Venus. One of the best lots in Christie's Los Angeles sale of Piero Fornasetti designs on May 19 is a 1950's chandelier positively dripping with strands of seashells. And contemporary architects, like Alison Spear of New York, routinely create shell parlors. Her own has two shell lamps, a vitrine displaying exotic shells on a bed of sand, a Victorian shell mirror, a shell picture frame and a Victorian, shell-encrusted fern pedestal.

title: Taxi Agency Alters Exam After Charges of Cheating
description: After uncovering a scheme in which officials said a test proctor sold answers to prospective cabbies, the city said yesterday that it would introduce a new exam that would expand and rotate questions to guard against cheating.

title: Blair Blocks Release of Rules for Parades in Northern Ireland
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair blocked the publication today of Government restrictions on Northern Ireland's flashpoint summer parades, saying that he wanted to avoid destabilizing the province at a ''volatile time.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CONNOLLY, PAUL
description: CONNOLLY-Paul. The faculty, students, trustees, and staff of Bard College mourn the passing of Paul Connolly, who was John D. and Catherine T. MacArthur Professor of Humanities and director of the College's Institute for Writing and Thinking. Throughout his career Paul exemplified Bard's tradition of innovation and his untimely death is a loss to our community. His contributions to the intellectual life of the College were immeasurable and timeless. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Leon Botstein, president David E. Schwab II, chairman,

title: All Seems Normal, For Now, In Bronx
description: Thick debate surrounds the Yankees and their place of residence, of the present and the future, but the players are insulated from this. David Szen, the team's traveling secretary, arranges the itinerary and shepherds them all from one field to the next, whether in Detroit or Toronto. The Yankees, a flock comprised mostly of veterans, proceed without a bleat of protest.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, THOMAS
description: DAVIS-Thomas. The Officers and Members of the New York Joint Board UNITE express their deep sense of loss at the death of Thomas Davis, manager of Neckwear and Accessories Division. He was a veteran of World War II, co-founder and member of Borough Medical Center, former manager of Neckwear and Accessories Worker's Union ACTWU, Administrator of Neckwear and Accessories Health and Welfare Fund. His leadership, kindness and inspiration will be deeply missed. Our sympathies are extended to his wife Estelle, his children Mitchell and Susan and their spouses, and to his grandchildren. Sal Rumbolo, VP UNITE Olga Diaz, VP UNITE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCGILLIS, DANIEL B.
description: McGILLIS-Daniel B. April 23 of Milton, MA. Husband of Noreen (Vaughan) McGillis. Father of Patricia McGillis, Alana McGillis, Alec McGillis and Philip Archambault. Funeral Services Saturday in Milton. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the McGillis Trust, 134 M Street, South Boston, MA 02127.

description: In percent

title: Harry Harding, 94, Advertising Executive
description: Harry Harding, who was executive vice president of the Young & Rubicam advertising agency in the early 1960's and then a senior executive for Time Inc., died April 17 at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md., following a stroke, his son, Harry Harding Jr., said. He was 94.

title: PREMIERE TECHNOLOGIES BUYS TELECONFERENCE BUSINESS
description: Premiere Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had acquired American Teleconferencing Services Ltd. for $30 million in cash and $22 million in stock to strengthen its share of the conference-calling services market. Premiere, a provider of voice mail, conference calling and Internet services, also assumed $6 million in debt from American Teleconferencing, which provides teleconferencing services to several Fortune 100 companies. American Teleconferencing, based in Overland Park, Kan., had $30 million in revenue last year and has about 330 employees. Premiere had 1997 revenue of about $230 million. Premiere's stock fell $1.9375, to $31.125, in Nasdaq trading.

title: Atlanta Mayor Ousts Airport Chief and Hires Newark Official
description: Mayor Bill Campbell today dismissed the well-regarded but tenaciously independent general manager of the city's bustling airport, the second busiest in the world, and appointed the general manager of Newark's airport to replace her.

title: Calvin F. Craig, 64, Enigma In Klan and Civil Rights Work
description: Calvin F. Craig, an Atlanta construction worker who spent most of the 1960's in fiery opposition to racial desegregation, then abruptly resigned as the head of the Georgia Ku Klux Klan to work for integration, died on April 13 at his home in Newnan, Ga. He was 64 and had later rejoined, then abandoned, the Klan all over again.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: COFFEE FALLS. Coffee dropped on new evidence of abundant supplies in the United States and a big crop due from Brazil, the chief grower. May contracts fell 9.4 cents, to $1.386 a pound, a 15-month low.

title: Especially in India/Fair Color as a Cultural Virtue : Creams for a Lighter Skin Capture the Asian Market
description: NEW DELHI  When Abha Bhatnagar was growing up, her mother forbade her to go outdoors. She was not trying to keep her daughter out of trouble. "She was trying to keep my skin from getting dark," said Mrs. Bhatnagar, who disobeyed the order. Now she regrets that her olive skin is not lighter. But she believes there is a solution: fairness cream, which she recently started using on her face.

title: Prisoner Of Paradox
description: The Dalai Lama finds himself these days tending to so many fires at once that, whichever direction he turns, he is likely to get burned. A Nobel Peace Prize laureate treated in some quarters as a terrorist, a ubiquitous icon courted by certain heads of state only in private, he has had to lead his people from a distant exile for almost 40 years and to abandon full-time spiritual practice for the back rooms of geopolitics since the age of 15.

title: Group Forced Illegal Aliens Into Prostitution, U.S. Says
description: The young women were lured from Mexico with offers of jobs in landscaping, health care, housecleaning and restaurants. But in a case of modern-day slavery one Federal official called ''a chilling reminder of prior centuries,'' they were forced to work as prostitutes in agricultural migrant camps in Florida and South Carolina, and sometimes were raped, beaten and forced to have abortions, according to a Federal indictment.

title: Fred Friendly's News Integrity Is Recalled at Memorial Service
description: Justice Antonin Scalia of the Supreme Court first met Fred W. Friendly where he said he never wanted to be -- on Mr. Friendly's public television series ''The Constitution: That Delicate Balance.'' The Justice said he did not approve of judges' appearing in public and ''making a spectacle of themselves.''

title: Giuliani Drops Workfare Jobs At the Hospitals
description: Facing a legal challenge not only to his plans to lay off 900 hospital workers but also to his workfare program, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani abruptly pulled every workfare worker out of New York City's public hospitals yesterday.

title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/Technology; Steel Tries to Shed Its Heavy-Metal Image
description: WHAT will the body of your next car be made of?

title: Acer of Taiwan Gets Most of Siemens Unit
description: Acer Inc., the Taiwan personal computer maker, said yesterday that it would acquire most of the personal computer unit of the German telecommunications giant Siemens A.G. for an undisclosed sum. Acer said it had signed a memorandum of understanding with Siemens Nixdorf Informationssysteme A.G., the information system unit of Siemens, under which it would buy Siemens Nixdorf's main PC manufacturing plant in Augsburg, Germany.

title: Faster PC Chips Propel Makers of Equipment
description: Gordon Moore, the co-founder of Intel, is well known for observing in the 1960's that the number of transistors that can be placed on a silicon chip doubles every 18 months.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DOW, HELENA M.
description: DOW-Helena M. Four time U.S. National Fencing Champion and member of the 1948 Olympic Fencing Team. Died April 22, 1998. Reposing at her son's house at Ridge Road in Tuxedo Park, Friday, April 24, 1998 from 3:00 PM to 9:00 PM. Church services at St. Mary's in Tuxedo Park at 11:00 AM, Saturday, April 25, 1998. Her husband Warren, also an Olympic fencer passed away in 1965. She is survived by her son Robert, her daughter-in-law Christina Seix Dow and granddaughter Lindsay.

title: Where Nothing Lasts Forever; Subtle Reminders for Consumers on Replacing Products
description: When Gillette introduced a high-tech razor last week that took $750 million and more than five years to create, one of the low-tech features it promoted was a blue strip that fades to alert users that it is time to replace the blade. But does the blade really need to be tossed when Gillette says it does?

title: A 'Falstaff' Dwelling On Patterns Of Fate
description: Haydn and Mozart are poor examples of late-18th-century style: the first too eccentric, the second too dense. Antonio Salieri will do nicely. ''Falstaff,'' played at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Majestic Theater on Wednesday night, ties Shakespeare in a tidy package, with the wrapping equally as interesting as the contents.

title: London Journal; Dig These Digs! Digs Galore for Lord Chancellor
description: The reporters touring the Lord Chancellor's newly renovated state apartment didn't know about neo-Gothic design, but they knew what they didn't like.

title: 4 Airlines Setting Up Marketing Alliances
description: The nation's largest airlines have reached two agreements to form competing alliances that could portend a significant shift in the industry's landscape.

title: Braving It In Brooklyn
description: Whether or not there are alligators in New York City's sewers, a local river is filled with them, and the only bridge that crosses it has been washed out.

title: A Suit Is the Latest Snag for Bridgemarket
description: The on-again-off-again $16 million Bridgemarket retail and restaurant complex, which has been in the works for more than two decades in the vast historic space under the Queensboro Bridge at 59th Street and First Avenue, may be off again. This time there is a food fight.

title: Pat Sloan Joining DDB Needham
description: Pat Sloan, a longtime advertising journalist, is joining DDB Needham Worldwide in New York as senior vice president and corporate director for public affairs. Ms. Sloan, 45, who has worked for Advertising Age since 1978, succeeds Lou Tripodi, who died in January. Ms. Sloan has held posts at Advertising Age, owned by Crain Communications, that include senior editor and New York bureau chief. At DDB Needham, owned by Omnicom Group, she will help coordinate worldwide communications strategies.

description: Campaign finance overhaul has proved this year to be the issue that will not die. But that does not mean it will make it off life support to be approved by Congress.

title: French Insurer's Profit Tops Estimate
description: Groupe des Assurances Nationales earned a higher-than-expected profit in the second half of last year as a result of lower provisions for property losses and higher banking and casualty insurance income. The company, France's fifth-largest insurer, earned 170 million francs ($28.3 million), compared with a 4.7-billion-franc loss in the corresponding period last year. Analysts had expected the company to earn 136 million francs. Second-half profit was calculated by subtracting first-half profit from 1997 earnings.

title: Dow Chemical's Profit Falls 10%
description: The Dow Chemical Company said today that its first-quarter profit fell 10 percent, as it used lower raw-material costs and improvement in its specialty chemical businesses to partly offset a strong dollar and weakness in Asia.

title: State Reports First Case Of Resistant Staph Strain
description: State health officials investigating the case of a man who died in a Westchester County hospital have discovered the first case in New York of a strain of staph bacteria that can be resistant to antibiotics, the officials announced yesterday.

title: RIVAL BIDS POSSIBLE FOR MAKER OF ELECTRICAL PARTS
description: Applied Power Inc. of Butler, Wis., said yesterday that it would buy Vero Group P.L.C. for $:94.4 million ($157.6 million) in cash, but another American company, Pentair Inc., said it might make a higher bid. Applied Power, which makes hydraulic systems and tools, is offering 157 pence for each share of Vero, based in Hampshire, England. Pentair, based in St. Paul, makes tools and electrical equipment. Both Applied Power and Pentair want a larger chunk of the market for housings that protect telecommunications and electrical equipment, a fast-growing business. Applied Power fell 12.5 cents, to $37.875, while Pentair slipped $1.4375, to $43.875.

description: Phil Sims

title: Toyota Has 2d Thoughts on Big Trucks
description: TOYOTA'S first larger truck, the T100, has nibbled at Detroit's heels since 1993. But it has not taken much of a bite out of the full-size pickup market, which remains a playground for the Big Three.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TURCIHIN, LELYA
description: TURCIHIN-Lelya. On Thursday, April 23, 1998. Beloved and adored wife of Sten Evenhouse. Precious daughter of Ilusha and Jale Turcihin. Loving sister of Olya Turcihin Stern. Devoted aunt of Ayla Turcihin Stern and faithful friend to so many. Lelya fought bravely against Lymphoma. Graduate of Stuyvesant High School, University of Michigan, B.A. Art History and working toward the completion of a Master's Degree in Decorative Arts at Bard University. Such a diligent researcher and art historian of Islamic Decorative Arts. She was exceptional and filled with love, art, poetry, music, grace, elegance and beauty. Graveside service on Friday 1:30 PM at Shearith Israel cemetery, Queens, NY. In lieu of flowers, please contribute to University of Michigan Department of Literature, Science and Art, in memory of Lelya Turcihin.

title: Sampras, Never in Sync, Gets a Thrashing From Santoro
description: Pete Sampras has a fine chance of reclaiming the No. 1 ranking from Marcelo Rios at the end of the Monte Carlo Open, but anyone who had to sit through his agonizing display of baseline errors, missed serves and missed opportunities knows that Sampras is not the world's best player now.

description: Editor's Note Appended

title: Environmental Stalling in Congress
description: To commemorate Earth Day this week, President Clinton and Vice President Gore descended on Harper's Ferry, W.Va., to promote their plan to buy up the last 33 miles of unprotected land needed to finish the 2,158-mile Appalachian Trail. This is a worthy project costing a mere $15 million. But even this modest effort will not succeed without the consent of two powerful subcommittee chairmen, Senator Slade Gorton and Representative Ralph Regula, who are stubbornly refusing to release nearly $700 million in land acquisition money that Congress has already approved.

title: F.T.C. Gives Qualified Approval To Digital's Sale of a Unit to Intel
description: The Federal Trade Commission gave a green light today to the Intel Corporation's planned acquisition of the Digital Equipment Corporation's microprocessor production operations, provided that Digital makes its Alpha chip technology available to other manufacturers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYKOWSKI, FRANK A.
description: RYKOWSKI-Frank A. Died peacefully on April 22, 1998, after a yearlong battle with cancer. He is survived by his beloved children, Tony and Pamela Rykowski, his former wife, Jayne M. Kurzman, and a brother, Richard Rykowski. His extraordinary intellect and scholarship, sense of humor and wise counsel will be greatly missed. Services will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to The Rockefeller University, 1230 York Avenue, New York, NY 10021, to support its research in the fields of cancer and alcoholism.

title: CRITIC'S CHOICE/Film; Finnish Fortitude Behind the Despair
description: The Finnish director Aki Kaurismaki, one of Europe's most celebrated directors, has described the continuing theme in many of his films as ''the extraordinary phenomenon that is mistakenly described as Finnish national character, in other words the peculiar desire for self-destruction that haunts this semi-Western, semi-Slavic nation, something that's not without its comic aspects.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, ALBERT
description: EISENBERG-Albert. Beloved husband of Gloria, devoted father and father-in-law of Bruce and Gigi Eisenberg, Karen and Larry Goldberg. Dear brother and brother-inlaw of Estelle Gordon and Selma and Mort Sagalow. Adored grandfather of Bradley, Adam, Emily, Erica and Melissa. Loving son-inlaw of Helen Berkowitz. Services today, 12 noon, at the I.J. Morris Chapel, 46 Greenwich St., Hempstead, NY.

title: Time Warner Cable Sale
description: Time Warner Inc. said today that it had agreed to sell a 60 percent stake in its Wade Communications cable television system in Philadelphia to the privately held Inner City Broadcasting Corporation's Cable Television Systems. Terms were not disclosed. Inner City Broadcasting operates the New York radio stations WLIB-AM and WBLS-FM. Time Warner will continue to manage the system.

title: A Sampler Arousing Curiosity
description: Themes of introspection and recollection dominated the works presented by five young choreographers on Tuesday night as part of the ''Fresh Tracks'' series at Dance Theater Workshop. No single piece was memorable. But all were sufficiently well made as to arouse curiosity about other dances by these choreographers.

title: Con Man Made Millions in Phone Fraud
description: Thwarting Federal regulators, a con man set up fly-by-night marketing ventures that bilked consumers and long-distance companies of millions of dollars by fraudulently persuading people to switch phone companies, Congressional investigators testified today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BENEROFE, SHIRLEY
description: BENEROFE-Shirley. The officers and staff of the Westchester/ Greenwich division of State of Israel Bonds deeply mourn the passing of Shirley Benerofe, mother of Andrew, James and Mitchell and mother-in-law of Froma, Robin and Ada. She was a staunch supporter of many Jewish and community causes. Her presence among us will be sorely missed. Our heartfelt condolences to her family. Westchester/Greenwich Division Chairman Philip M. Schlussel Executive Director Ivan Helfand

title: The Senate's Duty on NATO
description: The Senate has betrayed its obligations with its pitiful performance on NATO expansion. Instead of illuminating the complex issues involved in extending the alliance eastward, and weighing the potentially grave consequences, the Senate has treated the matter as a legislative afterthought, flippantly fitting a few hours of debate between other bills. With discussion soon to resume on whether to approve membership for Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, the Senate can redeem itself by taking an exacting look at the most important foreign policy decision America has faced since the end of the cold war.

title: Cellular Phone Groups to Sue Over Wiretapping Regulations
description: Two cellular telephone industry groups plan to file a lawsuit today seeking to narrow the Government's interpretation of 1994 legislation intended to help law enforcement agencies listen in on the phone calls of suspected criminals.

title: SPARE TIMES
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Oilfields in Mind, White House Woos Turkmenistan's Chief
description: President Clinton and Vice President Gore met for several hours today with the authoritarian leader of a tiny Central Asian republic, hoping that a warm welcome, several nights at Blair House, a Marine honor guard and a $750,000 grant would win his cooperation in an economic struggle over control of the region's oil and gas.

title: POP AND JAZZ GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy pop and jazz concerts in New York City this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended concert.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STITHAM, MICHAEL
description: STITHAM-Michael. Age 55 on April 23, 1998. Beloved husband of Nancy (nee Parmet). Loving father of Hayley and Lawrence. Adored brother of Sarah, Nancy and Judy. Grandfather of Mikey. We will miss you. Friends may call Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St Saturday, 7-9PM and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9PM with service Monday, 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to establish the Palliative Care Program at the NYU Hospital, Medical Office, 550 First Ave., New York City 10016.

title: Mayor Hints He'll Talk About Tax Cut If Vallone Helps Him
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani hinted yesterday that he would be willing to negotiate with the City Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, on cutting the city's personal income tax if Mr. Vallone supported the Mayor's plan to help finance new baseball stadiums.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-9

title: Jerry Springer Loses a Chicago TV Contract, but Bounces Back
description: Sensitive to public protests and its own unhappy history with Jerry Springer, the daytime talk show host, the NBC station in Chicago yesterday dropped his show. It is the first station in a major market to do so, but the raucous and racy show was immediately snapped up by the Fox network's station in Chicago.

title: Sports of The Times; Questions Regarding The Stadium
description: THEY are opening Yankee Stadium again tonight, which should produce surging emotions in all Yankee fans.

title: Brightening Up Public Schools
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank is giving the New York City Board of Education contemporary artworks that will be hung in the public schools.

title: U.S. Has No Right to Halt Tobacco Sales Abroad
description: To the Editor:

title: American Express Net Gains 1.3%
description: The American Express Company reported first-quarter earnings yesterday that were stronger than expected.

title: COMPAQ PLANNING TO BUY BACK UP TO 100 MILLION SHARES
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation said yesterday that it would repurchase up to 100 million of its common shares, or about 6 percent of its outstanding stock. The company's stock closed at $28.875 yesterday, up 37.5 cents a share, meaning the buyback would approach $2.9 billion at current prices. The personal computer maker said it had about 1.5 billion shares outstanding on March 31. Compaq said the buyback program would help to offset dilution from stock issued under the company's stock incentive plans. Compaq, based in Houston, had 1997 sales of $24.58 billion.

title: British and Japanese Win Singapore Pact
description: A group led by British Telecommunications P.L.C. and the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation of Japan won a license to sell fixed and mobile phone services in Singapore and pledged to invest as much as $1.7 billion there. The group, called Starhub, which also includes Singapore Technologies Pte. and Singapore Power Ltd., will give Singapore Telecommunications Ltd. its first head-on competition, starting on April 1, 2000. Starhub beat competition for the license from Cable and Wireless P.L.C. and Worldcom Inc.

title: Knicks Can't Use Hate As a Motivating Factor
description: A free throw was lofted, and Charlie Ward planted his right hip into Miami's P. J. Brown with enough force to move a blocking dummy.

title: An Ear for Voices In a Diverse Diocese
description: When the Very Rev. Mark Sean Sisk, elected to be the 15th Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of New York, is consecrated tomorrow as Bishop Coadjutor at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, the service will be recited in 12 languages, among them Tagalog, Igbo and Malayalam, along with the more familiar French, Spanish, Japanese and English.

title: 4 Airlines Set 2 Alliances For Marketing
description: The nation's largest airlines have reached two agreements to form competing alliances that could portend a dramatic shift in the industry's landscape.

title: To Recap, J. R. Is Older; Pam's Still Dead
description: Southfork looks the same. There are J. R., Sue Ellen and Bobby having breakfast by the pool, just like old times. But things have changed since we first saw the Ewings at their sprawling ranch in ''Dallas'' in 1978, as J. R. (Larry Hagman) sums up in a little chatty exposition: ''Here we sit, three single multimillionaires under the same roof. Well, I guess every family has their little quirks.''

title: Kathleen Connelly, 49, Public Relations Executive
description: Kathleen F. Connelly, a corporate crisis and public relations executive, died Sunday while vacationing in the Virgin Islands. She was 49.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDAU, EDWARD (EDDIE)
description: LANDAU-Edward (Eddie). Beloved husband of Ruth. Devoted father of Meryl and Howard. Father-in-law of Sarah. Loving grandfather of Rebecca, Jacob and Katya. The only member of his immediate family to survive the Holocaust. He joined his parents, Malka and Chaim, brothers Vladek and Simon and sister Ruta on Yom Hashoah, April 23, 1998. Services ''Gutterman-Musicant'' cor. Park and Passaic Sts, Hackensack, Friday, 9AM, 1-800-522-0588

title: Leichter's Decision Not to Run Ignites Heated Race for State Senate
description: While it has been only days since State Senator Franz S. Leichter announced that he would not seek re-election this year, the race for his seat has been under way, full throttle, for months.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Lightning Reaction To Electric Guitar

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Site of Asia/Site of Body: Contemporary Asian Women Artists'

title: The Musketeers, At 2-for-1 Rates
description: Charlton Heston signed on to portray the wily Cardinal Richelieu. Faye Dunaway was cast as the scheming Milady and Geraldine Chaplin as the philandering Anne of Austria. In the role of Constance, dressmaker to the Queen, was Raquel Welch.

title: The Jones-Hill Battle Tips Off at Weigh-In
description: Today an ill breeze blew through the news conference for the light-heavyweight bout between Roy Jones Jr. and Virgil Hill on Saturday night. If that atmosphere carries over to the fight, it could be a war.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROCHASKA, HANS J., M.D. PH.D.
description: PROCHASKA-Hans J., M.D. Ph.D. It is with deep sorrow that the staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center note the death of their dear collealgue and friend, Dr. Hans Prochaska. From 1991 to 1996 Dr. Prochaska was the Head of the Laboratory for Chemical-Biological Interactions at Sloan-Kettering Institute, an Assistant Professor of Pharmacology at Cornell Graduate School of Medical Sciences and Cornell Medical College. In 1992, Dr. Prochaska was the recipient of the prestigious American Cancer Society's Junior Faculty Research Award. Dr. Prochaska had the instinctive ability to translate his imaginative research into therapeutic applications. He carried out the first experiments demonstrating the cancer protective effects of broccoli. Dr. Prochaska leaves the legacy of his work for future patients and researchers. He will be greatly missed. We extend sincerest condolences to his wife Kathleen, his daughter Erica, and the entire Prochaska family. The staff of Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center

title: Ex-Pan Am Workers Suing Agency for Pension
description: Richard A. Brooks expected a pension of $600 a month from Pan American World Airways, but the airline folded in 1991 and the Federal corporation that took over its pension plans says he will collect less than half of that amount when he reaches retirement age.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 10.

title: THE N.B.A. PLAYOFFS: Hardaway Thrives as Part Of Odd Couple; As Star Guard Improvises, The Star Coach Tolerates
description: Sometimes, when he is supposed to listen to his coach, Tim Hardaway looks into his teammates' eyes during timeouts in the fourth quarter. Scanning the Miami Heat huddle, he said he knows and feels when they want him to take over the game.

title: Accounts
description: -- Zeneca Pharmaceuticals, New York, to KPR, New York, part of Omnicom Group, to handle direct-to-consumer marketing for Accolate, an oral preventive therapy for asthma. Billings were estimated at $24 million. The account had been handled by Wunderman Cato Johnson, New York, part of Young & Rubicam Inc.

title: Anomie in a Fading Mountain Resort
description: The people in ''From Above,'' Tom Donaghy's melancholy comedy at Playwrights Horizons, never appear as fully three-dimensional as they do when they're seen in two dimensions. Between the brief second and third acts of this terminally wistful work, which opened last night under David Warren's direction, the characters you've been watching on stage show up in a splintered home movie in which they pose and clown at a barbecue.

title: HICKS, MUSE TO BUY CONTROLLING STAKE IN HOME INTERIORS
description: The investment firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc. agreed yesterday to buy control of Home Interiors and Gifts Inc., with the intent of turning the home-accessories and gifts company into one of the largest direct-selling marketers in the United States. Hicks, Muse, which is based in Dallas, is to pay $170 million in cash and $275 million in equity to gain a 65 percent stake in Home Interiors. It will also assume $475 million in debt. After the purchase, current management will own about 15 percent and other shareholders will own the rest. Home Interiors, a closely held company also based in Dallas, expects sales of more than $500 million in 1998. It sells products nationwide through about 48,000 independent representatives. The two companies share a headquarters and have been partners in previous ventures.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a sentence in the News Watch column in the Circuits section on Thursday was partly obscured by a photograph. The sentence, about the Go Book laptop computer, should have read, ''Most notebook computers today run out of juice somewhere over Nebraska on a cross-country flight, but the Go Book, in theory, can keep churning out spreadsheets or playing games all the way to the opposite coast, and even to Hawaii or Europe.''

title: CABARET GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing of new or noteworthy cabaret shows in Manhattan this weekend. * denotes a highly recommended show.
