description: To the Editor:

title: Grass Roots and Trees
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Sonatas by Beethoven Read as His Personal Story
description: The German violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter presented the second of her three concerts devoted to the Beethoven Violin Sonatas on Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall. Having played the first five on April 14, and with the final two reserved for the concluding concert next Wednesday, she and her pianist, Lambert Orkis, explored the three Sonatas that Beethoven composed in 1802 and published as Opus 30.

title: The Day After for Devils: Anger, Dismay, Disgust
description: It's exasperating when you're beaten at your own game, and even more so when it occurs at home, against an inexperienced team, in the first game of a playoff series that isn't supposed to be particularly challenging.

title: New Award to Spotlight Jazz And Benefit Its Musicians
description: Jazz has never had its own highly publicized annual awards like the Grammys or the Country Music Awards, but that will soon change. The date and nominees for the New York Jazz Awards, which are intended to become an annual event, were announced on Wednesday.

title: ART GUIDE
description: Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Galleries, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan and are open Tuesdays through Saturdays from 10 or 11 A.M. to 5 or 6 P.M.; gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZUGER, BERNARD, M.D.
description: ZUGER-Bernard, M.D. The faculty and staff of the Dept of Psychiatry of the NYU School of Medicine mourn the passing of our dear colleague Dr. Bernard Zuger on April 19, 1998. Dr. Zuger, a clinical Associate Professor of Psychiatry, joined the faculty in 1958 specializing in Pediatric Psychiatry. To his entire family, we at the School of Medicine extend our heartfelt sympathy. Robert Cancro, M.D., Professor and Chairman, Dept of Psychiatry, NYU School of Medicine

title: Metro Business; Building Set for Jersey City
description: The LeFrak Organization plans to break ground within 30 days on a 14-story office building on the Jersey City waterfront, even before an anchor tenant has been signed, the company announced yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDBERG, IRVING A.
description: GOLDBERG-Irving A. Beloved husband and partner to Ellen. Loving and proud father to Elizabeth and Michael. Dear ones Paula, Chaim, Faith and Rachel, Addie and Bette. Jack of all trades and master of all. We will receive family and close friends at home on Saturday 8-10, Sunday 2-8.

title: Broadcast and Cable Interests Debate Rules for Digital TV
description: Presidents of the largest companies in the television industry sparred at a Congressional hearing today over a question that is erupting into a nasty industry battle.

title: 'Bullet on a Wire'; Directed by Jim Sikora; Not rated; 84 minutes
description: Although Jim Sikora has made other films, ''Bullet on a Wire,'' opening today at Anthology Film Archives (32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village), smacks of apprentice work. Amateurishly acted and clumsily directed, this spare-looking, grainy black-and-white film rests on a single intriguing idea.

title: Should We Sell Supercomputers to Algeria?
description: Since January, the Clinton Administration has been quietly circumventing a new law intended to keep American supercomputers away from third-world bomb and missile makers. Supercomputers are the most powerful tools available for designing nuclear weapons and the missiles to deliver them. The world may soon face more weapons of mass destruction, all so computer companies can reap a few export dollars.

title: Metro Business; Bankers Trust Shows 11% Rise in Earnings
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation said yesterday that first-quarter earnings rose 11 percent, as net income from investment banking and equity investments outpaced a decline in Asia.

title: Experts Offer Tips on Getting In, Only by the Book
description: Of course, there are honest ways to land a reservation in the restaurants that keep playing hard to get.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OLDENBURG, LISA TURNURE
description: OLDENBURG-Lisa Turnure. On April 17th, 1998, at home. Deeply beloved wife of Richard E. Oldenburg and cherished daughter of Mrs. David A. Turnure. She was blessed with many friends she loved who loved her in return. Memorial service at St. Thomas Church, Fifth Avenue and 53rd Street, at 11 AM on Friday, May 1. Given her love for books, gifts in her memory in lieu of flowers would be gratefully received by the Amagansett Free Library, Main Street, Amagansett, L.I.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: Some new restaurants open with great fanfare: months before the stove is even installed you hear about the designer, the chef, the tableware the owners have ordered from Italy.

title: Trainer Won't Budge On Coronado's Quest
description: A full field of 20 horses is expected to crowd the starting gate at Churchill Downs one week from tomorrow for the 124th Kentucky Derby, the main event for any promising 3-year-old horse. But one of the most talented colts in this year's class will not be there: Coronado's Quest, winner of the Wood Memorial earlier this month but withheld by his trainer, Shug McGaughey, because he seemed mentally unsuited for the clamor of a race he otherwise might be favored to win.

title: How Puppy Love Can Teach New Tricks to Old Dogs
description: Henry Jaglom's autobiographical films, with their navel-gazing introspection, require a degree of patience that many moviegoers are loath to extend. But even the most self-indulgent Jaglom films loiter in psychic territory that more mainstream explorations of well-heeled angst often overlook.

title: Links Sought in 3 Attacks
description: The police are investigating whether one man is responsible for the slayings of two women and the rape of a third in the same Bronx neighborhood.

title: Mother of Man Charged With Murder Is Arrested
description: The mother of an Alloway Township man charged Sunday with killing a 10-year-old neighbor knew of the crime and told her son to dispose of the girl's body, the Salem County Prosecutor said yesterday.

title: Allies Creating Press-Control Agency in Bosnia
description: The United States and its Western allies in the Bosnia peacekeeping operation are creating a tribunal that will have the power to shut radio and television stations and punish newspapers that it decides are engaged in propaganda that is undermining the peace.

title: Workfare Official Refuses Questions From Council, Again
description: Two weeks after he stalked out of a New York City Council hearing about workfare, Jason A. Turner, the newly appointed Commissioner of the city's Human Resources Administration, failed to show up yesterday for another hearing on the same topic. And Council members say they may issue a subpoena to force him to appear.

title: Why Let Colleges Dictate Costs?; Community Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINLAY, TERENCE
description: FINLAY-Terence. The Rev. Dr. Terence J. Finlay died on April 8 at his home in Grimsby, Ontario, Canada. A memorial service will be held for him at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street, New York City, on Monday, April 27 at 11:00 AM. Dr. Finlay served as Rector of St. Bartholomew's from 1955 until his retirement in 1978.

title: ABB Quarterly Net Rises as Orders Dip
description: Asea Brown Boveri, the Swiss-Swedish engineering giant, said yesterday that its first-quarter net income rose 9 percent, to $258 million, from $236 million a year earlier, while orders fell slightly, in part because of weak demand from Asia.

title: As Havel Falters, So Does Czechs' Mood
description: PRAGUE  "Fear!" shouted the cover of the leading newsmagazine, Tyden, this week, in a fair reflection of the national mood.

title: Easy-Listening Oldies For the Rock Generation
description: The British Rock Symphony and Choir should have known better than to use ''My Generation'' to start the second half of its show at the Beacon Theater on Wednesday. ''Hope I die before I get old,'' chirped the so-called choir, nine apparent Broadway hopefuls in various states of hamminess. For the audience, it already felt too late.

title: STANLEY SAYS IT WILL ACQUIRE 90% OF ISRAELI COMPANY
description: The tool and hardware maker Stanley Works said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 90 percent of Zag Industries Ltd., an Israeli maker of plastic consumer products, for $14.30 a share, or $117 million. Zag surged 23 percent, gaining $2.5625, to $13.6875, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of Stanley fell $1.6875, to $51.9375, on the New York Stock Exchange. Stanley, based in New Britain, Conn., has full-year sales of $2.6 billion. Zag, based in Israel, had 1997 revenue of $63.6 million. Stanley said the remaining 10 percent of the shares would continue to be held by Zag's chairman and chief executive, Zvi Yemini.

title: Appeals Court Reinstates Widow's Marriott Suit
description: An appeals court yesterday reinstated a lawsuit in which the widow of the radical anti-Arab Rabbi Meir Kahane asserted that the Marriott Hotel Corporation was liable for the murder of her husband in one of its hotels longer than seven years ago.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: POUND FALLS. The pound weakened after The Financial Times reported that the Bank of England's policy-making committee had voted 5 to 3 in favor of keeping rates on hold. In New York, the pound fell to $1.6614 from $1.6717.

title: Revolv Wins Honors At Award Ceremony
description: Revolv in Minneapolis took top honors, winning the most awards, at the first annual One Show Interactive Awards ceremony for excellence in interactive advertising, sponsored by the One Club for Art and Copy in New York.

title: Emissions Rules May Tighten For Autos and Light Trucks
description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it planned to work on tighter rules for emissions of smog-causing gases and soot from cars and light trucks beginning in 2004.

title: U.S. Agents Whisk Atom Bomb Material From an Ex-Soviet Land
description: Shrouded in the pre-dawn darkness, a squad of Georgian policemen accompanied by American security agents entered a nuclear research laboratory outside this capital today, loaded a cargo of bomb-quality uranium onto a specially prepared truck, and drove into the night.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: SONAT INC., Birmingham, Ala., will sell oil and gas properties, consolidate offices and lay off 220 workers, resulting in a second-quarter charge of as much as $275 million, to improve returns from its exploration unit.

title: Pocket-Size Providence, Built of Hope
description: Lord Bryce, the English traveler, suggested that Providence might become the first American city-state. That never quite happened, but the city's name is embedded in the state's official title, Rhode Island and Providence Plantations, and it's hard to separate them.

title: Topics of The Times; Albany Loses a Maverick
description: As a liberal Democrat serving for the past 24 years in New York's Republican-controlled State Senate, Franz Leichter could not do much to control the flow of legislation. But Mr. Leichter, who will retire at the end of the year from his Manhattan seat, managed to find a useful outlet for his passion for reform. In a Legislature not known for independence or initiative, he has seen his job as ''raising issues and making noise'' on important matters most Albany hands would prefer to ignore -- like the need to rewrite New York's scandalously lax campaign finance laws and change the partisan Legislature's costly, secretive way of doing business.

title: Good Earnings Have Spurred Stock Increases
description: Earnings reports are doing what investors like best: giving them a nice dose of positive surprises.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SMITH, FRANCES A.
description: SMITH-Frances A. On April 20, 1998. Loving sister of the late Marion, Jane and Eleanor. Beloved friend to many. Friends may call at Andrett Funeral Home, 353 2nd Avenue (at 20th Street), New York City, Friday 2-5 and 7-9PM. Mass of Christian Burial Epiphany R.C. Church, Saturday 10AM. Interment in Calvary Cemetery.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELLIOTT, BARBARA B.
description: ELLIOTT-Barbara B. The Board of Directors of the Indpendence Savings Bank extend their deepest sympathy to fellow director Donald H. Elliott and his family on the loss his wife Barbara Burton Elliott. This remarkable woman will be remembered for her love of her family, her commitment to the education of the young people of Brooklyn through Il Piccolo Teatro dell Opera and her enduring friendship with the Indpendence family. We will miss her. Board of Directors, Independence Savings Bank

title: Whitman Gets Help With Revived Tourism Ad
description: Former Gov. Tom Kean politely coaches Gov. Christine Todd Whitman on how to ''properly'' pronounce ''pehhfect'' in a new 30-second television commercial that revives the state's tourism slogan from the 1980's: ''New Jersey and You Are Perfect Together.''

title: Mysteries in the Crystalline World of a Flemish Master
description: No aspect of premodern European art has been as exhaustively studied as the painting produced in 15th-century Flanders. And almost no art remains as tantalizingly elusive about who painted what, when and for whom.

title: Corrections
description: An article by Bloomberg News in Business Day yesterday about the first-quarter results for three airline companies misstated the figure Wall Street analysts had forecast for Trans World Airlines. The prediction of 75 cents a share for the quarter was for a loss, not a profit. (On Wednesday, T.W.A. reported a loss of 76 cents a share.)

title: Dissident Says Students Bore Some Blame In Tiananmen
description: Wang Dan, the dissident freed by China last weekend, expressed feelings of guilt yesterday about his role in the Tiananman Square protests, in which hundreds were killed by the Chinese Army.

title: Georgetown Relay Strategy: Get a Big Lead and Keep It
description: The 104th annual Penn Relays began a three-day carnival today of 33 hours of running, walking, jumping and throwing. A combination of good running and good logic helped Georgetown win the day's big race, the women's 4x800-meter relay.

title: Mellon Sues Bank of New York to Stop Bid
description: Seeking to halt an unwanted takeover bid, the Mellon Bank Corporation sued the Bank of New York Company yesterday, contending that it used confidential information gleaned from previous merger talks when it offered to buy Mellon for $23.7 billion on Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KATZ, ELSIE ENGEL
description: KATZ-Elsie Engel, on April 23, 1998. Beloved wife of the late A. Raymond. Devoted mother of Joan Jacobson and Don and Mary Katz. Loving grandmother of Eric Jacobson, Dan Jacobson and Amy Sumner, Emily and George Whitehead, Susan Katz and David Zigas. Dear great-grandmother of Zeb, Ethan, Ivan, Kelly, Odessa and Cezar. Memorial service Sunday, 2PM, Plaza Memorial, 91st Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Mets Unveil Model Stadium: Its Roof Moves, as Does Grass
description: The Mets, who have quietly planned to replace Shea Stadium for several years, unveiled a model yesterday of a $500 million ball park that blends nostalgic design elements from Brooklyn's beloved Ebbets Field with modern features like a retractable roof and a removable grass playing field.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PERGAMENT, MOLLIE
description: PERGAMENT-Mollie. To our grandmother and great grandmother, Mollie Pergament, to the end of an era. May the younger generation of the family learn from your wisdom, strength, moxie and love. Words cannot describe what you have meant to us. We will always remember you as someone who put the family first. You have been a great inspiration to the great grandchildren. We are so happy that we all had an opportunity to spend quality time with you. Grandchildren, Jeffrie and Arthur Pergament Lori and Howard Dorman Debbie and Andy Levine Great grandchildren, Lizzy, Lucas, Harrison, Benjamin, Evan, Louis, Jenna and Mitchell

title: SPAGHETTI WAREHOUSE CONSIDERS A TAKEOVER OFFER
description: Spaghetti Warehouse Inc. said yesterday that it was considering a takeover bid of as much as $8.50 a share, or about $47 million in cash, from Conquest Partners. Conquest Partners, a closely held Dallas-based investment firm that advises and buys food service companies, said the total value of the acquisition would be as much as $58 million, including debt refinancing and transaction costs. The sale would allow Spaghetti Warehouse, a regional chain based in Garland Tex., access to private capital it needs for further expansion. Spaghetti Warehouse has 40 restaurants in 14 states and Canada. The company's stock rose 50 cents, to $7.8125.

title: RJR Nabisco Posts 16% Drop in First-Quarter Earnings
description: The RJR Nabisco Holdings Corporation reported a 16 percent drop in first-quarter earnings yesterday, attributing the decline to economic troubles in Asia and Brazil, a stronger dollar, higher marketing costs and increased legal expenses from the proposed tobacco litigation settlement.

title: INSIDE
description: Setback to I.M.F. Funds

title: Senators Endorse Tax Breaks For Education Savings Accounts
description: The Senate today narrowly passed a showcase Republican bill that would provide a modest tax break for parents who save for elementary and secondary school expenses, including private school tuition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORCHELLI, DOROTHEA
description: FORCHELLI-Dorothea. On April 21, 1998. Beloved wife of Astoria attorney, Vincent. Devoted mother of Charles N., John F., and Kathleen M. Goode. Cherished grandmother of seven. Reposing at Farenga F.H., 38-08 Ditmars Blvd., L.I.C., Thursday and Friday, 2-5, 7-9 PM. Religious services on Friday, 8 PM. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her name to Calvary Fund, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461.

title: Communists Risk Perks and Power in Challenge to Yeltsin
description: To hear Yuri I. Chunkov tell it, he and other Communists in the Russian Parliament have no choice but to vote down President Boris N. Yeltsin's nominee for prime minister on Friday, even if that vote ends up costing them their seats.

title: Secret Service Officer Worried About Lewinsky
description: A Secret Service officer two years ago warned a senior White House official that he was concerned about the behavior of Monica S. Lewinsky, then a low-level aide in the White House legislative affairs office, according to a former White House official.

title: $1 Million Pledged for Needle Exchanges
description: A billionaire financier offered $1 million on a matching basis yesterday to finance the distribution of clean needles to addicts who inject illegal drugs.

title: Thailand Plans to Sell $1 Billion in Bonds
description: Thailand plans to sell at least $1 billion of international bonds next month, Government officials said yesterday, in the nation's first sale in a year and a key test of investor confidence in the country. Thailand will probably hire investment banks to arrange the sale after Finance Minister Tarrin Nimmanahaeminda returns from the Asian Development Bank's annual meeting in Geneva next week, officials said. Mr. Tarrin returned this week after two weeks in the United States, where he met with numerous bankers.

title: Tip for Manhattan Tourists: Astoria Has the Right Stuff
description: A STREET pitchman for one of those double-decker tourist buses that clog Manhattan traffic far more than Giulianiville's whipping boy, the jaywalker, was asked if the itinerary included Astoria.

title: ART IN REVIEW
description: 'Large-Scale Drawings from the Collection of Wynn Kramarsky'

title: Jordan: Jittery? Sure. Concerned? Not at All.
description: Even Michael Jordan gets nervous before the playoffs, and he admitted as much. This was following the Bulls' practice early this afternoon and Jordan, in his white Bulls' warm-ups, was talking about expectations for his team. The Bulls open their first-round playoff series against the Nets at home Friday evening.

title: Why Let Colleges Dictate Costs?; Try Teaching Them
description: To the Editor:

title: Shift in Control Of Halston Seen
description: The Catterton Group, an investment company based in Greenwich, Conn., plans to take control of Halston International, one of the most storied names in American fashion, people involved in the deal said yesterday.

title: Agencies prepare an additional honor to join an already crowded firmament of awards.
description: THERE are Addys and Clios and Andys, Obies and Aces and Kellys, Fifis and Reggies and Effies. Now seven big agencies want to further augment the oh-so-long list of advertising awards by founding an honors competition for campaigns aimed at children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAYLOR, JAMES
description: SAYLOR-James. Died in New York City, April 21. A native of Lexington, KY, he was a special assistant to Nelson Rockefeller, manager Rockefeller Collection, and businessman. He is survived by a sister, nieces and nephews.

title: A Polish Satirist Obsessed With Identity
description: ''Witkacy'' is one of the shorter, tamer nicknames the Polish writer and artist Stanislaw Ignacy Witkiewicz (1885-1939) gave himself. He signed his letters with ''Chevalier de St. Vitecasse,'' ''half-crazed Witkacy,'' ''completely pulverized Wit,'' ''the overworked and half-dead drunk Onanislaw Spermacy Wyfiutkiewica'' and ''Witkasinski del Campo Vasto and what not.''

title: Leader Says She Will Resign From Times Square Group
description: Gretchen Dykstra, the president of the Times Square Business Improvement District, said yesterday that she would resign at the end of August, ending a six-year tenure as the head of a property owners' group that has been widely praised for helping lead the redevelopment of Times Square.

title: Of Internet Inequality
description: To the Editor:

title: Costly Sidewalk Falls
description: To the Editor:

title: A Boy Is Slain, and Gives Life to Others
description: A veteran cast pushing a commendable message is not quite enough to elevate ''Nicholas' Gift,'' a two-hour television film having its premiere tomorrow night at 9 on CBS, above being a by-the-numbers tear-jerker.

title: Battle of the Guards Goes to Hardaway
description: When he spent much of the week talking about how much New York's Allan Houston had improved and how his own star, Tim Hardaway, needed to muzzle his shot from time to time, you knew Pat Riley was up to something.

title: A Prometheus Yielding to Newer Lights; Paz Defined Mexico's Soul; Now Comes a Pluralism
description: Many of Mexico's finest writers and thinkers gathered in sorrow around the coffin of the poet Octavio Paz when it lay in state on Monday, draped in a Mexican flag, in the great domed hall of the Palace of Fine Arts, the high temple of Mexican culture.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GENDUSO, SALLY
description: GENDUSO-Sally. Beloved wife of Anthony, devoted mother of Sandra and Leonard. Loving grandmother of John L., Anthony, and Jeffrey. Much loved by all who knew her; much missed by all who loved her. Services Saturday and Sunday, April 25 and 26, 2-5 PM and 7-9 PM, at Fox Funeral Home, 98-07 Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, New York. Interment Monday, April 27, St. Charles Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

title: Olympians on Top
description: David O'Conner, Bruce Davidson and Karen O'Connor, winners of a team silver medal for the United States at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics, captured the first four places in the dressage phase at the Rolex-Kentucky Horse Trials yesterday in Lexington, Ky.

title: LORAL SPACE INCREASING ITS STAKE IN GLOBALSTAR
description: Loral Space and Communications Ltd. said yesterday that it had offered to increase its interest in Globalstar L.P., a company building a worldwide satellite-based mobile telephone system, to 42 percent. Loral, based in New York, now owns 38 percent of Globalstar. Globalstar is a partnership of several telecommunications service providers and equipment manufacturers. Under the proposal, Loral will buy up to 4.2 million of partnership interests in Globalstar for $420 million. It will then sell half of the shares acquired to a group of funds managed by George Soros for a premium of $8.333 a share over the price paid by Loral. The company said the partners accepting the Loral-Soros offer would be required to reinvest half of their proceeds into a Globalstar project.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERNSTEIN, LUJZA (ALICE)
description: BERNSTEIN-Lujza (Alice). On April 20, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Solomon Berstein. Devoted mother of Jerry, Miriam and David Finer and Mindy and Philip Sinnreich. Loving grandmother of Leigh, Danny, Meredith, Tamir, Michael and Brooke. Dear greatgrandmother of Raphael, Gavriel, Yael, and Shifra, also survived by her brother Yekutiel Nebenzahl in Israel. Her presence will be sorely missed by family and friends.

title: Event of the Year Out of Derby With Broken Leg
description: Event of the Year, a lightly raced but unbeaten colt who was a tantalizing prospect for the Kentucky Derby, sustained a broken bone in his right foreleg yesterday morning during a workout at Churchill Downs in Louisville, Ky.

title: JonBenet Case Yields Court Fights Galore
description: A self-described performance artist is in jail for trying to burn down the house of JonBenet Ramsey. A friend of the Ramsey family pleaded guilty to brandishing a baseball bat at two men he mistook for tabloid reporters.

title: GIULIANI PROPOSES $34 BILLION BUDGET WITH CUT IN TAXES
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed a $34 billion spending package for New York City yesterday, setting the stage for a fight with Peter F. Vallone, the Speaker of the City Council, over which taxes to cut and whether to use city money to help build two new baseball stadiums.

title: Stirring From Their Slumber, Devils Arise and Even Series
description: Falling behind again to the Ottawa Senators seemed to awaken something important in the heavily favored Devils tonight, something that had remained dormant in their previous game but something so very necessary if a top team is to advance in the Stanley Cup playoffs.

title: Pearson Says It Sold 3 Publishing Units
description: Pearson P.L.C., the British media company, said yesterday that it had sold its consumer publishing units to the venture capital company Apax Partners & Company for $:142 million ($236.7 million), continuing a disposal program intended to focus the company and increase profitability. Pearson sold Future Publishing Ltd., its British consumer magazine business; Edicorp Publications S.A. in France, and Futurenet, an Internet consumer content publisher.

title: Let Taxpayers Vote On New Stadiums
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-6

title: Jane Reid-Petty, 70, Founder of a Theater
description: Jane Reid-Petty, director, playwright and founder of New Stage Theater in Jackson, Miss., died on Thursday in Jackson at the home of her daughter, Diane Petty Maddux. She was 70.

title: Bungling in Sex Criminal's Escape Riles Belgians
description: In the last two years, Belgians by the tens of thousands variously raged, cried and marched to vent their feelings about the man they see as the country's most despicable criminal. They have also laid flowers in remembrance of those he is accused of killing and those he is convicted of raping.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENE, BRADDOCK
description: GREENE-Braddock, 76. Of Pinehurst, NC, died 4/22/98. Born in New York City a son of Constance and Stanley Greene. Retired from Yound & Rubicam. Resident of Pinehurst since 1986.

title: Thucydides Is Cool
description: To the Editor:

title: Investigation by Starr Looking Toward '99
description: No one -- except perhaps the public -- seems to expect an end this year to the hubbub over whether President Clinton had an affair with Monica S. Lewinsky and lied about it under oath. Kenneth W. Starr, the independent prosecutor, seeking new witnesses and more cooperation from old ones, has said there is no end in sight to the inquiry. Some Republicans say that they do not expect hearings until next year on any report issued by Mr. Starr.

title: Iran Nearly Got A Missile Alloy From Russians
description: A truck laden with 22 tons of stainless steel that could be used to make missiles has been intercepted on its way to Teheran, raising new questions about Russia's determination to end assistance to Iran's missile program.

title: For Female Expression, The Virility of Tori Amos
description: Tori Amos took steroids before introducing her new album, ''From the Choirgirl Hotel,'' at Irving Plaza Thursday night. ''I'm losing my mind up here,'' she said after the majestic crescendo that is the climax of the ballad ''Northern Lad.'' The drugs, she explained, boosted her voice, which is suffering from overwork. Whatever contribution they made to Ms. Amos's euphoric stage presence, her real source of power was grounded in her new musical approach.

title: Iridium Wireless Link Is Near Completion
description: Iridium L.L.C. said today that it would complete its 66-satellite global wireless communications network with a final satellite launching on Sunday, making it the first company to complete such a system.

title: Cargo Airline Fined $5 Million for Improper Parts
description: A cargo airline with a history of safety violations, a major crash and a two-month license suspension has agreed to pay fines and restitution of $5 million for flying planes with unapproved parts, Federal prosecutors announced this evening.

title: Market's 'Hidden Fist'
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPAMARKOU, ALEXANDER P.
description: PAPAMARKOU-Alexander P. We extend deepest sympathy to Lisa Jewell on the loss of her brother and to those who knew and loved him. His thoughtfulness and generosity to Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts Inc will long be remembered with sincere gratitude. Beverly Sills Chairman of the Board Nathan Leventhal President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Inc.

title: Holding Students Back Won't Help; PBS and Kids' Toys
description: To the Editor:

title: David Blum, 62, Conductor and Author
description: David Blum, a symphonic conductor and a writer on classical music, died on April 17 at a hospice in Kirkland, Wash., near his home in Bellevue. He was 62.

title: Doctors Debate Use of Drug to Help Women's Sex Lives
description: About 100 scientists from drug companies, academia and the Food and Drug Administration met in a hotel here today to ask a pressing question: If Viagra or a drug like it works in women, how would you know?

title: State Police Shoot 3 After Van Backs Into Trooper and Cars
description: A traffic stop on the New Jersey Turnpike erupted into chaos Thursday night when state police troopers shot and wounded three men in a van that backed into a trooper, his cruiser and a passing car that burst into flames.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINLAY, TERENCE. THE REV. DR.
description: FINLAY-Terence. The Rev. Dr. Terence J. Finlay died on April 8 at his home in Grimsby, Ontario, Canada. A memorial service will be held for him at St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue at 51st Street, New York City, on Monday, April 27 at 11:00 AM. Dr. Finlay served as Rector of St. Bartholomew's from 1955 until his retirement in 1978.

title: THE N.B.A PLAYOFFS: Nets Come Close, While Knicks Come Apart; It Takes Overtime For Bulls to Prevail Over Ailing Team
description: The Nets did not march out of the locker room for the start of tonight's game against the Chicago Bulls, they staggered. Keith Van Horn, trying to recover from a stomach virus, appeared ready to faint. Jayson Williams, Rony Seikaly and Sam Cassell, held together with tape and wonders of modern medicine, did not look all that much better.

title: Gilmour Puts on Playoff Face
description: Right now, Doug Gilmour is the only offense the Devils have. And if he keeps playing the way he has been, he might be all they need.

title: FILM IN REVIEW
description: 'Midoq Alley'

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEYER, JOHN
description: MEYER-John. On April 24. Devoted brother of Fred and Eric. Dear brother-in-law of Ruth and Ursula. Loving uncle of Clifford, Tamara, Cathy, Paul, Jonathan and David. Devoted friend of Peggy, Stuart and Julia. He will always be in our hearts. Services 12:15 PM, Sunday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: PRIMESTAR IN DEAL TO BUY UNITED VIDEO SATELLITE UNIT
description: Primestar Partners Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the large-dish satellite television business of United Video Satellite Group for $430 million in securities, aiming to switch the 1.2 million subscribers to Primestar's direct broadcast TV service. Primestar will issue about $430 million in convertible preferred stock to buy Superstar/Netlink Group L.L.C. from United Video, Liberty Media Group Inc. and Turner Vision Inc. It will also assume $50 million in liabilities. The United Video unit is the biggest United States provider of C-band, or large-dish, satellite programming.

title: Layoffs Rupture Tie Between Giuliani and Labor Leader
description: To many New Yorkers, Stanley Hill, head of the giant union representing 120,000 city workers, had long been something of an enigma: He has the power to make mayors quake, yet he had been remarkably docile toward Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and conspicuously silent about the city's much-criticized workfare program.

title: COLONIAL BANCGROUP IS ADDING FIRST MACON BANK
description: Colonial Bancgroup Inc. of Alabama agreed yesterday to acquire the First Macon Bank and Trust Company for about $61 million in stock, as the bank expands into central Georgia. First Macon, a closely held bank with $195 million in assets and five branches, would be Colonial's fourth purchase in Georgia, where it has $500 million in assets around Atlanta and northern Georgia. In the last decade, Colonial, based in Montgomery, Ala., has expanded into fast-growing markets in Florida, Georgia and Tennessee to escape fierce competition in its home state. It acquired 12 Florida banks in the past 18 months, gaining $2.3 billion in assets there. Colonial is Alabama's fifth-largest bank, with $8 billion in assets.

title: Origin of the Pose: Saying 'Cheese' for Darwin
description: The story of how Charles Darwin collected the specimens of human frowns, grimaces, smiles and sneers for his 1872 book ''The Expression of the Emotions in Man and Animals'' would make any naturalist's hair stand on end.

title: FILM IN REVIEW
description: 'The Big Hit'

title: Paid Notice: Memorials   MERESMAN, HELEN CHAFETS
description: MERESMAN-Helen Chafets Whoever said that time heals Did not know grief that seals Within the heart and there it stays As clocks tick on to eternal days And yet we still will share tomorrow Whose joy defuses our deep sorrow.

title: Bush's Letters on Testimony of Agents
description: Following is the text of a letter dated April 15, followed by that of a cover letter, that former President George Bush sent to Lewis C. Merletti, director of the United States Secret Service, regarding the Whitewater independent counsel's effort to compel agents to testify in the investigation of President Clinton:

title: Sentence by Judge Reflects Historic Documents' Value
description: Saying that the theft of hundreds of priceless maps and documents from Columbia University had deprived generations of scholars from being able to study and learn from the past, a Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday sentenced the man responsible to five years in prison.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stocks End Week Lower, Hurt by Earnings Doubts

title: Hooks to Resign Post As Secretary of State
description: Lonna Hooks, who has been Secretary of State since Gov. Christine Todd Whitman took office in 1994, is to leave the position on June 30 for a job at Bloomfield College.

title: Oxford Health Plan's Turnaround Strategy Emerging
description: Norman C. Payson, the doctor named to take the reins of Oxford Health Plans, has begun to outline to employees a strategy to turn around the troubled managed care company. The plan includes overhauling the company's systems and tightening controls.

title: Hill Says Bout Won't Be His Last
description: Questions will surround Virgil Hill, 34, tonight when he steps into the ring in Biloxi, Miss., against Roy Jones Jr. in a 12-round light-heavyweight bout that will be broadcast on HBO. Is he looking at this as a final payday? Can he handle Jones's explosive knockout power?

title: About New York; High Hard One For Families Asking Shelter
description: THE sign atop Yankee Stadium said reassuringly, ''SAFE AT HOME,'' in case fans driving by missed the engineer's decision that their beloved ball park was fit for play. It was almost enough to make you forget that the city's First Fan, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, has suggested spending hundreds of millions for a new stadium, most likely in Manhattan. For now, the Yankees have a place to stay.

title: Bold Double, Killing Lead; A Contract Goes to Its Doom
description: If there were to be an award for the world's most luxurious bridge club, the Regency Whist at 15 East 67th Street, which has its roots in the ancestor game of whist, would be a strong contender. Its playing rooms, bar and dining room are of a quality that would be hard to match anywhere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARREN, VIVIAN ZOE
description: WARREN-Vivian Zoe. Beloved mother of Linda Tirdel. Grandmother of Edward Haber. Sister of the late Metropolitan Opera baritone Leonard Warren and the late Martin Warenoff. Passed away April 23. She was an active member of the Metropolitan Opera Club, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Leonard Warren Foundation, and devoted patron of the vocal arts. Memorial service 9:30, Tuesday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to either the Leonard Warren Foundation, 510-855-2000, or to the cancer fund of your choice.

title: HAIN IN ACCORD TO BUY NATURAL-FOOD BUSINESSES
description: Hain Food Group Inc., the leading natural-food company, said yesterday that it would buy four natural-food businesses from Shansby Group and others for about $80 million. The companies are Arrowhead Mills Inc., which makes organic cereals and flours; DeBoles Nutritional Foods Inc., which produces pasta; Dana Alexander Inc., the inventor of vegetable-based Terra Chips, and Garden of Eatin' Inc., maker of tortillas, corn chips and other snack foods. Hain Food said the companies would more than triple its annual revenue to almost $200 million from $65.4 million. Hain, a producer of natural and kosher foods, said the purchase price included the assumption of $20 million in debt.

title: Lining Up for Kindergarten
description: Now is the season when parents in New York City fret about signing up their children for kindergarten. Choosing the right school, whether it is a magnet school or a traditional neighborhood school, can be difficult, but the decision is even harder when public schools are desperately overcrowded.

title: Setting the Surplus
description: The Congressional Budget Office has put a damper on budget-surplus projections, saying its study of tax receipts shows a surplus range of $8 billion to $18 billion. Page A9.

title: Religion Journal; Old Events and New Help Jews Hold On to Memory
description: Shortly before his synagogue held a service commemorating Yom Hashoah, Holocaust Memorial Day, on Wednesday evening, Rabbi Avi Weiss said the staff at the Hebrew Institute of Riverdale, which he serves as spiritual leader, wanted to try something different.

title: A Hollow Election in Cambodia
description: Cambodia is scheduled to have elections on July 26, and the world is deciding whether to help. If the vote is free and fair, providing the organization running the elections with funds could be crucial to returning elected government to that country. If it is not, the world's participation will provide Cambodia's dictator, Hun Sen, with legitimacy he does not deserve. So far he has shown no willingness to allow even a remotely fair election. The United States and European and Asian countries should refuse to participate in his charade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PALL, HELEN R.
description: PALL-Helen R. Peacefully, at home, at the age of 80, after a very long illness. Loving and beloved wife of David; cherished mother of Jane Block, Ellen Pall and Richard Dicker, Abigail and Fred Weinshank, the late Stephanie Pall, and Olivia and the late William Pall; doting grandmother of Stephen and Lauren Block, Kathryn and Bob Bechler, Elizabeth Block, Hillary and Scott Weinshank, Alex and Caitlin Pall, and Benjamin Dicker; delighted ''G-G'' of Kameron and Mikayla Block and Adam Bechler. Skier, hiker, traveler, lover of the arts and of life. To her husband of 38 precious years, she was the best wife a man ever had. Her gift for reaching out to others created a network of friendships throughout the world. Those who met her as one of the ''Helens'' of the Getler-Pall Gallery remember her enthusiasm, knowledge and warmth. She will be missed by all who knew her. She was a lady. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the American Parkinson Disease Association Inc., 1250 Hylan Blvd., Suite 4B, Staten Island, NY 10305. Services at 2 PM, Sunday, April 26th, at Sunset Chapels, Manhasset, NY (516-482-3600).

title: Dollar's Rise Against Yen Helps to Lift Treasuries
description: Treasury prices ended higher yesterday for the first time this week, lifted in part by the dollar's rally against the yen.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about Michael Naumann, chief executive of Henry Holt & Company, rendered a phrase incorrectly in a remark he made about Salman Rushdie, a Holt author. Mr. Nauman said, ''He's one of the greatest writers of our time'' (not ''the greatest writer of all time'').

title: A.C.L.U. and Speech
description: To the Editor:

title: FILM IN REVIEW
description: 'Bullet on a Wire'

title: Cuts as Political Art
description: In the political petri dish of City Hall, inhabitants learn to communicate in ways that do not always translate well beyond its walls. What is said is not always what is meant; what is meant is not always said.

title: 2 Teen-Agers Are in Limbo After Pleas In Baby Death
description: In the aftermath of their guilty pleas for manslaughter in the death of their newborn son, life for Brian C. Peterson and Amy S. Grossberg remains in limbo -- a patchwork of part-time work, volunteerism, study and curfews. Their lawyers say they have not spoken to each other in months.

title: A $50 Billion Surplus? Doubtful, Report Says
description: Projecting ever bigger Federal budget surpluses has become almost a parlor game here, with politicians and economists pushing the number in the last few weeks to more than $50 billion for this year, a stunning windfall for a nation that long had a reputation for spending away its future.

title: Owen Butler, 74, A Former Chairman Of Procter & Gamble
description: Owen Bradford Butler, who was chairman of the Procter & Gamble Company for much of the 1980's, died on Tuesday at his home in Denver.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDSON, SALLY
description: DAVIDSON-Sally. Suddenly at age sixty-three. Loving wife of Norman. Devoted and beloved mother of Lawrence, Gary and Doreen. Adored grandmother of Andrew, Kristin and Dylan. Cherished mother-in-law of Josie Davidson and Gary P. Gold. Dear sister of Martin and sister-in-law of Marilyn Burstein. Services Sunday, April 26, 9:30AM, the Schwartz BrothersJeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd. at 76th Road, Forest Hills, NY. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, N.J.

title: MEPC, A BRITISH PROPERTY CONCERN, SELLS U.S. HOLDINGS
description: MEPC P.L.C., the British property investment company, said yesterday that it had sold its remaining United States office and industrial properties to three buyers for $368.8 million. MEPC, which said earlier this week that it had sold its eight United States shopping malls to the Chicago-based General Growth Properties Inc. for $871 million, sold the office and industrial properties to Equity Office Properties Trust, Duke Realty Investments and the Weeks Corporation. The properties, which are in Texas, Minnesota and Washington, D.C., were sold for a premium of 8 percent over their book value, MEPC said. MEPC, Britain's third-largest property company, has been selling off its foreign property holdings to refocus its business activities in Britain.

title: Former County Official Guilty of Taking Bribes
description: A Federal jury yesterday convicted a former treasurer and business administrator of Essex County of taking $225,000 in kickbacks to steer municipal bond deals to two underwriting firms, the United States Attorney's office said.

title: Political Memo; Inquiry by Starr Has All the Signs of a Long Run
description: No one except perhaps the American public -- seems to expect an end this year to the hubbub over whether President Clinton had an affair with Monica S. Lewinsky and lied about it under oath.

title: ABC Is Canceling 'Ellen'
description: ABC confirmed yesterday that it had canceled the comedy ''Ellen,'' a year after the show made television history when its lead character, played by Ellen DeGeneres, declared she was a lesbian.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about companies' use of subtle reminders to consumers to replenish products reversed the names of the company that makes Arm & Hammer baking soda. It is the Church & Dwight Company, not Dwight & Church.

title: INSIDE
description: Punishments for Yugoslavia

title: On Workfare or in Union, Mourning Over Lost Jobs
description: For the last three months, Paula Delinois, 32, has shown up at Queens Hospital Center at 10 A.M. to work for her welfare check. She registered patients at the clinic and learned how to use the computers. She had hoped it would lead to a full-time job. But like 1,000 other workfare workers in hospitals around the city, she was told on Thursday that her assignment was over.

title: Giants Rookie Minicamp a Big Deal
description: They all came out to see the rookie show today on the practice field beside Giants Stadium. Both team owners, Wellington Mara and Bob Tisch, were there, as were General Manager Ernie Accorsi and the team's director of player personnel, Tom Boisture. So were a team physician and a team psychologist, and even some front-office personnel wandered out to watch.

title: Tarzan, Now 80, Still Sports a Mean Loincloth
description: A throwback to the days of Saturday afternoon adventures in exotic locales that were usually Hollywood back lots, ''Tarzan and the Lost City'' swung into theaters yesterday, carrying Edgar Rice Burroughs's durable ape-man closer to another millennium.

title: City Delays Enforcement Of New Rules On Vendors
description: Under a judge's prodding, New York City officials agreed yesterday to put off for three weeks the enforcement of new regulations limiting the number of adult magazines that sidewalk newsstands can display and sell.

title: Jean-Francois Lyotard, 73, Dies; Philosopher of the Post-Modern
description: Jean-Francois Lyotard, an eclectic post-modern French philosopher and prolific author who most recently taught at Emory University in Atlanta, died on Tuesday at Necker Hospital in Paris. He was 73 and divided his time between Paris and Atlanta.

title: COTT'S EFFORTS TO FIND A BUYER COME UP EMPTY
description: The Cott Corporation, a soft drink maker, said yesterday that efforts to find a buyer had failed to result in an acceptable offer. Last fall, the Pencer family advised Cott's management that it wanted to sell all or a large part of its controlling interest in the Toronto-based company. In turn, Cott hired financial advisers to evaluate a possible sale of the company. Meetings with interested groups followed, but Cott said it was unlikely that an acceptable offer would be made, and the board was no longer actively pursuing that alternative.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALOMON, SOPHIE
description: SALOMON-Sophie. Age 88. Beloved wife of the late Mardoqueo I. Salomon. She is survived by her loving children Ruth and Edward King, and Hilel and Iole Salomon. She was the adored ''Nana'' of her grandchildren Judith King, Debbie and Jon Green, Diane and Gideon King, Jonny King and Jacqueline Sailer, Alexander and Anick Salomon, Rebekah and Thierry LeMagny, and Joshua Salomon and great-grandchildren Zachary, Aliza and Emma. A lady of unparalleled elegance, grace, dignity and generosity, she will be missed by all her family. We are proud and feel blessed to have had her for so many happy years. Funeral is private. Friends may call on Sunday evening through Tuesday afternoon.

title: For the Mets, It's Again a Familiar Margin of Victory
description: The way Mike Remlinger was pitching against them, the Mets' only hope last night appeared to be getting to the Cincinnati bullpen. But these Mets simply never quit. One-run deficits late in the game? Not to worry.

title: Nokia Profit Leaps 87% On Strong Sales Gains
description: Nokia, the Finnish telecommunications company, said yesterday that its profit soared by 87 percent, to 2 billion markka ($366.4 million) in the first quarter from 1.07 billion markka ($196 million) a year earlier as sales rose sharply in both its telephone equipment and mobile phone businesses. The company said that Nokia Telecommunications' sales rose 42 percent, to 5.287 billion markka ($968.6 million), while sales at Nokia Mobile Phones climbed 29 percent, to 7.959 billion markka ($1.46 billion). Total sales in the quarter rose 31 percent, to 14.97 billion markka ($2.74 billion), Nokia said.

title: ALLIED WASTE INDUSTRIES TO ACQUIRE RABANCO
description: Allied Waste Industries said yesterday that it would acquire the Rabanco Companies, the fourth-largest closely held waste hauler in the United States, adding $175 million in annual revenue. Terms were not disclosed. The Seattle-based Rabanco provides solid-waste collection, recycling, transportation and disposal services in the Pacific Northwest. Allied Waste, based in Scottsdale, Ariz., provides solid-waste services for 1.4 million residential and commercial customers in 18 states, through collection companies, recycling facilities and landfills. Shares of Allied Waste rose $2.625, to $26.1875, in Nasdaq trading.

title: A Haven for the Super-Rich With Room for the Servants
description: In a city of gargantuan ambition, where the Wall Street boom and soaring corporate profits have bestowed fabulous riches on a few, it was perhaps only a matter of time until someone came up with 515 Park Avenue.

title: BUYOUT FIRM JOINS WESCO MANAGERS IN TAKEOVER
description: Managers of the electrical-supply company Wesco Distribution Inc. and the buyout firm Cypress Group L.L.C. said yesterday that they would acquire Wesco for $1.1 billion, including assumed debt. Wesco, based in Pittsburgh, is the nation's No. 2 wholesale distributor of electrical supplies, with 1997 revenue of $2.6 billion. Wesco's current owner, the private investment firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice, acquired it in a $340 million leveraged buyout from the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, predecessor of the CBS Corporation, in 1994. Cypress is a New York-based investment firm. The deal ends a plan to take Wesco public. Clayton Dubilier had intended to sell its 66.4 percent in an initial public offering. CBS, which still has 15.9 percent, will also sell its stake.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN FALLS. The yen retreated on market disappointment with details of Japan's $128 billion package to invigorate the economy, which was viewed as insufficient. In New York the dollar rose to 131.16 yen from 130.18.

title: For a Flood-Weary Napa Valley, A Vote to Let the River Run Wild
description: A good 64 inches of rain has pelted this valley of fine wine and pursuers of the sublime since last July. So last month, in the middle of yet another El Nino-driven storm, Napa Valley residents went to the polls and decided to do something about it.

title: Gotti Lawyer Says Prosecutors' Fear of His Past Victories Is Behind Effort to Disqualify Him
description: Bruce Cutler, the combative lawyer who won national notoriety by keeping John J. Gotti out of prison for years, accused prosecutors today of trying to remove him from the racketeering case of Mr. Gotti's son because they are afraid to face him in court.

title: Fiat Profit Rises 32%, Lifted by State Incentives
description: Fiat S.p.A., Italy's largest car maker, said yesterday that its pretax profit rose 32 percent in the first quarter, bolstered by state incentives to buy new cars and strong truck sales, though it reported a slide in profit at its car division because of difficulties in Brazil. Fiat, which also ranks as Italy's largest industrial company, said its first-quarter pretax profit was 655 billion lire ($368.1 million), compared with 495 billion lire ($278.2 million) a year earlier, in line with expectations. Operating profit rose to 545 billion lire ($306.3 million) from 450 billion lire ($252.9 million), and sales rose 10.7 percent, to 23 trillion lire ($12.93 billion).

Mr. Shorter, one of the most influential jazz musicians of the last 35 years, has left an immense impression on jazz, both as a saxophonist and a composer. Some musicians bring technical innovations to the music; Mr. Shorter changed the emotional climate by bringing a new melancholic optimism that jazz had never heard.

title: F.D.A. Approval Is Just the First Step

If the report is accurate, these reactions are the fourth leading cause of death in this country -- just behind strokes and ahead of pulmonary disease and accidents. And the problem might even be worse than that: the study took into account only hospitalized patients. Plenty of people have reactions to medication at home.

title: City Hall's Good-Times Budget
description: The winds of Wall Street are certainly bringing good weather these days at City Hall. A beaming Mayor Rudolph Giuliani presented the city's $34 billion budget yesterday, a budget with an amazing expanding surplus -- estimated at $1.2 billion in January, $1.5 million in March and now up to $2 billion a few weeks later. And while this heady excess could drive others on a spending binge, the Mayor has prudently decided to use much of what could be a temporary windfall to plug expected spending gaps over the next few years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PROCHASKA, HANS J., M.D. PH.D.
description: PROCHASKA-Hans J., M.D. Ph.D. It is with deep sorrow that the staff of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center note the death of their dear colleague and friend, Dr. Hans Prochaska. From 1991 to 1996 Dr. Prochaska was the Head of the Laboratory for Chemical-Biological Interactions at Sloan-Kettering Institute, and Assistant Professor of Pharmacology at Cornell Graduate School of Medical Sciences and Cornell Medical College. In 1992, Dr. Prochaska was the recipient of the prestigious American Cancer Society's Junior Faculty Research Award. Dr. Prochaska had the instinctive ability to translate his imaginative research into therapeutic applications. He carried out the first experiments demonstrating the cancer protective effects of broccoli. Dr. Prochaska leaves the legacy of his work for future patients and researchers. He will be greatly missed. We extend sincerest condolences to his wife Kathleen, his daughter Erica, and the entire Prochaska family. The staff of Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center

title: U.S. Accord With Panama on Troops Hits a Snag
description: Late last year, the President of Panama announced that his Government had ''reached an agreement'' with Washington on a drug interdiction center that would permit American troops to stay here after the United States gives up control of the Panama Canal and the last of the military bases around it on Dec. 31, 1999. Only ''some details'' needed to be worked out, a State Department spokesman said.

title: How Conversions Can Take a Toll
description: INVESTORS who pester fund managers to convert their closed-end funds to open-end status should be careful what they hope for. Unless shareholders sell their closed-end shares at the right time, they may end up with lagging returns, high tax bills or both.

title: Miss Shackelford And Mr. Holland
description: Virginia Travis Shackelford, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Scott Shackelford 3d of Roanoke, Va., was married last evening to Kent Holland, the son of Martha Grimes of Washington and Edwin Van Holland of Baltimore. The Rev. Thomas Peyton O'Dell performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Roanoke.

title: Catherine Sitrick, A. R. B. Shepard
description: Catherine Baker Sitrick, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Baker Sitrick of New York, was married yesterday to Alexander Richard Broadley Shepard, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Giles Shepard of Nether Wallop, England. The Rev. Charles H. Clark, the former headmaster of St. Paul's School, performed the ceremony at St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.

title: Anger at Plan for Ex-Convicts
description: When Asia Speller spoke, she was angry. Ms. Speller opposes the Fortune Society's plans to establish a program for ex-convicts in a vacant castlelike building across from the apartment complex where her family lives, at Riverside Drive and 139th Street.

description: OVER the last three years, it would have been hard for an investor to go wrong buying the large mainstream stock funds managed by some of the country's biggest fund companies.

title: Hospital Merger Produces a Way to Do Good Close to Home
description: For the past month Khaliqa Bell, a 10-year-old fifth grader at George Washington Carver School here, has been a regular at a new clinic at the school, where she is treated for her eczema. The daily visits have replaced the twice-weekly appointments with a private physician who saw her when her mother could still afford the health insurance offered by her employer.

title: Benjamin Rosenstadt, Jane Lubowitz
description: Jane Lubowitz, the deputy bureau chief of the sex crimes and special victims unit in the Brooklyn District Attorney's office, was married last evening to Dr. Benjamin Edward Rosenstadt, an orthopedic surgeon. Rabbi William I. Kuhn officiated at the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia.

description: A Super Working Off Site

title: Culinary Tribute to the Titanic
description: SALIVATING over the elegance of the ocean liner Titanic is like eating bittersweet chocolate -- a gluttonous pleasure made more so by the pangs of guilt that accompany it. Fans of James Cameron's blockbuster film say they are fascinated by the ship's opulence, but it is that splendor paired with such colossal disaster that has awed millions.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEBER, MURRAY J.
description: WEBER-Murray J. Of Delray Beach, FL, formerly of Atlantic Beach, LI, died peacefully April 25, 1998. Beloved husband of Sydelle. Devoted father, father-in-law and grandfather. We will miss our loving father dearly. Margie, Eileen and Jackie

title: Our Towns; No Rush Here To Help Lure The Yankees
description: IT'S rush hour in this on-off ramp of a town, and it is vicious.

title: In Motion: Buses For the Disabled
description: WHEELCHAIR users have been waiting a long time for the bus. While buses with wheelchair lifts on their back doors are becoming commonplace in municipal systems around the country, they are almost nonexistent in the fleets of Greyhound and other major bus companies. But now lift buses may be on the way for intercity travel, a result of the sweeping 1990 civil rights law called the Americans With Disabilities Act.

title: DUCK AND COVER
description: When John Q. Motorist zips through Paradise Valley, Ariz., his speed is captured on automatic radar and a camera snaps his face and license plate. The ticket is processed by computer and arrives by mail soon after. The system is used elsewhere -- Oakland, Calif., for instance -- but the Arizonans are pacesetters in scofflaw techniques designed to obscure their faces or plates. (Without positive ID's for both, tickets can't be issued.) Lately, an increasing number of drivers have resorted to simply covering their mugs. Halloween masks, ski masks. . .one car appeared to have no driver at all. Apparently, a police department spokesman says, the driver ducked below the dashboard. The cops are considering criminal prosecution, but of course that's tough, since they can't identify the culprit.

title: Drugs in the Suburbs
description: Does drug use attract different attention when it takes place in the suburbs rather than the cities?

title: For Many Blue-Collar Fathers, Child Care Is Shift Work, Too
description: CHRISTOPHER HEIB rises before dawn to get to his day job as a power line worker for the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power. But just as important to him is his second shift -- taking care of his sons Rudy, 6, and Thomas, a newborn.

title: Tobacco Town Changing Image As Reports on Smoking Darken
description: Seven years ago, George Howard's telephone began to ring repeatedly with anonymous, belligerent calls. Wherever he went in Winston-Salem -- to church, to the supermarket -- the snide comments seemed to follow.

McEvoy, also of New York. The Rev. Kevin A. McGrath officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel took part in the service.

description: As a co-founder of the Parent Education and Custody Effectiveness (Peace) program, I would like to thank you for the April 5 article ''Program Helps Divorced Parents Ease the Effect on Children.''

title: Arcade Ban Ends
description: Despite protests from ministers and parents, the White Plains Common Council has ended its 20-year ban on arcades in the Galleria mall, paving the way for zoning officials to approve a 60-game arcade and entertainment store, recently proposed by a company called Dream Machine.

title: Discounted Tickets To N.Y. Attractions
description: Citypass, a booklet with tickets providing admission to six New York attractions, goes on sale in New York on May 1. It will be sold at the admission offices of the six attractions: the American Museum of Natural History, (212) 769-5100; the Empire State Building observatories, (212) 736-3100; the Intrepid Sea Air Space Museum, (212) 245-0072; the Metropolitan Museum, (212) 535-7710; the Museum of Modern Art, (212) 708-9400, and the observatories at 2 World Trade Center, (212) 323-2340.

description: Alexander Papamarkou, a philanthropist and international investment banker whose clients included royalty, industrialists and major institutions, died Thursday at St. Luke's Roosevelt Hospital in New York. He was 68 and lived in Manhattan.

title: Word & Image; Bribery Rules
description: They buried the stillborn fetus of campaign finance reform in Washington this month, and before closing the casket, they threw in the carcass of the marginally effective 1974 Watergate reform as well. Bill Clinton, Trent Lott and Newt Gingrich were the principal pallbearers, but they were followed to the grave by a cortege of politicians, pollsters, consultants and lobbyists, many weeping crocodile tears.

title: With Houston Misfiring, the Knicks Look for Answers
description: So this is what it is like to be the team star. It means being the focus of Coach Pat Riley's clipboard jottings and having attention heaped on you like dirt on a grave site.

title: Sue Kelly: An Upstart Settling In
description: HER detractors reside on both sides of the aisle, with many Democrats viewing her as a Newt Gingrich clone and some in the conservative wing of the Republican Party, her own party, rejecting her as a liberal. What no one disputes -- not even her supporters or Representative Sue W. Kelly herself -- is that the Congresswoman from the 19th District has been a controversial figure on Capitol Hill, especially when it comes to environmental matters.

title: Sports of The Times; The Trade That Wasn't Made: Richmond to Miami
description: SOMEWHERE during the playoffs, perhaps as soon as this afternoon, Tim Hardaway's jumpers from afar will not fall and Alonzo Mourning will have more fouls than points and Pat Riley will not be able to wish upon another star. He will regret not having found a way to bring Mitch Richmond home.

title: Husband and Wife Win In Central Park Race
description: Like all married couples, Alan Ruben and his wife, Gordon Bakoulis, of Manhattan do not agree on everything.

description: The Central Intelligence Agency, the cloak-and-dagger ministry that once seriously considered trying to eliminate Fidel Castro with a poisoned SCUBA suit, has a new caper, a website home page for children.

The Rev. Dr. Richard M. Cromie, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the Royal Poinciana Chapel.

title: Why 'Titanic' Conquered the World; Cairo
description: Most of the films showing in Egyptian cinemas these days tend to highlight the gritty side of life: poverty, street thuggery, even a vulgar competition for the affections of a man married to two women. Not so ''Titanic,'' of course, and critics say that this is an important reason that the American movie has so quickly become beloved in a country whose own classics have always reached for the romantic heights.

description: EVERY year I try to be in Montauk the second week in May.

title: Edith Head, the Costume Drama
description: AT a time when even the grungiest pop singers are playing the diva and dressing like Hollywood starlets, fashion is having an Edith Head moment. The spirit of Ms. Head, the legendary costume designer, is felt in every drop-dead evening gown on VH1 and every prim below-the-knee skirt on the runways. As the designer Betsey Johnson said last week, ''Fashion is more vintage and old-movie-inspired than ever.''

title: Through Trade and Aid, Iraqi Official Says, Embargo Is Eroding
description: With sanctions against Iraq likely to be extended next week for another six months, Iraq's Foreign Minister said today that the embargo imposed in 1990 is eroding and with it Baghdad's isolation. He predicted that this process would accelerate.

title: DRAKE RELAYS
description: Suzy Hamilton overcame a wind that gusted to 20 miles an hour to set a meet record of 2 minutes 1.68 seconds for 800 meters at the Drake Relays yesterday in Des Moines.

title: World Shopping
description: To the Editor: Sarah Ferrell's ''Storytelling Souvenir'' (April 5) reminded me of some meaningful souvenirs given me in exchange for my dime-store possessions.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the Streetscapes column last Sunday, about East 57th Street between Third and Lexington Avenues, misstated the progress of the refacing of a power plant. The project is planned, but has not yet taken place.

title: A Bit of History Is Dried Up
description: As caretaker of the Billiou-Stillwell-Perine House at 1476 Richmond Road near Cromwell Avenue, Lorraine Danischewski is responsible for the security of Staten Island's oldest home. But she couldn't stop the city from taking away something she considered a valuable part of the 1662 property.

description: BY looking backward, Jay Seldin provides some assurance that the computer may figure in the future of art as more than a labor-saving tool. It may lead to new kinds of art, art that shakes free of obvious technological underpinnings.

title: Voters, Though Just a Few, Pass Most School Budgets
description: Voters in 551 districts in the state voted last week on school budgets, candidates for boards of education and, in some districts, on whether they wanted to finance specific programs or building projects. The percentage of budgets that gained voter approval dropped to 74.6 percent from 76.2 percent last year. The percentage of special financing questions that were approved took the largest drop, going from 67.6 percent a year ago to 56.7 percent this year.

description: HOW do investors in Internet stocks feel this year?

title: POSTINGS: $50 Million Project in 1890 Building on West 13th Street in Far West Village; From a Printing Plant to 47 Loft Condominiums
description: Dust rose last week as a construction crew demolished the walls of the freight elevator shaft on the ground floor of 345 West 13th Street at Hudson Street in the Far West Village. The six-story 1890 buff-brick building, which was occupied by a printing company for 37 years, is being turned into a condominium with unconventional configurations.

title: 'You'll Be Hearing From Us Soon'
description: To hear the folks in human resources tell it, interviews bring out the oddest behavior in some applicants. Job seekers, though, have their own stories about interviewers who aren't ready for prime time. Applicants, unite and reveal all! Send your best stories to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or send them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

title: Remember Roy Jones? Virgil Hill Is Likely To
description: Roy Jones Jr. does not fight often, and he takes a lot of flak for that. But when he steps into the ring, it is worth the wait.

title: Salads of Rice, Barley and Wheat Berries, Enhanced by Herbs
description: WHOLE grains -- like rice, barley and wheat berries -- have rich, nutty, satisfying flavors, but they also beg for embellishment. With the addition of herbs, onions and other vegetables -- and a little dressing -- they can be turned into delicious salads.

title: Sports of The Times; The Saga of the Ottawa Senators: Silliness, Losses and Videotapes
description: ONCE the Ottawa Senators were hockey's version of the early New York Mets, or of pro football's early Tampa Bay Bucs -- good for a laugh, not good for the game. The night the burglars stole the expansion team's video equipment, they ignored the game tapes.

title: Proper Way to Use a Volt-Ohm Meter
description: TROUBLESHOOTING electrical malfunctions can be frustrating because breaks in insulated wires or within components are not obvious.

title: Why 'Titanic' Conquered the World; Beijing
description: ''Titanic'' was a hit in China well before its recent official opening in cities around the country. Urban young people are acutely aware of Hollywood's latest films and stars, and weeks ago, pirated, crudely made videos and laser disks of ''Titanic'' began selling briskly on street corners and playing in university lounges.

description: DVORAK: WORKS FOR VIOLIN

title: PLAY BRAWL
description: * A new book, ''World's Greatest Sports Brawls,'' calls baseball the ''best sport for tales of bad behavior by tantrum-throwing athletes.'' * Last year, 180 pro ballplayers were ejected (most for fighting and arguing), up from 176 in 1996. * Baseball fights have a storied history. In 1912, Ty Cobb attacked a handicapped heckler named Carl Lucker, kicking him while a bystander yelled, ''He has no hands!'' * During an at-bat in 1965, Juan Marichal (San Francisco Giants pitcher) decided that John Roseboro (Los Angeles Dodgers catcher) nicked his ear on a throw back to the pitcher, so he clubbed him with his bat. * Last summer, the all-female Colorado Silver Bullets tangled with the all-male Americus (Ga.) Travelers. ''As good a brawl as I've ever seen,'' said Phil Niekro, the Silver Bullets manager. * The upside of basebrawl: fines are tax deductible.

title: Weary Hands At the Throttle
description: FOR the Union Pacific Railroad workers crowded between shifts into a motel break room here, beetles crunching under their work boots, nights and weekends never arrive. And almost everyone has stories about their schedules.

title: Mothers Can't Win
description: I was surprised to find no article on lesbian mothers. I know several couples with babies, and several more who are currently trying to get pregnant.

title: Julie Goldstein And David Tager
description: Julie Michelle Goldstein, the daughter of Marvin R. Goldstein of Fair Lawn, N.J., and the late Florence Goldstein, is to be married this evening to David Ian Tager, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles W. Tager of Todt Hill, Staten Island, and Montauk, N.Y. Rabbi Simon Gluckstrom will officiate at the University Club in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Manhattan, Bronx, Westchester and Connecticut copies last Sunday about downtown Stamford included a company incorrectly among those that have left that city. Champion International retains its headquarters in downtown Stamford.

title: A Soft Revolution And Its Leaders
description: Are the cardigan and twin-sweater set replacing the century-old tailored jacket? Some women think so. The changing of the guard isn't yet official, but the cardigan is already being worn as a serious replacement. The most popular sweaters are solid-color twin sets and lush fur-trimmed cardigans. This spring's luxurious knitwear reflects a breezy American style, speaking loudly and eloquently of high fashion's turn to informality.
