description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The Acrostic on page 122 of The Times Magazine today renders Definition A incorrectly. The first line should read, ''there's a ---- in the old dame yet.''

title: Building Momentum With Foreign Stocks
description: IT would be difficult to find two more cosmopolitan stock pickers. Henrik Strabo, 38, a native of Copenhagen, moved to the United States as a teen-ager to attend the University of Washington and decided to stick around. Mark S. Kopinski, 41, meanwhile, took a different route, leaving his home outside of Chicago in 1973 to become a Rotary exchange student in Kariya, Japan. He liked it so much that he returned later, living in Tokyo for 10 years.

title: SOAPBOX; Steps in Time
description: AFTER we moved to Princeton from New York in 1945 when I was 2 years old, I so quickly started dancing classes in Rose Cottage that Princeton, dancing and Rose Cottage all seem one and the same to me. I was told that Rose Cottage had belonged to the daughter of Woodrow Wilson. I have no idea whether this is true, but I like the idea and choose to believe it. It conjures up the image of beaux arriving in Model T's, groups of boys and girls gathering for hot chocolate after a long walk down Nassau Street, and singing around the piano.

title: Once Upon a Time, the New Jersey Devil Meant More Than Hockey
description: Harry Leeds has more than a casual interest in the Jersey Devil, the legendary monster of the Pine Barrens that is also known as the Leeds Devil.

title: Commercial Fabric Changes as Paterson Silk Goes
description: Even before Virgin, the music and video retailer, and Circuit City, the electronics chain, announced they would join the other retail powerhouses in Union Square, Paterson Silks, at 14th Street and University Place, seemed like an anachronism. Its discount fabrics and mending supplies evoked the neighborhood's former days as a bargain mecca.

title: STRANGLED LIFELINE: A special report.; Shortage of Plasma Drug Creates Health Care Crisis
description: At first, Nick Valestrino seemed like just another teen-ager with a run-of-the-mill case of chicken pox. Then came the strep throat. Followed by the pneumonia. Followed by the stomach infections. Back again to strep. For more than a year, sickness ravaged Mr. Valestrino, leaving him weakened and desolate. Worst of all, his doctors could not explain why it was happening.

title: Suddenly the Object Of Much Attention
description: THESE days, people want to talk about sex with Paul Rudd, but he's just not in the mood.

title: April 19-25; Another Trade Zone (Maybe)
description: At the second Summit of the Americas in Santiago, Chile, President Clinton and 33 other heads of state from the Western Hemisphere agreed to begin negotiations in September to create the world's largest free-trade zone, stretching from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego.

title: April 19-25; A Teen Pleads Guilty In Baby's Death
description: The specter of a death sentence or life in prison is gone for Amy Grossberg and Brian Peterson, now that they have pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the death of their infant son in 1996 and Delaware has dropped its charges that they murdered him.

title: Report Cards on Bus Routes Spread to a Wider Public
description: The M79 bus arrived at a stop so crowded that dozens of people who were waiting could not board. A driver on the M15 failed to respond to a disabled man's request to call out a stop. Someone had to wait 20 minutes for the M86.

title: Money in the Bank? What's It Costing?
description: MARY PENGRIN-SAL isn't serious when she says, ''Bomb Citibank!'' She is just frustrated. ''They overcharge for everything,'' she said.

title: Causes Worth Applause
description: When it comes to things like helping youngsters, the arts, public TV and students, they also serve who stand and clap.

title: Sports of The Times; MetroStars' Ramos Makes Strong Claim for the Last Seat to Paris
description: They have been teammates, on and off, for 18 years, going back to a team called Thistle, a few New Jersey towns away in Kearny. This was the year that Tab Ramos and John Harkes were going to ride off into the sunset like Butch and Sundance -- maybe into a hail of cannonballs from Germany and Yugoslavia at the World Cup, but still not a bad way to leave the international soccer trail.

title: April 19-25; Ebbets Field Without Bums
description: Those who remember Ebbets Field in the 1950's recall a ballfield of peculiar charms: small enough to be both intimate and cramped, old enough to evoke memories and feel outdated even then. The sight lines could be awful, blocked by columns all down the foul lines. Arguably, the 75-cent upper-deck bleachers, directly behind the center field wall and high enough to let the common fan see every breaking pitch, offered some of the best views in the house.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARLSTEIN, RABBI AARON S.
description: PEARLSTEIN-Rabbi Aaron S. Age 61, of Rockville, MD. Beloved husband of Dr. Peggy Kronsberg Pearlstein. Devoted son of Dr. Jacob Z'L and Edith Pearlstein Z'L. Adored father of Jack, Sam, and Dr. Ora Pearlstein. Loving fatherin-law of Marisol LaMadrid and Sheryl Saranga Pearlstein. Cherished zayde of Ivanna and Ian Pearlstein, and Joshua and Noah Pearlstein. Caring brother of Gilla Pearlstein (Rabbi Mordechai Z'L) Rubin Z'L. Dear brother-in-law of Rose and Ted Levin and Sandy and Gerry Skalka, treasured uncle of Dr. Shuly Rubin (Rabbi Gerson) Schwartz, Dr. Alisa Rubin (Rabbi Neil) Kurshan, Jack (Leslie) Rubin, Bruce (Abby) Levin, Daphne (Ofer) Hubara, Jenn, Michael and Ariel Skalka. Esteemed son-in-law of Adele and Macey Kronsberg. Services today 1 PM at ''Gutterman's'' (Parkside Bldg.) 98-60 Queens Blvd., at 66th Rd., Rego Park, NY. Shiva is observed at 14 Shagbark Court, Rockville, MD. Contributions in his memory can be made to Masorti Foundation for Conservative Judaism in Israel, 6525 Belcrest Rd., Suite 602, Hyattsville, MD 20782 or Ziv Tzedakah Fund, 384 Wyoming Ave., Millburn, NJ 07041.

title: Crackdown on Cheating
description: Fifty people are accused of collecting unemployment checks while employed, stealing anywhere from $1,316 to $8,475 each from the State Department of Labor, Commissioner James J. McGowan and District Attorney Jeanine Pirro of Westchester reported last week. All are charged with fourth-degree grand larceny, a felony punishable by up to four years in jail.

title: Tracey Navin and Bruce Ewing
description: Tracey Ann Navin and Bruce Roy Millar Ewing were married last evening by the Rev. James Covington at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title: Authors to Sign Books At Annual School Fair
description: THE Post Road School in White Plains is celebrating its annual Author/Illustrator Evening on Wednesday, and the event has been keeping many people busy. Teachers selected books from the 50 guests to assign or read to their classes. They also prepared classroom and assembly visits by selected authors and illustrators, and students made banners for participants to identify their book-signing tables.

title: A Plaza, a Blight, Perhaps a Park
description: For years, neighborhood residents and community leaders have complained that Sheffield Plaza, on Ninth Avenue between 56th and 57th Streets, is an unsightly haven for criminals and the homeless.

title: Colin Powell's Calypso Tour
description: When Americans think of calypso music, they usually imagine a steel-drum orchestra playing beachfront Muzak. Gen. Colin Powell grew up with the real thing: Trinidadian music derived from traditional African chanting and drumming, often containing sexual double-entendre lyrics. Although Powell, the son of Jamaican immigrants, was a model Episcopalian acolyte during his boyhood in the Bronx, he's no choirboy. The reserved military man is a serious calypso fan, and his favorite artist is the Mighty Sparrow, a legendary singer who is known as ''the master of the naughty phrase.'' During a recent visit to give a speech to Trinidad's business community, Powell -- pictured with the Sparrow (center) and Trinidad's Prime Minister, Basdeo Panday (right) -- demonstrated that he knows the territory, both naughty and nice. Here's a look.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARREN, VIVIAN ZOE
description: WARREN-Vivian Zoe. Beloved mother of Linda Tirdel. Grandmother of Edward Haber. Sister of the late Metropolitan Opera baritone Leonard Warren and the late Martin Warenoff. Passed away April 23. She was an active member of the Metropolitan Opera Club, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the Leonard Warren Foundation, and devoted patron of the vocal arts. Memorial service 9:30, Tuesday, at ''The Riverside,'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her memory to either the Leonard Warren Foundation, 510-855-2000, or to the cancer fund of your choice.

title: Mothers Can't Win
description: As the mother of two young daughters, I was frankly too tired to read yet another dissection of motherhood. So I turned first to the food section, expecting to get the usual laugh from your recipes, which typically are geared to those with unlimited time and money and no kids. Imagine my surprise to find that the first recipe was one for macaroni and cheese. Thanks for the token nod to us moms who actually cook to feed the next generation of New York Times readers.

title: Suspicion That Strangles Love
description: SOCRATES was accused of corrupting youth. So is John Burroughs, who happens to be a teacher of classical civilization in ''The Council of 30,'' at the George Street Playhouse here. Between 399 B.C. in Athens and ''the present in multiple locales,'' in the words of the program, perverters of the young and the pure, proven and alleged, factual and fictitious, have been defended and vilified by the thousands. But they weren't all wearing togas.

title: Stephanie Ades, Glenn Salzman
description: Stephanie Ann Ades, a daughter of Ellen and Norman Ades of West Orange, N.J., was married last evening to Glenn Matthew Salzman, the son of Andrea and Martin J. Salzman of Orangeburg, N.Y. Rabbi Steven Fox officiated at the Olde Mill Inn in Basking Ridge, N.J.

title: Vacant! 4 Rms Nice Vu
description: Most people evidently walk right past without noticing them, but the four colorful birdhouses hanging off the light pole on the southeast corner of 29th Street and Fifth Avenue are a mystery to those who do look up. The habitats -- miniature models of a yellow taxi, a slope-roofed house, a helicopter with ''VIP'' on the tail and a graceful goose -- hang by chains along the pole that thrusts a traffic light over Fifth Avenue. Each is a foot long, with a circular entrance.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIDSON, SALLY
description: DAVIDSON-Sally. Suddenly at age sixty-three. Loving wife of Norman. Devoted and beloved mother of Lawrence, Gary and Doreen. Adored grandmother of Andrew, Kristin and Dylan. Cherished mother-in-law of Josie Davidson and Gary P. Gold. Dear sister of Martin and sister-in-law of Marilyn Burstein. Services Sunday, April 26, 9:30AM, the Schwartz BrothersJeffer Memorial Chapels, 114-03 Queens Blvd. at 76th Road, Forest Hills, NY. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, N.J.

title: Culture of Scandal Turns Inquiry Into an Industry
description: The Washington scandal machine has now come full circle.

title: Fears of Deadly Organism Cast Shadow on Chesapeake
description: Shortly after sunup today, Doug Hall and his helper, Jim Arnold, were busy loading 120 crab pots onto Mr. Hall's boat to be dropped into the Pocomoke River, something they will do routinely now through late fall.

title: Time and Again in North Carolina
description: A WORD of advice if you're tempted to merely pass through New Bern, N.C., en route to the ever popular Outer Banks: Don't. A quick stopover won't do it justice. Last May my husband, Van, and I learned this the hard way when, in a misguided attempt to reach the Banks before dusk the next day, we allotted ourselves just 24 hours to spend in this historic Low Country port situated at the confluence of the Neuse and Trent Rivers.

title: Japan of Green Gables
description: Every year, thousands of Japanese tourists make a pilgrimage to a green-gabled Victorian farmhouse in the town of Cavendish on Prince Edward Island, Canada. Kids, the elderly, young couples and the biggest fans, Japanese women -- they all come to snap pictures of a house that inspired ''Anne of Green Gables,'' the 1908 novel by the Canadian author Lucy Maud Montgomery. The book has been huge in Japan since 1954, when it was printed in Japanese and made part of the junior-high curriculum. A TV program based on a sequel, ''Anne of Avonlea,'' increased the pool of fans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ALPERT, ETHEL JEAN
description: ALPERT-Ethel Jean. On April 23, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Aaron. Loving mother of Steven and Lawrence. Dear sister of Florence and Maralin. Devoted grandmother of Leslie, Caren, Lily and Jacob. Graveside service on Sunday, at 11:15 A.M., at the Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Can't Dance, and Doesn't Have To
description: Walter McCloud, the protagonist of Jane Hamilton's third novel, THE SHORT HISTORY OF A PRINCE (Random House, $23), loves the ballet, and as a teen-ager in suburban Chicago he dreams of starring as the prince in a production of ''The Nutcracker'' or ''Swan Lake.'' However, the ballet does not love clumsy, nearly flat-footed Walter, so his devotion turns into an extra source of adolescent humiliation. With intelligence and empathy -- and drawing on rich veins of irony -- Hamilton tells the story of Walter's search to define his talents and defy the meaning of his all-too-appropriate name (which, the Oxford English Dictionary tells him, means ''to move or go unsteadily; to totter, stumble''). Thus the novel deftly alternates between two sections of narrative, set during two crucial years in his life. The first introduces us to 15-year-old Walter in Illinois in 1972, coming to grips with his homosexuality, his lack of dancing skills and the fact that his confident, all-American brother is dying of cancer. The second, which begins in September 1995, reveals 38-year-old Walter as a witty, warmhearted man full of regret for having spent his early adulthood pursuing ''the pleasures consigned to youth'' in Manhattan's gay community -- and full of determination to reorder his life by taking a job teaching high school English in a farm town near his family's summer home. By subtly amassing a wealth of emotional detail from these very different periods in Walter's life, Hamilton summons up his compassion, his devotion to his family and his gifts as a connoisseur, all of which are displayed in a finale that is at once surprising and redemptive. Megan Harlan

title: The World: The Mayor and the Mullahs; The Mouths That Roared in Iran
description: IRAN hasn't been quite the same since the popular Mayor of Teheran was thrown into prison on April 4 on charges of embezzlement and corruption that many Iranians believe are politically motivated. The arrest of the Mayor, Gholam Hussein Karbaschi, unleashed a storm of debate in the press not seen since the early days of the Islamic revolution that overthrew Shah Mohammed Reza Pahlevi in 1979. The public furor reflected the more open political atmosphere ushered in with the election last May of President Mohammed Khatami, an ally of the Mayor.

title: Weathers Puts a Dominating Victory in Perspective
description: Sitting in a Philadelphia hotel room last Tuesday afternoon, David Weathers began, in his own words, to prioritize his life. He had five hours to reflect on baseball's place in it before an airplane took him home to rural Tennessee, where his 56-year-old father, Rual, had died that morning.

title: Math, Math Everywhere
description: NEATLY dressed in a shirt and tie, Luis Andrade studied the computer in the reservations office of the Hyatt Regency here. His job was to determine the total room rate for a family staying six days in a $224 room, a snap, perhaps, for the hotel's regular staff, but Luis is only in the fourth grade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPAMARKOU, ALECKO
description: PAPAMARKOU - Alecko. The Board of Trustees and the staff of the Central Park Conservancy mourn the passing of Alecko Papamarkou, a very generous friend to Central Park. In loving memory of his mother Margot, Alecko recently endowed the Pond landscape, located in the southeastern section of Central Park. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his family, friends and colleagues. Ara M. Millstein, Chairman Karen H. Putnam, President

title: Why 'Titanic' Conquered the World; Buenos Aires
description: In Argentina, where an average of 70,000 people have seen ''Titanic'' each week since it opened in February, the film has become the stuff of television parody. On one popular morning talk program, for example, the host, Georgissa, let fly barbs about the country's social and political ills as she hung on to a sinking ship, soaked to the skin.

title: By Request
description: JAPANESE restaurants require careful navigation, especially on the part of visitors who don't know the terrain. Novices can walk into Ichiban Sushi Masa, a modest Japanese restaurant in a typically dull shopping center, eat gluey teriyaki and pre-fab sushi, and wonder, why all the hoopla?

title: For Actor, 'Break a Leg' Meant Bad Luck
description: Bryan Hull broke the record one more time, and then walked out of the Sullivan Street Playhouse and broke his leg. The freak accident abruptly ended one of the most remarkable runs in the history of the New York theater.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction
description: STILL LIVES By Natsuki Ikezawa. Kodansha, $25.

title: In the Region/Long Island; For Gurney's Inn, an End in Sight From Bankruptcy
description: THE sky was sullen and April winds still had a sharp bite. But inside the Gurney's Inn Resort & Spa co-op on Old Montauk Highway overlooking the Atlantic Ocean, the mood was the brightest it has been since December 1994 when the 109-unit time-share resort filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection to ward off foreclosure.

description: FEIVELSON-Sheila F. Happy Birthday April 30. You are always in our hearts. Hugs and kisses. Your loving family and friends

title: Mothers Can't Win
description: I read your issue cover to cover. As a 35-year-old newlywed, I have observed with interest a phenomenon I call the single-mother spouse -- women who are married but are so single-handedly involved in the child rearing that they are de facto single mothers. The women I have known well enough to ask tell me that this was not an agreement made with their husbands but something that evolved ''naturally,'' much to their frustration. I have yet to see a case of ''the single-father spouse.''

title: The World; With Promises, Promises, NATO Moves the East
description: IN the United States, the question of whether to expand NATO eastward has been debated only in fits and starts, and then most passionately on the issues of how the Russians feel about it and whether it might cost too much.

description: THE Polo Grille and Wine Bar in New Haven is a bustling new restaurant on familiar ground, the large corner space recently occupied by Bagdon's, before that by L'Avventura and, still earlier, by Curious Jane's.

description: A parole hearing date of May 21 has been set for Tony Ayala Jr., the 35-year-old former world junior-middleweight contender, who has served 15 years in three New Jersey prisons for a rape he committed as a 19-year-old in 1981.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEDIN, EMERIC J.
description: BEDIN-Emeric J., 77. Passed away April 22, 1998 in the loving warmth of his wife, daughter and son after a courageous battle with cancer. Born Oct. 18, 1920 in Rockford, IL, son of Girolamo & Angela. His youth was spent in Brendola, Italy and returned to Rockford in 1928 through Ellis Island. After his retirement in 1980 from the City of Rockford with 34 years of service, he spent most of his time in Italy, and in New York City where his daughter Janet lives. Emeric was a U.S. Army World War II hero landing in Normandy and was interviewed by WABC-TV in 1995 for carrying out his battle with cancer like a military operation, ''he just wouldn't give up.'' When he was hit with a piece of shrapnel in France he didn't fall down, he just kept on fighting for which he received the Purple Heart and many other medals. Emeric said, ''You were taught to outfox your enemy, that is what I did in the war and that is what I'll do with my cancer.'' The family would like to thank the doctors who believed in Emeric's valiant fight and to not give up on him because of a terminal illness & to those he convinced he was a warrior with every comeback defying the odds. The battle ended 2 years beyond the statistics; his spirit won and lives on. Emeric's legacy in battling cancer are in the following: ''We shall go on to the end. We shall fight in France, we shall fight on the beaches, we shall fight in the landing grounds, we shall never surrender''. (Churchill, 1940). Survivors include his wife Dolores, son Alexander of Rockford and daughter Janet Bedin of NYC, all of whom will miss and love him dearly. Funeral services 10:30 am, April 30, St. Anthony Church in Rockford. Visitation from 6-8 PM, April 29 at the Olson Funeral Chapel, 2811 N. Main Street, Rockford, Il. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be given to the family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERRISFORD, CHRISTOPHER
description: BERRISFORD-Christopher. April 19, 1998, at age 68, in Hong Kong, from complications following heart surgery. Beloved husband of Suzy Moser, devoted father of Sara and Nicholas, and loving brother of Hillary Adair of Haslamere, England. Mr. Berrisford had a distinguished career in education as Headmaster of St. Mark's School in Dallas, TX, of the Harvard School in North Hollywood, CA, of Trinity School from 1987 to 1991, and since 1991, head of the Chinese International School in Hong Kong. He was born in Hampshire, England, and received a degree in Honors History at Queens College, Oxford, & a Masters in Education at Harvard University. Contributions in his memory may be made to the HarvardWestlake School, 3700 Coldwater Canyon Avenue, North Hollywood, California 91604, and the Chinese International School, 1 Hau Yuen Path, Braemar Hill, Hong Kong.

description: Rosemary Gaynor McCown and Jonathan David Miller were married yesterday at the Church Center for the United Nations in New York. The Rev. Robert M. McCown, a Roman Catholic priest and an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony with Rabbi Charles D. Lippman.

description: THE PROUDEST DAY

title: Lawsuits Challenging Fees on Waste Disposal
description: Two trade associations of waste-disposal companies last week filed lawsuits against Atlantic and Gloucester Counties to overturn a surcharge on garbage used to pay off bonds issued to build waste-disposal facilities.

title: 'Dishonorable' River
description: American Rivers of Washington, a national environmental organization, has given the Hudson River a ''dishonorable mention'' on its 1998 list of the country's 20 most endangered rivers. The designation follows the United States Environmental Protection Agency's announcement last month that it would delay its decision on whether to dredge polychlorinated biphenyls from the bottom of the Hudson.

title: Editorial Observer; Urban Geometry Along the East River's Edge
description: Last week I took a taxi from La Guardia across the Triborough Bridge and down the F.D.R. to midtown Manhattan. It was a warm evening, just at sunset, and the air smelled like summer for the first time this year. I found myself watching the trees in bloom along the highway and beyond them the dark backdrop of the city. It occurred to me how much the eye loves order and how well this city satisfies that love, especially from its edges. Row after row of bricks, column after column of windows, a platoon of buildings on every block and the blocks themselves receding into the distance -- all that tessellation! Then I looked at the East River, where the grid falls away. Two tugboats were passing under the Queensboro Bridge, one of them pushing a barge.

title: Food; Soul Food, Balinese Style
description: We weren't chasing romantic dreams or a wider worldview as we hurtled, from Denpasar to Ubud, through tourist-dense Bali. My husband, two expatriate friends and I were fleeing the Western tourist culture that has taken root there. The road, choked with souvenirs, is like a strip mall that never ends.

title: Even Pessimists Erred on Cendant
description: JUDGING by the short-interest tables from the New York Stock Exchange last week, somebody must have made money on Cendant Corporation shares when word of accounting irregularities hammered down the stock 46 percent in a single day.

description: THEME PARK

title: Why 'Titanic' Conquered the World
description: LONG before ''Titanic'' the movie, the enduring appeal of Titanic the story had already been proved by books, plays, exhibitions, documentaries and other films. Even so, who could have gauged the world's appetite for more? Until the last several months, fascination with accounts of the ship that went down in the North Atlantic in April 1912, killing more than 1,500 people, had been largely limited to the United States and Europe. Yet the movie was able to captivate audiences even in countries where the sinking of the unsinkable was never part of popular lore. And for them the movie became the story.

title: Douglas Dupin, Rebecca Cooper
description: Rebecca Jane Cooper and Douglas Paul Dupin were married in Washington on Friday evening at the Hotel Washington. The Rev. Shannon L. Cooper Lao, a sister of the bride and a Unitarian minister, officiated.

title: On Love, Betrayal, Honesty: A Dialogue
description: THE wave of British and Irish plays that arrived in New York theaters this season has carried with it the ubiquitous Oscar Wilde, on his own surfboard, as it were: the Almeida Theater's London production of ''The Judas Kiss'' by David Hare.

description: George Steinbrenner has a chance to become the most popular person in the history of New York baseball.

title: Olympic Rematch Looms in Lexington
description: A rematch of the 1996 Olympic Games at Atlanta took shape after the second day of competition at the Rolex-Kentucky Three-Day Event today when the team silver medalist Bruce Davidson and his mount, Squelch, jumped to the lead with 55.6 penalties. Phillip Dutton, a member of the Australian gold medal team with True Blue Girdwood stood second at 56.4 penalties.

title: April 19-25; Hey! I Can See L.A.!
description: On a clear day in Los Angeles, you can't see forever, but you can see at least to Pasadena, and these days, you can do so more often. The city still has the nation's smoggiest air, but pollution control efforts have paid off and last year the city recorded its cleanest air in the four decades since official monitoring began. There was just a single Stage 1 smog alert, compared with 122 such warnings in 1977, and the winter winds of El Nino have scoured the skies to an unusual degree this spring. But the annual smog season begins May 1, and environmentalists are now warning this is no time to celebrate by relaxing tough standards, as some business groups want. TODD S. PURDUM

title: Mothers Can't Win
description: Susan Chira's experiences in her article ''Beyond Fear'' echo mine of more than 20 years ago, when I quit my job to stay home with my year-old son, who had just sustained brain damage during open-heart surgery. Just as her friends urged her to return to work, so did a wise friend of mine, who recognized my needs when I could not.

title: Why 'Titanic' Conquered the World; London
description: The British public, which generally shares American tastes in films, has flocked to ''Titanic'' along with the rest of the world -- the film earned more than $60 million here in its first six weeks. But critically, the reaction has been all over the map. Some critics -- full of national pride at the casting of Ms. Winslet as the heroine -- hailed the movie as a triumph of old-fashioned filmmaking and applauded its depiction of the class tensions that so inform the British view of the world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, SEYMOUR
description: NELSON-Seymour. The Staff of the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation (MDRC) are deeply saddened by the death of our long-time, loyal colleague and friend. His dedication and humor provided a source of support to all of us for 19 years. Our sincere condolences go to his family.

title: A Republican With Rough Edges
description: John R. Kasich was a skinny freshman at Ohio State University, not many months out of McKees Rocks, Pa., when someone broke a window in a dormitory. The rule was clear; everyone on the floor had to chip in for the repairs. Kasich balked, for two reasons: a, he thought the rule was unfair, and b, he didn't have the money. So he called the university's president ''a few million times,'' as he says in his understated way, got nowhere, then planted himself in the president's outer office.

title: At the Casinos
description: What's happening onstage at all the Atlantic City casinos this week.

title: Be Careful What You Wish For
description: ''IT'S in Spanish,'' the mother of the brilliant daughter decided at last. She held the letter up to the light in the kid's bathroom, which has the brightest lights in the house, teen-agers being pretty unafraid of what the mirror shows. The letter was unopened, of course, and addressed to the daughter, and its return address mentioned an important college and the words Office of Admissions. Reading a folded letter inside an envelope is hard, but the mother is good at it, except when the typing seems to spell ''Ysidro esta noce.'' Of course, the letter turned out to be in English, and to say something else.

title: Babes in Toys-'R'-Us-Land
description: The Teletubbies just ended their second week on PBS, and already American cultural critics are in overdrive. We hear from so-called children's advocates that the flabby foursome of Tinky Winky, Dipsy, Laa Laa and Po threaten to turn our 1-to-3-year-olds into preternatural consumer zombies, the youngest television audience ever singled out by greedy merchandisers. Already, Teletubbies dolls are being hyped as the hottest toy for Christmas.

title: 11 NATIONS TAKING NEXT PIVOTAL STEP TOWARD THE EURO
description: Nearly 50 years after European leaders dreamed of uniting their nations to prevent another world war, 11 countries led by Germany and France are soon to surrender a central pillar of national sovereignty: control over their currencies.

title: 2 Bird-Watchers, Last of American Hostages in Colombia, Are Freed
description: Two American bird-watchers who had been held captive by Colombian guerrillas for more than a month were released yesterday, unharmed, to members of the International Red Cross, as foreign and local reporters recorded the scene on a rugged mountaintop near Bogota where heavy fighting erupted between the army and the rebels.

title: Correction
description: A report on the Travel Advisory page on Feb. 22 about packages at the Lygon Arms hotel in Broadway, England, that include excursions in antique automobiles misstated the prices. They range from $1,232 to $1,506 a couple, not $2,465 to $3,013. The hotel's United States spokesman alerted The Times to a possible error on March 4, and the spokesman's effort to verify the prices delayed this correction.

Brown this week suspended the director for three days without pay and ordered her to develop a new sensitivity-training program for city employees.

title: The Simpsons Never Change But the Audience Does
description: YOU know the rule. If you stuff the last pork rind or beer can into the trash can, filling it to the brim, it's your duty to tie it up and take it out. It's certainly the rule in the Simpson household, unless you're that man-child patriarch Homer.

title: European Auto Divisions Calling for Improved Fuel Economy
description: The European operations of Ford and General Motors are supporting a plan by European auto makers to raise the average fuel economy of cars sold in Europe by nearly 20 percent, to 39 miles per gallon, even as the North American operations of both auto makers resist pressures to improve the far worse fuel economy of family vehicles here.

title: Consultants Due Soon On Courthouse Repair
description: THE state agency that has been hired by Westchester to overhaul and expand the County Courthouse -- the largest public works project in Westchester history -- expects to select its first consultants for the project within a few weeks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPAMARKOU, ALEXANDER P.
description: PAPAMARKOU - Alexander P. The Rockefeller University community deeply mourns the loss of our beloved friend, Alexander P. ''Alecko'' Papamarkou, an esteemed member of The Rockefeller University Council for more than fourteen years. He was a cherished advocate of biomedical research. His generosity advanced a broad spectrum of University initiatives, including the Council's yearly outreach programs, which convey exciting discoveries of basic research to non-scientific audiences. Most recently, Alecko Papamarkou established the Dr. Plutarch Papamarkou Professorship of Microbiology and Infectious Diseases, in honor of his late father, a distinguished microbiologist who, among his many contributions to medicine, played a vital role in the eradication of malaria in Greece. Alecko will be remembered for his generosity of spirit, inspiring zest for life, endearing wit and warmth, and steadfast loyalty to his friends and family. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his sister, Lisa Jewell, and her family. Torsten N. Wiesel, President Richard M. Furlaud, Chairman Board of Trustees David Rockefeller, Honorary Chairman and Life Trustee Stephen Stamas, Vice Chairman

title: A Mother and Daughter Team With Drive
description: IT'S hard for most teen-age daughters to share anything with their mothers. But a race car? Helen Wintermyer and her daughter, Joey, of Quogue, are both race dragsters. Actually it was Joey who started the racing. ''She was doing everything I wanted to do as a child,'' her mother said. So Ms. Wintermyer, 54, took up the sport three years ago. Now the women have three race cars, including a new one they will share.

title: Why 'Titanic' Conquered the World; Moscow
description: People all over the world have wept at the end of ''Titanic.'' But in Russia, apparently, the grief has been particularly noticeable. ''Russian people are very soulful,'' said Irina Valova, director of marketing at Kodak Kinomir, the theater in which ''Titanic'' played exclusively in Moscow for the film's first month here. (Houses were full despite a ticket price of 100 rubles, or $14, more than the twice the usual fare.) ''Many needed a couple of days to recover from the tragedy.''

description: CONSTANT-Maud Carter. Beloved wife of the late Boris. Motther of Alan and William. Grandmother of Lauren, James and Mary. title: Togetherness
description: Surely Carroll Ballard's BLACK STALLION (1979) is the most royal movie ever made about a youngster and a horse. The story, based on the novel by Walter Farley, begins with a dra matic shipwreck that brackets the youngster (Kelly Reno) and the magnif icent untamed stallion as island cast aways. Rescued together, they form a kindred spirit and finally triumph in a heart-stopping race to end them all. You may not cheer but your pulse will pound. Dialogue is held to a minimum, accenting the superbly evocative pho tography of this splendid picture, Kelly Reno is irresistible and so is an old friend, Mickey Rooney, as a seasoned horse trainer -- Friday at 10 P.M. on Turner Classic Movies. Howard Thompson

title: The Nation: And Liberty for Some; Switching Sides on Free Speech
description: WHEN a Chicago jury ruled last week that a group of abortion opponents had violated a Federal anti-racketeering statute, officials of the National Organization for Women cheered: A law intended to hobble the mafia had been used successfully to punish aggressive protesters.

Most residents will be asked to vote on local school spending that day, with a few exceptions, including Yonkers -- one of the cities that does not vote on school budgets -- and the special-act districts in the county.

title: April 19-25; Death of a Terror Group
description: For years they cast the former West Germany into its darkest period of urban terror. But, when the guerrillas of the Red Army Faction finally announced their self-dissolution last week, the few remaining, anonymous members were merely acknowledging what investigators had been saying for months: As an organization, the Red Army Faction was defunct.

title: Gold of a Sort in an Impoverished Landscape
description: IF the Stamford branch of the Whitney Museum's ''Morris Graves: Paintings 1931-1997'' isn't exactly a retrospective, it is a long, revealing look at the work of the protean artist whose base has always been the Pacific Northwest. If geography in part accounts for why Mr. Graves is still in the shadows after more than six decades, another reason might be that his painting is nothing if not spiritual. Historically, spiritual concerns have been on the periphery of American art, but lately audiences have become more receptive to them.

title: The Hollow Men
description: THE ARCHIVIST

title: Mothers Can't Win
description: In David Blum's article ''Car Talk,'' a father warns his daughter that she may find herself having sex, either because it seems like the thing to do or because a boyfriend coerces her. He seems not even to consider that his soon-to-be teen-age daughter might have sexual longings of her own. This odd way of thinking often colors articles on teen-age sexuality and pregnancy.

title: Why 'Titanic' Conquered the World; Paris
description: The critics and intellectuals who serve as guardians of French cultural correctness are usually quick to dump on Hollywood blockbusters, yet even they endorsed ''Titanic'' because, for them, the movie is more than simple entertainment. ''The subject of the film is not -- this is obvious -- the sinking of a famous ship, but the suicide in the middle of the Atlantic of a society divided in classes,'' explained Serge July, the editor of Liberation, the Left Bank daily. In the same newspaper, Didier Peron, a critic, reassured readers, '' 'Titanic' is a politically committed film.''

title: Correction
description: An art review on April 5 about ''Out of Actions: Between Performance and the Object, 1949-1979,'' an exhibition of postwar experimental art at the Geffen Contemporary at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles, misidentified an artist who throws himself though layers of rice paper, leaving his image in his wake. He is Saburo Murakami, not Shozo Shimamoto.

title: The Subways Are Getting Dirtier, a Straphanger Survey Says
description: Asserting that two of every three subway cars are dirty, a report released this weekend by a subway riders' advocacy group criticized the Metropolitan Transportation Authority for cutting back on the number of subway cleaning workers even as ridership has increased sharply.

title: Q&A/Martina Robinson; Life That Shows Activism Has No Limits
description: FOR several years now, Martina Robinson, a senior at Purchase College with cerebral palsy, has had these ideas spinning in her head on what she would like to present as her senior dramatics project.

title: Sounding Off on the Wave Of Imports From London
description: DOES it sound familiar? ''The insistence on trying for the Snob Hit and importing wave after wave of English special material is just one more reason why American writing talent is shying clear of Broadway. . . . If American producers insist on losing money, let it be on an American play. Let the American playwright know that somebody wants him.''

title: Mackie To Fit
description: Bob Mackie, of slinky beaded dress fame, will soon introduce a customized collection that could bring out the Cher in every woman.

title: In the Lines From 7,000 Gotti Tapes, 'Goodfellas' Meet the Government
description: Was it a line from a movie?

title: Cyclists in Riverbank Park Deserve Equal Protection
description: To the Editor:

title: MOVIES THIS WEEK
description: A top-notch crime melodrama, a stately play, a quirky tale about the film capital and a rousing story about old San Francisco highlight television's screen attractions this week.

title: Why 'Titanic' Conquered the World; Warsaw
description: In Poland, Central and Eastern Europe's biggest movie market, reviews of ''Titanic'' reflected unabashed adoration for things American. It has often been said that the Poles are so in love with the United States that they are ready to fight for it. The only critical tweak came from Zdsislaw Pietrasik in the weekly Polityka, who wrote, ''It would be difficult for even the biggest fans of the movie to prove that this is a masterpiece that opens new horizons in movie making.''

title: POSTINGS: A Panel Discussion and a Walking Tour; Two Looks At Preservation
description: Whether it's walking or talking, devotees of New York City's architectural history can take advantage of two programs this week.

title: French Classics Prevail in Granite Springs
description: IT seems like only yesterday that we first reviewed Maxime's. How delicious memories can linger on! This year Maxime Ribera, the chef and owner of this elegant restaurant, celebrates the 15th anniversary of its opening, and may it live to be 120.

title: Open to Innovation
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Tread on My Tax Rate
description: No one would ever mistake the town of Worcester for picture-postcard Vermont. There are no quaint inns for tourists, nor any ski slopes striping the peaks that cast a shadow above what once was downtown. Worcester is a sleepy burg of 900 people living in dilapidated farmhouses and mobile homes, tied together by nothing more than the lines on a map and a fixation on Stowe, the town on the snowier side of the mountain.

title: The World: Democracy's Desert; A Rising Tide of Freedom Bypasses the Arab World
description: PRESIDENT CLINTON was at it again in Latin America last weekend, congratulating democratically elected leaders of countries that not long ago were better known for their dictators. Barely weeks before his visit to Chile, the President was delivering the same encouraging pat on the back to Africans. In June in China, he will no doubt be touting the virtues of democracy again, hoping Beijing will soon match its economic liberalization with more of the political kind.

title: A Single Father, Far From Sitcom Land
description: FIVE years ago, Burke Mazyck was left with a 2-month-old son and decided to go the distance. As you read this, he is probably baking cookies and muffins -- their favorite Sunday activity -- with 5-year-old Paul.

title: Mothers Can't Win
description: I admire Elizabeth Munro's decision to give up her lucrative job to stay home with her children. Munro is right when she says, ''Getting people to take you seriously is the hardest thing for a stay-at-home mom.'' It's even harder when you can't say, ''I used to be a corporate lawyer.'' At parties, when people ask me what I do and I tell them that I stay at home to take care of my three children (ages 4, 3 and 9 months), I know they'd rather be talking to someone who has had a ''real'' job.

title: A Starter Mansion's Interiors With Elan
description: IT could have been a tumbledown shack they rejuvenated. Instead the Young Women's League of New Canaan chose a newly built starter mansion with an asking price of $1,695,000 for a designers' show house in New Canaan. Rosebrook Farm is the name given the 5,200-square-foot center hall Colonial-style house lent to the organization for the event by the designer and builder, Country Club Homes Inc. in New Canaan.

title: Funds Given to Study 1777 Site
description: FOR the first time in the history of the American Battlefield Protection Program, a Federal grant has been made to study a Revolutionary War site.

title: Keep the Old Site
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Eager Buyers but Very Little Land
description: A BOOMING real-estate market has Long Island developers hurrying to put up new houses, but a dwindling supply of land has driven up prices and builders are running out of places to build.

title: Folk Hero Strips Teflon From Thailand's Corrupt
description: Lieut. Gen. Seri Temiyavej is a modest career police officer who makes an outlandish claim, at least for Thailand: ''I have never taken a bribe.''

title: Help Out the Little Guy, New York: Set a Standard
description: It does my small-town heart good to watch from afar the percolating stadium debate in your big city. New Yorkers often think that the world revolves around them. But, the professional sports world actually deals its ugliest -- and most expensive -- hand most starkly in the middle-size cities of this country.

title: LONG ISLAND VINES
description: The Chablisienne

title: U.S. Asks Whether Leniency for Rabbi Had Link to a Pataki Backer
description: Federal prosecutors are examining whether state officials gave lenient treatment to a Hasidic rabbi imprisoned in a widely publicized kidnapping case after appeals were made on his behalf by a fund-raiser for the campaign of Gov. George E. Pataki, officials and others involved in the inquiry say.

title: Another School Funding Suit Creates a 3-Ring Legal Circus
description: In the latest legal assault against the way New Jersey pays for public schools, a coalition of 25 middle-income school districts filed a lawsuit last week asking the courts to order the state to come up with a new way to finance public education.

title: Habitats/Lower Manhattan; When 1 Co-op Won't Do, A Family of 5 Buys 2
description: NICHOLAS GRANT had a question when he learned his family would be moving to a new apartment. ''Will I have a toy room?'' he asked his mother, Yvonne Brooks.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: Free Choices

title: Passport Checks End On Italian Borders
description: Beginning April 1, passport checks and police border controls on Italy's frontiers with France and Austria came to an end, bringing Italy into compliance with the Schengen agreement on free movement among signatory countries. The countries that have signed up so far are Austria, the Benelux countries, France, Germany, Spain, Portugal and Italy.

title: April 19-25; Castro Avoids a Black Eye On Human Rights
description: A resolution to condemn Cuba's human rights practices was in the bag, or so the United States thought. For six years, the 53-nation United Nations Human Rights Commission in Geneva had voted to rebuke Fidel Castro's regime, and this year a United Nations investigator had reported that Havana engages in systematic, brutal repression of critics.

title: Show With Images of Food, but Not for the Hungry
description: ALL that food and not a crumb to eat: this is the situation at the Pelham Art Center here. Yet, it hardly matters if we, the people, are no longer capable of just enjoying our food, having decided that to pig out is to pay later. Or so says Dominick Lombardi, who, impressed by this dilemma, has gathered images of food by 25 artists, adding an introduction, which in effect asks, How come?

title: Changing Law of Trade at a Freewheeling Beach
description: For decades, Venice Beach and its boardwalk have been a mecca for the funky, a manifestation of California's permissive environment where people could freely explore their unconventional interests.

title: Law and Order at the Meadowlands
description: AS supervisor of the New Jersey State Police unit at the Meadowlands Sports Complex, Lieut. Patrick Aramini can be compared to the police chief of a small city.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HAFT, PHILIP, D.D.S.
description: HAFT-Philip, D.D.S. Of Paterson, NJ. Beloved husband of Dorothy, loving father of Karen Weisberg and father-in-law of Edwin, adored grandfather of Eric, brother of Harry Haft and Nathan Haft. Services are 1:30 PM, today, King Solomon Cemetery, Clifton, NJ.

title: Goal! Chat. Goal! Chat.
description: THE SETTING: The start of spring soccer season at the Prospect Park Parade Grounds for boys and girls 4 to 12 who are enrolled in the American Youth Soccer Organization. The group, run by volunteers, says it emphasizes mutual respect, rather than a ''win at all costs'' attitude.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STARFIELD, HARRY
description: STARFIELD-Harry. Died peacefully in his bed on April 20 at the age of 93. He was a well beloved teacher of Spanish at Tilden High School before his retirement. He spent many happy summers in Schroon Lake, NY. He is survived by his sisters, Esther Siegel, Phoebe Gozan and Florence Surovell. He is also survived by three generations of adoring nieces and nephews.

title: The Giants Have Big Plans For 2 Rookies
description: They have been bookends to every formation in this weekend's rookie minicamp. Joe Jurevicius and Brian Alford, the wide receivers the Giants drafted a week ago, position themselves at opposite ends of the line -- dual threats with different weaponry.

title: Lola, Long Dead, Is Still Getting Attention
description: Like so many men, Bruce Seymour succumbed to the charms of Lola Montez.

title: Mothers Can't Win
description: The relevant story is not that mothers can't win but that fathers aren't fathering. An estimated 40 percent of our children don't have a father in their lives on a regular basis. The absence of fathers correlates with myriad societal ills.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-17

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALLAHAN, WALTER D.
description: CALLAHAN-Walter D. On Wednesday, April 22nd, 1998 in Dayton, OH. Loving husband of Joanne. Father of Colleen, John, Tim and Anne. Grandfather of nine. Brother and uncle. Former Vice President/General Manager, Cooper Industries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRIBETZ, DENNIS
description: GRIBETZ-Dennis. Age 83, of Monsey, NY, on April 25. Beloved husband of Florence (Ruchames) Gribetz. Devoted father of Kenneth, Allen and Michael. Loving father-in-law, grandfather and great - grandfather. Cherished brother of Lester, Harriet Soffes, and Rhoda Gorfaine. Service will be held at 1 PM, today, at Ashar, 70 High View Rd., Monsey, NY. Shiva will be observed through Friday at 10 Jeffrey Place, Monsey, NY.

title: The Clues Are in the Blood
description: A menacing spider creeps across the floor of the h. w. miller memorial Sanitarium and Hospital on the Philippine island of Cebu, but Ronald Munger appears not to notice. Dozens of gecko lizards, all the same grayish color as the dingy, peeling paint, skitter along the walls, but Munger seems not to see them either. Making his way down a sweltering hallway, he passes countless children, their faces marred since birth, with raw, gaping holes where their lips and noses should be. The children stare at Munger -- his red beard and pale skin are oddities here -- but he does not stare back. Though they may never have seen a face like his, he has seen hundreds of faces like theirs. The sight has lost its power to shock, but not to sadden, so he keeps his gaze straight ahead and walks on.

description: Honor for Beverly Sills

description: New Season at Kykuit

title: Too Much Of a Good Thing
description: SPRING is a wonderful time of year, especially for gardeners. A lot of their plant friends from last summer start to appear -- astilbes, hardy geraniums and day lilies. All push up as soon as there is a genuine hint of mild weather.

title: Hollywood by the Bay
description: ONE week from today, the Hollywood film producer Paul Kurta, the director Martin Davidson, and a crew of 60 actors (including Armand Assante) and technicians are to descend on the Trump Taj Mahal casino hotel for a five-day location shoot. Mr. Kurta hopes it will result in several crucial scenes for his movie, ''Looking for an Echo.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KELLY, IRENE LENORE (NEE DUNN)
description: KELLY-Irene Lenore (nee Dunn). On April 23rd, 1998. Beloved wife of James V. Loving mother of Rosemary Kelly Mullen, Tricia Kelly Turco and James V. Kelly, Jr. Dear sister of Constance Daley and Genevieve Berger. Cherished grandmother of Lauren, Courtney and Jacqueline. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Boulevard at 193rd Street. Visiting hours Sunday, April 26, 2-5 and 7-10 PM. Funeral Mass Monday, 9:15 A.M., Holy Family R.C. Church. Interment Calverton Nstional Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Hospice Care Network of Queens.

title: On the Other Side of Arrival
description: THE PAGE TURNER

title: Behind the Veil
description: OSCAR WILDE'S

title: For Better or Worse, Israel Is 'Special' in U.S. Eyes
description: Its image has been tarnished, its need for billions in aid questioned in Congress. But to most Americans, Israel remains a worthy recipient of support, and to almost half it is a ''special place,'' rather than just another country, the latest nationwide New York Times poll shows.

title: Winegrowing Entrepreneurs To Cultivate Other Fields
description: TWENTY-FIVE years after the Hargrave Vineyard was established on the North Fork, stimulating the creation of Long Island's modern wine industry, the founders have put it on the market.

title: Giuliani and Vallone Spar Over Competing Tax Plans
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Peter F. Vallone, the City Council Speaker, stepped up their dispute yesterday over how to cut city taxes, with a mayoral aide accusing Mr. Vallone of employing ''classic left-wing approaches.'' Mr. Vallone replied that the Mayor must not have read his plan.

title: Ms. Williams, Mr. Davenport
description: Lynn E. Williams, a lawyer at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, was married yesterday to Ronald R. Davenport Jr., the general counsel in the New York office of the Sheridan Broadcasting Corporation. The Rev. Harold T. Lewis performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: A Child Dies in State's Custody
description: A MONTH after her 11-year-old son Andrew died of traumatic asphyxia while staff members were restraining him in a padded room at the Elmcrest Psychiatric Center in Portland, Lucinda McClain is still waiting for the state to tell her how and why the tragedy happened.

title: In the 20's, 'Radio Gals'
description: THE show isn't ''The 1940's Radio Hour''; thank the Downtown Cabaret Theater in Bridgeport for avoiding the hazards of overexposure. If only to get the MTV generation to remember radio, the show is instead ''Radio Gals,'' a relatively unknown semi-book, semi-revue, semi-concert sort of musical that lasted Off Broadway one mere month a year ago.

title: White's Wife Criticizes CBS
description: In an interview to be shown tomorrow on ABC's ''20/20,'' Reggie White's wife said CBS was ''too scared of the Sodomite community'' to hire her husband as a pro football commentator, according to excerpts provided by ABC.

title: Devils Add To Playoff Tension
description: It is not quite Devils-Rangers II yet, but something is brewing between New Jersey and the Ottawa Senators.

title: Why 'Titanic' Conquered the World; Istanbul
description: In its first five weeks on Turkish screens, ''Titanic'' drew a phenomenal average of more than 26,000 viewers each day. At that rate, ''Titanic'' will probably overtake the film that now holds the attendance record in Turkey, the locally produced ''Bandit,'' which was the country's entry in this year's Academy Award competition for foreign films.

title: Mothers Can't Win
description: The articles in ''Mothers Can't Win'' eloquently captured the sense of being trapped in a no-win and often thankless job that can overshadow the pleasure of parenting.

title: Ideas & Trends: Due Processor; Hey! Computers Go Faster Than the Courts.
description: EVEN the Justice Department acknowledges that its current antitrust case against the Microsoft Corporation may be outdated.

title: Offer of Lower Electricity Bills
description: LOWER electric bills, a result of deregulation, are now possible. Last month, Metromedia Energy of Eatontown, N.J., began enrolling Westchester households in the first group to take advantage of Consolidated Edison's pilot program called Retail Choice.

title: Sunken Treasures In a Divers' Paradise
description: I WAS hovering over bodies much larger than my own, where flattened snouts were armed with teeth that were also much sharper, more plentiful and longer than mine. It was a Sunday at 9:30 A.M., and I was swimming in full scuba gear at a depth of 120 feet, around the rusted, encrusted World War II wreck of the Papoose, 31 miles south of Morehead City, N.C. I was one of 20 divers who had signed up for the trip, but I was among twice that number of sand tiger sharks patrolling the hull of this torpedoed tanker. That day (my second one out), I was diving without a cage or a protective chain-mail suit. It was my first time diving with sharks. I was doing this for fun.

title: The Dean's List
description: FAILING THE FUTURE

title: Volkswagen Expected to Set Off a Bidding War for Rolls-Royce
description: Nearly one month after the German car manufacturer BMW A.G. reached an agreement to buy Rolls-Royce Motor Cars, the board of Volkswagen A.G. met today and is expected to ignite a new bidding war by offering more money and lavish promises to invest billions of dollars in future expansion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BANDLER, ARANKA
description: BANDLER-Aranka. Deeply beloved wife of George Bandler. Sister of Karol and Katarina Szabo and their families. The College at 60 at Fordham University at Lincoln Center and Project Open deeply mourns the loss of their valuable member. Funeral services Wednesday, April 29, at 11 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Not the Look and Feel of a Typical Chain
description: RESTAURANT chains are like Holiday Inns. They offer consistency and predictability. Their customers can order the same dish in Sheboygan, Sacramento or Savanna. Their menus, decor and portion sizes adhere to a strict standard set at company headquarters.

title: The Spry Legs Of Strawberry Help Yankees Keep Rolling
description: Most baseball clubs try to confine their bouts of nostalgia to one day a season. But pardon Darryl Strawberry and the Yankees if they continue to treat every game as if it were Roll Back the Clock Day.

title: INSIDE
description: INVESTING IT /Page 4/

title: Alison Townley, Kurtis Fechtmeyer
description: Alison Townley, a brand manager at L'Oreal, the cosmetics company in New York, was married yesterday to Kurtis Paul Fechtmeyer, an associate at Dewey Ballantine, the New York law firm. The Rev. Dr. Peggy Johnson Betzholtz performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church of Santa Barbara in California.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''We're in this mode of permanent scandal.''

title: Michelle Deutsch, Michael Grossberg
description: Michelle Lee Deutsch, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham P. Deutsch of New Rochelle, N.Y., is to be married this evening to Michael Ross Grossberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald A. Grossberg of Jupiter, Fla. Rabbi Melvin N. Sirner is to officiate at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: Preserving Diversity

title: Stars Take Up Batons at the Penn Relays
description: Except in an Olympic year, the largest track and field crowds in the United States turn out for the Penn Relays. The attractions are the highly competitive races for college and high school athletes, with an occasional star in the open events.

title: EXERCISE FINDS U.S. UNABLE TO HANDLE GERM WAR THREAT
description: On a bright spring day last month, 40 officials from more than a dozen Federal agencies met secretly near the White House to play out what would happen if terrorists attacked the United States with a devastating new type of germ weapon, Government officials say.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NISTICO, FRANK J.
description: NISTICO-Frank J. 71, on April 24, 1998 in Norwalk, CT. Restaurateur, proprietor of the Red Barn Restaurant, Westport, CT. Wake 1-9 PM Monday, Collins Funeral Home, 92 East Ave., Norwalk, CT (I-95 exit 16). Mass, Tuesday 10 AM, Assumption Church, 98 Riverside Ave., Westport, CT.

title: Tracking Cancer as Never Before
description: It started in a few small towns where the breast cancer rate seemed suspiciously high. Anxious residents would record new cases on homemade maps, noting their proximity to dry cleaners, factories, wells or anything else that might have made their neighbors sick.

title: Ups, Downs and Ups in Newark
description: THE people in Newark who in just seven months have presented more ballet, folk dance and symphonic music than the city has seen in decades are about to put their brand new culture palace in context.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FUTERSACK, SONIA
description: FUTERSACK-Sonia. My first and only love. Have thoughts about you every day, see your smiling face in every star. Rest well.

title: Hard-Hatted Women
description: WE'LL CALL YOU IF WE NEED YOU Experiences of Women Working Construction. By Susan Eisenberg. Illustrated. 216 pp. Ithaca, N.Y.: ILR Press/Cornell University Press. $25.

title: Eugene Walter, 76, a Novelist of the South
description: Eugene Walter, a poet and novelist, died on March 29 at the University of South Alabama Medical Center in Mobile, where he lived. He was 76.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIKE, REBECCA M.
description: PIKE-Rebecca M. Died suddenly and unexpectedly April 21 of cardiac arrest at age 48, near her home in Annadale, New Jersey. An outstanding, accomplished executive and warm, enthusiastic friend to her colleagues at Taro Pharmaceuticals U.S.A. and her many associates at the Health Care Business Women's Association. Beloved wife of Lawrence, cherished daughter of Joseph and Joyce Hassler, loving sister of James and Timothy. Memorial Service at the Robert Ford Funeral Home, Flemington, New Jersey, 11 A.M. on Saturday, April 25th. Donations to the Hunterdon County ASPCA would be appreciated.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction
description: James Joyce and Censorship The Trials of ''Ulysses.'' By Paul Vanderham. New York University, $34.95.

title: Why the Allergies? The El Nino Effect Triggers Increase
description: EL NINO, the 5,000-mile-wide pool of warm ocean off the coast of South America, has been blamed for the hurricanes in Mexico, droughts in Australia, tornadoes in Florida, and the wettest, warmest winter Long Island has experienced in decades. It is also the culprit behind a bumper crop of greenery responsible for the appearance of itchy and running eyes and noses already plaguing allergy-prone Long Islanders.

title: Designing Man
description: BECOMING HUMAN

title: Lots of Voices, Raised Constructively
description: MOST of the 19th century's big choral works were composed for volunteer singing groups. Next month's profusion of concerts in New Jersey featuring masses and oratorios, in rehearsal since the end of Christmas performances, testifies to the amount of great music that glows when it is sung for love.

title: Chantal Akerman And the Point Of Point of View
description: IN a Chantal Akerman movie, there is no Hitchcockian suspense. There are no zoom shots or shifting points of view, no cross-cutting and little dialogue. Her films often consist of long takes with the camera fixed in one place, at a medium distance from the subject.

title: In the Future
description: In the 21st century, Jamesburg, N.J., is the largest city remaining on Earth.

title: Tigers Win in Rout
description: The Princeton men's heavyweight crew, which lost its undefeated status last Saturday when beaten by Harvard by six-tenths of a second, trounced Yale and Cornell yesterday in the Carnegie Cup at Princeton. Tiger crews swept all five heavyweight races, plus four lightweight ones against Pennsylvania crews.

title: John Paul's Jewish Dilemma
description: If you go to rome any time between now and the year 2000, look out for falling rock. Rome, eternal ruin, is rebuilding again. There's an old church under renovation in one piazza after another. Scaffolding is everywhere -- obscuring the mosaics in Santa Maria Maggiore, alongside the Caravaggios in Santa Maria del Popolo, stuck onto the front of St. Peter's Basilica.

title: Aisle Seat for Movie Buffs
description: When Karen Cooper became director of the Film Forum in 1972, the theater was a two-year-old showcase for independent films but not for old movies. It didn't need to be. The Thalia, the New Yorker, the Bleecker Street and the Regency movie theaters did that. Today, those theaters are dark, and the nonprofit Film Forum, which has managed to thrive in a difficult film market, is one of the last revival houses and one of the few theaters regularly to feature independent movies in New York.

title: Is the New Hot Playwright Profound or Just Slick?
description: GETTING the measure of a new playwright takes awhile. Especially someone as exuberantly nervy and talented as Martin McDonagh, whose ''Beauty Queen of Leenane'' has just moved from the Atlantic Theater Off Broadway for what could be a hit run at the Walter Kerr Theater on Broadway. Having just seen a second McDonagh comedy, ''The Cripple of Inishmaan,'' now at the Joseph Papp Public Theater, I'm still not sure what to make of him, which is mostly for the good.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Deep in Their Hearts Is Texas
description: When Diane Barron, a 25-year-old artist, moved to New York from Texas two years ago, she got into an argument with a cab driver over the pronunciation of Houston Street. She steadfastly stuck to the pronunciation favored by the Texas city, and ended up having to get another cab.

title: DIARY
description: DEALS

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: Mason & Dixon

title: Evenings Filled With Masterpieces, One After Another
description: THERE have been times this season when one could hear balletgoers sighing with delight -- not over brilliant stars or sumptuous spectacles, although there has been opulence to admire. No, these dancegoers were savoring varied repertories of one-act ballets. Among the companies that inspired especially contented purrs were American Ballet Theater in its engagement last autumn at City Center and the Ohio Ballet at the Joyce Theater.

title: World Shopping
description: To the Editor: The articles on tourist shopping April 5 were most interesting. They reminded me of several excursions into socialist countries during the height of Marxism. Since the government operated all commerce and industry, prices were fixed, with no haggling.

title: Ideas & Trends; For Tracks, the Glue Factory
description: NEXT Saturday, the annual hoopla surrounding the Kentucky Derby will briefly elevate horse racing to the major television networks and the front pages of newspapers.

title: Q&A;/H. R. Shepherd; Inspiration, Sabin; Mission, Vaccines
description: AT the age of 76, H. R. Shepherd has little time for the presumed perks of a life well-lived. He's too busy shuttling between his offices in New Canaan and Washington, D.C., marshaling scientists, government officials and business executives to do more to prevent disease through the 200-year-old science of vaccines.

title: Military Group Finds Doors Closed for a Fair in Europe
description: As if caught in a time warp from the Vietnam War era, a private, military-oriented American organization is having trouble finding a home for its European fair.

title: Dining Out With the Owls
description: Erin Turner likes a nice meal late at night. Her reservations are always for after midnight. ''There's something really romantic about being out in the middle of the night,'' said Ms. Turner, 25, an art director from the East Village, as she nibbled on celery-root ravioli at the recently opened One/Three, at 13 Barrow Street, at 1:30 A.M. last Saturday night. ''And I avoid diners. I like a more ambient environment.''

title: Saving for College: Why Bother?
description: ''Guess Who Didn't Save for College'' (March 8), by Pamela Kruger, discussed how baby-boomer parents were underestimating the cost of their children's college education -- and often failing to put enough money aside to cover it. The article elicited a large response from readers, many of whom saw a Catch-22 in the college financial aid system. Others, however, expressed disapproval at the parents' planning methods.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSS, HERMAN L. DR.
description: GROSS-Herman L. Dr. Of Lauderhill, FL. Former dentist of Paterson, NJ. Survived by sister Mina Nacht of Hackensack, and Boca Raton, FL. Predeceased by sister Lillian G. Frank.

title: Egypt Opens Pyramids Built for Royal Women
description: IN the shadows of the Great Pyramids on the Giza plateau, three smaller pyramids, built to honor royal women, have been opened to the public for the first time since they were discovered 70 years ago. title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Bug-Eyed Monsters and Nearly Naked Women
description: Remington Schuyler, Charles B. Falls, Wesley Neff, George Rozen and Walter M. Baumhofer are comparatively unknown in the annals of commercial art. Yet they were prolific cover artists for magazines like Argosy, The Shadow, Mystery Adventure, Weird Tales and Thrills of the Jungle. Although these pulp magazines were not as respectable as The Saturday Evening Post, as a genre they claimed an even larger total circulation. Scores of pulp titles were published monthly, and whether the theme was romance, adventure, war, intrigue, science fiction, the wild West or sports, the hyperrealistic cover paintings were more provocative and titillating than any others on the newsstands. As Frank M. Robinson and Lawrence Davidson show in their lush PULP CULTURE: The Art of Fiction Magazines (Collectors Press, $39.95), the genre had masters who were capable of creating great artwork. Granted, certain cliches were often repeated -- scantily clad women, heroic men, evil villains, horrific monsters -- but the art was totally convincing. It takes considerable imagination to create a fresh image every month on the same theme, and the masters of pulp art met the challenge. My favorites are covers for All Detective Magazine, showing the metamorphosis of a man into a cobra (its fangs are knives), and Spicy-Adventure Stories, in which a sultry pinup, her already minimal garb torn to shreds, heroically fires a heavy machine gun at an evil enemy. With more than 300 full-color examples, there is something for everyone in this comprehensive collection of a virtually forgotten American popular art. Steven Heller

Graduated from Allen-Stevenson, Millbrook and Princeton, Class of 1945. Served 32 months in field artillery with 44th Division, 7th Army, in Germany, World War II. description: A 15-year-old Curt Schilling was devouring lunch at Shadow Mountain High School in Phoenix one afternoon when a friend dared him to try some smokeless tobacco for dessert. Schilling was a fastball-pumping pitcher and a maverick, so the challenge was really no challenge. Of course he would do it.

title: What the Biggest Cities Can Learn From the Upstarts
description: WHEN Richard J. Riordan, an entrepreneur who made a fortune as a venture capitalist in the booming 1980's, became Mayor of Los Angeles in 1993, he confronted a city still smoldering from the riots of the previous year, a virtually moribund economy and a city budget heading deeply into the red. Yet the Mayor saw the collapse of the local business leadership as perhaps his greatest long-range problem.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, DONALD EDUARDO (WILLIE PEP)
description: WILLIAMS-Donald Eduardo (Willie Pep). Beloved husband, father, and grandfather. Retired merchant seaman, S.S. United States, passed quietly in his home on Thursday, April 23. He leaves a devoted wife, Vena; two daughters, Dolores and Conchita; one son-inlaw Lionel; seven grandchildren, Lionel II, Damien, Vegia, Eboni, Javier, Renaldo and Conchita; one great-grandchild, Destini; three step-grandchildren, Ashley, Jerald and Kyra; one brother Stanley and great-aunt Aggie. Call Benta's Funeral Home, 212-281-8850 for the wake and funeral arrangements scheduled for early this week.

title: In America; Dreams of The Rich & Famous
description: Let's start with the madness. We can get to the real world in a moment.

title: It's a Mix of the Classic and Innovative
description: THE restaurant J. DeCarlo's is a chef's dream: a stylish place where the kitchen commander not only cooks the food but calls the shots. Jeffrey DeCarlo has come into his own. When he worked for others at the Grill Room in Hauppauge, some of his dishes soared while others fell flat. At his new eponymous restaurant in Huntington, nearly every offering drew raves.

title: Quarterback Lets Adviser Call the Plays
description: FOR Boomer Esiason, the cold shower came at the end of his first season as a professional quarterback. In June 1984, fresh out of the University of Maryland, he had signed a three-year contract with the Cincinnati Bengals, reaped an immediate $600,000 signing bonus and, three months later, received his first year's pay of $275,000.

title: Annual Report Mantra: New! Improved!
description: MORE than a few companies think the worst possible sin would be to stop reinventing themselves. At least,that's the impression their annual reports convey.

title: ON THE TOWNS
description: An opinionated guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. To submit items for consideration, write to On the Towns, Sunday New Jersey Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036, or send a fax to (212) 556-7219 or e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Mothers Can't Win
description: Thank you for the wonderful issue ''Mothers Can't Win'' (April 5). When I examined the cover, I smiled in recognition. I staved off all interruptions until I had finished every article. It captured, eloquently, the essence of what it means to be an American mother in the 1990's.

description: Driving Cross Country

title: A Love of Music Inspires a Crusade
description: Growing up in the same East Bronx neighborhood during and after the Great Depression, Murray and Lillian Barbash always seemed to be surrounded by music.

title: Athens
description: Athens finds itself in the unrelenting grip of progress. The initial euphoria over a successful bid for the 2004 Summer Olympics has been tempered by repeated government cautioning that the hard work has just begun, with austerity measures and a huge overhaul of the capital's infrastructure ahead. Spring brought with it a wave of strikes by disgruntled public employees, a 14 percent devaluation of the drachma and a freak storm that triggered a citywide blackout, painful indications of just how far Athens has to go before it enters the 21st century.

We will miss you. Friends may call Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St Saturday, 7-9PM and Sunday, 2-5 and 7-9PM with service Monday, 11:30 AM. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory may be made to establish the Palliative Care Program at the NYU Hospital, Medical Office, 550 First Ave., New York City 10016.

title: Israel Is Still Special In Americans' Eyes
description: As Israel prepares to celebrate its 50th anniversary, most Americans continue to have a positive view of the country, saying that Israel is vital to the interests of the United States and a reliable ally, according to a nationwide poll by The New York Times.

description: Ernest Bailey, an expert on the genetics of racehorses, is a professor of veterinary science at the University of Kentucky.

description: SEVERAL season finales are on today's concert schedule. At 3 o'clock, Newtown Friends of Music winds up its 20th year by welcoming the Audubon String Quartet to the Edmond Town Hall, the ensemble playing works by Mozart, Dvorak and Kodaly.

title: Elizabeth Lynch, Robert MacNeill 3d
description: Elizabeth Virginia Lynch, the daughter of Virginia Evans Lynch and Daniel Llang Lynch, both of New York, was married last evening to Robert Sherer MacNeill 3d, the son of Barbara and Robert MacNeill Jr. of Indianapolis. The Rev. Charles A. Amstein performed the ceremony at Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York.

description: The County Airport will receive $2.35 million in Federal grants for runway and taxiway improvements, County Executive Andrew J. Spano learned by way of a phone call from Vice President Al Gore on April 15. The county is one of only 11 jurisdictions nationwide to receive the grants, which total $55 million, the County Executive's office said.

description: SHAPIRO-Minnie C. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Minnie C. Shapiro, associated with The Times from 1968, until retiring in 1983.

title: The Case for Minimal Bach: One Singer to a Part
description: MUSICOLOGISTS don't often come to blows. But it happened at the 1981 meeting of the American Musicological Society, when Joshua Rifkin announced that Bach's ''chorus'' was really a quartet. Introducing no newly discovered documents but simply taking a fresh look at familiar ones, Mr. Rifkin argued that Bach performed most of his sacred music with just one singer to a part. On the rare occasions when Bach added extra voices to his ensemble, they would merely have been ''ripienists,'' doubling the solo ''concertists.'' So the B minor Mass would need only 10 singers.

title: Exploring the Maze of New-Car Navigation Systems
description: AS gas-station attendants have evolved into change dispensers behind bulletproof glass, the landscape is dotted with lost motorists seeking directions. (Is it an oil-company conspiracy? After all, the more lost you become, the more gas you use.) The navigation computer, optional on some new cars, fills the vacuum. It shows what street you're on, recites directions, even finds a nearby Chinese restaurant.
