description: MONDAY

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  WALSEY, BETTY
description: WALSEY-Betty. Gone but never forgotten. You will be in our hearts & minds forever! Milton, Steven, Elliot and Joanne

title: Struggling Artist Bags the Blues
description: Filmmakers have been known to beg, borrow and max out their credit cards to finance their work. Etsuko Kizawa, whose first film, ''New York Geisha,'' was widely praised, has given struggling-artist resourcefulness a new spin. She makes and sells handbags to support herself while working on projects. Inspired by her mother, a knitwear designer in Japan, Ms. Kizawa started her company, Duh, a year and a half ago. (About the name: ''It was just a goof, something silly,'' she said.) With business booming, Ms. Kizawa, who hand sews about 10 bags a day, plans to open a space next year. Her simple totes and evening bags in soft pastels are $30 and $40 and are sold in several boutiques downtown, including Naked Ape, 36 East Fourth Street, and Verve, 353 Bleecker Street. ''My first love is filmmaking,'' she said. ''My handbags are about instant gratification.''

title: Rewarding the Best, Forgetting the Rest
description: A few weeks ago, the Educational Testing Service threw itself a 50th anniversary party in Trenton. Searchlights played against the sky, Tom Brokaw and Secretary of Education Richard Riley gave speeches, and Vice President Al Gore and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey offered their videotaped congratulations. E.T.S.'s 93-year-old founding president, Henry Chauncey, stood up and took a bow.

title: Put Your Tiny Hand In Mine
description: EVER since Billy, promoted as ''the first out and proud gay doll,'' was given a partner, Carlos, early this year, the doll couple has kicked up a stir among adult collectors -- a considerably large, and growing, market.

title: See the Movie, Skip the Play
description: THE play is horrid but don't miss the movie -- the movie about the play, that is. ''Moon Over Broadway'' -- at Real Art Ways Cinema (56 Arbor Street, Hartford; 860-232-1006) Wednesday through May 5 -- deals illuminatingly with the making of the Broadway play ''Moon Over Buffalo,'' which toughed it out for nine months during the 1995-96 season thanks to the star presence of Carol Burnett.

title: Capturing the Voices of 'the People' on Record
description: OF all the peculiar ideas in the history of the music business, Folkways Records may be the nuttiest. With shoestring budgets and a roster of little-known and unknown musicians, with unassuming packages and underwhelming marketing, Folkways set itself a boundless mission: it would record everything in the world that's worth hearing. Everything, that is, except the commercial pop that pays most recording companies' bills.

description: FAIRY TALE

title: From a Flaky Foundation, a Food Empire
description: AT his bakery in St. Andrew, Jamaica, Ephraim Hawthorne makes a few hundred Jamaican meat patties a day. At his factory in the Bronx, Lowell Hawthorne produces as many as 20,000 patties an hour -- beef, but also chicken, shrimp, vegetable, calaloo and soya. This year, some 25 million patties, which hold their spicy fillings in a flaky, folded crust with a burnt-orange color, will roll off his automated assembly lines.

title: New Wave of Building for Shore Resort Near Seattle
description: A NEW spurt of development is under way on this windswept six-mile peninsula a three-hour drive southwest of Seattle, whose beaches now draw 3.5 million visitors a year.

title: Why 'Titanic' Conquered the World; New Delhi
description: In India, a country that claims the world's largest moviegoing audience, ''Titanic'' has been the first foreign film to break the language barrier between English and Hindi. In its first five weeks here, the film, in the original English version, has been seen by more than two million people including many with little or no English.

title: Rory Abrams, Leon Van Gelder
description: Rory Ilyssa Abrams, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Abrams of New York, was married last evening to Leon Howard Van Gelder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Van Gelder of Princeton, N.J. Rabbi David A. Posner officiated at the St. Regis in New York.

title: Philharmonia Virtuosi Ends 20th-Year Fare
description: IT is hail and farewell for ensembles concluding their 1997-98 seasons. Philharmonia Virtuosi is offering two final programs in its 20th-anniversary year: today at 3 P.M. at Purchase College and next Saturday at 8 P.M. at the Paramount Center for the Arts in Peekskill.

title: Israel Turns 50
description: Fifty years ago, in the shadow of the Holocaust, a small, determined band of Jews realized a dream that had spanned 19 centuries of exile and harrowing hardship for the Jewish people. They founded the country of Israel, beginning a remarkable epic of nation-building and survival that is one of the stirring sagas of the 20th century. As the 50th anniversary approaches this week, the world marvels at the faith and fortitude that have not only sustained Israel through five turbulent decades but brought it within reach of a new era of peace and prosperity. With wise leadership in Israel, and continued American support, Israel can reach that promised land.

title: Cassadaga Journal; A Beacon for Those Seeking Answers from Beyond the Grave
description: Browsing with her husband and a friend among the storefronts of Cassadaga, a community of about 200 people nestled in lush green and rolling hills off Interstate 4 between Orlando and Daytona Beach, Anna Christoff shopped around for a medium.

description: DISSIDENTS expelled from the Soviet Union in the 1980's were sent to London, Frankfurt, Tel Aviv or Berlin. But now that China has begun exiling political dissidents, they are being sent somewhere a bit less cosmopolitan: Detroit.

title: Medleys the Titanic's Band Might Have Played
description: THE chief musical consequence of James Cameron's film ''Titanic'' has been the ubiquity of James Horner's soupy, swelling soundtrack, which was released on a classical label and has risen to the top of the overall sales charts, eclipsing even Madonna. But happily, it is not the only consequence. Now three compact disks appear, each claiming to feature works actually heard on the ill-fated liner.

title: Hedda Nussbaum Joins Newspaper in Harrison
description: HEDDA NUSSBAUM has a new job as editor in chief of Women's News, a monthly newspaper based in Harrison.

title: April 19-25; Clinton Backs Away From Needle Exchanges
description: Eight years ago, amid controversy over the distribution of clean needles to drug addicts, Congress declared that no Federal money could be used for needle exchange until top Government scientists certified the programs reduced the spread of AIDS and did not encourage drug use. The certification has now come, but President Clinton, fearing a political backlash on Capitol Hill, refused to lift the funding ban. In doing so, he was siding with his drug czar, Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, over his Secretary of Health and Human Services, Donna E. Shalala.

title: Low Jobless Rate Aside, a Lot of Job Hunters
description: THOUGH the state's economy is roaring ahead with an official unemployment rate of just 3.8 percent, there are still more than 10,000 managerial, technical and professional workers looking for jobs according to the Department of Labor. Why?

title: Sticker Shock
description: To the Editor: This concerns the letter to the editor Feb. 15 about highway traps in Austria that lead to hefty fines for cars without the required sticker. Travelers to Switzerland should be aware that that country presents the same risk.

title: Culture Zone; Window on The World
description: From the instant the lights go down in the seedy Kit Kat Klub in Times Square and Alan Cumming takes the stage as the club's sleazily seductive emcee, all the old incarnations of ''Cabaret'' are magically swept away. You forget Christopher Isherwood's ''Berlin Stories'' and John van Druten's ''I Am a Camera.'' You forget Liza Minnelli in Bob Fosse's hit movie. You forget Joel Grey in Hal Prince's groundbreaking Broadway production. In fact, you forget that this gritty show is based on material that's more than six decades old.

title: Parking Court: Everything but 'the Devil Made Me Do It'
description: Looking sorrowfully at the judge, the comely young woman explained that her dog had been injured, and she had thought it more important to pay his veterinary bills than her seven parking summonses. Besides, she said, shifting in her suede jacket and leather pants, she was a struggling actress.

title: Home for Latino Arts
description: FIFTEEN artists associated with Taller Boricua (the Puerto Rican Workshop) have their works on display, through May 15, at the workshop's new home in the Julia de Burgos Latino Cultural Center on East 106th Street.

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; Deep in Their Hearts Is Texas
description: When Diane Barron, a 25-year-old artist, moved to New York from Texas two years ago, she got into an argument with a cab driver over the pronunciation of Houston Street. She steadfastly stuck to the pronunciation favored by the Texas city, and ended up having to get another cab.

description: BARBARA GOLDSMITH has always been fascinated by controversial figures who wield exceptional power.

title: Junta Shows New Name Of Brutality To Burmese
description: Slorc is extinct, but its most celebrated opponent, the Nobel laureate Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, has yet to see any difference.

title: Ordinary Things Made Extraordinary By a Playful Wit
description: FROM the 1940's on, Piero Fornasetti of Milan produced plates, ash trays, bathtubs and other furnishings that puzzled and pleased fans the world over. A master of visual trickery, he printed exotic, surreal and outrageous motifs on ordinary objects, some of them made from scratch in his own workshop: skyscrapers decorated tall, skinny cabinets, palazzos covered Venetian blinds, erotica embellished dinner plates, and bookshelves -- or the illusion of them -- adorned refrigerators.

title: Lives; Puppy Love
description: I do not like small dogs. Most men don't. Confronted with the sight or the very idea of them, we tend to respond with threats of graphic and creative violence or with shudders of revulsion. And such boyish antics should come as no surprise. After all, we learned back in our formative years that cute stuffed animals and other pretty and portable items -- like, say, pocketbooks -- are for girls. Big dogs are for big boys: mammoth, slobbering beasts that lope after baseballs and conk out in front of the television; man's best friend, acting more or less like our other best friends. Dogs with names like Gunther and Thoreau and with tails like wrecking balls and paws the size of -- well, about the size, each of them, of the puppy that cowered that first morning in the middle of the living room.

title: BOOKEND; Marx's Masterpiece at 150
description: This year marks the 150th anniversary of the Communist Manifesto. It was prepared in its early stages collaboratively by Marx and Engels, but the final version was almost certainly composed by Marx. It was published in February 1848 in London as a 23-page pamphlet. Its appearance coincided with the eruption of the revolutions of 1848, which began in Paris and spread rapidly across Europe before they all in one way or another failed or were put down.

title: Veterans of Israel's War of Independence
description: BY his own admission, Irving Meltzer didn't know the first thing about Zionism. He grew up in Glen Cove, L.I., and served as a ship's radio officer on Merchant Marine convoys through treacherous Nazi-held sea routes during World War II. When the war ended, he found himself at a Jewish community center in Bremen, Germany, where Holocaust survivors had gathered to search for surviving relatives. It was there that Mr. Meltzer quickly learned about the movement that sought to restore a Jewish state in what was then British-ruled Palestine.

title: Style; Sneaker Attack
description: Just when you think you have French people figured, they get hold of your irony nerve and squeeze until you scream oncle. I'm thinking here not of Jerry Lewis but of sneakers. It once was an article of faith among the French to sneer at the American fondness for rubber soles and our, it must be said, unfortunate taste for wearing athletic shoes with street clothes. This habit, which became locally entrenched around the time of the 1980 transit strike, has gone a long way toward forming one's view of sneakers as a dangerous contaminant of the visual environment whose use outside gymnasium settings should be regulated by strict international treaty and monitored by Unscom inspectors. I'd always assumed that the French concurred.

title: Women Sail Harbor With Lady Liberty as Mascot
description: Vicki Sodaro of San Francisco has never sailed in New York Harbor before. But she has been close enough to know about the strong currents on the water and the winds that peel off the skyscrapers. And she has personal knowledge about the barges that do not give way.

title: 13 Bells Will Ring From Ocean City Tower
description: Thirteen bells representing the original colonies were lifted onto a 50-foot open-framework church bell tower in Ocean City last week. The bells themselves were commissioned in 1893 for the First Methodist Church in Camden, to mark the 100th anniversary of the laying of the cornerstone of the Capitol building in Washington. The church property was bought 15 years ago by Cooper Medical Center, and the bells stayed there until the hospital donated them to the Ocean City Tabernacle Association, a nondenominational religious organization.

Representative Rick Lazio of New York and Senator Connie Mack of Florida, the sponsors, are negotiating a compromise. And he seems to be thinking that way about the rookie Scott Frost, who is trying to make the remarkable transition from championship-winning quarterback at Nebraska to big league safety.

title: Struggling Trees
description: Long before builders planted skyscrapers named Woolworth, Empire State and Chrysler, New York boasted vast stands of towering trees, including elm, oak, hickory and chestnut. Yet New York's affinity for bricks and mortar has always dwarfed its interest in the urban forest. An arborists' report in 1914 bemoaned New York's status as the only city of its size that snubbed its trees and woodlands. According to a valuable new study, the city still invests too little in its trees. This is no way to treat a multibillion-dollar asset that cleans the air and enlivens the streetscape.

She had been given the role of a middle-class housewife who is all but annihilated when her husband walks out on her, and who keeps wondering why, why. A rather thankless part, but Ms. Alexander acquitted herself with the measured grace, wit and emotional substance that audiences had already come to expect of her.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CHISOLM, WILLIAM ANDERTON
description: CHISOLM-William Anderton. Died April 24 after a thankfully brief struggle. Born December 6, 1924, in New York City, son of Ruth Anderton and William Garnett Chisolm. Married late Frances Wyatt May 25, 1961. Loving father of Richard Garnett, Frances Allison, Page Anderton and Elizabeth Wyatt. Adored grandfather of four. Graduated from Allen-Stevenson, Millbrook and Princeton, Class of 1945. Served 32 months in field artillery with 44th Division, 7th Army, in Germany, World War II. Received Bronze Star and battle stars for three campaigns, achieving rank of sergeant. Joined First Boston Corporation in 1947, retired in 1979 as managing director. Devoted member and past master, Holland Lodge, No. 8, F.&A.M.; Director, Francis Asbury Palmer Fund; member Union Club and Bond Club. Longtime friend of Bill Wilson. We will miss his wry humor and selfless service to others. Masonic rite April 27, 10:45 AM at St. James' Church with funeral to follow at 11. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAYE, STEPHEN JOHN
description: KAYE-Stephen John. Of New Canaan, CT. Died on April 22, 1998 at age 54 from complications of a stroke at Norwalk Hospital, CT. Beloved father and friend. Survived by daughter and son, Jennifer and Jeffrey Kaye, of Washington, D.C. and fiancee, Sandra W. Libbey, of Stamford, CT. A master story teller, he lived his life and shared his life to the fullest. His humor, kindness, loyalty and individuality will be deeply missed. Born April 23, 1943 in Hillsdale, MI. He was the son of the late Lester and Marjorie Kaye. Graduated from Logansport High School in Indiana. He attended Northwestern University in Evanston, IL where he earned a Bachelor of Science and a Master of Science in Journalism from the Medill School of Journalism. He was also president of the Northwestern Phi Gamma Delta Fraternity. Steve was at the top of his game in public relations and was a self-employed communications consultant. During the past 23 years, he has held top communication positions at International Paper Company, Illinois Tool Works, Inc., G.D. Searle & Co., Sara Lee Corporation and Morton Salt. Among the many honors and chairs this incredible man held were Charter Member in the Hall of Achievement from the Medill School of Journalism at Northwestern University, Chairman of Public Relations Seminar, Chairman and Trustee of the Institute for Public Relations Research and Education, Advisory Board of Kellog School of Management at Northwestern University, Chairman of the Business Advisory Board of Youth For Understanding International Exchange, Eagle Scout, The Silver Beaver Award for Distinguished Service to Youth from the Boy Scouts of America. A memorial service was held on Saturday, April 25. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in his memory to the Boy Scouts of America, National Office, 1325 West Walnut Hill Lane, P.O Box 152079, Irving, TX 75015-2079.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HILTON, ORDWAY
description: HILTON-Ordway, 84. A consultant in Questioned Document Examination, who was active in national and international professional organizations, died April 15, 1998. He received both BS and MA degrees from Northwestern University. Mr. Hilton maintained a private practice in New York City from 1946 to 1979, when he moved his practice to Landrum, SC. He was past president of the American Society of Questioned Document Examiners, past president and distinguished Fellow of the American Academy of Forensic Sciences, Chairman and Co-convener first International Meeting in Questioned Documents, London, 1963. He was author of ''Scientific Examination of Questioned Documents'', ''Detecting and Deciphering erased pencil writing'' and more that 80 articles published in Professional and Legal Journals here and abroad. He is survived by his wife, Lillie Lee Atkinson Hilton of South Carolina, and his sister, Beatrice Hilton Moulton of Michigan.

title: Mr. Pataki's Misguided Vetoes
description: Had Gov. George Pataki wanted to strike a blow for fiscal discipline, he could have vetoed many items in New York State's budget besides money to rebuild crumbling city schools. Only last year he supported a $2.4 billion bond issue for schools that was rejected by voters. Now he is deploring the Legislature's smaller $500 million bond issue for school construction as ''a huge taxpayer-funded boondoggle.'' With students crammed into closets and running for cover from collapsed ceilings, Mr. Pataki's veto of state help in this area demonstrates confused leadership and warped priorities.

title: 30-Year Treasury Is Off Sharply As Fears Re-emerge About Rates
description: The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond reached its highest level in nearly two months yesterday after a report that Federal Reserve officials were pondering an increase in interest rates. As investors sought to price in the risk of such a move, bond prices, which move opposite to yields, fell sharply.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LURIN, SHELLA (NEE STOPLER).
description: LURIN-Shella (nee Stopler). Of Wayne, NJ. Beloved wife of the late Philip, devoted mother of Elaine Goodman, Lawrence and Mitch, dear sister of Pearl Liebeskind, loving grandmother of five grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. Services Gutterman-Musicant, Hackensack, NJ.

description: To the Editor:

title: Budget Cuts For Schools Draw Protests
description: Officials of the New York City Board of Education and the teachers' union said yesterday that Gov. George E. Pataki had dealt the school system a substantial blow when he pruned $202 million from the city's school construction budget and eliminated a $72 million fund intended to make the salaries of city teachers more competitive with those in the suburbs.

title: Pataki's Hard Line
description: By vetoing $1.6 billion in items from the State Legislature's budget on Sunday, George E. Pataki risks resurrecting an image of himself as an unfeeling, budget-cutting conservative, an image that Democrats worked hard to cultivate in 1995 and 1996, and that he has worked hard to bury since then.

title: Suspect Is Arrested in Threat To Store That Was Set Ablaze
description: Even before the smoke had cleared, the police said they had the description of a suspect in the firebombing of a sporting goods store in Harlem: they said that a man with an unmistakable tattoo of an AK-47 assault rifle emblazoned across his chest had been in the store several days earlier, making racist remarks and threatening to burn the store down.

title: SCIENCE WATCH; Help for Mall Trips
description: It started as a discussion by a couple about how to choose a parking spot. He picked the first spot he saw even if it was far from the door, while she circled the lot to find the closest space. It became a research project that might one day affect how people park their cars.

title: A van Gogh Portrait, Once Obscure, Now Unseen
description: PORTRAIT OF DR. GACHET

title: A Positioning Unit, of Sorts, in the Brain
description: FEELING lost -- and then finding your way home -- seems to be in large part the work of a powerful and previously unknown place-processor unit within the brain, one that perceives richly complex landscapes.

title: Hernandez Showing Off Veteran Form
description: Looking more like a major league veteran than a refugee who has been in the United States half a year, Orlando Hernandez turned in another superb effort tonight on his climb through the Yankee system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEYER, CLARENCE
description: BEYER-Clarence. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation note with deep sadness the death of our dedicated supporter Clarence Beyer, founder of Beyer Farms. He was devoted to our organization, serving as UJA Federation chair at Maspeth Jewish Center and chair of the Milk and Allied Industries Division. His son Henry, former chair of the Milk and Allied Industries Division, carries on the family tradition of philanthropy. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife, Bernice; his children, Maureen and Henry, and Heidi and Michael; his grandchildren, and all the members of the family. May they be consoled among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P. Steven Schwartz, Chair, Milk and Allied Industries Div.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MORRILL, ALAN
description: MORRILL-Alan. Age 90, born March 13, 1908, died April 26, 1998. Beloved husband of Dorothy for 66 years. Adored father of Carma (dec.). Loving grandfather of Sarah. Graduate of Boston Latin School 1925; Harvard University 1929. Broadway producer, actor, play doctor, raconteur, he left theater to enter business in difficult times-the Depression. A brilliant and witty man, he will be greatly missed. Services at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 Street, today, Tuesday, 11 AM.

title: Armstrong Is Back With Good Showing
description: Lance Armstrong, the 25-year-old American cyclist who is returning from a case of testicular cancer, raced Sunday for the first time since he quit the Paris-Nice race in early March. With fewer than 20 miles remaining in the 17-lap, 119-mile Outdoor Life Network Grand Prix in Atlanta, he almost broke away with five others, and he finished in the main pack, 52d among the 70 riders.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOWLER, GEORGE T.
description: FOWLER-George T. Of Glen Rock, NJ, died April 26, 1998, while in his 83rd year. Beloved husband of the late Marie. Loving father of Beth Fowler-Witham and Irene Conville. Adoring grandfather of Three. He was Vice President of Premises & Staff Services of Morgan Guaranty Trust CO., N.Y. where he worked for 51 years. Funeral Mass will be Thurs. 10am at St. Catharine RC Church, Glen Rock, NJ, with interment to follow in Maryrest Cemetery, Mahwah, NJ. Friends may call Wednesday 2-4 and 7-9 PM, at the Feeney Funeral Home, 232 Franklin Ave, Ridgewood, NJ 201-444-7650. Donations to the American Cancer Society, 20 Mercer St, Hackensack, NJ 07601, would be appreciated.

title: Ancestral Humans Could Speak, Anthropologists' Finding Suggests
description: While scientists agree that speech is probably the most important behavioral attribute that distinguishes human beings from other animals, they have been at a loss to determine when and how that transforming evolutionary step occurred.

title: People
description: * Martin Copus was named new business development director for Europe at Ammirati Puris Lintas, London, a unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., succeeding Ian Creasey, who was named regional client director for Europe, Middle East and Africa for the Compaq Computer Corp. account. Mr. Copus was also named to a new position, worldwide director for Ammirati Puris brand development. Mr. Copus had been senior vice president and account director for special projects and new business on the Philip Morris Cos. account at the Leo Burnett Co., Chicago. At Burnett, Doug Porter, senior vice president and account director, will succeed Mr. Copus.

title: Speeds in Workouts for Derby Are Back to Normal
description: Rain fell overnight on Churchill Downs, so the four Kentucky Derby horses who worked out this morning, including three of the favorites, had little chance to write another chapter to the history of memorable Derby workouts.

title: Nets Think Game 5 Is No Joking Matter
description: In two close playoff losses to the Bulls in Chicago, the Nets have seen the best the National Basketball Association has to offer. But with the sort of naive belief that comes with youth and inexperience, they just shrugged their shoulders like teen-agers and expressed confidence they could extend their first-round playoff series more than just about everybody else believed it could go.

title: After a Break, Going Back to an Old Love: Piano
description: Ken Noda walked away from a promising international career as a pianist seven years ago, disillusioned with the music world and his place in it. Since then he has worked as an administrator at the Metropolitan Opera. There are signs, however, that Mr. Noda is easing his way back into public life, first in a piano four-hands recital with James Levine a year ago, and on Thursday in a solo recital at the Metropolitan Museum.

title: Oxford Health Plans Posts A Deficit of $45.3 Million
description: In preparation for an important offering of high-yield bonds, Oxford Health Plans yesterday reported its financial results for the first three months of 1998. While the results were better than the guesses of many Wall Street analysts, the company continues to lose money from operations.

title: Jews and Arabs, Painting a Mural Together, Find a Mosaic of Mistrust
description: It was a noble plan: Three peace-loving artists from conflicting backgrounds -- an Israeli Jew, an Israeli Arab and a Palestinian -- would produce a mural depicting a future without fear, a symbolic guide to trying to live together in this disputed land. But the process proved far more tortured than any of them imagined, a microcosm of mistrust and betrayal that mirrored the hostilities they had set out to overcome.

title: Award of $44.9 Million In Brain Damage Case
description: A Brooklyn jury awarded $44.9 million yesterday to the family of a girl who suffered brain damage after doctors gave her mother too much anesthesia during childbirth, lawyers for the child's family said.

title: Judge Upholds the Law Protecting Pine Barrens
description: The constitutionality of a law meant to protect the Long Island Pine Barrens from land developers has been upheld by a state judge, officials said yesterday.

title: Weapon Against Strokes
description: Researchers have found a way to use a drug to help people avoid strokes by keeping open the blood's channels to the brain.

title: Seeking a Focus on Joy In Field of Psychology
description: PSYCHOLOGISTS rarely think much about what makes people happy. They focus on what makes them sad, on what makes them anxious. That is why psychology journals have published 45,000 articles in the last 30 years on depression, but only 400 on joy.

title: Tips to Lift Heavy Hands Off Cab Horns
description: NOT to tread on the science section's turf, but are you familiar with the shortest measure of time in the universe?

title: BAYOU STEEL DROPS PURSUIT OF NORTHWESTERN STEEL
description: The Bayou Steel Corporation said yesterday that it had ended discussions to acquire a larger rival, the Northwestern Steel and Wire Company. After reviewing Northwestern's books, Bayou said, it concluded it could not agree to a higher offer sought by Northwestern. In February, Bayou agreed to buy Northwestern for $2.29 a share cash and the issue of seven million Bayou class A shares, for a total of about $100 million. Bayou would have also assumed around $140 million in debt. Bayou Steel, based in La Place, La., operates a steel mini-mill that produces light structural steel products. Northwestern Steel, based in Sterling, Ill., produces structural and other steel products.

title: Gabe Paul, Ex-Yankee Official, Dies at 88
description: Gabe Paul, the baseball executive who arranged for George Steinbrenner to buy the Yankees, then built their championship teams of the late 1970's, died on Sunday at Memorial Hospital of Tampa (Fla.). Mr. Paul, who lived in Tampa, was 88.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WYMAN, WILLIAM
description: WYMAN-William. The Ford Dealers Alliance would like to express our sincerest condolences to the family and friends of Bill (Earl) Wyman. Bill was a founding member of the Ford Dealers Alliance. He had a reputation as being a straight arrow and was well respected by the dealers and the Ford Motor Company alike. Thirty years ago the Alliance initiated an outside study on warranty reimbursement. Bill chaired that study, which received national attention. He had challenged the Ford Motor Company policy at a time when this was considered revolutionary and we as dealers knew that no one flew close to Air Force One. In that climate, Bill was one of my heroes. As a group, we were able to make a difference. I will remember him with admiration and respect. We at the Alliance will truly miss him. Ed Mullane, Ford Dealers Alliance

title: Australian Coal Miner To Cut 1,300 Jobs
description: The coal division of the Broken Hill Proprietary Company, the Australian mining concern, will lay off 1,300 coal employees by the end of its fiscal year in May, the company said yesterday. A spokesman for BHP Coal, Ian Dymock, said the layoffs were part of a job reduction program that started in September.

title: Sanity in Russia
description: There are many in the Western press who think President Boris Yeltsin of Russia has gone mad. First, he fired several top ministers, including his Prime Minister, Viktor Chernomyrdin. He then pressured the Parliament to accept Sergei Kiriyenko, a young official largely unknown abroad, as his replacement.

title: Devils Searching for the Finishing Touch
description: Is it fair to compare? To do so is to notice that Bill Guerin, the exiled ex-Devil, has scored four goals in three playoff games for the Edmonton Oilers, and Claude Lemieux, the best performer in New Jersey's Stanley Cup spring of 1995, has two goals in three games for the Colorado Avalanche.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PEARLSTEIN, RABBI AARON S.
description: PEARLSTEIN-Rabbi Aaron S. We record wtih sorrow the passing of our beloved colleague. Ordained in 1964, he served pulpits in Bowie, MD., and New London, CT., before returning to the Washington area in 1980. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Dr. Peggy, children Sam, Jack and Dr. Ora, and to his nieces, Dr. Alisa (Rabbi Neil) Kurshan and Dr. Shuly (Rabbi Gershon) Schwartz, and all who were touched through his rabbinate. Rabbi Seymour L. Essrog, President Rabbi Joel H. Meyers, Exec VP The Rabbinical Assembly

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: SUGAR NEAR 5-YEAR LOW. Raw sugar fell on expectations of a bumper crop from Brazil at a time of waning global demand. May contracts fell 0.11 cent, or 1.2 percent, to 9.04 cents a pound. Prices have fallen 26 percent this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLER, CELE (ISLER).
description: GELLER-Cele (Isler). Tragically on April 26, 1998. Beloved, loving and most caring sister, sister-inlaw and aunt.

title: Chretien Finds Castro Willing to Deal, but Not on Rights
description: Prime Minister Jean Chretien set modest goals for his first visit to Cuba this week: further Canada's substantial business interests here and prod Cuba into doing something about human rights.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A stock offering provides a rare look at potential conflicts.
description: MARIO J. GABELLI, the famed stock picker and mutual fund manager, wants to sell part of his mutual fund and investment empire to the public -- but only part. He plans to keep control of the company and, perhaps, many of his best investment ideas.

title: A CONVERSATION: With Sir Martin Rees; Tracing Evolution of Cosmos From Its Simplest Elements
description: SIR Martin Rees, 55, one of the world's leading theorists on cosmic evolution, the Astronomer Royal of England and the author of ''Before the Beginning: Our Universe and Others'' (Addison-Wesley, 1997), was in the United States this month to receive the Franklin Institute's $250,000 Bower Award for ''achievement in science.'' Sir Martin spoke with Science Times over lunch in the cafeteria at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRISHER, HONEY SONDRA
description: FRISHER-Honey Sondra. On April 26, 1998. Beloved sister of Francie Loupis, loving aunt of Nicole and Michael. Devout and cherished friend of Ilene Berliner. Services Tuesday, 12 PM, ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. Contributions may be made to Historical and Holocaust Art Musem, Yad Vashem, PO Box 3477, Jerusalem, Israel 91000.

title: Political Briefing; Glenn's Priority Has The Party Seeing Stars
description: Democrats face an uphill battle in Ohio, where Republicans are given a good shot at holding on to the governorship and picking off the Senate seat being vacated by John Glenn. And the hill just got steeper.

title: Diamondbacks Send Jones to Giants
description: The Arizona Diamondbacks traded outfielder Chris Jones to the San Francisco Giants yesterday for the minor league pitcher Ricky Pickett.

title: Stocks Tumble On Worries Of Rate Rise
description: The stock market dropped sharply across-the-board yesterday, as a sudden fear that the Federal Reserve may raise interest rates spread doubt about the durability of Wall Street's strong 1998 rally.

title: Foreign Affairs; Ben & Jerry & NATO
description: Ben Cohen, head of Ben & Jerry's ice cream, is struggling for the right analogy: If NATO expansion against a newly democratic Russia were like the ice cream biz, what would it be?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BONDULIC, TOMISLAV
description: BONDULIC-Tomislav. Devoted husband of Angela (nee Ivancic). Beloved father of Bonnie Javor, John and Debbie. Loving grandfather. Dear brother of Vinko and Miljenko. Fond uncle. Mass St. Ciril Methodius 10 A.M., Wednesday. In repose Raccuglia and Son 321-323 Court St, Brooklyn 718-855-7737.

title: Israel Mural Reveals The Fault Lines at 50
description: An effort to have an Israeli Jew, an Israeli Arab and a Palestinian work together to produce a mural depicting a future without fear proved far more tortured than any of them imagined -- a microcosm of mistrust and betrayal that mirrored the hostilities they had set out to overcome.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOSTANY, JAMES MARK,
description: BOSTANY-James Mark, 29. On April 25 at Memorial SloanKettering in Manhattan succumbing to Myelodysplastic Syndrome (MDS) while waiting for a matched bone marrow transplant donor. Jim won a tough battle with Hodgkins five years ago and was diagnosed with MDS several months ago, a disease he got from the chemotherapy. Honors graduate from Xaverian H.S. in 1986, B.S. in accounting from Fairfield University in Conn. in 1990. Awarded a CPA and was a Senior Associate at Delloitte & Touche when he was stricken with Hodgkins at the age of 23. Was trading stocks at Shonfeld Securities at the time of his death. Jim's energies were unbounded. He was a pioneer in the Laser Video Disc business at the age of 22 starting the only Video Disc rental business that delivered to Upper East Side residents. Then started Tower League softball consisting of Big 6 accounting & law firms, banks, and businesses in Manhattan. Jim was Commissioner of the league and 1997 MVP of Ridge/Price Waterhouse coed softball team. Played for varsity tennis teams at Xaverian and Fairfield. Extraordinary painter of abstract art, collector of antiques, philosopher, writer of ''The Muse'' a modern screenplay. Jim's life was brief but he leaves an indelible mark on his many friends and family. His profound and resourceful ways influenced all of us immensely. His tireless and adoring mother Janet Raheb Bostany, his loving father Joseph Elias, his brother Joseph Gregory and John Peter will miss him more than can be imagined. Jim's style of living and total unprejudicial, nonjudgmental views and loving attitude toward humanity proves he was way ahead of our time. He will be forever in our mind's eye. Instead of flowers the family requests donations in Jim's name to Aplastic Anemia Foundation of America, Inc. P.O. Box 613, Annapolis, Maryland 21404.

title: Place at Table for All
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMERCIAL UNION PLANS TO ACQUIRE FARMERS UNION
description: Commercial Union P.L.C. said yesterday that its United States unit had agreed to buy the Farmers Union Insurance Acquisition Corporation of Aurora, Colo., for about $118 million. The announcement comes as Commercial Union, based in London, seeks to extend its insurance business in the United States, diversify operations internationally and merge with General Accident P.L.C. Farmers Union's businesses include the National Farmers Union Service Corporation, the National Farmers Union Property and Casualty Company and the National Farmers Union Standard Insurance Company. The businesses operate in rural areas of 12 states and had net assets of $72 million at the end of 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RATTNER, R. LILLIAN.
description: RATTNER-R. Lillian. Beloved wife of the late Joseph, devoted companion of Jay Levy, loving sister-in-law of Nancy Rolnick, cherished aunt of Amy, Paul and Sabina, and Kevin and Erin Rolnick. Great aunt of Addie, Henry, Kristen and Katie. Services 1 P.M. Wednesday at Plaza Memorial Chapel, 91 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, New York City.

title: Reyna Gets Sharp in Germany
description: Claudio Reyna hates to lose. Any time. Any place.

title: Times Mirror Sells Legal Unit To British-Dutch Publisher
description: The Times Mirror Company moved to focus more closely on its newspaper roots yesterday by agreeing to sell its legal publishing business to the British-Dutch publishing giant Reed Elsevier for $1.65 billion in cash.

title: Sports of The Times; For Malone And Starks, Adjusting
description: NOW the Knicks are home again. Home in what, presumably, is the Garden of roses for them, the Garden of thorns for intruders, especially when Pat Riley is strutting in front of the enemy bench. But Jeff Van Gundy does not presume.

title: Pentagon Seeks to Open Unknowns' Tomb
description: On a rainy Memorial Day 14 years ago, six gray horses slowly pulled a black caisson from Capitol Hill to Arlington National Cemetery, where the remains of an unidentified American killed in Vietnam were laid to rest in the Tomb of the Unknowns, as an emotional President Reagan looked on.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about Hillary Rodham Clinton's testimony to the Whitewater independent counsel referred imprecisely to Nicole S. Seligman, a member of the Clinton legal team. She is a partner at the Washington law firm of Williams & Connolly.

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: A Rock Legend And His Wild Muse

title: Johnson a Quiet but Steady Force for Knicks
description: In an obscure corner of the Knicks' harried locker room on Sunday, tucked away from a swarm gathered around John Starks and to the side of Chris Childs handing out sound bites like cigars, Larry Johnson was talking to a teammate about an awesome display of might.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAGAN, VALESKA
description: FAGAN-Valeska, 89, of Orient, L.I. On April 26, 1998. Loving wife of the late Frank. Dear mother of Andrea Rowsom, Dona Arno and Peter Fagan. Cherished grandmother of 9, great grandmother of 3. Graveside service Wednesday, April 29, 1998, 11am, Orient Central Cemetery, Orient, Long Island, Pastor James Cavanaugh officiating. Info: S.B. Horton Funeral Home, Greeport, Long Island.

title: Restrictions on Iraq Will Stay in Force, U.N. Council Rules
description: The Security Council decided tonight to extend sanctions against Iraq, ignoring threats from Baghdad that it would disrupt future arms inspections if the sanctions were not lifted.

title: Court Allows Hospital Layoffs, But Doesn't Settle Workfare Issue
description: A judge in Manhattan ruled yesterday that the city's public hospital system could go forward with its plans to lay off 905 employees on Friday. But the judge, Richard F. Braun of State Supreme Court, left unsettled the core of the legal battle between union leaders and the Giuliani administration: the extent to which the city uses workfare workers in municipal jobs.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MEAD, ROBERT H.
description: MEAD-Robert H. After an extended illness. Cherished husband of Henrietta Mills. Beloved father of Robert, Slade and Winter, and grandfather of six young children. A graduate of Yale University Class of 1954; teacher, coach and counselor at Salisbury School for 25 years; longterm President of the Hartley Corporation Charitable Foundation, and a civic leader in his hometown of Norfolk, CT. A memorial service will be held at 3PM on Saturday, May 2 at Church of Christ Congregational, Norfolk.

title: Lucent Technologies to Acquire Yurie Systems for $1 Billion
description: Extending an aggressive push into the data networking business, Lucent Technologies Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire Yurie Systems Inc., a small but fast-growing manufacturer of devices that make it easier to send data and video over the Internet, in a cash transaction valued at $35 a share, or $1 billion.

title: Transaction Systems Deal
description: Transaction Systems Architects Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire Intranet Inc., a privately held provider of electronic payment systems based in Newton, Mass., for $49.1 million in stock. Transaction Systems Architects, based here, makes software that processes bank transactions. It had six-month revenue of $125.2 million as of March 31.

title: Metro Business; Lilco Bonds Receive A- Investment Rating
description: Two financial rating services awarded investment grade ratings yesterday to the bonds being sold for the state's takeover of most of the Long Island Lighting Company. The planned sale, expected next month, would be the largest municipal bond issue in the nation's history.

title: Few Follow as Giuliani Leads Way on New Site for Yankees
description: Two years after he first unveiled a proposal to build a stadium for the Yankees on the West Side of Manhattan, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani finds himself with few allies in an effort to build an expensive new home for the team at a new location.

title: Shortsighted Medicare Oversight
description: The Health Care Financing Administration spends about $2 billion a year overseeing the $230 billion Medicare program, or only about 1 percent of revenues. By contrast, private insurers spend more than 10 percent on administration. Yet even while denying the agency the money it needs to do its job, Congress piles on new responsibilities.

title: Lawrence Bailey, 80, First Black To Join Transit Agency's Board
description: Lawrence R. Bailey Sr., a lawyer in upper Manhattan who was the first black member and officer of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority board, died on Thursday at Jamaica Hospital Medical Center in Queens. He was 80 and a longtime resident of Jamaica, Queens.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBINSTEIN, DAVID
description: RUBINSTEIN-David. Beloved husband of the late Alice Rubinstein. Dear brother of Morris Robbins, Paul Rubinstein and the late Sam Bensen. Adored uncle of Gale (Ken), Debby (Paul), Gene (Annette). Cherished great uncle of Sylvie, Max, Carly, Jennifer and Rachel. Funeral Services Tuesday, April 28, at 12 noon Sinai Chapel, 162 Street and Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, N.Y.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOVI, PAUL
description: KOVI-Paul. The Board and staff of Citymeals-on-Wheels are deeply saddened by the loss of our generous friend and former Board member, Paul Kovi. We all will miss his wise insights and caring conern for frail and isolated New Yorkers who depend on daily hand-delivered meals. Our sympathy goes to Paul's family, his friends, and his colleagues at The Four Seasons Restaurant.

title: Armenian, Playing Subtly, Wins the New York Open
description: Artashes Minasian, a 30-year-old Armenian grandmaster, won the prestigious New York Open Tournament, which ended on March 22 at the New Yorker Hotel. He was awarded the $14,000 first prize for his top score of 8-1. With a 7 1/2-1 1/2 score, Minasian's compatriot, the grandmaster Smbat Lputian, took the $7,000 second prize in the nine-round, Swiss-system event.

title: EMPLOYER-SPONSORED CHILD CARE COMPANIES TO MERGE
description: Bright Horizons Inc. and Corporatefamily Solutions Inc. agreed yesterday to merge in a stock swap, in an effort to snare a bigger piece of the growing market in child care offered by companies. Bright Horizons shareholders will get 1.15022 shares in a new company called Bright Horizons Family Solutions for each of their shares. Investors in Corporatefamily Solutions will get one share for each share held. Bright Horizons had $85 million in sales last year while Corporatefamily Solutions had $77.7 million. Corporatefamily Solutions, based in Nashville, has 100 centers in 29 states. Boston-based Bright Horizons has 155 centers in 29 states. Shares of Bright Horizons rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $27.375, while Corporatefamily fell $4.125, to $26.

title: Political Briefing; For Popular Governor, Resistance From Right
description: When Gov. Fife Symington of Arizona was convicted of real estate fraud and forced to resign late last year, he was succeeded under state law by Secretary of State Jane Dee Hull, a fellow Republican. In just a few months on the job, Governor Hull has won high praise from scandal-weary Arizonans -- in the latest poll, 57 percent rated her performance ''excellent'' or ''good'' -- and she is now running for a full term.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SKOLNICK, MINNIE
description: SKOLNICK-Minnie, died April 26, 1998 at home in her ninty-ninth year. Beloved wife of the late Paul Skolnick. Survived by daughter, Selma Figer and son Raymond Skolnick and daughter-in-law, Francine. Loving grandmother of six grandchildren and nine great grandchildren. She will live in our hearts forever.

title: Ranks of Lawyers Grow, As Do Those Disciplined
description: The number of lawyers in the state reached an all-time high last year, and so did the number of lawyers publicly disciplined, according to a report released yesterday by the Supreme Court's Office of Attorney Ethics.

title: In the Wings: Euro as Potential Rival to the Dollar
description: For the better part of this century the dollar has reigned supreme in global finance, both a symbol of American economic might and a contributor to it. But a new rival to the dollar could eventually prove more powerful than the German mark or the Japanese yen: a single European currency.

title: Vasser Shows a Short Game at Nazareth
description: Mile ovals are not among Jimmy Vasser's preferred race courses. And for good reason -- he rarely finishes well on them.

title: NPC TO SELL TONY ROMA'S UNIT AND REORGANIZE PIZZA HUTS
description: NPC International Inc. said yesterday that it would sell the unit that operates Tony Roma's restaurants to Sentinel Capital Partners of New York and the unit's executives for $121.5 million, and would reorganize its Pizza Hut business. NPC, of Pittsburg, Kan., said it would receive $118 million in cash and $3.5 million in stock for Romacorp Inc.; it could receive another $5 million, depending on the unit's performance. The company, the world's largest Pizza Hut franchisee, also plans to close 31 money-losing Pizza Hut restaurants, move 53 others to better sites and combine another 11 with current Pizza Huts. Its shares rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $13.25.

title: Corporate Push To Save Break On Foreign Tax
description: American multinational corporations are lobbying fiercely to preserve a loophole inadvertently created two years ago by the Clinton Administration that allows them to avoid paying foreign governments billions of dollars a year in taxes.

description: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Court Takes a Skeptical Look at Line Item Vetoes
description: When is a line item veto not really a veto?

title: AFICIONADO OF SCIENCE: Gary Larson; An Amateur of Biology Returns to His Easel
description: GARY LARSON and his closest friends agree. If you want to understand the man -- the comic genius, the author of the blackly buoyant and sorely missed ''Far Side'' comic strip, and a cartoonist so revered among scientists that they have named a louse and a butterfly after him -- then look at his work.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POMMIER, HENRI
description: POMMIER-Henri. Age 85. Of Coral Gables, Fla. Passed away Saturday, April 25, 1998. He was born in Prague, Czechoslovakia on July 12, 1912. For much of his life he was a specialist in the manufacturing of fine jewelry and worked closely with other jewelers including Harry Winston of New York City. He designed & imported jewelry and was invited to be the first agent for Ebel watches in the United States. He was a member of the Twenty-Four Karat Club. At the time of his retirement, he was the Executive Vice President for Spritzer and Fuhrmann Jewelers of the Caribbean in New York City. One of Mr. Pommier's proudest accomplishments was to get his family out of Europe just ahead of Hitler's invasion of Czechoslovakia. He, himself, immigrated to the United States om 1939, where he started his first jewelry manufacturing business. Mr. Pommier was dedicated to and found great joy in his family. He is survived by his wife Shirley Pommier, his son Marc of North Berwick, Maine, daughters Michele Pommier Diel of Miami, Florida, Monica Pommier Kravitt of Katonah, New York, Denise Pommier Johnson of Cape Neddick, Maine, his nephew Paul Alony of Tel Aviv, Israel. There are six grandchildren Danielle and Jessica Johnson, David and Jacqueline Diel, Alexandra Kravitt and Max Pommier. Funeral services will be held at Congregation Beth-El in Norwalk, Conn., Wednesday, April 29, 1998 at 11 AM. Burial will be at Beth Israel. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to American Parkinson's Disease Association or the American Parkinson Foundation.

title: Manavi Journal; Georgia's Celestial Wine: Is the World Ready?
description: When a truck pulled up on the dirt road in front of Misha Kevkhishvili's home this morning, he knew that one of his friends had come for wine, and not just for a few bottles.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: AIRGAS INC., Radnor, Pa., a distributor of industrial, medical and specialty gases, said that it would take a pretax charge of $25 million in its fourth quarter and that it expected its operating profit to fall short of analysts' estimates as it reorganizes and sells off several businesses.

title: Siebe Buying Rival In Thermostat Business
description: The British engineering company Siebe P.L.C. said yesterday that it would pay $:439 million ($733 million) in cash and stock to acquire Eurotherm P.L.C., a rival British maker of temperature-control devices. Siebe said it would offer 0.2322 share of its common stock and 140 pence in cash for each Eurotherm share, making the offer worth about 460 pence a share. Eurotherm's stock jumped 96.5 pence yesterday, to 445 ($7.43).

title: Media Edge Gets Tricon Assignment
description: Tricon Global Restaurants, which owns and operates the Pizza Hut, Taco Bell and KFC restaurant chains, has consolidated the duties for buying $260 million to $300 million worth of television commercial time annually at the Media Edge division of Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York. Various agencies had handled those duties, with Media Edge overseeing TV buying for KFC.

title: A Sham Transition in Nigeria
description: To no one's surprise, Nigeria's five legal political parties, all government-financed, have chosen the country's dictator as their nominee in presidential elections Aug. 1. Gen. Sani Abacha is the sole legal candidate, although he has not yet formally announced whether he will run. It is now clear that the election, which was billed as the centerpiece of Nigeria's return to democracy after five years of Mr. Abacha's iron fist, will only whitewash his rule.

title: Largest Business for Harlem Improvement Zone
description: Broadway Video, a video production company based in midtown Manhattan, opened an 8,600-square-foot video duplication center yesterday in a western Harlem warehouse, becoming the largest business to set up shop in the two-year-old Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone.

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page article last Friday described a change in news organizations' responses to subpoenas from Federal prosecutors demanding notes or tapes. The article reported that such subpoenas were generating less outrage and resistance than they did a decade or two ago.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NADLER, SYLVIA
description: NADLER-Sylvia. The National Mah Jongg League mourns the passing of its esteemed past Board member, colleague and friend. She will be sorrowfully missed, but not forgotten. Ruth Unger, President The Board of Directors National Mah Jongg League

description: ST. GEORGE-Agnes E. On April 27, 1998 of Jackson Heights, NY. Retired employee of Con Edison. Reposing Joseph V. McGrath Funeral Home, 91-20 37th Ave, Jackson Heights. description: To the Editor:

title: Flies Provide Clues to Vision
description: The fly has the fastest visual system in the animal kingdom -- so fast that a fly in a movie theater would see a slide show, not the blur that people interpret as motion. But how does that fast-moving visual information lead to the twitch that zips the fly to safety before a fly swatter can crash down?

description: SCIENTISTS have seen the future of computing in a thimbleful of chloroform.

description: POWELL-Mel. The Board, members and staff of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers are greatly saddened by the loss of our member, Mel Powell, one of our nation's most illustrious and versatile musical treasures. Marilyn Bergman, President & Chairman, ASCAP

title: Whitman and New Jersey Senate Reach Car Insurance Compromise
description: The State Senate and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman agreed tonight on a compromise auto insurance plan that promises a 15 percent rate reduction for most motorists but puts off until 2000 the highly contentious issue of how much more urban drivers can be charged.

title: Dark Days for Marquee Matchups
description: The pitching matchup at Yankee Stadium last night prompted Don Zimmer to recall his days with the Brooklyn Dodgers. ''Whenever we played the Phillies,'' the Yankees' coach related, ''it seemed like Roberts always hooked up against Newcombe.''

description: NEWS

title: Group Argues Against Use of Police Computers
description: Unrestricted use of computers in police cars to check on vehicle registration and driving records violates a constitutional ban on unreasonable search and seizure, a lawyer for the state American Civil Liberties Union argued before the State Supreme Court yesterday.

title: Dueling Senators
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Business; SL Green in Several Deals
description: The SL Green Realty Corporation said yesterday it had acquired control of 711 Third Avenue, a 520,000-square-foot building between 44th and 45th Streets, for $61.4 million.

title: Space Station Is Assembled, But Only on the Ground
description: AFTER years of planning and promises, pieces of the proposed international space station are finally coming together. But instead of being assembled in orbit, they are stacking up at testing sites and prelaunch warehouses awaiting a decision to begin putting the giant laboratory together in space.

title: Sergeant Says Fellow Officer Shot Him, and Kept Shooting
description: A city police sergeant shot two months ago during an undercover drug raid in Brooklyn said yesterday that he was wounded by a fellow police officer who kept shooting his weapon after he was ordered to stop firing.

title: GENESIS HEALTH TO ACQUIRE VITALINK FOR $600 MILLION
description: Genesis Health Ventures Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Vitalink Pharmacy Services Inc. for $600 million in cash or securities plus $90 million in assumed debt. Under the deal, Genesis would exchange $22.50 a share in cash or convertible securities for each of Vitalink's shares outstanding. Vitalink's stock rose $1.6875 a share, to $21.50. Manor Care Inc., which holds a 50 percent stake in Vitalink, will exchange its shares for the convertible stock. Vitalink, based in Naperville, Ill., provides pharmacy services to nursing homes and to patients receiving treatment at home. Genesis Health, of Kennett Square, Pa. supplies pharmacy, rehabilitation and management services to geriatric-care providers. Its shares fell 93.75 cents yesterday, to $24.8125.

title: Cox Reported Close to a Deal For Las Vegas Cable System
description: Cox Cable Communications Inc. is close to a deal to acquire 60 percent of the Prime Cable cable television system in Las Vegas, Nev., two executives close to the negotiations said yesterday.

title: Burrowing Crustaceans Cause Closing of Pier
description: A popular West Side pier that plays host to urban sunbathers, weekend concerts and expensive private cruises was closed abruptly Friday afternoon when inspectors discovered that marine borers had dangerously eroded pilings that support parts of its two and a half acres.

title: Y.& R., in 'strategic opportunity,' buys consulting entity and folds it into Wunderman Cato.
description: SEEKING to expand its services, Young & Rubicam Inc. in New York will acquire the consulting practice of a Connecticut company and fold the operation into its Wunderman Cato Johnson unit.

title: Israel Seeks U.S. Aid, Not Troops; Arabs Are Citizens
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics of The Times; Kiss, Kiss, Grovel, Grovel
description: The annual spring urge to party with pols has always been one of the least attractive attributes of Washington reporting. For years the artificial show of good fellowship at the Gridiron and other dinners has been exceeded only by their atmosphere of coziness and tackiness. Presidents and other politicians forced to sing for their supper usually look as if they really want to be someplace else. But the White House Correspondents Dinner over the weekend hit some kind of a new low even for these events. A useless event has evolved into a tasteless exercise of fawning celebrity worship.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KURI, RICHARD F.
description: KURI-Richard F. Passed away peacefully at age 86 on April 23, 1998. Forever in the hearts of, and sorely missed by daughters, Renate, Loraine, Linda and Gisella, and by son Richard J. His children, 12 grandchildren and six great grandchildren, as well as countless friends, miss his presence.

title: On My Mind; Gifts For Israel
description: On Israel's 50th anniversary, its friends can give the country certain gifts of importance. They can recognize Israel's achievements and take joy from them. And they can accept without denial or flinching the fact that after a half-century Israel's neighbors still want it dead.

title: Honda Chief to Step Down; Few Changes Are Expected
description: Nobuhiko Kawamoto, the engineer who has led Honda to record profits and market shares in the United States and Japan over the last eight years, announced yesterday his retirement as president and chief executive.

title: Japan Disciplines 112 Finance Officials
description: The Japanese Finance Minister, Hikaru Matsunaga, said today that 112 ministry officials would be punished for accepting excessive entertainment from banks, brokerage firms and insurers under their supervision.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: MARK STRENGTHENS. The mark and other major European currencies rose as the dollar fell in reaction to heavy selloffs in American stocks and bonds. In New York the dollar fell to 1.7876 marks, from 1.7895 Friday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAGER, FRANZ,
description: SCHAGER-Franz, Baron von Eckartsau. 88, of Locust Valley, on April 25, 1998. Born in Vienna, Austria. Funeral April 30, 10:30 AM, at St. Paul the Apostle R.C. Church, Route 107, Brookville, NY. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Humane Society of New York.

title: PRO FOOTBALL: Flutie Tries to Get Past 'The Pass'; At 35, Football's Everyman Takes Another Shot at the N.F.L.
description: The football keeps floating, floating, hanging in the lights. It is the miracle pass thrown by Doug Flutie almost 14 years ago and it will never come down. He was the little man that could, and he had the arm that did. Flutie was the quarterback for Boston College and that 48-yard ''Hail Mary'' pass into rain and gusty winds to Gerard Phelan led the Eagles to a 47-45 victory over Miami in the Orange Bowl on Nov. 23, 1984. That is a day Flutie will never forget; mainly because no one will ever let him.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Treasury Yields Surge On Fear of Rising Rates

title: GIULIANI ENDORSES VETOES BY PATAKI, DESPITE CITY LOSS
description: While state lawmakers voiced outrage today over Gov. George E. Pataki's vetoes of more than $1.5 billion in state spending, Mr. Pataki won a vote of confidence from an unlikely source: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York City.

title: A Bit of Bias Covered in Froth
description: The Kirov Opera, on the third evening of its festival at the Metropolitan Opera House on Saturday, got down to serious exotica. Well, not so serious: Prokofiev's ''Betrothal in a Monastery'' from 1946 is studiedly lighthearted, designed in part to keep the composer clear of deep Soviet political waters at the time.

title: Surgeon General Warns of Rise in Ethnic Smoking
description: In a report that afforded President Clinton the perfect opportunity to renew his call for comprehensive tobacco legislation, the Surgeon General, Dr. David Satcher, warned today that increases in smoking by minorities, especially minority teen-agers, threaten to reverse significant declines in the incidence of cancer.

title: Perfection, And Game, Escape Franco
description: Usually, it is the Mets who come from behind. Usually, it is the Mets who win one-run games. But yesterday afternoon at Shea Stadium, the Mets did neither. John Franco, who had not allowed a run in seven prior appearances, let a two-run ninth-inning lead slip away as the Houston Astros rallied for a 4-3 victory. The defeat was the first a Met reliever has been charged with this season.

title: On the Use of Buildings For Decorative Effect
description: Ellsworth Kelly was easy to spot on the roof of the Metropolitan Museum of Art a few days ago. His orange baseball cap distinguished him from the 38 people involved in the complex installation of his sculptures.

title: 2 Women Abducted in Massachusetts End Up in Bronx
description: Two women were kidnapped Sunday and taken on a 200-mile ride that ended in the Bronx early yesterday after a foiled robbery in Massachusetts that left one gunman dead and another at large, the authorities said.

title: Looks Can Be Deceiving
description: PICK your homily: ''You can't judge a book by its cover'' or ''Beauty is but skin deep.'' Either way, you'd be correct, although not necessarily in agreement with others when it comes to assessing health, according to the findings of a study published in the journal Psychological Science.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''If he is in there, what good is it going to do? My son is . . . I couldn't hug him or anything.''

title: Alternative Medicine Makes Inroads, but Watch Out for Curves
description: ALTERNATIVE medicine is clearly the largest growth industry in health care today. Last year, 42 percent of American adults used some type of alternative care -- herbal therapy, chiropractic, acupuncture, massage therapy or any of a number of other methods not taught in medical school, according to a nationwide telephone survey conducted for Landmark Healthcare Inc., a managed alternative care company in Sacramento, Calif.

title: Many See Fed's Hand In Report Of Rate Intent
description: Decisions made during the Federal Reserve's eight-times-a-year policymaking sessions are usually among the few true secrets in Washington, impervious to leak or spin.

title: A Novelist Builds Out From Fact To Reach The Truth; John Irving Begins With His Memories
description: Running through John Irving's novels is the theme of lost children and absent parents: from the unknown father in ''The World According to Garp'' to ''The Cider House Rules,'' in which ''all the parents are missing.'' In Mr. Irving's new novel, ''A Widow for One Year,'' a mother, severely depressed by the accidental death of her two sons, disappears for 37 years. A pivotal line in the book says, ''The grief of lost children never dies.''

title: Founder Is Resigning Over Troubles at Ascii
description: The Ascii Corporation, a major Japanese computer-related publisher and software developer, said yesterday that its founder and president, Kazuhiko Nishi, would resign to take responsibility for poor earnings. Ascii said it now expected a net loss for the year that ended on March 31, because of sluggish sales and losses from liquidating 10 affiliates in an effort to revamp operations.

title: Brother Versus Brother; Koch Family's Long Legal Feud Is Headed for a Jury
description: In the annals of family feuds, the slugfest of the Koch family of Kansas is one of the biggest, meanest and longest-running.

title: A Winding Path of Laughter From Stage to TV and Back
description: In the rehearsal room, the man in the wheelchair extended a candy box to a visitor. It was supposed to be an offer of welcome, a gesture of mundane generosity. But as the visitor reached into the box, the man in the chair, his inordinate selfishness kicking in, suddenly became alarmed; his favorite chocolate was about to be swiped, and he abruptly swiveled the box around to protect it.

title: Shortage of Housing for Poor Grows in U.S.
description: Despite a robust national economy, a shortage of affordable housing for poor people -- once a problem found only in cities -- is growing in many suburbs around the country, according to a report by the Department of Housing and Urban Development that will be delivered to Congress on Tuesday.

title: Son of Paterson Bishop Choked on Bag of Drugs
description: The son of a Paterson clergyman who died in police custody on Friday night choked on a bag of marijuana he had swallowed voluntarily, the Passaic County Prosecutor said yesterday.

title: Ruling Says Salinas Sister-in-Law Told of Bribes
description: Within weeks after Swiss police investigators found more than $130 million that Raul Salinas de Gortari, the elder brother of former Mexican President Carlos Salinas, had secreted away in Swiss banks, Raul Salinas's wife admitted to the authorities that the money had come from bribes, newly released court papers show.

title: White House to Fight California Initiative to Ban Bilingual Classes
description: The Clinton Administration announced its opposition today to a California ballot initiative that would end bilingual education in that state, saying the President and other officials would actively campaign against it.

title: Topics of The Times; Mr. Vacco's Smokescreen
description: It is hard not to fume about Attorney General Dennis Vacco's starring role in anti-smoking ads now airing around New York State. The ads feature Mr. Vacco lecturing about the perils of teen-agers smoking. While they may be good for Mr. Vacco, who is running for re-election, most experts on teen-age smoking believe that the last thing we need is some adult, particularly a politician, lecturing on why tobacco is bad.

title: SENATE JOUSTING STARTS A DEBATE ON WIDENING NATO
description: After several desultory months of occasional hearings and monologues, the Senate began a real debate today over the future of NATO. Advocates of expanding the military alliance said it would unite and stabilize Europe. But opponents argued that it would antagonize Russia and, perhaps, set off a nuclear calamity.

title: Now Playing, the Angels (Yet Again)
description: Does ESPN love the Anaheim Angels too much? Last Wednesday night, ESPN blessed us with the Orioles-Angels game at Anaheim. ESPN followed up on Sunday with the Angels playing the Devils Rays at Tampa Bay. So it seemed peculiar to learn during the telecast that ESPN would return to Anaheim next Sunday for the Angels' game against the White Sox.

title: Political Briefing; To His Own Party, Persona Non Grata
description: The National Republican Campaign Committee customarily supports all Republican candidates for re-election, providing big-name guest speakers, holding fund-raisers, getting out the vote. But Representative Jay C. Kim of California's 41st Congressional District, east of Los Angeles, will get none of that help this year.

title: Addicted to the Gas Tax
description: There is an easy solution to the problem of pork barrel spending in the recently passed Federal highway legislation.

description: MERHAN-Harold. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to our friend, Councilwoman June Eisland, on the loss of her beloved father, Harold Merhan. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President Rabbi Moshe Drelich, Youth Dir.

description: AMPOLSKY-Irving. On April 27, 1998. description: Wang Dan, eight days out of a Chinese prison, propped his elbows on the white linen tablecloth yesterday and poured over the menu at Tapika, an airy West Side restaurant.

description: How doth the little crocodile

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAUL, GABRIEL (GABE) H.,
description: PAUL-Gabriel (Gabe) H., 88. Of Tampa died Sunday at Memorial Hospital. A native of Rochester, NY, he led a distinguished career in professional baseball. Starting as a batboy for the Rochester Baseball Club in 1920, he attained the position of President of the Cincinnati Reds, New York Yankees and Cleveland Indians and was a member of Baseball's Executive Council. He held ownership positions in all three clubs. He also was the first General Manager of the Houston Colt 45's, now the Houston Astros. He is survived by his beloved wife, Mary Frances; four sons, Gabriel Jr, of Reston, VA, Warren of Plano, TX, Michael of Boca Raton, FL, Henry Lee of Tampa; one daughter, Jennie of Gambrills, MD; one brother, Sam of Woodmere, Long Island, NY; three sisters; Bess Benewick of Rochester, NY, Mildred Levine of Oneonta, NY, and Sylvia Lasky of Olena, NY; and nine grandchildren. Private services will be held on Wednesday. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the National Jewish Medical and Research Center, 1400 Jackson Street, Denver, CO 80206.

title: Studying Sleep in Space
description: Take a group of people under stress and have them travel from New York to London every day, then ask them to sleep in a noisy room where they cannot lie down. NASA does the equivalent to its astronauts, and the toll is predictable: crew members lose two or three hours of sleep a night.

title: Party Animals, or, Frolics Of the Rich and Tacky
description: Champagne, presumably of a most expensive vintage, flows freely in ''High Society,'' the musical that opened last night at the St. James Theater. But the characters consuming it in this latest variation on ''The Philadelphia Story,'' Philip Barry's 1939 comedy about life among the rich and charming, might as well be sophomores at a beer blast.

title: Giuliani to Trim Spending By 3 Percent (See Asterisk)
description: Since Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani took office in 1994, the fiscal rites of spring in New York City have focused on arguments over what programs and services to cut from its budget. But this April, a curious and politically sensitive new debate has arisen: How fast is the city's spending growing?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, THOMAS ALLISON,

Williams III. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the Foundation for United Hospital, 406 Boston Post Road, Port Chester, NY 10573 or the Rye Free Reading Room, Boston Post Road, Rye, NY 10580. Services will be held on Wednesday, April 29, 10AM at the Rye Presbyterian Church on Boston Post Road, Rye, NY, and 3PM at American Yacht Club, Milton Point, Rye, New York. Mr. Williams was currently Commodore of the American Yacht Club, Chairman of the PGA Buick Classic, President of The Depository Trust Co, New York, NY, and past Chairman of Board of Directors of United Hospital Medical Center, Portchester, New York.

title: 2 Sides in Brawley Case Reject Judge's Settlement
description: In an effort to gain control over the meandering Tawana Brawley defamation case, Justice S. Barrett Hickman yesterday proposed a settlement in the lawsuit for the second time in a month, according to lawyers involved in the case. But his offer was immediately rejected by all sides.

title: Shortage Prompts Release of Data on Drug
description: Responding to a critical national shortage of a life-saving drug, the four largest manufacturers of the blood-derived product yesterday announced that they would begin releasing production data so the public could better monitor the severity of the shortage.

title: Teletubbies' Marketer Is Their Biggest Fan
description: IT is a rare marketing creature -- or an extremely clever one -- who refuses to pose with ''the product,'' but this is the case with Kenn Viselman, the whiz behind the ''Teletubbies'' blitz.

title: For Specialty Users, Browser Price May Be Right

title: KNIGHT-RIDDER WILL MOVE HEADQUARTERS TO CALIFORNIA

Some corporate functions will remain in Miami, along with about 90 of its 150 corporate employees. Knight-Ridder did not disclose the specific city in California, but said Palo Alto was a candidate. title: The Chef

It's a favorite of mine not just because it brings back memories of my hometown, but because it accomplishes what we so often strive for in cooking: a sense of counterpoint, striking just the right balance between mild and pungent. The mild part is the liver, rich and silky and luxurious in texture, and so subtle in flavor it's almost tasteless.

title: Sugar's Latest Everglades Threat
description: The most ambitious environmental project to emerge from the Clinton Administration has been its promise to restore the Everglades and Florida Bay to good health. The White House has worked hard to carry out that promise, and Congress has been generous with its checkbook. Yet the Florida State Legislature, goaded by one of Florida's powerful sugar cane growers, is close to approving two amendments that could arrest the momentum of what is still a fragile enterprise. If the amendments pass, it is up to Gov. Lawton Chiles, long a friend of the Everglades, to veto them.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PAPAMARKOU, ALEXANDER P.
description: PAPAMARKOU-Alexander P. We at the Library of Congress are deeply saddened by the death of our esteemed friend and counselor Alecko Papamarkou. As a founding member of the Library's private-sector support group, the James Madison Council, he supported many important programs that have brought the unique resources of this institution to people everywhere. In honor of his grandfather, an eminent educator who brought the concept of public education to Greece, he established the Harissios Papamarkou Chair in Education at the Library of Congress, a position which will advance the Library's expanding role in education and in using electronic versions of the Library's collections in the nation's schools. He sponsored a special evening at the Library in October 1997 honoring the Ecumenical Patriarch of Constantinople and was an imaginative and generous supporter of the Library's international outreach. We will miss Alecko's warmth, humor and keen wisdom. He was a rare friend and we are grateful that he allowed us to be a part of his life. James H. Billington The Librarian of Congress

The great diamond on her finger flashes as the maitre d'hotel pulls out her table and she slides onto the banquette. He hands her a card and produces a bottle of Champagne. ''Krug '85,'' he intones, pulling the cork. ''How sweet of him,'' the woman murmurs. The Champagne foams into the glass and she picks it up, pausing before taking a sip.
