title: Vickers Names New Chief Executive
description: Vickers P.L.C., which is selling its luxury-car-making arm, appointed a former executive of BTR P.L.C., Paul Buysse, as its chief executive. He will assume the role on Friday, allowing Sir Colin Chandler to relinquish one of his titles and concentrate on being chairman. Sir Colin took over for a year in April 1997.

title: MICROSOFT BUYS MESA GROUP TO BOLSTER E-MAIL SOFTWARE
description: The Microsoft Corporation said yesterday that it had bought the closely held Mesa Group Inc., which helps electronic mail users move from I.B.M. software to Microsoft software, in a bid to take corporate E-mail customers from I.B.M. The Boston-based Mesa Group provides software and services to companies wanting to switch from I.B.M.'s Lotus Notes E-mail to Microsoft's Exchange E-mail software. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Mesa's Jumpstart products complement Microsoft's Notes Connector software, which enables companies to use Lotus Notes and Exchange at the same time. Mesa's software lets users move permanently from I.B.M. to Microsoft.

title: League Signs Sales, Folkl and Penicheiro
description: The Women's National Basketball Association scored a resounding coup yesterday when it announced the signing of three of the most sought collegiate players -- Nykesha Sales of Connecticut, Kristin Folkl of Stanford and Ticha Penicheiro of Old Dominion -- on the day before the league's draft.

title: Assisted Suicide: A Slippery Slope
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ODENHEIMER, SONIA
description: ODENHEIMER-Sonia. April 28, 1998. Wife of the late Monroe. Mother of Robert (Barbara) Odenheimer. Grandmother of Alexis and Mark Fried and Shari Odenheimer. Great-grandmother of Steven and Carly. Funeral services will be held Thursday, 10:30AM, at Goldsteins Rosenberg Raphael Sacks, 6410 North Broad Street, Philadelphia. Additional services Thursday, 2 P.M., at the Chapel of Cedar Park Cemetery Mausoleum, Paramus, NJ. Family will be at the residence of Robert and Barbara Odenheimer.

title: Arizona Court Strikes Down Law Requiring English Use
description: The Arizona Supreme Court ruled today that a 1988 law requiring state and local government business to be conducted in English was unconstitutional.

title: Cancer Rates Fell in '96, But Stay Among Highest
description: Cancer rates in New Jersey declined in 1996, but were still among the highest in the nation, according to a report released yesterday.

title: Baffert Sticks to the Routine of a Derby Winner
description: Having won the Kentucky Derby last year and two years ago, too, the trainer Bob Baffert is following a similar schedule with his horses in this year's race.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Sunday about plans to introduce a single European currency, the euro, misstated the given name and affiliation of a professor who was quoted on the development's potential cost to the United States economy. He is Richard Portes of the London Business School, not Robert Portes of the London School of Economics.

title: Clinton Raises $1 Million For Democratic Hopefuls
description: President Clinton came to New York last night to raise $1 million for Democratic Senate campaigns across the nation this year, attending a high-priced fund-raiser that saw all three New York Senate candidates gather in the same candle-lit Upper East Side mansion.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVID, CLARA WILHELMINA
description: DAVID-Clara Wilhelmina. On April 26, 1998 at Vero Beach, FL. Beloved wife of Commander Edmonds David (USN ret); adored mother of Katherine David Norris, Evelyn David, Anne David, James Rhoads David and Dr. John Edmonds David. Willie was the dearly loved grandmother of Christine, Alexandra, Edward and Nicole David. Burial will be in Tuxedo Park, New York. A memorial service will be held later in the spring.

title: Sips; Framboise Beer? A Bad Idea Gone Good
description: FRUIT beer sounds like a very bad idea, but long ago, Belgium's brew masters figured out a way to make it work; in the case of Lindemans framboise, brilliantly. The beer -- tart and light bodied, with a champagnelike effervescence -- delivers a ton of bright, luscious raspberry flavor in each corked and capped bottle. It cuts thirst faster than a ginsu knife can slice a Jersey tomato.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Stock Rebound Falters; Market Ends Mixed

title: Surging Economy Is Lifting Social Security, U.S. Finds
description: Even before the Clinton Administration and Congress settle on the politically delicate steps needed to insure Social Security's long-term health, the strong economy has bolstered the retirement system's financial condition, the Government reported today.

title: Zito Makes Inner Peace His Priority at the Derby
description: Nick Zito, the boy from the big city who twice in the decade of the 1990's came to the bluegrass country and won the Kentucky Derby, stood outside Barn 42 at Churchill Downs on this cold morning and contemplated the whims of fate.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  SCHACHTER, JACK
description: SCHACHTER-Jack. 4/29/95. The third anniversary of your death makes us realize even more how very much we miss you. It is so hard to believe you are not in our world, but you are and always will be in our hearts and thoughts. Rest in peace, dearest brother. Cindy and Slomo

description: FAGAN-Valeska, 89, of Orient, L.I. On April 26, 1998. Loving wife of the late Frank. Dear mother of Andrea Rowsom, Dona Arno and Peter Fagan. Cherished grandmother of 9, great grandmother of 3. Graveside service Wednesday, April 29, 1998, 11AM, Orient Central Cemetery, Orient, Long Island, Pastor James Cavanaugh officiating. Info: S.B. Horton Funeral Home, Greeport, Long Island.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SIEGEL, MURIEL COGAN
description: SIEGEL-Muriel Cogan. The Rabbi, Officers, Trustees and Members of Temple Beth El, Cedarhurst, NY and its Affiliates express deepest sympathy on the passing of the mother of our member Carolyn Garter. We grieve with the family on its loss. Dr. Sholom Stern, Rabbi Allan Kroningold, President

title: After Sound and Fury in Russia, Cabinet Change Is Slight
description: The first round of appointments to Russia's new Government, announced today after a meeting between President Boris N. Yeltsin and his protege, Prime Minister Sergei N. Kiriyenko, revealed no surprises, no political concessions and hardly any change.

title: Lenders Pull Two Bonnards From a Show At the Modern
description: When the Museum of Modern Art's Pierre Bonnard retrospective opens on June 21, two paintings of female nudes -- one rendered in bright yellow, rose and orange, the other in subtle blue and gray -- will be missing, withdrawn from the show by their owners.

title: A Mandate to Force Computer Expertise
description: Only last February, the ninth-grade biology class at North Broward Preparatory began with the shuffle of notebooks and pencils. Now lessons open with the sound of Web site addresses being tapped into computers.

title: Excerpts From Unabomber's Journal
description: Following are excerpts from documents prosecutors filed yesterday in Federal District Court in Sacramento, Calif., in support of a 34-page sentencing memorandum for Theodore J. Kaczynski, who on Jan. 22 pleaded guilty to 13 counts that included the bombing deaths of three people in the Unabom case. The idiosyncrasies in spelling, capitalization and abbreviation are Mr. Kaczynski's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LICHTENSTEIN, RUTH GOLDFARB
description: LICHTENSTEIN-Ruth Goldfarb. Age 81. Died peacefully April 25, 1998. A spirited, creative woman with a zest for life that was beautifully expressed in art work, travel, gardening and sewing. Lived graciously, modestly, savoring every moment by seizing the day, carpe diem. Much beloved by children, grandchild, brother, sister-in-law, nieces: Judith Merchant, Michael, Joan and Keira Lichtenstein, and Myron, Jetta, Tamar and Eve Gordon. Our lives were made richer and fuller by you. May God grant you peace and serenity.

title: From Welfare Roll to Child Care Worker
description: Many day care centers, especially for-profit chains, are hiring welfare recipients to care for young children.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LYONS, SHIRLEY
description: LYONS-Shirley. On April 28, 1998. Beloved mother of Lenore and Terry. Cherished grandmother of Michelle and Crispen. Funeral is private.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASEBALL

title: STUDENT DISPATCHES: Iowa City; Love, Sex and Other Misunderstandings
description: NINE juniors and seniors from City High School were sprawled around a basement family room in this university town when the conversation turned to the truths about high-school dating.

title: EQUITY OFFICE TO BUY 13 PROPERTIES FOR $394 MILLION
description: Equity Office Properties Trust said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire 13 buildings totaling about 2.7 million square feet from affiliates of Miller Global Properties L.L.C. and the Anschutz Properties Company, for about $394 million. Equity Office Properties, based in Chicago, is a real estate investment trust. Miller Global Properties, based in Denver, is a commercial real estate concern. The purchase price consists of mortgage debt of about $48 million, $280 million in cash and Equity Office Properties stock valued at $66 million. Under the deal, Equity Office Properties will acquire nine buildings in the Denver area and four in Albuquerque, N.M., plus two future development sites in Denver.

title: 2 Former Union Officials Are Charged With Fraud
description: Two former officials of the teamsters' union were charged yesterday with setting up an elaborate scheme in which they set up two bogus union locals so they could sell health insurance at a profit.

title: Weary of the Grief of War, an Israeli Cries Stop!
description: Nella Cassouto remembers that her husband's grave was dug in a third row of tombstones in a section of the Israeli military cemetery in the city of Haifa. Now, she says, the ranks of the fallen stretch far beyond it, as far as the eye can see.

title: World News Briefs; Mubarak and Netanyahu In First Meeting in a Year
description: The leaders of Egypt and Israel held their first face-to-face meeting here today in nearly a year, but there was no sign that the session had healed strains over the stalled path toward peace.

title: Words of Warning in the NATO Battle: Senators Tilt at Europe's Future
description: Following are excerpts from the Senate debate today and on Monday on a measure to expand NATO to include Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic, as provided by The Congressional Record and Senators' offices. The passages on today's debate focus on a proposed amendment, which was defeated, to limit United States spending to expand NATO.

title: Liggett & Myers to Assist Tobacco Industry Inquiry
description: The Justice Department said yesterday that Liggett & Myers Inc., the maker of L & M and other cigarette brands, had agreed to cooperate with the Government in its four-year-long criminal investigation into possible wrongdoing by the tobacco industry.

title: Mixed Day for Share Prices as Inflation Worries Still Nag
description: Stocks started to make a modest comeback yesterday from Monday's tumble, but many blue chips gave up ground once again, leaving major stock indexes mixed.

title: Clinton Picks Career Diplomat For Disputed Mexico Vacancy
description: President Clinton said today that he would nominate a career diplomat, Assistant Secretary of State Jeffrey Davidow, as Ambassador to Mexico, a post vacant for almost 10 months because of wrangling between the White House and the Senate.

title: A Shimmering Arrival For the Strawberry Tart
description: AFTER a mild yet drab winter, the brilliant fruit tarts that have started beckoning from the showcases of just about every pastry shop in town are as alluring as lilacs. It's not peak season yet -- the fruit isn't quite what it should and will be -- but the tarts call out irresistibly anyway. And the strawberry tarts, in particular, look gorgeous.

title: Will Police Crackdown Make for a Better Village?
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GROSZ, IRENE (MRS. EUGENE)
description: GROSZ-Irene (Mrs. Eugene). Born Hungary. Died Florida, 4/9. Designer, artist, sculptor, Irene embraced life with style and elegance. Greatly missed by family and friends worldwide.

title: People
description: * Greg Davis was named to the new position of business development director at Berlin, Cameron & Partners, New York. He had been vice president for business development at ABP/Draft Worldwide, New York, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on April 20 about technology companies' hiring of foreign workers misstated the name of one company. It is the Mastech Corporation, not Mastech Systems. The article also misspelled the surname of the company's investor relations director. He is Chuck Rudisill, not Rusdill.

title: Alternative Public Schools Cost More but Do Better Job, Report Says
description: Seeking to resolve a contentious question surrounding New York City's small, alternative public schools, researchers have found that they spend more per pupil than traditional schools but get better results for their money by graduating more students in four years.

title: Sumitomo Bank Cuts Its Earnings Forecast
description: Sumitomo Bank Ltd. reduced its earnings forecasts yesterday for the fiscal year that ended on March 31 as it accelerated write-offs of problem loans and increased reserves. Sumitomo, a major Japanese bank, now expects a pretax loss of 615 billion yen for the year, considerably worse than its previous forecast of a loss of 440 billion yen.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BARRETT, FRAN
description: BARRETT-Fran. Died April 27. Beloved wife of Frank. Loving mother of Jason. Dearly beloved daughter of Dorothy and sister of Alyce. She will live forever in the hearts of all who were touched by her caring, her devotion to her teaching career and her courage.

title: O'Brien Shooting For a Record
description: Dan O'Brien, the Olympic champion and world record-holder in the decathlon, is preparing for this summer's Goodwill Games decathlon by doing anything except an actual decathlon.

title: 8% Revenue Growth Seen for Chips in '98
description: The worldwide semiconductor market is experiencing its third consecutive lackluster year, with industry revenue projected to grow 8 percent, to $159 billion, this year, according to Dataquest.

title: Wellesley Donor Pledges $11 Million To Rescue Russian Studies Programs
description: Fresh out of Wellesley College back in 1928, Kathryn Wasserman Davis rode on horseback deep into the Caucasus Mountains in search of adventure and an obscure Muslim tribe, subsisted on berries and goats, almost starved, and conceived a lifelong passion for things Soviet and Russian.

title: Woolworth Plans to Sell Its Landmark Building
description: The dismantling of Frank W. Woolworth's five-and-dime empire reached the pinnacle yesterday -- the cloud-piercing, spun-sugar Gothic pinnacle -- as the Woolworth Corporation formally announced its intention to sell the landmark tower at 233 Broadway that has been its headquarters for 85 years.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOCH, PEARL
description: KOCH-Pearl. The Board of Directors of the United Hebrew Geriatric Center mourns the passing of Mrs. Pearl Koch, beloved mother of Jerome Koch, esteemed member and Past President of our Board. Our heartfelt sympathy and prayers are extended to the Koch family. Malcolm Lazarus, President David Shatz, Chairman Rita C. Mabli, Exec Vice Pres.

title: In Investment Sector: Rumor And Hot Denial
description: Frank Quattrone has never minced words about his lack of love for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, the firm he left two years ago to head up DMG Technology Group, the technology banking arm of Deutsche Bank A.G. ''We left Morgan Stanley and showed we could do everything,'' Mr. Quattrone, an investment banker who is the group's chief executive, boasted recently. ''Suddenly we became a threat.''

title: INSIDE
description: Inspector Reports on Iraq

title: Meet the Beatles Again, And Their Musical Fans
description: You can't go wrong with a Beatles tune. For the generation that can afford $125 tickets to benefit shows, Lennon-McCartney songs are so deeply and fondly remembered that a competent performance is lovable and anything better is pure delight. That's what Sting and his cohorts realized for the ninth annual Rainforest Foundation benefit concert, which took place at Carnegie Hall on Monday night.

title: Calipari Puts Series In Hands Of Players
description: After the Nets finished practice today, what could be their last day of practice, some of the players hurried to their cars before Coach John Calipari could change his mind and call them back.

title: Another Accused Of Yield Burning
description: Though it has already settled allegations of ''yield burning'' against the Corestates Financial Corporation and a former employee, the Securities and Exchange Commission sued another former worker today who refused to settle the case.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARTZ, LOUIS
description: SCHWARTZ-Louis. April 27, 1998. Husband of Sylvia (nee Rosenblum); father of Bernard Schwartz and Mark (Sharon) Schwartz; brother of Harry Schwartz. Grandfather of Jennifer and Joshua. Relatives and friends are invited to graveside services Wednesday at 2 PM at Mount Hebron Cemetery.

title: Mets Fall In the 10th As Franco Flops Again
description: Live by the bullpen, die by the bullpen.

title: I.R.S. Hearings Resume
description: The Senate Finance Committee has begun a second round of hearings into complaints of abuses by the Internal Revenue Service. Democrats say the incidents -- including car theft and armed raids on nonviolent taxpayers -- are exaggerated. But Republicans have an eye on poll results after hearings last September showing that the alleged abuses are their most potent issue.

title: Greek Cypriots To Get Missiles From Russians
description: Russia plans to deliver advanced antiaircraft missiles to the Greek Cypriot Government in August, despite American protests that the sale will inflame tensions on the island, part of which is Turkish-controlled.

title: Pork for Private Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: The Universe Catches Up as Art; Scientists Have Always Known It Was Exquisite, But a Little Color Helps Bolster the Popular Image
description: Out in deep space, our universe of heavenly bodies is a riot of glorious colors and fantastical shapes. But you won't know that by looking at the night sky, which, even in the clearest weather when it's dotted by seemingly endless stars, is a minimalist study in black and white. That's because the eye is unable to perceive colors when the source of light is small and faint.

title: Women's Hardcourts To Be in New Haven
description: The United States women's hardcourt championships, which has been looking for a new home, not only found one yesterday but also came up with a new name -- the Pilot Pen International women's championship.

description: WIESEL-Philip. description: Seeking to reignite the spirit of the 1994 ''Contract With America,'' a senior Republican today began trying to clear the way for a budget containing far larger tax cuts than those envisioned by either President Clinton or the Senate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WASSERMAN, JACK
description: WASSERMAN-Jack. On April 27, 1998 of Boca Raton, FL. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved husband of Min. Devoted father of Bert W. and Sandra Wasserman, Rosanne and Al Whyard, Adele J. and Bill Redisch. Loving grandfather of Mindee Wasserman, Craig and Marla Wasserman, Debra W. and Monty Amdursky, Cynthia and Mark Albers, Deborah Redisch, Elissa and Jarrett Schube. title: Reader's Digest Names a New Chairman
description: Reader's Digest Association Inc. said last night that it had named a senior American Express executive to be its chairman and chief executive, ending an eight-month search.

title: Sports of The Times; Heat Stills The Knicks And the Fans
description: IN the garden of good and evil -- somebody ought to use that for a book title -- they were back at it again last night. Good vs. Evil, officially certified by the hometown fans.

title: Moliere, Treating Doctors, Buries His Patients
description: It has been a good year for French theater in New York. Ionesco's ''Chairs'' and Yasmina Reza's ''Art'' are among the hottest tickets on Broadway. Feydeau's ''Flea in Her Ear'' has been a top draw for the Roundabout Theater, and the Ubu Repertory scored a twin success with revivals of Camus's ''Misunderstanding'' and ''The Just.'' Now the Francophilia parade has wound its way downtown where the Cocteau Repertory is staging Moliere's last play, ''The Imaginary Invalid.''

title: $25 and Under; Dutch Schultz Was the Downstairs Neighbor
description: SYDNEY B. was named after a madam. No, not the Mayflower Madam, but a similarly named woman who operated a brothel in Chelsea in the 1920's. What's more, said Ian Topper-Kapitan, the chef and an owner, the basement below this inviting bar and restaurant used to be a speakeasy owned by Dutch Schultz.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  QUELL, MARION
description: QUELL-Marion. Of Stewart Manor, April 27 (retired Trust Officer of Irving Trust). Beloved sister of John, loving aunt of Christine, Carolyn, and Barbara. Reposing at Krauss Funeral Home Inc, 1097 Hempstead Turnpike, Franklin Square, Thursday 3-5 and 7-9 P.M. Religious service 8 P.M. Funeral on Friday 10:30 A.M. Interment Lutheran Cemetery.

description: PARKER-Jason C. Of Elmsford, NY, on April 27, 1998. Husband of Elizabeth Ambler Parker. Father of Jason S. and Judith Parker. Grandfather of four. A Memorial Service will be conducted at a time and place to be announced. Interment Kensico Cemetery. Memorial contributions to White Plains Hospital Center, White Plains, NY, 10601 would be appreciated.

title: Stop Worrying About Russia
description: This week, the Senate will be asked to ratify the admission of Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic to NATO.

title: Cendant Makes More Changes
description: The Cendant Corporation said today that it had named three new executive vice presidents, continuing a string of management changes prompted by an accounting debacle.

title: Gore to Address State Convention
description: Vice President Al Gore has agreed to be the keynote speaker at the New York State Democratic Convention in May, Mr. Gore's office said yesterday.

title: Liberties; The Bulworth Doctrine
description: It is delicious that Warren Beatty should be the one to come to Washington to tell us to snap out of our addiction to sex.

title: Senatorial Privilege: Toppling the Devils
description: Rocked hard again tonight by the Ottawa Senators, the reeling Devils might soon get rolled out of the Stanley Cup playoffs, perhaps as early as Game 5 Thursday night back in the Meadowlands. The Senators, the eighth and last-seeded team in the Eastern Conference, beat the conference champions, 4-3, to take a three-games-to-one lead in their first-round series.

title: Curious Cook; Why the Rubber Chicken Leg Can Bounce Across the Road
description: ANY meat can be cooked badly. Heat it too little and it's metallic and chewily limp; heat it too much and it's dry. Chicken has a special talent: it can become so springy that knife and fork practically bounce right off it. When a reader asked how she could avoid making yet another rubber chicken, I found that the best answer isn't a simple matter of hitting the right temperature. The real key is patience.

title: Judge in Brawley Case Lets His Deadline Lapse
description: The judge who promised on Monday to take control of the pace of the Tawana Brawley defamation case backed down first thing this morning, as he allowed a defense lawyer to go beyond a court-ordered deadline to complete his cross-examination of the plaintiff.

title: S.& P. Lowers Ratings Of 3 Japanese Airlines
description: The Standard & Poor's Corporation lowered the ratings of three major Japanese airlines yesterday. The long-term rating of the Japan Airlines Company was lowered to BB-plus from BBB-plus and its short-term rating was lowered to B from A-2. The outlook on the long-term rating is negative.

title: RSL TO ACQUIRE WESTINGHOUSE COMMUNICATIONS FROM CBS
description: RSL Communications Ltd. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the CBS Corporation's Westinghouse Communications for about $90 million. The unit provides telecommunications services to small and medium-sized businesses. RSL, based in Hamilton, Bermuda, is a telecommunications company that specializes in international services. It had annual revenue of $300.7 million last year. The New York-based CBS had full-year sales of $5.36 billion in 1997. Under the pact, RSL will also receive exclusive use of the name Westinghouse Communications for several years. Shares of RSL rose 75 cents, to $25.75, in Nasdaq trading, while CBS was up 6.25 cents, at $34.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: TV Notes; Piling On the Effects
description: NBC is not really ready to rest on its ''Merlin'' success, however. Its ongoing deal with Mr. Halmi, who runs Hallmark Entertainment, includes a number of other projects in the works for NBC, including the next likely miniseries event, ''Noah's Ark,'' which will probably be on the air next season. That one will star Jon Voight, and Mr. Halmi has been promising NBC even more special effects in that one.

title: STUDENT DISPATCHES: Manteo, N.C.; Making Money Is Good, but It's Work, Work, Work
description: ASK teen-agers who live on the Outer Banks of North Carolina how to spell work and they'll probably say, l-i-f-e. That's because working is a way of life for teen-agers in this community of barrier islands. For them, school days consist of classes and jobs, while their summers, which begin Memorial Day weekend in May and last through Labor Day in September, are filled with work, work and more work.

title: Germany, the Unlikely Friend
description: MUNICH  Israel and Germany, now prosperous, powerful and middle-aged, belong to that category of tales beginning with: "Back then, only lunatics would have predicted that . . ."

title: Restoring the City Arts Budget
description: For the last four years, one of New York City's familiar rites of spring has been the cat-and-mouse game the Mayor and the City Council play with the budget of the Department of Cultural Affairs. The Mayor cuts the budget to show fiscal responsibility, the Council restores it to show support for the arts, and politics is served. To the arts organizations that rely in part on city money, this budgetary game is an annual source of anxiety. At the very least it is a hindrance to planning, and the fear remains that one day the City Council will balk.

title: 3 Dealers Told to Prove Validity of $5 Car Ads
description: The ads boasted used cars for as low as $5. But the city's Department of Consumer Affairs was skeptical that the deals existed, officials said yesterday.

title: Social Security Gets Lift From Economy
description: The nation's strong economy has bolstered the financial condition of Social Security, extending the retirement system's solvency by three years, to 2032, from the date of 2029 projected last year.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place -- A Red Scare in Hong Kong; China's Prominent Public Stocks Lose Their Luster
description: China may now be the undisputed ruler of this former British colony. But some of China's most prominent public companies are feeling less welcome here today than they did before last year's handover.

title: India's Nuclear Venture
description: To the Editor:

title: F.S.U.'s Kendra To Miss Opener
description: Dan Kendra, the all-America quarterback candidate at Florida State, is not expected to be ready to play in the Kickoff Classic against Texas A&M at Giants Stadium on Aug. 31, said his coach, Bobby Bowden.

title: 'Anything Is Possible':The Hard Struggle to Build a Nation
description: JERUSALEM  For many years, most Israelis lived in an atmosphere of constant uncertainty and doubt. Basically pessimistic and prepared for the worst, temporariness was the most common feeling among them: anything could happen at any moment, including the destruction of the country. According to local folklore, this is why Israelis flying El Al would applaud upon safe landing. They naturally assumed that the plane would crash, or get hijacked, or run out of fuel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PACKALES, SIDNEY ''PACK''
description: PACKALES-Sidney ''Pack''. 85, of Palm Beach, died April 27. He is survived by his loving wife of 57 years, Shirley. Adoring father of Terry Gamer (Donald), and Jill Sullins (Garland). Four loving grandchildren. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to a charity of your choice. Services today, 10:00 A.M., Riverside-Gordon, West Palm Beach, Florida.

title: On Springer Show, Violence Is All Too Real
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Bronx Men Are Charged in Suffocation of Teacher in 1996
description: Two Bronx men were charged yesterday with robbing and suffocating a 39-year-old high school teacher nearly two years ago, law enforcement officials said.

title: Wright Morris, a Novelist of the Nebraska Prairie, Dies at 88
description: Wright Morris, whose taut American Gothic novels, stories, essays and photographs plumbed the mysteries of the stark Nebraska landscape and who was often called one of the nation's most unrecognized recognized writers, died on Saturday in Mill Valley, Calif. He was 88.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: OIL RISES 2.7 PERCENT. Crude oil rallied after OPEC members Libya and Algeria joined Venezuela, the United Arab Emirates and Qatar in supporting further production cuts. June contracts rose 42 cents, to $15.74 a barrel.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TATE, WILLIAM
description: TATE-William. A longtime Stamford resident passed away at the Courtland Gardens Health Care Center on Wednesday, April 22, 1998 due to stroke. He was 87. Born in Hackensack, New Jersey on November 6, 1910, he was the son of the late Thomas and Sarah Tate. Mr. Tate was employed at the New York Times for forty-seven years from 1929-1976. He served in classified, national and international advertising. He was named Assistant Advertising Manager in 1946, Director of Special Advertising Project in 1965, International Advertising Manager in 1968 and Advertising Manager with responsibility for the retailadvertising department in 1973. A World War II army veteran, Mr. Tate was a sergeant in the Second United States Calvary from 1943 to 1945. He served as an Armored Car Commander during World War II and was distinguished with The Silver Star, The Purple Heart and The Bronze Star. He was predeceased by his sister Doris Mitros in 1997. He is survived by his wife Mildred A. Hemmerich Tate of Stamford, Connecticut. His 3 sons: Bill Tate of Palm Harbor, FL, Brad Tate of Oceanside, CA., and Allan Tate of Bedford, MA; his two daughters Joyce Robinson of Tolland, CT., and Elaine Hjelte of Ridgefield, CT.; his sister Ethel Bullett of Fairlawn, New Jersey and eight grandchildren. Funeral services will be held at the Arlington National Cemetery in Arlington, Virginia on Friday, May 1, 1998 at 2 PM. There will be no calling hours. For further information, contact Bouton & Reynolds Funeral Home, 2900 Summer Street, Stamford, Connecticut. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to The Alzheimer's Association, Fairfield County, Chapter 607, Main Avenue, Norwalk, CT 06851.

title: Wine Talk; Good Whites Are Not Solo Acts
description: SOMETIMES, when I work late at the bureau in Paris, I like to walk around the corner to the Opera and take the 95 bus to the Gare Montparnasse. La Coupole, just down the street from the station, is the place for the perfect dinner for one: a Dover sole meuniere, a boiled potato and a half-bottle of a decent Chablis. Years earlier, when Sancerre was more or less the bar wine of Paris, I would have ordered it. But Sancerre is overpriced these days, and delicious Chablis is not.

title: JEFFERSON SMURFIT IN MERGER TALKS WITH STONE
description: The Irish paper and packaging company Jefferson Smurfit Group P.L.C. said yesterday that along with its 46.5 percent-owned United States unit, the Jefferson Smurfit Corporation, it had begun talks with the Stone Container Corporation about a ''stock for stock business combination.'' Smurfit warned that ''there can be no assurance that such discussions will continue or result in any definitive agreement.'' The Chicago-based Stone Container is the world's largest producer of paperboard and paper packaging materials. Stone's stock rose 50 cents yesterday, to $16, giving the company a market capitalization of $1.59 billion. Shares of Jefferson Smurfit were down 25 cents, to $20.50, giving the company's United States stock a $2.27 billion value.

title: Business Travel; For corporate fliers, airlines' alliances may mean more convenience but with higher fares.

title: PSA Peugeot Citroen Sales Rise by 24%
description: PSA Peugeot Citroen, France's largest car maker, said yesterday that its sales soared 24 percent in the first quarter. Sales reached 57.8 billion French francs ($9.63 billion), up from 46.5 billion francs in the corresponding period a year earlier. The figure a year earlier was recalculated to consolidate sales of Bertrand Faure S.A., a car parts unit that Peugeot's Ecia S.A. subsidiary took control of in December.

title: NATO and the Lessons of History
description: The small but vociferous band of senators opposed to NATO expansion retreated yesterday to trying to sell a series of amendments they hoped would delay enlargement or limit the financial costs to Washington. Only one, offered by Daniel Patrick Moynihan and John Warner, would put off this round of growth by making NATO membership for Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic contingent on their gaining admission to the European Union.

title: Who Are These People, Anyway?
description: TRYING to label America's nearly 60 million teen-agers is about as easy as staying on the trail of a snowboarder in a whiteout. No definition can stretch far enough to include bubbly Hanson fans and moody Marilyn Manson devotees, marijuana-smoking homeboys and savvy junior entrepreneurs, born-again virgins and single moms, student activists and frustrated truants -- especially when one teen-ager might inhabit several of those identities. As adults circle, fascinated, teen-agers survive and thrive within these interlocking universes. If these teen-agers must be tagged, call them the Autonomous Generation, creating themselves in nobody's image but their own.

title: Bits and Bytes; Cruising the Internet For Blue-Plate Specials
description: With the return of warm weather, it's time for the American family to hit the road again. Because families, like armies, travel on their stomachs, they need places to eat along the way, and in the age of the interstate that usually means the ubiquitous chains. But it wasn't always so, say Gary and Kathy Nickerson on www.eathere.com. They evoke long family vacation trips of the 1950's and 60's that stopped at homespun little restaurants, diners, drive-ins and coffee shops, which served the blue-plate special, local seafood and country breakfasts.

title: Temptation; A Baguette for a Party With Hatter and Hare

title: The Minimalist; A Quick, Bright Bean Puree, Born to Play Many Roles

It had much more life than most and at the same time less of the harshness of raw garlic that I associate with hummus or Southwestern purees. When I asked the chef, Mirko Prando, what it was, he offered to make it with me.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MAYER, ELEANOR S. (SCHWARZ)
description: MAYER-Eleanor S. (Schwarz), 84, of Washington, Maine, died April 26, 1998 at home. Born in New York, of Robert and Sylvia Schwarz, she received a B.S. from Wellesley College, a M.S. from Teachers College, Columbia University and became the nation's first woman brewing chemist at Schwarz Laboratory (NY). She married Malvin J. Mayer on June 30, 1939. They lived in New Rochelle, NY until 1965 and then made their home in Washington, Maine. Mrs. Mayer was active in many community, education and civic groups. She was appointed as a member of the Maine Health Systems Agency and the Maine Seat Belt Coalition. In recent years Mrs. Mayer traveled widely, visiting 119 countries and working as an international brewing consultant. Mrs. Mayer was pre-deceased by a daughter Sylvia Morrison and a brother Robert Schwarz. She is survived by her husband; son Donald Mayer, daughter, Barbara Mayer; brother, David Schwarz; nine grandchildren; and three great grandchildren. In accordance with her wishes, there will be no funeral service. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Washington (ME) Library Association or the Multiple Sclerosis Society of ME.

description: The City Center Encores series has always prided itself on resurrecting and renovating classic American musicals that have fallen into eclipse and various stages of disrepair. But they had never encountered a problem quite like ''St. Louis Woman.''

title: People
description: * Robin K. Dhoble was named president and chief operating officer at a new health care practice at Rapp Collins Worldwide, New York, part of Omnicom Group. He had been executive vice president and chief operating officer at Torre Lazur Health Care Group, New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos.

title: The Year 2000 Problem: Offering Second Thoughts
description: In response to ''Wanted: A Fix With Finesse for Year 2000 Problem'' and ''Checking a Home Computer'' (April 23), several astute readers have pointed out that it is important to back up files before setting your clock to Jan. 1, 2000, to see how your software will behave in the new millennium. That is good advice and people should mind it even if they are not doing the test.

title: Bias Said to Hurt Independent Mexican Unions
description: A United States Government report that found favoritism toward unions aligned with Mexico's ruling party in labor elections here provoked a vigorous Mexican Government response today.

title: Another Blow to Miami: Knight Ridder's Move
description: Knight Ridder's plan to move its corporate headquarters from here to Northern California will have little economic impact on Miami but has nonetheless delivered a symbolic blow to a city trying to recover from an image hewn in recent years by corruption, financial trouble and voter fraud.

title: Currents; ARTFUL GARDENER -- Almost Too Good For Weeds
description: Hand-forged garden tools transform chores into art. Hida's finely crafted implements include the Hori Hori (top, $19.80), good for dandelions. Hard-to-reach weeds come out with the V-shaped scraper ($14.80). The dual-purpose Ika hoe ($19.80) cultivates and makes holes for transplants. More Hida tools are available: (800) 443-5512; gardening catalogue, $2. MAC GRISWOLD

title: Florence Skelly Altman, 73, Market Research Pioneer, Dies
description: Florence Skelly Altman, an innovator in opinion research, died on Tuesday at Scottsdale, Ariz., Memorial Hospital. She was 73 and lived in Scottsdale.

title: Senate Rejects Bid to Create a NATO Unit to Resolve Conflicts
description: The Senate today rejected an attempt to create a tribunal within NATO to help resolve conflicts that might affect the alliance before they erupt into full-blown hostilities, as happened in Bosnia.

title: India Cuts Key Rate In Move to Ease Lending
description: India's central bank cut its key interest rate to 9 percent from 10 percent and eased other restrictions on lending to stimulate the economy and reduce the cost of financing India's growing fiscal deficit. The central bank will also allow foreign institutional investors to trade treasury bills for the first time.

title: 3 Businessmen Testify of Armed Raids by I.R.S.
description: Three businessmen told the Senate Finance Committee today of Internal Revenue Service agents who, with guns drawn, broke down doors, terrified workers and forced teen-age girls to change clothes in front of male agents in raids at the men's homes and businesses that they said were unnecessary.

title: U.S. and China Gain Rapport, Albright Says
description: The United States and China ''have moved well down the road toward building a constructive, strategic partnership,'' Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright said today, as she began two days of high-level meetings intended to produce results when President Clinton comes here for a summit meeting around June 24.

title: The Fine Art of Making Faces
description: EVERYTHING about video games these days has become more lifelike. The cityscapes and passageways are elaborate science fiction creations or historically accurate recreations. Game characters are clad in digital reproductions of movie costumes or team uniforms. Scenes show the variations of light on water, through fog or in dim rooms. Both video and computer games achieve a visual subtlety that leaves the players with few gaps for their imaginations to fill in.

title: Giuliani Plans to Bypass Referendum on Stadium Financing
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani plans to summon little-known powers granted to him by the City Charter to block any attempts to hold a referendum on the future home of the New York Yankees, an aide to the Mayor said last night.

title: Sex Shops Try Using Words Of Giuliani Against Him
description: A lawyer for New York City told a Federal appeals court panel in Manhattan yesterday that Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani was wrong when he said that a zoning law banning X-rated businesses from residential neighborhoods would mean the demise of all but 20 to 30 sex shops.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, KATE (ZOREK)
description: HIRSCH-Kate (Zorek). On April 28, 1998. Beloved mother of Robert Pincus. Cherished grandmother of Allison and Liza. Services Friday 10 A.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Inflows to Mutual Funds Were Lower in April
description: Investors put an estimated $21 billion into stock and bond mutual funds in April, about a third less than last month's near record, industry groups reported yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLFE, IRIS
description: WOLFE-Iris. On April 29, 1998. Of Tampa, FL. Formerly of Bradley Beach, NJ. Sister of Saul Zimmerman, Sandra Wexlin and Florence Marks. Funeral from BernheimApter - Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood on Thursday, April 30, at 2 PM. Interment Oheb Shalom Cemetery, Hillside, NJ.

title: FRANCHISE BUYS AND SELLS HOTEL SITES FOR $84 MILLION
description: U.S. Franchise Systems Inc. said yesterday that it had bought the franchise rights to Best Inns and Suites hotels and 17 of its properties for $84 million, expanding operations into the midlevel economy hotel business. The Atlanta-based company then immediately sold the 17 properties to the New York-based investment fund Alpine Capital Group for $84 million. The seller was America's Best Inns, which is privately held. The deal includes 35 franchises run under the Best Inns and Suites names and the management company that services most of those hotels. U.S. Franchise, formed in 1995, owns franchise rights to Microtel Inn and Suites and Hawthorn Suites. It has 145 franchised hotels, with 507 more under construction.

title: Assembly Panel Faults Proposal On Mutual Insurance Companies
description: In the latest chapter in the national debate over the structure of mutual insurance companies, the State Assembly's Insurance Committee said yesterday that changes being considered in New York could financially harm millions of policyholders.

title: Family Pushes To Sell Mantle More
description: Don't expect to see jars of Mickey Mantle toothpicks, but the late Yankee's family has hired the International Creative Management agency to expand his commercial appeal in the film, literary, interactive and television realms.

title: At Hearing in Brooklyn, Crowd Jeers Proposal for Trash Station
description: Waving placards proclaiming ''Stop Dumping on Us,'' a jeering crowd last night protested a proposal to build a garbage transfer station on a stretch of Brooklyn waterfront property also under consideration for a public park.

title: Footlights
description: NEWS

title: Gains in Hard-Hit Blue-Chip Issues Push Markets Higher
description: The stock market rallied yesterday, ending five sessions of declines that were fueled by fears that the Federal Reserve would increase interest rates.

title: Piano Suite, New on Market, Uses Variety to Fan Interest
description: PIANO SUITE

title: PUBLIC LIVES
description: Movie Announcer In Another Version

title: NEWS WATCH
description: STARBUCKS ON THE WEB -- Hardly satisfied with conquering the downtown corners of practically every major city in North America, the Starbucks Coffee Company announced this week that it was setting its caffeine-widened gaze on the Internet.

title: Accounts
description: * eToys, Santa Monica, Calif., a unit of Idealab, to Kalis & Savage Advertising, Pacific Palisades, Calif., as the first agency to handle advertising for the Internet toy store. Billings were estimated at more than $1 million.

title: EXECUSTAY PLANS EXPANSION IN INTERIM HOUSING MARKET
description: The Execustay Corporation in Gaithersburg, Md., said it had agreed to buy Accommodations America, expanding its presence in the interim housing market. The stock of Execustay, which provides temporary housing for corporate clients, rose $1.875 a share, to $13.875. Terms were not disclosed. Accommodations America operates in 23 United States markets and is expected to report 1998 revenue in excess of $50 million, Execustay said. Accommodations America is an affiliate of the Trammell Crow Residential Companies, which is not affiliated with the Dallas-based Trammell Crow Company.

title: Defining a Modern Classic
description: It was back to the future on Tuesday night when the New York City Ballet opened its spring season, which runs through June 28 at the New York State Theater.

title: A 94-Candle Salute To Land Preservation
description: Webster's defines a patriot as ''one who loves his country,'' and it is fitting that on April 19, Patriots Day, Richard Hooper Pough of Pelham, N.Y., who has done more than anyone in this country to preserve ecologically significant land, celebrated his 94th birthday.

title: Harsh Verdict In Coup Trial Puts Nigeria In a New Bind
description: One day after a Nigerian military tribunal sentenced the country's former deputy head of state and five others to death in connection with a coup plot, reactions in both Nigeria and abroad suggest that far from clearing his path of perceived enemies, the verdict has narrowed the maneuvering space of an already badly isolated head of state, Gen. Sani Abacha.

title: Holik Hopes to Shake Dry Spell in Time
description: Bobby Holik cannot help feeling responsible for the Devils' post-season predicament. He led the team in scoring during the regular season, but has yet to score a goal in the playoffs, where the Devils face elimination at home against the Ottawa Senators on Thursday night.

title: U.N. Panel May Approve Limit on Guns Despite N.R.A. Pleas
description: A proposal by a United Nations commission intended to curb the illicit trade in firearms moved toward almost certain adoption today, in the wake of a sharp attack by the National Rifle Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNALL, SEYMOUR
description: SCHNALL-Seymour. Died April 28, 1998. Beloved brother of Gladys Noveck (z''l), Evelyn Domb (z''l), Jerome Schnall, Edith Artzt, Harriet Malen. Adored uncle and great uncle. A man of integrity, he enriched the lives of all who knew him. Funeral services Sinai Chapel, Queens, NY, April 30, at 11 AM

title: An Evening of Rorem Songs
description: A great song is like a great hole: what is not there is as important as what is. Ned Rorem's admirers must surely feel this strongly. His generally simple rhythm, light harmony, modest melodic phrases and frequent repetition of those phrases would then be seen as virtues. This is music that stands back and lets the words come through. It is music, too, that gives the singer plenty of scope: those simple rhythms can be tugged tight and loosened, those wisps of melody given more substance by means of accent, dynamic nuance or vocal color.

title: Trying to Save Satellite, Company Is Sending It to Moon
description: In an ambitious salvage effort that is the first of its kind, a satellite manufacturer said today that it was trying to correct the orbit of a now unusable satellite by flinging it around the Moon and back toward Earth.

title: Vallone Urges Favoritism For State Contracts
description: Unveiling a centerpiece of his economic plan as he runs for governor, Peter F. Vallone, the New York City Council Speaker, proposed yesterday that the city and the state favor contractors within the state when buying products and services.

title: Justices, Criticizing Appeals Court, Restore a Death Sentence
description: Criticizing fellow Federal judges in unusually harsh language, a narrowly divided Supreme Court ruled today that the Federal appeals court in California had committed a ''grave abuse of discretion'' by intervening at the last minute to overturn a convicted murderer's 14-year-old death sentence.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HYMAN, ROGER, M.D.
description: HYMAN-Roger, M.D. The New York State Radiological Society mourns the passing of our former president, Roger Hyman, M.D. At the time of his passing, he was the Chairman of the Dept of Radiology at North Shore University Hospital, and was a member of the governing board of the American College of Radiology. He served our Society with distinction for many years, and we shall miss his intelligence and dedication. We express our deepest sympathies to the members of his family. N.Y.S. Radiological Society E. Stephen Amis, M.D.,Pres.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINCH, EMILY GRANT
description: FINCH-Emily Grant. Age 84. Died on April 25, 1998 in Green Valley, Arizona. after a long illness. Beloved wife of the late Philip Fiske Finch Jr. and loving mother of Philip III, Catherine (Kay), Christopher and Reynolds. She leaves nine grandchildren and four greatgrandchildren. She was a graduate of Elmira College and earned a MSW at Western Reserve University. She spent many years as a full time mother and was a social worker, both paid volunteer, specializing in children and families. Former resident of Elmira, New York, Reading, PA., Westport and Fairfield, CT. Services Friday, May 1, at 2PM, Green Valley Presbyterian Church. In lieu of flowers contributions to your favorite charity would be appreciated.

title: Wong Doody Wins Top Andy Award
description: Wong Doody in Seattle won the grand prize, known as the Grandy Award, at the presentation last night of the 34th annual International Andy Awards for creativity, sponsored by the Advertising Club of New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOODMAN, JULIE
description: GOODMAN-Julie. Age 31, after her long and valiant fight, on April 29, 1998. Beloved daughter of Leni Goodman and Stuart Goodman. Loving sister of Cache. Dear niece of Joan L. Ellenbogen. Cherished granddaughter of Harriet Hecht Ellenbogen. Special friend of Lynette Gerald and her loving family of ''Patterners''. Services on Friday, 12 PM at ''The Riverside'', 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Toast Robot Keeps Orders On Light Side
description: AT first glance, it seemed like the perfect marriage of marmalade and microchips. The Electronic Toast-Butler -- as advertised in a catalogue from the Edge Company (www.edgeco.com) in Vermont -- offers to ''pluck the toast, manipulate the knife, spy the dish and put your favorite spreadable on for you'' via skinny robotic arms protruding from the sides of a sturdy-looking appliance.

title: On-Line Trail to an Off-Line Killing
description: For nearly a year, Elisa DeCarlo had been logging on to the Internet daily to type messages to an on-line support group about her battle against alcohol. It did not matter that Ms. DeCarlo did not know where most of the 200 or so other members of the group lived, or even their names. All that mattered was that they were there for her, and she for them, in a fight that some days sapped all of her strength and sense of humor.

title: Bronx Girl, 2, Dies After Being Scalded
description: A 2-year-old Bronx girl who the authorities said suffered second-degree burns last month after her baby sitter dipped her in scalding water has died, the police said yesterday.

title: S.E.C. Approves Sale of Hilton Stock
description: The chairman of the Hilton Hotels Corporation, Barron Hilton, has been cleared by the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell as many as 24 million Hilton shares from a charitable trust he controls, the company said today.

title: Israelis, Proud and Worried, Now Ask, What Is Our State?
description: It has been the fashion among Israelis on this 50th anniversary of their state to feign indifference to the jubilee, and Israeli commentators have expended considerable ink in analyzing why.

title: Divorce and the Church; Teaching Is Respected
description: To the Editor:

title: Double-Canopy Umbrella Has Aversion to Inversion
description: When it rains, and winds are high on the golf course, a good umbrella is a golfer's best friend. A Long Island father-and-son team, Arnold and Steve Asman, has come up with an umbrella that can withstand winds of up to 60 miles an hour. According to the Asmans, the umbrella, the Gustbuster, has rung up $1 million in sales in its second year on the market.

title: Comedy Net Will Find Out If Geeks Have Funny Bones
description: Do computer geeks giggle?

title: New-Home Sales Fell in March, As Months-Long Rise Is Ended
description: Sales of new single-family homes fell in March for the first time in four months, a lull for the housing market, which is providing solid support for the economy.

title: U.S. to Ask for a U.N. Tribunal to Prosecute the Khmer Rouge
description: The United States will ask the United Nations Security Council to form a tribunal to bring genocide charges against the surviving leaders of the Khmer Rouge, the guerrilla group responsible for the deaths of more than a million Cambodians in the 1970's, Administration officials said today.

title: Dell Wants to Lead Way In Move to Pentium II's
description: Dell Computer Company, which bills itself as the planet's leading company for direct computer sales (it sells its consumer wares only by telephone or on line) says that beginning Friday, it will offer only Intel's Pentium II processors in its Dell Dimension PC.

title: Earnings at Ericsson Are Below Predictions
description: The shares of the Swedish telecommunications giant Ericsson fell yesterday after the company released first-quarter earnings that fell short of expectations. Ericsson posted a pretax profit of 2.64 billion Swedish kronor ($341.1 million), up from 2.02 billion kronor in the similar period of 1997 but far below predictions of about 3.42 billion kronor.

title: Housing Authority Found Liable in Rape
description: Agreeing with a woman who claimed she was raped because the Housing Authority failed to supply adequate security in her Brooklyn housing project, a jury in Federal District Court in Brooklyn awarded her $3 million in damages yesterday.

title: Tax Break Can Help Public Schools; Paying for Others
description: To the Editor:

title: Vickers Says It Accepts BMW Offer for Rolls
description: Vickers P.L.C. formally accepted a $566 million takeover offer for Rolls-Royce Motor Cars from BMW today, but the rival suitor, Volkswagen A.G., immediately promised a sweeter price for Britain's premier luxury-car maker.

title: Browning Ross, 74, Founder of Road Runners
description: Browning Ross, a two-time Olympian who started America's first magazine for runners and then founded the organization that promoted the development of distance running in the United States, died on Monday, a day after his 74th birthday.

description: Starting Seeds

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DENSA, SOL
description: DENSA-Sol. The Riverdale Jewish Center extends profound condolences to our member Vally Densa on the loss of her beloved husband. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Jonathan I. Rosenblatt, Rabbi Tobias B. Schapiro, President

title: Sports of The Times; Rileyball's Challenge To Basketball
description: MICHAEL JORDAN returned to Continental Arena last night and quickly remembered that it is a long river walk from Broadway. ''It's not the glamour of Madison Square Garden,'' he said before the Bulls swept the Nets out of the playoffs, 116-101. ''But this is a dynamic young team, certainly a team of the future.''

title: Legal Immigrants Attain Parity in Pay and Taxes
description: Legal immigrants in New York make more money and pay more taxes the longer they live here, and after 15 years of residence, they earn and pay more than natives. And their children grow up to earn just as much as other Americans, according to a new study of the incomes and taxes of immigrants in the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STILLMAN, DR. RAYMOND E.
description: STILLMAN-Dr. Raymond E. Devoted husband to Elsie. Loving and guiding father to Dr. Michael and Esther and Dr. Robert and Linda. Cherished grandfather to Lisa, John, David, Jessica and Joel. Beloved brother of Fred, Sylvia, Harry, Sylvia and Eva. The senior leader of the entire Stillman family. Your smile, charm, style and love will be with us all forever. Rest in peace sweet man. Services at 1 P.M. on Sunday, May 3 at Westchester Reform Synagogue, Scarsdale, New York.

title: Correction
description: An article on Tuesday about the Federal highway bill misstated the year that the gas tax was started. It began in 1932, not 1956.

title: Dr. Rena Taub, 71, Therapist and Educator
description: Dr. Rena Taub, a psychotherapist and specialist in art therapy in Manhattan and Valley Stream, Long Island, died on April 19 at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 71 and lived in Valley Stream.

title: Boy, 3, Falls to Death From 9th-Floor Window
description: A 3-year-old Brooklyn boy was killed last night when he fell out of a window in his grandmother's ninth-floor apartment, the police said.

title: Mariners' Turnaround Gets a New York Jolt
description: The Seattle Mariners came into New York City last night in search of the .500 mark, but missed the goal, losing to the Yankees, 8-5.

title: Economic Scene; Local Payoff On a Stadium Is Uncertain
description: According to a two-year-old study by KPMG Peat Marwick, a new baseball stadium for the Yankees on the West Side of Manhattan would create about $100 million in annual income for New Yorkers. Check that: according to the Giuliani administration, the 45,000-seat stadium would generate a cool billion.

title: Unexpected Profit Reported In Viacom's First Quarter
description: Viacom Inc. reported an unexpected profit yesterday for the first quarter, as it benefited from the phenomenal success of the movie ''Titanic,'' its cable-television channels and a recovery at its Blockbuster video chain.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MENDELSON, NADINE
description: MENDELSON-Nadine. On April 28, 1998. Beloved wife of the late Myer D. Mendelson, M.D. Mother of Joel and Valerie. Grandmother of Isaac, Dylan and Jean. Service Thursday, 9:45AM at ''The Riverside'', 76 St and Amsterdam Ave.

description: ACKERSON-H. Ward of Brightwaters, NY on April 28, 1998. Beloved husband of Eleanor King Ackerson. Cherished father of Richard K. and Bartlett L. Ackerson. Brother of Warren C. Ackerson. Devoted grandfather of 7 and great grandfather of 9. Visiting Thursday, 2-5 and 7-9 PM at the Overton Funeral Home, Inc., 172 Main St., Islip, NY. Funeral Friday, 10 A.M. at the funeral home. Interment Oakwood Cemetery, Bay Shore, NY. In lieu of flowers the family requests donations to S. Peters-bythe-Sea Episcopal Church, Montauk Highway, Bay Shore, NY or Southside Hospital, Bay Shore, NY

title: In America; Ganging Up on the Schools
description: Some of the parent leaders who gathered in a small group outside City Hall looked bewildered. Others were angry. They had come to express their dismay over Gov. George Pataki's veto of desperately needed funds for school construction and repairs, and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's unconscionable support of the veto.

title: Lucent Value Tops Ex-Parent AT&T's
description: Lucent Technologies Inc. shot past its former parent, the AT&T Corporation, in market value today, two years after the telephone-equipment maker went public.

description: States Intent on Blocking Microsoft's Windows 98

title: Candidate Drops Denial That Father Was in Mafia
description: Moving to quiet an issue that could complicate her campaign to become state attorney general, Catherine M. Abate has dropped her denials of reports that her father was an organized crime figure, and now acknowledges that the allegations might be true.

description: To the Editor:

title: David G. Leach, 85, Geneticist Who Bred Ornamental Plants
description: David Goheen Leach, a plant geneticist, authority on horticulture and internationally renowned breeder of ornamental plants like hybridized rhododendrons, magnolias and azaleas, died on April 22 at his home in Madison, Ohio. He was 85.

title: Mariners Get Whiff Of Cone At His Best
description: Once upon a time David Cone was an innovator, concocting pitches and arm angles from inning to inning and batter to batter in the National League. Joe Girardi played against Cone then, and last night, when Cone threw a sweeping slider and starting improvising with his delivery, Girardi remembered the Cone of old.

title: When E-Mail Words Pall, A Program Can Add Pizazz
description: Want to spark up your electronic mail? If writing lively prose just isn't enough, the folks at Novita Communications say they have the answer: Novita Liveletter 1.1, software that can make E-mail, the most popular use of the Internet, multimedia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDIN, HARRY, M.D.
description: GOLDIN-Harry, M.D. The President and Board of Trustees of Montefiore Medical Center mourn the passing of Dr. Harry Goldin, a venerable clinician of extraordinary devotion to his profession. A 1924 graduate of Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons who went on to specialize in gastroenterology, Dr. Goldin came to Montefiore nearly 50 years ago and remained actively engaged in the life of the medical center well into his 100th year. We shall miss his wisdom, his gentlemanly manner, and his active encouragement of younger colleagues. Our heartfelt condolences are extended to his children and entire family. Spencer Foreman, M.D., Pres. Jay B. Langner, Chairman Board of Trustees Montefiore Medical Center

title: Infant Mortality Rate Shows Steady Decline
description: The state's infant mortality rate declined in the most recent statistics available, continuing a nearly decadelong trend, a report released yesterday by a Newark-based children's advocacy group said.

title: Now New Jersey Must Seize the Moment
description: THE Nets are officially history. Chicago made quick work of the challengers, sweeping them out of the playoffs, three games to none.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HORTON, MARCIA
description: HORTON-Marcia. April 27, 1998, of West Haven, Connecticut. Wife of the late Dr. Leon L. Horton; mother of Dr. Harold L. Horton of Woodbridge, CT. and Mrs. Richard (Rosalyn) Feldman of Harrison, N.Y. Also survived by five granddaughters and six great-grandchildren. Memorial contributions may be made to the Jewish Home for the Elderly, 175 Jefferson Street, Fairfield, CT. or Alzheimers Association for Research, 919 North Michigan Avenue, Suite 1000, Chicago, IL. Period of mourning will be observed in Harrison, N.Y. Saturday evening & Sunday.

title: Windows 98, The Tuneup
description: COMPUTER stores stayed open past midnight to accommodate long lines of customers when Microsoft's Windows 95 was released on Aug. 24, 1995. There was such prerelease hype for Windows 95, an operating system upgrade, that some people bought the software even though they did not yet own a computer on which to run it.

title: Want a Challenge? Try Humming Along to This
description: Jenifer Herrema and Neil Hagerty of Royal Trux cultivate a roughed-up, zonked-out audiovisual package, not rare among underground rock bands. But their brand of greasiness feels particularly objective, as if they're outsiders looking into the world of grease. When the group began 10 years ago, it was an experimental, cacophonous duo, using cheap electronics and washes of echo; now without making any clumsily obvious brand-name references to 70's culture, Royal Trux is an actual rock band making a canny art project about AM radio hard-rock of the Ford Administration. Imagine if Lynyrd Skynyrd made its music not for mass consumption but for the judging committee of the Whitney Biennial, and you're in Royal Trux's ball park.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ABRAMSON, DR. BELLE
description: ABRAMSON-Dr. Belle. The Board of Directors and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Dr. Belle Abramson. A dedicated supporter of UJA-Federation, Belle served with distinction on the board of directors of Surprise Lake Camp, one of our member agencies, and on the board of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, a predecessor organization. We extend our deepest sympathies to her entire family. Judith Stern Peck, Board Chair Louise B. Greilsheimer, President Stephen D. Solender, Exec. V.P.

title: ESSAY; Finding Liberation in Cyberspace
description: For me, the Internet is paradise. It is as if I am sitting at a table full of appetizing foods after suffering from chronic starvation. Or as if I am a beggar who finds herself in a department store that, incomprehensibly, gives out everything for free. When I surf the Web, it is as if I am going around with my shopping cart, piling it up with all the bounty that I was deprived of for so long.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOVI, PAUL
description: KOVI-Paul. Everyone at The Four Seasons restaurant is deeply saddened by the death of our friend and mentor, Paul Kovi. A generous man and patient teacher, Mr. Kovi was like a father to us, gently guiding and encouraging us for more than thirty years. He was and will always remain in our hearts as a bon vivant, whose love of life transcended everything he did. From the kitchen to the dining rooms, Mr. Kovi strolled through the restaurant inspiring everyone he met to experience and cherish the very best that life has to offer. In doing so he shared with the world an uncommon dignity and playful sense of humor that will be greatly missed. We feel honored to have known him and lucky to have been a part of his life. We will all miss him dearly. To celebrate his life and share his legacy, we invite you to attend a memorial service in his honor on May 12, at 4 PM, at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, located on Lexington Avenue at 66th Street.

title: Rolling Stone Magazine Receives a Top Award
description: Jann Wenner had reason to smile yesterday at the National Magazine Awards, the Oscars of the magazine business. His company, Wenner Media, won three awards, including one for Rolling Stone in the category of general excellence for magazines with a circulation of more than a million.

title: Modjadji Journal; Even Into Rain Queen's Life, Some Rain Must Fall
description: This being the end of the rainy season in a year when scientists predicted that El Nino would roast southern Africa with a parching drought, it seems a fair time to consult Modjadji, the Rain Queen.

description: KNOLLER-Herman. Loving husband of Helen, devoted father of Robert, Cathy and Elizabeth, cherished grandfather of Alexander, Caroline, Devon, Calla and James. Beloved brother-in-law of Shirley Shaw and Edith and Manny Goodman. Funeral services 12:30PM Friday, May 1, at I.J. Morris, Inc., 46 Greenwich Street, Hempstead.

description: PLAY PIANO

title: Arizona Signs Giants' Brown
description: Dave Brown, who once competed with Kent Graham as the Giants' starting quarterback, moved into Graham's place as Arizona's backup quarterback by signing a two-year contract yesterday with the Cardinals. Graham has returned to the Giants as a free agent.

title: BellSouth to Acquire Stake In New German Phone Carrier
description: Making its most significant foray into Europe, the BellSouth Corporation plans to acquire a stake in Otelo, a new German long-distance telephone carrier backed by two of that nation's largest utility companies.

title: Pro-Choice Group Picks DeVito/Verdi
description: The Pro-Choice Public Education Project in Mamaroneck, N.Y., a coalition of national organizations that support the right to abortion, yesterday named DeVito/Verdi in New York as its first agency. DeVito/Verdi will create a campaign intended to help recruit young women as participants in efforts to maintain access to abortion services. DeVito/Verdi was awarded the assignment, with initial billings estimated at $1.6 million to $2 million.

title: Electrolux Income Nearly Doubles
description: The Swedish household appliance manufacturer Electrolux reported yesterday that its net income increased 87.9 percent in the first quarter, to 667 million kronor ($86.2 million) from 355 million in the 1997 period. Revenues increased 8.4 percent, to 28.5 billion kronor from the 26.3 billion last year. Operating profits rose 37.1 percent, to 1.37 billion kronor from 1 billion last year.

title: Executive Changes
description: BANKERS TRUST NEW YORK CORP., New York, said Eugene A. Ludwig, a former United States Comptroller of the Currency, would join the bank as vice chairman.

title: CROWN AMERICAN TO BUY TWO MALLS FOR $61 MILLION
description: Crown American Realty Trust said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire two regional shopping malls from the Beckley-Jacksonville Ltd. Partnership for $61 million. Crown American owns and operates regional shopping malls in Pennsylvania, Maryland, West Virginia, Virginia, New Jersey, Tennessee and Georgia. Under the deal, it will buy the Jacksonville Mall in Jacksonville, N.C., for $38 million and the Crossroads Mall in Beckley, W. Va., for $23 million. The company expects a 9.8 percent initial return from Jacksonville and a 12 percent initial return from Crossroads.

title: Making Books; The Many Ways Of Saying 'No'
description: ''Late'' is a spongy span of time in book publishing, and nowhere less firm than on the due date of a manuscript. What late means is that as long as a publisher really wants a book, it's delivery by the author is almost never too long overdue. The moment a publisher doesn't want it, even a day or a week can be too late and cause for a book's cancellation.

title: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS -- Global Tug, National Tether; As Companies Look Overseas, Governments Hold the Strings
description: For nearly three years, Caterpillar Inc. has been banging its head against the Clinton Administration door, trying to get Government-sponsored loans for the sale of its big earthmovers to China. Beijing is buying them by the dozens to build the giant Three Gorges Dam, which the Administration considers damaging to the environment.

title: Ina and Dungjen a Split Pair
description: Kyoko Ina and Jason Dungjen of the Skate Club of New York, the two-time national champions and fourth-place finishers at the 1998 Winter Olympics, have ended their partnership as pairs skaters, the United States Figure Skating Association said yesterday.

title: Chief Is Named By Chancellor
description: The Chancellor Media Corporation, one of the nation's largest radio broadcasting companies, said today that it had named Jeffrey A. Marcus president and chief executive.

title: Corrections
description: A glossary in the special Teens section yesterday with an article about the code used by youngsters to communicate using beepers misspelled the surname of the actress whose secret agent number was 099 in the television series ''Get Smart.'' She was Barbara Feldon, not Feldman.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARBER, HARRY DOUGLAS
description: GARBER-Harry Douglas. Of Garden City, NY and Winter Park, FL died at home Tuesday, April 28 after a prolonged battle with cancer. Beloved husband of Diane, father of Deborah MacKelcan, Juliet, John and Buckley, grandfather of Douglas, Matthew, Emily Joy, Alexander and Harry, brother of Johanna Hoot, Donna Marie Schroeppel, & the late Rae Kuhn. Mr. Garber was Vice Chairman of the Equitable Life Assurance Society until his retirement in 1993. He joined the Equitable upon his graduation from Yale University in 1950. Mr. Garber was a noted Actuary, serving as President of the Academy of Actuaries for several years. A Memorial service is scheduled for Saturday, May 2, at 3 P.M. at the Garden City Community Church, Stewart Avenue at Whitehall Blvd, Garden City, NY.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Public Lives column on Tuesday about David Benedict, a cantor who performed the wedding of Fran Drescher in the television show ''The Nanny,'' misidentified the actors he married earlier in a movie wedding, in ''Goodbye, Columbus.'' They were Gail Ommerle and Michael Meyers, not Ali McGraw and Richard Benjamin.

title: Profit at Lufthansa Shows Sharp Increase
description: Lufthansa A.G. said yesterday that its first-quarter net surged to 406 million marks ($226 million) from 1 million marks as it benefited from alliances, lower fuel costs and the sale of its stake in the travel and shipping company Hapag-Lloyd A.G.

title: Turf; Lover's Leap Mentality Hits Co-ops
description: IN Manhattan, fear and greed are fueling the white-hot real estate market. Deals are falling apart at record levels. Bidding wars occur every day. And even brokers and lawyers are starting to urge caution.

title: As Starks Battles Stresses, Knicks Face Elimination
description: Before he made a hasty exit from the locker room, John Starks took just a minute after Game 3 to tell his teammates about another cruel twist in his season.

title: New Rumblings in Cyprus Raise Specter of War
description: A television station in the self-proclaimed Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus scooped the world recently by broadcasting the film ''Titanic'' to an amazed and delighted audience.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCINTOSH, LORETTA E.
description: McINTOSH-Loretta E. Of Lynbrook on April 29. Known to all as ''Betty.'' Beloved wife of the late John A. Loving mother of Denise McNamara, James, Colleen, Kelley McGinn, and the late Johnny. Cherished grandmother of many. Dear sister of Joseph B. McGrath. Family will receive friends on Thursday 2-4 and 7-9PM, at the Flinch & Bruns Funeral Home, Inc, 34 Hempstead Avenue, (corner Peninsula Blvd), Lynbrook. Mass of Christian Burial Friday 10:30am at St. Anthony's RC Church, Oceanside. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. In lieu of flowers, contributions in Betty's memory to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Avenue, New York, New York 10021 would be appreciated.

title: For That Dancing Baby, A New Recording Career
description: If you haven't had enough of the Dancing Baby, hold on. That digitally created darling of the Internet and more recently, prime-time television released its first record this week. A full-blown retro-bubble-gum-pop compact disk is scheduled to follow next month. And, of course, a music video is in the works.

title: Pharmacia's Results Ease 3%; Rhone-Poulenc's Rise 30%
description: Pharmacia & Upjohn Inc. said yesterday that net income dropped 3 percent in the first quarter as spending on marketing and research increased and the dollar's strength cut into sales.

title: Currents; BUILT IN 1783 -- The Mission: Saving a Mission
description: ''There's absolutely nothing like it anywhere in this country,'' said Paul Schwartzbaum, the chief conservator of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museums, who was talking about the vividly painted interiors of the San Xavier del Bac Mission, built near Tucson, Ariz., in 1783 by Franciscan missionaries.

title: The Year 2000 Problem: Offering Second Thoughts
description: In response to ''Wanted: A Fix With Finesse for Year 2000 Problem'' and ''Checking a Home Computer'' (April 23), several astute readers have pointed out that it is important to back up files before setting your clock to Jan. 1, 2000, to see how your software will behave in the new millennium. That is good advice and people should mind it even if they are not doing the test.

title: Currents; 'FOUND' WOODS -- In From the Rain
description: Debris could hardly be more chic. Gabrielle Valenzuela's Heartwood collection of bowls, trays, vases and candlesticks is made from ''naturally discarded'' tropical wood: driftwood and fallen trees Ms. Valenzuela found on her property in a Costa Rican rain forest. She donates 5 percent of Heartwood's sales to the Rainforest Foundation. The large bowl, above, is $250 at Portico Home, 72 Spring Street (Greene Street). WILLIAM L. HAMILTON

title: South Korea in Accord With Monetary Fund
description: South Korea and the International Monetary Fund have agreed on new targets for the country's economy, including a forecast of the first recession since 1980, an I.M.F. official said yesterday.

title: Personal Shopper; Discovering Treasure in the Walls
description: SOME of the newest wallpaper patterns turn out to be some of the oldest.

title: Mayor Seeks High Fees to Curb Cruises by Gambling Industry
description: After economic development officials spent months encouraging ship lines to offer gambling cruises off New York piers, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that the city would try to curtail the cruises by charging extremely high fees for them to operate from city piers.

title: Kosovo: Yet Another Act In the Balkan Tragedy
description: At noon a convoy of a dozen cars, carrying men with faces painted black and red, wound its way through the streets of this city. The automatic assault rifles cradled in their arms poked through the windows as stunned onlookers gawked.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Travel section on Sunday about United States observances of Israel's 50th anniversary misstated the makeup of the ensemble that is to perform tonight at Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83d Street, in Manhattan. The six musicians are under contract with the Klezmer Conservatory Band of Boston, not permanent members.

title: Piano Teachers You Can Hush With a Click
description: THEY laughed when I sat down at the piano, but when I started to play!'' read a famous advertisement for mail-order music lessons in the 1920's. A classic piece of Madison Avenue copy, the ad played on the terror most adults feel when they approach a musical instrument for the first time and on the promise that yes, you can learn to play the piano without ever having to take lessons from the Sunday-school teacher who lives down the street.
