description: To most Americans, the euro (the common currency to replace the franc, mark, lira, etc.) is a MEGO (My Eyes Glaze Over).

title: He's a Cool Motivator: Riley Is All Business
description: The motivational tactics of the motivational master started seconds after the Miami Heat finished stretching yesterday at Madison Square Garden. Pat Riley, his hair slick, his voice sharp and his intentions obvious, stood at half court and offered a stern message to his jogging players.

title: Teams Play Waiting Game on Tourney Selections
description: It's tournament time. The lacrosse committees of the National Collegiate Athletic Association will make their choices known on Sunday, and the tournaments begin next week.

In lieu of flowers donations may be made to Great Neck Public Library, 159 Bayview Avenue, Great Neck, NY 11023, C/O Arlene Nevens.

title: Conservative Scholars Plan Rival Group on Race Issues
description: A group of prominent conservatives today divorced themselves from President Clinton's race relations initiative, ending what had been at best a shaky ideological truce with the Administration because they believed their views on racial issues were being ignored.

description: Michelle de Bruin of Ireland, the controversial winner of three gold medals during the Atlanta Olympics, is being investigated for possible manipulation of a urine sample during a drug test, swimming's world governing body said yesterday.

title: Bridge; When Four Are Available But the Goal Is Only Three
description: One of the best ways for a novice to improve is to play a session with an expert, but that is normally an expensive proposition. A special opportunity arises when a club organizes a pro-am game in which the experts donate their time and try to make sure that their partners enjoy themselves and learn something.

title: Metro Business; April Business Pace Slows
description: Business activity in the New York region grew at a slower pace this month as manufacturing stalled, a survey of service and factory executives that was released yesterday showed.

title: A Cramped Approach to Bilingualism
description: Frustration over the failure of bilingual education for many children has created widespread public support for a narrow-minded ballot measure in California that would dismantle all bilingual programs, regardless of effectiveness. Like most states, California currently allows different types of programs to help limited-English speakers. Some schools adopt the English as a Second Language approach, using English in most classes for newcomers. Others offer classes in basic subjects for students in their native language while they learn English separately.

title: Elan Plans to Acquire Neurex In a $700 Million Stock Swap
description: The Elan Corporation, a pharmaceuticals company based in Dublin, said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the Neurex Corporation, a biotechnology company based in Menlo Park, Calif., in a stock swap valued at about $700 million.

description: To the Editor:

title: Janet Reno's Latest Trick
description: Last September Attorney General Janet Reno tapped a seasoned, respected prosecutor, Charles LaBella, to invigorate the Justice Department's directionless campaign finance inquiry. She used Mr. LaBella's reputation to fend off demands, by F.B.I. Director Louis Freeh and many others, for appointment of an independent counsel. The department hinted that Mr. LaBella would look into the possible illegal use of ''soft money'' by President Clinton's re-election campaign, opening a door Ms. Reno had prematurely shut as part of her effort to prevent a searching independent inquiry into the Democrats' campaign financing.

title: Russia's Disarray Brings a Nuclear Risk to the U.S., Study Says
description: Russia's deteriorating control of its nuclear weapons is increasing the danger of an accidental or unauthorized attack on the United States, a Nobel Peace Prize-winning group warned today.

title: Spanish Bank Buys 55% Of Brazilian Institution
description: Banco Bilbao Vizcaya S.A. said yesterday that it had reached agreement to acquire for $450 million a 55 percent stake in Banco Excel Economico, which is based in Sao Paulo.

title: PRODUCTIVITY; Voice Mail vs. Answering Machine
description: NEARLY 70 percent of American households own telephone answering machines, according to a trade group study, but that does not mean they are easy to buy. A large electronics store may stock 30 or more models with a vast array of features. And given the availability of residential voice mail, it is possible that an answering machine may not be the best answer for staying in touch with friends and family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GILL, DAVID GRANDON
description: GILL-David Grandon. Of Darien, CT on April 27, 1998. Husband of Josephina J.W.M. Gill. Father of Stephanie J. Gill, Valerie M. Gill, & Eric D. Gill. Brother of Richard T. Gill and Myrtle Nelson. Memorial service will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church Darien, CT., on Saturday, May 2, 1998 at 3:00PM. Interment private. description: Helen Ward, who sang with the Benny Goodman band in the 1930's, died on April 21 at the Vencor Hospital in Arlington, Va. She was 82 and lived in Falls Church, Va.

title: NATIONWIDE FINANCIAL BUYING MORLEY FOR $32 MILLION
description: Nationwide Financial Services Inc. agreed to buy Morley Financial Services Inc., an investment manager, for $32.1 million in a move to add more lower-risk products to its line of investments. Acquiring Morley, which has more than $8.4 billion in financial assets, will allow Nationwide to offer funds that include ''guaranteed interest contracts,'' investment services that guarantee stable returns with lower risk. The new services are favored by public sector pension funds, which make up a large part of Nationwide's customer base. Nationwide, in Columbus, Ohio, is a publicly traded company that is 81.6 percent owned by the Nationwide Mutual Insurance Company.

description: If you believe that self-service gasoline stations still require a little too much of, well, yourself, consider what the Shell Oil Company is field testing in Sacramento, Calif.

title: U.S. and Allies Put Pressure On Yugoslavia to Negotiate
description: Seeking to bring an end to the violence in Kosovo, the United States and five of its allies imposed new economic sanctions on Yugoslavia today. They threatened further action if the Yugoslavs do not agree to hold negotiations with the province's ethnic Albanian separatists.

title: Garden Notebook; Where Teachers Say 'Ribbit!'
description: THE moment Velarian Francis, a fourth grader, reached the top of the rocky hill, swiveled the high-powered telescope onto the marsh below and shouted, ''I see little bugs!'' the New York Botanical Garden's new Everett Children's Adventure Garden leaped to the forefront of children's education.

description: William A. Fletcher of the University of California law school at Berkeley, faced mild questioning from the only two members of the 18-member Senate Judiciary Committee who showed up for today's hearing on his nomination to an appeals court.

description: Brazil promised today to set aside 62 million acres of Amazon rain forest for conservation, underscoring the Government's renewed commitment to the faltering preservation of the imperiled tropical wilderness.

title: Yeltsin Appoints Tycoon, a Foe, to Run Commonwealth of States
description: Boris Berezovsky, the tycoon who last week was sidelined in the battle over President Boris N. Yeltsin's nominee for Prime Minister, was given a new job today as chief executive of the Commonwealth of Independent States.

description: CHOQUET-Claude. The Lycee Francais de New York mourns the passing of Mr. Claude Choquet on April 6, 1998 in New York City after a long illness. description: The arched glass-and-steel exterior of the Regional Performing Arts Center in Philadelphia will glitter above its neighbors when it is completed in 2001. Inside, the Philadelphia Orchestra will have a 2,500-seat concert hall shaped like a cello. A 650-seat recital hall will have a stage on a turntable, for quick switches between performances.

description: Time Warner Inc. and the developer Stephen M. Ross have teamed up to bid on the New York Coliseum site in a plan to build the media giant's world headquarters and the city's first digital television production center, according to real estate executives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHWARZ, RUTH FISCHER
description: SCHWARZ-Ruth Fischer, 82, died April 28. Born Jan. 8, 1916, Vienna, Austria, daughter of Leopold and Elise Meyer Fischer. During WW II served with the British Army in No. Africa. Married Leo Schwarz in 1956. He died in 1995. Received her medical training in Vienna and Palestine. New York resident for many years; pathologist in several hospitals retiring in 1983. Moved to Hamilton 1985. Surviving: brother, Hanns Fischer, Vienna, Austria; niece, Eve Ann Shwartz; nephew, Elan Shwartz; great niece, Sasha C. Hoff; great nephews, Jesse L. Hoff, Ariel and Yissakhar Shwartz; many relatives in Austria, USA and Israel. She leaves behind a host of friends, neighbors, coworkers and animals who loved her dearly, and admired her loving and courageous spirit. Services private. Contributions to American Committee for the Weizmann Institute of Science, 51 Madison Ave., New York, New York 10010.

description: WHEN they rewarded themselves two weeks ago with an impromptu vacation, the members of the New York State Legislature were feeling pretty good about themselves.

description: Two weeks after the police arrested a group of teen-agers on charges they plastered band stickers on traffic signs along the West Side Highway, the city's Sanitation Department says it has netted a much bigger fish in its own crackdown on illegal advertisements: Virgin Records.

description: Indonesia is not moving fast enough to close or seize control of the weak banks in a ''dramatically undercapitalized'' banking system, the rating service Standard & Poor's said today.

title: Round Two on the Line Item Veto
description: A strong sense of deja vu pervaded this week's Supreme Court hearing on the constitutionality of the Line Item Veto Act. The justices held a similar hearing last May, but then dodged ruling on the merits, saying that the lawmaker plaintiffs, including Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, lacked legal standing to sue because they had not been personally injured.

title: Devils May Face a Blue Period
description: After a late Devils comeback fell short Tuesday night in a 4-3 defeat at Ottawa, the slumping center Bobby Holik observed, ''A couple more minutes, and we would have tied the game.'' But if the Devils lose again tonight to the Senators in the Meadowlands, they will have run out of minutes. Their season will be over.

description: MY biggest problem when I shop for a computer is that I always end up with something far more expensive than I set out to buy. Once I'm in the store, I invariably gravitate toward the fancy, expensive turbocharged boxes with subwoofers as big as pickle barrels.

title: ASPEN TECHNOLOGY TO BUY CHESAPEAKE DECISION
description: Aspen Technology Inc. agreed yesterday to acquire Chesapeake Decision Sciences Inc. for more than $135 million. Shares of Aspen rose 8 percent, gaining $3.8125, to $49.625. Under the deal, Aspen will pay 2.95 million shares for Chesapeake, a closely held company that is based in New Providence, N.J. Aspen, based in Cambridge, Mass., makes software that is used to analyze and automate manufacturing plants in the paper, chemical, electric power, metals and pharmaceutical industries. Chesapeake software is used to help control raw-material costs, maximize product values and control inventories in a range of industries. Chesapeake had revenue of $17 million last year.

description: France's fifth-ranking official was placed one step short of indictment today in an inquiry about multimillion-dollar payments made to a lobbyist promoting the sale of warships to Taiwan in 1991.

description: Malgorzata Dydek (pronounced malgo-ZHAH-teh DID-ik) of Poland may be unlike few other women anywhere, and not only because she weighs 223 pounds and is still skinny. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VEGHTE, MARY ALICE
description: VEGHTE-Mary Alice. Of New York City and Canajoharie, New York, died on April 28, 1998 at the age of 75 following a short illness. A graduate of Smith College, she was administrative officer of the tax department at Brown Brothers Harriman for forty-three years. She was an enthusiastic volunteer for many charitable organizations in the city. She was predeceased by her brother, Lewis Veghte Jr., and is survived by her niece, Elizabeth C. Veghte of Cardiff-bythe-Sea, California, and her nephew, William L. Veghte of Seattle, WA. A memorial service will be held in Canajoharie at a later date. description: Critics and voice buffs who disdain opera in English translation could cite the Juilliard Opera Center's production of Mozart's ''Magic Flute'' on Friday night as symptomatic of the problems involved. The witty translation was by Paul Griffiths, prepared some time before he began contributing music reviews to the New York Times. But for the most part the young singers did a poor job of projecting the words clearly. And with everyone now so accustomed to supertitles, straining to understand English is all the more exasperating.

title: Brawley Case Lawyer Is Jailed After Clashing With the Judge
description: The lawyer representing C. Vernon Mason in the Tawana Brawley defamation case was escorted to the Dutchess County Jail in handcuffs this afternoon after being cited for contempt of court for the second time in two days.

title: Public Eye; Good, Bad or Ugly?
description: THE Dutch have a saying: ''Act in a normal manner, and you will be acting strangely enough.'' In the last three years, young Dutch designers have used this doctrine to offer an ironic twist on the fine lines and smooth surfaces at the Milan Furniture Fair.

title: Modern Teen-Agers Aren't So Different
description: A nationwide poll of 13- to 17-year-olds conducted by The New York Times and CBS News shows that today's teen-agers are worldly and shaped by exposure to a culture that has dropped many of its inhibitions.

title: Wilde, Out And Down In London And Naples
description: Many traits distinguish the Oscar Wilde of ''The Judas Kiss,'' David Hare's dense marble monument of a play, from the more ordinary run of mankind that surrounds him: his epigrammatic articulateness, of course; his sartorial flair; his unbending insistence on his tailor-made philosophy. But as portrayed by the Irish actor and movie star Liam Neeson in the production that opened last night at the Broadhurst Theater, what truly sets the author of ''The Importance of Being Earnest'' apart is his height.

title: In a Contest of Tech Trivia, the West Beats the East
description: Much as it hurts anyone who loves the bow-tied, Burberried, cobblestoned Northeast and remembers the former glories of the high-tech corridor on Route 128 around Boston, there are times when one simply has to admit that primacy in the computer industry has long since passed, with the sun, to the West.

description: To the Editor:

title: So Glittery, So Chinese
description: Suddenly, glitzy productions of Chinese opera are everywhere in New York, with the City Center having recently played host to a Beijing opera troupe and Lincoln Center preparing a monster production of the Kunqu masterpiece ''The Peony Pavilion'' for the summer.

title: G.O.P. Agrees on Spending Bill That Faces Veto Threat
description: Republicans in the House and Senate agreed tonight to a bill providing nearly $6 billion in emergency relief to disaster victims as well as money to maintain American troops in Bosnia and the Middle East. Both houses are expected to approve the bill on Thursday.

title: NO IMMUNITY DEAL GIVEN TO LEWINSKY, JUDGE SAID TO FIND
description: A Federal district judge has ruled that Monica S. Lewinsky did not have an agreement with the independent counsel that would give her immunity from prosecution, lawyers involved in the inquiry said today.

title: HOME DEPOT TO BUY MOLSON'S 25% STAKE IN CHAIN
description: Home Depot Inc. agreed yesterday to buy the Molson Companies' 25 percent stake in their retail joint venture for $262 million, giving it complete ownership of the home-improvement chain in Canada. Home Depot, which is based in Atlanta, and Molson, which owns half of Canada's largest brewery, formed the venture in February 1994 when Home Depot acquired Aikenhead's Home Improvement Warehouse. They have since expanded the Home Depot Canada chain to 37 stores, from 7. Molson has said that it wants to get out of retailing and return to its roots as a beer maker.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FELDMAN, ANN (KEAN)
description: FELDMAN-Ann (Kean), age 95. Of Manhattan, on Tuesday, April 28, 1998. Wife of the late Albert Feldman, CEO of the Hollander Fur Corporation of NY and NJ, and Ambassador to Afghanistan. Mother of the late Wendy Nadel (1992). Surviving are several nieces and nephews. Graveside Services will be held Wednesday, April 29, 2:30 pm at B'Nai Abraham Memorial Park Cemetery, Union, NJ. Information: Higgins Home for Funerals, 752 Mountain Boulevard, Watchung, New Jersey.

title: For Shelter Island's Residents, Shock in Aftermath of Crime
description: As the 12-car ferry headed across Greenport Harbor toward Shelter Island this morning, Carol Grayson said that for the first time in 30 years, she was anxious about returning to her summer home.

title: A Nation Like No Other
description: Fifty years ago, the independence of Israel was declared, with David Ben-Gurion, the first Prime Minister, echoing an old Zionist slogan: ''It is the right of the Jewish people, like other nations, to determine its history under its own sovereignty.''

title: Currents; ROLL ON -- Pull Up A Chair
description: Paul Tuttle's rolling Skate furniture can go anywhere. He designed it to fit into any kind of interior, rustic to modern, and to stand any kind of weather, wet or dry. And because the casters are real roller-skate wheels, the pieces are easy to move around.

title: As Accidents Rise, Giuliani Seeks Stricter Rules for Cabbies
description: Responding to a sharp rise in taxi accidents during the 1990's, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has proposed major changes in the taxi industry that would make it easier for the city to suspend cabbies' licenses, require a driving course for new cabbies and quadruple liability insurance requirements for cabs.

title: Corrections
description: A brief report on Monday about the sixth International Cello Festival in Manchester, England, which began yesterday, referred incorrectly to Pinchas Zukerman, a participant. He is a violinist, not a cellist.

title: MSNBC Leads for the Month As the Top Web News Site
description: MSNBC, the on-air and on-line mixed marriage of Microsoft and NBC, was once again named this week the No. 1 general news site on the World Wide Web. The monthly ratings, measured by Media Metric, a PC Meter company, are based on March figures that tracked, using a sample group, the overall size of the audience and the number of times each person visited the news site (www.msnbc.com).

title: A Life With a Before and an After; For Christopher Reeve, It Isn't as Simple as Superman or Victim
description: Sometimes at night, Christopher Reeve said in an interview at his home in Bedford, N.Y., he dreams he is sailing aboard his yacht, ''Sea Angel.'' A gentle breeze fills the sails as he steers the boat along the reflection of the full moon. ''At night I am always whole,'' he said. ''I've never had a dream in which I am in a wheelchair.''

title: Reopening Postponed at School Where Bricks Fell
description: A week after a 60-foot swath of bricks tumbled down from its exterior, a 67-year-old Queens elementary school that officials had hoped to reopen after a couple of days of repairs remained closed yesterday, as construction crews worked to fortify the masonry.

description: KOENIG-Rose. 5/1/06-4/30/95. The world was infinitely better with you in it. Fran

title: 13 States Plan Antitrust Move Over Microsoft
description: Attorneys General from 13 states, apparently intent on blocking the imminent release of the Microsoft Corporation's next version of its Windows software, are in the final stages of preparing a joint antitrust action against the company.

title: Mlicki Again Has Stuff, But Not the Right Kind
description: High on promise. Short on results. That has been Dave Mlicki's story so far this year.

title: Editors' Note
description: A front-page article yesterday about a report by the New York State Task Force on Life and the Law on medically assisted reproduction omitted an address for obtaining copies. They are available, free, from the task force, at 5 Penn Plaza, Room 301, New York, N.Y. 10001-1803.

title: Currents; PLATES OLD AND NEW -- One Artist's Porcelain Period
description: Izhar Patkin must have had a modern bride in mind when he conceived his everyday service made of plates reglazed with Roman-nosed cops and big-haired geishas. Malo, the Italian luxury knitwear company, commissioned the service from Mr. Patkin, a New York artist, to accompany the introduction of Malo's second home line (cashmere-covered hot-water bottle, $256).

title: Reader's Digest Earnings Plunge 61%
description: Reader's Digest Association Inc. said yesterday that earnings fell 61 percent in its fiscal third quarter, as a strong dollar hurt overseas sales. The company also posted lower book and music sales.

title: Norman Plans to Enjoy Recovery From Injury
description: As he recovers from the major shoulder surgery he had last week, Greg Norman has time to contemplate his future. Will he return to golf six months from now with even more passion? Or will he lose some of the competitive edge that has made him one of the world's greatest players, especially with family and many business interests to keep him occupied?

title: The Year 2000 Problem: Offering Second Thoughts
description: In response to ''Wanted: A Fix With Finesse for Year 2000 Problem'' and ''Checking a Home Computer'' (April 23), several astute readers have pointed out that it is important to back up files before setting your clock to Jan. 1, 2000, to see how your software will behave in the new millennium. That is good advice and people should mind it even if they are not doing the test.

A clear plastic trash bag with two pieces of garbage -- an empty hand lotion bottle and a cardboard toilet paper roll -- was paraded in front of the befuddled high school student by her mother.
